ART 144.name: Artist Books as Objects
ART 144.description: Are artist books still relevant in the contemporary creative community? Focusing on intellectual content and raw physicality, students will explore this question and image/text relationships by creating handmade one-of-a-kind or edition book projects utilizing various mechanical reproduction techniques.
ART 144.prereqString: Prerequisite: (ART 20A or ART 30A or ART 40 or ART 51 or ART 65A or ART 71A or ART 81A or ART 91) and ART 9A

ART 150.name: Advanced Studio Topics--Painting
ART 150.description: Provides an intensive and specialized working environment. Thematic issues and material strategies will be explored. Materials fee.

ART 150C.name: Advanced Drawing
ART 150C.description: Advanced studio problems in visual exploration. Students pursue individual solutions to self-defined and presubscribed projects. Techniques/materials are individual choice. Continual analysis of the personal process.

ART 150F.name: Advanced Figure Drawing
ART 150F.description: Students develop technical skills in rendering the figure. Live model sessions and an introduction to anatomy. Investigates use of the figure in contemporary art. Materials fee.

ART 150G.name: Advanced Figure Painting
ART 150G.description: Students develop technical skills in painting the figure. Live model sessions and projects that investigate the use of the figure in contemporary art.

ART 151.name: Advanced Studio Topics--Sculpture
ART 151.description: Provides an intensive and specialized working environment. Thematic issues and material strategies will be explored.  Materials fee.

ART 152A.name: Advanced Studio Topics: Photography
ART 152A.description: Focused investigation of a range of issues in photographic practice, with an emphasis on developing individual student projects, refining critical thinking, and conceptual framing. Technical topics covered as required. Readings, lectures, critiques, labs. Materials fee.

ART 152B.name: Documentary Photography
ART 152B.description: Documentary practice is examined through the realization of photo-based projects. Thematic focus of student's choosing will be refined through lectures, discussion, technical demonstrations, field trips, labs, and individual meetings.  Materials fee.

ART 152C.name: The Public Image
ART 152C.description: Strategies for artistic intervention in the public circulation of images are examined alongside the role images play in constructing public identity. Individual or collaborative student projects will be directed around course themes. Materials fee.

ART 152D.name: The Photographic Tableau
ART 152D.description: Examines and develops photographic projects intended for traditional artistic venues (i.e., galleries and museums). In addition to exploring appropriate techniques and presentation strategies, students consider the interdependency between construction of images and semantic shaping of traditional art venues. Materials fee.

ART 152F.name: Seminar Production Component
ART 152F.description: Photographic and/or inter-media production course tied to a specific Issues course (for example, Issues in Photography, Issues in Feminism, Issues in New Genres). Critiques, labs, field trips, discussion, demonstrations. Materials fee.

ART 153.name: Digital Filmmaking Advanced Project II
ART 153.description: Directed to the production of individual or collaborative videotapes, using studio, portable camera, editing facilities, and sound and computer elements. Emphasis will be on individually initiated projects. Readings and screenings are assigned. Materials fee.

ART 154.name: Advanced Studio Topics: Performance
ART 154.description: An intensive investigation of the practice of performance art, with an emphasis on the development of individual projects, and the refinement of various technical skills, as well as audiences, spaces, and cultural connections.
ART 154.prereqString: Prerequisite: ART 91 or ART 109 or ART 128

ART 156.name: Advanced Studio Topics: Ceramic Sculpture
ART 156.description: Discussion of ideas, techniques, and personal control of form. Clay body, fabrication, glazing, and firing.  Emphasis on development of personal direction. Materials fee.

ART 166A.name: Digital Filmmaking Web Series
ART 166A.description: Original video projects produced in collaborative teams combining advanced video students with students from other areas, including Dance, Drama, and Music. Shoots may be carried out on the video stage as well as field locations. Materials fee.

ART 170.name: Advanced Projects
ART 170.description: Students working in different mediums will focus on ambitious research, planning, development, and experimentation, leading to a single work or focused series that is large in scope. The project will be exhibited and documented at the end of the quarter.  Materials fee.
ART 170.prereqString: Prerequisite: ART 150 or ART 150C or ART 151 or ART 152A or ART 152B or ART 152C or ART 152D or ART 152E or ART 152F or ART 153 or ART 166A or ART 190 or ART 190B or ART 190C

ART 189.name: Critical Aesthetics
ART 189.description: Surveys critical thought that has influenced twentieth-century art production, preparing the student to engage contemporary art with a critical eye, specifically addressing aesthetic and political debates of the historical avant-garde, the neo-avant garde, and postmodern culture.
ART 189.prereqString: Prerequisite: ART 1A and ART 1B and ART 1C
ART 189.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. Art Majors only.

ART 190.name: Senior Project and Critique
ART 190.description: Directed-study critique class in preparation for final project and life after graduation
ART 190.restriction: Restriction: Seniors only. Art Majors only.

ART 190B.name: Senior Projects and Critique in Photography
ART 190B.description: Directed group study focused on production of photographic projects of significant scope and ambition. Emphasis on preparation for continued study and/or practice in photography in advanced settings beyond the undergraduate university experience. Materials fee.
ART 190B.prereqString: Prerequisite: ART 1A and ART 1B and ART 1C and ART 71A and ART 71B
ART 190B.restriction: Restriction: Seniors only. Art Majors only.

ART 197.name: Art Internship
ART 197.description: Under faculty supervision, students participate directly in a variety of art institution settings, including museums, galleries, and nonprofit organizations.

ART 198.name: Honors Exhibition
ART 198.description: Preparation, installation, and participation in the annual honors exhibition. Materials fee.
ART 198.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. School of Arts Honors students only.

ART 199.name: Independent Study
ART 199.description: Individual study or directed creative projects as arranged with faculty member. Materials fee.

ART 210.name: First-Year Graduate Seminar
ART 210.description: Introductory theory class to contemporary art: intellectual history, theoretical antecedents, and current critical concerns.

ART 215.name: Graduate Seminar Topics
ART 215.description: In-depth discussion of contemporary art production in relation to a variety of theoretical, cultural, and historical topics. Material is determined by the given instructor's current research interest. Topics vary.

ART 220.name: Graduate Seminar: Issues in Contemporary Art
ART 220.description: Classroom interaction with artists, curators, critics, lecturers from fields outside of the arts or from cross-disciplines. Includes recommended readings, discussions, panel participation, writing assignments.

ART 230.name: Graduate Group Critique
ART 230.description: Focus on studio production. Students are expected to help foster and develop an environment in which serious and sophisticated peer critique can take place.

ART 236.name: Graduate Topics in Studio Production
ART 236.description: Graduate group study of a specific medium or art practice (e.g., painting

ART 240.name: Interdisciplinary Projects
ART 240.description: Intensive faculty-led discussion of in-progress graduate studio projects--can be discipline driven or working across fields in a rigorous interdisciplinary studio environment where students meet with the professor both individually and in small groups.

ART 250.name: Directed Reading and Research
ART 250.description: Independent study with a supervising faculty member to direct academic research, develop bibliographies, and discuss assigned readings.

ART 251.name: Special Topics Seminar
ART 251.description: Directed reading and/or study group on a given research topic. Agreed-upon meeting structure may be flexible in order to accommodate off-campus field trips and travel.

ART 255.name: Graduate Interdisciplinary and Collaborative Projects
ART 255.description: For graduate students working collaboratively across the School of the Arts or cross-university. May be team taught with one of the faculty members based in the Department of Art.

ART 261.name: Graduate Thesis Writing Seminar
ART 261.description: Seminar for writing as a component of the thesis. Different models of writing, text, and spoken word will be discussed. Required second year.
ART 261.prereqString:
Corequisite: ART 262
Prerequisite: ART 210 and ART 215 and ART 220

ART 262.name: Graduate Thesis Independent Study
ART 262.description: Tutorials and directed study in thesis writing, research and/or studio production with thesis committee chair and/or thesis committee members to be taken during final quarters of study.
ART 262.prereqString:
Corequisite: ART 261
Prerequisite: ART 210 and ART 215 and ART 220

ART 263.name: Graduate Thesis, Exhibition Critique
ART 263.description: Group critique required for matriculating M.F.A. students during the quarter in which their thesis exhibitions are scheduled. Public presentation/lecture on student's work required.
ART 263.prereqString: Prerequisite: ART 210 and ART 215 and ART 220 and ART 230 and ART 240 and ART 261 and ART 262

ART 264.name: Critical and Curatorial Thesis Exhibition
ART 264.description: Intensive tutorial geared toward execution of professional gallery exhibition, which is one half of the degree requirement for the M.F.A. concentration in Critical and Curatorial Studies. Must be taken under direction of Committee Chair.

ART 280.name: Contemporary Exhibition Systems
ART 280.description: Investigates contemporary case studies of curatorial practice. Sometimes taught in collaboration with a host institution. The history, theory and criticism or curatorial practice are tested through the explication of real exhibitions.

ART 280A.name: Introduction to Exhibition Systems
ART 280A.description: Introduces the basics of curating, covering the fundamentals of collection, research, fundraising, publicity, and installation. Also introduces the related categories of public programming and art criticism.

ART 399.name: University Teaching
ART 399.description: Limited to Teaching Associates working under the active guidance and supervision of a regular rank faculty member responsible for curriculum and instruction at the University.

ART HIS 30.name: Latin American Art and Architecture: 1492 to the Present
ART HIS 30.description: Charts the history of Latin American art and architecture from the invasion of the Americas in 1492 to the present. It examines the production of visual art in relation to colonization, imperialism, migration, international exchange, and racial formation.

ART HIS 40A.name: Ancient Greek and Roman Art, and Architecture
ART HIS 40A.description: An overview of Greek and Roman art, and related ancient visual cultures. Considers how and why the peoples of antiquity created art and architecture, as well as the significance of these works within their social, religious, and historical contexts.

ART HIS 40B.name: Arts of Europe: Medieval and Renaissance
ART HIS 40B.description: Focuses on the art of the Mediterranean area and Europe between ca. A.D. 350 and 1600. By means of movements and artists, examines the cultural identities of the Christian, Islamic, and Early Modern worlds.

ART HIS 40C.name: Early Modern and Modern Art in Europe and America
ART HIS 40C.description: The visual arts from the seventeenth to the twenty-first centuries. Explores the purposes and meaning of painting, sculpture, and architecture in relation to artists, viewers, and historical events.

ART HIS 42A.name: History of Asian Art: Arts of India
ART HIS 42A.description: Emphasizing Hindu, Buddhist, and Islamic art of greater India (Pakistan, Bangladesh, Sri Lanka) from proto-historic to modern times. Themes include art as a source of history, commercial and religious pan-Asian connections, nationalism, and modern versus historical identities.

ART HIS 42B.name: History of Asian Art: Arts of China
ART HIS 42B.description: An introduction to the arts and visual culture of China from Neolithic to modern times. Themes includes the representation of power, death and the afterlife, popular culture and elite arts, landscape and women's painting, and concludes with contemporary China.

ART HIS 42C.name: History of Asian Art: Arts of Japan
ART HIS 42C.description: Examines compelling images and objects of spirit and power created in Japan over many centuries. Themes include Buddhist icons, narative illustration, popular prints, architecture, manga, and the avant-garde. Japanese interactions with Korean, Chinese, and European culture are emphasized.

ART HIS 42D.name: History of Asian Art: Arts of Islam
ART HIS 42D.description: Examines past and present Islamic art, spanning 1,500 years and extending from the Americas through Indonesia. Themes include Islam as a globalizing force, the definition of "Islamic," and the competing roles of religion and politics in making art.

ART HIS 42E.name: Art and Archaeology of Ancient Persia, Egypt, and Mesopotamia
ART HIS 42E.description: An introduction to the art and archaeology of ancient Egypt, Mesopotamia, Anatolia, Persia, and the wider Iranian world from the Neolithic to the coming of Islam. Considers wider impact on the ancient and early medieval worlds and their present legacy.

ART HIS 44.name: Image Collision: A Multicultural Approach to Images and Their Users
ART HIS 44.description: Comparisons between present-day visual culture and pre-modern art to re-evaluate the ways in which one understands the contemporary histories of underrepresented groups in the United States.

ART HIS 55.name: Disneyland
ART HIS 55.description: From Dole Whips to roller coasters, the focus is on the innovations in industrial automation and manufacturing that made Disneyland’s attractions possible. Discusses fandom, guest experiences, operating procedures, technical and design patents, and how rides work.

ART HIS 100.name: Studies in Ancient Art
ART HIS 100.description: Topics in Egyptian, Prehistoric, and Etruscan art of the Mediterranean area treated with specific reference to relevant cultural and historical settings.  Specialized courses in Greek and Roman art are also taught.

ART HIS 103.name: Studies in Greek Art
ART HIS 103.description: Topics in Greek art, architecture, and topography from the Prehistoric period through the end of the fourth century B.C.E.

ART HIS 107.name: Studies in Roman Art
ART HIS 107.description: Topics in Hellenistic and Roman art and architecture

ART HIS 110.name: Studies in Medieval Art
ART HIS 110.description: Specialized topics in Medieval art and architecture in Europe, the Mediterranean area, and the Near East between the fourth and fifteenth centuries.  Examples:  the Art of the Migration Period, Medieval City.

ART HIS 111B.name: Byzantine Art: 650-1450
ART HIS 111B.description: Studies in the development of the art and architecture of the Byzantine Empire between ca. 650 and 1450.

ART HIS 112.name: Studies in Early Christian and Byzantine Art
ART HIS 112.description: Selected topics on the development of the art and architecture of the Later Roman and Byzantine Empires between ca. 300 and 1453. Examples: Early Christian architecture, Byzantine painting.

ART HIS 114.name: Studies in Western Medieval Art
ART HIS 114.description: Selected topics on the development of art and architecture in Western Europe between ca. 700 and 1400. Examples: Romanesque painting, Gothic architecture.

ART HIS 120.name: Studies in Renaissance and Baroque Art
ART HIS 120.description: Selected topics on the art and architecture of Europe between the fifteenth and eighteenth centuries. Examples: Renaissance and Baroque prints, Bruegel to Rubens.

ART HIS 121.name: Studies in Southern Renaissance Art
ART HIS 121.description: Selected topics determined by individual faculty members exploring historical developments and individual artists of the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries in Italy and Spain. Examples: Renaissance Venice, Age of Michelangelo.

ART HIS 125.name: Studies in Southern Baroque Art
ART HIS 125.description: Selected topics determined by individual faculty members exploring historical developments and individual artists of the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries in Italy and Spain. Example: Rome in the seventeenth century.

ART HIS 128.name: Studies in Northern Baroque Art
ART HIS 128.description: Selected topics determined by individual faculty members exploring historical developments and individual artists of the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries in Northern Europe. Example: the Age of Rembrandt.

ART HIS 134C.name: Modern European Art: From Impressionism to the Fauves
ART HIS 134C.description: History of European painting and urban transformation from 1851 to 1907, when Paris stood strong as the unquestioned cultural capital of the nineteenth century.

ART HIS 134D.name: Modern European Art: From Cubism to Surrealism
ART HIS 134D.description: History of European painting, sculpture, and design from 1907 to 1940, when Paris and painting lost their dominance as other cultural centers and other media claimed renewed importance.

ART HIS 134E.name: Topics in Modern European Art
ART HIS 134E.description: Selected topics within the period 1643 to 1940.

ART HIS 140A.name: History of Contemporary Art
ART HIS 140A.description: Selected topics exploring historical developments of contemporary art from 1945 to the present. Examples: American Art 1945-1989, European Art 1945-1989, Art After 1989. Works of art are studied as cultural, social, and political practices.

ART HIS 140B.name: Topics in Contemporary Art
ART HIS 140B.description: Selected topics exploring artistic movements, artists, and/or issues in contemporary art from 1945 to the present. Examples include Junk Art, Countercultures, Art and Politics Now. Works of art are studied as cultural, social, and political practices.

ART HIS 145A.name: Studies in Modern Architecture
ART HIS 145A.description: Architecture and related design practices from the late eighteenth century through 1945 are studied in relation to social, aesthetic, technological, and political questions.

ART HIS 145B.name: Studies in Architecture after 1945
ART HIS 145B.description: Architecture and related design practices from 1945 through present are studied in relation to social, aesthetic, technological, and political questions.

ART HIS 145C.name: Topics in the History of Modern and Contemporary Architecture
ART HIS 145C.description: Varying topics from the late eighteenth century to the present. Architecture and related design practices are studied in relation to social, aesthetic, technological, and political questions.

ART HIS 150.name: Studies in Asian Art
ART HIS 150.description: Topics include visual studies in China, Japan, Korea and India.

ART HIS 151B.name: Later Imperial China
ART HIS 151B.description: Investigates the uses, subjects, styles, and social contexts of art made in the later Imperial dynasties, whether court art, religious art, women's painting, scholar painting, or art for the market.

ART HIS 151C.name: Modern China
ART HIS 151C.description: Examines the evolution and media of Chinese art and visual culture in the context of modern China's sweeping historical, social, and political changes.

ART HIS 155A.name: Ancient India
ART HIS 155A.description: Examines the visual and religious history of the region defined as "India" today, but necessarily encompassing modern Bangladesh and Pakistan.  Culminates with the supposed Golden Age of the Gupta empire and its far-reaching legacies.

ART HIS 155B.name: Medieval India
ART HIS 155B.description: Begins with the Gupta period's aesthetic legacies in South Asia's architecture, sculpture, and painting. Explores the dispersal of Islam throughout South Asia, including the Muslim communities of southern India.

ART HIS 155C.name: Modern India
ART HIS 155C.description: Examines the imperial patronage of the Mughal emperors, covering their territorial holdings extending from Afghanistan through western Bangladesh.  Continues with the "aftermath" of the Mughal empire and the rise of British commercialism and colonialism.

ART HIS 155D.name: Topics in the Art and Architecture of India
ART HIS 155D.description: Studies in selected areas of Art and Architecture of India. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

ART HIS 156.name: Art and Globalization, Modern
ART HIS 156.description: Study of modern art as a cause and expression of increasing contacts between cultures. Focusing on regions in Asia and the Americas, adoption of European oil painting, indigenous art movements, and national capital architecture are explored.

ART HIS 162C.name: Contemporary Japan
ART HIS 162C.description: Study of various media of Japanese art from the time of war defeat in 1945 until the present. Topics include artists' responses to the nuclear bomb, the aesthetics of the "economic miracle," avant-garde groups, manga, and innovations in architecture.

ART HIS 163.name: Asian American Art, Contemporary
ART HIS 163.description: Study of the Asian American experience in contemporary art and visual culture. Art by Asian Americans of diverse backgrounds as well as the history of visualization of Asian identities in American art/visual culture.

ART HIS 164A.name: Modern African American Art
ART HIS 164A.description: Investigates the history of modern African American art

ART HIS 164B.name: Contemporary African American Art
ART HIS 164B.description: Investigates the history of contemporary African American art

ART HIS 164D.name: African American Women in Art
ART HIS 164D.description: Examines depictions of and by African American women in art and popular culture through a variety of media including textiles, painting, sculpture, photography, and installation. Focuses on African American women's experiences, perspectives, and strategies for contemporary representation.

ART HIS 164E.name: African Americans and Photography
ART HIS 164E.description: Explores depictions of and by African Americans through photography. Examines the history of photography in relationship to African American culture through a variety of media from early daguerreotype processes to digital imagery.

ART HIS 165A.name: Early American Art
ART HIS 165A.description: An examination of American visual culture from 1620 to 1860 from the era of European exploration and colonization of the New World to the beginning of the Civil War.

ART HIS 165B.name: Nineteenth Century American Art
ART HIS 165B.description: An exploration of American visual culture from 1860 to 1900, including paintings, sculpture, and photographs produced during the Civil War and during the decades of prosperity that followed.

ART HIS 165C.name: Modern American Art
ART HIS 165C.description: Focusing on the period from 1900 until 1965, this course considers the emergence and institutionalization of modern art in the United States.

ART HIS 165D.name: Topics in American Art
ART HIS 165D.description: Varying topics within the period 1620 to 1970. Works of art are studied in their cultural, social, and political contexts.

ART HIS 167.name: Latin American Art History
ART HIS 167.description: Historical periods vary with each offering and may range from pre-Columbian societies, through the colonial era, to developments in modern and contemporary art.

ART HIS 180.name: Topics in the Criticism of Art
ART HIS 180.description: Selected topics discussed on the theoretical and/or practical dimensions of art historical criticism.

ART HIS 181.name: Topics in Museum Studies
ART HIS 181.description: Addresses the historical and contemporary function of the museum as an instructional device.  The function of exhibitions in the public sphere, and the roles of curators, educators, and the public are analyzed.

ART HIS 183B.name: 20th Century Photographic History
ART HIS 183B.description: Varying topics within the history of photography in the 20th century. Photographic practice studied in relation to art history, cultural history, and social history.

ART HIS 183C.name: Selected Topics in Photographic History
ART HIS 183C.description: Varying topics within the history of photography from the early 19th century to the present. Photographic practice studied in relation to art history, cultural history, and social history. Examples include documentary

ART HIS 185.name: Topics in Visual Studies
ART HIS 185.description: Interdisciplinary topics on the cultural analysis of visual artifacts and practices.

ART HIS 190W.name: Art History Methods
ART HIS 190W.description: Theory and practice of art history, with an emphasis on formal and social models of analyzing and writing about art.
ART HIS 190W.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
ART HIS 190W.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. Art History Majors only.

ART HIS 196.name: Ethics, Law, and Art
ART HIS 196.description: Addresses a broad range of ethical and legal issues pertaining to art, ownership, looting and theft, museum policies, and cultural heritage.

ART HIS 198.name: Advanced Seminar: Topics in Art History
ART HIS 198.description: Discussion and report-oriented seminar with emphasis on reading, writing, and thinking about problems in art history. Examples: Gothic Cathedral, Portraiture East and West.
ART HIS 198.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. Art History Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ART HIS 199.name: Independent Study in Art History
ART HIS 199.description: Supervised, but independent reading or research on art historical topics.

ART HIS 255A.name: Ancient India
ART HIS 255A.description: Examines the visual and religious history of the region defined as "India" today, but necessarily encompassing modern Bangladesh and Pakistan. Culminates with the supposed Golden Age of the Gupta empire and its far-reaching legacies.

ART HIS 255B.name: Medieval India
ART HIS 255B.description: Begins with the Gupta period's aesthetic legacies in South Asia's architecture, sculpture, and painting. Explores the dispersal of Islam throughout South Asia, including the Muslim communities of southern India.

ART HIS 296.name: Ethics, Law, and Art
ART HIS 296.description: Addresses a broad range of ethical and legal issues pertaining to art, ownership, looting and theft, museum policies, and cultural heritage.
ART HIS 296.prereqString: Prerequisite: Background in Art History or Legal Studies.

ART HIS 298.name: Master's Seminar: Topics in Art History
ART HIS 298.description: Studies in selected areas of Art History. Examples include Gothic Cathedral, Portraiture East and West.

ART HIS 299.name: Master's Thesis Research
ART HIS 299.description: Research and writing of the Master's thesis.

ARTS 1.name: ArtsCore
ARTS 1.description: An introduction to the arts in general, and to the arts at UCI. Concentration on (1) the interdisciplinary nature of the arts, and (2) the content of particular arts disciplines.

ARTS 75.name: Digital Media: Exhibition
ARTS 75.description: A discussion and critique course in all media arts. Includes a review of key media arts concepts and the preparation of an end-of-quarter exhibition.

ARTS H81.name: Improvisation and Modes of Research / Creative Expression
ARTS H81.description: Through immersion, readings, analysis, and observation, students are trained to recognize, build, and engage a set of “improvisatory” cognitive skills in order to enhance artistic creation, the generation of language, data analysis, and the application of the scientific method.
ARTS H81.restriction: Restriction: Campuswide Honors Collegium students only. Seniors only.

ARTS 199.name: Independent Study
ARTS 199.description: Individual study or directed projects as arranged with faculty member.

ASIANAM 50.name: Asian American Histories
ASIANAM 50.description: Examines and compares diverse experiences of major Asian American groups since the mid-nineteenth century. Topics include origins of emigration

ASIANAM 51.name: The U.S. and Asia
ASIANAM 51.description: Explores the historical and contemporary transnational linkages between the U.S. and regions in Asia and their resultant flows of people, goods, and ideas. Attention given to the role of militarism and processes of globalization, and the histories of cultural contact/conflict.

ASIANAM 52.name: Asian American Communities
ASIANAM 52.description: Examines the renewal of Asian immigration following World War II. Explores contemporary Asian American populations and communities in the U.S., and the impact of contemporary Asian immigration on the U.S. political economy and social order.

ASIANAM 53.name: Asian Americans and Race
ASIANAM 53.description: Analyzes the Asian American experience in comparative perspective, which includes comparisons of different ethnic and racial groups, and across gender and class. Possible topics include labor, economy, politics, migration, nation, popular culture, gender, family, sexuality, and multiraciality.

ASIANAM 54.name: Asian American Stories
ASIANAM 54.description: Examines stories from Asian American communities through literary texts and other media. Selected themes may include the following: dislocation/relocation, finding/inventing a usable past, poetics/politics in language, identities/ethnicities.

ASIANAM 55.name: Asian Americans and the Media
ASIANAM 55.description: Investigates popular representations of and cultural productions by Asian Pacific Americans and Asians in the Americas from the late-nineteenth century to the present. Cultural media may include political cartoons, film/television, popular music, visual art, blogs/Web sites, and performance.

ASIANAM 100W.name: Research Methodologies for Asian American Studies
ASIANAM 100W.description: Explores various research methodologies for Asian American Studies combining theoretical knowledge with field research. Goals: conduct field research about immigrants and refugees from Asia. Topics vary: migration and labor, assimilation and cultural preservation, cultural expressions in the diaspora.
ASIANAM 100W.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

ASIANAM 110.name: Asian American Writers
ASIANAM 110.description: Literary analysis of Asian American writers' representations of issues of identity, class, history among others. Variety of literary forms—novel, poem, drama, essay—included in a study of a variety of Asian American ethnic groups.

ASIANAM 111.name: Asian American History
ASIANAM 111.description: Introduction to important themes in the history of people of Asian ancestry in the United States from the nineteenth century to the present.

ASIANAM 112.name: Asian American Art History
ASIANAM 112.description: Investigation of Asian American experience expressed by art and visual culture throughout the twentieth century. Art by Asian Americans of diverse backgrounds as well as the history of cultural visualization of Asian identities in American art/visual culture.

ASIANAM 114.name: Asian American Film and Video
ASIANAM 114.description: Topics include histories of Asian American film and video, including documentaries, experimental, short subjects, feature-length independent film, and other forms of cinematic expression. Explores issues of identity (national, racial, gendered, among others).

ASIANAM 116.name: Asian Americans and Popular Culture
ASIANAM 116.description: Focuses on Asian Americans' relationship to popular culture as both producers and consumers. Topics include consumer cultures and subcultures, cyberspace and public space, popular music, indy comics and other print media.

ASIANAM 130.name: Undocumented Immigrant Experiences
ASIANAM 130.description: Examines the experiences of undocumented immigrants and the policies that structure their educational, economic, social, and political participation.

ASIANAM 132.name: Comparative Minority Politics
ASIANAM 132.description: Examines the political experiences of Blacks, Latinos, and Asian Americans in the United States from roughly 1950 to the present. Focuses on how each group has pursued political empowerment via both conventional political channels and social movements.

ASIANAM 137.name: Asian American Labor
ASIANAM 137.description: Explores history of Asian Americans and work from the nineteenth century to the present. Areas of study include migration, colonialism, family, social organization, and work culture.

ASIANAM 138.name: Race and Urban Space
ASIANAM 138.description: Examines how ethnic and racial processes shape and structure interactions in urban settings, such as schools, housing, employment, and public spaces, with attention to the international impact of globalization and postcolonial forces.

ASIANAM 142.name: Islam in America
ASIANAM 142.description: Offers a critical academic study of Islam in America, focusing on the core tenets of belief, the diversity of practices, and historical transformations that have taken place since the arrival of Muslims in the United States.

ASIANAM 143.name: Religious Traditions of Asian Americans
ASIANAM 143.description: Studies the religious traditions of Asian Americans, focusing on the transplantation of religious institutions, establishment of sacred spaces, celebration of religious holidays, socialization of children, as well as birth, marriage, gender relations, death, family.

ASIANAM 144.name: The Politics of Protest
ASIANAM 144.description: Examines the Civil Rights, Black Power, and women’s movements in relationship to the Asian American movement. Uses social movement theories to illuminate the cases, and the cases to critique and revise the theories.

ASIANAM 150.name: Special Topics in Asian American Studies
ASIANAM 150.description: Analyzes a variety of themes in Asian American Studies—identity, history, culture—from various interdisciplinary perspectives in humanities, arts, social sciences.

ASIANAM 151C.name: Korean American Studies
ASIANAM 151C.description: Explores the factors that have distinctly shaped the Korean American experience, including patterns of racial domination, the profile of immigrant flow, immigrant roles in the urban political economy, politics in Korea, and the role of the church.

ASIANAM 151D.name: Vietnamese American Studies
ASIANAM 151D.description: Studies the resettlement of Vietnamese in the United States following their exodus from Southeast Asia. Topics include the Vietnam War, the 1975 evacuation, boat and land refugees, the shaping of Vietnamese communities, and Vietnamese American literature.

ASIANAM 151E.name: Japanese American Studies
ASIANAM 151E.description: Studies the settlement of Japanese in Hawaii and the continental United States since the late 19th century. Topics include sugar plantations, development of rural Japanese America, World War II internment, post-War community development, and persistence of Japanese American identity.

ASIANAM 151F.name: South Asian American Studies
ASIANAM 151F.description: Examines and compares the experiences of South Asian immigrants in the U.S. over time. Looks at the economic, political, and social positions of the immigrants, with special emphasis on religious changes and the changes in the second and later generations.
ASIANAM 151F.restriction: Restriction: Asian American Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Policy/Public Service Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ASIANAM 151H.name: Southeast Asian American Studies
ASIANAM 151H.description: Analyzes experiences of refugees and immigrants from Southeast Asia, which may include those from Cambodia, Laos, Vietnam, and the Philippines. Examines political and economic factors for their exodus and how they reconstruct their identities, histories, and communities.

ASIANAM 151J.name: Chinese American Studies
ASIANAM 151J.description: Analyzes the experiences of Chinese in the United States. Immigration, Chinese exclusion, racial and gender identity. Historical overview and contemporary issues covered.

ASIANAM 151K.name: Filipina/Filipino American Studies
ASIANAM 151K.description: Explores the experience of Filipina/Filipino Americans from the era of Spanish colonization of the Philippines to present-day community formations in the United States, with special emphasis on the 20th century. Topics include colonialism, nation, migration, gender, and culture.

ASIANAM 162.name: Asian American Women
ASIANAM 162.description: Examines the representations and experiences of Asian American women from diverse perspectives. Explores the commonalities and differences among various groups of Asian American women, with particular focus on history, culture, values, and family roles.

ASIANAM 164.name: Topics in Intersectionality
ASIANAM 164.description: Topics include intersectional analysis of various themes related to ethnicity, gender, sexuality, and race within Asian American communities.

ASIANAM 166.name: Race and Citizenship
ASIANAM 166.description: Explores historical and contemporary patterns of racialization in relation to citizenship. Topics may include racial categorization, immigration, and comparative racialization.

ASIANAM 168.name: Politics of Animal Rights
ASIANAM 168.description: Examines animal rights/welfare movement’s efforts to transform moral, practical, and legal standing of nonhuman animals in contemporary U.S. Explores intersection of racism, sexism, and speciesism informed by theories of race and ethnicity, including Asian American Studies.
ASIANAM 168.restriction: Restriction: Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Asian American Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ASIANAM 199.name: Independent Study
ASIANAM 199.description: Directed reading and research in consultation with a faculty member. Substantial written work required.

ASIANAM 200A.name: Theory and Methods in Asian American Studies
ASIANAM 200A.description: Introduction to the intersection of the social sciences, humanities, and other fields that constitute the theory and methodology of Asian American Studies. Focuses on the interventions and contestations within Asian American Studies that have transformed the discipline in recent years.

ASIANAM 200B.name: Contemporary Issues in Asian American Studies
ASIANAM 200B.description: Examines the interrelations between history, theory, and race in the aftermath of the twentieth-century decolonial movements, offering an account of race through postcolonial and postnationalist approaches in comparative contexts. Considers the interventions made by transnational feminist and racialized queer critiques.

ASIANAM 200C.name: Leadership and Social Change in Asian American Communities
ASIANAM 200C.description: Introduces students to models of community-engaged learning and leadership that are central to the field of Asian American studies. Designed to expose students to histories and models of organizing in Asian American communities and forms of community-based research.

ASIANAM 200D.name: Introduction to Asian American Studies Research
ASIANAM 200D.description: Introduces students to research topics and methods within the field of Asian American studies. Aims to expose students to core and affiliated faculty to help them identify possible advisors for master's research projects or members of doctoral committees.

ASIANAM 201.name: Graduate Topics in Asian American Studies
ASIANAM 201.description: Seminars on various topics in Asian American Studies.

ASIANAM 250.name: Advanced Topics in Asian American Studies
ASIANAM 250.description: Seminar covering various areas of research within Asian American Studies as an interdisciplinary field. Recommended for advanced graduate students.

ASIANAM 290.name: Directed Research
ASIANAM 290.description: Directed graduate study/research in Asian American Studies.

ASIANAM 291.name: Directed Reading
ASIANAM 291.description: Readings focused on specialized topics in consultation with, and with the consent of, a faculty member.

ASIANAM 399.name: University Teaching
ASIANAM 399.restriction: Restriction: Emphasis in Asian American Studies graduate students only.

BANA 200.name: Foundations of Business Analytics
BANA 200.description: Provides overview of the field of business analytics, and the theory and practice underpinnings of the three MSBA curricular tracks: Data Analytics, Marketing Analytics, and Operations Analytics. Provides students with a working knowledge of the R programming language.
BANA 200.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Business Analytics Majors only.

BANA 201A.name: Statistics for Data Science
BANA 201A.description: Methods of statistical inference, emphasizing applications to administrative and management decision problems. Topics include classical estimation and hypothesis testing, regression, correlation, analysis of variance, decision analysis, and forecasting.
BANA 201A.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Business Analytics Majors only.

BANA 201B.name: Management Science for Analytics
BANA 201B.description: An introduction to computer-based models for decision making. Topics include optimization (linear programming, integer programming, network flow models) and computer simulation. Uses spreadsheets extensively, including Excel built-in and add-in packages.
BANA 201B.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Business Analytics Majors only.

BANA 205.name: Foundations of Marketing
BANA 205.description: Introduction to the field of marketing. Objectives include developing familiarity with fundamental concepts, theories, and techniques in marketing, and acquainting students with the type of decisions made by marketing managers, including customer targeting, product, pricing, distribution, promotion, and research.
BANA 205.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Business Analytics Majors only.

BANA 211.name: MSBA ProSeminar
BANA 211.description: Provides students in the Merage School Master of Science in Business Analytics program with information and practical skills for success in the MSBA program and for business career planning.
BANA 211.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Business Analytics Majors only.

BANA 212.name: Data and Programming for Analytics
BANA 212.description: Challenges and teaches students how to handle data, from initial data acquisition to final data analysis. Provides students with a working knowledge of the Python programming language.
BANA 212.prereqString: Prerequisite: Basic familiarity with programming is recommended.
BANA 212.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Business Analytics Majors only.

BANA 241.name: Business Analytics Internship
BANA 241.description: Students apply analytics and big data knowledge obtained from classroom theory through work experiences. Provides knowledge of career opportunities, an understanding of the role analytics plays in business environments, and preparation for the business analytics profession.

BANA 271.name: Marketing Analytics
BANA 271.description: Introduces students to quantitative marketing analytics methods and teaches them how to apply the methods to business problems of interest. Topics include: resource allocation and ROI, marketing mix analytics, customer analytics, market segmentation and targeting, advertising, promotions, and digital marketing.

BANA 273.name: Machine Learning for Analytics
BANA 273.description: Introduces methods to mine data repositories for business intelligence to facilitate analytical decision-making. Topics include clustering for market segmentation, association rules to discover relationships between different purchase decisions, and  Naive-Bayes classification techniques for decision making using decision-trees.
BANA 273.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Business Analytics Majors only.

BANA 274.name: Deep Learning and Applications
BANA 274.description: Provides students with an understanding of specific topics in machine learning including networks and deep learning, improving neural networks, structuring deep learning projects, and convolutional neural networks.
BANA 274.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Business Analytics Majors only.

BANA 275.name: Natural Language Processing and Applications
BANA 275.description: Focuses on providing students knowledge of advanced techniques for data analytics. Students deepen their understanding of topics including: dimension reduction, text mining and topic modeling, sentiment analysis, collaborative filtering, and causal estimation.

BANA 277.name: Customer and Social Analytics
BANA 277.description: Examines how business managers can leverage Web 2.0 and social media analytics to create value for their organizations and customers. Topics include digital and social strategies

BANA 279.name: Business Data Management
BANA 279.description: Provides essential knowledge for business managers to store and utilize data effectively. Aims to introduce the core concepts in databases, data warehouses, and big data on cloud. Offers an in-depth understanding of each technology’s core concepts with hands-on programming.
BANA 279.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Business Analytics Majors only.

BANA 287.name: The Art and Science of Applied Forecast Modeling
BANA 287.description: Covers core and advanced techniques of forecasting. Emphasizes the innovation required to develop accurate models, inspires the need to break rules, leverages ideation needed to discover data sources and engineer variables, and seeks ways to build new models.
BANA 287.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Business Analytics Majors only.

BANA 288.name: Predictive Analytics
BANA 288.description: Deals with predicting entities (forecasting) and predicting membership of known groups (classification). Blends methodologies of forecasting and data mining, focusing on multiple regression, logistic regression, neural nets, ARIMA, discriminate analysis, and k-nearest neighbors, and applying these methods to managerial problems/decision-making.

BANA 290.name: Special Topics in Business Analytics
BANA 290.description: Studies in selected areas of business analytics. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

BANA 294.name: Big Data Analytics with Hadoop
BANA 294.description: In-depth hands-on exploration of various cutting-edge information technologies used for big data analytics. Focuses on using Hadoop, Sqoop, Pig, and Hive for ETL operations and on understanding the MapReduce algorithm using Apache Mahout for data mining algorithms.

BANA 295.name: Big Data Management Systems
BANA 295.description: Provides an introductory-level overview to the emerging technologies in database systems. Students gain critical insight into big data challenges, the choices of different systems and technologies available, relative advantages/disadvantages, and unique aspects of different systems.

BANA 298A.name: Business Analytics Capstone Prep
BANA 298A.description: Prep course for the required capstone project. Students apply the knowledge and methods acquired through the program’s coursework to an applied business analytics problem. Requirements include project selection, submission of project plan, and data collection/analysis.
BANA 298A.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Business Analytics Majors only.

BANA 298B.name: Business Analytics Capstone Project
BANA 298B.description: Continuation of the capstone project. Students apply the knowledge and methods acquired through the coursework in the program to an applied business analytics problem. Work includes data analysis, completed research paper, and final presentation.
BANA 298B.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Business Analytics Majors only.

BANA 299.name: Individual Study
BANA 299.description: Individual study under the direction of a selected faculty member.

BATS 209A.name: Introduction to Medical Statistics
BATS 209A.description: Provides understanding of medical statistics for clinicians and clinical researchers to read and interpret literature.

BATS 209B.name: Introduction to Medical Statistics II
BATS 209B.description: Provides sufficient understanding of medical statistics to read and interpret medical literature critically, identify appropriate statistics for basic research designs used in medicine, and discriminate between appropriate and inappropriate statistical applications for common research designs.

BATS 210A.name: Introduction to Clinical Epidemiology
BATS 210A.description: Introduces principles and practice of clinical epidemiology and the population-based approach to health and disease.

BATS 232.name: Design and Analysis of Clinical Trials
BATS 232.description: Presents history, organization and planning, rationale for methods, limits, and ethics in conducting clinical trials.

BATS 245A.name: Comparative Effectiveness Research
BATS 245A.description: Provides a comprehensive overview of comparative effectiveness research (CER) with in-depth methodologic clinical practice and policy/dissemination issues related to the conduct, interpretation, and clinical applications of CER.

BATS 247.name: Measurement Science, Outcomes Research, and Advanced Applied Methods
BATS 247.description: Further the understanding of methodologic issues involved in the conducting of comparative effectiveness research (CER). Topics: risk adjustment, balancing observational study designs, use of outcomes from multiple data sources, innovations clinical trial designs, the conduct of meta-analysis, and psychometric methods.

BATS 251.name: Quality Efficiency and Cost Effectiveness
BATS 251.description: Introduces the principles and practice of quality of care, patient safety, and patient experience research, along with major national and statewide policy and legislative initiatives related to quality of care and patient safety.

BATS 253.name: Disparities in Health and Health Care
BATS 253.description: Reviews all aspects of culture that influence health status, development of public health policy, and management and practice of health care. Explores how race and ethnicity affect health and health care, including health care services and policies governing these services.

BATS 255.name: Health Politics and Policy
BATS 255.description: Offers political and analytical insights into understanding U.S. health policymaking and developing strategies that influence health policy outcomes.

BATS 280.name: Biomedical and Translational Science Seminar
BATS 280.description: Students present their current research or a topic of interest and are exposed to diverse projects in the biomedical and translational science arena.

BATS 295.name: Master's Thesis Research and Writing
BATS 295.description: Master’s thesis research and writing with Biomedical and Translational Science faculty.

BATS 296.name: Ethics in Clinical Research
BATS 296.description: Covers major frameworks and concepts of ethics in public health research as well as human subject protection issues.

BATS 299.name: Independent Directed Research
BATS 299.description: Independent research with Biomedical and Translational Science faculty.

BIO SCI 1A.name: Life Sciences
BIO SCI 1A.description: Designed to introduce nonmajors to the basic concepts of modern biology. Discussion of evolutionary biology, ecology, molecular biology, and genetics.

BIO SCI 2A.name: Freshman Seminar
BIO SCI 2A.description: Weekly meetings consisting of presentations by faculty, professional staff, and Peer Academic Advisors provide information about the School of Biological Sciences, campus resources, learning skills, and special programs/opportunities.
BIO SCI 2A.restriction: Restriction: Freshmen only. School of Biological Sciences students only.

BIO SCI 2B.name: Freshman Seminar
BIO SCI 2B.description: Faculty presentations and readings focused on the structure, function, opportunities, and current issues in the biological sciences.
BIO SCI 2B.restriction: Restriction: Freshmen only. School of Biological Sciences students only.

BIO SCI 2C.name: Solutions in Science
BIO SCI 2C.description: Students will be introduced to approaches that can be used to solve scientific problems. These methods can be utilized in introductory to advanced classes and will allow students to become independent thinkers.

BIO SCI 2D.name: EASE Seminar
BIO SCI 2D.description: Seminars designed to help students achieve success in STEM courses. Provides collaborative learning environment facilitated by undergraduate mentor. Students develop critical thinking and study skills. Also receive guidance to campus resources that assist acclimation to University.

BIO SCI 3A.name: Career Decision Making
BIO SCI 3A.description: An introductory course designed to facilitate the career decision-making process. Decision-making processes, values, and standardized tests of aptitudes, interests, and values are utilized with non-test data in appraising biological sciences career options.

BIO SCI 3B.name: Non-Health Sciences Career Exploration
BIO SCI 3B.description: A survey course designed to assist students in exploring non-health science career options. Lectures by professionals in various fields.

BIO SCI 4B.name: Introduction to Field Biology
BIO SCI 4B.description: Field excursions to introduce students to local field sites and resources.
BIO SCI 4B.restriction: Restriction: Ecology and Evolutionary Biol Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

BIO SCI 6.name: Tropical Biology: Race to Save the Tropics
BIO SCI 6.description: Population growth combines with tropical resource consumption by industrialized nations to cause high rates of deforestation, pollution, habitat fragmentation, and extinction of species. Discusses tropical biomes, their population, community,  ecosystem processes, and possible means of conservation of biodiversity.

BIO SCI 9A.name: Nutrition Science
BIO SCI 9A.description: An introduction to nutrition science, integrating concepts from biology, biochemistry, microbiology, physiology, and psychology to explain the interaction between nutrients and the human body. Biological basis of nutrient standards is analyzed. Effects of nutrition, behavior, exercises on health/disease.

BIO SCI 9B.name: Biology and Chemistry of Food and Cooking
BIO SCI 9B.description: The kitchen is used as a laboratory to introduce fundamental principles of biology, chemistry, and physics. A molecular/cellular analysis of cooking, including concepts such as protein structure, browning reactions, colloids, emulsions, carbohydrate metabolism, and development of flavor/texture through biochemical transformations.

BIO SCI 9E.name: Horticulture Science
BIO SCI 9E.description: Scientific principles of horticulture at the UCI Arboretum. Taxonomy, plant life history strategies

BIO SCI 9G.name: Physiology of Fitness
BIO SCI 9G.description: An introduction to the organ systems of the human body, including muscle, cardiovascular, immune, and reproductive systems, with an emphasis on how the body responds to exercise, diet, and disease.

BIO SCI 9J.name: Biology of Oriental Medicine
BIO SCI 9J.description: With lectures, demonstrations, and hands-on learning, the theory and practice of herbal medicine, acupuncture, qigong, and manipulative therapies are explained in Western biomedical terms. The latest basic and clinical research advances in each area are also described.

BIO SCI 9K.name: Global Change Biology
BIO SCI 9K.description: Field trips and lectures that address ways in which humans are altering the global environment, with consequences for the ecology of animals, plants, and microbes.

BIO SCI 10.name: The Biology of Human Diseases
BIO SCI 10.description: Introduction to concepts of diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of major human infectious diseases. Covers some aspects of epidemiology. Scope and impact of infectious diseases in the present and past experiences in controlling infectious disease. Reviews biology of human organ systems.

BIO SCI 11.name: Topics in Biological Sciences
BIO SCI 11.description: Studies in selected areas of biological sciences.

BIO SCI 12.name: Molecular Basis of Human Disease
BIO SCI 12.description: Describes the cause and treatment of human diseases at the cutting edge of modern molecular understanding for non-science majors, including history, interviews, and stories.

BIO SCI 14.name: California Teach 1: Introduction to Science and Mathematics Teaching
BIO SCI 14.description: First in a series for students interested in becoming middle or high school teachers of mathematics or science. Students gain an understanding of effective, research-based teaching strategies. Includes supervised field experience in a K-12 classroom.
BIO SCI 14.restriction: Restriction: School of Physical Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Biological Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Engineering students have first consideration for enrollment.

BIO SCI 17.name: Evolutionary Psychology
BIO SCI 17.description: Introductory overview of the field of evolutionary psychology. Surveys topics operating at the interface of social sciences, i.e. behavioral psychology and evolutionary biology, while developing select aspects of the history of this developing field.

BIO SCI 23.name: Sustainable Landscaping: Design and Practices
BIO SCI 23.description: Through lectures and hands-on work, students learn how to design habitats around dwellings, within cities, and in rural environments. These include traditional/sustainable landscaping, restoration, stormwater/wastewater treatment, xeriscaping, and low impact development design. Sustainable landscape plant materials emphasized.

BIO SCI 25.name: Biology of Cancer
BIO SCI 25.description: Biological, clinical, and psychosocial nature of cancer through the perspectives of medical researchers, biologists, physicians, and health educators. For students of all majors, designed so that each can increase personal awareness of the biology of cancer.
BIO SCI 25.restriction: Restriction: BIO SCI 25 may not be taken for credit if taken after BIO SCI M125.

BIO SCI 35.name: The Brain and Behavior
BIO SCI 35.description: Introduction to how the brain works. Biological processes underlying perception, movement, sleep-wake cycles, motivation, language, learning, and memory. Changes in the brain associated with sex differences, drug use, aging, seasons, and time of day. Fundamental properties of the nervous system.

BIO SCI 36.name: Drugs and the Brain
BIO SCI 36.description: Introduction to the actions of drugs on the brain. How studying drug action helps reveal normal functions of neurons. How drugs can correct neural disorders or disrupt neural function. Biological issues related to drug abuse, drug addiction, and drug seeking.

BIO SCI 37.name: Brain Dysfunction and Repair
BIO SCI 37.description: Introduction to the disruptions in brain function that underlie disorders such as Alzheimer's disease, Parkinsonism, schizophrenia, and depression, and the basis for drug therapies. The brain's ability to repair itself after damage and the pros and cons of that repair.

BIO SCI 38.name: Mind, Memory, Amnesia, and the Brain
BIO SCI 38.description: Introduction to neural mechanisms underlying learning and memory. Emphasis on molecular changes that mediate memory as well as structures involved in different forms of memory. Additionally, examines the biology of memory phenomena, from extraordinary memory to false memory to amnesia.

BIO SCI 41.name: Aspects of Mood Disorder
BIO SCI 41.description: There are significant differences in response to psychiatric illness across cultures. Delves into the neuroscience underlying mood disorder, investigating current pharmacological treatments and sociocultural influences on treatment outcomes.

BIO SCI 43.name: Media on the Mind
BIO SCI 43.description: Surveys an ever-increasing collection of research, suggesting modern technology and social media are changing in the way our brains function.

BIO SCI 44.name: Stem Cells and Brain Repair
BIO SCI 44.description: Students introduced to the field of regenerative neurobiology. Both basic stem cell discoveries and their potential clinical application to brain disorders examined. Discussion of opportunities, challenges, and implications of this research.

BIO SCI 45.name: AIDS Fundamentals
BIO SCI 45.description: Considers the biological and sociological bases of the AIDS epidemic. Topics include the history of AIDS, current medical knowledge, transmission, risk reduction, and how the community can respond.

BIO SCI 46.name: Discussion and Literature Research in AIDS
BIO SCI 46.description: Students carry out two activities: (1) leading discussions about HIV/AIDS (predominantly regarding sociological and personal reactions) among students taking the AIDS Fundamentals course and (2) literature research about biomedical aspects of AIDS.

BIO SCI 47.name: Stress
BIO SCI 47.description: Investigates stress at a psychological, physiological, and molecular level, and provides a current overview of the field of stress research.

BIO SCI 55.name: Introduction to Ecology
BIO SCI 55.restriction: Restriction: No Biological Sciences Majors. BIO SCI 55 may not be taken for credit if taken after BIO SCI 96 or BIO SCI E106.

BIO SCI 56.name: Life Sciencing from Aristotle to Venter
BIO SCI 56.description: History of biology from Aristotle through to the scientific revolutions precipitated by Darwin, geneticists, molecular biologists, and now genomics. Introduces the practices and achievements of biological research to both beginning biology students and non-majors.

BIO SCI 75.name: Human Development: Conception to Birth
BIO SCI 75.description: Processes leading to the birth of a healthy child and the avoidance of birth defects. Male and female reproductive systems, hormonal control of egg-sperm formations, sexual intercourse, contraception, venereal diseases, fertilization, cell division, embryonic development, fetal physiology.

BIO SCI H90.name: The Idiom and Practice of Science
BIO SCI H90.description: The importance of biological sciences in our world is discussed. Topics may include brain and behavior, health and disease, genetics and society, and conservation biology. Primary goal is to encourage students to understand better the world in which they live.
BIO SCI H90.restriction: Restriction: Campuswide Honors Collegium students only.

BIO SCI 92.name: Curriculum
BIO SCI 92.description: Initiation, planning, and coordination of student-run courses.
BIO SCI 92.restriction: Restriction: School of Biological Sciences students only.

BIO SCI 93.name: From DNA to Organisms
BIO SCI 93.description: Cell biology, biochemistry, genetics, and the biology of organ systems. Covers concepts of building blocks (nucleotides, amino acids, and cells) and of information flow (DNA to proteins, receptors to nuclei, the blood to distant organs, and DNA to offspring).
BIO SCI 93.restriction: Restriction: BIO SCI 93 may not be taken for credit if taken after BIO SCI 97 or BIO SCI 98.

BIO SCI H93.name: Honors From DNA to Organisms
BIO SCI H93.description: Cell biology, biochemistry, genetics, and the biology or organ systems. Covers concepts of building blocks (nucleotides, amino acids, and cells) and of information flow (DNA to proteins, receptors to nuclei, the blood to distant organs, and DNA to offspring).
BIO SCI H93.restriction: Restriction: BIO SCI H93 may not be taken for credit if taken after BIO SCI 97 or BIO SCI 98.

BIO SCI 94.name: From Organisms to Ecosystems
BIO SCI 94.description: Patterns of diversity, ecology, and evolutionary biology. Emphasis is on the Tree of Life and how its members are distributed and interact.
BIO SCI 94.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI 93 or BIO SCI H93
BIO SCI 94.restriction: Restriction: BIO SCI 1A may not be taken for credit if taken after BIO SCI 94.

BIO SCI H94.name: Honors From Organisms to Ecosystems
BIO SCI H94.description: Patterns of diversity, ecology, and evolutionary biology. Emphasis is on the Tree of Life and how its members are distributed and interact.
BIO SCI H94.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI 93 or BIO SCI H93
BIO SCI H94.restriction: Restriction:  BIO SCI 1A may not be taken for credit if taken after BIO SCI H94.

BIO SCI 97.name: Genetics
BIO SCI 97.description: Introduction to genetics. Basic features of replication and expression of DNA, cell division, and gene transmission. Recombination and mutation in diploid organisms.
BIO SCI 97.restriction: Restriction: Pharmaceutical Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Public Health Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Nursing Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Biomedical Engr: Premedical Majors have first consideration for enrollment. School of Biological Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment.

BIO SCI H97.name: Honors Genetics
BIO SCI H97.description: Introduction to genetics. Basic features of replication and expression of DNA, cell division, and gene transmission. Recombination and mutation in diploid organisms.
BIO SCI H97.restriction: Restriction: Campuswide Honors Collegium students only. BIO SCI H97 may not be taken for credit if taken after BIO SCI 97.

BIO SCI 98.name: Biochemistry
BIO SCI 98.restriction: Restriction: School of Biological Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. Biomedical Engr: Premedical Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Nursing Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Pharmaceutical Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Public Health Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

BIO SCI 99.name: Molecular Biology
BIO SCI 99.description: Biochemistry and replication of nucleic acids
BIO SCI 99.restriction: Restriction: Pharmaceutical Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Public Health Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Nursing Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Biomedical Engr: Premedical Majors have first consideration for enrollment. School of Biological Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment.

BIO SCI 100.name: Scientific Writing
BIO SCI 100.description: Designed to give an overview of the basic aspects of scientific writing relevant to reporting research in the Biological Sciences.
BIO SCI 100.restriction: Restriction: School of Biological Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. Bio Sci and Educ Media Design Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Biomedical Engr: Premedical Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Pharmaceutical Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

BIO SCI 101.name: California Teach 2: Middle School Science and Mathematics Teaching
BIO SCI 101.description: Second in a series for students interested in becoming middle or high school teachers of mathematics or science. Students gain an understanding of effective, research-based teaching strategies for grades 6-8. Includes supervised field experience in a middle school classroom.
BIO SCI 101.restriction: Restriction: School of Physical Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Biological Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Engineering students have first consideration for enrollment.

BIO SCI D103.name: Cell Biology
BIO SCI D103.description: Analysis of the basic structure and function of animal cells, with an emphasis on the regulation of cellular processes. The basic features of membranes, cellular compartmentalization, protein trafficking, vesicular transport, cytoskeleton, adhesion, signal transduction, and cell cycle are covered.
BIO SCI D103.restriction: Restriction: Students who require this class for completion of their degree have first consideration for enrollment.

BIO SCI D104.name: Developmental Biology
BIO SCI D104.description: Cellular and molecular analysis of how a fertilized egg develops into an organism consisting of complex structures such as the eye, arms, and brain. Emphasis is on the key concepts of developmental processes underlying pattern formation, growth, and regeneration.
BIO SCI D104.restriction: Restriction: Students who require this class for completion of their degree have first consideration for enrollment.

BIO SCI D105.name: Cell, Developmental, and Molecular Biology of Plants
BIO SCI D105.description: Emphasizes the special features of plant cells and plant development as compared to animals. Two central topics: plants' ability to fuel our planet through photosynthesis, and the interactions of plants with microorganisms in making nitrogen available to other life forms.
BIO SCI D105.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI 97 or BIO SCI H97
BIO SCI D105.restriction: Restriction: Students who require this class for completion of their degree have first consideration for enrollment.

BIO SCI E106.name: Processes in Ecology and Evolution
BIO SCI E106.description: An in-depth study of the mechanisms that drive evolution and ecology including: natural selection, mutation, genetic drift, speciation, extinction, life history patterns, population dynamics, ecosystem and community structure, predator-prey and host pathogen interactions, and social behavior.
BIO SCI E106.restriction: Restriction: Students who require this class for completion of their degree have first consideration for enrollment.

BIO SCI E106L.name: Habitats and Organisms
BIO SCI E106L.description: Introduces students to local habitats and organisms through required field trips and applies ecological and evolutionary principles from BIO SCI E106. Students also explore related literature.
BIO SCI E106L.prereqString: Prerequisite: (BIO SCI 100 or BIO SCI 108) and BIO SCI E106. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
BIO SCI E106L.restriction: Restriction: Seniors only. BIO SCI E106L may not be taken for credit concurrently with or after taking BIO SCI E166. Students who require this lab for completion of their degree have first consideration for enrollment.

BIO SCI E107.name: Seminar in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology
BIO SCI E107.description: Invited speakers, graduate students, and faculty present current research in ecology and evolutionary biology.
BIO SCI E107.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. Ecology and Evolutionary Biol Majors only.

BIO SCI 108.name: Research Methods
BIO SCI 108.description: Explores tools of inquiry for developing and implementing science research projects.  Students undertake independent projects requiring data collection, analysis, and modeling, and the organization and presentation of results.  Additional topics include ethical issues and role of scientific literature.
BIO SCI 108.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI 14 or PHY SCI 5

BIO SCI E109.name: Human Physiology
BIO SCI E109.description: Functional features of the major organ systems in the human body. Emphasis on homeostasis and the interactions of organ systems in health and disease. (Discussion of behavior and brain function deferred to BIO SCI N110.).
BIO SCI E109.prereqString: Prerequisite: (BIO SCI 93 or BIO SCI H93) and CHEM 1C
BIO SCI E109.restriction: Restriction: Students who require this class for completion of their degree have first consideration for enrollment.

BIO SCI N110.name: Neurobiology and Behavior
BIO SCI N110.description: Consideration of the evolution of behavior, including ethological and psychological aspects and analysis of neuroanatomical, neurochemical, neurophysiological, and neuroendocrine systems underlying basic behavioral processes.
BIO SCI N110.restriction: Restriction: Students who require this class for completion of their degree have first consideration for enrollment.

BIO SCI D111L.name: Developmental and Cell Biology Laboratory
BIO SCI D111L.description: Covers the division of cells, isolate cellular organelles (chloroplasts, mitochondria, nuclei), and follows changes in cells undergoing programmed cell death. Development is demonstrated in experiments showing cooperation of individual cells in forming a multicellular organism.  Materials fee.
BIO SCI D111L.restriction: Restriction: Seniors only. Students who require this lab for completion of their degree have first consideration for enrollment.

BIO SCI E112L.name: Physiology Laboratory
BIO SCI E112L.description: Laboratory with a focus on the whole organism and its organ systems. Examples of structure-function relationships are drawn from both animal and human physiology. Cellular and molecular aspects are introduced as required.  Materials fee.
BIO SCI E112L.prereqString: Prerequisite: (BIO SCI 100 or BIO SCI 108) and (BIO SCI E109 or BME 120) and BME 121.
BIO SCI E112L.restriction: Restriction: Seniors only. Students who require this lab for completion of their degree have first consideration for enrollment.

BIO SCI D113.name: Genetics Majors Seminar
BIO SCI D113.description: Genetics majors attend a weekly seminar to discuss current research techniques and career opportunities in the field. Students have the opportunity to present their own independent research.

BIO SCI N113L.name: Neurobiology Laboratory
BIO SCI N113L.description: An in-depth exploration into biology and physiology of the nervous system. Labs include neuroanatomy, electrophysiology, pharmacology, behavior, experimental design, EEG, and scientific writing.  Materials fee.
BIO SCI N113L.restriction: Restriction: Seniors only. Students who require this lab for completion of their degree have first consideration for enrollment.

BIO SCI D114.name: Developmental and Cell Biology Majors Seminar
BIO SCI D114.description: Developmental and Cell Biology majors attend a weekly seminar to discuss current research techniques and career opportunities in the field. Students have the opportunity to present their own independent research.
BIO SCI D114.restriction: Restriction: Developmental and Cell Biology Majors only.

BIO SCI M114.name: Advanced Biochemistry
BIO SCI M114.description: Physical-chemical properties of macromolecules. Structure-function relationships in nucleic acids, protein, carbohydrates, and lipids. Integration and regulation of metabolism. Biochemistry of organs and biochemistry of diseases.

BIO SCI M114L.name: Biochemistry Laboratory
BIO SCI M114L.description: Properties of enzymes and the culture and isolation of mutants of microorganisms. Materials fee.
BIO SCI M114L.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI 99 and (BIO SCI 100 or BIO SCI 108)
BIO SCI M114L.restriction: Restriction: Seniors only. Students who require this lab for completion of their degree have first consideration for enrollment.

BIO SCI E115L.name: Evolution Laboratory
BIO SCI E115L.description: Students perform experiments which illustrate important concepts in evolutionary biology such as natural selection, random genetic drift, inbreeding, age-specific selection, sexual selection, and phylogenetic reconstruction. Materials fee.
BIO SCI E115L.prereqString: Prerequisite: (BIO SCI 100 or BIO SCI 108) and BIO SCI E106. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
BIO SCI E115L.restriction: Restriction: Seniors only. Students who require this lab for completion of their degree have first consideration for enrollment.

BIO SCI N115A.name: Advanced Neurobiology I
BIO SCI N115A.description: In-depth coverage of neurobiology, ranging from molecular neurobiology to functional brain imaging. Discussion of molecular, cellular, and developmental neurobiology.

BIO SCI N115B.name: Advanced Neurobiology II
BIO SCI N115B.description: In-depth coverage of neurobiology, ranging from molecular neurobiology to functional brain imaging.

BIO SCI M116.name: Advanced Molecular Biology
BIO SCI M116.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI 99 and (BIO SCI M114L or BIO SCI M116L)

BIO SCI M116L.name: Molecular Biology Laboratory
BIO SCI M116L.description: Students perform experiments which illustrate the chemical and biological properties of nucleic acids. Emphasis is placed on recent techniques in recombinant DNA technology including gene isolation and characterization.  Materials fee.
BIO SCI M116L.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI 99 and (BIO SCI 100 or BIO SCI 108)
BIO SCI M116L.restriction: Restriction: Seniors only. Students who require this lab for completion of their degree have first consideration for enrollment.

BIO SCI E117A.name: Exercise Sciences Seminar
BIO SCI E117A.description: Students are introduced to fundamental concepts and topics in exercise sciences with an emphasis on developing innovative approaches for exploring the biological response to physical activity/inactivity. Interactive course with robust discussion amongst faculty and students.
BIO SCI E117A.prereqString: Prerequisite: (BIO SCI E109 or PHRMSCI 120) and BIO SCI E112L and BIO SCI E183

BIO SCI E117B.name: Exercise Sciences Seminar
BIO SCI E117B.description: Students are introduced to fundamental concepts and topics in exercise sciences with an emphasis on developing innovative approaches for exploring the biological response to physical activity/inactivity. Interactive course with robust discussion amongst faculty and students.
BIO SCI E117B.prereqString: Prerequisite: (BIO SCI E109 or PHRMSCI 120) and BIO SCI E112L and BIO SCI E183

BIO SCI E117C.name: Exercise Sciences Seminar
BIO SCI E117C.description: Students are introduced to fundamental concepts and topics in exercise sciences with an emphasis on developing innovative approaches for exploring the biological response to physical activity/inactivity. Interactive course with robust discussion amongst faculty and students.
BIO SCI E117C.prereqString: Prerequisite: (BIO SCI E109 or PHRMSCI 120) and BIO SCI E112L and BIO SCI E183

BIO SCI N117.name: Introduction to Neuroscience Clinical Trials
BIO SCI N117.description: Provides an overview of the science of clinical development of treatments for neurological disease and injury.

BIO SCI E118.name: Ecosystem Ecology
BIO SCI E118.description: A mechanistic perspective on ecosystem processes. Covers ecosystem development, element cycling, and interactions with plants and microbes. The role of ecosystems in environmental change is also addressed.
BIO SCI E118.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI E106 or EARTHSS 51 or EARTHSS 60A or CHEM 51C
BIO SCI E118.restriction: Restriction: Earth System Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Ecology and Evolutionary Biol Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

BIO SCI M118L.name: Experimental Microbiology Laboratory
