BIO SCI M118L.description: Introductory general microbiology designed for preprofessional biology majors. Includes microscopy, cultivation of bacteria, morphological and biochemical characterization of bacteria, microbial metabolism, growth and genetics, microorganisms and human disease, and interactions of microorganisms with the environment.  Materials fee.
BIO SCI M118L.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI 99 and (BIO SCI 100 or BIO SCI 108)
BIO SCI M118L.restriction: Restriction: Seniors only. Students who require this lab for completion of their degree have first consideration for enrollment.

BIO SCI N118.name: Clinical Psychophysiology
BIO SCI N118.description: Psychophysiology investigates the relationships between physiological processes and psychological phenomena. Technologies examined include reaction times, heart rate variability, EEGs, ERPs, magnetoencephalography, and eye tracking. Applications include diagnosis, the longitudinal assessment, and the identification of individuals at risk of disease onset.
BIO SCI N118.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI N110 or BIO SCI N115A or PSYCH 9A or PSCI 11A

BIO SCI E119.name: Selfish DNA
BIO SCI E119.description: Focuses on the genetics and evolution of selfish DNA, and introduces necessary background knowledge from molecular biology, cytogenetics, and bioinformatics.
BIO SCI E119.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI 94 or BIO SCI 97

BIO SCI M119.name: Advanced Topics in Immunology
BIO SCI M119.description: Literature-based, interactive discussions focused on review of seminal historic and recent immunology literature. Student responsibilities include reading, critical evaluation, and discussion of manuscripts.
BIO SCI M119.restriction: Restriction: Microbiology and Immunology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

BIO SCI N119.name: History of Neuroscience
BIO SCI N119.description: An overview of the conceptual and technical foundations of contemporary neuroscience from ancient times to the present. The subjects include synapses, neurons, brain organization, sensory, motor and regulatory systems, learning and memory, human brain function and dysfunction.
BIO SCI N119.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI 35 or BIO SCI N110 or BIO SCI N115A or PSY BEH 115D or (PSYCH 9A and PSYCH 9B and PSYCH 9C)

BIO SCI E120.name: Marine Biology
BIO SCI E120.description: Examines the biotic and abiotic factors influencing the physiology, distribution, abundances, interactions, and evolution of marine organisms and the roles of those organisms in mediating ecosystem services and functions. A field trip is required. Materials fee.

BIO SCI M120.name: Signal Transduction in Mammalian Cells
BIO SCI M120.description: Introduction to major biochemical pathways that transmit information from extracellular cues into changes in cell behavior. Focuses on kinases, phosphateses, G proteins, second messengers, and protein-protein interactions. Includes discussion of primary research articles and experimental techniques.

BIO SCI N120A.name: Human Biology I
BIO SCI N120A.description: Provides an in-depth look at cutting-edge topics in physiology and epidemiology as they relate to global issues of ethics, anthropology, and socioeconomics, providing the student with an understanding of human health beyond basic biological function.

BIO SCI N120B.name: Human Biology II
BIO SCI N120B.description: Provides an in-depth look at cutting-edge topics in physiology and epidemiology as they relate to global issues of ethics, anthropology, and socioeconomics, providing the student with an understanding of human health beyond basic biological function.

BIO SCI N120C.name: Human Biology III
BIO SCI N120C.description: Provides an in-depth look at cutting-edge topics in physiology and epidemiology as they relate to global issues of ethics, anthropology, and socioeconomics, providing the student with an understanding of human health beyond basic biological function.

BIO SCI M121.name: Immunology with Hematology
BIO SCI M121.description: Antibodies, antigens, antigen-antibody reactions, cells and tissues of lymphoreticular and hematopoietic systems, and individual and collective components of cell-mediated and humoral immune response.

BIO SCI M121L.name: Advanced Immunology Laboratory
BIO SCI M121L.description: Emphasis is placed on learning modern techniques in immunology such as ELISAs, western blotting, and immunofluorescent staining assays.   Materials fee.
BIO SCI M121L.prereqString: Prerequisite: (BIO SCI 100 or BIO SCI 108) and BIO SCI M116L and BIO SCI M121
BIO SCI M121L.restriction: Restriction: Seniors only. Students who require this lab for completion of their degree have first consideration for enrollment.

BIO SCI N121.name: Drug Addiction
BIO SCI N121.description: Provides a comprehensive overview of topics in the addiction field, including drug pharmacology, models/approaches to investigate addiction, brain circuits, genetics, epigenetics, and the cellular and molecular biology of drug addiction.

BIO SCI E122.name: Physiology and Pathology of the Kidney
BIO SCI E122.description: Examines the structure, function, and pathology of the kidney. Topics include anatomy of the kidney, cellular function, urine formation, and disease states of the kidney.
BIO SCI E122.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI E109 or PHRMSCI 120

BIO SCI M122.name: General Microbiology
BIO SCI M122.description: Comparative metabolism of small molecules and cell structure and relationship to microbial classification. Macromolecule synthesis and regulation, sporulation, cell division, growth, and effect of antibiotics.

BIO SCI N122.name: Scientific Argumentation and Critical Thinking
BIO SCI N122.description: Explicitly teaches argument structure, deductive logic, inductive logic, and common fallacies in the biology context. Students identify assumptions and fallacies in faulty arguments and data figures and learn to compose sound arguments.
BIO SCI N122.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI 93. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

BIO SCI M123.name: Introduction to Computational Biology
BIO SCI M123.description: The use of theories and methods based on computer science, mathematics, and physics in molecular biology and biochemistry. Basics in biomolecular modeling. Analysis of sequence and structural data of biomolecules. Analysis of biomolecular functions.
BIO SCI M123.prereqString: Prerequisite: MATH 2D or MATH 3A or STATS 7 or STATS 8

BIO SCI N123L.name: Human Neuroimaging Lab
BIO SCI N123L.description: Hands-on laboratory course in human neuroimaging, with particular emphasis on using MRI to understand brain function and how it changes over the course of the lifespan and with disease.
BIO SCI N123L.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI 93 and (BIO SCI 100 or BIO SCI 108). Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
BIO SCI N123L.restriction: Restriction: Seniors only. Students who require this lab for completion of their degree have first consideration for enrollment.

BIO SCI D124.name: Biology of Integrative Medecine
BIO SCI D124.description: Presentation of biological principles and the latest clinical and basic research on complementary and alternative therapies (e.g., mind-body medicine, energy medicine, herbal medicine, acupuncture, manipulative therapies) and their integration with Western medicine. Lectures supplemented by demonstrations and hands-on learning sessions.

BIO SCI E124.name: Infectious Disease Dynamics
BIO SCI E124.description: Learn how the immune system interacts with infectious diseases, in particular with viral infections. An introduction to basic virology and immunology, it concentrates on the way in which the immune system is critical to the prevention of infections.

BIO SCI M124A.name: Virology
BIO SCI M124A.description: Replication of viruses in populations, animals, and the host cell. The effects of viral infection on populations, individuals, and specific molecular effects on the target cell. Role of viral infections in cancer and degenerative diseases.
BIO SCI M124A.restriction: Restriction: School of Biological Sciences students only.

BIO SCI M124B.name: Viral Pathogenesis and Immunity
BIO SCI M124B.description: The mechanisms of viral pathogenesis and of host resistance to viruses are explored in detail. HIV-1 and Influenza-A are used as examples. In each case, viral replication, cytopathic effects, immune response, and viral evasion are discussed.
BIO SCI M124B.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI M121 or BIO SCI M124A. Recommended: BIO SCI M122.

BIO SCI M125.name: Molecular Biology of Cancer
BIO SCI M125.description: Molecular mechanisms of carcinogenesis. Consideration of transformation by DNA tumor viruses, RNA tumor viruses, and chemical carcinogens.

BIO SCI M126.name: Learning to Read Primary Literature in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology
BIO SCI M126.description: An introduction to primary literature focusing on methods to approach, understand, and analyze scientific papers.

BIO SCI E127.name: Physiological Plant Ecology
BIO SCI E127.description: An examination of the interactions between plants and their environment. Emphasis on the underlying physiological mechanisms of plant function, adaptations and responses to stress, and the basis of the distribution of plants and plant assemblages across the landscape.
BIO SCI E127.prereqString: Prerequisite: EARTHSS 51 or BIO SCI 94 or (EARTHSS 60A and EARTHSS 60C)
BIO SCI E127.restriction: Restriction: Biological Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Earth System Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

BIO SCI N127.name: Foundations in Neuroimmunology
BIO SCI N127.description: The immune system supports normal brain development as well as controls central nervous system (CNS) infections and augments neurodegenerative and neurological diseases. Assesses how the immune system contributes to both host defense and disease.

BIO SCI E128.name: Chemical Ecology
BIO SCI E128.description: An introduction to the unspoken chemical language of nature. Emphasis on interactions between insects, plants, and microbes including plant defense, pollination, and microbial warfare.

BIO SCI N129.name: The Transparent Brain
BIO SCI N129.description: Teaches students how to perform new 3-D histology techniques that reveal the complex circuitry of the brain in unprecedented detail. Students work with real brain samples as part of ongoing neuroscience research projects. Materials fee.
BIO SCI N129.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI 93 or BIO SCI H93
BIO SCI N129.restriction: Restriction: Students who require this course for completion of their degree have first consideration for enrollment.

BIO SCI D130.name: Photomedicine
BIO SCI D130.description: Studies the use of optical and engineering-based systems (laser-based) for diagnosis, treating diseases, manipulation of cells and cell function. Physical, optical, and electro-optical principles are explored regarding molecular, cellular, organ, and organism applications.
BIO SCI D130.restriction: Restriction: Biomedical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

BIO SCI M130L.name: Advanced Molecular Lab Techniques
BIO SCI M130L.description: Discovery-driven experimentation in the fields of molecular biology, biochemistry, and cell biology. Also involves other aspects of the lab experience including group discussion of results, scientific paper analysis, and student presentations.   Materials fee.
BIO SCI M130L.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI 100 and (BIO SCI D111L or BIO SCI M114L or BIO SCI M116L or BIO SCI M118L)
BIO SCI M130L.restriction: Restriction: Students who require this lab for completion of their degree have first consideration for enrollment.

BIO SCI E131L.name: Image Analysis in Biological Research
BIO SCI E131L.description: Introduction to scientific image analysis including techniques such as high-speed, time-lapse, thermal imaging, and flow visualization. Students make movies using cameras, edit and analyze images using computers, and do a writing project.
BIO SCI E131L.prereqString: Prerequisite: (BIO SCI E106 or PHRMSCI 120 or BIO SCI E109) and (BIO SCI 100 or BIO SCI 108)

BIO SCI M131.name: Innate Immunity, Infection, and Pathogenesis
BIO SCI M131.description: Role of the innate immune system in health and disease. Molecular pathways of innate immune recognition, expression, and regulation of immune receptors, signal transduction, pathogen sensors, and detection of microbial ligands. Lecture and discussion of primary research articles.
BIO SCI M131.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI M121 or BIO SCI M122 or BIO SCI M124A or BIO SCI M124B or BIO SCI M143

BIO SCI N131.name: Human Neurodegenerative Diseases
BIO SCI N131.description: Clinical and epidemiological aspects of neurodegenerative diseases causing dementia are reviewed, including Alzheimer’s disease, Parkinson’s disease, Huntington’s disease, and Frontotemporal Dementia. Seminar format includes student presentation and group discussion.

BIO SCI D132.name: Introduction to Precision Medicine
BIO SCI D132.description: Introduction to the use of genomic techniques for the study of individual genomes and transcriptomes in healthy and diseased samples. Covers GWAS, current sequencing techniques, cancer genomics, and biomarker discovery.

BIO SCI D133.name: Advances in Regenerative Medicine
BIO SCI D133.description: Introduces the rapidly growing field of regenerative medicine. New developments in stem cell research are discussed. Cellular, molecular, and engineering aspects of stem cell-based organ replacement strategies are examined, with emphasis on specific regenerative therapies.
BIO SCI D133.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI D103 or BIO SCI D104

BIO SCI M133.name: Structural Biology
BIO SCI M133.description: Basic principles of magnetic resonance, X-ray crystallography, and CryoEM toward the determination of high-resolution biomolecular structures.

BIO SCI E134.name: Microbiomes
BIO SCI E134.description: Students develop an understanding of microbiomes in the context of both their environment and their impact on host physiology. Discussions on how microbiomes interact with the human body.

BIO SCI N134.name: Cognitive Neuroepigenetics
BIO SCI N134.description: Current topics in the emerging field of cognitive neuroepigenetics focusing on understanding the underlying epigenetic mechanisms of memory formation and persistence. Primary literature is used to explore these processes.
BIO SCI N134.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI N110 or BIO SCI N115A

BIO SCI D135.name: Cell Biology of Human Disease
BIO SCI D135.description: Builds on prior biology courses about the underlying cell biological mechanisms and recent treatment advances of several model diseases. Emphasizes literature searches, reading primary literature, and student group work.

BIO SCI D136.name: Human Anatomy
BIO SCI D136.description: Presents a systems approach to the analysis of human structure. Molecular, cellular, tissue, organ, and organ system levels of structure and organization are integrated throughout.

BIO SCI E136.name: The Physiology of Human Nutrition
BIO SCI E136.description: Examines the biochemical basis of energy metabolism, physiological processes in digestion and uptake, and the biochemical transformation of carbohydrates, fats, and proteins in the human body. The emphasis is on expanding the students' understanding of physiology.
BIO SCI E136.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI 98 and (BIO SCI E109 or PHRMSCI 120)

BIO SCI D137.name: Eukaryotic and Human Genetics
BIO SCI D137.description: Structure and function of genes in eukaryotes with emphasis on special problems of genetic studies in humans. Molecular methods of genetic analysis and gene transfer are discussed. Practical applications and ethical and social issues raised by genetic studies are addressed.
BIO SCI D137.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI 97 or BIO SCI H97

BIO SCI M137.name: Microbial Genetics
BIO SCI M137.description: Basic principles of microbial genetics are presented as lectures for the first half of the course. The second half is devoted to applications of these principles and requires reading review and original research papers and interactions with guest lecturers.

BIO SCI D138.name: Critical Thinking in Cell Biology
BIO SCI D138.description: Builds on prior biology courses about cell biology, and works to develop a deeper understanding of experimental techniques and interpretation of experiments. A key focus will be the question of how one moves from specific examples to general.

BIO SCI E138.name: Comparative Animal Physiology
BIO SCI E138.description: Maintenance aspects of physiology: water balance
BIO SCI E138.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI E109 or PHRMSCI 120

BIO SCI N138.name: Sex Differences in the Brain
BIO SCI N138.description: Explores the neural bases of sex influences on brain function.

BIO SCI D139.name: Intercellular Signaling and Disease
BIO SCI D139.description: Introduces cell-to-cell communication mechanisms, which are fundamentally essential but still not well understood. From well-established to cutting-edge, researches of intercellular communication and how its malfunction leads to diseases are discussed.
BIO SCI D139.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI D103 or BIO SCI D104

BIO SCI E139.name: Animal Locomotion
BIO SCI E139.description: The physiology, biomechanics, and neuroscience that determines how animals propel themselves and navigate through the world. Considers the principles that govern the walking, running, flying, and swimming of animals, including exercising humans.
BIO SCI E139.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI E109 or PHRMSCI 120

BIO SCI E140L.name: Evolution and the Environment Laboratory
BIO SCI E140L.description: Explores basic topics in ecology and evolutionary biology and applications to agriculture, conservation, environmental issues, and public health. Format involves lab activities and discussion of scientific journal articles, with focus on learning to evaluate scientific evidence.
BIO SCI E140L.restriction: Restriction: Seniors only. Students who require this lab for completion of their degree have first consideration for enrollment.

BIO SCI E142W.name: Writing/Philosophy of Biology
BIO SCI E142W.description: Philosophy of biology, e.g., scientific method in biology, the structure of evolutionary theory, teleology, ethics, and evolution. Course work includes one 4,000-word and four 1,000-word papers.
BIO SCI E142W.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

BIO SCI M143.name: Human Parasitology
BIO SCI M143.description: Introduction to human animal-parasitic diseases including worms and protozoan infections.

BIO SCI M144.name: Cell Organelles and Membranes
BIO SCI M144.description: Structure, function, and biogenesis of biological membranes and membrane-bound organelles.

BIO SCI D145.name: Genomics, Development, and Medicine
BIO SCI D145.description: Focuses on the applications of genomics and proteomics to problems in genetics, cell, and developmental biology.  Students will gain a comprehensive understanding of the techniques currently used for genomics analysis and how best to apply these tools to solve problems.

BIO SCI E145.name: Animal Coloration and Vision
BIO SCI E145.description: Physiological and behavioral mechanisms of color production and vision including crypsis, mimicry, aposematism, masquerade, sexual dimorphism, and predator-prey interactions through the lens of signals, receivers, and receptors

BIO SCI E146.name: Ecosystem Services
BIO SCI E146.description: Covers what ecosystem services are, how to classify them, what the impacts of land degradation are on ecosystem services, how to quantify and value them, and the importance of mainstreaming ecosystem services in decision-making.
BIO SCI E146.prereqString: Prerequisite: (EARTHSS 70A and EARTHSS 70B) or (EARTHSS 51 and EARTHSS 53 and EARTHSS 55)

BIO SCI E147.name: Behavioral Endocrinology
BIO SCI E147.description: Comparative examination of the major hormone systems that regulate behavior across animals. Emphasizes the reciprocating nature of hormone-behavior interactions and seeks to understand how natural selection drives the evolution of hormone structure and function.
BIO SCI E147.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI E109 or PHRMSCI 120

BIO SCI N147.name: Hearing and the Brain
BIO SCI N147.description: An overview of brain mechanisms of hearing, including perception of simple sounds, speech, and music. Begins with sound itself, and looks at processing by the ear, auditory pathways, auditory cortex, and beyond. Also auditory development, learning, and clinical issues.
BIO SCI N147.prereqString: Prerequisite: PSYCH 160A or BIO SCI 93 or BIO SCI H93
BIO SCI N147.restriction: Restriction: Cognitive Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Biological Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

BIO SCI D148.name: Development and Disease
BIO SCI D148.description: Development of animal embryos from a fertilized egg to a functioning organism. Topics include reproduction, body-axis formation, growth and differentiation of embryonic cells, and organogenesis, with an emphasis on congenital birth defects and diseases that disrupt these processes.
BIO SCI D148.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI D103 or BIO SCI D104

BIO SCI E150.name: Conservation Biology
BIO SCI E150.description: Genetic and ecological issues in conservation biology, including effects of human population growth, the value of biodiversity, conservation genetics, demography, metapopulation dynamics, community and ecosystem processes, species invasions, global climate change, and reserve design and management.

BIO SCI N150.name: Brain Dysfunction and Repair
BIO SCI N150.description: Introduction to the disruptions in brain function that underlie disorders such as Alzheimer's disease, Parkinsonism, schizophrenia, and depression, and the basis for drug therapies. The brain's ability to repair itself after damage and the pros and cons of that repair.
BIO SCI N150.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI N110 or BIO SCI N115A

BIO SCI E151.name: Evolutionary and Ecological Principles in Medicine
BIO SCI E151.description: Explore the dynamics of populations on an ecological, epidemiological, and medical level. Considers the dynamics of competition, predation, and parasitism
BIO SCI E151.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI 93 or BIO SCI H93

BIO SCI N151.name: Neurobiology of Aging
BIO SCI N151.description: Multidisciplinary overview of the functional capacity of the aging brain, its structural changes and the mechanisms underlying function and structure. Emphasis is on successful brain aging and those mechanisms which lead to the development of Alzheimer's disease.
BIO SCI N151.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI N110 or BIO SCI N115A

BIO SCI N152.name: Developmental Neurobiology
BIO SCI N152.description: The development of the nervous system is discussed with emphasis on the processes that underlie the appearance of complex and highly ordered neural circuits. Topics include neural induction, specification, migration and death
BIO SCI N152.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI 93 or BIO SCI H93

BIO SCI E153.name: Functional and Structural Evolutionary Genomics
BIO SCI E153.description: Function and organization of genomes analyzed from an evolutionary perspective. Review of some of the most recent experimental approaches in genome analysis and comparative genomics. Relevant software to analyze DNA and expression data is used.
BIO SCI E153.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI 97 or BIO SCI H97

BIO SCI N153.name: Neuropharmacology
BIO SCI N153.description: Survey of neurotransmitter systems, focusing on how transmitters are made, how they interact with their receptors, and how drugs can influence these processes to alter neural function and behavior.
BIO SCI N153.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI N110 or BIO SCI N115A

BIO SCI E154.name: Genetics and Human History
BIO SCI E154.description: Explores topics in human health/history from an evolutionary perspective, with emphasis on genetics. Topics include the relationship between genetics and human disease as an evolutionary question, and how modern genetic techniques are used to study the history of human populations.

BIO SCI N154.name: Molecular Neurobiology
BIO SCI N154.description: Provides a fundamental understanding of how the brain works at the molecular level. Topics include nature and actions of molecules that regulate the functioning of the brain and cellular mechanisms underlying learning and memory.

BIO SCI E155.name: Physiology in Extreme Environments
BIO SCI E155.description: An in-depth look at the physiological mechanisms that allow animals, including humans, to be physically active and survive in extreme environments. Physiological responses to high altitude, diving, microgravity, deserts, and extreme cold are examined.

BIO SCI N155.name: Wiring the Developing Brain
BIO SCI N155.description: The development of the nervous system is discussed with particular emphasis on the processes that underlie the appearance of complex and highly ordered neural circuits. Basic neurodevelopmental processes are discussed and correlated with normal brain function/dysfunction.
BIO SCI N155.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI N110 or BIO SCI N115A or BIO SCI N152

BIO SCI N156.name: Molecular Mechanisms of Memory
BIO SCI N156.description: Current topics focused on understanding the molecular mechanisms that contribute to synaptic plasticity, learning, and memory. Primary literature is used to explore the variety of molecular mechanisms underlying these processes.

BIO SCI N158.name: Neurobiology of Learning and Memory
BIO SCI N158.description: How the brain and behavior change as a result of experience, with an emphasis on identifying the neurochemical processes through which memory is stored and the parts of the brain that are involved.
BIO SCI N158.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI 35 or BIO SCI N110 or BIO SCI N115A

BIO SCI N159.name: Animal Behavior
BIO SCI N159.description: Explores why animals behave the way they do from evolutionary/mechanistic perspectives. Considers selective pressures and evolutionary constraints that shape animal behavior and the underlying neural and hormonal mechanisms by using examples such as why dogs bark, why some birds migrate.
BIO SCI N159.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI N110 or BIO SCI N115A

BIO SCI E160.name: Biology of Birds
BIO SCI E160.description: A thorough introduction to the biology of birds, covering topics ranging from avian anatomy and physiology to behavior, natural history, ecology, genetics, evolution, systematics, and conservation. Examples from both local and global avifauna.
BIO SCI E160.prereqString:
Corequisite: BIO SCI E160L
Prerequisite: BIO SCI 94

BIO SCI E160L.name: Biology of Birds Lab
BIO SCI E160L.description: The companion to Biology of Birds (E160). Consists primarily of field trips to identify local birds and study avian natural history. Students must provide their own transportation to field sites, some with entrance fees. Students must have field binoculars.
BIO SCI E160L.prereqString:
Corequisite: BIO SCI E160
Prerequisite: (BIO SCI 100 or BIO SCI 108)
BIO SCI E160L.restriction: Restriction: Seniors only. Students who require this lab for completion of their degree have first consideration for enrollment.

BIO SCI M160.name: Structure-Function Relationships of Integral Membrane Proteins
BIO SCI M160.description: Integral membrane proteins such as voltage and ligand-gated ion channels, water channels, pumps, cotransporters, and receptors (e.g., GPCRs). The emphasis is on the relationship between atomic structure and the functional properties of these proteins.
BIO SCI M160.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI 98 and BIO SCI 99. BIO SCI 98 with a grade of B or better. BIO SCI 99 with a grade of B or better

BIO SCI N160.name: Language and the Brain
BIO SCI N160.description: Research analysis on biological bases of human linguistic capacity. Development, focusing on hemispheric specialization, plasticity
BIO SCI N160.prereqString: Prerequisite: (PSYCH 7A or PSY BEH 9 or PSYCH 9A or PSY BEH 11A) and (PSYCH 9B or PSY BEH 11B or BIO SCI 35 or BIO SCI N110 or BIO SCI N115A)
BIO SCI N160.restriction: Restriction: Cognitive Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Biological Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

BIO SCI N164.name: Functional Neuroanatomy
BIO SCI N164.description: How neuroscience uses tools of many disciplines, from imaging to behavior, to develop and test hypotheses about functions of specific parts of the brain. Basic organization of nerve cells/vertebrate nervous system

BIO SCI N165.name: Brain Disorders and Behavior
BIO SCI N165.description: Examines the localization of human brain functions and the effects of neurological disorders on psychological functions such as perception, motor control, language, memory, and decision-making.
BIO SCI N165.prereqString: Prerequisite: (PSYCH 7A or PSY BEH 9) ( or (PSYCH 9A or PSY BEH 11A) and (PSYCH 9B or PSY BEH 11B)) or BIO SCI 35 or BIO SCI N110 or BIO SCI N115A
BIO SCI N165.restriction: Restriction: Cognitive Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Biological Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

BIO SCI E166L.name: Field Biology
BIO SCI E166L.description: Conducting group and independent studies in Southern California ecosystems, this course covers the fundamentals of experimental design, statistical analysis, communicating scientific findings (orally, visually, in writing), and other skills necessary for the scientific investigation of biological processes in the field.  Materials fee.
BIO SCI E166L.prereqString: Prerequisite: (BIO SCI 100 or BIO SCI 108) and BIO SCI E106. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

BIO SCI E168.name: Evolution
BIO SCI E168.description: An integrative treatment of evolutionary biology that covers evolutionary processes, basic research methods, and the history of life.

BIO SCI D170.name: Applied Human Anatomy
BIO SCI D170.description: Systems approach to analyze the form and function of the human body with an emphasis on applying anatomical concepts to evaluate clinical cases. The laboratory uses human models and a simulated cadaver dissection for structure. Materials fee.
BIO SCI D170.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI E109 or PHRMSCI 120. BIO SCI E109 with a grade of C or better. PHRMSCI 120 with a grade of C or better

BIO SCI N170.name: Clinical Neuroscience
BIO SCI N170.description: An introduction to the neuroclinical bases of human behavior, including neuropsychological approaches to mental disorders. Also includes case formulations, research articles, therapeutic approaches, and other discussions related to select psychopathology and other neurobehavioral topics.
BIO SCI N170.prereqString: Prerequisite: PSCI 9 or PSYCH 7A or PSCI 11A or PSYCH 9A or BIO SCI 99
BIO SCI N170.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Biological Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

BIO SCI E172.name: Plant Diversity in a Changing World
BIO SCI E172.description: Investigation of planet diversity in California and throughout the world, including basic systematic concepts, an introduction to major groups of flowering plants, and the effects of global biological change on plant diversity.

BIO SCI N172.name: Regenerative Neurobiology
BIO SCI N172.description: Explores the field of regenerative neurobiology. Both basic stem cell discoveries and their potential clinical application to brain disorders examined. Opportunities, challenges, and implications of this research also discussed.
BIO SCI N172.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI N110 or BIO SCI N115A

BIO SCI N173.name: Human  Neuropsychology
BIO SCI N173.description: A survey of human brain disorders using a clinical case study approach to illustrate fundamental issues in studying brain and behavior. Topics include sensory deficits, attentional neglect, amnesia, cortical organization, clinical psychopathology, and more.
BIO SCI N173.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI N110 or BIO SCI N115A or PSYCH 9A or PSCI 11A
BIO SCI N173.restriction: Restriction: School of Biological Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. Cognitive Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

BIO SCI N174.name: Principles of Neural Computation
BIO SCI N174.description: Introduction to the theoretical principles and biological mechanisms underlying how brains acquire, assimilate, store, and retrieve information, and how they compute adaptive responses to external inputs.
BIO SCI N174.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI N110 or BIO SCI N115A

BIO SCI N176.name: Cerebral Cortex: Structure, Function, and Plasticity
BIO SCI N176.description: The cerebral cortex is highly developed in mammals and is responsible for higher perceptual and cognitive functions. Explores some amazing aspects of cortical structure, function, and plasticity emphasizing primary literature.
BIO SCI N176.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI N110 or BIO SCI N115A

BIO SCI E179.name: Limnology and Freshwater Biology
BIO SCI E179.description: Biology of freshwater environments: lakes, ponds, rivers, their biota, and the factors which influence distribution of organisms.
BIO SCI E179.prereqString:
Corequisite: BIO SCI E179L
Prerequisite: BIO SCI 94

BIO SCI E179L.name: Field Freshwater Ecology
BIO SCI E179L.description: Analytical techniques for common water-quality variables of lakes, streams, and rivers. Benthic fauna, vertebrates and invertebrates, algae, and aquatic plants. Emphasis on field methods with an experimental approach
BIO SCI E179L.restriction: Restriction: Seniors only. Students who require this lab for completion of their degree have first consideration for enrollment.

BIO SCI M180.name: Biotechnological Applications of  Energy and Environmental Research
BIO SCI M180.description: Covers microbiological and biochemical background related to current biotechnological applications, case studies of biotech-companies, and basic information related to patents and start-up companies. Topics include biofuel, bioremediation, agricultural, and environmental applications.

BIO SCI E182.name: Mediterranean Ecosystems: Biodiversity and Conservation
BIO SCI E182.description: Biodiversity, history of human impacts, and conservation efforts are examined in the five Mediterranean-type ecosystems. Remaining natural habitat, approaches to ecological habitat restoration, control of exotic species, and predicted consequences of global climate change are described. Field trip required.

BIO SCI N182.name: Vision
BIO SCI N182.description: Visual perception and the anatomy and physiology of the visual system. Topics include the retina and the visual pathway
BIO SCI N182.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Cognitive Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. School of Biological Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment.

BIO SCI E183.name: Exercise Physiology
BIO SCI E183.description: Focus upon critical topics in the area of exercise biology using the comparative physiological approach. Specifically examine the physiological factors that limit the capacity of an organism to sustain high levels of aerobic metabolism.
BIO SCI E183.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI 98 and (BIO SCI E109 or PHRMSCI 120)

BIO SCI E184.name: Ecology and Diversity of Insects
BIO SCI E184.description: Insects—representing two-thirds of all species—play fundamental roles in human health, agriculture, and natural ecosystems. Topics include insect morphology, development, physiology, taxonomy, ecology, and insects in human affairs. Lecture includes interactive demonstrations and an optional weekend trip.  Materials fee.

BIO SCI E186.name: Population and Community Ecology
BIO SCI E186.description: Population structure, function, development, and evolution. Topics include population structure, population growth and regulation, metapopulations, predation, competition, species diversity, ecosystem function, macroecology, and island biogeography. Offered every other Winter.

BIO SCI E186L.name: Population and Community Ecology Lab
BIO SCI E186L.description: Covers processes specific to groups of the same species (populations) and multiple species (communities). Includes growth, regulation, dynamics, and persistence of populations and community interactions, development, diversity, and macroecology. Lab activities focus on application of population prediction and biodiversity assessment.
BIO SCI E186L.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI E106 and (BIO SCI 100 or BIO SCI 108). Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

BIO SCI E187.name: Exercise as Medicine
BIO SCI E187.description: Explores the link between regular physical activity and health, focusing on mechanistic insights into how regular exercise improves overall health and alters disease trajectories of cancer, type-II diabetes, depression, and other chronic  illnesses.
BIO SCI E187.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI E109 or PHRMSCI 120

BIO SCI E188.name: Introduction to Insect Physiology
BIO SCI E188.description: Physiology of insects. Insect respiration, digestion, excretion, and neurobiology, including sensory systems and effectors.
BIO SCI E188.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI E109 or PHRMSCI 120

BIO SCI E189.name: Environmental Ethics
BIO SCI E189.description: History of evolution of environmental ethics in America. Management problems in national parks, wilderness areas, wild and scenic rivers, national forests. Contemporary and historical aspects/contributors to the field. Mitigation, endangered species, habitat restoration, biodiversity, and environmental activism. Field trips required.

BIO SCI 190.name: Transfer Student Seminar
BIO SCI 190.description: Weekly meetings consisting of presentations by faculty, professional staff, and New Student Peer Academic Advisors provide information about the School of Biological Sciences, campus resources, and special programs/opportunities.

BIO SCI D190.name: Topics in Developmental and Cell Biology
BIO SCI D190.description: Studies in selected areas of developmental and cell biology.
BIO SCI D190.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. School of Biological Sciences students only.

BIO SCI E190.name: Topics in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology
BIO SCI E190.description: Studies in selected areas of ecology and evolutionary biology.

BIO SCI M190.name: Topics in Molecular Biology and Biochemistry
BIO SCI M190.description: Studies in selected areas of Molecular Biology and Biochemistry.

BIO SCI N190.name: Topics in Neurobiology and Behavior
BIO SCI N190.description: Studies in selected areas of neurobiology and behavior.
BIO SCI N190.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI N110 or BIO SCI N115A

BIO SCI 191A.name: Senior Seminar on Global Sustainability I
BIO SCI 191A.description: Students attend weekly seminar to discuss current issues in global sustainability. Weekly attendance at Global Sustainability Forum is also required. Seminar utilized to analyze forum presentations.  Prepare bibliography.
BIO SCI 191A.restriction: Restriction: Seniors only. Global Sustainability Minors have first consideration for enrollment.

BIO SCI 191B.name: Senior Seminar on Global Sustainability II
BIO SCI 191B.description: Students attend weekly seminar to discuss current issues in global sustainability. Weekly attendance at Global Sustainability Forum is also required. Seminar utilized to analyze forum presentations.  Prepare research proposal.
BIO SCI 191B.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI 191A or SOCECOL 186A or EARTHSS 190A

BIO SCI 191CW.name: Writing/Senior Seminar on Global Sustainability III
BIO SCI 191CW.description: Students attend weekly seminar to discuss current issues in global sustainability.  Weekly attendance at Global Sustainability Forum also is required.  Seminar utilized to analyze Forum presentations and to prepare senior research paper.  Prepare/write research paper under direction of faculty member.
BIO SCI 191CW.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI 191B or EARTHSS 190B or SOCECOL 186B. BIO SCI 191B or EARTHSS 190B or SOCECOL 186B. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

BIO SCI 192.name: Topics in Biological Sciences Tutoring
BIO SCI 192.description: Tutoring programs with biological sciences student peers.
BIO SCI 192.restriction: Restriction: Students tutoring under School of Biological Sciences programs only.

BIO SCI 193A.name: Campus as a Living Lab I
BIO SCI 193A.description: Students study sustainability concepts and theories and how they apply to our most pressing environmental, social, and economic challenges. Concurrently, they work on hands-on projects to improve the sustainability of campus operations and systems.

BIO SCI 193B.name: Campus as a Living Lab II
BIO SCI 193B.description: Students study sustainability concepts and theories and how they apply to our most pressing environmental, social, and economic challenges. Concurrently, they work on hands-on projects to improve the sustainability of campus operations and systems.

BIO SCI 193C.name: Campus as a Living Lab III
BIO SCI 193C.description: Students study sustainability concepts and theories and how they apply to our most pressing environmental, social, and economic challenges. Concurrently, they work on hands-on projects to improve the sustainability of campus operations and systems.

BIO SCI 194S.name: Safety and Ethics for Research
BIO SCI 194S.description: Introduces students to the concepts, techniques, and ethics involved in biological sciences laboratory work.

BIO SCI H195.name: Honors Topics in Biological Sciences
BIO SCI H195.description: Varied course topics in Biological Sciences designed for students in Honors in Biological Sciences.
BIO SCI H195.restriction: Restriction: Biological Sciences Honors students only.

BIO SCI 197.name: Special Study in Biological Sciences
BIO SCI 197.description: Individualized instruction dealing with conceptual or theoretical problems in the biological sciences, rather than technical problems.
BIO SCI 197.restriction: Restriction: Maximum of 5 units (per quarter) between BIO SCI 197, BIO SCI 198, and BIO SCI 199.

BIO SCI 198.name: Directed Group Studies
BIO SCI 198.description: Small group experimental laboratory or field work performed under the direction of a faculty member.

BIO SCI 199.name: Independent Study in Biological Sciences Research
BIO SCI 199.description: Individual experimental laboratory or field research under a professor's direction. Required for participation in the Excellence in Research Program.

BIO SCI 199W.name: Research Writing
BIO SCI 199W.description: Development of research skills such as learning how to plan and conduct research experiments, read and analyze scientific journal articles, and practice presenting the data experiments and journal articles with an emphasis on scientific writing.

BIO SCI 285.name: Topics in Allied Health Microbiology
BIO SCI 285.description: Basic microbiology with emphasis for allied health professions such as nursing. Emphasis is on micro-organisms involved in human health, disease and food safety.
BIO SCI 285.restriction: Restriction: Program in Nursing Science students only. Master of Nursing Degree students only.

BIOCHEM 200A.name: Research in Biological Chemistry
BIOCHEM 200A.description: Individual research under the supervision of a professor.

BIOCHEM 200B.name: Research in Biological Chemistry
BIOCHEM 200B.description: Individual research under the supervision of a professor.

BIOCHEM 200C.name: Research in Biological Chemistry
BIOCHEM 200C.description: Individual research under the supervision of a professor.

BIOCHEM 200R.name: Research in Biological Chemistry for First-Year Students
BIOCHEM 200R.description: Independent research within the laboratories of graduate training faculty in the Department of Biological Chemistry for first-year Ph.D. students.

BIOCHEM 202A.name: Laboratory Seminar Series
BIOCHEM 202A.description: Study within a laboratory group including research and journal presentations.

BIOCHEM 202B.name: Laboratory Seminar Series
BIOCHEM 202B.description: Study within a laboratory group including research and journal presentations.

BIOCHEM 202C.name: Laboratory Seminar Series
BIOCHEM 202C.description: Study within a laboratory group including research and journal presentations.

BIOCHEM 207.name: Current Topics in Cancer Genomics
BIOCHEM 207.description: Literature-based discussion of molecular principles in genetics and functional genomics, with focus on cancer and stem cell biology.

BIOCHEM 210A.name: Medical Biochemistry and Molecular Biology
BIOCHEM 210A.description: Covers the following topics from a biomedical perspective: protein and nucleic acid biochemistry, carbohydrates, lipids, amino acids, purines and pyrimidines, genome structure, molecular mechanisms of development, and signal transduction.

BIOCHEM 215.name: Mouse Developmental Genetics
BIOCHEM 215.description: Introduction to using the mouse in contemporary biomedical research. The biology and development of the laboratory mouse, methods for manipulation of the mouse genome and embryos, and examples of application of these methods to understand mammalian development and homeostasis.

BIOCHEM 217.name: Human Evolution and Behavior
BIOCHEM 217.description: Covers theories and empirical research concerning the evolutionary origins of human behaviors and their variations. An interdisciplinary course emphasizing both evolutionary psychology (e.g., mating strategies, kinship, and parenting) and molecular evolution (i.e., evolution of genes for various behaviors).

BIOCHEM 225.name: Epigenetics in Health and Disease
BIOCHEM 225.description: Focuses on the role of chromatin/nuclear structure organization (histone and DNA modification, chromatin remodeling, higher order chromatin structure and nuclear organization) on gene regulation, DNA replication and repair, relevant to development, metabolism, learning and memory, and human disease.
BIOCHEM 225.prereqString: Prerequisite: MOL BIO 203 or MOL BIO 204 or NEURBIO 206

BIOCHEM 291.name: Research Seminar
BIOCHEM 291.description: Student research-based colloquium covering current topics in gene organization and expression, cell cycle and differentiation, DNA repair, checkpoint control, and the physical, chemical, and biological properties of macromolecules. Students are encouraged to read critically and analyze recent literature.

BIOCHEM 292A.name: Scientific Communication
BIOCHEM 292A.description: Small group meetings for graduate students to practice scientific writing, debate, and presentation skills.

BIOCHEM 292B.name: Scientific Communication
BIOCHEM 292B.description: Small group meetings for graduate students to practice scientific writing, debate, and presentation skills.

BIOCHEM 292C.name: Scientific Communication
BIOCHEM 292C.description: Small group meetings for graduate students to practice scientific writing, debate, and presentation skills.

BME 1.name: Introduction to Biomedical Engineering
BME 1.description: Introduction to the central topics of biomedical engineering. Offers a perspective on bioengineering as a discipline in a seminar format. Principles of problem solving, design, engineering inventiveness, entrepreneurship, information access, communication, ethics, teamwork, and social responsibility are emphasized.
BME 1.restriction: Restriction: Biomedical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Biomedical Engr: Premedical Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

BME 3.name: Engineering Innovations in Treating Diabetes
BME 3.description: Innovations in diabetes treatment from the 1800s until the present: purification of insulin, measuring and control of blood glucose, recombinant DNA, clinical trials, and ethics. Solving optimization problems in engineering with Excel.

BME 50A.name: Cell and Molecular Engineering
BME 50A.description: Molecular, structural, genetic, biophysical, and cellular principles of life and bioengineering. Introduction to molecular bioengineering, genetic engineering, synthetic biology, and cell biology. Applications to genetic and biomolecular design.
BME 50A.restriction: Restriction: Biomedical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Chemical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Materials Science and Engr Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

BME 50B.name: Cell and Molecular Engineering
BME 50B.description: Physiological function from a cellular, molecular, and biophysical perspective. Introduction to genetics, neuronal signaling, and cell cycle control.
BME 50B.restriction: Restriction: Biomedical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Chemical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

BME 60A.name: Engineering Analysis/Design: Data Acquisition
BME 60A.description: Fundamentals of LabVIEW programming, basics of computer-based experimentation, establishing interface between computer and data acquisition instrumentation, signal conditioning basics. Materials fee.
BME 60A.restriction: Restriction: Biomedical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Biomedical Engr: Premedical Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

BME 60B.name: Engineering Analysis/Design: Data Analysis
BME 60B.restriction: Restriction: Biomedical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Biomedical Engr: Premedical Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

BME 60C.name: Engineering Analysis/Design: Computer-Aided Design
BME 60C.description: Introduction to SolidWorks and Computer-Aided Design software
BME 60C.restriction: Restriction: Biomedical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Biomedical Engr: Premedical Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

BME 110A.name: Biomechanics I
BME 110A.description: Introduction to statics and dynamics. Topics include rigid bodies, analysis of structures, forces in beams, moments of inertia, friction, kinetics, work, and energy.
BME 110A.prereqString: Prerequisite: PHYS 7C and MATH 3A and MATH 3D and BME 60B and BME 60C
BME 110A.restriction: Restriction: Biomedical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Biomedical Engr: Premedical Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Materials Science and Engr Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

BME 110B.name: Biomechanics II
BME 110B.description: Introduction to biomechanics from subcellular to tissue levels. Introduction to stress, strain, and constitutive laws of cells and tissues. Emphasis is placed on biosolids. Introduction to elastic and viscoelastic behaviors with emphasis on the standard linear model of viscoelasticity.
BME 110B.restriction: Restriction: Biomedical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Biomedical Engr: Premedical Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Materials Science and Engr Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

BME 110C.name: Biomechanics III
BME 110C.description: Introduction to human biomechanics with emphasis on cardiovascular biomechanics and biofluid mechanics.
BME 110C.restriction: Restriction: Biomedical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

BME 111.name: Design of Biomaterials
BME 111.description: Natural and synthetic polymeric materials. Metal and ceramics implant materials. Mechanical properties, degradation, surface characterization, and design of materials. Wound repair, blood clotting, foreign body response, biocompatibility of material. Artificial organs and medical devices. Government regulations.
BME 111.restriction: Restriction: Biomedical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Biomedical Engr: Premedical Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Materials Science and Engr Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

BME 114.name: Genetic Engineering and Synthetic Biology
BME 114.description: Exploring how biological function can be engineered and "synthesized" from the DNA level up.
BME 114.prereqString: Prerequisite: (CHEM 1C or CHEM H2C) and MATH 3D and BME 50A and BME 50B
BME 114.restriction: Restriction: Biomedical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

BME 120.name: Sensory Motor Systems
BME 120.description: A quantitative and systems approach to understanding physiological systems. Systems covered include the nervous and musculoskeletal systems.
BME 120.prereqString: Prerequisite: (BME 60B or EECS 10 or EECS 12 or CEE 20 or MAE 10) and MATH 3D and PHYS 7D
BME 120.restriction: Restriction: Biomedical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Biomedical Engr: Premedical Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Materials Science and Engr Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

BME 121.name: Quantitative Physiology:  Organ Transport Systems
BME 121.description: A quantitative and systems approach to understanding physiological systems. Systems covered include the cardiopulmonary, circulatory, and renal systems.
BME 121.prereqString: Prerequisite: (BME 60B or EECS 10 or EECS 12 or CEE 20 or MAE 10) and MATH 3D
BME 121.restriction: Restriction: Biomedical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Biomedical Engr: Premedical Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Chemical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

BME 130.name: Biomedical Signals and Systems
BME 130.description: Analysis of analog and digital biomedical signals
BME 130.restriction: Restriction: Biomedical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Biomedical Engr: Premedical Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

BME 132.name: Introduction to Computational Biology
BME 132.description: The use of theories and methods based on computer science, mathematics, and physics in molecular biology and biochemistry. Basics in biomolecular modeling. Analysis of sequence and structural data of biomolecules. Analysis of biomolecular functions.
BME 132.prereqString: Prerequisite: MATH 2D or MATH 3A or STAT 7 or STAT 8

BME 135.name: Photomedicine
BME 135.description: Studies the use of optical and engineering-based systems (laser-based) for diagnosis, treating diseases, manipulation of cells and cell function. Physical, optical, and electro-optical principles are explored regarding molecular, cellular, organ, and organism applications.
BME 135.restriction: Restriction: Biomedical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

BME 136.name: Engineering Medical Optics
BME 136.description: Principles of optics and photonics, integration of optical components into systems and devices, and analysis of physiological signals obtained from Biophotonics measurements.
BME 136.prereqString: Prerequisite: BME 130 and (BME 135 or BIOL D130)
BME 136.restriction: Restriction: Biomedical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

BME 137.name: Introduction to Biomedical Imaging
BME 137.description: Introduction to imaging modalities widely used in medicine and biology, including X-ray, computed tomography (CT), nuclear medicine (PET and SPET), ultrasonic imaging, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), optical tomography, imaging contrast, imaging processing, and complementary nature of the imaging modalities.
BME 137.prereqString: Prerequisite: BME 130 or EECS 50 or EECS 150
BME 137.restriction: Restriction: Biomedical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

BME 138.name: Spectroscopy and Imaging of Biological Systems
BME 138.prereqString: Prerequisite: (MATH 3A or ICS 6N) and MATH 3D. Recommended: STAT 8.
BME 138.restriction: Restriction: Biomedical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Biomedical Engr: Premedical Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

BME 140.name: Design of Biomedical Electronics
BME 140.description: Analog and digital circuits in bioinstrumentation. AC and DC circuit analysis, design and construction of filter and amplifiers using operational amplifier, digitization of signals and data acquisition, bioelectrical signals, design and construction of ECG instrument, bioelectrical signal measurement and analysis.  Materials fee.
BME 140.restriction: Restriction: Biomedical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

BME 142.name: Microfabrication
BME 142.description: Essentials of photolithography, soft-lithography, microfabrication, Microelectromechanical Systems (MEMS), BioMEMS
BME 142.restriction: Restriction: Biomedical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

BME 147.name: Microfluidics and Lab-on-a-Chip
BME 147.description: Introduction to principles of microfluidics and state-of-the-art micro Total Analysis Systems (uTAS). Lab-on-a-Chip for bimolecular assays with device design principles for microscale sample preparation, flow transport, bimolecular manipulation, separation and detection, and the technologies for integrating these devices into microsystems.
BME 147.restriction: Restriction: Biomedical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

BME 148.name: Microimplants
BME 148.description: Essential concepts of biomedical implants at the micro scale. Design, fabrication, and applications of several microimplantable devices including cochlear, retinal, neural, and muscular implants.
BME 148.restriction: Restriction: Biomedical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

BME 150.name: Biotransport Phenomena
BME 150.description: Fundamentals of heat and mass transfer, similarities in the respective rate equations. Emphasis on practical application of fundamental principles.
BME 150.prereqString: Prerequisite: (BME 60B or CEE 20) and (MATH 3A or ICS 6N) and MATH 3D
BME 150.restriction: Restriction: Biomedical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Biomedical Engr: Premedical Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

BME 160.name: Tissue Engineering
BME 160.description: Quantitative analysis of cell and tissue functions. Emerging developments in stem cell technology, biodegradable scaffolds, growth factors, and others important in developing clinical products. Applications of bioengineering.
BME 160.prereqString: Prerequisite: (BME 50B or BIOL 99) and BME 111 and BME 121 and BME 150
BME 160.restriction: Restriction: Biomedical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Biomedical Engr: Premedical Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Chemical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

BME 170.name: Biomedical Engineering Laboratory
BME 170.description: Measurement and analysis of biological systems using engineering tools and techniques. Laboratory experiments involve living systems with the emphasis on measuring physiological parameters. Materials fee.
BME 170.prereqString: Prerequisite: BME 50B and BME 120 and BME 130
BME 170.restriction: Restriction: Biomedical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

BME 171.name: Cell and Tissue Engineering Laboratory
BME 171.description: Techniques in molecular, cellular, and tissue engineering.  Topics include bacterial and mammalian cell culture, DNA cloning and gene transfer, fabrication of biomaterial scaffolds, and immunassays and microscopy techniques for cell-based assays.
BME 171.restriction: Restriction: Biomedical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Biomedical Engr: Premedical Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

BME 180A.name: Biomedical Engineering Design
BME 180A.description: Design strategies, techniques, tools, and protocols commonly encountered in biomedical engineering
BME 180A.prereqString: Prerequisite: (BME 60B or MAE 10 or EECS 10) and (BME 60C or MAE 52 or EECS 31L) and (BME 140 or MAE 106 or EECS 170B). BME 180A, BME 180B, and BME 180C must be taken in the same academic year.
BME 180A.restriction: Restriction: Seniors only. Biomedical Engineering Majors only.

BME 180B.name: Biomedical Engineering Design
BME 180B.description: Design strategies, techniques, tools, and protocols commonly encountered in biomedical engineering
BME 180B.prereqString: Prerequisite: BME 180A. BME 180A, BME 180B, and BME 180C must be taken in the same academic year.
BME 180B.restriction: Restriction: Seniors only. Biomedical Engineering Majors only.

BME 180C.name: Biomedical Engineering Design
BME 180C.description: Design strategies, techniques, tools, and protocols commonly encountered in biomedical engineering
BME 180C.prereqString: Prerequisite: BME 180B. BME 180A, BME 180B, and BME 180C must be taken in the same academic year.
BME 180C.restriction: Restriction: Seniors only. Biomedical Engineering Majors only.

BME 195.name: Special Topics in Biomedical Engineering
BME 195.description: Studies in selected areas of Biomedical Engineering. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

BME 197.name: Seminars in Biomedical Engineering
BME 197.description: Presentation of advanced topics and reports of current research efforts in Biomedical Engineering.
BME 197.restriction: Restriction: Seniors only. Biomedical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

BME 199.name: Individual Study
BME 199.description: Independent research conducted in the lab of a biomedical engineering core faculty member. A formal written report of the research conducted is required at the conclusion of the quarter.

BME 199P.name: Individual Study
BME 199P.description: Supervised independent reading, research, or design for undergraduate Engineering majors. Students taking individual study for design credit are to submit a written paper to the instructor and to the Undergraduate Student Affairs Office in the School of Engineering.

BME 201P.name: Biomedical Big Data
BME 201P.description: Analysis and visualization of large biomedical datasets. Topics covered include cloud computing, learning Structured Query Language (SQL), database normalization and joins, using Google’s BigQuery, using the statistical analysis package R, machine learning algorithms, application of machine learning for classification problems.
BME 201P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

BME 202P.name: Biomedical Imaging and Biophotonics
BME 202P.description: Designed as a subfield of optical imaging and biophotonics as it applies to their applications to basic lifesciences and in vivo imaging to diagnose disease. Topics span all of of the areas of biophotonics and techniques.
BME 202P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

BME 203P.name: Digital Health
BME 203P.description: Digital health is the convergence of genomics and technology to radically change the way health and medicine is practiced. Explores the history of healthcare in the U.S., its current status, and the future of digital health.
BME 203P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

BME 210.name: Molecular and Cellular Engineering
BME 210.description: Engineering of physiological function at the genetic, cellular, and tissue scales. Topics include cloning and genetic engineering, extracellular matrix biomaterials, principles of regenerative medicine and tissue engineering, and experimental design.

BME 210P.name: Molecular and Cellular Engineering
BME 210P.description: Engineering of physiological function at the genetic, cellular, and tissue scales. Topics include cloning and genetic engineering, extracellular matrix biomaterials, principles of regenerative medicine and tissue engineering, and experimental design.
BME 210P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

BME 211.name: Microscale Tissue Engineering
BME 211.description: Engineering of physiological function at the scale of individual cells. Topics include cell micropatterning, microfluidic tissue culture, engineering the cellular microenvironment, and microphysiological systems.

BME 211P.name: Microscale Tissue Engineering
BME 211P.description: Engineering of physiological function at the scale of individual cells. Topics include cell micropatterning, microfluidic tissue culture, engineering the cellular microenvironment, and microphysiological systems.
BME 211P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

BME 212.name: Cardiovascular Mechanobiology
BME 212.description: Advanced topics in cellular engineering and mechanobiology, with focus on the cardiovascular system.  Tools and techniques used to manipulate and measure mechanical forces at the molecular, cellular, tissue, and organ levels, and their applications in cardiovascular devices and tissue engineering.

BME 212P.name: Cardiovascular Mechanobiology
BME 212P.description: Advanced topics in cellular engineering and mechanobiology, with focus on the cardiovascular system. Tools and techniques used to manipulate and measure mechanical forces at the molecular, cellular, tissue, and organ levels, and their applications in cardiovascular devices and tissue engineering.
BME 212P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

BME 213.name: Systems Cell and Developmental Biology
BME 213.description: Introduces concepts needed to understand cell and developmental biology at the systems level, i.e., how the parts (molecules) work together to create a complex output. Emphasis on using mathematical/computational modeling to expand/modify insights provided by intuition.

BME 215.name: Linking Modeling and Experiments in Bioengineering
BME 215.description: Overview of modeling based on experimental techniques in bioengineering. Construct and evaluate models of varying complexity and to relate them to experimental data.

BME 220.name: Sensory Motor Systems
BME 220.description: A quantitative and systems approach to understanding physiological systems. Systems covered include the nervous and musculoskeletal systems.

BME 220P.name: Sensory Motor Systems
BME 220P.description: A quantitative and systems approach to understanding physiological systems. Systems covered include the nervous and musculoskeletal systems.
BME 220P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

BME 221.name: Organ Transport Systems
BME 221.description: A quantitative and systems approach to understanding physiological systems. Systems covered include the cardiopulmonary, circulatory, and renal systems.

BME 221P.name: Organ Transport Systems
BME 221P.description: Applies engineering models and mathematics to understand human physiology in order to understand the physiology. Covers the pulmonary, cardiac, and cardiovascular systems focusing on transport phenomena.
BME 221P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

BME 222.name: Biofluid Mechanics
BME 222.description: Introduces principles of biofluid mechanics in a research oriented scheme and approaches a wide spectrum of biofluid related problems in human body and solutions that involves engineering concepts.

BME 224.name: Molecular and Cellular Biophotonics
BME 224.description: Principles underlying the application of photonic technologies to biomolecular and cellular systems. Sample technologies Optical Tweezers, Linear and Nonlinear Optical Microscopy and Fluorescence Lifetime and Correlation Methods, and their use to investigate emergent problems in Molecular, Cellular, and Developmental Biology.

BME 225.name: Tissue and Organ Biophotonics
BME 225.description: Principles underlying the application of photonic technologies to tissues, organs, organisms. Sample technologies include Optical Coherence Tomography, Optical Speckle Imaging, Optoacoustic Imaging, Wide-Field Spectroscopic Imaging, Diffuse Optical Spectroscopy. Addressing the use of these technologies to detect/monitor disease and physiological processes.

BME 230A.name: Applied Engineering Mathematics I
BME 230A.description: Analytical techniques applied to engineering problems in transport phenomena, process dynamics and control, and thermodynamics.

BME 230B.name: Applied Engineering Mathematics II
BME 230B.description: Focuses on biomedical system identification. Includes fundamental techniques of model building and testing such as formulation, solution of governing equations, sensitivity theory, identifiability theory, and uncertainty analysis.

BME 232.name: Introduction to Computational Biology
BME 232.description: The use of theories and methods based on computer science, mathematics, and physics in molecular biology and biochemistry. Basics in biomolecular modeling. Analysis of sequence and structural data of biomolecules. Analysis of biomolecular functions.

BME 233.name: Dynamic Systems in Biology and Medicine
BME 233.description: Introduces principles of system theory to analyze biological, biochemical, physiological, and bioengineering systems. Analytical and computational tools are used to model and analyze dynamic systems such as population, neuronal and heart dynamics, biochemical and physiological systems, oxygen diffusion and similar.

BME 233P.name: Dynamic Systems in Biology and Medicine
BME 233P.description: Introduces the elements of system theory, and applies these principles to analyze biomedical, chemical, social, and engineering systems. Using analytical and computational tools to model and analyze various dynamic systems.
BME 233P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

BME 234.name: Neuroimaging Data Analysis
BME 234.description: Knowledge and understanding of recent techniques for the analysis of healthy and pathological structure and function in neuroimaging data.

BME 234P.name: Neuroimaging Data Analysis
BME 234P.description: Knowledge and understanding of recent techniques for the analysis of healthy and pathological structure and function in neuroimaging data.
BME 234P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

BME 238.name: Spectroscopy and Imaging of Biological Systems

BME 238P.name: Spectroscopy and Imaging of Biological Systems
BME 238P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

BME 240.name: Introduction to Clinical Medicine for Biomedical Engineering
BME 240.description: An introduction to clinical medicine for graduate students in biomedical engineering. Lectures and rotations through nephology, gastroenterology, pulmonary, and critical care cardiology.
BME 240.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Biomedical Engineering Majors only.

BME 240P.name: Introduction to Clinical Medicine for Biomedical Engineering
BME 240P.description: An introduction to clinical medicine for graduate students in biomedical engineering. Lectures and rotations through nephology, gastroenterology, pulmonary, and critical care cardiology.
BME 240P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

BME 251.name: Engineering Medical Optics
BME 251.description: Principles of optics and photonics, integration of optical components into systems and devices, and analysis of physiologic signals obtained from Biophotonics measurements.

BME 251P.name: Engineering Medical Optics
BME 251P.description: Principles of optics and photonics, integration of optical components into systems and devices, and analysis of physiologic signals obtained from Biophotonics measurements.
BME 251P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

BME 252.name: Critical Thinking in Biophotonics
BME 252.description: Critical thematic review of current research papers in the field of Biophotonics.

BME 260.name: Microfluids and Lab-On-A-Chip
BME 260.description: Introduction to microfluidics and state-of-the-art micro Total Analysis Systems (uTAS). Lab-on-a-Chip for biomolecular assays with device design principles for microscale sample preparation, flow transport, biolmolecular manipulation, separation and detection, and the technologies for integrating these devices into microsystems.

BME 260P.name: Microfluids and Lab-on-a-Chip
BME 260P.description: Introduction to microfluidics and state-of-the-art micro Total Analysis Systems (uTAS). Lab-on-a-Chip for biomolecular assays with device design principles for microscale sample preparation, flow transport, biolmolecular manipulation, separation and detection, and the technologies for integrating these devices into microsystems.
BME 260P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

BME 262.name: Microimplants
BME 262.description: Essential concepts of biomedical implants at the micro scale. Design, fabrication, and applications of several microimplantable devices including cochlear, retinal, neural, and muscular implants.

BME 262P.name: Microimplants
BME 262P.description: Essential concepts of biomedical implants at the micro scale. Design, fabrication, and applications of several microimplantable devices including cochlear, retinal, neural, and muscular implants.
BME 262P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

BME 290.name: Critical Thinking and Writing
BME 290.description: Critical thinking and writing are essential ingredients for success in scientific research. Examines examples from the scientific literature to extract principles of good scientific reasoning, experimental design, and writing.

BME 295.name: Special Topics in Biomedical Engineering
BME 295.description: Studies in selected areas of Biomedical Engineering. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

BME 295P.name: Special Topics in Biomedical Engineering
BME 295P.description: Studies in selected areas of Biomedical Engineering. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
BME 295P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

BME 296.name: Master of Science Thesis Research
BME 296.description: Individual research or investigation conducted in the pursuit of preparing and completing the thesis required for the M.S. in Engineering.

BME 297.name: Doctor of Philosophy Dissertation Research
BME 297.description: Individual research or investigation conducted in the pursuit of preparing and completing the dissertation required for the Ph.D. in Engineering.

BME 298.name: Seminars in Biomedical Engineering
BME 298.description: Presentation of advanced topics and reports of current research efforts in biomedical engineering. Designed for graduate students in the Biomedical Engineering program.

BME 299.name: Individual Research
BME 299.description: Individual research or investigation under the direction of an individual faculty.

CBE 1.name: Introduction to Chemical Engineering
CBE 1.description: Helps new students successfully transition to UCI, build a sense of community in the department, develop networking and professional skills, and introduce a variety of industries who employ chemical engineers through a series of guest lectures.
CBE 1.restriction: Restriction: Chemical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CBE 40A.name: Chemical Processes and Material Balances
CBE 40A.description: Introduction to chemical engineering and the industries where chemical engineers play vital roles. Problem-solving skills and techniques. Quantitative calculations and applications using mass and energy balances. Stoichiometric equations, multiple bypasses, and others in process industries.
CBE 40A.prereqString: Prerequisite: MATH 2B and PHYS 7C and (CHEM 1B or CHEM H2B)
CBE 40A.restriction: Restriction: Chemical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CBE 40B.name: Process Thermodynamics
CBE 40B.description: Principles of thermodynamics: definitions, basic concepts, and laws
CBE 40B.prereqString: Prerequisite: CBE 40A and (MATH 3A or ICS 6N). CBE 40A with a grade of C- or better
CBE 40B.restriction: Restriction: Chemical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CBE 40C.name: Chemical Engineering Thermodynamics
CBE 40C.description: Elements of chemical engineering thermodynamics, including equilibrium and stability
CBE 40C.restriction: Restriction: Chemical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CBE 100.name: Introduction to Numerical Methods in Engineering
CBE 100.description: An introduction to the fundamentals of numerical analysis and the computer algorithms in MATLAB for the solution of engineering problems, with emphasis on problems arising in chemical engineering thermodynamics, transport phenomena, and reaction engineering.
CBE 100.restriction: Restriction: Chemical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CBE 105.name: Engineering Physical Chemistry
CBE 105.description: Provides an integrated view of both classical and molecular perspectives on thermodynamics, thermodynamic potentials, entropy, and the second law. Students learn how to use statistical mechanics to create a bridge between the quantum mechanical world and the familiar macroscopic one.
CBE 105.prereqString: Prerequisite: CHEM 1C and CBE 40C and (PHYS 7D or PHYS 7E)
CBE 105.restriction: Restriction: Chemical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CBE 110.name: Reaction Kinetics and Reactor Design
CBE 110.description: Introduction to quantitative analysis of chemical reactions and chemical reactor design. Reactor operations including batch, continuous stirred tank, and tubular reactor. Homogeneous and heterogeneous reactions.
CBE 110.prereqString: Prerequisite: CHEM 1C and MATH 3D and CBE 40B and CBE 40C and CBE 100. CBE 40B with a grade of C- or better. CBE 40C with a grade of C- or better
CBE 110.restriction: Restriction: Chemical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Materials Science and Engineering majors have second consideration for enrollment.

CBE 120A.name: Momentum Transfer
CBE 120A.description: Fluid statics, surface tension, Newton's law of viscosity, non-Newtonian and complex flows, momentum equations, laminar and turbulent flow, velocity profiles, flow in pipes and around objects, piping systems design, pumps and mixing, and other applications to chemical and related industries.
CBE 120A.prereqString: Prerequisite: CBE 40C and MATH 3D. CBE 40C with a grade of C- or better
CBE 120A.restriction: Restriction: Chemical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CBE 120B.name: Heat Transfer
CBE 120B.description: Principles of conduction, radiation, and convection of heat
