CBE 120B.prereqString: Prerequisite: CBE 120A. CBE 120A with a grade of C- or better
CBE 120B.restriction: Restriction: Chemical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Materials Science and Engineering majors have second consideration for enrollment.

CBE 120C.name: Mass Transfer
CBE 120C.description: Molecular and continuum approaches to diffusion and convection in multi-component mixtures
CBE 120C.restriction: Restriction: Chemical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Materials Science and Engineering majors have second consideration for enrollment.

CBE 130.name: Separation Processes
CBE 130.description: Application of equilibria and mass and energy balances for design of separation processes. Use of equilibrium laws for design of distillation, absorption, stripping, and extraction equipment. Design of multicomponent separators.
CBE 130.prereqString: Prerequisite: CBE 40B and CBE 40C. CBE 40B with a grade of C- or better. CBE 40C with a grade of C- or better
CBE 130.restriction: Restriction: Chemical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Materials Science and Engineering majors have second consideration for enrollment.

CBE 140A.name: Chemical Engineering Laboratory I
CBE 140A.description: Experimental study of thermodynamics, fluid mechanics, and heat and mass transfer. Operation and evaluation of process equipment, data analysis.  Materials fee.
CBE 140A.restriction: Restriction: Chemical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CBE 140B.name: Chemical Engineering Laboratory II
CBE 140B.description: Continuation of the CBE 140A covering mass transfer operations such as distillation, absorption, extraction, etc. Rate and equilibria studies in simple chemical systems with and without reaction. Study of chemical process. Materials fee.
CBE 140B.prereqString: Prerequisite: CBE 130 and CBE 145 and CBE 140A
CBE 140B.restriction: Restriction: Chemical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CBE 145.name: Chemical Process Control
CBE 145.description: Dynamic responses and control of chemical process equipment, dynamic modeling of chemical processes, linear system analysis, analyses and design of feedback loops and advanced control systems.
CBE 145.prereqString: Prerequisite: CBE 110 and CBE 120B and CBE 120C
CBE 145.restriction: Restriction: Chemical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CBE 150A.name: Chemical Engineering Design I
CBE 150A.prereqString: Prerequisite: CBE 110 and CBE 120C and CBE 130
CBE 150A.restriction: Restriction: Seniors only. Chemical Engineering Majors only.

CBE 150B.name: Chemical Engineering Design II
CBE 150B.description: Application of chemical engineering basics to practical design problems
CBE 150B.restriction: Restriction: Seniors only. Chemical Engineering Majors only.

CBE 160.name: Engineering Biology
CBE 160.description: First-principle introduction to the modern biochemistry, molecular biology, and cell biology with an engineering language. The goal is to demonstrate that the vastly diverse biological phenomena can be explained by a set of fundamental principles in chemistry, thermodynamics, and kinetics.

CBE 161.name: Introduction to Biochemical Engineering
CBE 161.description: Application of engineering principles to biochemical processes. Topics include microbial pathways, energetics and control systems, enzyme and microbial kinetics, and the design and analysis of biological reactors.
CBE 161.prereqString: Prerequisite: CBE 110 and CBE 160 and (CHEM 1C or CHEM H2C) and MATH 3D
CBE 161.restriction: Restriction: Chemical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CBE 163.name: Kinetics of Biochemical Networks
CBE 163.description: Principles from statistical mechanics, thermodynamics, and chemical kinetics applied to biochemical systems, from fundamental processes such as receptor-ligand binding and enzyme catalysis, to complex cellular functions including signal transduction and gene regulation.
CBE 163.restriction: Restriction: Chemical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CBE 172.name: Applied Spectroscopy
CBE 172.description: Designed to teach fundamental principles of spectroscopy and their application to photon and electron spectroscopies of the gas and condensed phases. Covers theoretical principles of rotational, vibrational, and electronic spectroscopies. Specific topics include infrared and Raman spectroscopies, Auger, X-ray, etc.

CBE 175.name: Electrochemical Engineering
CBE 175.description: Introduction to fundamentals of electrochemical engineering and its application to variety of energy conversion- and storage-technologies. Planned topics include: electric double layers, reaction kinetics, transport, batteries, fuel-cells.

CBE 176.name: Nuclear and Radiochemistry
CBE 176.description: Advanced treatment of nuclear structure, nuclear reactions, and radioactive-decay processes. Introduction to nuclear activation analysis, isotope effects, radiation chemistry, hot-atom chemistry, nuclear age-dating methods, nuclear reactors, and nuclear power.
CBE 176.prereqString: Prerequisite: (CHEM M3C or CHEM 1C or CHEM H2C or CHEM M2C) and MATH 2D
CBE 176.restriction: Restriction: Chemistry Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Chemical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CBE 181.name: Polymer Science and Engineering
CBE 181.description: An introduction to physical aspects of polymers, including configuration and conformation of polymer chains and characterization techniques
CBE 181.restriction: Restriction: Chemical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CBE 183.name: Surface and Adhesion Science
CBE 183.description: Structure, thermodynamics of, kinetics, and reactions on surfaces. Surface electronic and mechanical properties and characterization of all classes of materials including metals, semiconductors, ceramics, polymers, and soft materials. Adhesion between different materials is also addressed.
CBE 183.prereqString: Prerequisite: (CBE 110 or MSE 165C) and (MSE 141 or MSE 69)
CBE 183.restriction: Restriction: Chemical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Materials Science and Engr Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CBE 187.name: Semiconductor Device Packaging
CBE 187.description: Introduction to the semiconductor device packaging and assembly process. Electrical, thermal, optical, and mechanical aspects of package design and reliability. Special topics on optoelectronics packaging are covered.
CBE 187.restriction: Restriction: Chemical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Materials Science and Engr Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CBE 195.name: Special Topics in Chemical Engineering
CBE 195.description: Studies in selected areas of Chemical Engineering. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

CBE 198.name: Group Study
CBE 198.description: Group study of selected topics in engineering.

CBE 199.name: Individual Study
CBE 199.description: For undergraduate engineering majors in supervised but independent readings, research, or design. Students taking individual study for design credit are to submit a written paper to the instructor and to the Undergraduate Student Affairs Office in the School of Engineering.
CBE 199.restriction: Restriction: Chemical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CBE 199P.name: Individual Study
CBE 199P.description: For undergraduate Engineering majors in supervised but independent reading, research, or design. Students taking individual study for design credit are to submit a written paper to the instructor and to the Undergraduate Student Affairs Office in The School of Engineering.

CBE 200.name: Applied Engineering Mathematics I
CBE 200.description: Analytical techniques applied to engineering problems in transport phenomena, process dynamics and control, and thermodynamics.

CBE 210.name: Reaction Engineering
CBE 210.description: Advanced topics in reaction engineering, reactor stability analysis, diffusional effect in heterogeneous catalysis, energy balance, optimization of reactor operation, dispersed in phase reactors.

CBE 220A.name: Transport Phenomena I
CBE 220A.description: Continuum modeling and analysis of heat and mass transfer from an integrated viewpoint. Scaling concepts, relevance of characteristic time- and length-scales, steady- and unsteady-state processes, bounded and unbounded problems, and convective transport, with applications to chemical and biological processes.

CBE 220B.name: Transport Phenomena II
CBE 220B.description: Introduces flow of isothermal fluids from a momentum transport viewpoint. Steady- and unsteady-state creeping and laminar flows

CBE 240.name: Advanced Engineering Thermodynamics
CBE 240.description: Introduction to modern thermodynamics and applications, with a focus on aspects relevant to chemical and materials engineering. Mathematical tools

CBE 249.name: Special Topics in Chemical Engineering
CBE 249.description: Studies in selected areas of Chemical Engineering. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

CBE 250.name: Research Methods and Technical Communication
CBE 250.description: Intended for Ph.D. students to develop critical research skills in creating archival papers, intellectual property and technical proposals, and in analysis of the scientific literature.

CBE 261.name: Molecular Biotechnology
CBE 261.description: Engineering and biological principles important in recombinant cell technology. Host/vector selection

CBE 262.name: Metabolic Engineering and Synthetic Biology
CBE 262.description: Synthesis of chemicals from renewable carbon and energy sources using.

CBE 264.name: Drug Delivery
CBE 264.description: Introduction to design of drug delivery systems. Includes physicochemical and pharmacokinetic considerations in drug formulations, types of therapeutics, routes of administration, biomaterials, and novel drug delivery systems.

CBE 266.name: Bioseparation Processes
CBE 266.description: Introduction to design of bioseparation processes. The recovery and purification of biologically produced proteins, chemicals, and particulates are important. Focuses on the use of chemical engineering skills and principles in the analysis and design of biologically-based processes.

CBE 272.name: Applied Spectroscopy
CBE 272.description: Designed to teach fundamental principles of spectroscopy and their application to photon and electron spectroscopies of the gas and condensed phases. Covers theoretical principles of rotational, vibrational, and electronic spectroscopies. Specific topics include infrared and Raman spectroscopies, Auger, X-ray, etc.

CBE 276.name: Nuclear and Radiochemistry
CBE 276.description: Advanced treatment of nuclear structure, nuclear reactions, and radioactive-decay processes. Introduction to nuclear activation analysis, isotope effects, radiation chemistry, hot-atom chemistry, nuclear age-dating methods, nuclear reactors, and nuclear power.

CBE 277.name: Detection and Measurement of Radiation
CBE 277.description: Basic principles of detection and measurement of ionizing radiation

CBE 280.name: Advanced Polymer Science and Engineering
CBE 280.description: The synthesis, characterization, microstructure, rheology, and properties of polymer materials. Polymers in solution and in the liquid, crystalline and glassy states. Engineering and processing properties, including viscoelasticity and rheology. Forming and processing methods. Environmental issues.

CBE 282.name: Colloid Science and Engineering
CBE 282.description: An introduction to the basic foundations of colloid science, interfacial phenomena, suspensions and complex fluids, and engineering and assembly of colloidal materials.

CBE 283.name: Surface and Adhesion Science
CBE 283.description: Structure, thermodynamics of, kinetics, and reactions on surfaces. Surface electronic and mechanical properties and characterization of all classes of materials including metals, semiconductors, ceramics, polymers, and soft materials. Adhesion between different materials is also addressed.

CBE 288.name: Optoelectronics Packaging
CBE 288.description: Basic and current issues in the packaging of integrated circuits (IC) and fiber-optic devices are discussed.

CBE 295.name: Seminars in Engineering
CBE 295.description: Seminars scheduled each year by individual faculty in major field of interest.

CBE 296.name: Master of Science Thesis Research
CBE 296.description: Individual research or investigation conducted in preparation for the thesis required for the M.S. degree.

CBE 297.name: Doctor of Philosophy Dissertation Research
CBE 297.description: Individual research or investigation conducted in preparation for the dissertation required for the Ph.D. degree.

CBE 298.name: Seminars in Engineering
CBE 298.description: Presentation of advanced topics and reports of current research efforts in chemical engineering.

CBE 299.name: Individual Research
CBE 299.description: Individual research or investigation under the direction of an individual faculty member.

CHC/LAT 61.name: Introduction to Chicano/Latino Studies I
CHC/LAT 61.description: An introduction to the study of the historical foundations of the Chicano/Latino experience.  Addresses such topics as empire, migration, immigrant settlement, economic integration, race, gender, and the formation of group identities.

CHC/LAT 62.name: Introduction to Chicano/Latino Studies II
CHC/LAT 62.description: Provides an introduction to the arts, literature, and culture of Chicano/Latino communities. Analyzes representations of and cultural production in Chicano/Latino communities through such media as folklore, literature, art, film, architecture, dance theatre, performance, music, poetry, mass media, and language.

CHC/LAT 63.name: Introduction to Chicano/Latino Studies III
CHC/LAT 63.description: Examines contemporary public policy issues in Chicano/Latino communities. Each offering addresses at least three of the following themes: migration, immigrant incorporation, identity construction, language policy, health policy, politics, sexuality, gender, labor, class, and education.

CHC/LAT 64.name: Introduction to Race and Ethnicity in Political Science
CHC/LAT 64.description: Examines major theories that attempt to explain the roles of race and ethnicity in U.S. politics.

CHC/LAT 65.name: Ethnic and Immigrant America
CHC/LAT 65.description: Focusing on Asian, Latino, and Black immigrant groups, examines the second generation's experience of straddling two cultures and growing up American. Covers topics such as assimilation, bilingualism, race relations, education, bicultural conflicts, interracial marriage, and multiracial identities.

CHC/LAT H80.name: Latina/o Childhoods: Comparative Approaches to the Study of Children and Youth
CHC/LAT H80.description: Students in this seminar compare the experiences of Latina/o children to other young people in the U.S. and around the world, analyzing the historical, political, economic, and sociocultural factors that have differently structured the life stage we understand as “childhood.”.
CHC/LAT H80.restriction: Restriction: Campuswide Honors Collegium students only.

CHC/LAT 101.name: Research in the Latino Community
CHC/LAT 101.description: Students engage in firsthand research in the local Orange County environment. Students identify a research problem, conduct a literature review, develop questions and/or hypotheses, appropriate methods, and write a proposal.
CHC/LAT 101.prereqString: Prerequisite: Two courses from CHC/LAT 61 or CHC/LAT 62 or CHC/LAT 63 and two courses from CHC/LAT 110-189.
CHC/LAT 101.restriction: Restriction: Chicano/Latino Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CHC/LAT 102W.name: Chicano/Latino Research Seminar
CHC/LAT 102W.description: Taught as a writing and research seminar in Chicano/Latino Studies.  Student develops own project
CHC/LAT 102W.prereqString: Prerequisite: CHC/LAT 101. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
CHC/LAT 102W.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. Chicano/Latino Studies Majors only.

CHC/LAT 110.name: Topics in Chicano Literature and Culture
CHC/LAT 110.description: Studies in selected areas of Chicano/Latino Studies. Topics addressed vary each quarter. Taught in English.

CHC/LAT 118.name: Anthropology of Food
CHC/LAT 118.description: Examines how food communicates ideas about ethnocentrism, disgust, privilege, gender, race, labor, social identities and hierarchies, globalization, power, and the "Western diet" and its health consequences.

CHC/LAT 120.name: Peoples and Cultures of Latin America
CHC/LAT 120.description: Surveys the prehistory of Latin America and its indigenous cultures, emphasizing the impact of colonial rule, capitalism, and 20th-century transformations.  Emphasis on communities from several countries. In some years, emphasis on comparisons between the Latin American and Caribbean experiences.

CHC/LAT 121.name: Latina/Latino Pop:  Latina/Latino Popular Culture
CHC/LAT 121.description: With a focus on the politics of language and space/place, prepares students to critically analyze sites of Latina/Latino popular culture including: music, film, performance, sports, media, and varied subcultures.
CHC/LAT 121.restriction: Restriction: Chicano/Latino Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment. History Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CHC/LAT 123.name: Immigration, Nation, and Media
CHC/LAT 123.description: Examines media shapes and reflects public opinion on immigration and its representation of immigrants, citizens, and ideas about the nation, and who belongs and who is a potential threat

CHC/LAT 124W.name: Immigrant Emotionality
CHC/LAT 124W.description: Explores the emotional universe created by the Latin American immigrant experience, and guides students in the creation of a literary work based on an investigation into, or reflection on that experience.
CHC/LAT 124W.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

CHC/LAT 129.name: Special Topics in Literature, Arts, Media, Culture
CHC/LAT 129.description: Studies in selected areas of Chicano/Latino Studies. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
CHC/LAT 129.restriction: Restriction: Chicano/Latino Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CHC/LAT 132B.name: Chicana/Chicano History: Twentieth Century
CHC/LAT 132B.description: Examines social history of the Southwest with emphasis on Mexican-origin people. Discusses major questions, theory and research methods pertinent to Chicana/Chicano history. Themes explored include: immigration, xenophobia, class struggle, leadership, generational cohorts, unionization, education, barrioization, ethnicity, patriarchy, sexuality.

CHC/LAT 134.name: U.S. Latino Literature and Cultures
CHC/LAT 134.description: Focuses on aspects of literature, art, cultural production, and history of the multifaceted Latino cultures that have developed within the United States.  Focuses on one group, such as Caribbean Americans, Chicanos, Central Americans, or a comparative perspective of several groups.

CHC/LAT 135.name: Latinas in the Twentieth Century U.S.
CHC/LAT 135.description: Latinas in the U.S. from 1900 to present, offering a diversity of their cultures, regional histories, sexualities, generations, and classes.

CHC/LAT 139.name: Special Topics in Chicano/Latino History
CHC/LAT 139.description: Studies in selected areas of Chicano/Latino History. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

CHC/LAT 146.name: Latinx Racial Formations
CHC/LAT 146.description: Students explore the meanings attributed to Latina/o/x racial identities over time

CHC/LAT 147.name: Comparative Minority Politics
CHC/LAT 147.description: Examines the political experiences of Blacks, Latinos, and Asian Americans in the United States from roughly 1950 to the present. Focuses on how each group has pursued political empowerment via both conventional political channels and social movements.

CHC/LAT 148.name: Racial and Ethnic Relations in the United States
CHC/LAT 148.description: Examines central questions and issues in the field of race and ethnicity
CHC/LAT 148.restriction: Restriction: Chicano/Latino Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Sociology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CHC/LAT 148W.name: Racial and Ethnic Relations in the United States
CHC/LAT 148W.description: Examines central questions and issues in the field of race and ethnicity
CHC/LAT 148W.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
CHC/LAT 148W.restriction: Restriction: Chicano/Latino Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Sociology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CHC/LAT 150.name: U.S. Intervention in Latin America
CHC/LAT 150.description: Explores political, economic, social, and cultural ties that bind Latin America to the United States. Focuses on U.S. intervention and Latin American response from early nineteenth century to present day. Case studies include Mexico, Guatemala, Cuba, Chile, and Central America.

CHC/LAT 150A.name: Sex and Conquest in Latin America
CHC/LAT 150A.description: Competing ideas of masculinity and femininity, sexual violence, sexual identities, and gendered hierarchies informed how the Spanish engaged in military and religious domination of Mexican and Andean communities, as well as the forms of native resistance throughout colonial Latin America.

CHC/LAT 151.name: Latinos in U.S. Politics
CHC/LAT 151.description: Comparing the political issues facing Latino groups by examining their migration histories, voting behavior, nonelectoral participation, and policy issues.  Latino issues are examined on the national, state, and local levels, including formal representation, immigration, affirmative action, and language policy.

CHC/LAT 151B.name: Revolution in Latin America
CHC/LAT 151B.description: Presents a comparative analysis of the causes, development, and consequences of selected revolutionary movements, focusing on outbreaks in Mexico, Bolivia, Cuba, Chile, Nicaragua, and Grenada.  Explores topics of state formation, economic nationalism, social justice, ethnicity, and role of international affairs.

CHC/LAT 152A.name: Race, Ethnicity, and Social Control
CHC/LAT 152A.description: Provides a historical and sociological survey of racial and ethnic group relations in contexts of crime control, emphasizing the roles of racial ideology, structural racism, and social movements in shaping these dynamic relations, and their significance to American liberal democracy.

CHC/LAT 152B.name: Community, Social Justice, and Health Equity Research for Action
CHC/LAT 152B.description: Focuses on community as a unit of identity, community, well-being, and social justice perspectives and initiatives to promote community health. Addresses community change and improvements in community well-being, with a focus on health equity research for action.
CHC/LAT 152B.prereqString: Prerequisite: PUBHLTH 1 or PUBHLTH 2 or CHC/LAT 61 or CHC/LAT 62 or CHC/LAT 63

CHC/LAT 154.name: Latino Metropolis
CHC/LAT 154.description: Explores the processes of Latino urbanization in the United States and the spatialization of Latino identities, particularly in the context of Southern California with selected comparisons drawing from other cities.

CHC/LAT 155.name: Culture Change and the Mexican People
CHC/LAT 155.description: Reviews culture contact and colonization, innovation diffusion, acculturation, assimilation, culture conflict and marginality, modernization, urbanization, legal transformations. Mexico and the Southwestern U.S. are reviewed through several centuries to better appreciate the indigenous base of the Mexican people.

CHC/LAT 156W.name: Chicano/Latinos and Labor
CHC/LAT 156W.description: Explores theories that explain the occupational pathways and workplace experiences of Latinos in various work sectors. Investigates jobs such as migrant labor, child street vendors, Latina/Latino professionals, and Latinos migrating to the U.S. South that work in poultry processing plants.
CHC/LAT 156W.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

CHC/LAT 157.name: Cuban Society and Revolution
CHC/LAT 157.description: Explores the causes, development, and legacy of the 1959 Revolution. Themes include economic dependency, democracy, race, gender, culture, and the always volatile relations between Cuba and the United States.

CHC/LAT 158.name: Feminisms of Color
CHC/LAT 158.description: Surveys the development of Chicana feminist thought and practice.  Focuses on historical contemporary writings by and about Chicana feminists.  Draws from interdisciplinary scholarship in order to survey the diversity of Chicana feminisms.

CHC/LAT 159.name: Special Topics in Society, Labor, Politics, Law, Gender, Race, Ethnicity
CHC/LAT 159.description: Studies in selected areas of Chicano/Latino Studies. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

CHC/LAT 161.name: Transnational Migration
CHC/LAT 161.description: Examines the movement of people across national borders, governmentality and the role of state practices to control populations, and issues of citizenship, belonging, and identity. Examples are drawn from the United States, Europe, Latin America, Asia, and Africa.

CHC/LAT 161A.name: Transnational Central America
CHC/LAT 161A.description: Offers an overview of the history of Central America and its diasporas, as well as the struggles, accomplishments, and activism, art and cultural expressions of Central Americans in the United States.
CHC/LAT 161A.restriction: Restriction: Chicano/Latino Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CHC/LAT 162A.name: Urban America
CHC/LAT 162A.description: Students examine the historical, social, political, and economic factors that contributed to the construction of the American urban context, one that is poverty concentrated and racially/ethnically segregated. Students also critically assess the consequence of growing up in America's urban neighborhoods.

CHC/LAT 163.name: U.S. Immigration Policy
CHC/LAT 163.description: Examines selected immigration policy debates since the nineteenth century, rationale and consequences of immigration law since 1965, problems of administration, implementation and enforcement, impact of immigration policy on foreign relations, and contemporary debate regarding the future of U.S. policy.

CHC/LAT 164A.name: Undocumented Immigrant Experiences
CHC/LAT 164A.description: Examines the experiences of undocumented immigrants and the policies that structure their educational, economic, social, and political participation.

CHC/LAT 166.name: Chicano Movement
CHC/LAT 166.description: Explores the history of Mexicans in the U.S. with particular attention paid to their integration into the U.S. capitalist economy.  Examines this economic history and the Chicano movement, "El Movimiento," within the wide context of socio-economic change.
CHC/LAT 166.restriction: Restriction: Chicano/Latino Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Urban Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CHC/LAT 167.name: Latinos in a Global Society
CHC/LAT 167.description: Examines interconnections between diverse Latino groups in the U.S. and the effects of globalization on their social, cultural, and political realities. Topics include immigration, demographics, socioeconomic differentiation, familial relations, political protest/resistance, law and policy, and links to "homeland" issues.

CHC/LAT 168.name: Chicano/Latino Social Psychology
CHC/LAT 168.description: Examines theories, research, and major issues of relevance to understanding social psychological processes in Chicano/Latino populations. Topics include social development, cultural orientations, gender and sexuality, close relationships, happiness and well-being, stereotyping, prejudice and discrimination, and mental and physical health.
CHC/LAT 168.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
CHC/LAT 168.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Chicano/Latino Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CHC/LAT 169.name: Special Topics in Globalization, Transnationalism, Immigration, U.S.-Mexico Border
CHC/LAT 169.description: Studies in selected areas of Chicano/Latino Studies. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

CHC/LAT 170.name: Chicano/Latino Families
CHC/LAT 170.description: Introduction to the research, literature, and issues surrounding the topic of Chicano/Latino families including cultural history, contemporary issues, organization of family, traditions, lifestyles, values, beliefs, generational differences, gender issues, ethnic identity, evolution of demographic patterns, current economic and political standings.

CHC/LAT 176.name: Race, Gender, and Science
CHC/LAT 176.description: Perfect for pre-health, science and social science majors wanting to appreciate how science and society interact. Race and gender as biological and socio-cultural constructs are examined. Questions explored: What is disease? What is science? What are social and biological differences.

CHC/LAT 178.name: Health and the Latino Paradox
CHC/LAT 178.description: Examines research and theories concerning the physical and mental health of U.S. Latino populations. Contemporary accounts, health care implications, and new directions for understanding sources of risks and resilience for health in Latino populations are evaluated and discussed.
CHC/LAT 178.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
CHC/LAT 178.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Chicano/Latino Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CHC/LAT 178A.name: Medical Anthropology
CHC/LAT 178A.description: Introduces students to cross-cultural perspectives and critical theories in anthropological studies of medicine. Special attention is given to diverse ways of understanding bodies, illnesses, and therapeutic practices in our changing world.

CHC/LAT 179.name: Special Topics in Health, Medicine, and Psychosocial Dynamics
CHC/LAT 179.description: Studies in selected areas of Chicano/Latino Studies. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
CHC/LAT 179.restriction: Restriction: Chicano/Latino Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CHC/LAT 181.name: Chicanx/Latinx Education
CHC/LAT 181.description: Provides a historical and empirical overview of educational issues affecting diverse Latinx low-income, immigrant, and U.S. born student populations enrolled in American schools. Examines policies and issues such as DACA, generation, culture, racism, and gender on educational mobility.

CHC/LAT 183.name: Multicultural Education in K-12 Schools
CHC/LAT 183.description: Provides a theoretical and empirical overview of educational issues affecting low-income immigrant and U.S. born minority student populations in an increasingly diverse and changing society.

CHC/LAT 189.name: Special Topics in Educational Policy and Issues
CHC/LAT 189.description: Studies in selected areas of Chicano/Latino Studies. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

CHC/LAT H190A.name: Honors Research Preparation
CHC/LAT H190A.description: Students write a proposal describing their research question, the relevant background literature, and the method of data collection and analysis.  Field work for the project may begin this quarter.
CHC/LAT H190A.restriction: Restriction: Chicano/Latino Studies Honors students only.

CHC/LAT H190B.name: Honors Field Research
CHC/LAT H190B.description: Students begin or continue their research for their senior honors thesis.

CHC/LAT H190C.name: Honors Thesis
CHC/LAT H190C.description: Student drafts a senior honor thesis (typically) with the following sections:  problem statement, literature review, description of the methods, results, and conclusions.
CHC/LAT H190C.prereqString: Prerequisite: CHC/LAT H190A and CHC/LAT H190B

CHC/LAT H190W.name: Honors Thesis
CHC/LAT H190W.description: Student drafts a senior honor thesis (typically) with the following sections:  problem statement, literature review, description of the methods, results, and conclusions.
CHC/LAT H190W.prereqString: Prerequisite: CHC/LAT H190A and CHC/LAT H190B. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

CHC/LAT 200A.name: Theoretical Issues in Chicano/Latino Research
CHC/LAT 200A.description: Introduction to theoretical issues in the scholarship in Chicano/Latino Studies. Theories from social sciences, humanities, critical theory. Topics: immigration, identity, gender and sexuality, globalization, transnationalism, social, political, and economic integration, race theory, labor market participation, social history, cultural productions.

CHC/LAT 210A.name: Cultural and Historial Precedents for Latinos and Medical Care
CHC/LAT 210A.description: Introduction to the history of Latinos, focusing on relevant pre-Columbian, colonial, and modern social and cultural developments, including issues of race, gender, sexuality, religious beliefs, and health beliefs and practices.

CHC/LAT 210B.name: Cultural and Historical Precedents for Latinos and Medical Care
CHC/LAT 210B.description: Introduction to the history of Latinos, focusing on relevant pre-Columbian, colonial, and modern social and cultural developments, including issues of race, gender, sexuality, religious beliefs, and health beliefs and practices.
CHC/LAT 210B.restriction: Restriction: CHC/LAT 210A-210B and CHC/LAT 212 may not both be taken for credit.

CHC/LAT 211A.name: Latinos/Latinas and Medical Care: Contemporary Issues
CHC/LAT 211A.description: Introduction to medical anthropological and social science perspectives on Latinos/Latinas in relation to a number of health and medically-related issues, i.e., immigration, gender, reproduction, culture, social structure, political economy, sexuality, utilization of medical services, and health beliefs.

CHC/LAT 211B.name: Latinos/Latinas and Medical Care: Contemporary Issues
CHC/LAT 211B.description: Introduction to medical anthropological and social science perspectives on Latinos/Latinas in relation to a number of health and medically-related issues, i.e., immigration, gender, reproduction, culture, social structure, political economy, sexuality, utilization of medical services, and health beliefs.

CHC/LAT 215.name: Transnational Migration
CHC/LAT 215.description: Examines borders and boundaries as material and semiotic constructs. Drawing upon an array of literatures, but loosely situated in U.S. geo/biopolitics, explores transformative troublings of places, spaces, borders, and bodies of all sorts.

CHC/LAT 217.name: Ethnography
CHC/LAT 217.description: Explores the theory and practice of ethnography with a focus on anthropology, the discipline most associated with ethnography. Students are exposed to the theoretical underpinnings of ethnographic work, traditional and innovative practices, and sample ethnographies.

CHC/LAT 222.name: Theorizing Illegality and the Experiences of Undocumented Immigrants
CHC/LAT 222.description: Examines theories of illegality and citizenship, historical and contemporary undocumented immigrant experiences, and methodological concerns in this area of study.

CHC/LAT 223.name: Ethnic America
CHC/LAT 223.description: Examines critically the meaning and measurement of ethnicity, race, and nation in sociological theory and research. Theories of ethnicity are explored, along with empirical studies of the construction of ethnic and pan-ethnic identities in historical and contemporary contexts.

CHC/LAT 224.name: Immigrant America
CHC/LAT 224.description: The study of the causes and consequences of international migration has become one of the most vital fields of sociological theory and research. Examines principal theoretical perspectives and empirical research on contemporary immigration flows and the processes of incorporation.

CHC/LAT 225.name: Crimmigration
CHC/LAT 225.description: Examines the criminalization of immigration, with an emphasis on U.S. enforcement procedures and outcomes. Analyzes the devolution of federal immigration law to local authorities, the rise in immigrant detention and deportation, and the militarization of the U.S.-Mexico border.

CHC/LAT 251.name: Models of Practice and Intervention at the Community Level
CHC/LAT 251.description: Examines and critiques current models, frameworks, theories for.

CHC/LAT 299.name: Independent Study
CHC/LAT 299.description: Independent study with Chicano/Latino Studies faculty.

CHEM 1A.name: General Chemistry
CHEM 1A.description: General chemistry with applications to life sciences, physical sciences, and engineering. Atomic structure
CHEM 1A.restriction: Restriction: School of Biological Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Physical Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Engineering students have first consideration for enrollment. Program in Nursing Science students have first consideration for enrollment. Dept Pharmaceutical Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. Program in Public Health students have first consideration for enrollment. Undeclared Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CHEM 1B.name: General Chemistry
CHEM 1B.description: General chemistry with applications to life sciences, physical sciences, and engineering. Properties of gases, liquids, solids
CHEM 1B.prereqString: Prerequisite: CHEM 1A or ENGR 1A or CHEM H2A or AP Chemistry or CHEM M2A. CHEM 1A with a grade of C- or better. ENGR 1A with a grade of C- or better. CHEM H2A with a grade of C- or better. AP Chemistry with a minimum score of 4. CHEM M2A with a grade of C- or better
CHEM 1B.restriction: Restriction: School of Biological Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Physical Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Engineering students have first consideration for enrollment. Program in Nursing Science students have first consideration for enrollment. Dept Pharmaceutical Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. Program in Public Health students have first consideration for enrollment. Undeclared Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CHEM 1C.name: General Chemistry
CHEM 1C.description: General chemistry with applications to life sciences, physical sciences, and engineering. Equilibria, aqueous acid-base equilibria, solubility equilibria, oxidation reduction reactions, electrochemistry
CHEM 1C.prereqString:
Corequisite: CHEM 1LC
Prerequisite: CHEM 1B. CHEM 1B with a grade of C- or better
CHEM 1C.restriction: Restriction: School of Biological Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Physical Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Engineering students have first consideration for enrollment. Program in Nursing Science students have first consideration for enrollment. Dept Pharmaceutical Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. Program in Public Health students have first consideration for enrollment. Undeclared Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CHEM 1LA.name: General Chemistry Laboratory
CHEM 1LA.description: Training and experience in basic laboratory techniques through experiments related to lecture topics in Chemistry 1A.  Materials fee.

CHEM 1LC.name: General Chemistry Laboratory
CHEM 1LC.description: Training and experience in basic laboratory techniques. Chemical practice and principles illustrated through experiments related to lecture topics of CHEM 1A-B-C. Materials fee.
CHEM 1LC.prereqString:
Corequisite: CHEM 1C
Prerequisite: CHEM 1B. CHEM 1B with a grade of C- or better
CHEM 1LC.restriction: Restriction: Div of Undergraduate Education students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Biological Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Physical Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Engineering students have first consideration for enrollment. Nursing Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Pharmaceutical Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Public Health Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CHEM 1LD.name: General Chemistry Laboratory
CHEM 1LD.description: Training and experience in basic laboratory techniques. Chemical practice and principles illustrated through experiments related to lecture topics in CHEM 1A-B-C. Materials fee.
CHEM 1LD.prereqString: Prerequisite: (CHEM 1C and CHEM 1LC) or CHEM 1LE. CHEM 1C with a grade of C- or better. CHEM 1LC with a grade of C- or better. CHEM 1LE with a grade of C- or better
CHEM 1LD.restriction: Restriction: School of Biological Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Physical Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Engineering students have first consideration for enrollment. Program in Nursing Science students have first consideration for enrollment. Pharmaceutical Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Public Health Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Undecided/Undeclared students also have first consideration for enrollment.

CHEM 1LE.name: Accelerated General Chemistry Lab
CHEM 1LE.description: Lecture and experiments covering chemical concepts for accelerated students who do not plan to take organic chemistry. Properties of gases, liquids, solutions, and solids
CHEM 1LE.restriction: Restriction: School of Engineering students have first consideration for enrollment. Biomedical Computing Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CHEM 1P.name: Preparation for General Chemistry
CHEM 1P.description: Units of measurement, dimensional analysis, significant figures
CHEM 1P.restriction: Restriction: School of Biological Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Physical Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Engineering students have first consideration for enrollment. Program in Nursing Science students have first consideration for enrollment. Dept Pharmaceutical Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. Program in Public Health students have first consideration for enrollment. Biomedical Computing Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Undeclared Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CHEM 1X.name: General Chemistry Plus
CHEM 1X.description: Units of chemical measurements, dimensional analysis, significant figures
CHEM 1X.prereqString: Prerequisite: Students who meet the requirements for taking Chem 1A through their SAT, ACT, or AP test scores are not eligible for enrollment in Chem 1X. Specifically, the students must have ALL of the following advisory prerequisites (the inverse of the Chem 1A prerequisites): S02<600 (score below 600 on the SAT Mathematics Reasoning test) A02<27 (score below 27 on the ACT Mathematics test) Z43<700 (score below 700 on the SAT Chemistry subject exam) AP25<3 (score below 3 on the AP Chemistry exam) AP66<4 (score below 4 on the AP Calculus AB Exam) AP68<3 (score below 3 on the AP Calculus BC Exam) Students who meet Chem 1A eligibility through ALEKS-based training are permitted to enroll in Chem 1X. Chem 1X is open to interested BioEASE students.

CHEM H2A.name: Honors General Chemistry
CHEM H2A.description: Covers the same material as CHEM 1A-CHEM 1B-CHEM M3C but in greater depth. Additional topics will also be included as time permits.
CHEM H2A.prereqString:
Corequisite: CHEM H2LA
Prerequisite: AP Chemistry or SAT Subject Chemistry. AP Chemistry with a minimum score of 4. SAT Subject Chemistry with a minimum score of 700
CHEM H2A.restriction: Restriction: Campuswide Honors Collegium students only.

CHEM H2B.name: Honors General Chemistry
CHEM H2B.description: Covers the same material as CHEM 1A-CHEM 1B-CHEM M3C but in greater depth. Additional topics are also included as time permits.
CHEM H2B.prereqString:
Corequisite: CHEM H2LB
Prerequisite: CHEM H2A and (CHEM H2LA or CHEM M2LA). CHEM H2A with a grade of C- or better. CHEM H2LA with a grade of C- or better. CHEM M2LA with a grade of C- or better
CHEM H2B.restriction: Restriction: Campuswide Honors Collegium students only.

CHEM H2C.description: Covers the same material as CHEM 1A-CHEM 1B-CHEM M3C but in greater depth. Additional topics are also included as time permits.
CHEM H2C.prereqString: Prerequisite: CHEM H2B and (CHEM H2LB or CHEM M2LB). CHEM H2B with a grade of C- or better. CHEM H2LB with a grade of C- or better. CHEM M2LB with a grade of C- or better
CHEM H2C.restriction: Restriction: Campuswide Honors Collegium students only.

CHEM H2LA.name: Honors General Chemistry Laboratory
CHEM H2LA.description: Training and experience in fundamental and analytical laboratory techniques through experiments related to lecture topics in CHEM H2A-CHEM H2B-CHEM H2C. Materials fee.
CHEM H2LA.prereqString:
Corequisite: CHEM H2A
Prerequisite: AP Chemistry or SAT Subject Chemistry. AP Chemistry with a minimum score of 4. SAT Subject Chemistry with a minimum score of 700
CHEM H2LA.restriction: Restriction: Campuswide Honors Collegium students only.

CHEM H2LB.description: Training and experience in fundamental and analytical laboratory techniques through experiments related to lecture topics in CHEM H2A-CHEM H2B-CHEM H2C. Materials fee.
CHEM H2LB.prereqString:
Corequisite: CHEM H2B
Prerequisite: CHEM H2A and (CHEM H2LA or CHEM M2LA). CHEM H2A with a grade of B or better. CHEM H2LA with a grade of B or better. CHEM M2LA with a grade of B or better
CHEM H2LB.restriction: Restriction: No credit for CHEM 1LC if taken after CHEM H2LB or CHEM M2LB.

CHEM H2LC.description: Training and experience in fundamental and analytical laboratory techniques through experiments related to lecture topics in CHEM H2A-CHEM H2B-CHEM H2C. Materials fee.
CHEM H2LC.prereqString:
Corequisite: CHEM H2C
Prerequisite: CHEM H2B and (CHEM H2LB or CHEM M2LB). CHEM H2B with a grade of B or better. CHEM H2LB with a grade of B or better. CHEM M2LB with a grade of B or better

CHEM M2A.name: Majors General Chemistry Lecture
CHEM M2A.description: Covers the same material as CHEM 1A but in greater depth. Additional topics are included as time permits.
CHEM M2A.restriction: Restriction: Chemistry Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CHEM M2B.name: Majors General Chemistry Lecture
CHEM M2B.description: Covers the same material as CHEM 1B but in greater depth. Additional topics will also be included as time permits.
CHEM M2B.prereqString: Prerequisite: CHEM M2A and CHEM M2LA. CHEM M2A with a grade of C- or better. CHEM M2LA with a grade of C- or better
CHEM M2B.restriction: Restriction: Chemistry Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CHEM M2C.name: Majors General Chemistry Lecture
CHEM M2C.description: Covers the same material as CHEM 1C but in greater depth. Additional topics are also included as time permits.
CHEM M2C.prereqString: Prerequisite: CHEM M2B and CHEM M2LB. CHEM M2B with a grade of C- or better. CHEM M2LB with a grade of C- or better
CHEM M2C.restriction: Restriction: Chemistry Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CHEM M2LA.name: Majors General Chemistry Laboratory
CHEM M2LA.description: Training and experience in basic laboratory techniques through experiments related to lecture topics in CHEM 1A-CHEM 1B-CHEM M3C. Materials fee.

CHEM M2LB.name: Majors General Chemistry Laboratory
CHEM M2LB.description: Training and experience in basic laboratory techniques through experiments related to lecture topics in CHEM 1A-CHEM 1B-CHEM M3C. Materials fee.

CHEM M3C.name: Majors Quantitative Analytical Chemistry
CHEM M3C.description: Topics include equilibria, aqueous acid-base equilibria, solubility equilibria, oxidation reduction reactions, electrochemistry, and kinetics with a special emphasis on the statistical treatment of data and analytical methods of chemical analysis.
CHEM M3C.prereqString:
Corequisite: CHEM M3LC
Prerequisite: (CHEM 1B or CHEM H2B or CHEM M2B) and (CHEM M2LB or CHEM H2LB). CHEM 1B with a grade of C- or better. CHEM H2B with a grade of C- or better. CHEM M2B with a grade of C- or better. CHEM M2LB with a grade of C- or better. CHEM H2LB with a grade of C- or better

CHEM M3LC.name: Majors Quantitative Analytical Chemistry Laboratory
CHEM M3LC.description: Foundational principles of analytical chemistry and experimental methods for quantitative analysis of real samples. Materials fee.
CHEM M3LC.prereqString: Prerequisite: (CHEM 1B or CHEM H2B or CHEM M2B) and (CHEM M2LB or CHEM H2LB). CHEM 1B with a grade of C- or better. CHEM H2B with a grade of C- or better. CHEM M2B with a grade of C- or better. CHEM M2LB with a grade of C- or better. CHEM H2LB with a grade of C- or better

CHEM 5.name: Scientific Mathematical and Computing Skills
CHEM 5.description: Introduces students to mathematical skills, including complex numbers, linear algebra, differential equations, multivariable calculus, infinite series, Fourier series, and integral transforms
CHEM 5.restriction: Restriction: Chemistry Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CHEM 11.name: New Chemistry Student Seminar
CHEM 11.description: Seminar for students who recently joined the chemistry major. Addresses available tracks in the major, research opportunities in the chemistry department, careers in chemistry, and relevant programs and resources for students.
CHEM 11.restriction: Restriction: Freshmen students, transfer students, and students who recently changed their major to Chemistry have first consideration for enrollment.

CHEM 12.name: Chemistry Around Us
CHEM 12.description: Addresses ways in which chemistry affects everyday life. Topics include pollution, global warming, water supply/demands, biodiesel fuels, foods we eat, natural/synthetic materials, common drugs, drug design. Learn and apply basic chemistry concepts. Use risk/benefit analysis for optimal solutions.

CHEM 14.name: Sense and Sensibility in Science
CHEM 14.description: Gives an overview of scientific methods and heuristics through group exercises and discussion. Discusses the benefits and limitations of applying rational scientific approaches to real-world examples from philosophy, cognitive and social psychology, game theory, economics, political science, law, and negotiation.

CHEM 51A.name: Organic Chemistry
CHEM 51A.description: Fundamental concepts relating to carbon compounds with emphasis on structural theory and the nature of chemical bonding, stereochemistry, reaction mechanisms, and stereoscopic, physical, and chemical properties of the principal classes of carbon compounds.
CHEM 51A.restriction: Restriction: School of Biological Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Physical Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Engineering students have first consideration for enrollment. Program in Nursing Science students have first consideration for enrollment. Dept Pharmaceutical Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. Program in Public Health students have first consideration for enrollment. Undeclared Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CHEM 51B.name: Organic Chemistry
CHEM 51B.description: Fundamental concepts relating to carbon compounds with emphasis on structural theory and the nature of chemical bonding, stereochemistry, reaction mechanisms, and stereoscopic, physical, and chemical properties of the principal classes of carbon compounds.
CHEM 51B.prereqString: Prerequisite: CHEM 51A and (CHEM 1LD or CHEM M52LA or CHEM H52LA). CHEM 51A with a grade of C- or better. CHEM 1LD with a grade of C- or better. CHEM M52LA with a grade of C- or better. CHEM H52LA with a grade of C- or better
CHEM 51B.restriction: Restriction: Undeclared Majors have first consideration for enrollment. School of Physical Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Biological Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Engineering students have first consideration for enrollment. Program in Nursing Science students have first consideration for enrollment. Dept Pharmaceutical Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. Program in Public Health students have first consideration for enrollment.

CHEM 51C.description: Fundamental concepts relating to carbon compounds with emphasis on structural theory and the nature of chemical bonding, stereochemistry, reaction mechanisms, and stereoscopic, physical, and chemical properties of the principal classes of carbon compounds.
CHEM 51C.prereqString: Prerequisite: CHEM 51B and (CHEM 51LB or CHEM M52LB or CHEM H52LB). CHEM 51B with a grade of C- or better. CHEM 51LB with a grade of C- or better. CHEM M52LB with a grade of C- or better. CHEM H52LB with a grade of C- or better
CHEM 51C.restriction: Restriction: Undeclared Majors have first consideration for enrollment. School of Physical Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Biological Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Engineering students have first consideration for enrollment. Program in Nursing Science students have first consideration for enrollment. Dept Pharmaceutical Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. Program in Public Health students have first consideration for enrollment.

CHEM 51LB.description: Modern techniques of organic chemistry, using selected experiments to illustrate topics introduced in CHEM 51A-CHEM 51B-CHEM 51C. Materials fee.
CHEM 51LB.prereqString:
Corequisite: CHEM 51B
Prerequisite: CHEM 51A and (CHEM 1LD or CHEM H2LB or CHEM M2LB). CHEM 51A with a grade of C- or better. CHEM 1LD with a grade of C- or better. CHEM H2LB with a grade of C- or better. CHEM M2LB with a grade of C- or better
CHEM 51LB.restriction: Restriction: School of Biological Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Physical Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Engineering students have first consideration for enrollment. Program in Nursing Science students have first consideration for enrollment. Dept Pharmaceutical Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. Program in Public Health students have first consideration for enrollment. Prerequisite: CHEM 51B and CHEM 51LB. CHEM 51B with a grade of C- or better. CHEM 51LB with a grade of C- or better
CHEM 51LC.restriction: Restriction: School of Biological Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Physical Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Engineering students have first consideration for enrollment. Program in Nursing Science students have first consideration for enrollment. CHEM 51LD.description: Modern techniques of organic chemistry using selected experiments to illustrate topics introduced in CHEM 51A-CHEM 51B-CHEM 51C. Materials fee.
CHEM 51LD.prereqString: Prerequisite: CHEM 51C and CHEM 51LC. CHEM 51C with a grade of C- or better. CHEM 51LC with a grade of C- or better
CHEM 51LD.restriction: Restriction: School of Biological Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Physical Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. CHEM H52LA.prereqString:

Prerequisite: (CHEM 1C or CHEM H2C or CHEM M2C or CHEM M3C) and (CHEM M2LB or CHEM H2LB or CHEM 1LD). CHEM 1C with a grade of C- or better. CHEM H2C with a grade of C- or better. CHEM M2C with a grade of C- or better. CHEM M3C with a grade of C- or better. CHEM M2LB with a grade of C- or better. CHEM H2LB with a grade of C- or better. CHEM 1LD with a grade of C- or better

CHEM H52LC.description: Fundamental techniques of modern experimental organic chemistry. Materials fee.
CHEM H52LC.prereqString: Prerequisite: CHEM 51B and CHEM H52LB. CHEM 51B with a grade of C- or better. CHEM H52LB with a grade of C- or better

CHEM M52LA.description: Modern techniques of organic chemistry, using selected experiments to illustrate topics introduced in CHEM 51A-B-C. Materials fee.
CHEM M52LA.prereqString:
Corequisite: CHEM 51A
Prerequisite: (CHEM 1C or CHEM H2C or CHEM M2C or CHEM M3C) and (CHEM H2LB or CHEM M2LB or CHEM 1LD). CHEM 1C with a grade of C- or better. CHEM H2C with a grade of C- or better. CHEM M2C with a grade of C- or better. CHEM M3C with a grade of C- or better. CHEM H2LB with a grade of C- or better. CHEM M2LB with a grade of C- or better. CHEM 1LD with a grade of C- or better

CHEM M52LB.description: Modern techniques of organic chemistry, using selected experiments to illustrate topics introduced in CHEM 51A-B-C. Materials fee.

Prerequisite: CHEM 51A and CHEM M52LA. CHEM 51A with a grade of C- or better. CHEM M52LA with a grade of C- or better

CHEM M52LC.name: Majors Organic Chemistry Laboratory
CHEM M52LC.description: Modern techniques of organic chemistry, using selected experiments to illustrate topics introduced in CHEM 51A-B-C. Materials fee.
CHEM M52LC.prereqString:
Corequisite: CHEM 51C
Prerequisite: CHEM 51B and CHEM M52LB. CHEM 51B with a grade of C- or better. CHEM M52LB with a grade of C- or better

CHEM H90.name: The Idiom and Practice of Science
CHEM H90.description: A series of fundamental and applied problems in the chemical sciences are addressed. Topics may include the periodic table, electronic structure of atoms, chemical bonding, molecular structure, thermodynamics, and kinetics, with applications to energy and the environment, and/or biochemistry.
CHEM H90.restriction: Restriction: Campuswide Honors Collegium students only.

CHEM 100.name: Special Topics in Chemistry
CHEM 100.description: Devoted to current topics in the advanced fields of chemical sciences. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
CHEM 100.prereqString: Prerequisite: (CHEM 51C or CHEM H52C) and (CHEM M3C or CHEM M2C or CHEM 1C or CHEM H2C)
CHEM 100.restriction: Restriction: Chemistry Honors students only. Chemistry Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CHEM 100S.name: Laboratory Safety for Chemists
CHEM 100S.description: Provide students with the fundamentals of safety involved in chemical laboratory work.
CHEM 100S.restriction: Restriction: Chemistry Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CHEM 101W.name: Writing in Chemical Sciences
CHEM 101W.description: Students receive guidance on preparing research papers, proposals, reports, and other forms of scientific writing in chemistry-related fields, on effectively searching for and using chemical information, and on communicating data in poster and platform presentations.
CHEM 101W.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
CHEM 101W.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. Chemistry Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CHEM 107.name: Inorganic Chemistry
CHEM 107.description: Introduction to modern inorganic chemistry. Principles of structure, bonding, and chemical reactivity with application to compounds of the main group and transition elements, including organometallic chemistry.
CHEM 107.restriction: Restriction: Chemistry Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CHEM 107L.name: Inorganic Chemistry Laboratory
CHEM 107L.description: Modern techniques of inorganic and organometallic chemistry, including experience with glove box, Schlenk line, and vacuum line methods. Materials fee.
CHEM 107L.restriction: Restriction: Chemistry Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CHEM 125.name: Advanced Organic Chemistry
CHEM 125.description: Rapid-paced comprehensive treatment of organic chemistry.  Focuses  on molecular structure, reactivity, stability, scope and mechanisms of organic reactions. Topics include: structure and bonding
CHEM 125.restriction: Restriction: Chemistry Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CHEM 127.name: Inorganic Chemistry II
CHEM 127.description: Advanced treatment of selected fundamental topics in inorganic chemistry, building on material presented in Chemistry 107. Molecular symmetry with applications to electronic structure and spectroscopy.  Reaction kinetics and mechanisms
CHEM 127.restriction: Restriction: Chemistry Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CHEM 128.name: Introduction to Chemical Biology
CHEM 128.description: Introduction to the basic principles of chemical biology: structures and reactivity
CHEM 128.prereqString:
Corequisite: CHEM 128L
Prerequisite: (CHEM 51C or CHEM H52C)
CHEM 128.restriction: Restriction: Chemistry Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CHEM 128L.name: Introduction to Chemical Biology Laboratory Techniques
CHEM 128L.description: Introduction to the basic laboratory techniques of chemical biology: electrophoresis, plasmid preparation, PCR, protein expression, isolation, and kinetics. Materials fee.
CHEM 128L.restriction: Restriction: Chemistry Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CHEM 132A.name: Chemical Thermodynamics, Kinetics, and Dynamics
CHEM 132A.description: Energy, entropy, and the thermodynamic potentials. Chemical equilibrium. Chemical kinetics.
CHEM 132A.restriction: Restriction: Chemistry Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CHEM 132B.name: Quantum Principles, Spectroscopy, and Bonding
CHEM 132B.description: Principles of quantum chemistry with applications to the elements of atomic structure, energy levels, and spectroscopy.
CHEM 132B.prereqString: Prerequisite: (CHEM 132A or CBE 40C) and (PHYS 7D or PHYS 7E). CHEM 132A with a grade of C- or better
CHEM 132B.restriction: Restriction: Chemistry Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CHEM 132C.name: Molecular Structure and Elementary Statistical Mechanics
CHEM 132C.description: Principles of quantum mechanics with applications to molecular spectroscopy and structure determination, and chemical bonding in simple molecules. Elements of statistical mechanics.
CHEM 132C.restriction: Restriction: Chemistry Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CHEM 133.name: Nuclear and Radiochemistry
CHEM 133.description: Advanced treatment of nuclear structure, nuclear reactions, and radioactive-decay processes. Introduction to nuclear activation analysis, isotope effects, radiation chemistry, hot-atom chemistry, nuclear age-dating methods, nuclear reactors, and nuclear power.
CHEM 133.prereqString: Prerequisite: (CHEM M3C or CHEM 1C or CHEM H2C or CHEM M2C) and MATH 2D
CHEM 133.restriction: Restriction: Chemistry Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Chemical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CHEM 133L.name: Nuclear and Radiochemistry Laboratory
CHEM 133L.description: Practical aspects of production, separation, safe handling, detection, and measurement of radioactive isotopes. Experiments use the UCI nuclear reactor and emphasize uses of radioisotopes in chemistry, engineering, biology, and medicine.  Materials fee.
CHEM 133L.restriction: Restriction: Chemistry Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CHEM 137.name: Computational Chemistry
CHEM 137.description: Short introduction to programming languages and to representative algorithms employed in chemical research. Students have the opportunity to devise and employ their own codes and also to employ codes which are widely used in various fields of chemistry. Materials fee.
CHEM 137.prereqString:
Corequisite: CHEM 132C
Prerequisite: CHEM 51C and (CHEM 131A or CHEM 132B)
CHEM 137.restriction: Restriction: Chemistry Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CHEM 138.name: Introduction to Computational Organic Chemistry
CHEM 138.description: An introduction to the use of computational chemistry to investigate reaction mechanisms, to calculate structures, and to predict properties of molecules. Students have the opportunity to perform calculations employing computational methods which are widely used in various fields of chemistry. Materials fee.
CHEM 138.restriction: Restriction: Chemistry Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CHEM 141.name: Environmental Chemistry
CHEM 141.description: Processes that control the fate of chemicals in the environment. Chemistry of the atmosphere, hydrosphere, and soils, especially as it pertains to pollutants.
CHEM 141.prereqString: Prerequisite: (CHEM 51C or CHEM H52C) and (MATH 2B or AP Calculus BC). AP Calculus BC with a minimum score of 4

CHEM 145A.name: Gas-Phase Atmospheric Chemistry
CHEM 145A.description: Sources, chemistry, sinks, and measurements of key atmospheric gaseous species. Chemistry of photochemical oxidant formation, transformation of key inorganic and organic trace gases, and stratospheric ozone cycling. Applications of atmospheric chemistry models to control strategies.
CHEM 145A.prereqString: Prerequisite: CHEM 132A and CHEM 132B and CHEM 132C

CHEM 145B.name: Multi-Phase Atmospheric Chemistry
CHEM 145B.description: Chemical and physical processes leading to the production, aging, and removal of atmospheric particles. Multi-phase processes involving gases, particles, water droplets, and environmental surfaces. Approaches for modeling these processes with applications to control strategies.

CHEM 150.name: Computational Chemistry
CHEM 150.description: Basic concepts, methods, and techniques in computational chemistry: density functional and wavefunction theory, molecular property calculations, analysis tools, potential energy surfaces, vibrational effects, molecular dynamics simulations.
CHEM 150.restriction: Restriction: Chemistry Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CHEM 150L.name: Computational Chemistry Laboratory
CHEM 150L.description: Introduction to the practice of modern computational chemistry through a series of advanced computational experiments.
CHEM 150L.prereqString: Prerequisite: CHEM 150 and (CHEM 5 or PHYS 50 or EECS 12)
CHEM 150L.restriction: Restriction: Chemistry Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CHEM 152.name: Advanced Analytical Chemistry
CHEM 152.description: In-depth treatment of modern instrumental methods for quantitative analysis of real samples and basic principles of instrument design. Laboratory experiments using spectroscopic, chromatographic, mass spectrometric, and other instrumental methods. Materials fee.
CHEM 152.prereqString: Prerequisite: (CHEM 1C or CHEM M3C or CHEM H2C or CHEM M2C) and (CHEM M3LC or CHEM H2LC)
CHEM 152.restriction: Restriction: Chemistry Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CHEM 153.name: Physical Chemistry Laboratory
CHEM 153.description: Introduction to the modern experimental approaches and software tools used in spectroscopy, kinetics, electrochemistry, and other physical chemistry experiments. Basics of interfacing with instruments using LabView. Materials fee.
CHEM 153.restriction: Restriction: Chemistry Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CHEM 156.name: Advanced Laboratory in Chemistry and Synthesis of Materials
CHEM 156.description: Modern synthesis and characterization of organic and inorganic materials including polymers, nanomaterials, and biomaterials. State-of-the-art characterization techniques include gel permeation chromatography, dynamic light scattering, thermal analysis, mechanical analysis, electron and scanning probe microscopy, X-ray diffraction, and porosimetry. Materials fee.
CHEM 156.prereqString: Prerequisite: (CHEM 51C or CHEM H52C) and (CHEM 51LC or CHEM H52LC or CHEM M52LC) and (CHEM 131A or CHEM 132B or PHMS 171)
CHEM 156.restriction: Restriction: Chemistry Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CHEM 160.name: Organic Synthesis Laboratory
CHEM 160.description: Modern experimental techniques in organic synthesis including experience with thin-layer chromatography, liquid chromatography, and gas chromatography. Modern methods of structure elucidation including FT NMR are employed in the characterization of products. Materials fee.
CHEM 160.restriction: Restriction: Chemistry Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CHEM 177.name: Medicinal Chemistry
CHEM 177.description: An introduction of the basics of drug activity and mechanisms. Strategies used to identify lead compounds such as natural product chemistry, combinatorial chemistry, molecular modeling, and high-through put screening.  Relationship of molecular structure to pharmacological activity.
CHEM 177.prereqString: Prerequisite: CHEM 51A and CHEM 51B and CHEM 51C and (BIOL 98 or CHEM 128)
CHEM 177.restriction: Restriction: Pharmaceutical Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CHEM 177L.name: Medicinal Chemistry Laboratory
CHEM 177L.description: An introduction of the basics of drug activity and mechanisms. Strategies used to identify lead compounds such as natural product chemistry, combinatorial chemistry, molecular modeling, and high-through put screening.  Relationship of molecular structure to pharmacological activity. Materials fee.
CHEM 177L.prereqString:
Corequisite: PHRMSCI 177 or CHEM 177.
Prerequisite: CHEM 51A and CHEM 51B and CHEM 51C and BIOL 100 and (BIOL 98 or CHEM 128)
CHEM 177L.restriction: Restriction: Pharmaceutical Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CHEM 180.name: Undergraduate Research
CHEM 180.description: Research for credit arranged with a faculty member to sponsor and supervise work. Student time commitment of 10 to 15 hours per week is expected, and a written research report is required at the end of each quarter.

CHEM 180W.name: Senior Thesis in Chemistry
CHEM 180W.description: Students receive guidance on preparing research papers, proposals, reports, and other forms of scientific writing in chemistry-related fields
CHEM 180W.prereqString: Prerequisite: CHEM 180 or CHEM 199 or PHYS 195 or ESS 199 or CEMS 199 or CEE 199 or MAE 199 or BIOL 199 or PUBH 199. CHEM 180 with a grade of A or better. CHEM 199 with a grade of A or better. PHYS 195 with a grade of A or better. ESS 199 with a grade of A or better. CEMS 199 with a grade of A or better. CEE 199 with a grade of A or better. MAE 199 with a grade of A or better. BIOL 199 with a grade of A or better. PUBH 199 with a grade of A or better. Consent of the instructor is also accepted. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
CHEM 180W.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. Chemistry Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CHEM H180A.name: Honors Research in Chemistry
CHEM H180A.description: Undergraduate honors research in Chemistry. A student time commitment of 10-15 hours per week is required.
CHEM H180A.restriction: Restriction: Chemistry Honors students only. Campuswide Honors Collegium students only.

CHEM H180B.name: Honors Research in Chemistry
CHEM H180B.description: Undergraduate honors research in Chemistry. A student time commitment of 10-15 hours per week is required.
CHEM H180B.restriction: Restriction: Campuswide Honors Collegium students only.

CHEM H180C.name: Honors Research in Chemistry
CHEM H180C.description: Undergraduate honors research in Chemistry.  A student time committment of 10-15 hours per week is required.
CHEM H180C.restriction: Restriction: Chemistry Honors students only. Chemistry majors participating in the Campuswide Honors Program students only.

CHEM H181W.name: Honors Seminar in Chemistry
CHEM H181W.description: Students will receive guidance in the preparation of oral and written research presentations.  A written thesis will be prepared and a formal research seminar will be presented.
CHEM H181W.prereqString:
Corequisite: CHEM H180C
Prerequisite: CHEM H180A and CHEM H180B. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

CHEM 191.name: Chemistry Outreach Program
CHEM 191.description: Involves intensive participation in the UCI Chemistry Outreach Program, which performs Chemistry demonstrations at local high schools.

CHEM 192.name: Tutoring in Chemistry
CHEM 192.description: Enrollment limited to participants in the Chemistry Peer Tutoring Program.
CHEM 192.restriction: Restriction: The first eight may be taken for a letter grade. The remaining ten units must be taken Pass/Not Pass only. NOTE: No more than eight units may be counted toward the 180 units required for graduation. Satisfies no degree requirement other than contribution to the 180-unit total.

CHEM 193.name: Research Methods
CHEM 193.description: Explores tools of inquiry for developing and implementing science research projects.  Students undertake independent projects requiring data collection, analysis, and modeling, and the organization and presentation of results.  Additional topics include ethical issues and role of scientific literature.

CHEM 197.name: Professional Internship
CHEM 197.description: Internship program that provides students with opportunity to develop professional skills necessary for competitive placement in their chosen chemical-inspired industry. Students gain new and field-specific skills outside the classroom while participating in a supervised internship.
CHEM 197.prereqString: Prerequisite: Enrollment requires completion of an application form. Student selection is made by a selection committee.
CHEM 197.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. Chemistry Majors only.

CHEM 199.name: Independent Study in Chemistry
CHEM 199.description: Independent research with Chemistry faculty.  Student time commitment of three to four hours per week per unit is expected, and a written report on the independent study is required at the end of each quarter of enrollment.

CHEM 200.name: Conduct of Research
CHEM 200.description: Introduces new graduate students to ethical conduct of scientific research, mentoring, and current research in the Department of chemistry.

CHEM 201.name: Organic Reaction Mechanisms I
CHEM 201.description: Advanced treatment of basic mechanistic principles of modern organic chemistry. Topics include molecular orbital theory, orbital symmetry control of organic reactions, aromaticity, carbonium ion chemistry, free radical chemistry, the chemistry of carbenes and carbanions, photochemistry, electrophilic substitutions, aromatic chemistry.
CHEM 201.prereqString: Prerequisite: CHEM 132A and CHEM 132B and CHEM 132C

CHEM 202.name: Organic Reaction Mechanisms II
CHEM 202.description: Topics include more in-depth treatment of mechanistic concepts, kinetics, conformational analysis, computational methods, stereoelectronics, and both solution and enzymatic catalysis.

CHEM 203.name: Organic Spectroscopy
CHEM 203.description: Modern methods used in structure determination of organic molecules. Topics include mass spectrometry
CHEM 203.prereqString: Prerequisite: (CHEM 51A and CHEM 51B and CHEM 51C) or (CHEM H52A and CHEM H52B and CHEM H52C)

CHEM 204.name: Organic Synthesis I
CHEM 204.description: Fundamentals of modern synthetic organic chemistry is developed. Major emphasis is on carbon-carbon bond forming methodology. Topics include carbonyl annelations, cycloadditions, sigmatropic rearrangements, and organometallic methods.

CHEM 205.name: Organic Synthesis II
CHEM 205.description: Fundamentals of modern synthetic organic chemistry will be developed. Major emphasis this quarter is on natural product total synthesis and retrosynthetic (antithetic) analysis.

CHEM 206.name: Advanced Data Acquisition and Analysis
CHEM 206.description: Introduces students to a variety of practical laboratory techniques, including lock-in, boxcar, coincidence counting, noise filtering, PID control, properties of common transducers, computer interfacing to instruments, vacuum technology, laboratory safety, basic mechanical design, and shop skills. Materials fee.

CHEM 207.name: Applied Physical Chemistry
CHEM 207.description: Introduction to fundamental concepts in molecular structure and reactivity: theory of bonding, valence and molecular orbitals

CHEM 208.name: Math Methods
CHEM 208.description: Applications of mathematics to physical and chemical problems. Calculus of special functions, complex variables and vectors

CHEM 213.name: Chemical Kinetics
CHEM 213.description: Surveys gas phase and organic reaction mechanisms and their relationship to kinetic rate laws
CHEM 213.prereqString: Prerequisite: CHEM 132A and CHEM 132B and CHEM 132C

CHEM 215.name: Inorganic Chemistry I
CHEM 215.description: Principles of modern inorganic chemistry with applications to chemical systems of current interest. Inorganic phenomena are organized into general patterns which rationalize observed structures, stabilities, and physical properties.
CHEM 215.prereqString: Prerequisite: CHEM 107 and CHEM 132A and CHEM 132B and CHEM 132C

CHEM 216.name: Organometallic Chemistry
CHEM 216.description: Synthesis and reactivity of organometallic complexes with an emphasis on mechanisms. Topics include bonding and fluxional properties

CHEM 217.name: Physical Inorganic Chemistry
CHEM 217.description: General principles of the spectroscopy and magnetism of inorganic compounds. Characterization of inorganic complexes by infrared, near-infrared, visible, ultraviolet, NMR, EPR, EXAFS, and Mossbauer spectroscopies. Some necessary group theory developed.

CHEM 218.name: Metallobiochemistry
CHEM 218.description: A review of the biochemistry of metallic elements emphasizing: methods for studying metals in biological systems

CHEM 219.name: Chemical and Structural Biology
CHEM 219.description: A survey of the organic chemistry underlying biological function. Introduction to chemical genetics, receptor-ligand interactions, small molecule agonists and antagonists, combinatorial synthesis, high throughput assays, molecular evolution, protein and small molecule design.

CHEM 221A.name: Fundamentals of Molecular Biophysics
CHEM 221A.description: An overview of the principles and concepts in molecular biophysics.  Topics covered include energy and entropy in biology, non-equilibrium reaction kinetics, random walks and molecular diffusion, molecular forces in biology.
CHEM 221A.prereqString: Prerequisite: Undergraduate courses in physical chemistry and biochemistry.

CHEM 223.name: Biological Macromolecules
CHEM 223.description: Introduction to nucleic acid and protein structure, dynamics, and function. Topics include analytical methods, molecular evolution, folding, and catalysis.

CHEM 224.name: Molecular and Cellular Biophotonics
CHEM 224.description: Principles underlying the application of photonic technologies to biomolecular and cellular systems. Sample technologies Optical Tweezers, Linear and Nonlinear Optical Microscopy and Fluorescence Lifetime and Correlation Methods, and their use to investigate emergent problems in Molecular, Cellular, and Developmental Biology.

CHEM 225.name: Polymer Chemistry:  Synthesis and Characterization of Polymers
