CHEM 225.description: Structure of synthetic and natural polymers.  Survey of modern polymer synthetic methods.  Molecular weight and molecular weight distribution.  Chain conformation and stereochemistry. Introduction to polymer characterization, chain models, and solution behavior.
CHEM 225.prereqString: Prerequisite: Undergraduate courses in organic and physical chemistry.

CHEM 228.name: Electromagnetism
CHEM 228.description: Maxwell’s equations, electrodynamics, electromagnetic waves and radiation, wave propagation in media, interference and quantum optics, coherent and incoherent radiation, with practical applications in interferometry, lasers, waveguides, and optical instrumentation.

CHEM 229A.name: Computational Methods
CHEM 229A.description: Mathematical and numerical analysis using Mathematica and C programming, as applied to problems in physical science.

CHEM 230.name: Classical Mechanics and Electromagnetic Theory
CHEM 230.description: Fundamentals of classical mechanics and electromagnetic theory are developed with specific application to molecular systems. Newtonian, Lagrangian, and Hamiltonian mechanics are developed. Boundary value problems in electrostatics are investigated. Multipole expansion and macroscopic media are discussed from a molecular viewpoint.
CHEM 230.prereqString: Prerequisite: CHEM 132A and CHEM 132B and CHEM 132C

CHEM 231A.name: Fundamentals of Quantum Mechanics
CHEM 231A.description: The postulates of quantum mechanics are discussed and applied to a variety of model problems.
CHEM 231A.prereqString: Prerequisite: CHEM 131A and CHEM 131B and CHEM 131C

CHEM 231B.name: Applications of Quantum Mechanics
CHEM 231B.description: Approximate methods for solving atomic and molecular structure problems are developed, and the application of quantum mechanics to spectroscopy is introduced.

CHEM 231C.name: Molecular Spectroscopy
CHEM 231C.description: Theory and techniques of spectroscopy as used for the study of molecular and condensed phase properties. Coherent time domain spectroscopies are covered.

CHEM 232A.name: Thermodynamics and Introduction to Statistical Mechanics
CHEM 232A.description: A detailed discussion from an advanced point of view of the principles of classical thermodynamics. The fundamentals of statistical mechanics. Topics include an introduction to ensemble theory, Boltzmann statistics, classical statistical mechanics, and the statistical mechanics of ideal gas systems.
CHEM 232A.prereqString: Prerequisite: CHEM 131A and CHEM 131B and CHEM 131C

CHEM 232B.name: Advanced Topics in Statistical Mechanics
CHEM 232B.description: Continued discussion of the principles of statistical mechanics. Applications to topics of chemical interest including imperfect gases, liquids, solutions, and crystals. Modern techniques such as the use of autocorrelation function methods.

CHEM 232C.name: Non-Equilibrium Statistical Mechanics
CHEM 232C.description: Phenomenology of material processes, including: kinetic theories of transport and continuum, linear response theory, critical phenomena of phase transition, self-assembly, and nucleation.

CHEM 233.name: Nuclear and Radiochemistry
CHEM 233.description: Advanced treatment of nuclear structure, nuclear reactions, and radioactive-decay processes. Introduction to nuclear activation analysis, isotope effects, radiation chemistry, hot-atom chemistry, nuclear age-dating methods, nuclear reactors, and nuclear power.

CHEM 237.name: Mathematical Methods in Chemistry
CHEM 237.description: Survey of essential math methods in chemistry. Topics may include series and limits, complex analysis, Fourier and Laplace transforms, linear algebra and operators (theory and algorithms), differential equations, and probability concepts for stochastic processes.

CHEM 241.name: Current Issues Related to Air Quality, Climate, and Energy
CHEM 241.description: Current issues related to the atmosphere, climate, and air quality in the context of energy conversion and sustainability. Topics include transportation systems
CHEM 241.prereqString: Prerequisite: MAE 261 or CHEM 245 or ESS 240

CHEM 243.name: Advanced Instrumental Analysis
CHEM 243.description: Theory and applications of modern advanced instrumental methods of analysis. Includes data acquisition, storage, retrieval, and analysis
CHEM 243.prereqString: Prerequisite: CHEM 152 and CHEM 132C. CHEM 152 with a grade of B or better. CHEM 132C with a grade of B or better

CHEM 244.name: Detection and Measurement of Radiation
CHEM 244.description: Basic principles of detection and measurement of ionizing radiation

CHEM 245A.name: Gas-Phase Atmospheric Chemistry
CHEM 245A.description: Sources, chemistry, sinks, and measurements of key atmospheric gaseous species. Chemistry of photochemical oxidant formation, transformation of key inorganic and organic trace gases, and stratospheric ozone cycling. Applications of atmospheric chemistry models to control strategies.
CHEM 245A.prereqString: Prerequisite: CHEM 132A and CHEM 132B and CHEM 132C

CHEM 245B.name: Multi-Phase Atmospheric Chemistry
CHEM 245B.description: Chemical and physical processes leading to the production, aging, and removal of atmospheric particles. Multi-phase processes involving gases, particles, water droplets, and environmental surfaces. Approaches for modeling these processes with applications to control strategies.

CHEM 245C.name: Special Topics in Atmospheric Chemistry
CHEM 245C.description: The subjects covered vary from year to year.

CHEM 246.name: Separations and Chromatography
CHEM 246.description: Introduction to modern separation techniques such as gas chromatography, high-performance liquid chromatography, supercritical fluid chromatography, capillary electrophoresis, and field flow fractionation. Applications of these separation strategies are discussed.

CHEM 247.name: Current Problems in Analytical Chemistry
CHEM 247.description: Surveys current research challenges in analytical chemistry. Topics include electrochemistry, chromatography, spectroscopy, and mass spectrometry.

CHEM 248.name: Electrochemistry
CHEM 248.description: Fundamentals of electrochemistry including thermodynamics and the electrochemical potential, charge transfer kinetics, and mass transfer. Methods based on controlled potential and controlled current are described

CHEM 249.name: Analytical Spectroscopy
CHEM 249.description: Advanced treatment of spectroscopic techniques and instrumentation. Atomic and molecular absorption, emission, and scattering processes and their application to quantitative chemical analysis are outlined. Puts different spectroscopic techniques in perspective and demonstrates most appropriate applications to analytical problems.

CHEM 250.name: Computational Chemistry
CHEM 250.description: Basic concepts, methods, and techniques in computational chemistry: density functional and wavefunction theory, molecular property calculations, analysis tools, potential energy surfaces, vibrational effects, molecular dynamics simulations.

CHEM 250L.name: Computational Chemistry Laboratory
CHEM 250L.description: Introduction to the practice of modern computational chemistry through a series of advanced computational experiments.

CHEM 252.name: Special Topics in Physical Chemistry
CHEM 252.description: Advanced topics in physical chemistry. Materials fee.

CHEM 254.name: Special Topics in Computational and Theoretical Chemistry
CHEM 254.description: Subjects covered vary from year to year.

CHEM 263.name: Materials Chemistry
CHEM 263.description: An introduction to crystalline solids, descriptive crystal chemistry, solid-state synthesis and characterization techniques, x-ray and electron diffraction, phase diagrams, electronic band structure of extended solids, semi conductors, and nanoscale inorganic materials.

CHEM 264.name: Analytical Methods for Organic Nanomaterials
CHEM 264.description: Fundamentals of analytical techniques related to measuring the structure and dynamics of organic nanomaterials. Topics include transmission electron microscopy, cryo-electron microscopy, liquid phase electron microscopy, scanning electron microscopy, atomic force microscopy, light scattering, small angle X-ray, and neutron scattering.

CHEM 266.name: Current Topics in Chemical, Applied, and Materials Physics
CHEM 266.description: The subjects covered vary from year to year.  Connection between fundamental principles and implementations in practice in science, industry, and technology.

CHEM 267.name: Photochemistry
CHEM 267.description: Photochemical and photovoltaic processes in molecules and semiconductors
CHEM 267.restriction: Restriction: Seniors only. Graduate students only.

CHEM 268.name: NMR Spectroscopy
CHEM 268.description: Students learn the theoretical basis of solid-state or solution NMR (alternate times), including the basics of pulse sequence design. Extensive literature reading is required.

CHEM 273.name: Technical Communication Skills
CHEM 273.description: Development of effective communication skills, oral and written presentations, through examples and practice.

CHEM 280.name: Research
CHEM 280.description: Supervised original research toward the preparation of a Ph.D dissertation or M.S. thesis.

CHEM 290.name: Seminar
CHEM 290.description: Weekly seminars and discussions on general and varied topics of current interest in chemistry.

CHEM 291.name: Research Seminar
CHEM 291.description: Detailed discussion of research problems of current interest in the Department. Format, content, and frequency of the course are variable.

CHEM 292.name: Graduate Symposium
CHEM 292.description: Students present public seminars on literature-based research topics in contemporary chemistry.  Topics to be chosen by student and approved by instructor.

CHEM 399.name: University Teaching
CHEM 399.description: Required of and limited to Teaching Assistants.

CHINESE 1A.name: Fundamental Mandarin Chinese
CHINESE 1A.description: Natural approach emphasizing four fundamental skills: listening, speaking, reading and writing. Specifically designed for students with no previous experience in any dialect of Chinese. Conducted in Mandarin Chinese using the Pinyin system of Romanization, traditional and simplified Chinese characters.
CHINESE 1A.prereqString: Prerequisite: Placement into CHINESE 1A is also accepted.
CHINESE 1A.restriction: Restriction: CHINESE 1A and CHINESE 1DA and CHINESE 1MA and CHINESE S1AB may not be taken for full credit.

CHINESE 1B.name: Fundamental Mandarin Chinese
CHINESE 1B.description: Natural approach emphasizing four fundamental skills: listening, speaking, reading and writing. Specifically designed for students with no previous experience in any dialect of Chinese. Conducted in Mandarin Chinese using the Pinyin system of Romanization, traditional and simplified Chinese characters.
CHINESE 1B.prereqString: Prerequisite: CHINESE 1A. CHINESE 1A with a grade of C or better. Placement into CHINESE 1B is also accepted.
CHINESE 1B.restriction: Restriction: CHINESE 1B and CHINESE 1DB and CHINESE 1MB and CHINESE S1AB and CHINESE S1BC may not be taken for full credit.

CHINESE 1C.name: Fundamental Mandarin Chinese
CHINESE 1C.description: Natural approach emphasizing four fundamental skills: listening, speaking, reading and writing. Specifically designed for students with no previous experience in any dialect of Chinese. Conducted in Mandarin Chinese using the Pinyin system of Romanization, traditional and simplified Chinese characters.
CHINESE 1C.prereqString: Prerequisite: CHINESE 1B or CHINESE S1AB. CHINESE 1B with a grade of C or better. CHINESE S1AB with a grade of C or better. Placement into CHINESE 1C is also accepted.
CHINESE 1C.restriction: Restriction: CHINESE 1C and CHINESE 1DC and CHINESE 1MC and CHINESE S1BC may not be taken for full credit.

CHINESE 1MA.name: Fundamentals of Mandarin Chinese - Mandarin Background Track
CHINESE 1MA.description: Natural approach emphasizing four fundamental skills: listening, speaking, reading and writing. Specifically designed for students with previous background in Mandarin Chinese.  Conducted in Mandarin Chinese using the Pinyin system of Romanization, traditional and simplified Chinese characters.
CHINESE 1MA.restriction: Restriction: CHINESE 1MA and CHINESE 1DA and CHINESE 1A and CHINESE S1AB may not be taken for full credit.

CHINESE 1MB.name: Fundamentals of Mandarin Chinese - Mandarin Background Track
CHINESE 1MB.description: Natural approach emphasizing four fundamental skills: listening, speaking, reading and writing. Specifically designed for students with previous background in Mandarin Chinese. Conducted in Mandarin Chinese using the Pinyin system of Romanization, traditional and simplified Chinese characters.
CHINESE 1MB.prereqString: Prerequisite: CHINESE 1MA. CHINESE 1MA with a grade of C or better. Placement into CHINESE 1MB is also accepted.
CHINESE 1MB.restriction: Restriction: CHINESE 1MB and CHINESE 1DB and CHINESE 1B and CHINESE S1AB and CHINESE S1BC may not be taken for full credit.

CHINESE 1MC.name: Fundamentals of Mandarin Chinese - Mandarin Background Track
CHINESE 1MC.description: Natural approach emphasizing four fundamental skills: listening, speaking, reading and writing. Specifically designed for students with previous background in Mandarin Chinese. Conducted in Mandarin Chinese using the Pinyin system of Romanization, traditional and simplified Chinese characters.
CHINESE 1MC.prereqString: Prerequisite: CHINESE 1MB. CHINESE 1MB with a grade of C or better. Placement into CHINESE 1MC is also accepted.
CHINESE 1MC.restriction: Restriction: CHINESE 1MC and CHINESE 1DC and CHINESE 1C and CHINESE S1BC may not be taken for full credit.

CHINESE S1AB.name: Fundamentals of Mandarin Chinese
CHINESE S1AB.description: First half of first-year Mandarin Chinese in an intensive setting using natural approach with emphasis on listening, speaking, reading, and writing.
CHINESE S1AB.prereqString: Prerequisite: Placement into CHINESE 1A or CHINESE 1B.

CHINESE S1BC.name: Fundamentals of Mandarin Chinese
CHINESE S1BC.description: Second half of first-year Mandarin Chinese in an intensive setting using natural approach with emphasis on listening, speaking, reading, and writing.
CHINESE S1BC.prereqString: Prerequisite: CHINESE S1AB or CHINESE 1B. CHINESE S1AB with a grade of C or better. CHINESE 1B with a grade of C or better. Placement into CHINESE 1C or CHINESE 1DC or CHINESE 1MC is also accepted.

CHINESE 2A.name: Intermediate Mandarin Chinese
CHINESE 2A.description: Both authentic and pedagogically-prepared materials are used to further develop students' ability to communicate in culturally, socially, and linguistically appropriate manners. Taught in Chinese using Pinyin romanization system and both traditional and simplified forms of Chinese.
CHINESE 2A.prereqString: Prerequisite: CHINESE 1C or CHINESE S1BC or CHINESE 1MC. CHINESE 1C with a grade of C or better. CHINESE S1BC with a grade of C or better. CHINESE 1MC with a grade of C or better. Placement into CHINESE 2A is also accepted.

CHINESE 2B.name: Intermediate Mandarin Chinese
CHINESE 2B.description: Both authentic and pedagogically-prepared materials are used to further develop students' ability to communicate in culturally, socially, and linguistically appropriate manners. Taught in Chinese using Pinyin romanization system and both traditional and simplified forms of Chinese.
CHINESE 2B.prereqString: Prerequisite: CHINESE 2A. CHINESE 2A with a grade of C or better. Placement into CHINESE 2B is also accepted.
CHINESE 2B.restriction: Restriction: CHINESE 2B and CHINESE 2DB and CHINESE 2MB may not be taken for full credit.

CHINESE 2C.name: Intermediate Mandarin Chinese
CHINESE 2C.description: Both authentic and pedagogically-prepared materials are used to further develop students' ability to communicate in culturally, socially, and linguistically appropriate manners. Taught in Chinese using Pinyin romanization system and both traditional and simplified forms of Chinese.
CHINESE 2C.prereqString: Prerequisite: CHINESE 2B. CHINESE 2B with a grade of C or better. Placement into CHINESE 2C is also accepted.
CHINESE 2C.restriction: Restriction: CHINESE 2C and CHINESE 2DC and CHINESE 2MC may not be taken for full credit.

CHINESE 2MA.name: Intermediate Mandarin Chinese - Mandarin Background Track
CHINESE 2MA.description: Authentic and pedagogically prepared materials are used to further develop communication in culturally, socially, and linguistically appropriate manners for students with initial experience in Mandarin Chinese. Conducted in Mandarin using the Pinyin Romanization system, traditional and simplified Chinese characters.
CHINESE 2MA.prereqString: Prerequisite: CHINESE 1MC or CHINESE S1BC. CHINESE 1MC with a grade of C or better. CHINESE S1BC with a grade of C or better. Placement into CHINESE 2MA is also accepted.
CHINESE 2MA.restriction: Restriction: CHINESE 2MA and CHINESE 2DA and CHINESE 2A may not be taken for full credit.

CHINESE 2MB.name: Intermediate Mandarin Chinese - Mandarin Background Track
CHINESE 2MB.description: Authentic and pedagogically prepared materials are used to further develop communication in culturally, socially, and linguistically appropriate manners for students with initial experience in Mandarin Chinese. Conducted in Mandarin using the Pinyin Romanization system, traditional and simplified Chinese characters.
CHINESE 2MB.prereqString: Prerequisite: CHINESE 2MA. CHINESE 2MA with a grade of C or better. Placement into CHINESE 2MB is also accepted.
CHINESE 2MB.restriction: Restriction: CHINESE 2MB and CHINESE 2DB and CHINESE 2B may not be taken for full credit.

CHINESE 2MC.name: Intermediate Mandarin Chinese - Mandarin Background Track
CHINESE 2MC.description: Authentic and pedagogically prepared materials are used to further develop communication in culturally, socially, and linguistically appropriate manners for students with initial experience in Mandarin Chinese. Conducted in Mandarin using the Pinyin Romanization system, traditional and simplified Chinese characters.
CHINESE 2MC.prereqString: Prerequisite: CHINESE 2MB. CHINESE 2MB with a grade of C or better. Placement into CHINESE 2MC is also accepted.
CHINESE 2MC.restriction: Restriction: CHINESE 2MC and CHINESE 2DC and CHINESE 2C may not be taken for full credit.

CHINESE 3A.name: Advanced Mandarin Chinese
CHINESE 3A.description: A continuation of CHINESE 2A-CHINESE 2B-CHINESE 2C emphasizing conceptualization, self-expression and academic skills in Chinese. Authentic texts from modern Chinese prose and newspapers are used. Taught in Mandarin Chinese using both traditional and simplified forms of Chinese characters.
CHINESE 3A.prereqString: Prerequisite: CHINESE 2C or CHINESE 2DC or CHINESE 2MC. CHINESE 2C with a grade of C or better. CHINESE 2DC with a grade of C or better. CHINESE 2MC with a grade of C or better. Placement into CHINESE 3A is also accepted.

CHINESE 3B.name: Advanced Mandarin Chinese
CHINESE 3B.description: A continuation of CHINESE 2A-CHINESE 2B-CHINESE 2C emphasizing conceptualization, self-expression, and academic skills in Chinese. Authentic texts from modern Chinese prose and newspapers are used. Taught in Mandarin Chinese using both traditional and simplified forms of Chinese characters.
CHINESE 3B.prereqString: Prerequisite: CHINESE 3A. CHINESE 3A with a grade of C or better

CHINESE 3C.name: Advanced Mandarin Chinese
CHINESE 3C.description: A continuation of CHINESE 2A-CHINESE 2B-CHINESE 2C emphasizing conceptualization, self-expression, and academic skills in Chinese. Authentic texts from modern Chinese prose and newspapers are used. Taught in Mandarin Chinese using both traditional and simplified forms of Chinese characters.
CHINESE 3C.prereqString: Prerequisite: CHINESE 3B. CHINESE 3B with a grade of C or better

CHINESE 10.name: Peer Tutoring Program
CHINESE 10.description: Tutoring Program in which advanced Chinese students provide assistance to students at a lower level. One hour of tutoring per week.

CHINESE 40.name: Topics in Professional Chinese
CHINESE 40.description: Designed for students with native or near native fluency in Chinese. Develops students’ language learning to professional levels with cultural and contextual knowledge and with formal communication and presentation skills.
CHINESE 40.prereqString: Prerequisite: CHINESE 3C. CHINESE 3C with a grade of C or better. Native speakers also accepted.

CHINESE 100A.name: Classical Chinese
CHINESE 100A.description: Introduction to classical Chinese grammar and vocabulary with emphasis on reading basic texts.
CHINESE 100A.prereqString: Prerequisite: CHINESE 3C or JAPANSE 3C or KOREAN 3C

CHINESE 100B.name: Classical Chinese
CHINESE 100B.description: Introduction to classical Chinese grammar and vocabulary with emphasis on reading basic texts.
CHINESE 100B.prereqString: Prerequisite: CHINESE 3C or JAPANSE 3C or KOREAN 3C

CHINESE 100C.name: Classical Chinese
CHINESE 100C.description: Introduction to classical Chinese grammar and vocabulary with emphasis on reading basic texts.
CHINESE 100C.prereqString: Prerequisite: CHINESE 3C or JAPANSE 3C or KOREAN 3C

CHINESE 101A.name: Fourth-Year Mandarin Chinese
CHINESE 101A.description: Continued emphasis on comprehension, grammar, and proficiency in reading, composition, and conversation through intensive study and analysis of specific literary texts.

CHINESE 101B.name: Fourth-Year Mandarin Chinese
CHINESE 101B.description: Continued emphasis on comprehension, grammar, and proficiency in reading, composition, and conversation through intensive study and analysis of specific literary texts.

CHINESE 101C.name: Fourth-Year Mandarin Chinese
CHINESE 101C.description: Continued emphasis on comprehension, grammar, and proficiency in reading, composition, and conversation through intensive study and analysis of specific literary texts.

CHINESE 115.name: Topics in Chinese Literature: Advanced Texts
CHINESE 115.description: Designed for students with near-fluency in reading Chinese. Readings may include both literary and philosophical work by important writers, but the emphasis is on literary texts and writings that interpret those texts.

CHINESE 199.name: Independent Study
CHINESE 199.description: Investigation of special topics through directed reading in Chinese. Paper required.

CHINESE 201.name: Readings in Traditional Chinese Narrative and Prose
CHINESE 201.description: Close reading of selected premodern prose texts such as historical narratives, novels, short stories, and essays.

CHINESE 202.name: Readings in Traditional Chinese Poetry
CHINESE 202.description: Close readings of selected premodern poetic texts.

CHINESE 203.name: Readings in Modern Chinese Literature
CHINESE 203.description: Close readings of selected modern literary texts.

CHINESE 204.name: Readings in Chinese Literary and Cultural Theory
CHINESE 204.description: Close readings of selected texts in premodern criticism and theory.

CHINESE 211A.name: Studies in Traditional Chinese Narrative and Prose
CHINESE 211A.description: Two-quarter seminar in traditional Chinese narrative and prose, with topics varying from year to year.

CHINESE 211B.name: Studies in Traditional Chinese Narrative and Prose
CHINESE 211B.description: Two-quarter seminar in traditional Chinese narrative and prose, with topics varying from year to year.

CHINESE 212A.name: Studies in Traditional Chinese Poetry
CHINESE 212A.description: Two-quarter seminar in traditional Chinese poetry, with topics varying from year to year.

CHINESE 212B.name: Studies in Traditional Chinese Poetry
CHINESE 212B.description: Two-quarter seminar in traditional Chinese poetry, with topics varying from year to year.

CHINESE 213A.name: Studies in Modern Chinese Literature
CHINESE 213A.description: Two-quarter seminar in modern Chinese literature, with topics varying from year to year. Research paper required.

CHINESE 213B.name: Studies in Modern Chinese Literature
CHINESE 213B.description: Two-quarter seminar in modern Chinese literature, with topics varying from year to year. Research paper required.

CHINESE 214.name: Studies in Chinese Literature and Cultural Theory
CHINESE 214.description: Seminar in Chinese literature and cultural theory, with topics varying from year to year. Research paper required.

CHINESE 230.name: Topics in Chinese Literature and Culture
CHINESE 230.description: Seminar in Chinese literature and culture, with topics varying from year to year. Research paper required.

CHINESE 290.name: Independent Study
CHINESE 290.description: Directed research on topic determined in consultation with faculty member. A term paper or project is required.

CLASSIC 10.name: Scientific and Specialized Terminology
CLASSIC 10.description: A study of English terms derived from Greek and Latin and important to contemporary medicine, science, and other professions, with emphasis on development of word-building skills. No prior knowledge of Greek or Latin required.

CLASSIC 36A.name: The Formation of Ancient Greek Society: Early Greece
CLASSIC 36A.description: A survey of ancient Greek civilization from its origins in the Bronze Age to the mid-Archaic period. Examines political and social history, as well as literature, art, religion, and archaeological remains.

CLASSIC 36B.name: The Formation of Ancient Greek Society:  Late Archaic and Classical Greece
CLASSIC 36B.description: A survey of ancient Greek civilization from the Late Archaic period to the Classical period. Focuses on major institutions and cultural phenomena as seen through the study of ancient Greek literature, history, archaeology, and religion.

CLASSIC 36C.name: The Formation of Ancient Greek Society: Fourth-Century and Hellenistic Greece
CLASSIC 36C.description: A survey of ancient Greek civilization from the fourth century BCE through to the Hellenistic period. Focuses on major institutions and cultural phenomena as seen through the study of ancient Greek literature, history, archaeology, and religion.

CLASSIC 37A.name: The Formation of Ancient Roman Society: Origins to Roman Republic
CLASSIC 37A.description: A survey of the development of Roman civilization from its eighth century BCE beginnings to the civil wars of the first century BCE. Examines political and social history, as well as literature, art, architecture, and religion.

CLASSIC 37B.name: The Formation of Ancient Roman Society: Roman Empire
CLASSIC 37B.description: A survey of Roman civilization from Augustus’s consolidation of power following the civil wars of the first century BCE to the crisis of the third century CE. Includes social history, literature, art, architecture, and religion.

CLASSIC 37C.name: The Formation of Ancient Roman Society: The Fall of Rome
CLASSIC 37C.description: A survey of Roman civilization from the crisis of the third century CE to the so-called “fall of Rome” in 476 CE.  Examines political and social history, as well as literature, art, architecture, and religion.

CLASSIC 45A.name: Classical Mythology: The Gods
CLASSIC 45A.description: An overview of the main myths of the gods of the ancient Greeks and Romans and their influence in contemporary and later literature and art. Includes readings from both ancient and modern sources.

CLASSIC 45B.name: Classical Mythology: The Heroes
CLASSIC 45B.description: An overview of the main myths of the heroes of the ancient Greeks and Romans and their influence in contemporary and later literature and art. Includes readings from both ancient and modern sources.

CLASSIC 45C.name: Classical Mythology: Ancient and Modern Perspectives of Classical Mythology
CLASSIC 45C.description: Detailed examination of key Greek and Roman myths, their interpretations, and the influence they have exerted on literature, art, and popular culture in subsequent periods.

CLASSIC 99.name: Special Studies in Classics
CLASSIC 99.description: Lower-division level independent research with Classics faculty.

CLASSIC 140.name: Classics and History: The Ancient World
CLASSIC 140.description: Selected topics in society and culture of the Graeco-Roman world. Readings in translation.

CLASSIC 150.name: Classical Mythology
CLASSIC 150.description: Selected myths and legends as used in Classical literature, and their modern interpretations.

CLASSIC 160.name: Topics in Classical Literature in English Translation
CLASSIC 160.description: Studies in selected areas of Classical literature. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

CLASSIC 160W.name: Topics in Classical Literature in English Translation
CLASSIC 160W.description: Studies in selected areas of Classical literature. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
CLASSIC 160W.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

CLASSIC 166.name: Topics in Classical Reception
CLASSIC 166.description: Studies in selected areas of Classical reception. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

CLASSIC 170.name: Topics in Classical Civilization
CLASSIC 170.description: Studies in selected areas of Classical civilization. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

CLASSIC 176.name: International Studies and the Classics
CLASSIC 176.description: Develops a broader understanding of the formation of different cultures and countries of Classical times and their impact on the modern world.

CLASSIC 192A.name: Senior Capstone
CLASSIC 192A.description: Under the guidance of a faculty mentor, majors design and execute a senior project. This project may be a research paper, dramatic production, school curriculum, etc. All projects must be approved by the faculty mentor.
CLASSIC 192A.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

CLASSIC 192B.name: Senior Capstone
CLASSIC 192B.description: Under the guidance of a faculty mentor, majors design and execute a senior project. This project may be a research paper, dramatic production, school curriculum, etc. All projects must be approved by the faculty mentor.
CLASSIC 192B.prereqString: Prerequisite: CLASSIC 192A. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

CLASSIC 198.name: Directed Group Study
CLASSIC 198.description: Special topics in Classical studies through directed reading and research.

CLT&THY 200A.name: Political Economy: Methods and Critique
CLT&THY 200A.description: Introduction to canonical texts in Marxism coupled with an examination of the questions of race, gender, ethnicity, and sexuality that distend the calculus of the canon’s assumptive logic. May be taken after CLT&THY 200B.

CLT&THY 200B.name: Libidinal Economy: Methods and Critique
CLT&THY 200B.description: Introduction to canonical texts in psychoanalysis coupled with an examination of the questions of race, gender, ethnicity, and sexuality that distend the calculus of the canon’s assumptive logic. May be taken before CLT&THY 200A.

CLT&THY 200C.name: Theory from Below
CLT&THY 200C.description: Introduction to systems of thought understudied or undervalued in academic canons--for instance, systems constituted in communities' practices or theories that do not seek permanence or generality.

CLT&THY 241.name: Ethics, Erotics, and Will: Gendered Black Politics, Sexualized Racisms, and the Humanities
CLT&THY 241.description: Introduces doctoral students to an interdisciplinary conversation about black queer sexuality and black heteropatriarchy. Uses disciplinary formations as a tool for understanding knowledge formations about the shifting relations that constitute sexuality, gender, and racial blackness.

CLT&THY 242.name: Afro-Pessimism and the Status of the Subject
CLT&THY 242.description: Afro-Pessimism theorizes the Black as a being against which all other beings become legible as human subjects. Focuses on either the subject of psychoanalysis or the subject of capital accumulation in their explorations of the antagonism between Blackness.

CLT&THY 280.name: Independent Study
CLT&THY 280.description: Limited to students who have not yet received the M.A. degree.

CLT&THY 289.name: Topics in Culture and Theory
CLT&THY 289.description: Seminars on various topics in Culture and Theory.

CLT&THY 298.name: Directed Reading
CLT&THY 298.description: Directed readings on a specific topic agreed upon by students and their instructors. Limited to students who have completed their M.A. degree and are preparing for their qualifying exam.
CLT&THY 298.prereqString: Prerequisite: Completion of the M.A. degree.

CLT&THY 299.name: Dissertation Research
CLT&THY 299.description: Dissertation research in Culture and Theory.

COGS 14P.name: Scientific Python for Research
COGS 14P.description: Introduces Python for data analysis and modeling encountered in cognitive science and neuroscience. Topics include data structures, execution control, graphic visualization, and interaction with sound and display interfaces. Application in statistical analysis, model simulation, and stimulus presentation and experimental control.
COGS 14P.restriction: Restriction: Cognitive Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

COGS H101A.name: Honors Seminar in Psychology and Cognitive Sciences I
COGS H101A.description: Focuses on the research activities and honors thesis research projects of each student and the research of various Cognitive Sciences faculty. Students discuss their research interests in the early and later stages of their projects. Research projects and write-ups required.
COGS H101A.restriction: Restriction: Cognitive Sciences Honors students only. Psychology Honors students only.

COGS H101B.name: Honors Seminar in Psychology and Cognitive Sciences II
COGS H101B.description: Focuses on the research activities and honors thesis research projects of each student and the research of various Cognitive Sciences faculty. Students discuss their research interests in the early and later stages of their projects. Research projects and write-ups required.
COGS H101B.restriction: Restriction: Cognitive Sciences Honors students only. Psychology Honors students only.

COGS H101C.name: Honors Seminar in Psychology and Cognitive Sciences III
COGS H101C.description: Focuses on the research activities and honors thesis research projects of each student and the research of various Cognitive Sciences faculty. Students discuss their research interests in the early and later stages of their projects. Research projects and write-ups required.
COGS H101C.restriction: Restriction: Cognitive Sciences Honors students only. Psychology Honors students only.

COGS 106.name: Computational Lab Skills
COGS 106.description: Teaches programming tools, skills, and conventions for collaborative work in computational cognitive science. Topics covered include program structure, version control, random number generation, plotting, basic model fitting, and numerical optimization methods.
COGS 106.prereqString: Prerequisite: (PSYC 14M or COGS 14P or ICS 31) and (PSYC 10C or STAT 7 or STAT 110)

COGS 107.name: Cognitive Modeling
COGS 107.description: Cognitive process models analyzed using computational Bayesian methods. Formal statistical specification of models, parameter estimation, model evaluation, and research applications. Covers multinomial process trees, signal detection theory, Thurstone ranking models, item-response theory, decision models, and reaction time models.
COGS 107.prereqString: Prerequisite: (PSYC 14M or COGS 14P or ICS 31) and (PSYC 10C or STAT 7 or STAT 110)
COGS 107.restriction: Restriction: Cognitive Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

COGS 108.name: Neural Analytics
COGS 108.description: Introduces the theoretical foundations and practical applications of neural data analysis. Topics include models of neural signals, neural time series analysis, and machine learning applications in cognitive neuroscience.
COGS 108.prereqString: Prerequisite: (PSYC 14M or COGS 14P or ICS 31) and (PSYC 10C or STAT 7 or STAT 110)
COGS 108.restriction: Restriction: Cognitive Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

COGS 109.name: Cognitive Sciences Research Seminar
COGS 109.description: Read and discuss examples of the primary research leading to the concepts covered in Psychology Fundamentals. Focuses on how this research is conducted and how inferences from it are drawn.

COGS 110.name: Quantitative Methods for Cognitive Sciences Research
COGS 110.description: Basics of quantitative methods used in cognitive sciences research focusing on linear algebra, Fourier analysis, multivariate statistics, and signal detection theory. Examples drawn from models and methods used in cognitive sciences research with practical examples.
COGS 110.prereqString: Prerequisite: MATH 2B and STAT 7 and (PSYC 114M or ICS 31)

COGS 112LP.name: Research in Perception and Psychophysics Laboratory
COGS 112LP.description: Required laboratory section and co-requisite for COGS 112P.
COGS 112LP.restriction: Restriction: Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

COGS 112LR.name: Cognitive Robotics Laboratory
COGS 112LR.description: Required laboratory section and corequisite for PSYCH 112R.
COGS 112LR.restriction: Restriction: Cognitive Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

COGS 112P.name: Research in Perception and Psychophysics
COGS 112P.description: Introduction to design and practice of experiments: students perform auditory, visual, tactile, or other experiments. Emphasis on methodology, finding and reading previous research, generating research ideas, statistical analysis.
COGS 112P.prereqString:
Corequisite: COGS 112LP
Prerequisite: (PSYC 9A and PSYC 9B and PSYC 9C) or (PSCI 11A and PSCI 11B and PSCI 11C) and (PSYC 10C or SSCI 10C or ANTH 10C or PLSC 10C or SOCL 10C) or (MATH 2B and STAT 7)
COGS 112P.restriction: Restriction: Cognitive Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

COGS 112R.name: Cognitive Robotics
COGS 112R.description: Introduces concepts on experimental design, embodiment, robot construction, and computer programming. Concepts of embodied intelligence and case studies of cognitive robotics are covered in lecture. Simple robots are constructed and programmed to carry out different behavioral experiments in lab.
COGS 112R.prereqString:
Corequisite: PSYC 112LR
Prerequisite: (PSYC 9A and PSYC 9B and PSYC 9C) or (PSCI 11A and PSCI 11B and PSCI 11C) and (PSYC 10C or SSCI 10C or ANTH 10C or PLSC 10C or SOCL 10C) or (MATH 2B and STAT 7)
COGS 112R.restriction: Restriction: Cognitive Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

COGS 201A.name: Cognitive Sciences Research Seminar
COGS 201A.description: Weekly reports and colloquia by faculty, students, and visitors.
COGS 201A.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Cognitive Neuroscience Majors only. Cognitive Sciences Majors only. Psychology Majors only.

COGS 201B.name: Cognitive Sciences Research Seminar
COGS 201B.description: Weekly reports and colloquia by faculty, students, and visitors.
COGS 201B.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Cognitive Neuroscience Majors only. Cognitive Sciences Majors only. Psychology Majors only.

COGS 201C.name: Cognitive Sciences Research Seminar
COGS 201C.description: Weekly reports and colloquia by faculty, students, and visitors.
COGS 201C.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Cognitive Neuroscience Majors only. Cognitive Sciences Majors only. Psychology Majors only.

COGS 202A.name: Proseminar in the Cognitive Sciences
COGS 202A.description: Introduction to the conceptual foundations and basic research results in the cognitive sciences for first-year graduate students.
COGS 202A.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Cognitive Neuroscience Majors only. Cognitive Sciences Majors only.

COGS 203A.name: Statistical Models for Cognitive Sciences I
COGS 203A.description: Logic and set theory are covered during the first three weeks, using an interactive computer system. The remaining seven weeks are devoted to probability theory and cover elementary concepts from samples spaces to Chebychev's Inequality and the moment generating function.

COGS 203B.name: Statistical Models for Cognitive Sciences II
COGS 203B.description: An introduction to statistical estimation and statistical inference. Topics include sufficiency and the Rao-Blackwell Theorem, completeness and the Lehmann-Scheffe Theorem. The method of maximum likelihood is explored in some detail. Inference in linear models covers regression and analysis of variance.

COGS 203C.name: Statistical Models for Cognitive Sciences III
COGS 203C.description: Discussion of the fundamentals of statistical inference and computational implementations of common statistical models.

COGS 203D.name: Applied Mathematics for Cognitive Sciences
COGS 203D.description: Covers the basics of linear systems analysis, focusing on linear algebra, Fourier analysis, differential equations, and elementary signal processing. Applications in Cognitive Science and Cognitive Neuroscience research are developed.
COGS 203D.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Cognitive Neuroscience Majors only. Cognitive Sciences Majors only. Psychology Majors only.

COGS 204A.name: Seminar in Professional Development
COGS 204A.description: Development of professional skills. Focuses on grant writing and submission process, responsible conduct of research, and ethics training.
COGS 204A.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Cognitive Neuroscience Majors only. Cognitive Sciences Majors only. Psychology Majors only.

COGS 204B.name: Seminar in Professional Development
COGS 204B.description: Development of professional skills. Focus on scientific presentations and preparation.
COGS 204B.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Cognitive Neuroscience Majors only. Cognitive Sciences Majors only. Psychology Majors only.

COGS 204C.name: Seminar in Professional Development
COGS 204C.description: Development of professional skills. Focuses on career opportunities, interests and information, and community outreach.
COGS 204C.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Cognitive Neuroscience Majors only. Cognitive Sciences Majors only. Psychology Majors only.

COGS 205A.name: Introduction to Programming
COGS 205A.description: Introduces rudiments of programming, statistical analysis and probability theory, graphic visualization, GUI design, spectral analysis, and simulation models using MATLAB, a software package for solving quantitative problems often encountered in experimental psychology.

COGS 205B.name: Computational Lab Skills for Cognitive Scientists I
COGS 205B.description: Provides an in-depth introduction to writing MATLAB programs to run auditory and visual experiments. Topics covered include program structure, stimulus generation, presentation, and data collection.

COGS 205C.name: Computational Lab Skills for Cognitive Scientists II
COGS 205C.description: Introduction to a number of computational statistics approaches including exploratory data analysis and modeling using a probabilistic framework with Bayesian graphical models. Emphasis on in-class programming using MATLAB.

COGS 205D.name: Neural Networks and Machine Learning
COGS 205D.description: An introduction and review of the current state of the art in neural networks and machine learning with specific emphasis of applications to behavioral and neuroscience data analysis and modeling.

COGS 210A.name: Cognitive and Brain Sciences I: Topics in Perception
COGS 210A.description: Discusses models of cognition and evidence linking cognition and the brain. Focus is on visual, auditory, and somatic perception and bottom-up mechanisms of attention.

COGS 210B.name: Cognitive and Brain Sciences II: Topics in Cognition
COGS 210B.description: Discusses models of cognition and evidence linking cognition and the brain. Focus is on emotion, top-down attention, goal-directed behavior, categorization, judgment, and decision-making.

COGS 210C.name: Cognitive and Brain Sciences III: Topics in Learning and Development
COGS 210C.description: Discusses experimental data, formal models of learning, and evidence linking learning and development to its neural substrates. Topics include Pavlovian and instrumental conditioning, language acquisition, causal reasoning, perceptual learning, category formation, and structure learning.

COGS 213.name: The Mind/Body Problem
COGS 213.description: Multidisciplinary, drawing on information from the fields of quantum physics, computer vision, artificial intelligence, cognition, neurophysiology, philosophy, and psychophysics.

COGS 214.name: Bayesian Cognitive Modeling
COGS 214.description: Considers a range of statistical methods of data analysis and simple cognitive models using the Bayesian graphical modeling framework.

COGS 218.name: Hearing
COGS 218.description: Examines auditory sensation and perception using psychophysical and neuroscientific perspectives. Covers physical aspects of sound

COGS 229.name: Special Topics in Human Cognition
COGS 229.description: Current research in brain/ behavior relationships, human memory, and learning theory is presented.

COGS 237.name: Advanced Bayesian Cognitive Modeling
COGS 237.description: Considers a range of advanced cognitive process models including models of signal detection, memory retention, category learning, stimulus representation, and reasoning using the Bayesian graphical modeling framework.

COGS 239.name: Special Topics in Methodology and Models
COGS 239.description: Current research in cognitive sciences methodologies, concepts, and models is presented.

COGS 259.name: Special Topics in Human Performance
COGS 259.description: Current research in the human issues involved with sensation, perception, and cognition.

COGS 261N.name: Cortical Neuroscience
COGS 261N.description: Physiology of the cerebral cortex, theoretical neuroscience, and the neural basis of perception.

COGS 262.name: Functional Neuroanatomy
COGS 262.description: It is impossible to truly understand human behavior without some understanding of the physical structure that enables behavior. Examines recent findings in functional neuroantomy through lectures and papers discussing links between particular behaviors and specific brain structures.

COGS 265.name: Introduction to Functional MRI
COGS 265.description: Describes the fundamentals of imaging the human brain function using functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging (fMRI). Topics include basic fMRI physics, experimental design, and data acquisition and analysis.

COGS 268A.name: Computational Neuroscience
COGS 268A.description: Introduction to computational neuroscience. Mathematical models of single neurons, neural circuits, thalamocortical systems, and cortical mass action can stimulate single-unit, local field potential, and EEG dynamics. These models are used to investigate mechanisms of sensation, motor control, attention, and consciousness.
COGS 268A.prereqString: Prerequisite: COGS 210A or COGS 210B or COGS 210C

COGS 268R.name: Cognitive Robotics
COGS 268R.description: Introduces concepts for studying cognitive function by embedding brain models on robotic platforms. Topics include robot construction, computer programming, and the notion of embodiment. Students construct simple robots and program these robots to perform different behaviors.

COGS 289.name: Special Topics in Sensation and Perception
COGS 289.description: Current research in the reception and processing of visual and auditory stimuli presented.

COGS 290.name: Dissertation Research
COGS 290.description: Dissertation research with Cognitive Science faculty.
COGS 290.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Cognitive Sciences Majors only.

COGS 299.name: Individual Study
COGS 299.description: Individual research with Cognitive Science faculty.

COM LIT 3.name: Just Reading: Developing the Reading Experience
COM LIT 3.description: Develops the reading experience apart from writing. Develops tools for sustained attention in reading practice across a wide range of genres and media from across the globe. Students learn to appreciate elements of reading experience such as attention and perplexity.

COM LIT 8.name: Travels in Comparative Literature
COM LIT 8.description: Readings in English and in English translation on such topics as love, war, cities, travel writing, politics, fantasy and science fiction, violence.

COM LIT 9.name: Introduction to Multiculturalism
COM LIT 9.description: Various themes and forms of literary and cultural production within a multicultural framework, including African American, Asian American, Chicano/Latino, and Native American literatures and cultures.

COM LIT 10.name: Topics in World Literature
COM LIT 10.description: Introduction to texts from across the globe and from different historical periods.  Readings in English and English translation.

COM LIT 60A.name: World Literature
COM LIT 60A.description: An introduction to the comparative study of literatures and cultures in a global context. Studies literary texts and other media across the borders of various cultures, historical periods, and traditions. All texts are read in English translation.

COM LIT 60B.name: Reading with Theory
COM LIT 60B.description: Introduction to theory and methods of literary and cultural criticism in a global context. Students read theoretical approaches to literature, culture, and ideas. Marx and Freud, e.g., may be studied alongside readings in narrative poetry, film, song lyrics, novel.

COM LIT 60C.name: Cultural Studies
COM LIT 60C.description: Introduces students to a variety of cultural practices (literature, blogs, films, radio, comics) from across the globe. Focuses on the ways that context, genre, and medium (e.g., written, visual, oral) affect how these practices are produced, circulated, and received.

COM LIT 100A.name: Nations, Regions, and Beyond
COM LIT 100A.description: Intensive study of national and regional cultural and literary traditions from across the globe, among them the literary and cultural production of the Middle East, Africa, Europe, the Americas, and Asia.

COM LIT 101W.name: An Introduction to Translation Studies
COM LIT 101W.description: Focuses on theories of translation and on how these theories help students understand the role of translation in the world. Students develop a critical vocabulary for discussing translation in multiple linguistic traditions and complete a final translation project.
COM LIT 101W.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement. Working knowledge of at least one foreign language.

COM LIT 102W.name: Comparative Studies in Literature and Theory
COM LIT 102W.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

COM LIT 105.name: Topics in Comparative Multiculturalism
COM LIT 105.description: Treats the literatures and cultures of one or more minority groups in California and the United States, including African Americans, Asian Americans, Chicano/Latinos, and Native Americans, and their relations to other national literatures.
COM LIT 105.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the lower-division writing requirement.

COM LIT 107.name: Colonialisms and Postcolonialisms
COM LIT 107.description: Explores topics such as colonialism and race, decolonization, pre- and postcoloniality, globalization, and the cultural dynamics of colonization and subjectivity.

COM LIT 108.name: Diasporic Literatures and Cultures
COM LIT 108.description: Literatures, cultures, and histories of diasporic groups, e.g., literature of the Persian diaspora

COM LIT 121.name: Narrative, Pattern, and Text
COM LIT 121.description: Explores textual patterns, structures, and effects.  May include topics such as novel, hypertext, genre, reader responses, intertextuality.

COM LIT 123.name: Literatures in Dialogue
COM LIT 123.description: Studies how texts interact across time and space in a global context. Uses concepts of influence, imitation, and parody, to ask, for example, how the Homeric epics can help us understand Caribbean novels and U.S. movies such as Troy.

COM LIT 130.name: Gender, Sexuality, Race, Class
COM LIT 130.description: Discusses the roles of differences such as race, class, gender, and sexuality in society, culture, and literature across the globe, covering topics such as theoretical and literary representations of queer sexuality, gender performance, critical race theory.

COM LIT 131.name: Psychoanalysis and Culture
COM LIT 131.description: Discusses major psychoanalytic writings of Freud and others in connection with questions of culture.

COM LIT 132.name: Discourse, Ideologies, and Politics
COM LIT 132.description: Compares ideologies and systems, e.g., nationalism and fundamentalism, as they affect literature and culture in a global context.

COM LIT 140.name: Critical Cultural Studies
COM LIT 140.description: Introduces a variety of ways of understanding cultural phenomena in relation to different power structures.  These cultural phenomena may include comics, film, literature, sports, music, festivals, telling stories, or eating out.

COM LIT 142.name: The Metropolis and Other Cultural Geographies
COM LIT 142.description: Examines the relationship between space and culture

COM LIT 143.name: Literature, Arts, and Media
COM LIT 143.description: Explores literature and other arts and media in a global context. May include film and electronic media, fine arts, oral cultures, architecture, in an international framework.

COM LIT 144.name: Literature, History, and Society
COM LIT 144.description: Explores the relationship between literary texts and their historical and social contexts in an international framework. Courses may address, for example, literary and cultural expressions in social revolutions or the way literary texts talk back to medicine, religion, and anthropology.

COM LIT 150.name: Literature in Translation
COM LIT 150.description: The study of literary works in one or more genres in English translation.  May be a comparative study of works from several different original languages or a concentration on works from a single cultural/linguistic tradition.

COM LIT 160.name: World Cinema
COM LIT 160.description: Comparative analysis of contemporary film in languages other than English.

COM LIT 190W.name: Advanced Seminar in Comparative Literature and Theory
COM LIT 190W.description: Capstone seminar for the Comparative Literature major. Deepens understanding of the field through investigation of a special topic and a substantial research and writing project.
COM LIT 190W.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
COM LIT 190W.restriction: Restriction: School of Humanities students only.

COM LIT 199.name: Independent Study in Comparative Literature
COM LIT 199.description: To be taken only when the materials to be studied lie outside the normal run of departmental offerings.

COM LIT 200A.name: History of Comparative Literature and Introduction to Methods and Theories of CL
COM LIT 200A.description: Seminar designed to introduce graduate students in Comparative Literature to the discipline of Comparative Literature. Issues and theories of comparative literary and cultural study are covered. Strongly recommended for first and second year students before the M.A. exam and review.

COM LIT 200B.name: Theories of Translation
COM LIT 200B.description: The reproduction, translation, and transfer of literary and cultural, ideological and political, and symbolic codes and texts have long been the object of study in Comparative Literature. Addresses the diverse ways in which expressive systems interact and intersect.

COM LIT 200C.name: Theories of Globalization, Inter-Nationalism, and Postcolonialism
COM LIT 200C.description: Addresses both theories and the complex history of literary and cultural expression in a national, trans-, inter-, and post-national, global frame. Topics may include: globalism and nationhood, theories of citizenship and political subjecthood, postcolonial literature and theory.

COM LIT 210.name: Comparative Studies
COM LIT 210.description: Studies in selected areas of Comparative Literature. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

COM LIT 220.name: Translation Workshop
COM LIT 220.description: Trains students in the methodologies and practice of translation.  Students focus on the translating process in a series of case studies and individual projects.

COM LIT 280A.name: Professionalization Seminar
COM LIT 280A.description: The first of two required professionalization seminars in Comparative Literature. Intended for second and third year students and covers preparation for the M.A. and Ph.D. exams, conference presentations, teaching and classroom management, and publishing journals.

COM LIT 280B.name: Professionalization Seminar
COM LIT 280B.description: The second of two required professionalization seminars in Comparative Literature. Intended for fourth and fifth year students and covers course design, applying for grants, dissertation prospectus and support, and the job application process.
COM LIT 280B.prereqString: Prerequisite: COM LIT 280A. COM LIT 280A with a grade of B or better

COM LIT 290.name: Reading and Conference
COM LIT 290.description: Studies in selected areas. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

COM LIT 291.name: Guided Reading Course
COM LIT 291.description: Studies in selected areas. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

COM LIT 292.name: Teaching Practicum
COM LIT 292.description: Graduate students develop their pedagogical practices by accompanying a professor teaching a UCI undergraduate class. Meets individually with the professor to discuss relevant pedagogical practices, syllabus design, lecturing, assessment, classroom management, etc. Actively participates in one teaching component.

COM LIT 299.name: Dissertation Research
COM LIT 299.description: A units-only course for students in the dissertation phase.

COMPSCI 103.name: Advanced Programming and Problem Solving with C++
COMPSCI 103.description: Advanced programming language concepts for more complex, higher performance software design. Builds depth of programming skills in C++ as a foundation for upper-division courses and projects. Focuses on strengthening programming, debugging, and problem solving skills.
COMPSCI 103.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

COMPSCI 111.name: Digital Image Processing
COMPSCI 111.description: Introduction to the fundamental concepts of digital signal and image processing as applicable in areas such as multimedia, graphics, AI, data mining, databases, vision, or video games. Topics include image representation, space- and frequency-domain transformations, filters, segmentation, and compression.
COMPSCI 111.prereqString: Prerequisite: (I&C SCI 46 or CSE 46) and I&C SCI 6D and (MATH 3A or I&C SCI 6N). I&C SCI 46 with a grade of C or better. CSE 46 with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 6D with a grade of C or better. MATH 3A with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 6N with a grade of C or better
COMPSCI 111.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

COMPSCI 112.name: Computer Graphics
COMPSCI 112.description: Introduction to the fundamental principles of 3D computer graphics including polygonal modeling, geometric transformations, visibility algorithms, illumination models, texturing, and rasterization. Use of an independently-learned 3D graphics API to implement these techniques.
COMPSCI 112.prereqString: Prerequisite: I&C SCI 46 and (MATH 3A or I&C SCI 6N). I&C SCI 46 with a grade of C or better. MATH 3A with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 6N with a grade of C or better
COMPSCI 112.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

COMPSCI 113.name: Computer Game Development
COMPSCI 113.description: Introduction to the principles of interactive 2D and 3D computer game development. Concepts in computer graphics, algorithms, software engineering, art and graphics, music and sound, story analysis, and artificial intelligence are presented and are the basis for student work.
COMPSCI 113.prereqString: Prerequisite: COMPSCI 112 or COMPSCI 171 or IN4MATX 121 or ART 106B or I&C SCI 163 or I&C SCI 166
COMPSCI 113.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

COMPSCI 114.name: Projects in Advanced 3D Computer Graphics
COMPSCI 114.description: Projects in advanced 3D graphics such as illumination, geometric modeling, visualization, and animation. Topics include physically based and global illumination, solid modeling, curved surfaces, multiresolution modeling, image-based rendering, basic concepts of animation, and scientific visualization.
COMPSCI 114.prereqString: Prerequisite: COMPSCI 112 and (I&C SCI 45C or CSE 45C). I&C SCI 45C with a grade of C or better. CSE 45C with a grade of C or better. Recommended: COMPSCI 161 or CSE 161 or COMPSCI 164 or COMPSCI 165.
COMPSCI 114.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

COMPSCI 115.name: Computer Simulation
COMPSCI 115.prereqString: Prerequisite: I&C SCI 6B and (I&C SCI 6N or MATH 3A) and (STATS 67 or STATS 7) and STATS 120A and I&C SCI 51 and IN4MATX 43. I&C SCI 6B with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 6N with a grade of C or better. MATH 3A with a grade of C or better. STATS 67 with a grade of C or better. STATS 7 with a grade of C or better. STATS 120A with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 51 with a grade of C or better. IN4MATX 43 with a grade of C or better
COMPSCI 115.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

COMPSCI 116.name: Computational Photography and Vision
COMPSCI 116.description: Introduces the problems of computer vision through the application of computational photography. Specific topics include photo-editing (image warping, compositing, hole filling), panoramic image stitching, and face detection for digital photographs.
COMPSCI 116.prereqString: Prerequisite: I&C SCI 6D and (MATH 6G or MATH 3A or I&C SCI 6N) and MATH 2B and (I&C SCI 46 or CSE 46). I&C SCI 6D with a grade of C or better. MATH 6G with a grade of C or better. MATH 3A with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 6N with a grade of C or better. MATH 2B with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 46 with a grade of C or better. CSE 46 with a grade of C or better
COMPSCI 116.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

COMPSCI 117.name: Project in Computer Vision
COMPSCI 117.description: Students undertake construction of a computer vision system. Topics include automatically building 3D models from photographs, searching photo collections, robot navigation, and human motion tracking.
COMPSCI 117.prereqString: Prerequisite: I&C SCI 6D and (MATH 3A or I&C SCI 6N) and MATH 2B and (I&C SCI 46 or CSE 46) and (COMPSCI 112 or COMPSCI 116 or COMPSCI 171 or COMPSCI 178). I&C SCI 6D with a grade of C or better. MATH 3A with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 6N with a grade of C or better. MATH 2B with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 46 with a grade of C or better. CSE 46 with a grade of C or better
COMPSCI 117.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

COMPSCI 118.name: Introduction to Virtual Reality
COMPSCI 118.description: Introduces virtual reality systems and software. Topics include computer graphics pipeline, human visual system and perception, head mounted displays, image formation, sensors and tracking, and 3D sound. Students use a popular cross-platform game engine to create VR environments.
COMPSCI 118.prereqString: Prerequisite: (I&C SCI 6N or MATH 3A) and I&C SCI 33
COMPSCI 118.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

COMPSCI 121.name: Information Retrieval
COMPSCI 121.description: An introduction to information retrieval including indexing, retrieval, classifying, and clustering text and multimedia documents.
COMPSCI 121.prereqString: Prerequisite: (I&C SCI 45C or I&C SCI 45J) and (STATS 7 or STATS 67). I&C SCI 45C with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 45J with a grade of C or better
COMPSCI 121.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment.

COMPSCI 122A.name: Introduction to Data Management
COMPSCI 122A.description: Introduction to the design of databases and the use of database management systems (DBMS) for applications. Topics include entity-relationship modeling for design, relational data model, relational algebra, relational design theory, and Structured Query Language (SQL) programming.
COMPSCI 122A.prereqString: Prerequisite: I&C SCI 33 or EECS 114. I&C SCI 33 with a grade of C or better
COMPSCI 122A.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

COMPSCI 122B.name: Project in Databases and Web Applications
COMPSCI 122B.description: Introduces students to advanced database technologies and Web applications. Topics include database connectivity (ODBC/JDBC), extending databases using stored procedures, database administration, Web servers, Web programming languages (Java servlets, XML, Ajax, and mobile platforms).
COMPSCI 122B.prereqString: Prerequisite: (COMPSCI 122A or EECS 116) and I&C SCI 45J
COMPSCI 122B.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

COMPSCI 122C.name: Principles of Data Management
COMPSCI 122C.description: Covers fundamental principles underlying data management systems. Content includes key techniques including storage management, buffer management, record-oriented file system, access methods, query optimization, and query processing.
COMPSCI 122C.prereqString: Prerequisite: COMPSCI 122A and (I&C SCI 53 or COMPSCI 143A)
COMPSCI 122C.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

COMPSCI 122D.name: Beyond SQL Data Management
COMPSCI 122D.description: Survey of modern data management and analysis technologies beyond relational (SQL) database management. Topics include semistructured data, NoSQL databases, big data analysis, and text search/query engines. Additional topics vary and may include data frames, streaming data, and/or time-series data.
COMPSCI 122D.prereqString: Prerequisite: I&C SCI 46 and I&C SCI 51 and (COMPSCI 122A or EECS 116)
COMPSCI 122D.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science and Engineering and all School of ICS majors have second right of consideration.

COMPSCI 125.name: Next Generation Search Systems
COMPSCI 125.description: Discusses concepts and techniques related to all aspects of search systems. After considering basic search technology and the state-of-art systems, rapidly developing techniques for multimedia search, local search, event-search, and video-on-demand are explored.
COMPSCI 125.prereqString: Prerequisite: I&C SCI 31 or CSE 41 or I&C SCI 32A
COMPSCI 125.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

COMPSCI 131.name: Parallel and Distributed Computing
COMPSCI 131.description: Parallel and distributed computer systems. Parallel programming models. Common parallel and distributed programming issues. Specific topics include parallel programming, performance models, coordination and synchronization, consistency and replication, transactions, fault tolerance.
COMPSCI 131.prereqString: Prerequisite: (I&C SCI 53 and I&C SCI 53L) or COMPSCI 143A
COMPSCI 131.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

COMPSCI 132.name: Computer Networks
COMPSCI 132.description: Computer network architectures, protocols, and applications.  Internet congestion control, addressing, and routing. Local area networks. Multimedia networking.
COMPSCI 132.restriction: Restriction: Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

COMPSCI 133.name: Advanced Computer Networks
COMPSCI 133.description: Fundamental principles in computer networks are applied to obtain practical experience and skills necessary for designing and implementing computer networks, protocols, and network applications. Various network design techniques, simulation techniques, and UNIX network programming are covered.
COMPSCI 133.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

COMPSCI 134.name: Computer and Network Security
COMPSCI 134.description: Overview of modern computer and networks security, attacks, and countermeasures. Authentication, identification, data secrecy, data integrity, authorization, access control, computer viruses, network security. Also covers secure e-commerce and applications of public key methods, digital certificates, and credentials.
COMPSCI 134.prereqString: Prerequisite: I&C SCI 6D and (I&C SCI 33 or CSE 43) and (COMPSCI 122A or EECS 116 or COMPSCI 132 or COMPSCI 143A)
COMPSCI 134.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

COMPSCI 137.name: Internet Applications Engineering
COMPSCI 137.description: Concepts in Internet applications engineering with emphasis on the Web. Peer-to-Peer and Interoperability. Topics include HTTP and REST, Remote Procedure/Method Calls, Web Services, data representations, content distribution networks, identity management, relevant W3C/IETF standards, and relevant new large-scale computing styles.
COMPSCI 137.prereqString: Prerequisite: (COMPSCI 132 or EECS 148) and I&C SCI 45J
COMPSCI 137.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

COMPSCI 141.name: Concepts in Programming Languages I
COMPSCI 141.description: In-depth study of several contemporary programming languages stressing variety in data structures, operations, notation, and control. Examination of different programming paradigms, such as logic programming, functional programming and object-oriented programming
COMPSCI 141.prereqString: Prerequisite: (I&C SCI 51 or CSE 31 or EECS 31) and (I&C SCI 46 or CSE 46). I&C SCI 51 with a grade of C or better. CSE 31 with a grade of C or better. EECS 31 with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 46 with a grade of C or better. CSE 46 with a grade of C or better
COMPSCI 141.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

COMPSCI 142A.name: Compilers and Interpreters
COMPSCI 142A.description: Introduction to the theory of programming language processors covering lexical analysis, syntax analysis, semantic analysis, intermediate representations, code generation, optimization, interpretation, and run-time support.
COMPSCI 142A.prereqString: Prerequisite: CSE 141 or COMPSCI 141 or IN4MATX 101
COMPSCI 142A.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

COMPSCI 142B.name: Language Processor Construction
COMPSCI 142B.description: Project course which provides working laboratory experience in construction and behavior of compilers and interpreters. Students build actual language processors and perform experiments which reveal their behaviors.
COMPSCI 142B.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

COMPSCI 143A.name: Principles of Operating Systems
COMPSCI 143A.description: Principles and concepts of process and resource management, especially as seen in operating systems. Processes, memory management, protection, scheduling, file systems, and I/O systems are covered. Concepts illustrated in the context of several well-known systems.
COMPSCI 143A.prereqString: Prerequisite: (I&C SCI 46 or CSE 46) and (I&C SCI 51 or EECS 31 or CSE 31)
COMPSCI 143A.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

COMPSCI 143B.name: Project in Operating System Organization
COMPSCI 143B.description: Detailed specification and design of critical components of an actual operating system including a memory manager, a process server, and a file/IO subsystem. Hardware/software tradeoffs. Emphasis on logical organization of system and communication.
COMPSCI 143B.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

COMPSCI 145.name: Embedded Software
COMPSCI 145.description: Principles of embedded computing systems: embedded systems architecture, hardware/software components, system software and interfacing, real-time operating systems, hardware/software co-development, and communication issues. Examples of embedded computing in real-world application domains. Simple programming using an embedded systems development environment.
COMPSCI 145.prereqString:
Corequisite: COMPSCI 145L
Prerequisite: (CSE 46 or I&C SCI 46) and (I&C SCI 51 or EECS 31 or CSE 31)
COMPSCI 145.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

COMPSCI 145L.name: Embedded Software Laboratory
COMPSCI 145L.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

COMPSCI 146.name: Programming in Multitasking Operating Systems
COMPSCI 146.description: User- and systems-level programming of modern Internet-connected, multi-user, multitasking operating systems. Shells, scripting, filters, pipelines, programmability, extensibility, concurrency, inter-process communication. Concrete examples of a modern operating system (such as, but not necessarily, Unix programmed in C) are used.
COMPSCI 146.prereqString: Prerequisite: (I&C SCI 46 or CSE 46) and I&C SCI 51. I&C SCI 46 with a grade of C or better. CSE 46 with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 51 with a grade of C or better. Recommended: COMPSCI 143A.
COMPSCI 146.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

COMPSCI 147.name: Internet of Things (IoT) Software and Systems
COMPSCI 147.description: Introduction to the Internet of Things (IoT) from a systems and software perspective. IoT ecosystem including sensors, embedded CPUs, networking protocols, software, cloud services, and security and privacy requirements. IoT use cases, system design, and programming project.
COMPSCI 147.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

COMPSCI 151.name: Digital Logic Design
COMPSCI 151.description: Boolean algebra. Design/analysis of combinational and sequential systems using SSI/MSI/LSI modules. Number systems. Error detecting and correction codes. Arithmetic algorithms. Hardware/ firmware implementation of algorithms.
COMPSCI 151.prereqString: Prerequisite: (I&C SCI 33 or CSE 43) and I&C SCI 51 and I&C SCI 6B and I&C SCI 6D. I&C SCI 33 with a grade of C or better. CSE 43 with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 51 with a grade of C or better
COMPSCI 151.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

COMPSCI 152.name: Computer Systems Architecture
COMPSCI 152.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

COMPSCI 153.name: Logic Design Laboratory
COMPSCI 153.description: Introduction to standard integrated circuits. Construction and debugging techniques. Design of digital systems using LSI and MSI components. Practical use of circuits in a laboratory environment, including implementation of small digital systems such as arithmetic modules, displays, and timers.
COMPSCI 153.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

COMPSCI 154.name: Computer Design Laboratory
COMPSCI 154.description: Underlying primitives of computer instruction sets. Principles of microprogramming. Microprogramming. Microprograms written for one or more systems. Typical microprogramming applications discussed and implemented or simulated.
COMPSCI 154.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

COMPSCI 161.name: Design and Analysis of Algorithms
COMPSCI 161.description: Techniques for efficient algorithm design, including divide-and-conquer and dynamic programming, and time/space analysis. Fast algorithms for problems applicable to networks, computer games, and scientific computing, such as sorting, shortest paths, minimum spanning trees, network flow, and pattern matching.
