COMPSCI 161.prereqString: Prerequisite: (I&C SCI 46 or CSE 46) and I&C SCI 6B and I&C SCI 6D and MATH 2B. I&C SCI 46 with a grade of C or better. CSE 46 with a grade of C or better
COMPSCI 161.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Software Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Data Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Business Information Management, Computer Game Science, and Informatics majors have second right of consideration.

COMPSCI 162.name: Formal Languages and Automata
COMPSCI 162.description: Formal aspects of describing and recognizing languages by grammars and automata.  Parsing regular and context-free languages. Ambiguity, nondeterminism. Elements of computability
COMPSCI 162.prereqString: Prerequisite: (I&C SCI 46 or CSE 46) and MATH 2B and I&C SCI 6B and I&C SCI 6D. I&C SCI 46 with a grade of C or better. CSE 46 with a grade of C or better
COMPSCI 162.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Cognitive Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Language Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

COMPSCI 163.name: Graph  Algorithms
COMPSCI 163.description: Algorithms for solving fundamental problems in graph theory. Graph representations, graph traversal, network flow, connectivity, graph layout, matching problems.
COMPSCI 163.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

COMPSCI 164.name: Computational Geometry and Geometric Modeling
COMPSCI 164.description: Algorithms and data structures for computational geometry and geometric modeling, with applications to game and graphics programming. Topics: convex hulls, Voronoi diagrams, algorithms for triangulation, motion planning, and data structures for geometric searching and modeling of 2D and 3D objects.
COMPSCI 164.prereqString: Prerequisite: I&C SCI 46 or CSE 46. I&C SCI 46 with a grade of C or better. CSE 46 with a grade of C or better
COMPSCI 164.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

COMPSCI 165.name: Project in Algorithms and Data Structures
COMPSCI 165.description: Design, implementation, execution, and analysis of algorithms for problems such as sorting, searching, data compression, and data encryption. Time-space-structure trade-offs.
COMPSCI 165.prereqString: Prerequisite: COMPSCI 161 or CSE 161. Recommended: I&C SCI 45C OR CSE 45C.
COMPSCI 165.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science and Engineering majors and all School of ICS majors have second right of consideration.

COMPSCI 166.name: Quantum Computation and Information
COMPSCI 166.description: Basic models for quantum computation and their foundations in quantum mechanics. Quantum complexity classes and quantum algorithms, including algorithms for factoring and quantum simulation. Introduction to quantum information theory and quantum entanglement.
COMPSCI 166.prereqString: Prerequisite: (I&C SCI 6N or MATH 3A) and COMPSCI 161
COMPSCI 166.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

COMPSCI 167.name: Introduction to Applied Cryptography
COMPSCI 167.description: An introduction to the essential aspects of applied cryptography, as it is used in practice. Topics include classical cryptography, block ciphers, stream ciphers, public-key cryptography, digital signatures, one-way hash functions, basic cryptographic protocols, and digital certificates and credentials.
COMPSCI 167.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

COMPSCI 169.name: Introduction to Optimization
COMPSCI 169.description: A broad introduction to optimization. Unconstrained and constrained optimization. Equality and inequality constraints. Linear and integer programming. Stochastic dynamic programming.
COMPSCI 169.prereqString: Prerequisite: (I&C SCI 6N or MATH 3A) and (STATS 67 or (STATS 7 and STATS 120A))
COMPSCI 169.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

COMPSCI 171.name: Introduction to Artificial Intelligence
COMPSCI 171.description: Different means of representing knowledge and uses of representations in heuristic problem solving. Representations considered include predicate logic, semantic nets, procedural representations, natural language grammars, and search trees.
COMPSCI 171.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

COMPSCI 172B.name: Neural Networks and Deep Learning
COMPSCI 172B.description: Neural network and deep learning from multiple perspectives. Theory of parallel distributed processing systems, algorithmic approaches for learning from data in various manners, applications to difficult problems in AI from computer vision, to natural language understanding, to bioinformatics and chemoinformatics.
COMPSCI 172B.prereqString: Prerequisite: (STATS 120A and STATS 120B) or MATH 121A or COMPSCI 178 or COMPSCI 273A
COMPSCI 172B.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

COMPSCI 172C.name: Artificial Intelligence Frontiers: Technical, Ethical, and Societal
COMPSCI 172C.description: Explores the frontiers of artificial intelligence and related technologies with a focus on the underlying ethical, legal, and societal challenges and opportunities they create. Encourages critical thinking about these issues.
COMPSCI 172C.prereqString: Prerequisite: COMPSCI 171 and COMPSCI 172B. Recommended: COMPSCI 178
COMPSCI 172C.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

COMPSCI 175.name: Project in Artificial Intelligence
COMPSCI 175.description: Construction of a working artificial intelligence system. Evaluation of capabilities of the system including impact of knowledge representation.
COMPSCI 175.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

COMPSCI 177.name: Applications of Probability in Computer Science
COMPSCI 177.description: Application of probability to real-world problems in computer science. Typical topics include analysis of algorithms and graphs, probabilistic language models, network traffic modeling, data compression, and reliability modeling.
COMPSCI 177.prereqString: Prerequisite: MATH 2B and STATS 67 and I&C SCI 6B and I&C SCI 6D and (MATH 3A or I&C SCI 6N)
COMPSCI 177.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

COMPSCI 178.name: Machine Learning and Data-Mining
COMPSCI 178.description: Introduction to principles of machine learning and data-mining applied to real-world datasets. Typical applications include spam filtering, object recognition, and credit scoring.
COMPSCI 178.prereqString: Prerequisite: I&C SCI 6B and I&C SCI 6D and (I&C SCI 6N or MATH 3A) and MATH 2B and (STATS 67 or (STATS 7 and STATS 120A))
COMPSCI 178.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

COMPSCI 179.name: Algorithms for Probabilistic and Deterministic Graphical Models
COMPSCI 179.description: Graphical model techniques dealing with probabilistic and deterministic knowledge representations. Focuses on graphical models such as constraint networks, Bayesian networks, and Markov networks that have become a central paradigm for knowledge representation and reasoning in AI and general computer science.
COMPSCI 179.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

COMPSCI 180A.name: Project in Computer Science
COMPSCI 180A.description: Students to solve a substantial real-world problem with knowledge gained from many areas in computer science. Project has a focus on computer science but can overlap with neighbor disciplines.
COMPSCI 180A.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment.

COMPSCI 180B.name: Project in Computer Science
COMPSCI 180B.description: Students to solve a substantial real-world problem with knowledge gained from many areas in computer science. Project has a focus on computer science but can overlap with neighbor disciplines.
COMPSCI 180B.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment.

COMPSCI 183.name: Introduction to Computational Biology
COMPSCI 183.description: The use of theories and methods based on computer science, mathematics, and physics in molecular biology and biochemistry. Basics in biomolecular modeling. Analysis of sequence and structural data of biomolecules. Analysis of biomolecular functions.
COMPSCI 183.prereqString: Prerequisite: MATH 2D or MATH 3A or STATS 7 or STATS 8

COMPSCI 184A.name: Artificial Intelligence in Biology and Medicine
COMPSCI 184A.description: Introduction to computational methods in molecular biology, aimed at those interested in learning about this interdisciplinary area. Covers computational approaches to understanding and predicting the structure, function, interactions, and evolution of DNA, RNA, proteins, and related molecules and processes.
COMPSCI 184A.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

COMPSCI 184C.name: Computational Systems Biology
COMPSCI 184C.description: Computational inference and modeling of gene regulation networks, signal transduction pathways, and the effects of regulatory networks in cellular processes, development, and disease. Introduction of required mathematical, computational, and data handling tools.
COMPSCI 184C.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

COMPSCI 190.name: Special Topics in Information and Computer Science
COMPSCI 190.description: Studies in selected areas of Information and Computer Science. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
COMPSCI 190.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment.

COMPSCI H198.name: Honors Research
COMPSCI H198.description: Directed independent research in computer science for honors students.
COMPSCI H198.restriction: Restriction: Campuswide Honors Collegium students only. Bren School of ICS Honors students only. Upper-division students only.

COMPSCI 199.name: Individual Study
COMPSCI 199.description: Individual research or investigation with Computer Science faculty.

COMPSCI 200S.name: Seminar in Computer Science Research
COMPSCI 200S.description: Graduate colloquium series. Includes weekly talks by notable computer scientists.

COMPSCI 201.name: Foundations of Cryptographic Protocols
COMPSCI 201.description: Explores fundamental cryptographic tools, including encryption, signatures, and identification schemes. Students are introduced to the provable security paradigm of modern cryptography, focusing on understanding of security properties provided by cryptographic tools, and on proving security (or insecurity) of cryptographic constructions.

COMPSCI 201P.name: Introduction to Computer Security
COMPSCI 201P.description: Introduction to computer security, including systems, technology, and management. Topics include authorization, authentication, data integrity, malware, operating systems security, network security, web security, and basic cryptography.
COMPSCI 201P.prereqString: Prerequisite: Knowledge of Python or C++ programming is required.
COMPSCI 201P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Computer Science Degree students only. Graduate students only.

COMPSCI 202.name: Applied Cryptography
COMPSCI 202.description: Design and analysis of algorithms for applied cryptography. Topics include symmetric and asymmetric key encryption, digital signatures, one-way hash functions, digital certificates and credentials, and techniques for authorization, non-repudiation, authentication, identification, data integrity, proofs of knowledge, and access control.

COMPSCI 202P.name: Applied Cryptography
COMPSCI 202P.description: Design and analysis of algorithms for applied cryptography. Topics include symmetric and asymmetric key encryption, digital signatures, one-way hash functions, digital certificates and credentials, and techniques for authorization, non-repudiation, authentication, identification, data integrity, proofs of knowledge, and access control.

COMPSCI 203.name: Network and Distributed Systems Security
COMPSCI 203.description: Modern computer and networks security: attacks and countermeasures, authentication, identification, data secrecy, data integrity, authorization, access control, computer viruses, network security. Group communication and multicast security techniques. Covers secure e-commerce and applications of public key methods, digital certificates, and credentials.

COMPSCI 203P.name: Network Security
COMPSCI 203P.description: Introduction to network security, including network threats and attacks, as well as defenses against such attacks. Topics include network infrastructure security, mobile and Wi-Fi security, spam, phishing, firewalls, anonymity, secure email, secure and private cloud computing, and web security.
COMPSCI 203P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Computer Science Degree students only. Graduate students only.

COMPSCI 205.name: Computer and Systems Security
COMPSCI 205.description: Lecture and discuss latest security research in software, OS, protocols, mobile devices, machine learning, sensors, and emerging IoT/CPS systems such as smart home and smart transportation. Students perform research projects and gain hands-on experience evaluating and designing secure systems.
COMPSCI 205.prereqString: Prerequisite: COMPSCI 134 and COMPSCI 142A and COMPSCI 143A
COMPSCI 205.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Graduate students only.

COMPSCI 206.name: Principles of Scientific Computing
COMPSCI 206.description: Overview of widely used principles and methods of numerical and scientific computing, including basic concepts and computational methods in linear algebra, optimization, and probability.
COMPSCI 206.prereqString: Prerequisite: Basic courses in multivariate calculus, linear algebra, and probability.

COMPSCI 206P.name: Principles of Scientific Computing
COMPSCI 206P.description: Overview of widely used principles and methods of numerical and scientific computing, including basic concepts and computational methods in floating-point, linear algebra, optimization, simulation, modeling, and probability/statistics as it relates to model evaluation.
COMPSCI 206P.prereqString: Prerequisite: Basic knowledge of multivariate calculus, linear algebra, and familiarity with MATLAB.

COMPSCI 210P.name: Computer Graphics and Visualization
COMPSCI 210P.description: Interactive 3D graphics rendering pipeline, illumination and shading, ray tracing, texture-, bump-, mip-mapping, hidden surface removal, anti-aliasing, multiresolution representations, volume rendering techniques, iso-surface extraction.
COMPSCI 210P.prereqString: Prerequisite: Familiarity with linear algebra is required.
COMPSCI 210P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Computer Science Degree students only. Graduate students only.

COMPSCI 211A.name: Visual Computing
COMPSCI 211A.description: Fundamentals of image processing (convolution, linear filters, spectral analysis), vision geometry (projective geometry, camera models and calibration, stereo reconstruction), radiometry (color, shading, illumination, BRDF), and visual content synthesis (graphics pipeline, texture- bump-, mip-mapping, hidden surface removal, anti-aliasing).

COMPSCI 211B.name: Computer Graphics and Visualization
COMPSCI 211B.description: Interactive 3D graphics rendering pipeline,  illumination and shading, ray tracing,  texture-, bump-, mip-mapping, hidden surface removal, anti-aliasing,  multiresolution representations, volume rendering techniques, iso-surface extraction.

COMPSCI 211C.name: Realistic Image Synthesis
COMPSCI 211C.description: Provides an in-depth overview on a core sub-field of computer graphics. Graduate  students who take this course are better prepared for conducting research on the related topics in computer graphics, vision, and scientific computing.
COMPSCI 211C.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students only. Graduate students only.

COMPSCI 212.name: Multimedia Systems and Applications
COMPSCI 212.description: Organization and structure of modern multimedia systems
COMPSCI 212.prereqString: Prerequisite: COMPSCI 143A and COMPSCI 161. B.S. degree in Computer Science is also accepted. Recommended: COMPSCI 131 and COMPSCI 132 and COMPSCI 133.

COMPSCI 213.name: Introduction to Visual Perception
COMPSCI 213.description: Introduction to the process of human visual perception. Offers the physiological and psychophysical approach to understand vision, introducing concepts of perception of color, depth, movement. Examples of quantification and application of these models in computer vision, computer graphics, multimedia, HCI.

COMPSCI 216.name: Image Understanding
COMPSCI 216.description: The goal of image understanding is to extract useful semantic information from image data. Course covers low-level image and video processing techniques, feature descriptors, segmentation, objection recognition, and tracking.
COMPSCI 216.prereqString: Prerequisite: I&C SCI 6D and (I&C SCI 6N or MATH 6G or MATH 3A) and MATH 2B and I&C SCI 46

COMPSCI 217.name: Light and Geometry in Computer Vision
COMPSCI 217.description: Examines the issues of light transport and multiview geometry in computer vision. Applications include camera calibration, 3D understanding, stereo reconstruction, and illumination estimation.
COMPSCI 217.prereqString: Prerequisite: I&C SCI 6D and (I&C SCI 6N or MATH 6G or MATH 3A) and MATH 2B and I&C SCI 46 and COMPSCI 211A

COMPSCI 219S.name: Seminar in Graphics and Visualization
COMPSCI 219S.description: Current research and research trends in computer graphics, visualization, virtual/augmented reality, and other visual computing topics.
COMPSCI 219S.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students only. Graduate students only.

COMPSCI 220P.name: Databases and Data Management
COMPSCI 220P.description: Introduction to the design of databases and the use of database management systems (DBMS) for managing and utilizing data. Topics include entity-relationship modeling for design, relational data model, relational algebra, relational schema design, and use of SQL (Structured Query Language).
COMPSCI 220P.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students only. Graduate students only.

COMPSCI 221.name: Information Retrieval, Filtering, and Classification
COMPSCI 221.description: Algorithms for the storage, retrieval, filtering, and classification of textual and multimedia data. The vector space model, Boolean and probabilistic queries, and relevance feedback. Latent semantic indexing
COMPSCI 221.prereqString: Prerequisite: COMPSCI 161 and COMPSCI 171 and (I&C SCI 6N or MATH 3A or MATH 6G)

COMPSCI 222.name: Principles of Data Management
COMPSCI 222.description: Covers fundamental principles underlying data management systems. Content includes key techniques including storage management, buffer management, record-oriented file system, access methods, query optimization, and query processing.
COMPSCI 222.prereqString: Prerequisite: COMPSCI 122A and (I&C SCI 53 or COMPSCI 143A)

COMPSCI 222P.name: Principles of Data Management
COMPSCI 222P.description: Covers fundamental principles underlying data management systems. Understanding and implementation of key techniques including storage management, buffer management, record-oriented file system, access methods, query optimization, and query processing.
COMPSCI 222P.prereqString: Prerequisite: Required: C++ programming skills, understanding of data structures and algorithms.
COMPSCI 222P.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students only. Graduate students only.

COMPSCI 223.name: Transaction Processing and Distributed Data Management
COMPSCI 223.description: Covers fundamental principles underlying transaction processing including database consistency, concurrency control, database recovery, and fault-tolerance. Includes transaction processing in centralized, distributed, parallel, and client-server environments.

COMPSCI 223P.name: Transaction Processing and Distributed Data Management
COMPSCI 223P.description: Introduction to fundamental principles underlying transaction processing systems including database consistency, atomicity, concurrency control, database recovery, replication, commit protocols, and fault-tolerance. Includes transaction processing in centralized, distributed, parallel, and client-server environments.
COMPSCI 223P.prereqString: Prerequisite: COMPSCI 222P or COMPSCI 222. COMPSCI 222P with a grade of B or better. COMPSCI 222 with a grade of B or better

COMPSCI 224P.name: Big Data Management
COMPSCI 224P.description: Focuses on Big Data management frameworks such as Hadoop and Spark. Also covers relational and non-relational database technologies, including document (“NoSQL”) databases as well as emerging cloud data management solutions.
COMPSCI 224P.prereqString: Prerequisite: COMPSCI 220P or COMPSCI 122A. COMPSCI 220P with a grade of B or better. COMPSCI 122A with a grade of C or better
COMPSCI 224P.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students only. Graduate students only.

COMPSCI 225.name: Next Generation Search Systems
COMPSCI 225.description: Discusses concepts and techniques related to all aspects of search systems. After considering basic search technology and the state-of-art systems, rapidly developing techniques for multimedia search, local search, event-search, and video-on-demand are explored.
COMPSCI 225.prereqString: Prerequisite: I&C SCI 21 or CSE 21 or IN4MATX 41 or I&C SCI 31 or CSE 41
COMPSCI 225.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. Graduate students only.

COMPSCI 230.name: Distributed Computer Systems
COMPSCI 230.description: Principles of distributed computing systems. Topics covered include message-passing, remote procedure calls, distributed shared memory synchronization, resource and process/thread management, distributed file systems, naming and security.

COMPSCI 230P.name: Distributed Computer Systems
COMPSCI 230P.description: Principles of distributed computing systems. Topics covered include message-passing, remote procedure calls, distributed shared memory synchronization, resource and process/thread management, distributed file systems, naming and security.

COMPSCI 231P.name: Parallel and Distributed Computing for Professionals
COMPSCI 231P.description: Covers a wide variety of concepts related to the design and application of high-performance concurrent computing systems, including architectural features, communications networks and models, parallel program development for numerical and non-numerical applications, programming models, and more.
COMPSCI 231P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Computer Science Degree students only. Graduate students only.

COMPSCI 232.name: Computer and Communication Networks
COMPSCI 232.description: Network architecture of the Internet, telephone networks, cable networks, and cell phone networks. Network performance models. Network performance models. Advanced concepts and implementations of flow and congestion control, addressing, internetworking, forwarding, routing, multiple access, streaming, and quality-of-service.

COMPSCI 232P.name: Computer and Communication Networks
COMPSCI 232P.description: Internet architecture, protocols, and services. Advanced concepts of IP and TCP, including addressing, internetworking, forwarding, routing, and implementations of flow and congestion control. Internet services such as Network Address Translation and Domain Name Servers. Overview of Local Area Networks.

COMPSCI 233.name: Networking Laboratory
COMPSCI 233.description: A laboratory-based introduction to basic networking concepts such as addressing, sub-netting, bridging, ARP, and routing. Network simulation and design. Structured around weekly readings and laboratory assignments.

COMPSCI 234.name: Advanced Networks
COMPSCI 234.description: Design principles of networked systems, advanced routing and congestion control algorithms, network algorithms, network measurement, management, security, Internet economics, and emerging networks.
COMPSCI 234.prereqString: Prerequisite: NET SYS 201 or COMPSCI 232 or EECS 248A

COMPSCI 236.name: Wireless and Mobile Networking
COMPSCI 236.description: Introduction to wireless networking. The focus is on layers 2 and 3 of the OSI reference model, design, performance analysis, and protocols. Topics covered include: an introduction to wireless networking, digital cellular, next generation cellular, wireless LANs, and mobile IP.

COMPSCI 237.name: Middleware for Networked and Distributed Systems
COMPSCI 237.description: Discusses concepts, techniques, and issues in developing distributed systems middleware that provides high performance and Quality of Service for emerging applications. Also covers existing standards (e.g., CORBA, DCOM, Jini, Espeak) and their relative advantages and shortcomings.
COMPSCI 237.prereqString: Prerequisite: An undergraduate-level course in operating systems and networks.

COMPSCI 238.name: Advanced Operating Systems
COMPSCI 238.description: Focuses on advanced and graduate-level topics in operating systems. Presents important recent developments in operating systems, topics not covered in undergraduate operating systems courses. This includes novel operating system designs and techniques to improve existing ones.

COMPSCI 238P.name: Operating Systems
COMPSCI 238P.description: In-depth organization of the core operating system abstraction and its implementation (virtual memory, kernel and user mode, system calls, threads, context switches, interrupts, inter-process communication, hardware interface, etc.) and a range of recent developments in de-facto industry standard operating systems.
COMPSCI 238P.prereqString: Prerequisite: Working knowledge of C and the Linux environment.
COMPSCI 238P.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students only. Master of Computer Science Degree students only. Graduate students only.

COMPSCI 241.name: Advanced Compiler Construction
COMPSCI 241.description: Advanced study of programming language implementation techniques: optimizations such as common sub-expression elimination, register allocation, and instruction scheduling. Implementation of language features such as type-directed dispatch, garbage collection, dynamic linking, and just-in-time code generation.

COMPSCI 242.name: Parallel Computing
COMPSCI 242.description: Definition of parallel processing systems. Theory and application of arrays, trees, and hypercubes. Computational models, applications: sorting, integer arithmetic, matrix operations, Fast Fourier Transform, and others. Interconnection networks: a framework for the description, analysis, and construction of hypercube-derived networks.

COMPSCI 242P.name: Compilers and Interpreters
COMPSCI 242P.description: Provides in-depth study of compilers and interpreters which are the primary forms of programming language processing in computing.
COMPSCI 242P.prereqString: Prerequisite: Knowledge of C++ programming is required.
COMPSCI 242P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Computer Science Degree students only. Graduate students only.

COMPSCI 243.name: High-Performance Architectures and Their Compilers
COMPSCI 243.description: Emphasis on the development of automatic tools (i.e., compilers/environments) for the efficient exploitation of parallel machines, and the trade-offs between hardware and software in the design of supercomputing and high-performance machines.

COMPSCI 244.name: Introduction to Embedded and Ubiquitous Systems
COMPSCI 244.description: Embedded and ubiquitous system technologies including processors, DSP, memory, and software. System interfacing basics
COMPSCI 244.prereqString: Prerequisite: I&C SCI 51 and COMPSCI 152 and COMPSCI 161 and (I&C SCI 6N or MATH 3A or MATH 6G or I&C SCI 6D). B.S. degree in Computer Science is also accepted.

COMPSCI 244P.name: Introduction to the Internet of Things
COMPSCI 244P.description: Develops a comprehensive understanding of the hardware and software technology, the communication protocols, and the security and privacy requirements underlying the Internet of Things ecosystem, particularly those using computing elements (processors, DSPs/ ASIPs), sensors, and accessing cloud services.
COMPSCI 244P.prereqString: Prerequisite: Undergraduate-level familiarity with fundamentals of integrated circuit blocks, processors, optimization/algorithm design, and some programming experience.

COMPSCI 245.name: Software for Embedded Systems
COMPSCI 245.description: Embedded computing elements, device interfaces, time-critical IO handling. Embedded software design under size, performance, and reliability constraints. Software timing and functional validation. Programming methods and compilation for embeddable software. Embedded runtime systems. Case studies of real-time software systems.
COMPSCI 245.prereqString: Prerequisite: I&C SCI 51 and COMPSCI 152 and COMPSCI 161 and (I&C SCI 6N or MATH 3A or MATH 6G or I&C SCI 6D). B.S. degree in Computer Science is also accepted.

COMPSCI 248A.name: Introduction to Ubiquitous Computing
COMPSCI 248A.description: The "disappearing computer" paradigm. Differences to the desktop computing model: applications, interaction in augmented environments, security, alternate media, small operating systems, sensors, and embedded systems design. Evaluation by project work and class participation.

COMPSCI 248B.name: Ubiquitous Computing and Interaction
COMPSCI 248B.description: Principles and design techniques for ubiquitous computing applications. Conceptual basis for tangible and embodied interaction. Interaction in virtual and augmented environments. Design methods and techniques. Design case studies. Examination by project work.

COMPSCI 250A.name: Computer Systems Architecture
COMPSCI 250A.description: Study of architectural issues and their relation to technology and software: design of processor, interconnections, and memory hierarchies.

COMPSCI 250B.name: Modern Computer Systems
COMPSCI 250B.description: Fundamental concepts and recent advances in computer systems architecture necessary to achieve high performance and efficiency on systems available today. Topics span modern processor features, accelerators, storage and network architectures, as well as architecture-optimized software.
COMPSCI 250B.prereqString: Prerequisite: Required: Undergraduate-level understanding of computer architecture concepts.

COMPSCI 250P.name: Computer Systems Architecture
COMPSCI 250P.description: Study of architectural issues and their relation to technology and software: design of processor, interconnections, and memory hierarchies.
COMPSCI 250P.prereqString: Prerequisite: Undergraduate-level familiarity with fundamentals of integrated circuit blocks, processors, and optimization/algorithm design, and some programming experience.

COMPSCI 252.name: Introduction to Computer Design
COMPSCI 252.description: The methodology and use of CAD tools for computer design, accomplished by a lab in which students practice design using commercially available silicon compilers and other tools.

COMPSCI 253.name: Analysis of Programming Languages
COMPSCI 253.description: Concepts in modern programming languages, their interaction, and the relationship between programming languages and methods for large-scale, extensible software development. Empirical analysis of programming language usage.

COMPSCI 253P.name: Advanced Programming and Problem Solving
COMPSCI 253P.description: Provides in-depth preparation for industry interviews requiring demonstration of problem solving and programming skills. Emphasis is on understanding problem statements, considering edge cases, developing effective test cases, designing correct solutions, explaining these clearly, and implementing a solution correctly.
COMPSCI 253P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Computer Science Degree students only. Graduate students only.

COMPSCI 259S.name: Seminar in Design Science
COMPSCI 259S.description: Current research and research trends in design science. Forum for presentation and criticism by students of research work in progress.

COMPSCI 260.name: Fundamentals of the Design and Analysis of Algorithms
COMPSCI 260.description: Covers fundamental concepts in the design and analysis of algorithms and is geared toward non-specialists in theoretical computer science. Topics include: deterministic and randomized graph algorithms, fundamental algorithmic techniques like divide-and-conquer strategies and dynamic programming, and NP-completeness.

COMPSCI 260P.name: Fundamentals of Algorithms with Applications
COMPSCI 260P.description: Covers fundamental concepts in the design and analysis of algorithms and is geared toward practical application and implementation. Topics include greedy algorithms, deterministic and randomized graph algorithms, models of network flow, fundamental algorithmic techniques, and NP-completeness.
COMPSCI 260P.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students only. Graduate students only.

COMPSCI 261.name: Data Structures
COMPSCI 261.description: An in-depth treatment of data structures and their associated management algorithms including resource complexity analysis.

COMPSCI 261P.name: Data Structures with Applications
COMPSCI 261P.description: Data structures and their associated management algorithms, including their applications and analysis.
COMPSCI 261P.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students only. Graduate students only.

COMPSCI 262.name: Computational Complexity
COMPSCI 262.description: Advanced course in computational models and complexity classes. Covers the fundamentals of Turing Machines, Decidability, and NP-completeness. Includes discussion of more advanced topics including polynomial hierarchy, randomized complexity classes, #P-completeness and hardness of approximation.

COMPSCI 262P.name: Text Processing and Pattern Matching
COMPSCI 262P.description: Techniques for pattern matching and parsing character strings. Topics include substring searching, finite state machines, regular expressions, and context-free grammars, as well as applications in lexical analyzers, compilers, word processors, malware detectors, and search engines.
COMPSCI 262P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Computer Science Degree students only. Graduate students only.

COMPSCI 263.name: Analysis of Algorithms
COMPSCI 263.description: Analysis of correctness and complexity of various efficient algorithms

COMPSCI 264.name: Quantum Computation and Information
COMPSCI 264.description: Basic models for quantum computation and their foundations in quantum mechanics. Quantum complexity classes and quantum algorithms, including algorithms for factoring and quantum simulation. Introduction to quantum information theory and quantum entanglement.
COMPSCI 264.prereqString: Prerequisite: Basic courses in linear algebra and algorithms.

COMPSCI 265.name: Graph Algorithms
COMPSCI 265.description: Graph definitions, representation methods, graph problems, algorithms, approximation methods, and applications.

COMPSCI 266.name: Computational Geometry
COMPSCI 266.description: An overview of some of the basic problems in computational geometry and of some algorithmic and data-structuring techniques appropriate to their solution.

COMPSCI 267P.name: Data Compression
COMPSCI 267P.description: An introduction to the theory and practice of modern data compression techniques. Topics include codes, coding, modeling, text compression, lossless and lossy image compression standards and systems, audio compression.
COMPSCI 267P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Computer Science Degree students only. Graduate students only.

COMPSCI 268.name: Introduction to Optimization
COMPSCI 268.description: A broad introduction to optimization. Unconstrained and constrained optimization. Equality and inequality constraints. Linear and integer programming. Stochastic dynamic programming.
COMPSCI 268.prereqString: Prerequisite: STATS 67 or (STATS 7 and STATS 120A) and (I&C SCI 6N or MATH 3A)
COMPSCI 268.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment.

COMPSCI 268P.name: Introduction to Optimization Modeling
COMPSCI 268P.description: A broad introduction to optimization methods and their applications. Unconstrained and constrained optimization. Direct, first, and second order methods. Use of optimization software libraries. Equality and inequality constraints, optimal conditions, and methods. Applications to modeling in computer science, engineering.

COMPSCI 269S.name: Seminar in the Theory of Algorithms and Data Structures
COMPSCI 269S.description: Current research and research trends in the Theory of algorithms and data structures.

COMPSCI 271.name: Introduction to Artificial Intelligence
COMPSCI 271.description: The study of theories and computational models for systems which behave and act in an intelligent manner. Fundamental subdisciplines of artificial intelligence including knowledge representation, search, deduction, planning, probabilistic reasoning, natural language parsing and comprehension, knowledge-based systems, and learning.

COMPSCI 271P.name: Introduction to Artificial Intelligence
COMPSCI 271P.description: The study of theories and computational models for systems which behave and act in an intelligent manner. Fundamental sub-disciplines of artificial intelligence, including knowledge representation, search, deduction, planning, probabilistic reasoning, natural language parsing and comprehension, knowledge-based systems, and learning.
COMPSCI 271P.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students only. Graduate students only.

COMPSCI 272.name: Statistical Natural Language Processing
COMPSCI 272.description: Statistical models, machine learning algorithms, and computational tasks involved in natural language processing. Focuses on approaches that learn these models from data, and covers applications such as information extraction, dialog systems, machine translation, and question answering.
COMPSCI 272.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Graduate students only.

COMPSCI 273A.name: Machine Learning
COMPSCI 273A.description: Computational approaches to learning algorithms for classifications, regression, and clustering. Emphasis is on discriminative classification methods such as decision trees, rules, nearest neighbor, linear models, and naive Bayes.

COMPSCI 273P.name: Machine Learning and Data Mining
COMPSCI 273P.description: Introduction to principles of machine learning and data-mining. Learning algorithms for classifications, regression, and clustering. Emphasis is on discriminative classification methods such as decision trees, rules, nearest neighbor, linear models, and naive Bayes.
COMPSCI 273P.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students only. Graduate students only.

COMPSCI 274A.name: Probablistic Learning: Theory and Algorithms
COMPSCI 274A.description: An introduction to probabilistic and statistical techniques for learning from data, including parameter estimation, density estimation, regression, classification, and mixture modeling.

COMPSCI 274B.name: Learning in Graphical Models
COMPSCI 274B.description: Models for data analysis are presented in the unifying framework of graphical models. The emphasis is on learning from data but inference is also covered. Real world examples are used to illustrate the material.

COMPSCI 274C.name: Neural Networks and Deep Learning
COMPSCI 274C.description: Neural network and deep learning from multiple perspectives. Theory of parallel distributed processing systems, algorithmic approaches for learning from data in various manners, applications to difficult problems in AI from computer vision, to natural language understanding, to bioinformatics and chemoinformatics.
COMPSCI 274C.prereqString: Prerequisite: (STATS 120A and STATS 120B) or MATH 121A or COMPSCI 178 or COMPSCI 273A

COMPSCI 274D.name: Artificial Intelligence Frontiers: Technical, Ethical, and Societal
COMPSCI 274D.description: Explores the frontiers of artificial intelligence and related technologies with a focus on the underlying ethical, legal, and societal challenges and opportunities they create.  Encourages critical thinking about these issues.

COMPSCI 274E.name: Deep Generative Models
COMPSCI 274E.description: Discusses probabilistic approaches to deep learning such as generative models and their applications in computer vision, NLP, the natural sciences, and other fields. Coursework may include both homework and project components.
COMPSCI 274E.prereqString: Prerequisite: COMPSCI 178 or COMPSCI 273A or STATS 120B. Recommended: Advanced machine learning or graphical models courses such as COMPSCI 274A or COMPSCI 274B or CS 273C or COMPSCI 276.
COMPSCI 274E.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Graduate students only.

COMPSCI 274P.name: Neural Networks and Deep Learning
COMPSCI 274P.description: Introduction to principles of machine learning and neural networks. Architecture design. Feedforward and recurrent networks. Learning models and algorithms.  Applications to data analysis and prediction problems in areas such as machine vision, natural language processing, biomed, and finance.
COMPSCI 274P.prereqString: Prerequisite: COMPSCI 271P. COMPSCI 271P with a grade of B or better. Required: Knowledge of Python programming.
COMPSCI 274P.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students only. Graduate students only.

COMPSCI 275P.name: Graphical Models and Statistical Learning
COMPSCI 275P.description: Introduction to principles of statistical machine learning with probabilistic graphical models. Studies efficient inference algorithms based on optimization-based variational methods, and simulation-based Monte Carlo methods. Several approaches to learning from data are covered.
COMPSCI 275P.prereqString: Prerequisite: Required: Knowledge of Python programming (COMPSCI 273P or equivalent).
COMPSCI 275P.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students only. Graduate students only.

COMPSCI 276.name: Reasoning in Probabilistic Graphical Models
COMPSCI 276.description: Focuses on algorithms for probabilistic reasoning using graphical models such as Bayesian Networks and Markov Networks that encode knowledge as local probabilistic relations. Tasks include finding most likely scenarios over a subset of variables, or updating posterior probability, given observations.
COMPSCI 276.prereqString: Prerequisite: A basic course in probability.

COMPSCI 277.name: Control and Reinforcement Learning
COMPSCI 277.description: In sequential decision-making problems, an agent interacts with its environment by observing the system state and taking actions to control it. This paradigm encompasses many important technologies, from robots to cyber-physical systems to virtual assistants.

COMPSCI 278.name: Probability Models
COMPSCI 278.description: Advanced probability, discrete time Markov chains, Poisson processes, continuous time Markov chains. Queuing or simulation as time permits.

COMPSCI 284A.name: Artificial Intelligence in Biology and Medicine
COMPSCI 284A.description: Introduction to computational methods in molecular biology, aimed at those interested in learning about this interdisciplinary area. Covers computational approaches to understanding and predicting the structure, function, interactions, and evolution of DNA, RNA, proteins, and related molecules and processes.
COMPSCI 284A.prereqString: Prerequisite: A Basic course in algorithms or a basic course in molecular biology.

COMPSCI 284C.name: Computational Systems Biology
COMPSCI 284C.description: Computational inference and modeling of gene regulation networks, signal transduction pathways, and the effects of regulatory networks in cellular processes, development, and disease. Introduction of required mathematical, computational, and data handling tools.
COMPSCI 284C.prereqString: Prerequisite: COMPSCI 284A or (BIO SCI 99 and MATH 2D)

COMPSCI 285.name: Mathematical and Computational Biology
COMPSCI 285.description: Analytical and numerical methods for dynamical systems, temporal-spatial dynamics, steady state, stability, stochasticity. Application to life sciences: genetics, tissue growth and patterning, cancers, ion channels gating, signaling networks, morphogen gradients. Probabilistic methods.

COMPSCI 290.name: Research Seminar
COMPSCI 290.description: Forum for presentation and criticism by students of research work in progress. Presentation of problem areas and related work. Specific goals and progress of research.

COMPSCI 294P.name: Keystone Professional Writing and Communication for Computer Science Careers
COMPSCI 294P.description: Well-developed written and oral communication skills relevant to computer science professionals including oral presentations, short descriptive writing assignments, and one longer writing assignment related to a research replication project.

COMPSCI 295.name: Special Topics in Information and Computer Science
COMPSCI 295.description: Studies in selected areas of Information and Computer Science. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

COMPSCI 295P.name: Keystone Project for Computer Science
COMPSCI 295P.description: Design and development of a software system or a hardware component of a system based on knowledge of advanced computer science principles. Students implement at least a working prototype and test this using relevant input data.

COMPSCI 296.name: Elements of Scientific Writing
COMPSCI 296.description: Introduces the concepts and principles of good scientific writing, demonstrates them by examples drawn from the literature, and uses a hands-on approach to apply them to documents being written by the participants.

COMPSCI 296P.name: Capstone Professional Writing and Communication for Computer Science Careers
COMPSCI 296P.description: Written and oral communication for computer science and IT careers. Production of the detailed design and development document for the concurrent capstone design class and refinement of written documents and oral communications skills needed for a successful job search.
COMPSCI 296P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Computer Science Degree students only. Graduate students only.

COMPSCI 297P.name: Capstone Design Project for Computer Science
COMPSCI 297P.description: Design and development of app, software system, or hardware component of system based on students' prior knowledge of advanced computer science principles. Implement at least a working prototype and test this using relevant use cases and/or input data.
COMPSCI 297P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Computer Science Degree students only. Graduate students only.

COMPSCI 298.name: Thesis Supervision
COMPSCI 298.description: Individual research or investigation conducted in preparation for the M.S. thesis option or the dissertation requirements for the Ph.D. program.
COMPSCI 298.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. School of Information and Computer Science majors only.

COMPSCI 298P.name: Computer Science Practicum
COMPSCI 298P.description: Internship in which students work individually at an outside organization to gain experience with the challenges involved in technology-related work.
COMPSCI 298P.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students only. Master of Computer Science Degree students only. Graduate students only.

COMPSCI 299.name: Individual Study
COMPSCI 299.description: Individual research or investigation with Computer Science faculty.
COMPSCI 299.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. School of Information and Computer Science majors only.

COMPSCI 299P.name: Individual Study
COMPSCI 299P.description: Supervised individual study in computer science.
COMPSCI 299P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Computer Science Degree students have first consideration for enrollment. Graduate students only.

CRITISM 200A.name: Political Economy: Methods and Critique
CRITISM 200A.description: Introduction to canonical texts in Marxism coupled with an examination of the questions of race, gender, ethnicity, and sexuality that distend the calculus of the canon’s assumptive logic. May be taken after CLT&THY 200B.

CRM/LAW C7.name: Introduction to Criminology, Law and Society
CRM/LAW C7.description: Introduces characteristics of the U.S. criminal justice system, including responses to crime, components of the system, and current challenges to the system. Examines structure and function of police and courts, criminal procedure, and sentencing and incarceration policies.
CRM/LAW C7.restriction: Restriction: Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Urban Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CRM/LAW C10.name: Fundamentals of Criminology, Law and Society
CRM/LAW C10.description: Introduces three interdisciplinary literatures: criminology, socio-legal studies, and justice studies. Focuses on theoretical and empirical work addressing law making, law breaking, and legal systems.
CRM/LAW C10.restriction: Restriction: Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CRM/LAW H80.name: The Properties of Property
CRM/LAW H80.description: Develops an understanding and critique of private property. Draws from interdisciplinary sources to explore the foundations of private property, the institutions that support it over time, and possible alternatives to it.
CRM/LAW H80.restriction: Restriction: Campuswide Honors Collegium students only.

CRM/LAW C100.name: Special Topics in Criminology, Law and Society
CRM/LAW C100.description: Course content varies with interest of the instructor.

CRM/LAW C101.name: American Law
CRM/LAW C101.description: Introduction to substantive and procedural law governing private dispute resolution, including common law (tort, property, contracts), lawsuits (civil procedure), and alternative dispute resolution
CRM/LAW C101.restriction: Restriction: Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CRM/LAW C102.name: Introduction to the Comparative Study of Legal Cultures
CRM/LAW C102.description: Traces the anthropological and comparative cultural study of law from the nineteenth century to the present
CRM/LAW C102.restriction: Restriction: Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. SocEcol-Urban & Regional Plan Majors have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CRM/LAW C103.name: US Legal Thought
CRM/LAW C103.description: Evolution of legal thought in socio-historical context from 19th century to present
CRM/LAW C103.restriction: Restriction: Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CRM/LAW C104.name: Sociology of Law
CRM/LAW C104.description: Examines law creation and law enforcement in their social and political context. Discusses the major theories of law and the modern state, and presents case studies in order to evaluate the strengths and weaknesses of these theoretical perspectives.
CRM/LAW C104.restriction: Restriction: Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CRM/LAW C105.name: Psychology and the Law
CRM/LAW C105.description: Psychological assumptions of the American legal system and mental health aspects of provision of criminal justice services. Civil commitment, insanity defense, competence to stand trial, jury selection, eyewitness identification. Use of police, courts, correctional institutions in prevention of behavior disorder.
CRM/LAW C105.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. SocEcol-Urban & Regional Plan Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CRM/LAW C106.name: Crime and Public Policy
CRM/LAW C106.description: Explores nature and dimensions of crime in America and uses and limits of various strategies to control it. Topics include growth of imprisonment, the problem of domestic violence, the death penalty, gun control, and the potential of crime prevention programs.
CRM/LAW C106.restriction: Restriction: Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CRM/LAW C107.name: Deviance
CRM/LAW C107.description: Perspectives on deviance and criminality in behavior, institution, community, and myth. The suitability of contemporary theories of deviant behavior.
CRM/LAW C107.restriction: Restriction: Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Sociology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CRM/LAW C108.name: Criminological Theory
CRM/LAW C108.description: Explores the question of crime causation from a number of theoretical perspectives in the social sciences. Schools of thought examined include utilitarianism, positivism, human ecology, social structural approaches, social process (learning) theories, labeling, and radical-critical (political) perspectives.
CRM/LAW C108.restriction: Restriction: Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CRM/LAW C109.name: Juvenile Delinquency
CRM/LAW C109.description: Patterns of delinquent behavior, theories that explain behavior, current research aimed at enhancing exploratory power. Attempts to prevent and control delinquency are put in historical perspective. Development of the current juvenile justice system and evolution of modern juvenile law.
CRM/LAW C109.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. SocEcol-Urban & Regional Plan Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CRM/LAW C110.name: Community Context of Crime
CRM/LAW C110.description: Examines the social context of high-crime communities, with special emphasis on the problems of poverty, joblessness, economic inequality, and racial discrimination. Assesses debates on the causes of these problems, and on the most effective policies to combat them.
CRM/LAW C110.restriction: Restriction: Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CRM/LAW C111.name: Theories of Punishment
CRM/LAW C111.description: Survey of the various schools of thought regarding formal punishment theory. The purposes of legal sanctions are examined, including those of deterrence, rehabilitation, retribution, and incapacitation. Considers problems in realizing formal goals of punishment in practice.
CRM/LAW C111.restriction: Restriction: Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CRM/LAW C112.name: Legal Sanctions and Social Control
CRM/LAW C112.description: Examination of criminal sanctions as mechanisms of social control. Includes the nature, function, and organization of courts as sanction generating institutions, and problems associated with punishing white-collar and corporate illegalities.
CRM/LAW C112.restriction: Restriction: Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CRM/LAW C113.name: Gender and Social Control
CRM/LAW C113.description: Examines the legal system's use of sex as an organizing characteristic, focusing particularly on sameness and difference feminism, and tracing the evolution of equal treatment of men and women in the areas of constitutional rights, employment, education, and military service.
CRM/LAW C113.restriction: Restriction: Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CRM/LAW C114.name: Miscarriages of Justice
CRM/LAW C114.description: Systematically describes, explains, and analyzes the causes and consequences of the wrongful accusation, prosecution, incarceration, and sometimes even execution, of the innocent in the American criminal justice system.
CRM/LAW C114.restriction: Restriction: Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CRM/LAW C115.name: Prisons, Punishment, and Corrections
CRM/LAW C115.description: A review of how the U.S. punishes and rehabilitates convicted law violators. The conflicts among the major purposes of sentencing—rehabilitation, deterrence, incapacitation—are discussed, as well as the effects of different sanctions on public safety, offender rehabilitation, and justice system costs.
CRM/LAW C115.restriction: Restriction: Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CRM/LAW C116.name: Race, Ethnicity, and Social Control
CRM/LAW C116.description: Provides a historical and sociological survey of racial and ethnic group relations in contexts of crime control, emphasizing the roles of racial ideology, structural racism, and social movements in shaping these dynamic relations, and their significance to American liberal democracy.

CRM/LAW C117.name: Imprisonment and Reentry
CRM/LAW C117.description: Offers an overview of imprisonment and reentry in the contemporary United States. Examines the development of the prison in the United States and explores changes in its composition, structure, and purpose over time.
CRM/LAW C117.restriction: Restriction: Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CRM/LAW C118.name: Domestic Violence
CRM/LAW C118.description: General perspectives about domestic violence and theoretical accounts about what causes such behavior.
CRM/LAW C118.restriction: Restriction: Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CRM/LAW C119.name: Violence in Intimate Relationships
CRM/LAW C119.description: Responses to various forms of domestic violence, such as intimate partner violence and child abuse. Covers barriers to reporting to the police, and prosecutors and courts. Human services, such as safety planning for victims, treatment programs, and restorative justice approaches.

CRM/LAW C120.name: Law and Inequality
CRM/LAW C120.description: Various aspects of the law as related to three specific areas of inequality: immigration and immigrants, race, and gender. The role of law as a tool of social reform and limitations of the legal system historically in resolving inequality issues.
CRM/LAW C120.restriction: Restriction: Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CRM/LAW C122.name: Constitutional Law
CRM/LAW C122.description: Examines the evolution of civil liberties and individual rights in the United States, focusing on how Constitutional Amendments and U.S. Supreme Court decision-making have shaped the ongoing political and legal struggles over issues such as privacy, abortion, and free speech.
CRM/LAW C122.restriction: Restriction: Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CRM/LAW C123.name: Family Law
CRM/LAW C123.description: Examines legal issues surrounding marriage, cohabitation, divorce, child custody and support, adoption, and the rights of parents and children in the family context. The findings of social science research are used to illuminate the legal issues.
CRM/LAW C123.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CRM/LAW C124.name: Mental Health and the Justice System
CRM/LAW C124.description: Covers the history of criminalization of persons with mental illness
CRM/LAW C124.restriction: Restriction: Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CRM/LAW C127.name: Hate Crimes
CRM/LAW C127.description: Examines the causes, manifestations, and consequences of hate crimes and the larger social context within which they occur. The politics and dynamics of intergroup violence born of bigotry and manifested as discrimination
CRM/LAW C127.restriction: Restriction: Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CRM/LAW C128.name: Environmental Law and Policy
CRM/LAW C128.description: Environmental law as a combination of traditional legal principles and newly created statutes, rules, and decisions applied to environmental protection. Investigates roles of courts, legislature, executive branch and administrative agencies, and private citizens attempting to regulate environmental quality.
CRM/LAW C128.restriction: Restriction: Criminology, Law and Society Majors only. Urban Studies Majors only.

CRM/LAW C130.name: Seminar on Gangs
CRM/LAW C130.description: An overview of gangs, including the nature and definition of gangs
CRM/LAW C130.restriction: Restriction: Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CRM/LAW C131.name: Organized Crime and American Society
CRM/LAW C131.description: Examination of the phenomenon of American organized crime from a sociological perspective. Explanation of methods by which organized crime is tolerated at various levels of society. Emphasis on ways in which "underworld" interests interact with legitimate economic and political institutions.
CRM/LAW C131.restriction: Restriction: Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CRM/LAW C132.name: Forensic Science, Law, and Society
CRM/LAW C132.description: Examines use of "forensic science" to resolve issues arising in criminal cases including crime scene analysis, DNA testing, fingerprints, trace evidence comparisons, profiling, lie detectors, other forensic techniques
CRM/LAW C132.restriction: Restriction: Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CRM/LAW C133.name: Homicide and Suicide
CRM/LAW C133.description: Examines similarities and differences among homicide and suicide, two major causes of death.
CRM/LAW C133.restriction: Restriction: Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CRM/LAW C134.name: Victimless Crimes
CRM/LAW C134.description: Examines major theoretical, empirical, and policy-oriented research related to the design, implementation, and analysis of government intervention, through the criminal sanction, in the spheres of vice and morality.
CRM/LAW C134.restriction: Restriction: Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CRM/LAW C135.name: Mass Incarceration and Social Inequality in America
CRM/LAW C135.description: Explores the origins and consequences of mass incarceration
CRM/LAW C135.restriction: Restriction: Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CRM/LAW C136.name: Forensic Psychology: Advanced Seminar
CRM/LAW C136.description: Focuses on the psychology of criminal offending, particularly violent behavior. Examines violence, sexual offending, and mental disorder related to crime with regard to clinical assessment and treatment
CRM/LAW C136.prereqString: Prerequisite: (PSCI 9 or PSCI 11C or PSYCH 7A or PSYCH 9C) and PSCI 102C and (PSCI 178S or CRM/LAW C149)
CRM/LAW C136.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CRM/LAW C138.name: Media Effects on Law and Justice
CRM/LAW C138.description: Examines theoretical and methodological frameworks necessary for understanding mass media effects. Trains students to analyze and create media content that cover a wide array of law and justice topics, such as criminal trial procedures, coerced confessions, and mass incarceration.
CRM/LAW C138.restriction: Restriction: Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CRM/LAW C139.name: Police and Change
CRM/LAW C139.description: Organizational efforts to modify police conduct are addressed by focusing on the history of policing in the United States including training, education, and the contributions of women.
CRM/LAW C139.restriction: Restriction: Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CRM/LAW C140.name: Surveillance and Society
CRM/LAW C140.description: Explores the development and deployment of surveillance technologies in contemporary society. The social and legal impact of surveillance technologies, in such areas as crime control, privacy, trust, community, democracy, and the war on terror.
CRM/LAW C140.restriction: Restriction: Criminology, Law and Society Majors only.

CRM/LAW C141.name: Anthropology of Law
CRM/LAW C141.description: Introduces the anthropological study of law through a focus on the foundations of this subfield, its primary methodologies, and several important topics of inquiry, including policing, immigration, and structural inequalities. Provides an international perspective on law and society.
CRM/LAW C141.restriction: Restriction: Anthropology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CRM/LAW C142.name: White-Collar Crime
CRM/LAW C142.description: Examines criminal activity in business and corporate enterprise, organizations, and the professions. Theories regarding the causes and control of white-collar and corporate crime are covered as well as the numerous definitions of these terms.
CRM/LAW C142.restriction: Restriction: Sociology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CRM/LAW C144.name: Criminal Law
CRM/LAW C144.description: Deals specifically with the substantive nature of criminal law and its historical development. Focuses on understanding the development of fundamental doctrinal principles upon which criminal law is based, including mens rea, actus reus, homicide, causation, group criminality, and exculpation.
CRM/LAW C144.restriction: Restriction: Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CRM/LAW C145.name: Government Crime
CRM/LAW C145.description: Examines the legal, organizational, and political issues involved in the generation and control of government lawlessness. Readings present historical and theoretical perspectives in the abuse of government authority and the ability of the legal system to control such behavior.
CRM/LAW C145.restriction: Restriction: Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CRM/LAW C149.name: Violence in Society
CRM/LAW C149.description: Current theory and research on aggression
CRM/LAW C149.prereqString: Prerequisite: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11C or PSYCH 7A or PSYCH 9C
CRM/LAW C149.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. SocEcol-Urban & Regional Plan Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CRM/LAW C150.name: The Legal Profession
CRM/LAW C150.description: Role of the legal profession in modern society, the diverse professional roles lawyers play, the American legal profession compared with that of other societies. "Litigation explosion," ethical problems, interactions between lawyers and other professionals, training and socialization of new lawyers.
CRM/LAW C150.restriction: Restriction: Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CRM/LAW C160.name: Forensic Psychology
CRM/LAW C160.description: Forensic psychology is the interface between clinical psychology and the law. Emphasizes clinically relevant legal topics (insanity defense
CRM/LAW C160.prereqString: Prerequisite: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11B or PSCI 11C
CRM/LAW C160.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CRM/LAW C162.name: Crime Hotspots
CRM/LAW C162.description: Criminological theories of local public safety hazards or hotspots are introduced. Spatial statistics are developed for different types of hotspots. Hotspot policing theories are introduced and research on the effectiveness of policing strategies is reviewed.
CRM/LAW C162.restriction: Restriction: Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CRM/LAW C163.name: Ethics and Politics of Justice
CRM/LAW C163.description: Theoretical perspective on how ethics and politics relate to criminal justice through an introduction to moral philosophy
CRM/LAW C163.restriction: Restriction: Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CRM/LAW C164.name: Social Control of Delinquency
CRM/LAW C164.description: Assumes familiarity with theories of delinquency, the juvenile justice system, and elements of juvenile law. Explores socio-historical origins and evolution of juvenile justice, current research and policy on delinquency prevention and treatment, and future directions of law, policy, and practice.
CRM/LAW C164.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CRM/LAW C165.name: The Death Penalty
CRM/LAW C165.description: Examines why the U.S. continues to have a death penalty when so many other countries have abandoned it. Arguments for and against the death penalty are covered.
CRM/LAW C165.restriction: Restriction: Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CRM/LAW C166.name: Spatial Criminology
CRM/LAW C166.description: Scholars have long noted crime events exhibit a spatial patterning. The principal theoretical perspectives that attempt to explain such a spatial patterning, as well as the research methods used to study crime in spatial context are considered.

CRM/LAW C167.name: Crime Measurement
CRM/LAW C167.description: The strengths and weaknesses of three crime measures (police reports, victim surveys, and offender self-reports) are illustrated through analyses of research articles. Common measurement problems are analyzed with a focus on reliability and validity.
CRM/LAW C167.restriction: Restriction: Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CRM/LAW C168.name: Extreme Punishment
CRM/LAW C168.description: Explores the history and law of America’s Eighth Amendment prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment, examining the death penalty, long prison sentences, harsh confinement conditions, and other punishments. Students debate practical, legal, and moral arguments for and against these punishments.
CRM/LAW C168.restriction: Restriction: Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CRM/LAW C169W.name: Advanced Research Methods
CRM/LAW C169W.description: For students planning to conduct senior research projects or apply to graduate school in social research fields. Topics include reviewing literature, preparing a research proposal, protecting human subjects, citing scholarly work, building measures, estimating sample size, interview and presentation skills.
CRM/LAW C169W.prereqString: Prerequisite: SOCECOL 10 and SOCECOL 13. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

CRM/LAW C172.name: Culture Change and the Mexican People
CRM/LAW C172.description: Reviews culture contact and colonization, innovation diffusion, acculturation, assimilation, culture conflict and marginality, modernization, urbanization, legal transformations. Mexico and the Southwestern U.S. are reviewed through several centuries to better appreciate the indigenous base of the Mexican people.

CRM/LAW C173.name: Maritime Piracy, Law and Society
CRM/LAW C173.description: Explores the historical and contemporary images and reality of pirates and piracy since the 16th century across the globe through an analysis of primary sources, key historiographical and legal debates, and criminological theories.
CRM/LAW C173.restriction: Restriction: Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CRM/LAW C174.name: Immigration and Crime
CRM/LAW C174.description: Examines immigration and crime in the global context, highlighting immigrants as criminals and victims

CRM/LAW C175.name: Issues in Policing
CRM/LAW C175.description: Lectures and readings focus on the history and strategies of policing, measuring the quality of policing, and police misconduct. Strategies for enhancing the quality of policing for controlling misconduct are covered.

CRM/LAW C176.name: Classics in Crime Cinema
CRM/LAW C176.description: A multidimensional understanding of crime films and how they shape public thinking about crime and criminals.
CRM/LAW C176.restriction: Restriction: CRM/LAW C176 and CRM/LAW C20 may not be taken for credit.

CRM/LAW C177.name: Eyewitness Testimony
CRM/LAW C177.description: Faulty eyewitness testimony is a major cause of wrongful convictions. Covers the fast-growing topic of eyewitness testimony and memory for real-world events, both how psychologists study eyewitness capacity, and how the legal system has dealt with eyewitness issues.
CRM/LAW C177.restriction: Restriction: Seniors only. Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CRM/LAW C178.name: Critical Race Theory
CRM/LAW C178.description: Introduction to Critical Race Theory and key American cases on racial inequality. Using this literature, examines the possibilities and pitfalls of legal claims of race, gender, and sexuality discrimination in the age of colorblindness.

CRM/LAW C179.name: Race and Incarceration
