CRM/LAW C179.description: Examines the racial politics of mass incarceration through historical, empirical, theoretical, and legal frameworks. Focuses on race, gender, and sexual differences to develop a critique on policing, incarceration, and other forms of punishment.

CRM/LAW C180.name: Power, Constructions of Deviance, and Social Control
CRM/LAW C180.description: Examines the forms and limits of power in the construction of social deviants. Theories of state power are covered to understand the prison system as a contemporary driver of social inequality. The collateral consequences of mass incarceration are discussed.
CRM/LAW C180.restriction: Restriction: Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. SocEcol-Urban & Regional Plan Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CRM/LAW C182.name: Illegal Economics
CRM/LAW C182.description: How illegal firms function in illegal markets, why individuals participate in these groups and markets, and what federal, state, and local governments do to disrupt organized illegal activity.
CRM/LAW C182.restriction: Restriction: Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CRM/LAW C183.name: Controversies, Courts, Cultures: The Anthropology of Law
CRM/LAW C183.description: Assesses the contributions anthropology has made to legal scholarship, reviewing historical and contemporary themes. Considers both comparative questions of law’s norms, structures, and practices around the globe, and the specific insights anthropology offers about contemporary U.S. law.

CRM/LAW C184.name: Economics of Criminal Justice
CRM/LAW C184.description: Provides an introduction to the economics of crime literature.
CRM/LAW C184.restriction: Restriction: Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CRM/LAW C186.name: Social Media and The Law
CRM/LAW C186.description: Examines legal and policy issues raised by the rise of social media. Surveys how social networking platforms and other emerging technologies impact the right to privacy, public perceptions of judicial systems, and the law generally.
CRM/LAW C186.restriction: Restriction: Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CRM/LAW C187.name: Undocumented Immigrant Experiences
CRM/LAW C187.description: Examines the experiences of undocumented immigrants and the policies that structure their educational, economic, social, and political participation.

CRM/LAW C190.name: Applied Statistics in Social and Behavioral Research
CRM/LAW C190.description: Covers statistical techniques used to describe and make generalizations about phenomena represented by data. Hands-on experience in data analysis and interpretation using statistical software (SPSS, STATA) is emphasized. Topics include data visualization, ANOVA, multiple regression, and categorical data analyses.
CRM/LAW C190.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Urban Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CRM/LAW C191.name: Law and Modernity
CRM/LAW C191.description: The rise and spread of Enlightenment legal traditions, social contract theory, individual rights, ideologies of "liberty, equality, fraternity"

CRM/LAW C196.name: Research Seminar in Criminology, Law and Society
CRM/LAW C196.description: Special topics research seminar. Content varies with interest of instructor. Capstone research opportunity with Criminology, Law and Society faculty members.
CRM/LAW C196.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. Anthropology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CRM/LAW C201.name: Research Methods
CRM/LAW C201.description: An introduction to techniques of inductive methodologies, including qualitative interviewing and participant observation, and deductive methodologies, including survey research and experimental and quasi-experimental design. Provides a sound overview of research methodology with tools to pursue specific methods in greater depth.

CRM/LAW C202.name: Research Methods II
CRM/LAW C202.description: Covers qualitative approaches (interview strategies, varieties of ethnography, archival and historical methods, etc.) and quantitative approaches (survey methods, experimental designs, secondary data sets, comparative and international data, etc.), and concludes with mixed-method approaches.
CRM/LAW C202.prereqString: Prerequisite: CRM/LAW C201. CRM/LAW C201 with a grade of B or better

CRM/LAW C203A.name: Qualitative Methods Practicum
CRM/LAW C203A.description: Designed to deepen students’ familiarity with qualitative research strategies and to guide them through the initial stages of their Second Year Project requirement, such as the development of an original research proposal and/or a research instrument.
CRM/LAW C203A.prereqString: Prerequisite: CRM/LAW C202. CRM/LAW C202 with a grade of B or better

CRM/LAW C203B.name: Quantitative Methods Practicum
CRM/LAW C203B.description: Deepens familiarity with quantitative research and provides a foundation for the second-year paper, e.g., initial models for data analysis and/or a replication study. Students evaluate what assumptions are necessary for credible inference in different evaluation approaches.
CRM/LAW C203B.prereqString: Prerequisite: CRM/LAW C202. CRM/LAW C202 with a grade of B or better

CRM/LAW C207.name: Land-Use Law
CRM/LAW C207.description: Investigates legal and institutional frameworks for development control. Review of constitutional issues implicated in land-use regulation. Traces development control historically and analyzes contemporary approaches to land-use control which reflect environmental and economic development concerns.

CRM/LAW C210.name: Introduction to Criminology, Law and Society
CRM/LAW C210.description: Familiarizes students with the interrelated fields of criminology, law and society studies, and criminal justice studies. Organized around three well-established interdisciplinary literatures: criminology, sociolegal studies, and criminal justice studies.
CRM/LAW C210.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Criminology, Law and Society Majors only.

CRM/LAW C211.name: Legal Institutions and Society
CRM/LAW C211.description: Acquaints students with the institutions of U.S. legal system and its operations, as well as with the constitutional framework undergirding this system, and defines the relationship between U.S. citizens and government at a variety of levels.

CRM/LAW C212.name: Policing
CRM/LAW C212.description: Introduces the subject of policing. Topics include the management of police organizations, the effectiveness of police patrol strategies, the experiences of women in policing, the recruitment and retention of police officers, and other related topics.

CRM/LAW C213.name: Crime and Social Deviance
CRM/LAW C213.description: Examines the major social scientific perspectives on criminal and deviant behavior. Specific deviant and criminal activities are described and explained using established theoretical frameworks.

CRM/LAW C214.name: Research Methods
CRM/LAW C214.description: Structures research methodology, the approach to developing and evaluating knowledge of the sciences for use in criminal justice professional activities. Special emphasis on differentiating scientific approaches from pseudo-science.

CRM/LAW C215.name: Applied Statistics
CRM/LAW C215.description: Provides a basis for the use of fundamental statistical analysis techniques for solving public policy and management problems through a series of assignments, examinations, and online discussions and demonstrations.

CRM/LAW C216.name: Public Policy, Crime, and Criminal Justice
CRM/LAW C216.description: Increases understanding of crime, violence, and the criminal justice system. Assesses the state of knowledge on key policy issues of our time. Discusses the contribution of communities, schools, employment, drugs, guns, and alcohol to crime and violence.

CRM/LAW C217.name: Leadership
CRM/LAW C217.description: Introduces concepts, ideas, and theories about leadership and its operation. Explores leadership concepts through interviews with leaders from the community and fellow classmates.

CRM/LAW C218.name: Social Problems, Law, and Policy
CRM/LAW C218.description: Capstone course for M.A.S. program in Criminology, Law and Society. Students choose a social problem related to crime, criminal justice, and law
CRM/LAW C218.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Criminology, Law and Society Majors only.

CRM/LAW C219.name: Hate Crime
CRM/LAW C219.description: Examines the causes, manifestations, and consequences of hate crimes, as well as the larger social context within which they occur, are reacted to, and seem to be proliferating.

CRM/LAW C221.name: Sentencing and Corrections
CRM/LAW C221.description: Reviews U.S. attempts to punish and rehabilitate convicted law violators. Conflicts among major purposes of sentencing (rehabilitation, deterrence, incapacitation, and retribution) are discussed, as well as effects of different sanctions on public safety, offender rehabilitation, and justice system costs.

CRM/LAW C222.name: Ethnography
CRM/LAW C222.description: Explores the theory and practice of ethnography with a focus on anthropology, the discipline most associated with ethnography. Students are exposed to the theoretical underpinnings of ethnographic work, traditional and innovative practices, and sample ethnographies.

CRM/LAW C224.name: Organizational Perspectives on the Legal System
CRM/LAW C224.description: Familiarizes students with organization theory and research as ways to make sense of, navigate, and act on the legal system. Acquaints students with major frameworks in organization theory and their application to the system of legal organizations.

CRM/LAW C226.name: Causal Methods for Policy Analysis
CRM/LAW C226.description: Provides students with hands-on experience using existing data to estimate the impact of policy and law on individual behavior or aggregate social outcomes. Covers different econometric strategies used to identify causal effects in the absence of an experiment.

CRM/LAW C228.name: Criminology: Micro Approaches
CRM/LAW C228.description: Introduces students to the dominant theories in modern criminology, their theoretical antecedents and extensions, major empirical tests and implications for programs, policy and practice, and focuses on micro-level, individual theories of crime causation. Formerly Criminology, Law and Society C233A.

CRM/LAW C229.name: Criminology: Macro Approaches
CRM/LAW C229.description: Introduces students to the dominant theories in modern criminology, their theoretical antecedents and extensions, major empirical tests and implications for programs, policy and practices, and addresses macro-level theories of crime causation. Formerly Criminology, Law and Society C233B.

CRM/LAW C231.name: Crime and Gender
CRM/LAW C231.description: Examines the legal, political, social, economic, and policy implications of making gender (primarily) and race (secondarily) the focus in the study of crime, criminal law, and the criminal justice system.

CRM/LAW C232.name: Juvenile Delinquency
CRM/LAW C232.description: Examines the major theoretical perspectives regarding the onset, persistence, and desistance of juvenile delinquency, and examines empirical evidence for each perspective.

CRM/LAW C234.name: Anthropology of Law
CRM/LAW C234.description: Law has been a key site of anthropological inquiry since the discipline's nineteenth-century origins. Course introduces and critically assesses the contributions anthropology has made to sociolegal lytic trends.

CRM/LAW C238.name: White-Collar Crime
CRM/LAW C238.description: Examines the illegal behavior of individuals who commit crimes in the course of their employment. Special attention will be paid to ways in which power and organizational structure affect the behavior of the white-collar offenders.

CRM/LAW C239A.name: Law and Society I
CRM/LAW C239A.description: Provides an introduction to the law and society field from its origins in social scientific, legal, and philosophical scholarship during the eighteenth, nineteenth, and early-twentieth centuries. Formerly Criminology, Law, and Society C239.

CRM/LAW C239B.name: Law and Society II
CRM/LAW C239B.description: Building on Law and Society I, addresses contemporary issues in the field from mid-twentieth century to the present with emphasis on the degree to which the field's foundational assumptions are being challenged, refined, or confirmed through current research.

CRM/LAW C240A.name: Socio-Legal Workshop
CRM/LAW C240A.description: Designed to foster intellectual discussion, encourage practice and skill-building in providing feedback, and build substantive knowledge of legal scholarship, this workshop is for both law and doctoral students across campus who are interested in interdisciplinary approaches to studying law.

CRM/LAW C240B.name: Socio-Legal Workshop
CRM/LAW C240B.description: Designed to foster intellectual discussion, encourage practice and skill-building in providing feedback, and build substantive knowledge of legal scholarship, this workshop is for both law and doctoral students across campus who are interested in interdisciplinary approaches to studying law.

CRM/LAW C240C.name: Socio-Legal Workshop
CRM/LAW C240C.description: Designed to foster intellectual discussion, encourage practice and skill-building in providing feedback, and build substantive knowledge of legal scholarship, this workshop is for both law and doctoral students across campus who are interested in interdisciplinary approaches to studying law.
CRM/LAW C240C.prereqString: Prerequisite: CRM/LAW C240B. CRM/LAW C240B with a grade of B or better

CRM/LAW C242.name: Crime Hotspots
CRM/LAW C242.description: Focuses on the criminological theory of hotspots, beginning with the “when, where, and why” questions and ending with the practical policing strategies that have been developed to mitigate hotspot public safety hazards.

CRM/LAW C248.name: Geographic Information Systems
CRM/LAW C248.description: Prepares students to become proficient in the basic GIS functionality including visualization, data management, and spatial analysis.

CRM/LAW C250.name: Preventing Errors of Justice
CRM/LAW C250.description: Examines the types of errors that are made in the U.S. criminal justice system and how we might prevent these errors, including failures to convict guilty offenders as well as wrongful convictions of the innocent.

CRM/LAW C252.name: Issues in Environmental Law and Policy
CRM/LAW C252.description: Treatment of legal and policy strategies for promoting environmental protection and deterring environmental degradation within the context of other societal objectives. Topical approach with a focus on problems of special interest to criminologists and to environmental policy specialists.

CRM/LAW C253.name: Cybercrime, Cybersecurity, and Society
CRM/LAW C253.description: Introduces students to the world of cybercrime in the age of globally networked digital, and information and communication technologies (ICT). Presents a socio-legal approach to the study of cybercrime, cybersecurity, and how it relates to society.
CRM/LAW C253.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Criminology, Law and Society M.A.S. students only.

CRM/LAW C254.name: Immigration in the US: Economic, Fiscal, and Social Outcomes
CRM/LAW C254.description: The changing patterns of immigration in the U.S. and the role that immigrants play in our society. In particular, the economic and social outcomes of immigration, as well as the relationship between immigration, crime, and criminal justice policy.
CRM/LAW C254.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Criminology, Law and Society Majors only.

CRM/LAW C255.name: Public Policy
CRM/LAW C255.description: Explores different approaches to public policy analysis, the diverse conceptions of the goals and objectives that should be served by policy, and the appropriate role of the policy analyst.  Policy consequences are traced to indirect and subtle incentives and disincentives.

CRM/LAW C257.name: Juvenile Justice and Gangs
CRM/LAW C257.description: Aims to understand the history and evolution of the juvenile justice system, and introduces the challenges that street and prison gangs pose to the mission and operations of juvenile justice in America.
CRM/LAW C257.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Criminology, Law and Society M.A.S. students only.

CRM/LAW C258.name: Crimmigration
CRM/LAW C258.description: Examines the criminalization of immigration, with an emphasis on U.S. enforcement procedures and outcomes. Analyzes the devolution of federal immigration law to local authorities, the rise in immigrant detention and deportation, and the militarization of the U.S.-Mexico border.

CRM/LAW C260A.name: Race and Justice Studies Proseminar
CRM/LAW C260A.description: A year-long proseminar conducted by a team of instructors specializing in race and justice studies. Conceived as a reading and peer mentor group focusing on intellectual and professional development. Required for students pursuing the Race and Justice Studies emphasis.

CRM/LAW C260B.name: Race and Justice Studies Proseminar
CRM/LAW C260B.description: A year-long proseminar conducted by a team of instructors specializing in race and justice studies. Conceived as a reading and peer mentor group focusing on intellectual and professional development. Required for students pursuing the Race and Justice Studies emphasis.

CRM/LAW C260C.name: Race and Justice Studies Proseminar
CRM/LAW C260C.description: A year-long proseminar conducted by a team of instructors specializing in race and justice studies. Conceived as a reading and peer mentor group focusing on intellectual and professional development. Required for students pursuing the Race and Justice Studies emphasis.

CRM/LAW C261.name: Race and Justice Studies Writing Seminar
CRM/LAW C261.description: A required writing-intensive seminar conducted by an instructor affiliated with the Race and Justice Studies emphasis. Students with manuscripts on relevant topics will read and critique peer manuscripts, and revise manuscripts toward completion of articles, dissertation chapters, and other publications.

CRM/LAW C262.name: Special Topics in Race and Justice Studies
CRM/LAW C262.description: A seminar focused on special issues in race and justice studies.

CRM/LAW C263.name: Eyewitness Testimony
CRM/LAW C263.description: Examines the evidence that shows that faulty eyewitness memory is the major cause of wrongful convictions. Explores what the legal system thinks of eyewitness testimony and how the legal system has dealt with eyewitness issues.

CRM/LAW C265.name: Memory and the Law
CRM/LAW C265.description: Examines the controversial topic of repressed memory, or perception and memory of real-world events.

CRM/LAW C266.name: Psychology and the Law
CRM/LAW C266.description: Overview of how psychology is applied to the civil and criminal justice systems, how case law shapes this application, and how legal decisions affect the direction of psychological research. Interdisciplinary approach to research in psychology, law, and/or  criminology.

CRM/LAW C268.name: Contemporary Issues in Crime and Justice
CRM/LAW C268.description: Intensive reading and discussion of several recent works that raise critical issues for criminology and criminal justice policy, with a special emphasis on issues of inequality, diversity, and social justice.

CRM/LAW C270.name: Economics of Crime
CRM/LAW C270.description: An introduction to the economic approach of thinking about criminal activity. Using the Becker model of rational criminal behavior as a starting point, we evaluate how education, employment, social insurance, and local economic development programs can affect criminal behavior.

CRM/LAW C271.name: Economics of Criminal Justice
CRM/LAW C271.description: Considers empirical research from the economics literature on various topics related to the criminal justice system, such as policing, bail reform, incarceration, or recidivism.

CRM/LAW C275.name: Special Topics in Criminology, Law and Society
CRM/LAW C275.description: Topics covered vary with interests of instructor.

CRM/LAW C280A.name: Professionalization Proseminar
CRM/LAW C280A.description: Focuses on two areas that are key to scholarly and professional success in graduate school but are rarely discussed in a structured setting: 1) publishing in peer-reviewed academic journals

CRM/LAW C280B.name: Professionalization Proseminar
CRM/LAW C280B.description: Focuses on two areas that are key to scholarly and professional success in graduate school but are rarely discussed in a structured setting: 1) publishing in peer-reviewed academic journals

CRM/LAW C280C.name: Professionalization Proseminar
CRM/LAW C280C.description: Focuses on two areas that are key to scholarly and professional success in graduate school but are rarely discussed in a structured setting: 1) publishing in peer-reviewed academic journals

CRM/LAW C296.name: Doctoral Dissertation Research and Writing
CRM/LAW C296.description: Dissertation research with Criminology, Law and Society faculty.

CRM/LAW C298.name: Directed Study
CRM/LAW C298.description: Directed study with Criminology, Law and Society faculty.

CRM/LAW C299.name: Independent Study
CRM/LAW C299.description: Independent research with Criminology, Law and Society faculty.

CSE 90.name: Systems Engineering and Technical Communications
CSE 90.description: Introduces systems engineering concepts, including specifications and requirements, hardware and software design, integration, testing, and documentation. Emphasizes organization and writing of reports and effective presentations.
CSE 90.restriction: Restriction: Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CSE 112.name: Electronic Devices and Circuits
CSE 112.description: A first course in the design of Very Large Scale Integrated (VLSI) systems. Introduction to CMOS technology
CSE 112.restriction: Restriction: Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

CSE 199.name: Individual Study
CSE 199.description: Supervised independent reading, research, or design for undergraduate Engineering majors. Students taking individual study for design credit are to submit a written paper to the instructor and to the Undergraduate Student Affairs Office in the School of Engineering.

DANCE 2.name: Dance Health and Injury Prevention
DANCE 2.description: An overview of factors that affect the health of dancers. Includes evaluation of general health measures and prevention and management of common dance injuries.
DANCE 2.restriction: Restriction: Dance Majors only. Dance - Choreography Majors only. Dance - Performance Majors only.

DANCE 3.name: Scientific Concepts of Health
DANCE 3.description: Introduction to the scientific foundations of health, emphasizing those pertaining to success in college and lifetime wellness. Includes principles of cardiorespiratory, musculoskeletal, flexibility, and nutritional fitness. A variety of learning experiences are offered to apply science to real life.

DANCE 14.name: Social Dance
DANCE 14.description: Current and historical forms that may include ballroom, disco, square dance, Latin styles, and other social dances from the early-to-mid 20th century.

DANCE 21A.name: Music for Dancers
DANCE 21A.description: Emphasis on the development of musical skills most pertinent to the dancer: vocabulary, notational literacy, rhythmic and melodic acuity, score reading, and fundamental analysis
DANCE 21A.restriction: Restriction: Dance Majors only. Dance - Choreography Majors only. Dance - Performance Majors only.

DANCE 30A.name: Studio Workshop in Ballet I
DANCE 30A.description: Beginning ballet: fundamentals and principles of classical ballet with an emphasis on technique.

DANCE 30B.name: Studio Workshop in Ballet I
DANCE 30B.description: Beginning ballet: fundamentals and principles of classical ballet with an emphasis on technique.

DANCE 30C.name: Studio Workshop in Ballet I
DANCE 30C.description: Beginning ballet: fundamentals and principles of classical ballet with an emphasis on technique.

DANCE 34.name: Men's Studio Workshop in Ballet
DANCE 34.description: Emphasis on men's traditional ballet, techniques, and movements.
DANCE 34.prereqString: Prerequisite: DANCE 30A and DANCE 30B and DANCE 30C

DANCE 40A.name: Studio Workshop in Modern/Contemporary Dance I
DANCE 40A.description: Fundamentals of modern/contemporary dance, including the use of breath, gravity, spatial awareness, and time values.

DANCE 40B.name: Studio Workshop in Modern/Contemporary Dance I
DANCE 40B.description: Fundamentals of modern/contemporary dance, including the use of breath, gravity, spatial awareness, and time values.

DANCE 40C.name: Studio Workshop in Modern/Contemporary Dance I
DANCE 40C.description: Fundamentals of modern/contemporary dance, including the use of breath, gravity, spatial awareness, and time values.

DANCE 50A.name: Studio Workshop on Jazz I
DANCE 50A.description: Fundamentals of jazz:  principles of jazz dance and contemporary forms incorporating the personal point of view of the instructor.

DANCE 50B.name: Studio Workshop on Jazz I
DANCE 50B.description: Fundamentals of jazz:  principles of jazz dance and contemporary forms incorporating the personal point of view of the instructor.

DANCE 50C.name: Studio Workshop on Jazz I
DANCE 50C.description: Fundamentals of jazz:  principles of jazz dance and contemporary forms incorporating the personal point of view of the instructor.

DANCE 52A.name: Workshop in Tap I
DANCE 52A.description: Beginning tap:  principles of rhythm and basic tap steps.

DANCE 52B.name: Workshop in Tap I
DANCE 52B.description: Beginning tap:  principles of rhythm and basic tap steps.

DANCE 52C.name: Workshop in Tap I
DANCE 52C.description: Beginning tap:  principles of rhythm and basic tap steps.

DANCE 53A.name: Studio Workshop in Hip Hop I
DANCE 53A.description: Designed to support non-major dance students learning outcomes in basic and foundational concepts of Hip Hop dance forms.

DANCE 53B.name: Studio Workshop in Hip Hop I
DANCE 53B.description: Designed to support non-major dance students learning outcomes in basic and foundational concepts of Hip Hop dance forms.

DANCE 53C.name: Studio Workshop in Hip Hop I
DANCE 53C.description: Designed to support non-major dance students learning outcomes in basic and foundational concepts of Hip Hop dance forms.

DANCE 60A.name: Choreography
DANCE 60A.description: Beginning-to-intermediate study of principles of dance composition.  May include composition assignments for stage and video.  By audition, works may be shown quarterly in public studio performances.
DANCE 60A.restriction: Restriction: Dance Majors only. Dance - Choreography Majors only. Dance - Performance Majors only.

DANCE 60B.name: Choreography
DANCE 60B.description: Beginning-to-intermediate study of principles of dance composition.  May include composition assignments for stage and video.  By audition, works may be shown quarterly in public studio performances.
DANCE 60B.restriction: Restriction: Dance Majors only. Dance - Choreography Majors only. Dance - Performance Majors only.

DANCE 60C.name: Choreography
DANCE 60C.description: Beginning-to-intermediate study of principles of dance composition.  May include composition assignments for stage and video.  By audition, works may be shown quarterly in public studio performances.
DANCE 60C.restriction: Restriction: Dance Majors only. Dance - Choreography Majors only. Dance - Performance Majors only.

DANCE 80.name: Introduction to Ballet and Modern Dance
DANCE 80.description: Survey of nineteenth and twentieth-century ballet, modern dance, and theatre dance.

DANCE 81.name: American Ballet and Modern Dance since 1900
DANCE 81.description: A survey of American ballet and modern dance in the twentieth and twenty-first centuries. Lectures are supplemented by video.
DANCE 81.restriction: Restriction: Non-major only. Dance 81 and Dance 90C may not both be taken for credit.

DANCE 90A.name: Dance History I
DANCE 90A.description: Global perspectives.  Topics and histories of dance and movement practices from various parts of the world.
DANCE 90A.restriction: Restriction: Dance Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Dance - Choreography Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Dance - Performance Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

DANCE 90B.name: Dance History II
DANCE 90B.description: The history of dance in the western tradition from the Renaissance through the 19th century.
DANCE 90B.restriction: Restriction: Dance Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Dance - Choreography Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Dance - Performance Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

DANCE 90C.name: Dance History III
DANCE 90C.description: The history of dance in the western tradition in the the 20th and 21st centuries.
DANCE 90C.restriction: Restriction: Dance Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Dance - Choreography Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Dance - Performance Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

DANCE 100.name: Kinesiology for Dance
DANCE 100.description: The study of the production of dance movement by the musculoskeletal system. Anatomical and dynamic analysis of dance movement.
DANCE 100.restriction: Restriction: Dance Majors only. Dance - Choreography Majors only. Dance - Performance Majors only.

DANCE 103.name: Pilates
DANCE 103.description: Basics of technique emphasizing alignment, breath control, correction of muscular imbalances.
DANCE 103.restriction: Restriction: Dance Majors only. Dance - Choreography Majors only. Dance - Performance Majors only.

DANCE 104.name: Pilates Reformer
DANCE 104.description: Utilizes the Universal Reformer apparatus, aiding the student in core stabilization, correcting muscular imbalances, increasing flexibility, and improving strength.
DANCE 104.restriction: Restriction: Dance Majors only. Dance - Choreography Majors only. Dance - Performance Majors only.

DANCE 110.name: World Dance
DANCE 110.description: Studio workshop of dances and movement sources of specified countries or areas.

DANCE 125A.name: Teaching of Dance
DANCE 125A.description: Pedagogy.  The methods and theory of teaching dance forms.
DANCE 125A.prereqString: Prerequisite: DANCE 133A and DANCE 133B and DANCE 133C and DANCE 143A and DANCE 143B and DANCE 143C
DANCE 125A.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. Dance Majors only. Dance - Choreography Majors only. Dance - Performance Majors only.

DANCE 127A.name: Costume Design for Dance
DANCE 127A.description: Costume design and construction specific to the body in motion. Theoretical study and practical execution.
DANCE 127A.restriction: Restriction: Dance Majors only. Dance - Choreography Majors only. Dance - Performance Majors only.

DANCE 130A.name: Pointe Class
DANCE 130A.prereqString: Prerequisite: DANCE 132A and DANCE 132B and DANCE 132C
DANCE 130A.restriction: Restriction: Dance Majors only. Dance - Choreography Majors only. Dance - Performance Majors only.

DANCE 132A.description: Intermediate ballet and beginning pointe work
DANCE 132A.prereqString: Prerequisite: (DANCE 30A and DANCE 30B and DANCE 30C) or audition. Prerequisites are for non-Dance majors only.
DANCE 132A.restriction: Restriction: Dance Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Dance - Choreography Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Dance - Performance Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

DANCE 132B.description: Intermediate ballet and beginning pointe work
DANCE 132B.restriction: Restriction: Dance Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Dance - Choreography Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Dance - Performance Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

DANCE 132C.description: Intermediate ballet and beginning pointe work
DANCE 132C.restriction: Restriction: Dance Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Dance - Choreography Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Dance - Performance Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

DANCE 133A.description: Advanced intermediate ballet and pointe work
DANCE 133A.prereqString: Prerequisite: DANCE 132C. DANCE 132C with a grade of B+ or better. Placement by audition is also accepted.
DANCE 133A.restriction: Restriction: Dance Majors only. Dance - Choreography Majors only. Dance - Performance Majors only.

DANCE 133B.description: Advanced intermediate ballet and pointe work

DANCE 133C.name: Advanced Studio Workshop in Ballet III
DANCE 133C.description: Advanced intermediate ballet and pointe work
DANCE 133C.restriction: Restriction: Dance Majors only. Dance - Choreography Majors only. Dance - Performance Majors only.

DANCE 134A.name: Advanced Studio Workshop in Ballet IV
DANCE 134A.description: Advanced ballet, pointe work, and performance styles: principles of classical ballet.
DANCE 134A.prereqString: Prerequisite: DANCE 133A and DANCE 133B and DANCE 133C. DANCE 133C with a grade of B+ or better. Placement by audition is also accepted.
DANCE 134A.restriction: Restriction: Dance Majors only. Dance - Choreography Majors only. Dance - Performance Majors only.

DANCE 134B.name: Advanced Studio Workshop in Ballet IV
DANCE 134B.description: Advanced ballet, pointe work, and performance styles: principles of classical ballet.
DANCE 134B.restriction: Restriction: Dance Majors only. Dance - Choreography Majors only. Dance - Performance Majors only.

DANCE 134C.name: Advanced Studio Workshop in Ballet IV
DANCE 134C.description: Advanced ballet, pointe work, and performance styles: principles of classical ballet.
DANCE 134C.restriction: Restriction: Dance Majors only. Dance - Choreography Majors only. Dance - Performance Majors only.

DANCE 135A.name: Advanced Studio Workshop in Ballet V
DANCE 135A.description: Advanced ballet, pointe work, and performance styles: principles of classical ballet.
DANCE 135A.prereqString: Prerequisite: DANCE 134A and DANCE 134B and DANCE 134C. DANCE 134C with a grade of B+ or better. Placement by audition is also accepted.
DANCE 135A.restriction: Restriction: Dance Majors only. Dance - Choreography Majors only. Dance - Performance Majors only.

DANCE 135B.restriction: Restriction: Dance Majors only. Dance - Choreography Majors only. Dance - Performance Majors only.

DANCE 135C.description: Advanced ballet, pointe work, and performance styles: principles of classical ballet.
DANCE 135C.restriction: Restriction: Dance Majors only. Dance - Choreography Majors only. Dance - Performance Majors only.

DANCE 137.name: Repertory
DANCE 137.description: Rehearsal and performance of repertoire from established ballet, modern, or jazz choreographers.
DANCE 137.prereqString: Prerequisite: (DANCE 133A and DANCE 133B and DANCE 133C) or (DANCE 143A and DANCE 143B and DANCE 143C)
DANCE 137.restriction: Restriction: Dance Majors only. Dance - Choreography Majors only. Dance - Performance Majors only.

DANCE 139.name: Partnering
DANCE 139.description: Principles of partnering techniques in various dance performance styles.
DANCE 139.prereqString: Prerequisite: DANCE 133A and DANCE 133B and DANCE 133C and DANCE 143A and DANCE 143B and DANCE 143C
DANCE 139.restriction: Restriction: Dance Majors only. Dance - Choreography Majors only. Dance - Performance Majors only.

DANCE 142A.description: Introduction to the principles of motion, including the use of breath, gravity, spatial awareness, and time values.
DANCE 142A.prereqString: Prerequisite: DANCE 40A and DANCE 40B and DANCE 40C. Prerequisites are for non-Dance majors only.

DANCE 142B.description: Introduction to the principles of motion, including the use of breath, gravity, spatial awareness, and time values.
DANCE 142B.restriction: Restriction: Dance Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Dance - Choreography Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Dance - Performance Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

DANCE 142C.description: Introduction to the principles of motion, including the use of breath, gravity, spatial awareness, and time values.

DANCE 143A.description: Builds on fundamentals of Dance 142A-B-C and introduces performance techniques.
DANCE 143A.prereqString: Prerequisite: DANCE 142C. DANCE 142C with a grade of B+ or better
DANCE 143A.restriction: Restriction: Dance Majors only. Dance - Choreography Majors only. Dance - Performance Majors only.

DANCE 143B.description: Builds on the fundamentals of DANCE 142A-DANCE 142B-DANCE 142C and introduces performance techniques.
DANCE 143B.restriction: Restriction: Dance Majors only. Dance - Choreography Majors only. Dance - Performance Majors only.

DANCE 143C.description: Builds on fundamentals of DANCE 142A-DANCE 142B-DANCE 142C and introduces performance techniques.

DANCE 155A.prereqString: Prerequisite: DANCE 53A and DANCE 53B and DANCE 53C. Audition is also accepted. Prerequisites are for non-Dance Majors only.

DANCE 156A.description: Builds on fundamentals of Dance 155A-B-C and introduces commercial and industry standards.
DANCE 156A.prereqString: Prerequisite: DANCE 155C. DANCE 155C with a grade of B+ or better
DANCE 156A.restriction: Restriction: Dance Majors only. Dance - Choreography Majors only. Dance - Performance Majors only.

DANCE 156B.description: Builds on fundamentals of Dance 155A-B-C and introduces commercial and industry standards.

DANCE 156C.restriction: Restriction: Dance Majors only. Dance - Choreography Majors only. Dance - Performance Majors only.

DANCE 160.name: Improvisation
DANCE 160.description: Structured and experiential improvisation to heighten the personal intuitive processes, the kinesthetic sense, spatial and temporal awareness, and to encourage insights into the potential movement resources of the individual for performance and choreography.  Course encourages freedom of exploration.

DANCE 162A.name: Choreography II
DANCE 162A.description: Directed choreographic projects for stage or video integrating the elements of stagecraft.  In process or completed works may be shown quarterly in public studio or stage performances.
DANCE 162A.prereqString: Prerequisite: DANCE 60A and DANCE 60B and DANCE 60C. Audition required.
DANCE 162A.restriction: Restriction: Dance Majors only. Dance - Choreography Majors only. Dance - Performance Majors only.

DANCE 162B.name: Choreography II
DANCE 162B.description: Directed choreographic projects for stage or video integrating the elements of stagecraft.  In process or completed works may be shown quarterly in public studio or stage performances.
DANCE 162B.restriction: Restriction: Dance Majors only. Dance - Choreography Majors only. Dance - Performance Majors only.

DANCE 163.name: Dance and Video Technology
DANCE 163.description: Introduction to video and audio documentation of dance performance. Integrating dance performance within the film aesthetic. Techniques and technologies of video cameras, formats, editing, and projection. Overview of video compression and DVD authoring.
DANCE 163.restriction: Restriction: Dance Majors only. Dance - Choreography Majors only. Dance - Performance Majors only.

DANCE 164.name: Screendance
DANCE 164.description: Overview of dance for film and choreography for the camera. Aesthetics of creating dance for the screen. Approaches for delivery of dance films to an audience, including projection, DVD, Web, and mobile devices. A final dance film project is required.
DANCE 164.restriction: Restriction: Dance Majors only. Dance - Choreography Majors only. Dance - Performance Majors only.

DANCE 165.name: Choreographic Projects
DANCE 165.description: Supervised choreographic projects for workshop productions.
DANCE 165.restriction: Restriction: Dance Majors only. Dance - Choreography Majors only. Dance - Performance Majors only.

DANCE 170.name: Dance Performance
DANCE 170.description: Rehearsal and performance in a faculty-choreographed production.

DANCE 171.name: Dance Workshop
DANCE 171.description: Rehearsal and performance in a student-choreographed production.

DANCE 172.name: Master of Fine Arts Concert
DANCE 172.description: Rehearsal and performance in a graduate student-choreographed production.

DANCE 176.name: UCI Jazz Dance Ensemble
DANCE 176.description: Rehearsal and performance in theatrical jazz dance, designed to provide an experience in assimilating various styles of jazz dance and in refining dance performance techniques.  Students will master aspects of dance company promotion.
DANCE 176.prereqString: Prerequisite: DANCE 152A and DANCE 152B and DANCE 152C
DANCE 176.restriction: Restriction: Sophomores only. Upper-division students only.

DANCE 178.name: Performance Laboratory
DANCE 178.description: Rehearsal and performance of graduate student-choreographed dance works for the M.F.A. thesis.

DANCE 179.name: UCI Etude Ensemble
DANCE 179.description: Repertory and performances by undergraduate Dance majors. Concert presentations on and off campus. Faculty directed, student/faculty choreographed.
DANCE 179.restriction: Restriction: Sophomores only. Upper-division students only.

DANCE 180C.name: Laban Studies
DANCE 180C.restriction: Restriction: Dance Majors only. Dance - Choreography Majors only. Dance - Performance Majors only.

DANCE 185W.name: Critical Issues in Dance
DANCE 185W.description: Critical thinking and writing about dance, with a section on dance criticism and a major emphasis on persuasive writing about significant issues in the dance world.
DANCE 185W.prereqString: Prerequisite: DANCE 90A and DANCE 90B and DANCE 90C. Satisfactory completion of the lower-division writing requirement.
DANCE 185W.restriction: Restriction: Dance Majors only. Dance - Choreography Majors only. Dance - Performance Majors only.

DANCE 193.name: Selected Topics in Dance
DANCE 193.description: Directed group studies of topics in dance.

DANCE 195.name: Arts Management
DANCE 195.description: Designed for students interested in the developmental and management of nonprofit arts organizations.  Examines the organizational structure and areas of operation such as marketing, fundraising, budgeting, production, and administration.

DANCE 197.name: Independent Study
DANCE 197.description: Individual independent projects in experimental laboratory, library, field, performance, under instructor's direction. Students can receive conceptual, creative, and theoretical instruction in the successful completion of a written report or performance.

DANCE 199.name: Senior Thesis
DANCE 199.description: Directed research or creative activity for senior Dance majors.  Research consists of a substantial essay on dance history, research in dance science, or the creation of original or reconstructed choreography.
DANCE 199.restriction: Restriction: Dance Majors only. Dance - Choreography Majors only. Dance - Performance Majors only.

DANCE 201.name: Seminar in Kinesiology for Dance
DANCE 201.description: Introduction to the anatomical, biomechanical, and physiological principles of dance movement.

DANCE 222.name: Musical Resources
DANCE 222.description: Detailed study of music as it relates to dance. Historical overview of musical form, style, and other elements.  Analysis of various affinities between music and dance.  Practical applications.

DANCE 225.name: Seminar in the Teaching of Dance Techniques
DANCE 225.description: Principles and theories of teaching dance techniques. Supervised presentation and teaching of technique class.

DANCE 231A.name: Graduate Studio: Ballet
DANCE 231A.description: Advanced ballet, pointe work, and performance style: principles of the classical ballet with an emphasis on technique.

DANCE 231B.name: Graduate Studio: Ballet
DANCE 231B.description: Advanced ballet, pointe work, and performance style: principles of  the classical ballet with an emphasis on technique.

DANCE 231C.name: Graduate Studio: Ballet
DANCE 231C.description: Advanced ballet, pointe work, and performance style: principles of the classical ballet with an emphasis on technique.

DANCE 241A.name: Graduate Studio Workshop in Modern/Contemporary
DANCE 241A.description: Advanced modern dance: synthesis of fundamentals and performance technique. Aims to bring students to the preprofessional level.

DANCE 241B.name: Graduate Studio Workshop in Modern/Contemporary
DANCE 241B.description: Advanced modern/contemporary dance offering a synthesis of fundamentals and performance technique.

DANCE 241C.name: Graduate Studio Workshop in Modern/Contemporary
DANCE 241C.description: Advanced modern/contemporary dance offering a synthesis of fundamentals and performance technique.

DANCE 251A.name: Graduate Studio: Jazz
DANCE 251A.description: Principles of jazz dance and contemporary forms, incorporating the personal views of the instructor.

DANCE 251B.name: Graduate Studio: Jazz
DANCE 251B.description: Principles of jazz dance and contemporary forms, incorporating the personal views of the instructor.

DANCE 251C.name: Graduate Studio: Jazz
DANCE 251C.description: Principles of jazz dance and contemporary forms, incorporating the personal views of the instructor.

DANCE 252A.name: Graduate Studio: Tap
DANCE 252A.description: An overview of tap concentrating on the development of various technique forms using basic and intermediate principles.

DANCE 252C.name: Graduate Studio: Tap
DANCE 252C.description: An overview of tap concentrating on the development of various technique forms using basic and intermediate principles.

DANCE 255A.name: Graduate Studio Workshop in Hip Hop
DANCE 255A.description: Advanced hip hop dance with an emphasis on technique and added study of commercial and industry standards.

DANCE 255B.name: Graduate Studio Workshop in Hip Hop
DANCE 255B.description: Advanced hip hop dance with an emphasis on technique and added study of commercial and industry standards.

DANCE 255C.name: Graduate Studio Workshop in Hip Hop
DANCE 255C.description: Advanced hip hop dance with an emphasis on technique and added study of commercial and industry standards.
DANCE 255C.prereqString: Prerequisite: DANCE 255A and DANCE 255B. Audition required.

DANCE 261A.name: Graduate Studio in Choreography
DANCE 261A.description: Graduate work in dance composition emphasizing the individual aesthetic.  Assignments in movement discovery, solo and group forms, with the main emphasis on independent work.

DANCE 261B.name: Graduate Studio in Choreography
DANCE 261B.description: Graduate work in dance composition emphasizing the individual aesthetic.  Assignments in movement discovery, solo and group forms, with the main emphasis on independent work.

DANCE 281.name: Dance and Video Technology
DANCE 281.description: Introduction to video and audio documentation of dance performance. Integrating dance performance within the film aesthetic. Techniques and technologies of video cameras, formats, editing, and projection. Overview of video compression and DVD authoring.

DANCE 282.name: Seminar in Movement Analysis
DANCE 282.description: Theories of movement analysis and nonverbal communication applied to dance.

DANCE 283.name: Critical Issues in Dance
DANCE 283.description: Reading, writing, discussing, and presenting key issues that relate to dance studies.  Basics of dance analysis and criticism.  Special emphasis on effective ways of defining, clarifying, and arguing for points of view.

DANCE 284.name: Bibliography and Research
DANCE 284.description: Understanding the field of dance studies, available resources, research methods, and academic formats in preparation for thesis writing.

DANCE 285.name: Graduate Projects
DANCE 285.description: Projects may be educational, choreographic, scientific, historical, or philosophical in scope and must have faculty advisor approval.

DANCE 286.name: Thesis
DANCE 286.description: Substantial research in a topic approved by the student's graduate committee.  Results of the research must be written in approved thesis style.

DANCE 287.name: Graduate Lectures in Dance
DANCE 287.description: A series of lectures and discussions of announced topics in dance. Content may be from history, ethnology, notation, medicine, music, or other areas in the field.

DANCE 296.name: Proseminar in Dance History
DANCE 296.description: Discussion seminar with emphasis on reading and thinking about problems in dance history

DANCE 297.name: Directed Reading
DANCE 297.description: Topic to be approved by instructor.  Paper required.

DANCE 399.name: University Teaching
DANCE 399.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Dance Majors only.

DATA 295P.name: Special Topics in Data Science
DATA 295P.description: Covers one or more emerging topics in data science. Course content may vary.
DATA 295P.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students only. Graduate students only.

DATA 296P.name: Capstone Writing and Communication
DATA 296P.description: Written and oral communication for data science careers. Production of a detailed document describing the design, methods, analytic strategy, interpretation, and conclusions as related to the concurrent capstone design and analysis class and refinement of written documents and oral communications.
DATA 296P.prereqString: Prerequisite: Required: Completion of at least 24 units in the Master of Data Science program.

DATA 297P.name: Capstone Design and Analysis
DATA 297P.description: Complete implementation of a data science analytic strategy for obtaining empirically-driven solutions to problems from science and industry. Focuses on the problem definition and analysis, data representation, algorithm selection, solution validation, and presentation of results.

DATA 298P.name: Curricular Practical Training
DATA 298P.description: Internship in which students work individually at an outside organization to gain experience with the challenges involved in data related work Materials fee.
DATA 298P.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students only. Graduate students only.

DATA 299P.name: Individual Study
DATA 299P.description: Supervised individual study in data science.
DATA 299P.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students only. Graduate students only.

DEV BIO 200A.name: Research in Developmental and Cell Biology
DEV BIO 200A.description: Independent research with Developmental and Cell Biology faculty.

DEV BIO 200B.name: Research in Developmental and Cell Biology
DEV BIO 200B.description: Independent research with Developmental and Cell Biology faculty.

DEV BIO 200C.name: Research in Developmental and Cell Biology
DEV BIO 200C.description: Independent research with Developmental and Cell Biology faculty.

DEV BIO 200R.name: Research in Developmental & Cell Biology for First-year Students
DEV BIO 200R.description: Independent research within the laboratories of graduate training faculty in the Department of Developmental and Cell Biology for first-year Ph.D. students.

DEV BIO 203A.name: Graduate Tutorial in Developmental and Cell Biology
DEV BIO 203A.description: Advanced study in areas not represented by formal courses. May involve individual or small group study through discussion, reading, and composition. Time and subject matter arranged individually.

DEV BIO 203B.name: Graduate Tutorial in Developmental and Cell Biology
DEV BIO 203B.description: Advanced study in areas not represented by formal courses. May involve individual or small group study through discussion, reading, and composition. Time and subject matter arranged individually.

DEV BIO 203C.name: Graduate Tutorial in Developmental and Cell Biology
DEV BIO 203C.description: Advanced study in areas not represented by formal courses. May involve individual or small group study through discussion, reading, and composition. Time and subject matter arranged individually.

DEV BIO 206A.name: Developmental and Cell Biology Journal Club
DEV BIO 206A.description: Advanced study of various topics in cell biology.

DEV BIO 206B.name: Developmental and Cell Biology Journal Club
DEV BIO 206B.description: Advanced study of various topics in cell biology.

DEV BIO 206C.name: Developmental and Cell Biology Journal Club
DEV BIO 206C.description: Advanced study of various topics in cell biology.

DEV BIO 207.name: Mouse Developmental Genetics
DEV BIO 207.description: Introduction to using the mouse in contemporary biomedical research. The biology and development of the laboratory mouse, methods for manipulation of the mouse genome and embryos, and examples of application of these methods to understand mammalian development and homeostasis.

DEV BIO 212.name: Topics in Systems Biology
DEV BIO 212.description: Studies in selected areas of Systems Biology.

DEV BIO 214.name: Principles of Genomics
DEV BIO 214.description: A survey course of the principal subfields of genomics and their applications to biological and health sciences that will cover genome assembly and annotation, genome structure, comparative genomics, population genomics, functional genomics, and medical genomics.

DEV BIO 231B.name: Cell Biology
DEV BIO 231B.description: A broadly based course including topics in extracellular matrix, cytoskeleton, organelle biogenesis, receptor-mediated endocytosis, signal transduction, cell cycle, and developmental biology.

DEV BIO 232.name: Systems Cell and Developmental Biology
DEV BIO 232.description: Introduces concepts needed to understand cell and developmental biology at the systems level, i.e., how the parts (molecules) work together to create a complex output. Emphasis on using mathematical/computational modeling to expand/modify insights provided by intuition.

DEV BIO 245.name: Stem Cell Biology
DEV BIO 245.description: The basic characteristics and development roles of embryonic, adult, and cancer stem cells in the human body and in model systems and the use of experimental and genetic methods to analyze and manipulate their properties.

DEV BIO 290A.name: Colloquium in Developmental and Cell Biology
DEV BIO 290A.description: Contemporary research problems. Research students, faculty, and other invited speakers introduce research and review topics.

DEV BIO 290B.name: Colloquium in Developmental and Cell Biology
DEV BIO 290B.description: Contemporary research problems. Research students, faculty, and other invited speakers introduce research and review topics.

DEV BIO 290C.name: Colloquium in Developmental and Cell Biology
DEV BIO 290C.description: Contemporary research problems. Research students, faculty, and other invited speakers introduce research and review topics.

DEV BIO 292A.name: Scientific Communication
DEV BIO 292A.description: Small group meetings for graduate students to practice scientific writing, debate, and presentation skills.

DEV BIO 292B.name: Scientific Communication
DEV BIO 292B.description: Small group meetings for graduate students to practice scientific writing, debate, and presentation skills.

DEV BIO 292C.name: Scientific Communication
DEV BIO 292C.description: Small group meetings for graduate students to practice scientific writing, debate, and presentation skills.

DRAMA 10.name: Introduction to Theatre
DRAMA 10.description: An interactive introduction to the world of theatre that serves to develop an appreciation of theatrical arts, to establish an awareness of landmarks within the performance history, and to create an understanding of the collaborative roles and departments that exist.

DRAMA 11.name: The Rock and Roll Spectacle Show
DRAMA 11.description: A thorough overview to the development and cultural significance of the Rock 'n' Roll Spectacle show. Focus on historical and recent developments of the spectacle show, trends in the aesthetics of the field, and various sub-genres.

DRAMA 14.name: Performing Rock 'N' Roll
DRAMA 14.description: Explores major movements in the history of rock 'n' roll in terms of performance, not virtuosity necessarily of the performers as musicians, rather as performances of aesthetics in modes of embodied ideology, iconoclastic spectacle, mixed media fashion, and subcultural formation.

DRAMA 15.name: Performance Now
DRAMA 15.description: Exposes students to what is most current in the world of performance and theatre.  Begins with a series of lectures on the idea of performance, and the various theories that frame it.
DRAMA 15.restriction: Restriction: Music Theatre Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Drama Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

DRAMA 16.name: Performing Culture
DRAMA 16.description: Culture, aesthetics, and ideology (combined in the concept "subculture") work to fashion social identities. Using theories and methodologies of performance studies, with an emphasis on American culture, this course explores why and how culture is reinforced through performance.

DRAMA 20A.name: Culture in Performance
DRAMA 20A.description: A three-quarter foundation series exploring the rich depth of theatre, drama, and other genres of performance across a wide variety of worldwide forms, for performer and audience.

DRAMA 20B.name: Culture in Performance
DRAMA 20B.description: A three-quarter foundation series exploring the rich depth of theatre, drama, and other genres of performance across a wide variety of worldwide forms, for performer and audience.

DRAMA 20C.name: Culture in Performance
DRAMA 20C.description: A three-quarter foundation series exploring the rich depth of theatre, drama, and other genres of performance across a wide variety of worldwide forms, for performer and audience.

DRAMA 30A.name: Acting
DRAMA 30A.description: Focuses on Stanislavski-based terminology and technique through theatre exercises and improvisation. The first part of a one-year series in basic acting technique and discipline.
DRAMA 30A.restriction: Restriction: Music Theatre Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Drama Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

DRAMA 30B.name: Acting
DRAMA 30B.description: Focuses on scene work and character development. The second part of a one-year series in basic acting technique and discipline.
DRAMA 30B.restriction: Restriction: Music Theatre Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Drama Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

DRAMA 30C.name: Acting
DRAMA 30C.description: Focuses on monologues, auditions, callbacks, and the profession of acting. The third part of a one-year series in basic acting technique and discipline.
DRAMA 30C.restriction: Restriction: Music Theatre Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Drama Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

DRAMA 34.name: Movement for Actors
DRAMA 34.description: A studio course in fundamentals of stretch, strength, and alignment

DRAMA 35.name: Speech for the Theatre
DRAMA 35.description: An introductory course in voice and speech for actors, combining the body-based approach to voice developed by Fitzmaurice, and speech work of Knight and Thompson. Designed for the needs of actors and is not a public speaking course.
DRAMA 35.restriction: Restriction: Music Theatre Majors only. Drama Majors only.

DRAMA 40A.name: Development of Drama
DRAMA 40A.description: The development of Western Drama, concentrating on the drama’s intellectual, social, and artistic foundations. About 10 plays and supplementary critical material are read each quarter. Greek Drama through Shakespeare.
DRAMA 40A.restriction: Restriction: Music Theatre Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Drama Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

DRAMA 40B.name: Development of Drama
DRAMA 40B.description: The development of Western Drama, concentrating on the drama’s intellectual, social, and artistic foundations. About 10 plays and supplementary critical material are read each quarter. Restoration Drama through Ibsen.
DRAMA 40B.restriction: Restriction: Music Theatre Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Drama Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

DRAMA 40C.name: Development of Drama
DRAMA 40C.description: The development of Western Drama, concentrating on the drama’s intellectual, social, and artistic foundations. About 10 plays and supplementary material are read each quarter. Contemporary Drama. Post Naturalistic theatre.
DRAMA 40C.restriction: Restriction: Music Theatre Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Drama Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

DRAMA 50A.name: Introduction to Costume Design
DRAMA 50A.description: Introduction to the process and procedures employed by the costume designer for the theatre. The elements of design are discussed in the context of character development, historical period, and style. Exercises extend to drawing, rendering, and investigation of human proportions.
DRAMA 50A.restriction: Restriction: Music Theatre Majors only. Drama Majors only.

DRAMA 50B.name: Introduction to Scenic Design
DRAMA 50B.description: Introduction to the principles and practice of scenic design. Weekly problems include research into various periods and styles of production with an emphasis on the conceptual idea. Perspective drawing, rendering, and model building are covered in studio exercises and assignments.
DRAMA 50B.restriction: Restriction: Music Theatre Majors only. Drama Majors only.

DRAMA 50C.name: Introduction to Lighting Design
DRAMA 50C.description: Introduction to the principles, theories, and equipment employed by the lighting designer for the stage.  Areas of investigation include history, technology, and script analysis. Detailed studio attention is given to the theory and practice of design.
DRAMA 50C.restriction: Restriction: Music Theatre Majors only. Drama Majors only.

DRAMA 50D.name: Introduction to Sound Design
DRAMA 50D.description: Principles, theories, equipment use, and terminology employed by the sound designer for the stage. Areas of study include history, technology, and script analysis.  Focuses on the theory and practice of design.
DRAMA 50D.restriction: Restriction: Music Theatre Majors only. Drama Majors only.

DRAMA 50E.name: Introduction to Stage Management
DRAMA 50E.description: A basic study of theatrical, dance, and opera stage management practices, forms, and methods, from first script reading to closing night.  Opportunity to observe professionals at work in regional and touring situations as available.
DRAMA 50E.restriction: Restriction: Music Theatre Majors only. Drama Majors only.

DRAMA 60.name: Topics in Advanced Stage Management
DRAMA 60.description: Nurtures a greater appreciation for the stage manager and his or her process, and supports students who are interested in pursuing a career in professional stage management.

DRAMA 65.name: Music Theatre Workshop I
DRAMA 65.description: Basic vocal technique and characterization of musical theatre repertoire explored.

DRAMA 80.name: Directing I
DRAMA 80.description: Introduction to comprehensive directing process from pre-production to opening. Focus on fundamental skills: analysis, staging, action, actor coaching, and elements of design. Skills applied to scripted theatrical material. Develop a language for commenting on theatrical production. Attending and critiquing productions.

DRAMA 100.name: University Theatre
DRAMA 100.description: Rehearsal and performance in a faculty-directed.

DRAMA 101A.name: Theatre Production:  Costume
DRAMA 101A.description: The production courses are offered to give students the opportunity to participate in departmental productions. Students engage in the production and construction of designed work as well as its applied execution during performance.
DRAMA 101A.restriction: Restriction: May be taken for credit for a maximum of 24 units provided productions change.

DRAMA 101B.name: Theatre Production:  Scenic
DRAMA 101B.description: The production courses are offered to give students the opportunity to participate in departmental productions. Students engage in the production and construction of designed work as well as its applied execution during performance.
DRAMA 101B.restriction: Restriction: May be taken for credit for a maximum of 24 units provided productions change.

DRAMA 101C.name: Theatre Production:  Lighting
DRAMA 101C.description: The production courses are offered to give students the opportunity to participate in departmental productions. Students engage in the production and construction of designed work as well as its applied execution during performance.
DRAMA 101C.restriction: Restriction: May be taken for credit for a maximum of 24 units provided productions change.

DRAMA 101D.name: Theatre Production:  Stage Management
DRAMA 101D.description: The production courses are offered to give students the opportunity to participate in departmental productions. Students engage in the production and construction of designed work as well as its applied execution during performance.
DRAMA 101D.restriction: Restriction: May be taken for credit for a maximum of 24 units provided productions change.

DRAMA 101E.name: Theatre Production:  Audio
DRAMA 101E.description: The production courses are offered to give students the opportunity to participate in departmental productions. Students engage in the production and construction of designed work as well as its applied execution during performance.
DRAMA 101E.restriction: Restriction: May be taken for credit for a maximum of 24 units provided productions change.

DRAMA 101S.name: Theatre Production: Theatre Management
DRAMA 101S.description: The production courses are offered to give students the opportunity to participate in departmental productions. Students engage in the production and construction of designed work as well as its applied execution during performance.
DRAMA 101S.restriction: Restriction: May be taken for credit for a maximum of 24 units provided productions change.

DRAMA 103.name: Lectures in Dramatic Literature
DRAMA 103.description: Courses include Medieval and Tudor Drama, Elizabethan and Jacobean Drama, Shakespeare, Restoration and Eighteenth Century Drama, Modern British Drama, Modern American Drama, Tragedy, and Comedy.
DRAMA 103.restriction: Restriction: Drama Majors only. Music Theatre Majors only.

DRAMA 103W.name: Lectures in Dramatic Literature
DRAMA 103W.description: Courses include Medieval and Tudor Drama, Elizabethan and Jacobean Drama, Shakespeare, Restoration and Eighteenth-Century Drama, Modern British Drama, Modern American Drama, Tragedy, and Comedy.
DRAMA 103W.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the lower-division writing requirement.
DRAMA 103W.restriction: Restriction: Drama Majors only. Music Theatre Majors only.

DRAMA 109.name: Special Topics in Theory and Criticism
DRAMA 109.description: Discussion of recent major trends and ideas in critical theory, concentrating on in-depth readings and lectures in particular facets of theory and criticism: Derrida, Butler, Lacan, Deleuze, and others.
DRAMA 109.restriction: Restriction: Music Theatre Majors only. Drama Majors only.

DRAMA 109W.name: Special Topics in Theory and Criticism
DRAMA 109W.description: Discussion of recent major trends and ideas in critical theory, concentrating on in-depth readings and lectures in particular facets of theory and criticism: Derrida, Butler, Lacan, Deleuze, and others.
DRAMA 109W.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
DRAMA 109W.restriction: Restriction: Music Theatre Majors only. Drama Majors only.

DRAMA 110.name: Special Topics in Classical Dramas
DRAMA 110.description: Designed to introduce students to various classical traditions-early Greek and Roman theatres, to be sure, but also, by way of comparison, the classical traditions of non-European cultures.
DRAMA 110.prereqString: Prerequisite: DRAMA 40A and DRAMA 40B and DRAMA 40C. Satisfactory completion of the lower-division writing requirement.
DRAMA 110.restriction: Restriction: Music Theatre Majors only. Drama Majors only.

DRAMA 110W.name: Special Topics in Classical Dramas
DRAMA 110W.description: Designed to introduce students to various classical traditions-early Greek and Roman theatres, to be sure, but also, by way of comparison, the classical traditions of non-European cultures.
DRAMA 110W.prereqString: Prerequisite: DRAMA 40A or DRAMA 40B or DRAMA 40C. Satisfactory completion of the lower-division writing requirement.
DRAMA 110W.restriction: Restriction: Music Theatre Majors only. Drama Majors only.

DRAMA 112.name: Special Topics in Early Modern and Neoclassical Theatre
DRAMA 112.description: Investigates aspects of European theatre and culture in the sixteenth, seventeenth, and eighteenth centuries
DRAMA 112.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the lower-division writing requirement.
DRAMA 112.restriction: Restriction: Music Theatre Majors only. Drama Majors only.

DRAMA 112W.name: Special Topics in Early Modern and Neoclassical Theatre
DRAMA 112W.description: Investigates aspects of European theatre and culture in the sixteenth, seventeenth, and eighteenth centuries
DRAMA 112W.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the lower-division writing requirement.
DRAMA 112W.restriction: Restriction: Music Theatre Majors only. Drama Majors only.

DRAMA 116.name: Special Topics in Nineteenth-Century Dramas
DRAMA 116.description: Looks at the various trends and conventions of theatres in the nineteenth century, both Euro-American and beyond, paying special attention to the culture and political milieu within which these various traditions appeared.
DRAMA 116.prereqString: Prerequisite: DRAMA 40A and DRAMA 40B and DRAMA 40C. Satisfactory completion of the lower-division writing requirement.
DRAMA 116.restriction: Restriction: Music Theatre Majors only. Drama Majors only.

DRAMA 116W.name: Special Topics in Nineteenth-Century Dramas
DRAMA 116W.description: Looks at the various trends and conventions of theatres in the nineteenth century, both Euro-American and beyond, paying special attention to the culture and political milieu within which these various traditions appeared.
DRAMA 116W.prereqString: Prerequisite: DRAMA 40A and DRAMA 40B and DRAMA 40C. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
DRAMA 116W.restriction: Restriction: Music Theatre Majors only. Drama Majors only.

DRAMA 118.name: Special Topics in Modern and Contemporary Drama
DRAMA 118.description: An investigation into the many forms and permutations of modern (1880-1945), and contemporary (since 1945) drama, paying special attention to the historical and philosophical interpretations of text and performance.
DRAMA 118.prereqString: Prerequisite: DRAMA 40A and DRAMA 40B and DRAMA 40C. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
DRAMA 118.restriction: Restriction: Music Theatre Majors only. Drama Majors only.

DRAMA 118W.name: Special Topics in Modern and Contemporary Drama
DRAMA 118W.description: An investigation into the many forms and permutations of modern (1880-1945), and contemporary (since 1945) drama, paying special attention to the historical and philosophical interpretations of text and performance.
DRAMA 118W.prereqString: Prerequisite: DRAMA 40A and DRAMA 40B and DRAMA 40C. Satisfactory completion of the lower-division writing requirement.
DRAMA 118W.restriction: Restriction: Music Theatre Majors only. Drama Majors only.

DRAMA 121.name: Introduction to Asian Theatre
DRAMA 121.description: An introduction to some of the major traditional theatrical forms and dramatic texts from India, China, and Japan.  Other than dramatic texts (in English translation), attention is also paid to theory, history, and performance styles of traditional Asian theatre.
DRAMA 121.restriction: Restriction: Drama Majors only. Music Theatre Majors only.

DRAMA 122.name: Asian American Theatre
DRAMA 122.description: An introduction to the history and development of Asian American theatre and drama. Besides play analysis, special attention is also paid to the history and politics of Asian American identity and experience, as well as to aspects of theatrical performance.
DRAMA 122.prereqString: Prerequisite: DRAMA 40A and DRAMA 40B and DRAMA 40C
DRAMA 122.restriction: Restriction: Drama Majors only. Music Theatre Majors only.

DRAMA 123.name: Multicultural Theatres
DRAMA 123.description: A study of the history, culture, aesthetics, and literature of various traditional performing arts and their connections to the contemporary multicultural society.
DRAMA 123.restriction: Restriction: Music Theatre Majors only. Drama Majors only.

DRAMA 126.name: African American Film and Drama
DRAMA 126.description: A critical investigation of films and plays written by African Americans, with emphasis on dramaturgical and cinematic strategies, individual and collective representation, and the legacy of African American political struggle.
DRAMA 126.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the lower-division writing requirement.
DRAMA 126.restriction: Restriction: Music Theatre Majors only. Drama Majors only.

DRAMA 126W.name: African American Film and Drama
DRAMA 126W.description: A critical investigation of films and plays written by African Americans, with emphasis on dramaturgical and cinematic strategies, individual and collective representation, and the legacy of African American political struggle.
DRAMA 126W.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the lower-division writing requirement.
DRAMA 126W.restriction: Restriction: Music Theatre Majors only. Drama Majors only.

DRAMA 129.name: Advanced Topics in Performance
DRAMA 129.description: Addresses particular issues in theatre and performance that typically lie outside of regular course offerings. May address such issues as the theatre of the Avant Garde, performing gender, transversality and performance, body art, installation and performance art, among other topics.
DRAMA 129.restriction: Restriction: Music Theatre Majors only. Drama Majors only.

DRAMA 129W.name: Advanced Topics in Performance
DRAMA 129W.description: Addresses particular issues in theatre and performance that typically lie outside of regular course offerings. May address such issues as the theatre of the Avant Garde, performing gender, transversality and performance, body art, installation and performance art, among other topics.
DRAMA 129W.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

DRAMA 130.name: Intermediate Acting
DRAMA 130.description: Rehearsal and presentation of scenes from contemporary material. Focus on connection with scene partner, playing actions, and text analysis. Introduction to the credibility and theatricality of characterization and style.
DRAMA 130.prereqString: Prerequisite: DRAMA 30A and DRAMA 30B and DRAMA 30C with an average grade of B or better. For transfer students: one year of beginning acting with an average grade of B or better.
DRAMA 130.restriction: Restriction: Drama Majors only. Music Theatre Majors only.

DRAMA 132A.name: Writing for Performance
DRAMA 132A.description: Completion of a full-length play or its equivalent
DRAMA 132A.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the lower-division writing requirement.
DRAMA 132A.restriction: Restriction: Music Theatre Majors only. Drama Majors only.

DRAMA 134.name: Studio for Advanced Movement for Actors
DRAMA 134.description: Studio course in conditioning and partnering techniques to the practice of contact improvisation. Contact improvisation is explored and applied in scene study.
DRAMA 134.prereqString: Prerequisite: DRAMA 34. DRAMA 34 with a grade of B or better

DRAMA 135.name: Master Classes in Acting
DRAMA 135.description: Advanced acting in specialized areas including acting for the camera: situation comedy, commercials
DRAMA 135.prereqString: Prerequisite: DRAMA 130. DRAMA 130 with a grade of B or better
DRAMA 135.restriction: Restriction: Drama Majors only. Music Theatre Majors only.

DRAMA 136.name: Music Theatre Acting
DRAMA 136.description: An acting class exclusive to the students in the B.F.A. in Music Theatre program.
DRAMA 136.prereqString: Prerequisite: DRAMA 30A and DRAMA 30B and DRAMA 30C

DRAMA 142.name: Music Theatre Workshop II
DRAMA 142.description: A workshop in audition technique and song interpretation.

DRAMA 143A.name: Music Theatre Workshop III
DRAMA 143A.description: Scene study and song repertoire examined by era for the advanced Music Theatre student. 1800s-1940.

DRAMA 143B.name: Music Theatre Workshop III
DRAMA 143B.description: Scene study and song repertoire examined by era for the advanced Music Theatre student. 1940s-1970s.

DRAMA 143C.name: Music Theatre Workshop III
DRAMA 143C.description: Scene study and song repertoire examined by era for the advanced Music Theatre student. 1970's-present.

DRAMA 144.name: Music Theatre Workshop IV
DRAMA 144.description: A performance class concentrating on role building. Work culminates with in-class performances of abbreviated versions of musicals.
DRAMA 144.prereqString: Prerequisite: For B.F.A. students: DRAMA 143A, DRAMA 143B, DRAMA 143C, and audition. For Drama graduate students: audition required.
DRAMA 144.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Music Theatre Majors only. Drama Majors only.

DRAMA 145.name: Music Theatre Singing
DRAMA 145.description: Private weekly voice lessons for the advanced Music Theatre student.

DRAMA 146.name: NYSP-Preparation
DRAMA 146.description: Class preparation for the New York Satellite Program (NYSP) - an immersion experience in New York City for the musical theatre performer.
DRAMA 146.prereqString: Prerequisite: Admission is by audition and the following prerequisites: DRAMA 30C and two quarters of DRAMA 148A, DRAMA 148B, or DRAMA 148C (if the 148 prerequisite is not complete at the time of auditions, student must enroll during the fall and winter quarters in the same year as the trip to New York)

DRAMA 148A.name: History of American Musical Theatre
DRAMA 148A.description: A survey of the influential artists who produce, write, direct, and perform on America's musical stages. Surveys 1700s-1940s.
DRAMA 148A.restriction: Restriction: Music Theatre Majors only. Drama Majors only.

DRAMA 148B.name: History of American Musical Theatre
DRAMA 148B.description: A survey of the influential artists who produce, write, direct, and perform on America's musical stages. Surveys 1940s-1970s.
