DRAMA 148B.restriction: Restriction: Music Theatre Majors only. Drama Majors only.

DRAMA 148C.name: History of American Musical Theatre
DRAMA 148C.description: A survey of the influential artists who produce, write, direct, and perform on America's musical stages. Surveys 1970s to present day.
DRAMA 148C.restriction: Restriction: Music Theatre Majors only. Drama Majors only.

DRAMA 149.name: Music Proficiency for Actors
DRAMA 149.description: A musicianship class introducing basic musical terminology, theory, and sight singing skills.
DRAMA 149.restriction: Restriction: Drama Majors only. Music Theatre Majors only.

DRAMA 150.name: Costume Production Techniques
DRAMA 150.description: Studio instruction in pattern making, draping, millinery, and construction techniques.
DRAMA 150.restriction: Restriction: Drama Majors only. Music Theatre Majors only.

DRAMA 157.name: Lighting Composition
DRAMA 157.description: Provides an opportunity for students to pursue stage lighting composition in a studio atmosphere.  Laboratory practice includes weekly exercises in style and genre. Emphasis is placed on the realization of conceptual ideas.
DRAMA 157.restriction: Restriction: Drama Majors only. Music Theatre Majors only.

DRAMA 158.name: Topics in Theatre Design
DRAMA 158.description: Examines the various functions of scenery and costume: locale, historical period, mood, and atmosphere, with special assignments in each area. Discussion of problems in scenic metaphors and visualization, emphasizing techniques of planning and presentation (e.g., floor plans, models, and rendering).
DRAMA 158.restriction: Restriction: Music Theatre Majors only. Drama Majors only.

DRAMA 159.name: Proseminar in Theatre Design
DRAMA 159.restriction: Restriction: Drama Majors only. Music Theatre Majors only.

DRAMA 164A.name: History of Costume
DRAMA 164A.description: A study of the development of dress and the influence of cultural factors on clothing from the time of Egyptians to Early Baroque.
DRAMA 164A.restriction: Restriction: Drama Majors only. Music Theatre Majors only.

DRAMA 164B.name: History of Costume
DRAMA 164B.description: A study of the development of dress and the influence of cultural factors on clothing from late Baroque to World War I.
DRAMA 164B.restriction: Restriction: Drama Majors only. Music Theatre Majors only.

DRAMA 176.name: Script and Score
DRAMA 176.description: A form and analysis seminar discussing the libretto and score of landmark musicals.
DRAMA 176.prereqString: Prerequisite: Two courses from DRAMA 148A or DRAMA 148B or DRAMA 148C.
DRAMA 176.restriction: Restriction: Drama Majors only. Music Theatre Majors only.

DRAMA 177.name: Song Repertoire
DRAMA 177.description: A song coaching class culminating in a song recital or showcase. Each quarter will feature a different composer, lyricist, or musical style.

DRAMA 180.name: Contemporary Dramatic Criticism and Theory
DRAMA 180.description: Reading and analysis of theories and critical approaches to contemporary theatre: Brecht, Artaud, and others who have contributed to the form and idea of the modern theatre. Writing of assigned exercises in dramatic criticism.
DRAMA 180.restriction: Restriction: Drama Majors only. Music Theatre Majors only.

DRAMA 180W.name: Contemporary Dramatic Criticism and Theory
DRAMA 180W.description: Reading and analysis of theories and critical approaches to contemporary theatre:  Brecht, Artaud, and others who have contributed to the form and idea of the modern theatre. Writing of assigned exercises in dramatic criticism.
DRAMA 180W.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the lower-division writing requirement.
DRAMA 180W.restriction: Restriction: Drama Majors only. Music Theatre Majors only.

DRAMA 182A.name: Dance Technique, Level I
DRAMA 182A.description: Advanced beginner and intermediate dance training including musical theatre, ballet, jazz and contemporary modern techniques and repertoire.  Body conditioning is also a major component of the course.
DRAMA 182A.prereqString: Prerequisite: DRAMA 65 or DRAMA 142. Audition required.
DRAMA 182A.restriction: Restriction: Music Theatre Majors only. Drama Majors only.

DRAMA 182B.name: Dance Technique, Level I
DRAMA 182B.description: Advanced beginner and intermediate dance training including musical theatre, ballet, jazz and contemporary modern techniques and repertoire.  Body conditioning is also a major component of the course.
DRAMA 182B.prereqString: Prerequisite: (DRAMA 65 or DRAMA 142) and DRAMA 182A. Audition required.
DRAMA 182B.restriction: Restriction: Music Theatre Majors only. Drama Majors only.

DRAMA 183A.name: Dance Technique, Level II
DRAMA 183A.description: Intermediate and advanced dance training including musical theatre, ballet, jazz and contemporary modern techniques and repertoire.  Body conditioning is also a major component of the course.
DRAMA 183A.prereqString: Prerequisite: DRAMA 65 or DRAMA 142. Audition required.
DRAMA 183A.restriction: Restriction: Music Theatre Majors only. Drama Majors only.

DRAMA 183B.name: Dance Technique, Level II
DRAMA 183B.description: Intermediate and advanced dance training including musical theatre, ballet, jazz and contemporary modern techniques and repertoire.  Body conditioning is also a major component of the course.
DRAMA 183B.prereqString: Prerequisite: (DRAMA 65 or DRAMA 142) and DRAMA 183A. Audition required.
DRAMA 183B.restriction: Restriction: Music Theatre Majors only. Drama Majors only.

DRAMA 184.name: Directing II
DRAMA 184.description: The principles of stage directing, covering the director's functions in the areas of interpretation, composition, coaching, and styling a theatrical production. Directing exercises and projects
DRAMA 184.prereqString: Prerequisite: DRAMA 30A and DRAMA 30B and DRAMA 40A and DRAMA 40B and DRAMA 40C and DRAMA 80
DRAMA 184.restriction: Restriction: Music Theatre Majors only. Drama Majors only.

DRAMA 185.name: Advanced Directing
DRAMA 185.description: A seminar in directorial organization and research.  Student prepares a textual and dramaturgical analysis, a production timetable, and a hypothetical production book of an assigned play.
DRAMA 185.restriction: Restriction: Drama Majors only. Music Theatre Majors only.

DRAMA 190.name: NYSP-Acting
DRAMA 190.description: New York Satellite Program acting classes taught by guest faculty in New York.

DRAMA 191.name: NYSP - Dance
DRAMA 191.description: New York Satellite Program dance classes in ballet, tap, jazz, and musical theatre styles taught by guest faculty in New York.

DRAMA 192.name: NYSP - Singing
DRAMA 192.description: New York Satellite Program private and group lessons in musical theatre singing taught by guest faculty in New York.

DRAMA 193.name: NYSP - Performance
DRAMA 193.description: New York Satellite Program rehearsals and public, staged readings of original musicals in New York.

DRAMA 194.name: NYSP-UCI Residency
DRAMA 194.description: New York Satellite Program follow-up classes and performances back on Irvine campus upon the return from New York.

DRAMA 195.name: Music Theatre Dance - Special Topics
DRAMA 195.description: Advanced dance classes in specialized areas including the dance styles of a choreographer (de Mille, Fosse, Robbins, Tune, Stroman), genre (tap, ballroom, jazz, swing, hip-hop), or in musical theatre choreography.
DRAMA 195.prereqString: Prerequisite: DRAMA 182A or DRAMA 182B or DRAMA 183A or DRAMA 183B. Audition required.
DRAMA 195.restriction: Restriction: Music Theatre Majors only. Drama Majors only.

DRAMA 198.name: Director Class Project
DRAMA 198.description: For students who are involved in the Director Class Projects at UCI as actors, directors, designers, stage managers and their assistants. M.F.A. Directors and the Head of Directing (HoD) supervise the projects.

DRAMA 199.name: Project in Theatre
DRAMA 199.description: Independent theatre projects with Drama faculty.

DRAMA 200.name: Graduate Studio: Acting
DRAMA 200.description: Work in graduate studio taken in tandem with graduate studios in stage voice (DRAMA 201), stage speech (DRAMA 202), and stage movement (DRAMA 203).
DRAMA 200.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Drama Majors only. Drama and Theatre Majors only.

DRAMA 201.name: Graduate Studio: Voice
DRAMA 201.description: Graduate studio in vocal production for actors.
DRAMA 201.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Drama Majors only. Drama and Theatre Majors only.

DRAMA 202.name: Graduate Studio: Speech
DRAMA 202.description: Graduate studio in speech for actors.
DRAMA 202.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Drama Majors only. Drama and Theatre Majors only.

DRAMA 203.name: Graduate Studio: Movement
DRAMA 203.description: Work in graduate studio: stage movement taken in tandem with nine graduate studios in acting (DRAMA 200), voice (DRAMA 201), speech (DRAMA 202), and voice/movement dynamics (DRAMA 206).
DRAMA 203.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Drama Majors only. Drama and Theatre Majors only.

DRAMA 206.name: Graduate Studio: Voice/Movement Dynamics
DRAMA 206.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Drama Majors only. Drama and Theatre Majors only.

DRAMA 219.name: Graduate Master Class
DRAMA 219.description: Various topics such as Shakespeare, comedy, Molière, improvisation, Kabuki, television acting.
DRAMA 219.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Drama Majors only. Drama and Theatre Majors only.

DRAMA 220.name: Seminar in Dramatic Literature
DRAMA 220.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Drama Majors only. Drama and Theatre Majors only.

DRAMA 225.name: Seminar on Theatre Pedagogy
DRAMA 225.description: A seminar on the major teaching systems in the dramatic arts with particular attention to professional arts training. Required prior to applying for Teaching Assistantships in studio areas.

DRAMA 240.name: Graduate Projects
DRAMA 240.description: Various projects depending on student’s concentration (acting, design, musical theatre, directing).
DRAMA 240.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Drama and Theatre Majors only. Drama Majors only.

DRAMA 241.name: Singing Pedagogy
DRAMA 241.description: Learning how to teach voice lessons and coach musical theatre singing. Experiences include both private voice lessons and observing the lessons given to the B.F.A./Music Theatre students.
DRAMA 241.restriction: Restriction: Graduate Music Direction students only.

DRAMA 242.name: Conducting
DRAMA 242.description: Private conducting instruction to develop freedom of movement/expression, baton technique, ear training, and tempo memory for both rehearsal and performance situations in musical theatre.

DRAMA 243.name: Script and Score
DRAMA 243.description: A form and analysis seminar discussing the libretto and score of landmark musicals.
DRAMA 243.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Music Majors only.

DRAMA 244.name: Dramaturgy: Theory and Methods
DRAMA 244.description: Examines the practice, place, and theory of dramaturgy.  Explores plays in terms of how they work: dramatic form and structure, historical context, and more. Study includes dramaturgy as a theatrical practice.
DRAMA 244.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Drama Majors only. Drama and Theatre Majors only.

DRAMA 246A.name: Musical Scene Study I
DRAMA 246A.description: Musically directing scenes from musicals of various time periods. Features works from the late 19th and early 20th centuries, including songwriters Gilbert and Sullivan, Irving Berlin, George Gershwin, Rodgers and Hart, and Cole Porter.
DRAMA 246A.restriction: Restriction: Graduate Music Director students only.

DRAMA 246B.name: Musical Scene Study II
DRAMA 246B.description: Musically directing scenes from musicals of various time periods. Features works from the middle of the 20th century including songwriters Rodgers and Hammerstein, Lerner and Loewe, Julie Styne, Kander and Ebb, and Jerry Herman.

DRAMA 246C.name: Musical Scene Study III
DRAMA 246C.description: Musically directing scenes from musicals of various time periods.  Features works from the late 20th and early 21st centuries including songwriters Stephen Sondheim, Andrew Lloyd Webber, Stephen Schwartz, Flaherty and Ahrens, and Jeanine Tesori.

DRAMA 247.name: Musicals Abridged
DRAMA 247.description: Musically directing abridged versions of musicals from various time periods and genres.

DRAMA 248A.name: History of American Music Theatre
DRAMA 248A.description: A survey of the influential artists who produce, write, direct, and perform on America's musical stages. Surveys 1700s-1940s.

DRAMA 248B.name: History of American Musical Theatre
DRAMA 248B.description: A survey of the influential artists who produce, write, direct, and perform on America's musical stages. Surveys 1940s-1970s.

DRAMA 248C.name: History of American Musical Theatre
DRAMA 248C.description: A survey of the influential artists who produce, write, direct and perform on America's musical stages. Surveys 1970s to present day.

DRAMA 249.name: Graduate Music Direction
DRAMA 249.description: Various musical direction activities including the vocal direction, accompanying, and conducting of musical theatre performances.
DRAMA 249.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Music Majors only.

DRAMA 251A.name: Foundations of Theatre
DRAMA 251A.description: Seeks to create greater understanding in the roots and theories of theatrical models, aesthetics, action vs. reaction of differing thoughts in theatrical doctrine, and art, architecture, music, and fashion that contributed to the style and practice of theatre.

DRAMA 251B.name: Foundations of Theatre
DRAMA 251B.description: Seeks to create greater understanding in the roots and theories of theatrical models, aesthetics, action vs. reaction of differing thoughts in theatrical doctrine, and art, architecture, music, and fashion that contributed to the style and practice of theatre.

DRAMA 251C.name: Foundations of Theatre
DRAMA 251C.description: Seeks to create greater understanding in the roots and theories of theatrical models, aesthetics, action vs. reaction of differing thoughts in theatrical doctrine, and art, architecture, music, and fashion that contributed to the style and practice of theatre.

DRAMA 254.name: Graduate Stage Management
DRAMA 254.description: Studio exercises and projects in stage management.

DRAMA 255.name: Graduate Design Seminar
DRAMA 255.description: Projects, lectures, and critical discussion in costume, scenery, lighting, and sound design.

DRAMA 256.name: Survival and Professional Practice in Design
DRAMA 256.description: Provides an in-depth examination of business skills needed to survive as a theatrical designer. Required 'Bridge' course in the Design MFA programs, relevant to all disciplines.

DRAMA 257A.name: Costume Thesis Project
DRAMA 257A.description: Development of thesis project with focus on organization, research, timeline, and execution.

DRAMA 257B.name: Scenic Thesis Project
DRAMA 257B.description: Development of thesis project with focus on organization, research, timeline, and execution.

DRAMA 257E.name: Thesis Writing Project-Stage Management
DRAMA 257E.description: Development of thesis topic with focus on organization, research, timeline, and execution.

DRAMA 258.name: Drawing for Designers
DRAMA 258.description: A multi-skill level course in drawing technique focusing on skills essential to stage designers including line, proportion, perspective and creating dynamic compositions. Focus will primarily be in figure drawing but may include still-life, landscape, and architectural drawings. Materials fee.

DRAMA 259.name: Theatre Colloquium
DRAMA 259.description: Exposes students to a wider range of theatrical practitioners, theories, and topics through guest lecturers, special projects, and cross-disciplinary dialogue.
DRAMA 259.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Drama Majors only. Drama and Theatre Majors only.

DRAMA 260A.name: Digital Costume Rendering
DRAMA 260A.description: A studio course in costume rendering for the theatre using computer image manipulation. Instruction in compositing and painting techniques and performance design conventions.

DRAMA 260B.name: Digital Textile Design and Printing
DRAMA 260B.description: A studio course in textile design using digital printing and embossing techniques. Instruction in state-of-the-art software and output manipulation for artistic expression.

DRAMA 261.name: Digital Design: Drawing/Painting/Rendering
DRAMA 261.description: A studio course in scenic or costume rendering for the theatre using the computer for drawing/painting through the use of the digital pen/tablet.
DRAMA 261.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Drama Majors only. Drama and Theatre Majors only.

DRAMA 262.name: Digital Design: 2D/3D Modeling
DRAMA 262.description: A studio course in CAD's 2D drafting and 3D modeling capabilities for theatrical design. Instruction in state-of-the-art software for 2D and 3D object creation and theatrical presentation conventions.
DRAMA 262.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Drama Majors only. Drama and Theatre Majors only.

DRAMA 263.name: Digital Design: 3D Rendering
DRAMA 263.description: A studio course in theatrical design through 3d modeling on computer and use of state-of-the-art rendering software. Instruction emphasizes collaborative design process through the use of scenic designer/lighting designer teams for all projects.
DRAMA 263.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Drama and Theatre Majors only. Drama Majors only.

DRAMA 264.name: Lighting Graphics
DRAMA 264.description: A studio course in the various graphic methods employed by lighting designers in the theatre.  Projects include manual and CAD techniques for Light Plot and Paperwork creation.
DRAMA 264.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Drama Majors only. Drama and Theatre Majors only.

DRAMA 265.name: Digital Design: 2D CAD
DRAMA 265.description: A studio course in theatrical design and architectural lighting design on the computer.  Instruction in state-of-the-art software for 2D object creation.  Theatrical and architectural standards implemented in performance design.
DRAMA 265.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Drama Majors only. Drama and Theatre Majors only.

DRAMA 266.name: Digital Design:  Digital Audio Systems
DRAMA 266.description: Comprehensive tutorial on digital audio including hard disk recording, editing, data compression, and ethernet audio distribution.  Focus is on recording, editing, and delivery of audio as used by the sound designer in the digital domain.

DRAMA 267.name: Digital Design: Creating Sounds from Scratch
DRAMA 267.description: The process of analyzing sounds for their core timbral components and using that data to create new sounds - from realistic to fantastic - by means of digital manipulation.

DRAMA 271.name: Conceptual Sound Design
DRAMA 271.description: An intensive, project-based seminar for exploring relationships between sound and sight.  Synesthesia, creative intent vs. audience perception, and sound/movement are typical of the many topics to be explored.  A series of creative projects are assigned and critiqued in peer review.

DRAMA 272.name: Musical Theatre Sound/Concert Sound
DRAMA 272.description: A concept-to-opening study of the process of designing sound systems for musicals and live/touring sound.  Special attention given to the paperwork and documentation required to package, build, and mix these shows.

DRAMA 277.name: Critical Listening
DRAMA 277.description: Exploration of the many variables that affect (and effect) the audio chain.  Perceiving and understanding these parameters unlocks the art of controlling sound and stylizing cues.  Also includes the process of equalizing/aligning sound systems and the art of audio mastering.

DRAMA 279.name: Advanced Sound Design
DRAMA 279.description: An in-depth investigation into sound design for the theatre. Special emphasis is placed on text analysis, design conception, content creation, content delivery, and design organization. Class projects include creating paper designs and paperwork for different texts.

DRAMA 280A.name: Techniques in Costume Design
DRAMA 280A.description: Student exercises in the techniques and implementation of costume design.

DRAMA 280B.name: Techniques in Scenery Design
DRAMA 280B.description: Student exercises in the techniques and implementation of scenic design.

DRAMA 280C.name: Techniques in Lighting Design
DRAMA 280C.description: Student exercises in the techniques and implementation of lighting design.

DRAMA 280D.name: Techniques in Sound Design
DRAMA 280D.description: Student exercises in the techniques and implementation of sound design.

DRAMA 282.name: Stage Electronics/Introduction to Show Control
DRAMA 282.description: Using computers and dedicated hardware to cue, control or automate sound, scenery, and lighting for live performance and themed entertainment applications.
DRAMA 282.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Drama Majors only. Drama and Theatre Majors only.

DRAMA 290.name: Dramatic Literature and Theatre History Prior to 1900
DRAMA 290.description: Studies in selected areas of dramatic literature and theatre history prior to 1900. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

DRAMA 291.name: Dramatic Literature and Theatre History, 1900 to Present
DRAMA 291.description: Studies in selected areas of dramatic literature and theatre history, 1900 to present. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

DRAMA 292.name: Cultural and Critical Theory
DRAMA 292.description: Studies in selected areas of cultural and critical theory. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

DRAMA 295.name: Professional Internship
DRAMA 295.description: An arranged internship at the South Coast Repertory Theatre, or other equity theatre company, for qualifying M.F.A. students. A stipend and equity points are provided by the theatre company.

DRAMA 297.name: Dramaturgy Practicum
DRAMA 297.description: Requires doctoral students to identify two plays from the Drama Department's season to work as dramaturges. Students write a Dramaturgy Booklet recording their research and interactions with director, actors, and the design team. Students will work with doctoral faculty.
DRAMA 297.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Drama and Theatre Majors only.

EARTHSS 1.name: Introduction to Earth System Science
EARTHSS 1.description: Covers the origin and evolution of the Earth, its atmosphere, and oceans, from the perspective of biogeochemical cycles, energy use, and human impacts on the Earth system.

EARTHSS 3.name: Oceanography
EARTHSS 3.description: Examines circulation of the world oceans and ocean chemistry as it relates to river, hydrothermal vent, and atmospheric inputs. Geological features, the wide variety of biological organisms, and global climate changes, such as greenhouse warming, are also studied.

EARTHSS 5.name: The Atmosphere
EARTHSS 5.description: The composition and circulation of the atmosphere with a focus on explaining the fundamentals of weather and climate. Topics include solar and terrestrial radiation, clouds, and weather patterns.

EARTHSS 7.name: Physical Geology
EARTHSS 7.description: Introduction to Earth materials and processes. Topics include rocks and minerals, plate tectonics, volcanoes, earthquakes, Earth surface processes, Earth resources, geologic time, and Earth history. Laboratory work involves hands-on study of geologic materials, maps, and exercises pertaining to geologic processes. Materials fee.

EARTHSS 15.name: Introduction to Global Climate Change
EARTHSS 15.description: Introduction of scientific, technological, environmental, economic, and social aspects underlying the threat and understanding of global climate change. Human and natural drivers of climate. Impacts of climate on natural, managed, and human systems, including their vulnerability and ability to adapt.

EARTHSS 17.name: Hurricanes, Tsunamis, and Other Catastrophes
EARTHSS 17.description: Introduction to the basic science and state of predictability of various natural catastrophic events including earthquakes, volcanic eruptions, tsunamis, landslides, floods, hurricanes, fires, and asteroid impacts and their interactions and implications with human society in the U.S. and globally.

EARTHSS 19.name: Introduction to Modeling the Earth System
EARTHSS 19.description: Simulate the Earth's system using computer models. Covers the interaction of the air, land, and ocean, and explores how changes to one part of the environment affect the complete Earth system. Utilizes technological tools to understand scientific principles.

EARTHSS 21.name: On Thin Ice: Climate Change and the Cryosphere
EARTHSS 21.description: Introduction of the basic science that governs the cryosphere and its interaction with the climate system. Covers some of the significant economic, sociological, and political consequences of the recent melting of the cryosphere driven by anthropogenic climate change.

EARTHSS 23.name: Air Pollution: From Urban Smog to Global Change
EARTHSS 23.description: Air pollution occurs on regional to global scales. A wide range of air pollution sources and physical, chemical, and meteorological sciences behind air pollution are introduced. The consequences of air pollution to our society are also discussed.

EARTHSS 27.name: The Sustainable Ocean
EARTHSS 27.description: An introduction to sustainability as it relates to marine resources and conservation. Topics include the scientific basis of our understanding of marine ecosystems, and the political, social, and cultural principles that govern resource protection.

EARTHSS 40A.name: Earth System Chemistry
EARTHSS 40A.description: To understand the cycling of matter on Earth, we need to learn about the chemistry of elements and molecules in the environment. Introduces students to the understanding of how chemical principles apply in context to their everyday lives.
EARTHSS 40A.restriction: Restriction: Environmental Science and Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EARTHSS 40B.name: Earth System Biology
EARTHSS 40B.description: Earth System Science is a highly interdisciplinary field that requires knowledge of various components of the Earth as a system, including the biosphere. Students are introduced to several fundamental principles of biology, from the smallest cells to the largest ecosystems.
EARTHSS 40B.restriction: Restriction: Environmental Science and Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EARTHSS 40C.name: Earth System Physics
EARTHSS 40C.description: Covers the fundamental physical forces and laws that affect the Earth system, such as electromagnetic radiation and energy transfer, atmospheric and ocean dynamics. Also covers aspects of physics related to environmental issues, such as electricity generation and transmission.
EARTHSS 40C.restriction: Restriction: Environmental Science and Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EARTHSS 45.name: New Student Seminar
EARTHSS 45.description: Weekly meetings led by faculty, current students, and staff, to provide information on the Department of Earth System Science, campus resources, and special programs and opportunities. Designed for students who recently joined the Earth System Science and Environmental Science majors.
EARTHSS 45.restriction: Restriction: Environmental Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Earth System Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. New students only (freshman, transfer, and change of major).

EARTHSS 51.name: Land Interactions
EARTHSS 51.description: The role of terrestrial processes in the Earth system. Provides an introduction to ecosystem processes that regulate the cycling of energy, water, carbon, and nutrients. Analysis of the impact of human activities. Materials fee.
EARTHSS 51.restriction: Restriction: Environmental Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Earth System Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EARTHSS 53.name: Ocean Biogeochemistry
EARTHSS 53.description: Overview of oceanography for those interested in Earth System Science. Focus is on physical, chemical, and biological processes that drive biogeochemical cycling in the oceans. Coastal systems are also reviewed, with an emphasis on California waters.
EARTHSS 53.restriction: Restriction: Earth System Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EARTHSS 55.name: Earth's Atmosphere
EARTHSS 55.description: Composition, physics, and circulation of Earth's atmosphere with an emphasis on explaining the role of atmospheric processes in shaping the climate system. Topics include atmospheric composition, the global energy balance, radiative transfer and climate, atmospheric circulation, and climate sensitivity.
EARTHSS 55.restriction: Restriction: Environmental Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Earth System Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EARTHSS 70A.name: Sustainable Energy Systems
EARTHSS 70A.description: Addresses how modern energy services can be provided sustainably and the challenges and barriers that must be overcome. Major environmental issues are discussed, such as climate change, air pollution, and resource demands.
EARTHSS 70A.restriction: Restriction: Environmental Science and Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Earth System Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EARTHSS 70B.name: Sustainable Food and Water Systems
EARTHSS 70B.description: Explores the biophysical underpinnings of food production, the history of agricultural development, and a range of environmental issues facing agricultural systems, including water management, climate change, and land use.
EARTHSS 70B.restriction: Restriction: Environmental Science and Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Earth System Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EARTHSS 100.name: Special Topics in Earth System Science
EARTHSS 100.description: Devoted to current topics in the field of Earth System Science. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
EARTHSS 100.prereqString: Prerequisite: (EARTHSS 51 and EARTHSS 53 and EARTHSS 55) or (EARTHSS 70A and EARTHSS 70B)
EARTHSS 100.restriction: Restriction: Environmental Science and Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Earth System Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EARTHSS 101.name: Paleoclimatology
EARTHSS 101.description: Explores past changes in Earth's climate. Topics include tools and techniques used to reconstruct past climate from natural archives
EARTHSS 101.prereqString: Prerequisite: EARTHSS 51 and EARTHSS 53 and EARTHSS 55
EARTHSS 101.restriction: Restriction: Earth System Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EARTHSS 112.name: Global Climate Change and Impacts
EARTHSS 112.description: Observations over the 20th century show extensive changes in atmospheric composition, climate and weather, and biological systems that have paralleled industrial growth. Evidence of globally driven changes in these biogeochemical systems is studied, including projected impacts over the 21st century.
EARTHSS 112.prereqString: Prerequisite: (EARTHSS 51 and EARTHSS 53 and EARTHSS 55) or (EARTHSS 70A and EARTHSS 70B)
EARTHSS 112.restriction: Restriction: Environmental Science and Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Earth System Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EARTHSS 114.name: Earth System Science Laboratory and Field Methods
EARTHSS 114.description: Introduction to methods used to measure exchange of gases and energy between the atmosphere and terrestrial ecosystems. Laboratories include data acquisition and isotopic and chromatographic analysis. Field measurements at UCI's Marsh Reserve include microclimate, hydrology, trace-gas exchange, and plant growth. Materials fee.
EARTHSS 114.prereqString: Prerequisite: (EARTHSS 51 and EARTHSS 53 and EARTHSS 55) or (EARTHSS 70A and EARTHSS 70B)
EARTHSS 114.restriction: Restriction: Environmental Science and Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Earth System Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EARTHSS 115.name: Aquatic Field Methods
EARTHSS 115.description: Students design sampling plans, conduct field research techniques, and carry out data analyses that are relevant to aquatic field research. Aquatic field sites covered in the course include marine, estuarine, and fluvial systems. Materials fee.
EARTHSS 115.prereqString: Prerequisite: (EARTHSS 51 and EARTHSS 53 and EARTHSS 55) or (EARTHSS 70A and EARTHSS 70B)
EARTHSS 115.restriction: Restriction: Environmental Science and Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Earth System Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EARTHSS 116.name: Introduction to Environmental Data Science
EARTHSS 116.description: Analysis and interpretation of geophysical data, including functional fitting, probability density functions, and multidimensional time-series methods, with applications in atmospheric, oceanic, and biogeochemical sciences.
EARTHSS 116.prereqString: Prerequisite: (EARTHSS 51 and EARTHSS 53 and EARTHSS 55) or (EARTHSS 70A and EARTHSS 70B)
EARTHSS 116.restriction: Restriction: Environmental Science and Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Earth System Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EARTHSS 118.name: Analysis, Modeling, and Visualization of Multidimensionnal Environmental Data
EARTHSS 118.description: Students learn programming and numerical methods in Python with applications in Earth System Science and ecology. Topics include regression, uncertainty and significance, the development of simple box models, and the visualization of multi-dimensional climate and satellite datasets.
EARTHSS 118.restriction: Restriction: Environmental Science and Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Earth System Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EARTHSS 122.name: Atmospheric Dynamics
EARTHSS 122.description: Fluid dynamical processes that determine the large-scale flow of the atmosphere and ocean. Most important are interactions between the density stratification and the Coriolis force associated with Earth's rotation. Topics include circulation, vorticity, planetary waves, and their role in climate.
EARTHSS 122.restriction: Restriction: Environmental Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Earth System Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EARTHSS 124.name: Weather Analysis
EARTHSS 124.description: Provides an overview of weather systems in midlatitudes and tropics. The fundamental dynamics possible for these weather systems are described. Elementary weather analysis and forecasting techniques are introduced.
EARTHSS 124.restriction: Restriction: Environmental Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Earth System Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EARTHSS 130.name: Physical Oceanography
EARTHSS 130.description: Physical processes that determine the distribution of water properties such as salt and temperature. Fluid-dynamical underpinnings of physical oceanography. Wave motions. The wind-driven and thermohaline circulation. Similarities and differences between ocean and atmosphere dynamics.
EARTHSS 130.restriction: Restriction: Earth System Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EARTHSS 132.name: Terrestrial Hydrology
EARTHSS 132.description: Comprehensive treatment of modern conceptual and methodological approaches to hydrological science. Combines qualitative understanding of hydrological processes with quantitative representation, approaches to measurement, and treatment of uncertainty. Components of the hydrological cycle and their linkages within the coupled Earth system.
EARTHSS 132.prereqString: Prerequisite: (EARTHSS 51 and EARTHSS 55) or (EARTHSS 40C and EARTHSS 70B)
EARTHSS 132.restriction: Restriction: Environmental Science and Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Earth System Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EARTHSS 133.name: Soil: It's the Good Dirt
EARTHSS 133.description: An introduction to the critical role soils play in sustaining land ecosystems and humans. Covers how soils form and how human actions contribute to the pollution and loss but also the health and productivity of soils.
EARTHSS 133.prereqString: Prerequisite: (EARTHSS 51 and EARTHSS 53 and EARTHSS 55) or (EARTHSS 70A and EARTHSS 70B)
EARTHSS 133.restriction: Restriction: Environmental Science and Policy Majors only. Environmental Science Majors only. Earth System Science Majors only.

EARTHSS 134.name: Fundamentals of GIS for Environmental Science
EARTHSS 134.description: Introduction to Geographic Information Systems (GIS). Topics include fundamentals of cartography, creating/editing GIS data, linking spatial and tabular data, georeferencing, map projections, geospatial analysis, spatial statistics, and the development of GIS models. Examples from hydrology, ecology, and geology.
EARTHSS 134.prereqString: Prerequisite: (EARTHSS 51 and EARTHSS 53) or (EARTHSS 70A and EARTHSS 70B)
EARTHSS 134.restriction: Restriction: Environmental Science and Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Earth System Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EARTHSS 138.name: Satellite Remote Sensing for Earth System Science
EARTHSS 138.description: Satellite remote sensing data are increasingly used to study the Earth system. Provides an overview of the principles behind remote sensing, and the types of satellite data available for study of the oceans, land, and atmosphere.
EARTHSS 138.prereqString: Prerequisite: (EARTHSS 51 and EARTHSS 53) or (EARTHSS 70A and EARTHSS 70B)
EARTHSS 138.restriction: Restriction: Environmental Science and Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Earth System Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EARTHSS 140.name: Advanced Geology
EARTHSS 140.description: Introduces students to the geological processes which have formed and continue to shape the Earth. Topics include geological time, minerals and the rock cycle, plate tectonics and associated geological hazards, earth resources, and earth surface processes. Materials fee.
EARTHSS 140.restriction: Restriction: Environmental Science and Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Earth System Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EARTHSS 142.name: Atmospheric Chemistry
EARTHSS 142.description: Chemistry of the troposphere and stratosphere. Topics include processes controlling the lifetime and reaction pathways of chemicals in the atmosphere, the role of the atmosphere in biogeochemical cycles, and interactions between atmospheric chemistry and the physical climate system.
EARTHSS 142.prereqString: Prerequisite: (CHEM 1C or CHEM H2C or CHEM M3C) and (PHYSICS 3C or PHYSICS 7E) and (MATH 2B or MATH 5B or AP Calculus BC). AP Calculus BC with a minimum score of 4
EARTHSS 142.restriction: Restriction: Environmental Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Earth System Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EARTHSS 144.name: Marine Geochemistry and Biogeochemistry
EARTHSS 144.description: Processes controlling the major and minor element composition of seawater and element distributions in the ocean. Gas exchange, carbon dioxide system, stable isotopes, radionuclides as tracers and chronometers, particle fluxes, organic geochemistry, sediment geochemistry, global cycles of biogeochemically important elements.
EARTHSS 144.restriction: Restriction: School of Physical Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Earth System Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EARTHSS 146.name: Consequences of Air Pollution
EARTHSS 146.description: From public health to the global climate system, this course explores the impacts of air pollution from the beginning of human history to current and emerging issues. Scientific concepts behind air pollution and solutions are discussed.
EARTHSS 146.prereqString: Prerequisite: (EARTHSS 51 and EARTHSS 53 and EARTHSS 55) or (EARTHSS 40C and EARTHSS 70A)
EARTHSS 146.restriction: Restriction: Environmental Science and Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Earth System Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EARTHSS 148.name: Marine Ecosystems and Global Change
EARTHSS 148.description: Presents an overview of marine ecosystem structure, diversity, and processes in the context of global change, including the impacts of climate warming, ocean acidification, marine fisheries, and anthropogenic additions of nutrients and pollutants.
EARTHSS 148.restriction: Restriction: Environmental Science and Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Earth System Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EARTHSS 154.name: Ecosystem Services
EARTHSS 154.description: Covers what ecosystem services are, how to classify them, what the impacts of land degradation are on ecosystem services, how to quantify and value them, and the importance of mainstreaming ecosystem services in decision-making.
EARTHSS 154.prereqString: Prerequisite: (EARTHSS 70A and EARTHSS 70B) or (EARTHSS 51 and EARTHSS 53 and EARTHSS 55)

EARTHSS 156.name: The Future of Forests
EARTHSS 156.description: Introduces students to the determinants of global forest distribution
EARTHSS 156.prereqString: Prerequisite: (EARTHSS 70A and EARTHSS 70B) or (EARTHSS 51 and EARTHSS 53 and EARTHSS 55)
EARTHSS 156.restriction: Restriction: Environmental Science and Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Earth System Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EARTHSS 158.name: Research Methods for Sustainable Systems Analysis
EARTHSS 158.description: Develops students' analytical skills that are necessary to engage and assess the sustainability of coupled human and natural systems and effectively communicate their findings.
EARTHSS 158.prereqString: Prerequisite: (EARTHSS 51 and EARTHSS 53 and EARTHSS 55) or (EARTHSS 70A and EARTHSS 70B). Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
EARTHSS 158.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. Environmental Science and Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Earth System Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Global Sustainability Minors have first consideration for enrollment.

EARTHSS 162.name: The Impact of Climate Change on California's Landscape
EARTHSS 162.description: Overview of anticipated impacts of climate change on California's landscape. Includes projections of future climate
EARTHSS 162.prereqString: Prerequisite: (EARTHSS 51 and EARTHSS 53 and EARTHSS 55) or (EARTHSS 70A and EARTHSS 70B)
EARTHSS 162.restriction: Restriction: Environmental Science and Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Earth System Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EARTHSS 164.name: Ecosystem Ecology
EARTHSS 164.description: A mechanistic perspective on ecosystem processes. Covers ecosystem development, element cycling, and interactions with plants and microbes. The role of ecosystems in environmental change is also addressed.
EARTHSS 164.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI E106 or EARTHSS 51 or EARTHSS 60A or CHEM 51C
EARTHSS 164.restriction: Restriction: Earth System Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Ecology and Evolutionary Biol Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EARTHSS 168.name: Physiological Plant Ecology
EARTHSS 168.description: An examination of the interactions between plants and their environment. Emphasis on the underlying physiological mechanisms of plant function, adaptations and responses to stress, and the basis of the distribution of plants and plant assemblages across the landscape.
EARTHSS 168.prereqString: Prerequisite: EARTHSS 51 or BIO SCI 94 or (EARTHSS 60A and EARTHSS 60C)
EARTHSS 168.restriction: Restriction: Biological Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Earth System Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EARTHSS 171.name: Microbial Biogeochemistry
EARTHSS 171.description: Develops an understanding of microorganisms in the context of their environment, environmental impact, and role in the global cycles of C,N,P, etc. Focuses on tools used to evaluate microbial diversity and function, and applications of microbial ecology.
EARTHSS 171.prereqString: Prerequisite: (EARTHSS 51 and EARTHSS 53 and EARTHSS 55) or (EARTHSS 70A and EARTHSS 70B)
EARTHSS 171.restriction: Restriction: Environmental Science and Policy Majors only. Environmental Science Majors only. Earth System Science Majors only.

EARTHSS 176W.name: Marine Conservation, Policy, and Society
EARTHSS 176W.description: Conservation of marine ecosystems is important yet challenging due to competing physical, ecological, social, and regulatory issues. Students explore the principles of marine conservation, the scientific basics of marine ecosystems, and political and social processes involved with resource protection.
EARTHSS 176W.prereqString: Prerequisite: (EARTHSS 51 and EARTHSS 53 and EARTHSS 55) or (EARTHSS 70A and EARTHSS 70B). Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
EARTHSS 176W.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. Environmental Science and Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Earth System Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EARTHSS 177W.name: Documenting and Understanding Earth System Change
EARTHSS 177W.description: Students select a time series of key environmental interest as the focus for their writing.They become familiar with common writing practices for the Earth Sciences, and exercise their ability to use the scientific method to produce reports.
EARTHSS 177W.prereqString: Prerequisite: (EARTHSS 51 and EARTHSS 53 and EARTHSS 55) or (EARTHSS 70A and EARTHSS 70B). Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
EARTHSS 177W.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. Environmental Science and Policy Majors only. Environmental Science Majors only. Earth System Science Majors only.

EARTHSS 179.name: Climate Solutions
EARTHSS 179.description: Focuses on carbon neutrality and climate stability, addressing.

EARTHSS 190A.name: Senior Seminar on Global Sustainability I
EARTHSS 190A.description: Students attend weekly seminar to discuss current issues in global sustainability. Weekly attendance at Global Sustainability Forum is also required. Seminar utilized to analyze forum presentations.  Prepare bibliography.
EARTHSS 190A.restriction: Restriction: Seniors only. Global Sustainability Minors have first consideration for enrollment.

EARTHSS 190B.name: Senior Seminar on Global Sustainability II
EARTHSS 190B.description: Students attend weekly seminar to discuss current issues in global sustainability. Weekly attendance at Global Sustainability Forum is also required. Seminar utilized to analyze forum presentations.  Prepare research proposal.
EARTHSS 190B.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI 191A or SOCECOL 186A or EARTHSS 190A

EARTHSS 190CW.name: Writing/Senior Seminar on Global Sustainability III
EARTHSS 190CW.description: Students attend weekly seminar to discuss current issues in global sustainability.  Weekly attendance at Global Sustainability Forum also is required.  Seminar utilized to analyze Forum presentations and to prepare senior research paper.  Prepare/write research paper under direction of faculty member.
EARTHSS 190CW.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI 191B or EARTHSS 190B or SOCECOL 186B. BIO SCI 191B or EARTHSS 190B or SOCECOL 186B. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

EARTHSS 191.name: Introduction to Research in Earth System Science
EARTHSS 191.description: Weekly presentations by Earth System Science faculty describing ongoing research in their laboratories. Students are introduced to the range of research topics and methods in Earth System Science and to the research opportunities available within the Department.
EARTHSS 191.prereqString: Prerequisite: (EARTHSS 60A and EARTHSS 60B) or (EARTHSS 51 and EARTHSS 53)
EARTHSS 191.restriction: Restriction: Earth & Atmospheric Sciences Minors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Earth System Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EARTHSS 192.name: Careers in Earth System Science
EARTHSS 192.description: A weekly seminar course designed to help students transition to post-graduation career paths. Topics include designing effective resumes, applying to graduate school, and seeking employment. Also includes presentations by faculty, business, and government leaders describing potential environmental science career trajectories.
EARTHSS 192.restriction: Restriction: Environmental Science and Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Earth System Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EARTHSS 197.name: Independent Study in Earth System Science
EARTHSS 197.description: Field study, educational outreach, or other independent projects under faculty direction. Interested students should arrange with an ESS faculty member to supervise and support an independent study project. A written summary is required at the end of each quarter.

EARTHSS 198W.name: Senior Thesis in Earth System Science
EARTHSS 198W.description: Students receive guidance on the effective oral and written communication of research results. Students prepare and present a seminar, a poster, and a written thesis describing their research in Earth System Science.
EARTHSS 198W.prereqString: Prerequisite: Two quarters of EARTHSS 199. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

EARTHSS H198.name: Honors Thesis in Earth System Science
EARTHSS H198.description: Students receive guidance on effective written and oral communication of research results.  Students prepare and present a seminar, poster, and written thesis describing their honors research in Earth System Science.  Submission of the thesis and successful completion of this course will also satisfy the UCI upper-division writing requirement.
EARTHSS H198.restriction: Restriction: Consent of instructor to enroll and Prerequisite required

EARTHSS 199.name: Undergraduate Research
EARTHSS 199.description: For undergraduates with majors in science or engineering. Interested students should arrange with an ESS faculty member to supervise and support a research project. A written summary is required at the end of each quarter.

EARTHSS H199A.name: Honors Research in Earth System Science
EARTHSS H199A.description: Undergraduate honors research in Earth System Science. A student commitment of 10-15 hours a week is expected, and a written report is required at the end of the quarter.
EARTHSS H199A.restriction: Restriction: Earth System Science Honors students only. Campuswide Honors Collegium students only.

EARTHSS H199B.name: Honors Research in Earth System Science
EARTHSS H199B.description: Undergraduate honors research in Earth System Science. A student commitment of 10-15 hours a week is expected, and a written report is required at the end of the quarter.
EARTHSS H199B.restriction: Restriction: Earth System Science Honors students only. Campuswide Honors Collegium students only.

EARTHSS H199C.name: Honors Research in Earth System Science
EARTHSS H199C.description: Undergraduate honors research in Earth System Science. A student commitment of 10-15 hours a week is expected, and a written report is required at the end of the quarter.
EARTHSS H199C.restriction: Restriction: Earth System Science Honors students only. Campuswide Honors Collegium students only.

EARTHSS 200.name: Global Physical Climatology
EARTHSS 200.description: A descriptive overview of Earth’s climate system and energy budget. Large-scale circulations, key physical processes, and climate sensitivity of the atmosphere, ocean, land surface, and cryosphere.

EARTHSS 202.name: Climate Change
EARTHSS 202.description: Explores past, present, and projected changes in Earth's climate. Topics include paleoclimate records and mechanisms of natural climate variability at a range of timescales (orbital to seasonal)

EARTHSS 204.name: Humans in the Earth System
EARTHSS 204.description: Focuses on the human systems of energy and food production which have the greatest effects on the Earth system. Assess the physical mechanisms and feedbacks of human-nature interactions and consider approaches of mitigation, interventions, and adaptation.
EARTHSS 204.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Earth System Science Majors only.

EARTHSS 212.name: Geoscience Modeling and Data Analysis
EARTHSS 212.description: Computer-based course. Fundamental statistical techniques needed to analyze Earth system data and models. Basic numerical techniques to solve Earth system models. Focuses on linear and non-linear ordinary differential equations, as well as simple partial differential equations.

EARTHSS 215.name: Cryosphere
EARTHSS 215.description: A global perspective of the major components of the cryosphere. Includes current extent and trends, mass balance, energetics, and physical processes. Quantitative assessment of current state, in situ and remote observations, and interactions with climate.

EARTHSS 225.name: Marine Biogeochemistry
EARTHSS 225.description: Overview of ocean biology and biogeochemistry, with a focus on lower trophic levels and the roles of biota in the marine biogeochemical cycles of key elements.
EARTHSS 225.restriction: Restriction: Doctor of Philosophy Degree students have first consideration for enrollment. Graduate students only. Earth System Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EARTHSS 226.name: Land Surface Processes
EARTHSS 226.description: A mechanistic perspective of the structure and functioning of terrestrial ecosystems. Includes processes such as nutrient cycling, biogeochemical cycling, mass balance, energetics, terrestrial hydrology, and water cycle.

EARTHSS 230.name: Physical Oceanography
EARTHSS 230.description: Physical processes that determine the distribution of water properties such as salt and temperature.  Fluid-dynamical underpinnings of physical oceanography.  Wave motions.  The wind-driven and thermohaline circulation.  Similarities and differences between ocean and atmosphere dynamics.
EARTHSS 230.prereqString: Prerequisite: MATH 2D and PHYSICS 7A and PHYSICS 7B and PHYSICS 7E

EARTHSS 238.name: Satellite Remote Sensing for Earth System Science
EARTHSS 238.description: Satellite remote sensing data are increasingly used to study the Earth system. Provides an overview of the principles behind remote sensing, and the types of satellite data available for study of the oceans, land, and atmosphere.

EARTHSS 242.name: Advanced Atmospheric Chemistry
EARTHSS 242.description: Chemistry of the troposphere and stratosphere.  Topics include: processes controlling the lifetime and reaction pathways of chemicals in the atmosphere, the role of the atmosphere in biogeochemical cycles, and interactions between atmospheric chemistry and the physical climate system.

EARTHSS 244.name: Introduction to Atmospheric Dynamics
EARTHSS 244.description: Covers fundamentals of atmospheric dynamics including thermodynamics, quasi-geostrophy, the weak-temperature gradient of the tropics, and the turbulent boundary layer.

EARTHSS 248.name: Marine Ecosystems and Global Change
EARTHSS 248.description: Presents an overview of marine ecosystem structure, diversity, and processes in the context of global change, including the impacts of climate warming, ocean acidification, marine fisheries, and anthropogenic additions of nutrients and pollutants.

EARTHSS 252.name: Environmental Isotope Geochemistry
EARTHSS 252.description: Covers the fundamentals of stable, radioactive, and radiogenic isotope variability in the Earth System. Focuses on theory, measurement techniques, biogeochemistry, hydrology, ecology, and climate related applications.

EARTHSS 256.name: Paleoclimatology and Paleoceanography
EARTHSS 256.description: Explores past changes in Earth's climate. Topics include tools and techniques used to reconstruct past climate from natural archives

EARTHSS 264.name: Ecosystem Ecology
EARTHSS 264.description: A mechanistic perspective on ecosystem processes. Covers ecosystem development, element cycling, and interactions with plants and microbes. The role of ecosystems in environmental change is also addressed.

EARTHSS 266.name: Global Biogeochemical Cycles
EARTHSS 266.description: Global biogeochemical cycling of the elements. Topics include global cycling of carbon, nitrogen, oxygen, and sulfur

EARTHSS 280A.name: Special Topics in Earth System Science
EARTHSS 280A.description: Each quarter is devoted to current topics in the field of Earth System Science. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

EARTHSS 280B.name: Special Topics in Earth System Science
EARTHSS 280B.description: Each quarter is devoted to current topics in the field of Earth System Science. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

EARTHSS 280C.name: Special Topics in Earth System Science
EARTHSS 280C.description: Each quarter is devoted to current topics in the field of Earth System Science. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

EARTHSS 282C.name: Special Topics in Climate
EARTHSS 282C.description: Each quarter is devoted to in-depth analysis of an important and rapidly developing area in the field of climate dynamics. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

EARTHSS 286A.name: Special Topics in Biogeochemistry
EARTHSS 286A.description: Each quarter is devoted to in-depth analysis of a subarea in biogeochemistry which is undergoing rapid development.  Topics addressed vary each quarter.

EARTHSS 286B.name: Special Topics in Biogeochemistry
EARTHSS 286B.description: Each quarter is devoted to in-depth analysis of a subarea in biogeochemistry which is undergoing rapid development.  Topics addressed vary each quarter.

EARTHSS 286C.name: Special Topics in Biogeochemistry
EARTHSS 286C.description: Each quarter is devoted to in-depth analysis of a subarea in biogeochemistry which is undergoing rapid development.  Topics addressed vary each quarter.

EARTHSS 288C.name: Special Topics in Ecosystems
EARTHSS 288C.description: Each quarter is devoted to current topics relating to Ecosystems. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

EARTHSS 290.name: Seminar
EARTHSS 290.description: Weekly seminars and discussions on topics of general and current interest in Earth System Science. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

EARTHSS 298.name: Practicum in Earth System Science
EARTHSS 298.description: Designed to introduce first-year graduate students to research. Students explore research opportunities and develop a proposal for a summer research project under the direction of a faculty mentor.

EARTHSS 299.name: Research
EARTHSS 299.description: Supervised original research in areas of Earth System Science.

EAS 15C.name: Introductory Topics in Chinese Literature
EAS 15C.description: Introduces students to major themes in Chinese literature and culture through the close reading, discussion, and analysis of selected texts in English translation.
EAS 15C.restriction: Restriction: Korean Literature and Culture Majors only. Chinese Studies Majors only. Japanese Language Literature Majors only. East Asian Cultures Majors only.

EAS 15J.name: Introductory Topics in Japanese Literature
EAS 15J.description: Introduces students to major themes in Japanese literature and culture through the close reading, discussion, and analysis of selected texts in English translation.
EAS 15J.restriction: Restriction: Korean Literature and Culture Majors only. Chinese Studies Majors only. Japanese Language Literature Majors only. East Asian Cultures Majors only.

EAS 15K.name: Introductory Topics in Korean Literature
EAS 15K.description: Introduces students to major themes in Korean literature and culture through the close reading, discussion, and analysis of selected texts in English translation.
EAS 15K.restriction: Restriction: Korean Literature and Culture Majors only. Chinese Studies Majors only. Japanese Language Literature Majors only. East Asian Cultures Majors only.

EAS 20.name: Topics in Asian Religions
EAS 20.description: An introduction to Asian religions (Hinduism, Buddhism, Confucianism, Taoism, Shamanism) including both elite doctrinal aspects and forms of more popular religiosity.

EAS 40.name: Topics in East Asian Popular Culture
EAS 40.description: Selected topics in the popular cultural traditions of East Asia designed to introduce students both to problems in situating culture in a specific time and place and to contemporary theories of popular culture and their application to East Asian contexts.

EAS 55.name: Introduction to East Asian Cultures
EAS 55.description: Interdisciplinary courses organized each year around a broad theme designed to introduce students to the cultures of East Asia. Topical organization of courses addresses issues that have been of importance historically and are reshaping East Asia today.

EAS H84.name: Traveling East/West
EAS H84.description: Traveling East/West presents a wide range of travel writings by Chinese, Indian, and Euro-American authors in which they contemplate the complexities of cross-cultural encounters and how knowledge about others and knowledge of ourselves are closely intertwined.
EAS H84.restriction: Restriction: Campuswide Honors Collegium students only.

EAS 110.name: Topics in Chinese Literature and Society
EAS 110.description: Studies in Chinese texts in their social and cultural context(s). Conducted in English.

EAS 116.name: Topics in East Asian Religions
EAS 116.description: Selected topics in the religions of East Asia, e.g., Buddhism, Daoism, Shintô, Christianity, popular religions.

EAS 117.name: Topics in East Asian Philosophy
EAS 117.description: Selected topics in the philosophies of East Asia, e.g., Yoga, Buddhism, Vedanta, Confucianism, Taoism, and Shinto.

EAS 120.name: Topics in Japanese Literature and Society
EAS 120.description: Studies in Japanese texts in their social and cultural context(s). Conducted in English.

EAS 123.name: Structure of Japanese
EAS 123.description: An overview of the linguistic features of modern Japanese. Provides students with a systematic introduction to the nature and characteristics of the language.

EAS 126.name: Topics in East Asian Linguistics
EAS 126.description: In-depth examination of selected topics in the linguistics of East Asian languages, including Chinese, Japanese, Korean, and Vietnamese.

EAS 130.name: Topics in Korean Society and Culture
EAS 130.description: Studies of the social and cultural forces that affect the lives of the Koreans, including those in the United States. Considers traditional values and contemporary issues within a historical framework.

EAS 140.name: Topics in Korean Literature and Society
EAS 140.description: Studies in Korean texts in their social and cultural context(s). Conducted in English.

EAS 150.name: Topics in East Asian Literature in Translation
EAS 150.description: East Asian literary works in translation. Taught in English.

EAS 155.name: Topics in Cultural Studies in East Asia
EAS 155.description: Interdisciplinary and theoretical introduction to issues in cultural studies that are pertinent to the study of East Asia. All readings in English.

EAS 160.name: Topics in East Asian Cinema
EAS 160.description: Study of East Asian cinema from historical, theoretical, and comparative perspectives. Taught in English.

EAS 170.name: Topics in Gender in East Asia
EAS 170.description: Explores the construction of gender in East Asian cultures and literatures. Pays close attention to the specificity of historical, cultural, and literary contexts of East Asia as it investigates various theoretical and critical perspectives on gender and sexuality.

EAS 190.name: Junior-Senior Colloquium
EAS 190.description: Specialized courses dealing with primary sources
EAS 190.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. Korean Literature and Culture Majors only. Chinese Studies Majors only. Japanese Language Literature Majors only. East Asian Cultures Majors only.

EAS 192W.name: Junior-Senior Seminar
EAS 192W.description: Analysis of a literary or cultural topic or problem through research and writing of two short and one long research paper for a minimum of 4,000 total words. Seminar follows EAS 190
EAS 192W.prereqString: Prerequisite: EAS 190. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

EAS 199.name: Independent Study
EAS 199.description: Investigation of special topics through directed reading in translation. Paper required.

EAS 216.name: Topics in East Asian Religions
EAS 216.description: Selected topics in the religions of East Asia, e.g., Buddhism, Daoism, Shintô, Islam, shamanism.

EAS 220.name: Topics in East Asian Cultural Studies
EAS 220.description: Seminar, with topics varying from year to year. Research paper required.

EAS 225.name: Topics in East Asian Applied Linguistics
EAS 225.description: In-depth examination of selected topics in applied linguistics, with a particular emphasis on language acquisition and language pedagogy.

EAS 260.name: Topics in East Asian Cinema
EAS 260.description: An examination of the possibilities of East Asian cinematic narrative. Possible topics: cinematic history

EAS 290.name: Independent Study
EAS 290.description: Directed research on topic determined in consultation with faculty member. A term paper or project is required.

EAS 299.name: Dissertation Research
EAS 299.description: Dissertation research for students who are advanced to doctoral candidacy.

ECO EVO 200A.name: Research in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology
ECO EVO 200A.description: Individual research with Ecology and Evolutionary Biological faculty.

ECO EVO 200B.name: Research in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology
ECO EVO 200B.description: Individual research with Ecology and Evolutionary Biological faculty.

ECO EVO 200C.name: Research in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology
ECO EVO 200C.description: Individual research with Ecology and Evolutionary Biological faculty.

ECO EVO 201.name: Seminar in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology
ECO EVO 201.description: Invited speakers, graduate students, and faculty present current research in ecology and evolutionary biology.

ECO EVO 203A.name: Graduate Tutorial in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology
ECO EVO 203A.description: Advanced study in areas not represented by formal courses. May involve individual or small group study through reading, discussion, and composition.

ECO EVO 203B.name: Graduate Tutorial in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology
ECO EVO 203B.description: Advanced study in areas not represented by formal courses. May involve individual or small group study through reading, discussion, and composition.

ECO EVO 203C.name: Graduate Tutorial in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology
ECO EVO 203C.description: Advanced study in areas not represented by formal courses. May involve individual or small group study through reading, discussion, and composition.

ECO EVO 204.name: Writing Grant Proposals
ECO EVO 204.description: Provides students with hands-on experience writing proposals in the research areas of ecology, evolution, or physiology.

ECO EVO 205.name: Special Topics in Ecology
ECO EVO 205.description: Survey of special topics in Ecology.

ECO EVO 206.name: Special Topics in Evolution
ECO EVO 206.description: Extensive introduction to the primary literature of evolutionary biology. Topics include population genetics, quantitative genetics, neutralism, molecular evolution, evolution of genetic systems, genetic architecture of fitness, speciation, and macroevolution.

ECO EVO 207.name: Quantitative Methods in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology
ECO EVO 207.description: Statistics for ecologists and evolutionary biologists. Emphasis on specific applications and underlying assumptions rather than on methods of calculation. Topics include experimental design, parametric and nonparametric methods, analysis of variance and covariance, and multiple regression.
ECO EVO 207.prereqString: Prerequisite: Completion of at least one quarter of statistics including regression and analysis of variance.

ECO EVO 208.name: Ecological and Evolutionary Physiology
ECO EVO 208.description: A summary of information in organismal biology, comparative and ecological physiology, and the biophysical basis of organismal function. Course offered every other fall.

ECO EVO 210.name: Foundations of Physiology
ECO EVO 210.description: Physical and functional principles common to many living forms. Course forms a basis for subsequent specialization in any of the subdisciplines of physiology. Course offered in even years.

ECO EVO 221.name: Advanced Topics in Ecology
ECO EVO 221.description: Weekly discussion of current topics in ecology at the graduate level.

ECO EVO 222.name: Statistical Learning in Ecology and Evolution
ECO EVO 222.description: Reviews basic principals of variance/bias trade-offs. Topics include models for prediction and classification, variable selection methods, cross-validation, tree based methods, unsupervised learning. Applications in ecology and evolution using R.
ECO EVO 222.prereqString: Prerequisite: ECO EVO 207. ECO EVO 207 with a grade of B or better

ECO EVO 227.name: Plant Physiological Ecology
ECO EVO 227.description: Provides a summary of information on plant organismal biology, comparative and ecological physiology, and functional ecology. Offered every other fall.

ECO EVO 230.name: Topics in Microbial Ecology
ECO EVO 230.description: Weekly discussion of current topics in ecology, biogeochemistry, evolution, and physiology of microbial organisms.

ECO EVO 235.name: Experimental Evolution
ECO EVO 235.description: Explores experimental evolution, which is now a well-established part of evolutionary biology. With the advent of genomics, it is now one of the most powerful tools for studying the genetic foundations of biology.
ECO EVO 235.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. School of Biological Sciences students only.

ECO EVO 236.name: Human Dimensions in Conservation and Restoration
ECO EVO 236.description: The non-human “environment” we know today is the result of past social, political, scientific, and economic forces. Examines the forces that drove environmental conservation efforts, which often sought progress at the expense of local cultures.

ECO EVO 237.name: Marine Conservation Ecology
ECO EVO 237.description: Theory-based seminar tackles pressing issues in marine ecology, conservation, and restoration. Focuses on the science of marine ecosystems, resources and tools for their conservation, and management and the socioeconomic and policy dimensions.

ECO EVO 246.name: Seminar in Ecology and Evolution Education
ECO EVO 246.description: Weekly discussion of teaching techniques and challenges that are specific to courses in ecology and evolutionary biology.  Emphasis will be on using evidence-based pedagogy techniques.  There will be a combination of readings, group discussions and speakers.

ECO EVO 247.name: Behavioral Endocrinology
ECO EVO 247.description: Comparative examination of the major hormone systems that regulate behavior across animals. Emphasizes the reciprocating nature of hormone-behavior interactions and seeks to understand how natural selection drives the evolution of hormone structure and function.

ECO EVO 251.name: Evolutionary and Ecological Principles in Medicine
ECO EVO 251.description: Explore the dynamics of populations on an ecological, epidemiological, and medical level. Considers the dynamics of competition, predation, and parasitism

ECO EVO 253.name: Functional and Structural Evolutionary Genomics
ECO EVO 253.description: Function and organization of genomes analyzed from an evolutionary perspective. Review of some of the most recent experimental approaches in genome analysis and comparative genomics. Relevant software to analyze DNA and expression data is used.

ECO EVO 262.name: Professional Workshop
ECO EVO 262.description: Identify and attend professional or technical skill workshops to gain professional knowledge and certifications related to conservation and restoration science.

ECO EVO 264.name: Conservation Biology
ECO EVO 264.description: Explores concepts in ecology with potential for conserving biological diversity. Identifies creative applications of ecological research that mitigate impacts of rapid human population growth and habitat destruction on biodiversity.

ECO EVO 265.name: Restoration Ecology
ECO EVO 265.description: Study of principles and practices that help recover degraded ecosystems  including restoration in different ecological systems, restoration motives and intensities, implementation and monitoring, and scope and success of case studies.

ECO EVO 266L.name: Field Methods in Restoration
ECO EVO 266L.description: Laboratory experience performing field methods that help recover degraded ecosystems  in different ecological systems.  Emphasis on the plant community composition, soil, irrigation, maintenance, and monitoring of a project.

ECO EVO 267.name: Science Communication
ECO EVO 267.description: Develops students' abilities to convey information related to conservation and restoration in a way that has broad appeal and/or effective messaging for non-scientific audiences by assessing the audience, developing effective storytelling, and deploying a persuasive information campaign.

ECO EVO 268.name: Technical Writing
ECO EVO 268.description: Practice developing key documents for restoration projects including a response to a request for proposal (RFP), a restoration project plan, and a monitoring and maintenance plan.

ECO EVO 269.name: Project Management
ECO EVO 269.description: Discover the planning, design, implementation, and aftercare phases of managing a conservation or restoration project.  Students will project cost, manage risk, analyze sites, evaluate and review projects, and become familiar with common permitting and consultation requirements.

ECO EVO 270.name: GIS for Environmental Science
ECO EVO 270.description: Introduction to the fundamental principles of GIS. Topics include cartography, creating/editing GIS data, georeferencing, map projections, geospatial analysis, spatial statistics, and development of GIS models. Focuses on theory and practice.

ECO EVO 271.name: Marine Research and Conservation Methods
ECO EVO 271.description: Field-based introduction to marine ecology and conservation management through the study of the ecology, resource management, and conservation of marine habitats and species, and the use of a variety of marine field research methods.

ECO EVO 272.name: Plant Diversity in a Changing World
ECO EVO 272.description: Investigation of plant diversity in California and throughout the world, including basic systematic concepts, introduction to major groups of flowering plants, and the effects of global biological change on plant diversity. Students carry out a phylogenetic analysis using appropriate software.

ECO EVO 275.name: Wildlife Ecology and Sampling
ECO EVO 275.description: Field-based introduction to wildlife management through the study of the ecology, physiology, population biology management, and conservation of vertebrate wildlife species, and the use of a variety of different wildlife sampling techniques.

ECO EVO 282.name: Fundamentals of Informatics for Biologists
ECO EVO 282.description: Students learn the fundamentals of bioinformatics and the unix operating system (including the shell and Sun Grid Engine) in order to assemble a eukaryotic genome.

ECO EVO 283.name: Advanced Informatics for Biologists
ECO EVO 283.description: Students learn advanced informatics including the analysis of: Poolseq, RNAseq, ATACseq, and ChiPseq datasets using programs such as bwa, tophat, cufflinks, DEseq, Trinity, Agustus, etc., in a unix high-performance computing environment. Statistical tests carried out and publication quality.

ECO EVO 285.name: Topics in Evolutionary Genetics
ECO EVO 285.description: Weekly discussion of recent research on evolutionary genetics.

ECO EVO 286.name: MCRS Capstone
ECO EVO 286.description: Apply knowledge and skills in a practical professional setting, working with practitioners to identify a conservation or management problem and then to plan, implement, and evaluate a solution.

ECO EVO 288.name: Documenting Research Through Cinematic Production
ECO EVO 288.description: Students gain advanced media expertise by conceptualizing investigative research into publicly engaging video projects. Popularly accessible research topics will be adapted into documentary, television, or cinematic pieces that provide opportunities for developing professionally marketable skills in educationally effective media production.

ECO EVO 341.name: Teaching Science in Secondary School
ECO EVO 341.description: Prospective secondary science teachers learn how to teach science in grades 7-12. Covers State science requirements, a variety of teaching methods, criteria for selecting science curricular materials, and how to plan science lessons, units, experiments, projects, and demonstrations.
ECO EVO 341.restriction: Restriction: Master of Arts in Teaching Degree students only.

ECO EVO 399.name: University Teaching
ECO EVO 399.description: Mandatory course for Ecology and Evolutionary Biology Teaching Assistants, required in each quarter in which student has a Teaching Assistant position. Limited to Teaching Assistants.

ECON 1.name: Introduction to Economics
