ECON 1.description: An analysis of the problems society faces in organizing itself to provide goods and services. How decisions of government, business, and the individual relate to current economic problems such as unemployment, inflation, poverty, and environmental pollution.
ECON 1.restriction: Restriction: No Economics Majors. ECON 1 may not be taken for credit if taken concurrently or after ECON 20A or ECON 20B.

ECON 11.name: The Internet and Public Policy
ECON 11.description: How the Internet works. Current public policy issues concerning the Internet. Introductory economics. Communications law. Interactions between information technology, economics, and law. Case studies about Internet and communications policy.

ECON 12.name: Federal Reserve: Past, Present, and Future
ECON 12.description: Studies central banking in the United States from colonial times to the present. Focuses on the past, present, and future of the Federal Reserve and precursors to that system, which was established in 1913.

ECON 13.name: Global Economy
ECON 13.description: Acquaints students with the fundamental patterns of the global economy. Emphasizes the historical roots and political implications of economic choices.
ECON 13.restriction: Restriction: International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ECON 15A.name: Probability and Statistics in Economics I
ECON 15A.description: An introduction to probability, statistics, and econometrics. Emphasis on a thorough understanding of the probabilistic basis of statistical inference. Examples from economics.
ECON 15A.restriction: Restriction: Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ECON 15B.name: Probability and Statistics in Economics II
ECON 15B.description: An introduction to probability, statistics, and econometrics. Emphasis on a thorough understanding of the probabilistic basis of statistical inference. Examples from economics.
ECON 15B.restriction: Restriction: Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ECON 17.name: An Economic Approach to Religion
ECON 17.description: Introduction to how basic economic concepts such as demand, supply, consumption, production, competition, free-riding, innovation, regulation, and rent-seeking can be applied to understand observed religious behavior.

ECON 20A.name: Basic Economics I
ECON 20A.description: The fundamentals of microeconomics. The behavior of firms and consumers: markets, supply/demand, utility maximization, resource allocation, and efficiency.
ECON 20A.restriction: Restriction: Economics, Quantitative Economics, Business Economics, and Business Info Management majors have first consideration for enrollment. For School of Social Sciences majors, MGMT 4A may not be used as a substitute for ECON 20A.

ECON 20B.name: Basic Economics II
ECON 20B.description: The fundamentals of macroeconomics. Government behavior: monetary and fiscal policy, inflation, and unemployment. Effective fall 2006, the content of Economics 20B is macroeconomics. This course cannot be taken to repeat Economics 20B taken prior to fall 2006.
ECON 20B.prereqString: Prerequisite: ECON 20A or ECON 13 or ECON 23
ECON 20B.restriction: Restriction: Business Information Mgmt Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Mechanical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Aerospace Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Civil Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment. For School of Social Sciences majors, MGMT 4B may not be used as a substitute for ECON 20B.

ECON 23.name: Basic Economics for Engineers
ECON 23.description: The fundamentals of microeconomics. The behavior of firms and of consumers: markets, supply/demand, utility maximization, resource allocation, and efficiency.
ECON 23.restriction: Restriction: Engineering Majors only. Mechanical Engineering Majors only. Aerospace Engineering Majors only. Civil Engineering Majors only. Environmental Engineering Majors only.

ECON 25.name: The Economics of Accounting Decisions
ECON 25.description: Introduction to accounting concepts and principles, including the accounting model and accounting style, transaction analysis, and preparation of financial statements. An analysis of the similarities and differences between accounting and economic concepts (e.g., value, profits).
ECON 25.restriction: Restriction: Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ECON 100A.name: Intermediate Economics I
ECON 100A.prereqString: Prerequisite: ECON 20A and ECON 20B and MATH 2A and MATH 2B
ECON 100A.restriction: Restriction: Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ECON 100B.name: Intermediate Economic II
ECON 100B.restriction: Restriction: Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ECON 100C.name: Intermediate Economic III
ECON 100C.restriction: Restriction: Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ECON 105A.name: Intermediate Quantitative Economics I
ECON 105A.description: An advanced and mathematical version of ECON 100A for students in the Quantitative Economics major.
ECON 105A.prereqString: Prerequisite: ECON 20A and ECON 20B and MATH 2A and MATH 2B and MATH 3A
ECON 105A.restriction: Restriction: Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ECON 105B.name: Intermediate Quantitative Economics II
ECON 105B.description: An advanced and mathematical version of ECON 100B for students in the Quantitative Economics major.
ECON 105B.restriction: Restriction: Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ECON 105C.name: Intermediate Quantitative Economics III
ECON 105C.description: An advanced and mathematical version of ECON 100C for students in the Quantitative Economics major.
ECON 105C.restriction: Restriction: Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ECON 107.name: Economics of Asymmetric Information
ECON 107.description: Focuses on the effects of asymmetric information in the markets for traditional economic goods and resources, such as labor, insurance, used cars, credit, and in auctions and bargaining problems. Prerequisite:.
ECON 107.restriction: Restriction: Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ECON 109.name: Special Topics in Economic Theory
ECON 109.description: Studies in selected areas of Economics. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
ECON 109.restriction: Restriction: Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ECON 115.name: Behaviorial Economics
ECON 115.description: Studies the behavioral and psychological biases in economics settings. Both individual decisions and games are discussed.
ECON 115.restriction: Restriction: Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ECON 116A.name: Game Theory I
ECON 116A.description: Extensive form games with perfect information, and coalitional games. The key solution concepts are Nash Equilibrium, Backward Induction, and the Core. Substantive examples include public good production, oligopoly, electoral competition, auctions, holdup, market entry, and voting.
ECON 116A.prereqString: Prerequisite: (ECON 15B or STAT 120B) and (ECON 100A or ECON 105A)
ECON 116A.restriction: Restriction: Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ECON 116B.name: Game Theory II
ECON 116B.description: Two-quarter sequence on game theory. Bayesian games, extensive form games with imperfect information, zero-sum games.
ECON 116B.restriction: Restriction: Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ECON 122A.name: Applied Econometrics I
ECON 122A.description: Introduction to econometrics emphasizing practical applications in microeconomics and macroeconomics.
ECON 122A.restriction: Restriction: Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ECON 122B.name: Applied Econometrics II
ECON 122B.description: Introduction to econometrics emphasizing practical applications in microeconomics and macroeconomics.
ECON 122B.restriction: Restriction: Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ECON 122CW.name: Data Analysis Writing
ECON 122CW.description: Research writing course in econometrics focusing on individual research projects. Students employ econometric analysis to address an economic question in a 20-page paper and present their findings to the class in a short presentation.
ECON 122CW.prereqString: Prerequisite: ECON 15A and ECON 15B and ECON 122A and ECON 122B. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
ECON 122CW.restriction: Restriction: Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ECON 123A.name: Econometrics I
ECON 123A.description: Specification, estimation, and testing of econometric models. Applications in various areas of microeconomics and macroeconomics.
ECON 123A.prereqString: Prerequisite: MATH 2A and MATH 2B and MATH 3A and (STAT 120C or MATH 130C) and (ECON 100A and ECON 100B and ECON 100C) or (ECON 105A and ECON 105B and ECON 105C)
ECON 123A.restriction: Restriction: Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ECON 123B.name: Econometrics II
ECON 123B.description: Specification, estimation, and testing of econometric models. Applications in various areas of microeconomics and macroeconomics.
ECON 123B.restriction: Restriction: Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ECON 123CW.name: Econometrics III
ECON 123CW.description: Seminar course in which students do an original econometric research project.
ECON 123CW.prereqString: Prerequisite: ECON 123B. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
ECON 123CW.restriction: Restriction: Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ECON 125.name: Business Forecasting
ECON 125.description: Students learn how to produce forecasts of the behavior of economic (and other) variables. The techniques examined are linear regression, nonlinear regression, and nonparametric kernel regression
ECON 125.restriction: Restriction: Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ECON 126.name: Computational Macroeconomics
ECON 126.description: Introduction to the computational methods for studying economic growth and the business cycle. Students learn how to write computer programs to simulate macroeconomic models, download and manage data from internet resources, and to do basic statistics.
ECON 126.restriction: Restriction: Business Economics Majors only. Economics Majors only. Quantitative Economics Majors only.

ECON 127A.name: Experimental Economics
ECON 127A.description: Students will learn what constitutes proper experimental design and what laboratory experiments teach us about human behavior and the economy. Students will participate in a sample experiment, evaluate the results, and discuss experiment design and larger issues. Formerly ECON 117.

ECON 128.name: Machine Learning for Economists
ECON 128.description: Develops the theory and computation of recent methods at the intersection of econometrics and machine learning as used in economics and business. Building on intermediate econometrics, it introduces causal random forests, double machine learning, and neural networks.
ECON 128.restriction: Restriction: Business Economics Majors only. Economics Majors only. Quantitative Economics Majors only.

ECON 129.name: Special Topics in Quantitative Methods
ECON 129.description: Studies in selected areas of Quantitative Methods. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
ECON 129.restriction: Restriction: Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ECON 131A.name: The Economics of Risk and Uncertainty
ECON 131A.description: The theory of insurance and joint-ownership of risky enterprises
ECON 131A.restriction: Restriction: Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ECON 132A.name: Introduction to Financial Investments
ECON 132A.description: Modern theories of investment and their application to the study of financial markets. The relation between risk and return, diversification, asset pricing, efficient markets hypothesis, and the market valuation of stocks, bonds, options, and futures.
ECON 132A.restriction: Restriction: Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ECON 134A.name: Corporate Finance
ECON 134A.description: Provides an overview of the modern theory and practice of corporate finance and focuses on two fundamental financial decisions
ECON 134A.prereqString: Prerequisite: (ECON 100A and ECON 100B and ECON 100C) or (ECON 105A and ECON 105B and ECON 105C) and (ECON 15A or MATH 130A or STAT 120A) and (ECON 15B or MATH 130B or STAT 120B)
ECON 134A.restriction: Restriction: Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ECON 134B.name: Corporate Finance II
ECON 134B.description: Advanced material in corporate finance. How to value companies, debt and equity financing, capital structure, IPOs, venture capital, private equity, and mergers and acquisitions. Applies knowledge through cases and real-life examples.
ECON 134B.restriction: Restriction: Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ECON 135.name: Mathematics of Finance
ECON 135.description: After reviewing tools from probability, statistics, and elementary differential and partial differential equations, concepts such as hedging, arbitrage, Puts, Calls, the design of portfolios, the derivation and solution of the Blac-Scholes, and other equations are discussed.
ECON 135.restriction: Restriction: Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Mathematics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ECON 137W.name: Financial Markets and the Macroeconomy
ECON 137W.description: Students are required to write a paper on a research question related to.
ECON 137W.prereqString: Prerequisite: ECON 122A or ECON 123A. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

ECON 139.name: Special Topics in Financial Economics
ECON 139.description: Studies in selected areas of Financial Economics. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
ECON 139.restriction: Restriction: Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ECON 140.name: Managerial Economics
ECON 140.description: A collection of concepts and methods for effective decision making. Explores how the tools of microeconomics, including game theory and industrial organization theory, can be used to make better managerial decisions, particularly those involving allocation of resources within firms.
ECON 140.prereqString: Prerequisite: (ECON 100A and ECON 100B) or (ECON 105A and ECON 105B)
ECON 140.restriction: Restriction: Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ECON 141A.name: Public Economics I
ECON 141A.description: Examines the role of the government in the economy and its impact on individuals and firms.
ECON 141A.prereqString: Prerequisite: (ECON 100A and ECON 100B) or (ECON 105A and ECON 105B)

ECON 141B.name: Public Economics II
ECON 141B.description: Theory of public goods, externalities, voting models, analysis of bureaucracy, the Tiebout model, income redistribution, intergovernmental grants.
ECON 141B.prereqString: Prerequisite: (ECON 100A and ECON 100B) or (ECON 105A and ECON 105B)
ECON 141B.restriction: Restriction: Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ECON 142A.name: Industrial Organization I
ECON 142A.description: The theory of market structure. Imperfect markets, government policies, and industry performance.
ECON 142A.prereqString: Prerequisite: (ECON 15A and ECON 15B) and (ECON 100A and ECON 100B) or (ECON 105A and ECON 105B)
ECON 142A.restriction: Restriction: Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ECON 142CW.name: Industrial Organization III
ECON 142CW.description: Research in industrial organization.  Satisfies the honors research requirement.
ECON 142CW.prereqString: Prerequisite: (ECON 100A and ECON 100B) or (ECON 105A and ECON 105B). Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
ECON 142CW.restriction: Restriction: Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ECON 143.name: Energy Economics
ECON 143.description: The economics of markets for oil, natural gas, electricity, and renewable energy, and their interactions with each other and the rest of the economy. Effects of government intervention, policy measures, economic policy issues arising between energy use and the environment.
ECON 143.restriction: Restriction: Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ECON 144A.name: Urban Economics I
ECON 144A.description: Why cities exist, economics of urban land-use, housing demand and tenure choice, traffic congestion.
ECON 144A.restriction: Restriction: Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ECON 144B.name: Urban Economics II
ECON 144B.description: Housing policy analysis, urban public goods and services, crime, pollution, urban amenities.
ECON 144B.prereqString: Prerequisite: ECON 20A and ECON 20B. Recommended: ECON 100A.
ECON 144B.restriction: Restriction: Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ECON 145E.name: Economics of the Environment
ECON 145E.description: Surveys economic aspects of natural resources, pollution, population, and the environment. Examines the causes of pollution
ECON 145E.restriction: Restriction: Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ECON 145FW.name: Economics of the Environment II
ECON 145FW.description: Applications of the tools covered in ECON 145E to topics such as global warming, destruction of the ozone layer, and emissions trading. Emphasis on independent research papers. Syllabus and classes include writing technique.
ECON 145FW.prereqString: Prerequisite: ECON 145E. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
ECON 145FW.restriction: Restriction: Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ECON 145L.name: Economics of Law
ECON 145L.description: Examination of several economic concepts which are useful in understanding legal rules: externalities, the assignment of property rights, and Coase's theorem. Examples are drawn from the fields of pollution control, no-fault insurance, medical malpractice, and product liability.
ECON 145L.restriction: Restriction: Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ECON 146A.name: Illegal Economics
ECON 146A.description: How illegal firms function in illegal markets, why individuals participate in these groups and markets, and what federal, state, and local governments do to disrupt organized illegal activity.
ECON 146A.restriction: Restriction: Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ECON 146B.name: Economics of Criminal Justice
ECON 146B.description: Provides an introduction to the economics of crime literature.
ECON 146B.restriction: Restriction: Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ECON 147A.name: Corporate Governance
ECON 147A.description: Studies topics in the internal organization of firms, including rent seeking, incentive contracts, principal-agent problems, internal labor markets, contests, and herd behavior.
ECON 147A.restriction: Restriction: Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ECON 147B.name: Economics of Strategy
ECON 147B.description: Uses tools of economics, game theory in particular, to develop an understanding of business decision-making. Deals with questions such as how the firm decides what kind of business to be in, how large should it be, and others.
ECON 147B.prereqString: Prerequisite: (ECON 100A and ECON 100B) or (ECON 105A and ECON 105B)
ECON 147B.restriction: Restriction: Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ECON 148.name: Business Decisions
ECON 148.description: Surveys normative and descriptive models of decision-making behavior, with an emphasis on organizational and policy contexts. Topics include rational choice theory, biases and heuristics, framing effects, and overconfidence. Management fads, panics, and herd behavior are also discussed.
ECON 148.prereqString: Prerequisite: (ANTH 10A and ANTH 10B and ANTH 10C) or (SOCL 10A and SOCL 10B and SOCL 10C) or (SSCI 10A and SSCI 10B and SSCI 10C) or (MATH 2A and MATH 2B and (STAT 7 or MGMT 7)) or (STAT 120A and STAT 120B and STAT 120C) or (ECON 15A and ECON 15B)
ECON 148.restriction: Restriction: Sociology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ECON 149.name: Special Topics in Economics of Public and Private Organizations
ECON 149.description: Studies in selected areas of Economics of Public and Private Organizations. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
ECON 149.restriction: Restriction: Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ECON 149W.name: Special Topics in Economics of Public and Private Organizations
ECON 149W.description: Studies in selected areas of Economics of Public and Private Organizations. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
ECON 149W.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
ECON 149W.restriction: Restriction: Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ECON 151A.name: Labor Economics and Human Resources I
ECON 151A.description: Labor demand, labor supply, human capital, personnel economics, and other topics.
ECON 151A.prereqString: Prerequisite: (ECON 15A and ECON 15B) and (ECON 100A and ECON 100B) or (ECON 105A and ECON 105B)
ECON 151A.restriction: Restriction: Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ECON 152A.name: Economic Anthropology
ECON 152A.description: Economic systems in comparative perspective: production, distribution, and consumption in market and non-market societies
ECON 152A.prereqString: Prerequisite: One course in general science, anthropology, economics, geography, or sociology.
ECON 152A.restriction: Restriction: Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Anthropology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ECON 153W.name: Political Institutions, Legal Systems, and Economic Development
ECON 153W.description: Studies a variety of empirical papers analyzing how institutions affect economic development. The topics include cross-country studies of institutions as well as narrower topics such as corruption, regulation of entry, political connections, and pork barrel politics.
ECON 153W.prereqString: Prerequisite: ECON 15A and ECON 15B and ECON 100A and ECON 100B and ECON 100C and ECON 122A. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

ECON 154.name: Voting and Political Manipulation
ECON 154.description: Introduction to social choice and cooperative games. Topics include majority rule, types of voting methods, apportionment and proportional representation, agenda manipulation, coalition formation, voting power, political consequences of electoral laws.
ECON 154.restriction: Restriction: Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ECON 155.name: Current Issues in Political Economy
ECON 155.description: Political economy seeks explanations that combine insights from both economics and politics. Topics include the interaction of government and markets, the causes of the Great Recession, and the sources of income and wealth inequality.
ECON 155.prereqString: Prerequisite: ECON 20A or ECON 20B or ECON 13 or IS 13

ECON 157.name: Economic Development
ECON 157.description: Considers the process of economic development across the globe and why some countries are rich and others poor. Discusses the major problems facing developing countries, such as population growth, education, capital formation, environmental protection, and international trade.
ECON 157.restriction: Restriction: Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ECON 158.name: Economics of Education
ECON 158.description: Arms students with tools, concepts, and evidence that can be used to analyze complex policy questions in education, enabling students to arrive at their own reasoned judgments about how to improve education.
ECON 158.restriction: Restriction: Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ECON 161A.name: Money and Banking
ECON 161A.description: Basic elements of money and banking: institutional features and economics of financial markets and, in particular, the U.S. banking system
ECON 161A.restriction: Restriction: Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ECON 161B.name: International Money
ECON 161B.description: Open economy macroeconomics and determination of exchange rates. Asset-market approach to the balance of payments. Internal and external balance in the economy. Macroeconomic policies under fixed and floating exchange rates. The international monetary system and institutions.
ECON 161B.restriction: Restriction: Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ECON 161D.name: Advanced Money and Banking
ECON 161D.description: Studies business cycles in the United States during the last century. The first portion of the course reviews the theoretical models employed to study economic fluctuations and empirical methods used to measure fluctuations.
ECON 161D.restriction: Restriction: Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ECON 162.name: Poverty, Growth, and Development
ECON 162.description: Examines India as a case study for each of the topics studied: growth experience of India along with its poverty eradication record, aspects of poverty, and the policies that have been undertaken to tackle poverty.
ECON 162.prereqString: Prerequisite: (ECON 15A or STAT 120A) and (ECON 15B or STAT 120B) and (ECON 100A and ECON 100B and ECON 100C) or (ECON 105A and ECON 105B and ECON 105C)

ECON 164AW.name: The Industrial Revolution in Western Europe
ECON 164AW.description: How do economists explain the process of economic development during the past three centuries? Has the process of industrialization affected living standards? Focusing on these questions, students learn how to apply economic theory and quantitative methods.
ECON 164AW.restriction: Restriction: Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ECON 164C.name: American Economic History from Colonization to the Present
ECON 164C.description: Examines how the American economy evolved from colonization to the post-war era. Topics include relations with foreign countries, the emergence of manufacturing and big business, railroads, slavery, war, the Great Depression, the rise of fiscal and monetary policies.

ECON 165.name: Economics of International Business
ECON 165.description: Students learn to understand and analyze the principal economic issues in the international business arena. Covers topics such as trade theory, foreign direct investment, foreign exchange market, and strategy of international business.

ECON 167.name: International Trade and Commercial Policy
ECON 167.description: Determination of trade flows and the relative prices. Gains from trade, the terms of trade, and income distribution. Imperfect competition and international trade. The effect of tariffs, export subsidies, and import quotas. The effects of free and restricted trade.
ECON 167.restriction: Restriction: Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ECON 169.name: Special Topics in Development Economics
ECON 169.description: Studies in selected areas of Development Economics. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
ECON 169.restriction: Restriction: Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ECON 190.name: Senior Thesis
ECON 190.description: Students work with faculty to complete their honors thesis.

ECON 190BW.name: Economics Honors Colloquium II
ECON 190BW.description: Colloquium required for honors students in Economics, Quantitative Economics, and Business Economics. Introduces students to independent research and helps students plan a research program. Students complete their thesis.
ECON 190BW.prereqString: Prerequisite: ECON H190A. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

ECON H190A.name: Economics Honors Colloquium I
ECON H190A.description: Colloquium required for honors students in economics, quantitative economics, and business economics. Introduces students to independent research. Helps students plan a research program. Prepares students for thesis writing.
ECON H190A.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

ECON 197.name: Field Study
ECON 197.restriction: Restriction: Authorization required or Enrollment by add card only

ECON 198.name: Directed Group Study
ECON 198.restriction: Restriction: Authorization required or Enrollment by add card only

ECON 200A.name: Graduate Colloquium for Economics I
ECON 200A.description: Weekly reports and colloquia by faculty, students, and visitors. Supplemented by class discussion of these presentations and other material on current research methodology.
ECON 200A.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Economics Majors only.

ECON 200B.name: Graduate Colloquium for Economics II
ECON 200B.description: Weekly reports and colloquia by faculty, students, and visitors. Supplemented by class discussion of these presentations and other material on current research methodology.
ECON 200B.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Economics Majors only.

ECON 200C.name: Graduate Colloquium for Economics III
ECON 200C.description: Weekly reports and colloquia by faculty, students, and visitors. Supplemented by class discussion of these presentations and other material on current research methodology.
ECON 200C.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Economics Majors only.

ECON 203A.name: Mathematics for Economists
ECON 203A.description: Gives students the mathematical background required for graduate work in economics. Topics covered include multivariate calculus, differential equations, and linear algebra.

ECON 210A.name: Microeconomic Theory I
ECON 210A.description: Theoretical microeconomics. Emphasis on the meaning and empirical interpretation of theoretical models. Topics include theory of the firm, theory of the market, theory of the consumer, duality theory, application to econometrics, general equilibrium and welfare economics, uncertainty, game theory.

ECON 210B.name: Microeconomic Theory II
ECON 210B.description: Theoretical microeconomics. Emphasis on the meaning and empirical interpretation of theoretical models. Topics include theory of the firm, theory of the market, theory of the consumer, duality theory, application to econometrics, general equilibrium and welfare economics, uncertainty, game theory.

ECON 210C.name: Microeconomic Theory III
ECON 210C.description: Theoretical microeconomics. Emphasis on the meaning and empirical interpretation of theoretical models. Topics include theory of the firm, theory of the market, theory of the consumer, duality theory, application to econometrics, general equilibrium and welfare economics, uncertainty, game theory.

ECON 210D.name: Macroeconomic Theory I
ECON 210D.description: Advanced macroeconomic theory including alternative macroeconomic models, microeconomic foundations of macroeconomics, investment and growth theory, inflation and unemployment, rational expectations and macroeconomic policy, wealth effects, crowding out and fiscal policy, money and interest, open economy models.

ECON 210E.name: Macroeconomic Theory II
ECON 210E.description: Advanced macroeconomic theory including alternative macroeconomic models, microeconomic foundations of macroeconomics, investment and growth theory, inflation and unemployment, rational expectations and macroeconomic policy, wealth effects, crowding out and fiscal policy, money and interest, open economy models.

ECON 210F.name: Macroeconomic Theory III
ECON 210F.description: Advanced macroeconomic theory including alternative macroeconomic models, microeconomic foundations of macroeconomics, investment and growth theory, inflation and unemployment, rational expectations and macroeconomic policy, wealth effects, crowding out and fiscal policy, money and interest, open economy models.

ECON 219.name: Special Topics in Economic Theory
ECON 219.description: Studies in selected areas of Economic Theory. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

ECON 220A.name: Statistics and Econometrics I
ECON 220A.description: Takes up where ECON 202 leaves off. Continuing in the likelihood perspective, begins with Bayesian point estimation and then covers interval estimation and hypothesis testing from both frequentist and Bayesian perspectives.

ECON 220B.name: Statistics and Econometrics II
ECON 220B.description: Begins by relaxing the ideal conditions of the standard regression model. Potential topics include kernel density estimation, instrumental variables (IV), two stage least squares (2SLS), panel data models, and simulation-based Bayesian methods, including Gibbs sampling, and the bootstrap.

ECON 220C.name: Statistics and Econometrics III
ECON 220C.description: Covers econometric time series, discrete choice and count models, sample selection, and duration models along with Bayesian and classical asymptotic methods.

ECON 221A.name: Statistics and Econometrics Laboratory I
ECON 221A.description: Discussion of problems in statistics and econometrics, and their relationships to statistical and econometrics theory. Instruction in the use of computers for applied econometric work.

ECON 221B.name: Statistics and Econometrics Laboratory II
ECON 221B.description: Discussion of problems in statistics and econometrics, and their relationships to statistical and econometrics theory. Instruction in the use of computers for applied econometric work.

ECON 221C.name: Statistics and Econometrics Laboratory III
ECON 221C.description: Discussion of problems in statistics and econometrics, and their relationships to statistical and econometrics theory. Instruction in the use of computers for applied econometric work.

ECON 223A.name: Discrete Choice Econometrics
ECON 223A.description: Specification, estimation, and testing of discrete choice models, with emphasis on cross-sectional and panel data models and applications. Students use computer packages to apply models and techniques to real data.
ECON 223A.prereqString: Prerequisite: ECON 220A and ECON 220B and ECON 220C

ECON 224A.name: Time Series Econometrics
ECON 224A.description: Econometric analysis of time series data. Moving average and autoregressive series, regression analysis, Box-Jenkins techniques, computational methods, and causality conditions.
ECON 224A.prereqString: Prerequisite: ECON 220A and ECON 220B and ECON 220C

ECON 227A.name: Experimental Econ I
ECON 227A.description: An introduction to experimental social science. Students learn experimental methodology, design, and analysis, and be exposed to active research areas. Each student writes a proposal for their own experiment and presents the design in class.

ECON 227B.name: Experimental Econ II
ECON 227B.description: Focuses on implementing experimental projects in a laboratory environment. Subjects learn about human subjects protection, program experimental software for their own projects, and conduct live experiment sessions.

ECON 229.name: Special Topics in Econometrics
ECON 229.description: Studies in selected areas of Econometrics. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

ECON 232.name: Business Cycles in Historical Perspective
ECON 232.description: Investigates business cycles in the United States and worldwide during the last two centuries. Topics include causes and consequences of business fluctuations, monetary and fiscal policy, models of fluctuations, and empirical macroeconomics.
ECON 232.prereqString: Prerequisite: ECON 210A and ECON 210B and ECON 210C and ECON 210D and ECON 210E and ECON 210F

ECON 234.name: American Economic History
ECON 234.description: Focuses on American economic history from colonization onwards. Topics include the development of legal systems, transport systems, financial markets, industrialization, migration, immigration, technological change, and the consequences of slavery.
ECON 234.prereqString: Prerequisite: ECON 210A and ECON 210B and ECON 210C and ECON 210D and ECON 210E and ECON 210F

ECON 239.name: Special Topics in Financial Economics
ECON 239.description: Studies in selected areas of Financial Economics. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

ECON 241A.name: Industrial Organization I
ECON 241A.description: Analysis of the structure and economic performance of markets, and the impact of public policy and their efficiency and equity. Effects of information structure. Oligopoly, cartels, mergers, vertical integration, patents, innovation, antitrust, and regulation.

ECON 241B.name: Industrial Organization II
ECON 241B.description: Analysis of the structure and economic performance of markets, and the impact of public policy and their efficiency and equity. Effects of information structure. Price flexibility and dispersion, auctions, search and industrial structure, intrafirm organization.
ECON 241B.prereqString: Prerequisite: ECON 241A and ECON 100B and ECON 203A

ECON 243A.name: Game Theory
ECON 243A.description: A formal introduction to non-cooperative game theory. Topics include properties of Nash Equilibrium and equilibrium refinements, games with imperfect information, and games with incomplete information.
ECON 243A.prereqString: Prerequisite: ECON 210A and ECON 210B and ECON 210C

ECON 243B.name: Advanced Game Theory
ECON 243B.description: Provides advanced instruction in game theory. The topics covered will be (i) the theory of repeated games and (ii) evolutionary game theory. Applications include bargaining, collusion, reputation, social norms, and the evolution of preferences via natural selection and cultural transmission.

ECON 245.name: Empirical Methods in Applied Microeconomics
ECON 245.description: Focuses on the empirical methods used in modern applied microeconomics. Teaches methods that can be applied to produce original research in applied fields using cross-sectional and panel data. Applications will be drawn heavily from labor, public, health and development economics.

ECON 249.name: Special Topics in Microeconomics
ECON 249.description: Studies in selected areas of Microeconomics. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

ECON 251A.name: Labor Economics I
ECON 251A.description: Analysis of the relationships between education and the labor market (human capital theory), between resources devoted to education and the return to education (the education production function) and between education and labor market inequality (the theory of skill-biased technical change).

ECON 251B.name: Labor Economics II
ECON 251B.description: Analysis of core topics in labor economics, with an emphasis on empirical methods.  Topics may include minimum wages, discrimination, gender, aging and retirement, labor market networks, personnel economics, and employment policy.

ECON 251C.name: Labor Economics III
ECON 251C.description: Discussion of treatment effect/program evaluation in labor economics, emphasizing identification. Classical labor topics, including human capital, technology, wages, labor supply, and migration are discussed in the context of causal inference. A unified framework is used in analyzing identification strategies.

ECON 255.name: Microeconomics and Public Policy
ECON 255.description: Introduces the fundamental principles of microeconomics that are required for applied policy analysis. Provides students with an intuitive understanding of the microeconomic approach, and familiarizes them with concepts used in applied public policy analysis.

ECON 259.name: Special Topics in Labor Economics
ECON 259.description: Studies in selected areas of Labor Economics. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

ECON 260B.name: Monetary Economics II
ECON 260B.description: Surveys recent issues on monetary policy in uncertain environments. Examines settings where both the policy makers and the private sector are uncertain of future outcomes or the underlying economic structure.

ECON 261A.name: International Trade I
ECON 261A.description: Covers theoretical models, empirical methods, and policy issues in international trade. Following the conventional treatment of the Richardian model, the Heckscher-Ohlin model and the specific factors model, new trade models which incorporate scale economics and imperfect competition will be discussed.

ECON 263A.name: Advanced Macroeconomics I
ECON 263A.description: Students build Dynamic Stochastic General Equilibrium (DSGE) macroeconomic models from microeconomic foundations. This approach emphasizes intertemporal optimization by firms and households and typically incorporates nominal rigidities such as sluggish price and/or wage adjustment.

ECON 269.name: Special Topics in Macroeconomics
ECON 269.description: Studies in selected areas of Macroeconomics. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

ECON 270A.name: Political Economy I
ECON 270A.description: Political Economy lies at the intersection of economics and political science. Studies effects of politics on the economy and uses tools derived from economics to understand the behavior of governments and of citizens when they deal with politics.

ECON 270B.name: Political Economy II
ECON 270B.description: Political Economy lies at the intersection of economics and political science. Studies effects of politics on the economy and uses tools derived from economics to understand the behavior of governments and of citizens when they deal with politics.

ECON 270C.name: Political Economy III
ECON 270C.description: Political Economy lies at the intersection of economics and political science. Studies effects of politics on the economy and uses tools derived from economics to understand the behavior of governments and of citizens when they deal with politics.

ECON 271.name: Economics of Criminal Justice
ECON 271.description: Considers empirical research from the economics literature on various topics related to the criminal justice system, such as policing, bail reform, incarceration, or recidivism.

ECON 272A.name: Public Economics I
ECON 272A.description: Covers welfare economics, the theory of optimal taxation, tax incidence, and empirical methods in tax policy. Empirical topics include tax evasion, measurement of incidence, efficiency costs, and other policy issues.
ECON 272A.prereqString: Prerequisite: ECON 210A and ECON 210B and ECON 210C

ECON 272B.name: Public Economics II
ECON 272B.description: Covers the theory of public goods and models of decentralized provision of such goods, including voluntary provision, voting, bureaucratic provision, and preference revelation mechanisms, as well as the Tiebout model. Also covers externalities, cost-benefit analysis, and intergovernmental competition.
ECON 272B.prereqString: Prerequisite: ECON 210A and ECON 210B and ECON 210C

ECON 272C.name: Public Economics III
ECON 272C.description: Covers the rationale for and effects of government intervention in insurance markets and for redistribution. Includes theoretical and empirical analyses of cash and in-kind assistance programs, unemployment insurance, disability insurance, Social Security, and other programs.
ECON 272C.prereqString: Prerequisite: ECON 210A and ECON 210B and ECON 210C

ECON 275.name: Economics of Government
ECON 275.description: Prepares students to analyze public policy questions with tools from economics. By the end, students should be able to identify important economic issues in public policy debates and consume and critique economic research on these topics.

ECON 279.name: Special Topics in Political Economy
ECON 279.description: Studies in selected areas of Political Economy. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

ECON 281A.name: Urban Economics I
ECON 281A.description: Economic reasons for the existence of cities, analysis of urban spatial structure, urban sprawl, Third World urbanization, hedonic price analysis, housing tenure choice.

ECON 281B.name: Urban Economics II
ECON 281B.description: Housing in the portfolio, land-use controls, rent control, homelessness, neighborhood effects, urban quality-of-life measurement, and subcenters.

ECON 282A.name: Transportation Economics I
ECON 282A.description: Applies microeconomic concepts of demand, costs, pricing, investment, and project evaluation to analyze transportation activities. Empirical studies include travel demand using discrete models, and cost functions.

ECON 282B.name: Transportation Economics II
ECON 282B.description: Economics of the airline industry. Hub-and-spoke networks, the effects of competition on airfares, price dispersion, airline alliances, airport congestion, product unbundling.

ECPS 202.name: Cyber-Physical Systems Design
ECPS 202.description: Requirements and specification, MoCs, tools, design, merging cyber and physical, manufacturing, examples (robots, energy house, self-driving car, pacemaker, etc.). Design process, specification, requirements, modeling, components, selection, interfaces, system structure, different levels, verification, testing.

ECPS 203.name: Embedded Systems Modeling and Design
ECPS 203.description: Embedded Systems definition, specification, and languages. Concepts, requirements, examples. Embedded system models at different abstraction levels. Test benches, design under test, Intellectual Property components. Discrete event simulation, semantics, algorithms. Design, analysis techniques for decentralized computer architectures, communication, and hardware-software systems.

ECPS 204.name: Embedded System Software
ECPS 204.description: Embedded system software concepts, requirements, examples, for engineering applications such as multimedia and automotive. Software methodology. Specification, design constraints. Embedded operating systems. Input/output, interrupt handling. Code generation, compilation, instruction set simulation. Distributed object model, distributed environment, platform-independent software agents, components.

ECPS 205.name: Sensors, Actuators and Sensor Networks
ECPS 205.description: Fundamental principles and applications of sensors, actuators. Smart sensors and microsensor/microactuator array devices. Introduction to signal processing and sensor/actuator networks, deployment and architecture, wireless communication, multiple access control layer, data gathering, routing and querying, collaborating signal processing.

ECPS 206.name: Real-Time and Distributed Systems
ECPS 206.description: Time dependent systems, clock synchronization, real-time communication protocols, specification of requirements, task scheduling. Validation of timelines, real-time configuration management. Middleware architecture for distributed real-time and secure services.

ECPS 207.name: Security and Privacy in Cyber-Physical Systems
ECPS 207.description: ES and CPS security: attacks and countermeasures, authentication, identification, confidentiality, data integrity, authorization, access control, malware attacks and counter-measures, security protocols. Privacy issues e.g., vehicular devices and smart metering. Applications of public key and symmetric cryptography, e.g., digital certificates, credentials.

ECPS 208.name: Control Systems for Cyber-Physical Systems
ECPS 208.description: State space representation (continuous and discrete), principles of optimization, model predictive control, robustness to actuation or communications limitations, control of networked systems, multi-agent co-operation and control.

ECPS 209.name: Cyber-Physical Systems Case Studies
ECPS 209.description: Covers CPS case studies in applications such as (but not limited to): automotive and transportation, manufacturing, power distribution grid, medical and healthcare, robotics, civil infrastructure, avionics.

ECPS 210.name: Cyber-Physical Systems Project
ECPS 210.description: Students are required to complete a project that deals with a specific emphasis of Cyber-Physical Systems, such as (but not limited to): automotive, transportation, manufacturing, power grid, medical healthcare, robotics, civil infrastructure, avionics.
ECPS 210.prereqString: Prerequisite: ECPS 202 and ECPS 204 and ECPS 209

ECPS 211.name: Machine Learning and Data Mining
ECPS 211.description: Introduction to principles of machine learning and data-mining.  Learning algorithms for classifications, regression, and clustering.  Emphasis is on discriminative classification methods such as decision trees, rules, nearest neighbor, linear models, and naive Bayes.

ECPS 212.name: Entrepreneurship for Scientists and Engineers
ECPS 212.description: Real-world introduction to the theory and practice of entrepreneurship. Explores organizational, strategic, and financial challenges

ECPS 299.name: Individual Research
ECPS 299.description: Individual research or investigation under the direction of an individual faculty member.

EDUC 10.name: Educational Research Design
EDUC 10.description: Designed to help students become intelligent consumers of research and independent researchers, and provides an introduction to the basic principles of educational research. Topics include research questions, literature reviews, and qualitative and quantitative research designs.
EDUC 10.restriction: Restriction: Education Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EDUC 15.name: Statistics for Education Research
EDUC 15.description: Provides an introduction to the use of statistics in educational research. Focuses on testing and measurement, and provides basic tools to read, interpret, and draw conclusions from quantitative educational research.
EDUC 15.restriction: Restriction: Education Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EDUC 25.name: Introduction to Education: Disciplinary Perspectives
EDUC 25.description: Provides insights into educational organizations and processes by developing understanding of concepts used by four different disciplines (economics, history, psychology, and sociology) to analyze key issues and phenomenon in the field of education that profoundly influence individual life course outcomes.
EDUC 25.restriction: Restriction: Education Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EDUC 30.name: 21st Century Literacies
EDUC 30.description: Provides an overview of literacies required for academic and career success in the 21st century. Issues addressed include reading, writing, academic language, research skills, media and technology skills, scientific literacy, critical thinking, communication, collaboration, and creativity.
EDUC 30.restriction: Restriction: Education Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EDUC 40.name: Theories of Development and Learning Applied to Education
EDUC 40.description: Provides an introductory examination of central theories of human development and learning in their application to contemporary educational settings.
EDUC 40.restriction: Restriction: Education Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EDUC 50.name: Origins, Purposes, and Central Issues in K-12 Education
EDUC 50.description: An introduction to the role of education in U.S. society and to central issues in K–12 education. Education is studied from four different perspectives: social, historical, philosophical, and political.
EDUC 50.restriction: Restriction: Education Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EDUC 52.name: Foundations of Bilingual Education and Bilingualism
EDUC 52.description: Provides a comprehensive overview of current issues in bilingual education and bilingualism. Topics include dimensions of bilingualism, the effects of bilingualism on children's linguistic and cognitive development, bilingual education programs, literacy, special needs, and assessment.

EDUC 55.name: Knowing and Learning in Mathematics and Science
EDUC 55.description: Multidisciplinary study of knowing and learning in secondary school mathematics and science. Topics include standards for knowing, scientific epistemologies, mental representations, problem solving, expert-novice studies, assessment, and domain-specific thinking, learning, and teaching. Applied analysis of learning through clinical interviews.

EDUC 100.name: Educational Strategies for Tutoring and Teacher Aiding
EDUC 100.description: Placement in a public elementary or secondary school to gain experience as a tutor or teacher aide. Emphasis on cognitive learning and the development of instructional strategies and resources which can be used in effective cross-age and cross-cultural experiences.
EDUC 100.restriction: Restriction: Education Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EDUC 101.name: Strategies for Tutoring and Teacher Aiding in a Bilingual Classroom
EDUC 101.description: Placement in a dual immersion school setting to gain experience as a bilingual (Spanish) tutor or teacher aide. Emphasis on cognitive learning and the development of instructional strategies and resources which can be used in effective cross-age and cross-cultural experiences.
EDUC 101.prereqString: Prerequisite: Must be able to communicate in Spanish.
EDUC 101.restriction: Restriction: Education Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EDUC 104D.name: The Arts and Human Development
EDUC 104D.description: Students use various arts disciplines (e.g. studio art, music, dance, drama, and media arts) to investigate how visual and performing arts support individual human development. Introduction to pedagogy for integrating the arts in K-12 settings. Materials fee.
EDUC 104D.restriction: Restriction: Education Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EDUC 104E.name: Multimedia and the Arts in the Multicultural Classroom
EDUC 104E.description: Multiculturalism and under-represented U.S. minorities and the visual and performing arts: perspectives in artistic perception, creative expression, historical and cultural context, aesthetic valuing, and media literacy in the interpretation and production of multimedia arts products and applications for K-12 classrooms.
EDUC 104E.restriction: Restriction: Education Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EDUC 106.name: Early Childhood Education Curriculum and Instruction
EDUC 106.description: Designed to provide an introductory survey of the nature, needs, and education of young children. Explores questions such as "What should we teach young children?" and "How should we teach?".
EDUC 106.restriction: Restriction: Education Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EDUC 107.name: Child Development in Education
EDUC 107.description: Explores the pathways of normally developing children's growth and change over time. In particular, focuses on how cognitive and social development impact and are driven by educational contexts.
EDUC 107.restriction: Restriction: Education Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EDUC 108.name: Adolescent Development and Education
EDUC 108.description: Explores the physical, cognitive, emotional, and social development of adolescents, with an emphasis on the practical implications of developmental theory and research findings for teachers and other professionals who work with adolescents in middle or high school contexts.
EDUC 108.restriction: Restriction: Education Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EDUC 109.name: Reading and Writing in Mathematics and Science
EDUC 109.description: Emphasis is placed on understanding the literacy processes (listening, speaking, viewing, thinking, reading, and writing) as they relate to middle and high school mathematics and science. Students integrate literacy-related strategies with curriculum-based goals supported in the California State Frameworks.

EDUC 120A.name: Introduction to Positive Psychology in Education
EDUC 120A.description: Positive psychology is a recent focus area within the field of psychology that explores what is positive, creative, and fulfilling in human behavior. It is the scientific study of well-being and flourishing.
EDUC 120A.restriction: Restriction: Education Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EDUC 122A.name: Foundations of Elementary Mathematics Learning I
EDUC 122A.description: Provides understanding of fundamental mathematics necessary to teach for conceptual understanding and higher-level reasoning and problem solving. Conceptual understanding of place value, fractions, proportionality, geometry, algebra, functions, probability, statistics, and measurement. Instructional applications of these concepts in grades K-8 teaching.
EDUC 122A.restriction: Restriction: Education Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EDUC 122B.name: Foundations of Elementary Mathematics Learning II
EDUC 122B.description: Provides understanding of fundamental mathematics necessary to teach for conceptual understanding and higher-level reasoning and problem solving. Conceptual understanding of place value, fractions, proportionality, geometry, algebra, functions, probability, statistics, and measurement. Instructional applications of these concepts in grades K-8 teaching.
EDUC 122B.restriction: Restriction: Education Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EDUC 122C.name: Foundations of Elementary Mathematics Learning III
EDUC 122C.description: Provides understanding of fundamental mathematics necessary to teach for conceptual understanding and higher-level reasoning and problem solving. Conceptual understanding of place value, fractions, proportionality, geometry, algebra, functions, probability, statistics, and measurement. Instructional applications of these concepts in grades K-8 teaching.
EDUC 122C.restriction: Restriction: Education Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EDUC 124.name: Multicultural Education in K-12 Schools
EDUC 124.description: Provides a theoretical and empirical overview of educational issues affecting low-income immigrant and U.S. born minority student populations in an increasingly diverse and changing society.

EDUC 125.name: Children, Schools, and Cinema
EDUC 125.description: Through popular films, analyzes aspects of school dynamics and interaction of schools with students, teachers, and public.  Melding educational studies and film studies provides deeper understanding of methods used to transmit information and attitudes about schools to the lay public.
EDUC 125.restriction: Restriction: Education Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EDUC 126.name: Ethics and Education
EDUC 126.description: Ethics in education and how ethicists frame moral problems.  Presents major ethical themes that affect education.   Analysis of models for dealing with ethical goals and developing morality for K–12 students.  Models for solving ethical dilemmas within an educational context.

EDUC 127A.name: Moral Education for Youth Development I
EDUC 127A.description: The first of a two-course series that examines research-based theories for how school settings and adult mentors contribute to the moral development of adolescents. Students examine theory in the context of real-world application in four program observations.

EDUC 127B.name: Moral Education for Youth Development II
EDUC 127B.description: Continuation of EDUC 127A. Allows students from 127A to experience the role of adults in the moral development of youth. Students receive training to deliver curriculum and apply research-based theories and methods in real-world youth settings.
EDUC 127B.restriction: Restriction: Education Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EDUC 128.name: Exceptional Learners
EDUC 128.description: An introductory survey of the nature, needs, and education of K–12 children with exceptionalities. Covers the categories and characteristics of exceptionalities, relevant state and federal legislation, and the role of general education teachers in special education.
EDUC 128.restriction: Restriction: Education Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EDUC 130.name: Children's Learning and Media
EDUC 130.description: Examines how popular media may impact how young people learn, develop, and communicate by looking at research related to the impacts of a wide range of popular media including television, video games, digital environments, mobile devices, and other multimedia.
EDUC 130.restriction: Restriction: Education Sciences Majors only. Informatics Majors only. Informatics Minors only.

EDUC 131.name: Educational Technology
EDUC 131.description: Presents an overview of the types and uses of educational technology to support and enhance the K–12 learning experience. Familiarizes students with lesson planning, instructional design, learning theory, and integrating technology into the curriculum.
EDUC 131.restriction: Restriction: Education Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EDUC 132.name: Reading and Writing Enrichment for After-School Programs
EDUC 132.description: Examines literacy development and the implementation of research-based practices to enrich learners' reading and writing skills in after-school programs. A minimum of 20 hours of after-school program fieldwork is required in order to design and implement literacy enrichment activities.
EDUC 132.restriction: Restriction: Education Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EDUC 134.name: Teaching English Internationally
EDUC 134.description: Covers methods of teaching English as a foreign language, basic language knowledge for English teachers, the social context of English language teaching around the world, and essential information about securing international employment as an English teacher.
EDUC 134.restriction: Restriction: Education Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EDUC 137.name: Arts for Elementary Learners
EDUC 137.description: Theory and practice in art education for the elementary school classroom. Includes content and pedagogy for future teachers and others interested in the relationship between child development and the production of visual art. Materials fee.
EDUC 137.restriction: Restriction: Education Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EDUC 138.name: Children's Literature in the Elementary Classroom
EDUC 138.description: Explores the wealth of children's literature that can be integrated into the elementary classroom. Surveys traditional literature, fiction, nonfiction, and poetry that make curriculum accessible to all students. Focuses on literary elements for both reading and creating text.
EDUC 138.restriction: Restriction: Education Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EDUC 140.name: Courts, Classrooms, and Controversies in Education Policy
EDUC 140.description: Examines policies and laws defining the K-12 U.S. education system and the politics and controversies surrounding the political decision-making process at the federal, state, and local levels. Discusses original intent versus effects on organization of schools and educational equity.
EDUC 140.restriction: Restriction: Education Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EDUC 142.name: American History and Education Policy: An Intimate Relationship
EDUC 142.description: Examines the interplay between history, politics, and policy. Students examine the interactions between sociopolitical development and environmental contexts (e.g. familial, social, school, cultural) and contemplate the power of normative values in the formulation of education policy.
EDUC 142.restriction: Restriction: Education Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EDUC 143.name: Controversies in College
EDUC 143.description: Explores the fascinating world of postsecondary education. Every week students dive deeper into controversies that make college more than just where students attend class, but rather, one of the most important social institutions shaping our world.
EDUC 143.restriction: Restriction: Education Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EDUC 143AW.name: Classroom Interactions I
EDUC 143AW.description: Focuses on research-based instructional strategies for enhancing the learning of secondary mathematics and science. Students learn about adolescent and second-language development to assist them in developing analyzing, teaching, and critiquing lessons for secondary classrooms.
EDUC 143AW.prereqString: Prerequisite: (PS 105 or BIOL 101) and EDUC 55. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

EDUC 143BW.name: Classroom Interactions II
EDUC 143BW.description: Focuses on equity and multicultural education research, special education, and research-based instructional and assessment strategies to assist students in designing, teaching, and assessing lessons that meet the needs of all secondary mathematics and science students.
EDUC 143BW.prereqString: Prerequisite: (PS 105 or BIOL 101) and EDUC 55 and EDUC 143AW and EDUC 148. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

EDUC 144.name: The American Charter School
EDUC 144.description: Explores the legitimacy of the charter school as a viable educational reform movement. Critical themes include the role of choice and privatization in public education and charter schools as a vehicle for fulfilling the promise of educational equality.
EDUC 144.restriction: Restriction: Education Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EDUC 145.name: Theories and Pedagogies of Race in Education
EDUC 145.description: Introduces theoretical frameworks to examine the role of race in American education. Emphasis is placed on introducing students to different race and ethnicity paradigms.
EDUC 145.restriction: Restriction: Education Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EDUC 146.name: Education, Learning, and Culture
EDUC 146.description: Exploration of learning and development through a cultural lens, drawing from a range of research traditions and disciplines to broaden understandings of theories that inform teaching and learning in formal and informal settings.

EDUC 147.name: Poverty, Education, and Social Change
EDUC 147.description: Explores how institutional and demographic changes in the U.S. have shaped disparities in education, the mechanisms through which poverty and social class influence families, and students, and promising programs and interventions to address inequity. Includes community service.
EDUC 147.restriction: Restriction: Education Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EDUC 148.name: Complex Pedagogical Design
EDUC 148.description: In this Cal Teach capstone course, students design lesson plans and complex instructional units, using approaches such as mathematics and science integration, problem-based instruction, project-based learning, technology, representations, scientific and mathematical analysis/modeling, authentic assessment, contextualization, and designing equitable learning environments.
EDUC 148.prereqString: Prerequisite: (PS 105 or BIOL 101) and EDUC 55 and EDUC 143AW

EDUC 149.name: Family, School, and Community in Early Childhood
EDUC 149.description: Focuses on the many socializing aspects of young children's social worlds. Through the use of ecological perspectives, explores the role of families, schools, and communities on children's social development, especially in early childhood.
EDUC 149.restriction: Restriction: Education Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EDUC 150.name: Changing the High School Experience
EDUC 150.description: Analysis of problems in high school education (e.g., student disengagement and underachievement of disadvantaged) and proposals for changing curriculum, instruction, and school organization. Students suggest own reforms and analyze effective/ineffective school practices.
EDUC 150.restriction: Restriction: Education Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EDUC 151.name: Language and Literacy
EDUC 151.description: Addresses the linguistic principles and processes that underlie oral and written language proficiency. Emphasis is on how to use phonology, morphology, orthography, semantics, syntax, and pragmatics to support literacy and oral language development for K-12 students.
EDUC 151.restriction: Restriction: Language Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Education Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EDUC 152.name: Theory and Practice of Reading Interventions for Students At-Risk for Reading Failure
EDUC 152.description: Examines the research concerning reading failure in young children and interventions used to support them. Topics include reading development and reading intervention. Students critically evaluate the relation between their fieldwork experience and the research and evaluation literature.

EDUC 154.name: Latino Families and Youth
EDUC 154.description: Current issues in theory, methods, and research in U.S. Latino/a youth and families are examined. An advanced level study, with a particular focus on history, theories, methods, research, and applied social issues.
EDUC 154.restriction: Restriction: Education Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EDUC 156.name: Introduction to Field Methods in Education
EDUC 156.description: Introduces students to methods for studying human behavior in context. It prepares students for conducting applied educational research, including designing needs assessments
EDUC 156.restriction: Restriction: Education Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EDUC 157.name: Educational Research and Evaluation
EDUC 157.description: Covers qualitative and quantitative research methods relevant for the evaluation of educational programs. Students have the opportunity to plan, execute, and write-up a small evaluation project.
EDUC 157.restriction: Restriction: Education Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EDUC 158.name: Student Teaching Mathematics and Science in Middle/High School
EDUC 158.description: Student teaching includes orientation, seminars, preparation, and assumption of secondary school classroom instructional responsibilities in accordance with State credentialing requirements and in conjunction with the public school calendar. Five days/week and a minimum four hours/day over two quarters.
EDUC 158.prereqString:
Corequisite: EDUC 109
Prerequisite: (PS 105 or BIOL 101) and EDUC 55 and EDUC 143AW and EDUC 143BW and EDUC 148

EDUC 159.name: Experimental Research Methods
EDUC 159.description: Designed to help students to develop the ability to think critically about research, and to develop an understanding of how to design and conduct experiments. The overall goal is to prepare students to independently plan and implement a research study.
