EDUC 159.restriction: Restriction: Education Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EDUC 160.name: Foundations of Out-of-School Learning
EDUC 160.description: Provides an overview of child and adolescent learning through participation in out-of-school activities and settings. Recognizes the importance of matching out-of-school experiences with the interests, needs, and development level of students. Observation-based fieldwork included.
EDUC 160.restriction: Restriction: Education Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. May be taken a second time if student is a candidate for Certificate in After-School Education, and the first time was prior to Fall 2008.

EDUC 161.name: Discovering Science in Out-of-School Hours
EDUC 161.description: Examines the design principles and teaching techniques that science museums and other out-of-school science programs use to motivate children and youth to learn science through discovery. Includes field experience at a science learning center or after-school program. Materials fee.
EDUC 161.restriction: Restriction: Education Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EDUC 170.name: Chicanx/Latinx Education
EDUC 170.description: Provides a historical and empirical overview of educational issues affecting diverse Latinx low-income, immigrant, and U.S. born student populations enrolled in American schools. Examines policies and issues such as DACA, generation, culture, racism, and gender on educational mobility.

EDUC 173.name: Cognition and Learning in Educational Settings
EDUC 173.description: Foundational concepts in cognition and development as applied to student learning. Primary topics include historical behaviorism, basic cognitive structure and processes, complex cognition, cognitive development, and motivation.
EDUC 173.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Education Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EDUC 174.name: Education and the American Dream: Historical Perspectives on Democracy and Education
EDUC 174.description: Examines the relationship between public schooling and the promotion of democratic ideals in American society over the past two centuries.

EDUC 175.name: Foundations of Education
EDUC 175.description: Foundational questions of education are viewed from newly emerging developmental perspectives which treat cognition as embodied action and learning as cultural recapitulation. Historical, sociological, psychological, and philosophical implications of views toward aspects of teaching, learning, curriculum, and pedagogy are considered.

EDUC 176.name: Psychology of Learning, Abilities, and Intelligence
EDUC 176.description: Overview of classic positions on the mind, human abilities, and intelligence, especially as related to academic achievement. Contrasting views: psychometric versus information processing
EDUC 176.prereqString: Prerequisite: PSYC 7A or PSCI 9 or PSCI 11A or PSCI 11B or PSCI 11C
EDUC 176.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Education Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EDUC 179W.name: Advanced Writing for Education Sciences
EDUC 179W.description: Writing for multiple audiences and purposes about central concepts in education sciences, such as schools as organizations
EDUC 179W.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
EDUC 179W.restriction: Restriction: Seniors only. Education Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EDUC 180.name: Interdisciplinary Topics in Education
EDUC 180.description: Analysis of issues in education from interdisciplinary perspectives. Topics covered vary with interests of instructor.
EDUC 180.restriction: Restriction: Education Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EDUC 181A.name: Principles and Practices of Coaching Sports I
EDUC 181A.description: Focuses on foundational theories and instructional practices in coaching sports from fourth grade to the collegiate level. Prepares students for the coach's mandatory state certification examination for high school sports in California.
EDUC 181A.restriction: Restriction: Education Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EDUC 185.name: Social Development in Education
EDUC 185.description: Examination of contextual, psychosocial, and biological factors contributing to the social development of children and adolescents. Theoretical perspectives, empirical findings, and methodological issues are emphasized. Implications of the scientific evidence for practical and policy decision-making surrounding development are discussed.
EDUC 185.restriction: Restriction: Education Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EDUC 190.name: Principles and Practices of K–6 After School Sports and Fitness
EDUC 190.description: Focuses on foundational theories and instructional practices in after-school sports and fitness for K–6 students. Includes a 20-hour field experience in an after-school setting.
EDUC 190.restriction: Restriction: Education Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EDUC 191.name: Advanced Fieldwork in After-School Education
EDUC 191.description: Capstone fieldwork experience for students seeking to earn the Department of Education-sponsored Certificate in After-School Education. Students are required to complete 50 or more hours of fieldwork and related assignments at an instructor-approved after-school program.
EDUC 191.restriction: Restriction: Education Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EDUC 193.name: Directed Studies in Early Childhood Education
EDUC 193.description: Advanced study of early childhood education under the direction of a faculty member, coupled with a community-based practicum.
EDUC 193.restriction: Restriction: Education Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EDUC 198.name: Directed Research in Education
EDUC 198.description: Individually or in small groups, students are exposed to or participate in work related to a faculty member's research. Students also attend a weekly seminar and complete a research paper or comparable project.
EDUC 198.restriction: Restriction: Sophomores only. Upper-division students only.

EDUC 199.name: Individual Study
EDUC 199.description: Intensified advanced study in areas in which a student has considerable background, under the direction of a faculty member who will guide and evaluate the study.

EDUC 202.name: Outcomes of Schooling/Student Assessment
EDUC 202.description: Focuses on establishment of learning goals and assessment tools that are valid for all students, inform educational decisions, and promote educational success. Provides critical examination of different forms of assessment used in K–12 schools, including developmental assessments and appropriate interventions.
EDUC 202.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Education-MA/PhD Majors only.

EDUC 206.name: Design of Learning Environments for Teachers in Secondary School Subjects
EDUC 206.description: Research on comprehension, conceptual understanding, reasoning, critical thinking, and problem solving with applications to pedagogy in secondary school subjects. Required for M.A.T. single subject students, unless substitution of Education 207 is authorized.

EDUC 208.name: Reading and Writing Development
EDUC 208.description: Covers major theories and evidence about mechanisms and factors that contribute to development and difficulties with reading and writing skills. These include language, cognition, biological and environmental factors, bilingual and second language acquisition, and educational implications.

EDUC 211.name: Writing Theory and Practice
EDUC 211.description: Offers an overview of histories, theories, and research in the field of composition studies from 1950 to the present. Addresses the influences of theory and research on teaching practice at K–12 and college levels.

EDUC 212.name: Literacy and Technology
EDUC 212.description: Examines theoretical, historical, and contemporary relationships of technology and literacy. Topics include online communication, multimodality, video games, the use of technology for literacy instruction in schools, and research approaches for investigating literacy development with technology.

EDUC 217.name: Foundations of Digital Learning
EDUC 217.description: Students are introduced to historical, constructionist, instructionist, and new literacies perspectives through reading major works in educational technology and discussing how they apply to both teaching and research.

EDUC 218.name: Special Topics in Teaching, Learning, and Educational Improvement
EDUC 218.description: Advanced seminar designed to engage students in highly interactive examination of current issues in teaching and learning. Topics and content vary by quarter, depending upon research interests of the faculty and students.

EDUC 220.name: Developing Adolescent Literacy
EDUC 220.description: Examines how adolescents leverage vocabulary knowledge, word-reading skills, background understanding, and knowledge of content-specific text features to master an increasing range of texts both independently and for subject-area learning.

EDUC 221.name: Longitudinal and Advanced Structural Equation Modeling
EDUC 221.description: Covers advanced and longitudinal structural equation models. Topics include measurement invariance, growth curve models, measurement models, mixture models, and missing data.

EDUC 222.name: Research Epistemologies and Methodologies
EDUC 222.description: Introduction to epistemological underpinnings of educational research and to a range of research methodologies in education. Includes examination of quantitative and qualitative studies through reading and analyzing contemporary research. Critique of selected research studies pertinent to educational practice and policy.

EDUC 223.name: Oral Language Acquisition and Education
EDUC 223.description: Learn about research on domains of development in oral language (phonology, vocabulary, grammar, and extended discourse), bilingual development, and second language acquisition with attention to cognitive, biological, and environmental factors. Focus on learning in school settings and educational implications.

EDUC 224.name: Special Topics in Educational Research Methods
EDUC 224.description: An advanced seminar focused on innovative educational research methods and analytic techniques. Topics and content vary by quarter, depending upon the research interests of the faculty and students.

EDUC 224A.name: Learning Analytics Fundamentals
EDUC 224A.description: Provides students with a survey of learning analytics (LA), emphasizing its application across educational contexts, rather than its underlying algorithmic details. A comprehensive overview orients students to this nascent field and prepares them for advanced research in LA.

EDUC 224B.name: Learning Analytics Practicum
EDUC 224B.description: Helps students gain hands-on experience working as educational data scientists, while simultaneously learning some of the key guiding principles behind effectively using data to make predictions and decisions. Culminates in an interdisciplinary group research project.

EDUC 225.name: Learning, Development, and Culture
EDUC 225.description: Explores issues of learning and development through a cultural lens. The interplay between culture and learning and culture and development is analyzed through the discussion of relevant readings from both psychological and anthropological research traditions.

EDUC 226.name: University Teaching: Concepts and Practices
EDUC 226.description: Prepares doctoral students for course design and instruction at the university level. Addresses topics including the university teaching context, preparing a syllabus, and inclusive teaching and learning.

EDUC 228.name: Science Education for the 21st-Century Classroom
EDUC 228.description: Aims to develop foundational understanding about science education research. Contemporary research from early childhood through high school is introduced. Issues of equity, social justice, pedagogy, professional development, and innovation in and out of school settings are addressed.

EDUC 229.name: Theories of Human Development
EDUC 229.description: Examines developmental theory as a guide for research and practice in education. The evolution of classical development theories and the emergence of new theoretical models are considered. Theoretical perspectives include ecological systems, life course, psychobiology, attachment, and social-cognitive theories.

EDUC 229A.name: Theories and Issues in Human Development - Part I
EDUC 229A.description: Examines seminal concepts, issues, and theories that underlie contemporary developmental science. Students develop an understanding of these concepts, and develop their skills in using theory as a guide in their own research and practice.

EDUC 230.name: The History and Culture of Schooling in the United States
EDUC 230.description: Considers the historical, cultural, and structural processes that contextualize American schooling. In particular, examines the roles of race, class, and gender in the context of public education in the United States.
EDUC 230.restriction: Restriction: Master of Arts in Teaching Degree students only.

EDUC 231.name: Interrogating Race and Education
EDUC 231.description: Critically explores how race is a socially constructed concept and how it manifests itself in American society. Attention is given to African American, Asian, and Mexican communities throughout U.S. history, with particular emphasis on educational inequality.

EDUC 232.name: Mathematics Cognition and Learning
EDUC 232.description: Study of mathematical cognition, learning, and development. Combines readings from cognitive and developmental psychology, education, and learning sciences with the purpose of identifying the most useful applications of cognitive theory and methods for educational research and practice.

EDUC 233A.name: Special Topics in Atypical Development
EDUC 233A.description: Includes advanced examination of current issues in theories of atypical development, assessment, and intervention as applied to special needs. Understanding physical and/or cognitive mechanisms of child development and disorders. Knowledge and skills for areas of disability.

EDUC 234.name: Measurement and Psychometrics
EDUC 234.description: Focuses on appraisal and development of measures, measurement theory, and its application using a classical test theory approach. Topics include scaling, construction, reliability and validity assessment, and item analysis

EDUC 236.name: Applied Linguistics and Literacy
EDUC 236.description: Examines research in applied linguistics as related to teaching literacy. Overview of language knowledge required to understand development and instruction of literacy.  Topics include English language structures, psychological processing of these structures, and methodologies to study language and literacy.

EDUC 237.name: Foundations of Teaching and Learning
EDUC 237.description: Situates learning in relation to teaching, content, and context. Locates the work of teaching and learning as a cultural practice and considers the limitations of existing theories for advancing learning opportunities for historically under-served and under-resourced communities.

EDUC 238.name: Special Topics in Human Development in Context
EDUC 238.description: An advanced seminar designed to engage students in highly interactive examination of current issues in human development. Topics and content vary by quarter, depending upon the research interests of the faculty and students.

EDUC 239.name: Cognitive Neuroscience and Human Development
EDUC 239.description: Focuses on the latest empirical work at the intersection of neuroscience, cognitive psychology, developmental science, and educational practice

EDUC 241.name: Children’s Sense Making in Science
EDUC 241.description: Investigates elementary students as individuals who construct understanding of concepts through their interactions with others and the world around them. Observations of children in informal settings to analyze learning in context.
EDUC 241.restriction: Restriction: Master of Arts in Teaching Degree students only.

EDUC 243.name: The Policy Environment of Teaching
EDUC 243.description: Examines research and public perceptions about school-based educational processes, the influence of institutional structures and educational policy on the lives of teachers, and the challenges of school reform at the local and classroom levels.
EDUC 243.restriction: Restriction: Master of Arts in Teaching Degree students only.

EDUC 245.name: Learning Inside and Outside of School
EDUC 245.description: A field-based course focused on observing adolescents in out-of-school contexts to examine adolescent learning and development in a range of contexts, how out-of-school contexts motivate learning and development, and consider the implications for teaching.
EDUC 245.restriction: Restriction: Master of Arts in Teaching Degree students only.

EDUC 246.name: Teaching Investigations: Identifying Dilemmas of Practice
EDUC 246.description: Focuses on identifying problems of teaching practice that arise in student teaching, examining the theoretical foundations that underlie problems of practice, and developing approaches for inquiring into strategies to systematically address instructional challenges.
EDUC 246.restriction: Restriction: Master of Arts in Teaching Degree students only.

EDUC 247.name: Teaching Investigations: Exploring Dilemmas of Practice
EDUC 247.description: Focuses on exploring problems of teaching practice that arise in student teaching, drawing on research to examine the theoretical foundations that underlie problems of practice, and to propose courses of action to address and study educational interventions.
EDUC 247.restriction: Restriction: Master of Arts in Teaching Degree students only.

EDUC 248.name: Understanding Teacher Agency
EDUC 248.description: Considers how teachers can become agents of change within their school contexts, through their participation in professional organizations and via social media. Candidates experiment with using different avenues for sharing images of practice and action research.
EDUC 248.restriction: Restriction: Master of Arts in Teaching Degree students only.

EDUC 250.name: Research Practice Partnerships
EDUC 250.description: An introduction to research-practice partnerships (RPPs). It examines the distinctive characteristics of this approach to education improvement by discussing examples of established partnerships and inviting students to become familiar with methods and tools to advance RPP work.

EDUC 251.name: Educational Policy and Politics
EDUC 251.description: An in-depth study of topics relevant to educational reform and policy-making. Topics include: the policy-making process, the role of values and interest groups, policy analysis, equality of educational opportunity, systemic reform, implementation, and politics at the school site.

EDUC 252.name: Social Organization of Schools and Classrooms
EDUC 252.description: Examines how schools are organizations with ambiguous goals, faced with challenges around effective leadership and cooperation, part of loosely coupled systems, and subject to coercive, normative, and mimemtic pressures from organizational environments, shaping institutional practices and structures.

EDUC 253.name: Foundations of Educational Policy
EDUC 253.description: Reviews disciplinary models that economists and sociologists employ in approaching education-related policy issues, including markets as emergent systems, human capital, social and cultural capital, and rational choice and institutional models of administrators and teachers.

EDUC 254.name: College Access and Persistence
EDUC 254.description: Introduction to how social, political, and economic forces impact college access and persistence in the U.S. higher education system. Investigates historical perspectives and theoretical underpinnings of college access and retention research and the link between K–12 schooling and postsecondary stratification.

EDUC 255.name: Immigration and the New Second Generation
EDUC 255.description: Focuses on Asian, Latino, and Black children of immigrants. Investigates how today's second generation adapts, incorporates into the U.S. social structure, transforms the social and economic landscape. Explores assimilation, immigrant families/communities, language, racial/ethnic identities, gender, education, changing U.S. racial structure.

EDUC 258.name: Special Topics in Educational Policy and Social Context
EDUC 258.description: An advanced seminar designed to engage students in highly interactive examination of current issues in educational policy and social context. Topics and content will vary by quarter, depending upon the research interests of the faculty and students.

EDUC 259.name: Community Research and Action
EDUC 259.description: Introduces the theoretical underpinnings and research approaches of the field of Community Psychology. Project-based course focused on research and action in communities, organizations, and other extra-individual units (e.g., schools).

EDUC 260.name: The Arts, Human Development, and Social Context
EDUC 260.description: Examines the state of empirical knowledge on the impact of visual and performing arts education on the development of academic, communication, and social-emotional skills. The role of the arts in forming personal and cultural identity is discussed.

EDUC 261.name: Social and Cultural Foundations of Education
EDUC 261.description: Provides a critical understanding of the social and cultural foundations of education through reproduction theory. Explores the unique ways in which culture and power intersect within schools and schooling systems to reproduce and resist educational inequality.

EDUC 264.name: Economic Foundations of Education and Social Policy
EDUC 264.description: Beginning/intermediate microeconomics course provides students with an introduction to how economists think about household decision-making, markets, benefit-cost analysis, social policy issues in general and education policy in particular.

EDUC 265.name: Applied Regression Analysis for Education and Social Scientific Research
EDUC 265.description: Provides students with a working knowledge of multiple regression and the statistical analysis of longitudinal data. Topics include a review of the OLS regression model, event-history methods, and various other techniques for analyzing longitudinal data.
EDUC 265.prereqString: Prerequisite: EDUC 288A. EDUC 288A with a grade of B or better

EDUC 266.name: Design-Based Implementation Research
EDUC 266.description: Explores design-based implementation research (DBIR) to organize research and improvement efforts in education. Delves deeper into different techniques of partnership development, design, implementation, and improvement science to build a repertoire of practices for students' studies.

EDUC 268.name: Out-of-School Learning and Development
EDUC 268.description: Examines theory, research, and policy concerning out-of-school time and youth development. Several out-of-school contexts are considered (e.g, unsupervised care, informal leisure activities, and organized activities). A range of developmental outcomes are considered (e.g., achievement, social-emotional competence, and physical health).

EDUC 274.name: Studies of Professional and Staff Development
EDUC 274.description: Research and theory of effective strategies for professional and staff development. Topics include: adult learning as related to professional growth of teachers, staff development as vehicle for systemic reform, reforms to enhance teacher professionalization and empowerment.

EDUC 276.name: Early Childhood Education Policy
EDUC 276.description: Covers core topics in the field of early education policy. Integrates research from the various perspectives relevant to child policy in a practical way to understand the mechanisms of intervention and to develop policy solutions.

EDUC 278.name: Experimental Designs in Educational Research
EDUC 278.description: Designed to enable students to think critically about experimental research, and to develop an understanding of how to design and conduct experiments. The overall goal is to prepare students to independently plan and implement an experimental research study.

EDUC 279.name: Advanced Qualitative Methods
EDUC 279.description: Further developing qualitative inquiry skills for examining human interaction and studying lived experiences of individuals and communities. Practices and techniques for collecting, working with, and analyzing qualitative data to develop and justify claims.

EDUC 280.name: Research Methods: Hierarchical Linear Modeling
EDUC 280.description: Research data often have a hierarchical structure, which require multi-level models. Students learn to use HLM
EDUC 280.restriction: Restriction: Doctor of Philosophy Degree students only. Graduate students only.

EDUC 283A.name: Qualitative Research Methods in Education I
EDUC 283A.description: Introduces students to qualitative research methodologies and methods and explores strengths and challenges of this research tradition. Topics include logistical and ethical issues, reliability, validity and generalizability, and the role of reflexivity. Students will also engage in fieldwork.

EDUC 283B.name: Qualitative Research Methods in Education II
EDUC 283B.description: Provides methods for conducting and analyzing qualitative research in educational settings. Topics include data collection, coding, representing qualitative data, and using software for qualitative data analysis.

EDUC 285.name: Theories of Learning Cognition
EDUC 285.description: Overview of theories applicable to learning in schools and extracurricular contexts. Cognitive, psychometric, behavioral, and neuroscience perspectives are applied to such topics as memory, knowledge structures, problem solving, motivation, self-referent beliefs, expertise, assessment, and cognitive abilities, including intelligence.

EDUC 287A.name: Quantitative Data Analysis in Education Research and Evaluation
EDUC 287A.description: Statistical aspects of survey-based evaluations and quantitative research in education. Includes sampling, coding open-ended information, data management, scale construction, statistical analysis, and presentation of findings. Students analyze data sets - a district-based evaluation and a national survey - using SPPS.

EDUC 287B.name: Causal Inference: Methods for Program Evaluation and Policy Research
EDUC 287B.description: Provides students with a comprehensive overview of how to perform some more advanced statistical methods useful in answering policy questions using observational or experimental data.

EDUC 288A.name: Educational, Social, and Behavioral Statistics
EDUC 288A.description: Designed for graduate students with previous course work in statistics, including experience with statistical software such as SPSS or Stata. The emphasis is on regression analysis and the general linear model. Students learn to analyze real data using Stata.

EDUC 288B.name: Structural Equation Modeling for Educ, Soc & Behavioral Analysis
EDUC 288B.description: Rigorous introduction to structural equation modeling for students with strong prior course work in statistics. Topics include path diagrams, SEM with observed variables, factor analysis, SEM with latent variables. Maximum likelihood estimating, goodness-of-fit measures, nested models, related topics.

EDUC 289.name: Use of Video in Educational Research
EDUC 289.description: Provides students with conceptual and methodological tools for using video in educational research.  Students work with their own video data or with publicly accessible databases.

EDUC 295.name: Pre-Dissertation Research
EDUC 295.description: Independent study course taken under the direction of a faculty member who guides the student's research. May include guidance on data collection, methodology, human subjects protocol, conference presentation, scholarly publication, program benchmark activities.

EDUC 296A.name: Professional Writing in Educational Research I
EDUC 296A.description: First of a two-course series designed to extend students’ knowledge of conducting and publishing educational research. Topics include the logic of research and how to effectively communicate research findings, with particular emphasis on proficient scientific writing.

EDUC 296B.name: Professional Writing in Educational Research II
EDUC 296B.description: Second of a two-course series designed to extend students’ knowledge of conducting and publishing educational research. Topics include the logic of research and how to effectively communicate research findings, with particular emphasis on proficient scientific writing.

EDUC 298.name: Independent Study
EDUC 298.description: Independent research on topics related to education.

EDUC 299.name: Dissertation Reserach
EDUC 299.description: Specifically designed for students researching and writing their dissertations.

EDUC 301.name: Directed Elementary Field Experiences in Diverse Schools
EDUC 301.description: Fieldwork experiences and seminars to provide introduction to the California Teaching Performance Expectations, including guidelines for professional expectations, observation and participation in classrooms, instructional planning, classroom management, and formative experiences and preparation for the state-mandated Teaching Performance Assessment.
EDUC 301.restriction: Restriction: Master of Arts in Teaching Degree students only.

EDUC 302.name: Directed Secondary Field Experiences
EDUC 302.description: Field work experiences and seminars to provide introduction to the California Teaching Performance Expectations, including guidelines for professional expectations, observation and participation in classrooms, instructional planning, classroom management, and formative experiences and preparation for the State-mandated Teaching Performance Assessment.
EDUC 302.restriction: Restriction: Master of Arts Degree students only.

EDUC 304.name: Student Teaching in the Elementary Schools
EDUC 304.description: Student teaching seminars prepare candidates for assumption of classroom instructional responsibilities in accordance with State credentialing requirements. Four full days a week of student teaching in public school elementary classrooms in winter quarter and five full days in spring quarter.
EDUC 304.restriction: Restriction: Master of Arts Degree students only.

EDUC 305.name: Learning to Learn from Teaching in Secondary Schools
EDUC 305.description: Analytic tools for (1) observing and reflecting on observed instruction
EDUC 305.restriction: Restriction: Master of Arts in Teaching Degree students only.

EDUC 306.name: Supervised Teaching in Bilingual Education, Elementary
EDUC 306.description: Student teaching experiences in bilingual public school classrooms to include orientation, regular seminars, and preparation for bilingual classroom instructional responsibilities in accordance with State credentialing requirements and in conjunction with the public school calendar.
EDUC 306.restriction: Restriction: Master of Arts in Teaching Degree students only.

EDUC 307.name: Student Teaching in Intermediate/Secondary School
EDUC 307.description: Student teaching includes orientation, seminars, and preparation for and assumption of secondary school classroom instructional responsibilities in accordance with State credentialing requirements and in conjunction with public school calendar. Five full days a week in both winter and spring quarters.
EDUC 307.restriction: Restriction: Master of Arts in Teaching Degree students only.

EDUC 320.name: Teaching Physical and Health Education in Elementary School
EDUC 320.description: Methods of teaching physical education for the elementary classroom teacher. Through an interactive environment, students experience the California Physical Education and Health content standards with appropriate pedagogy. Concepts address motor skills, physical fitness, and personal responsibility for lifelong health.
EDUC 320.restriction: Restriction: Master of Arts in Teaching Degree students only.

EDUC 322A.name: Curriculum and Methods for Elementary School Mathematics I
EDUC 322A.description: Scope, sequence, and methods of teaching mathematics at all levels of elementary school. Presented through lectures, discussions, demonstrations, and exploration of a variety of materials. Covers how to plan lessons, motivate students, diagnose difficulties, and evaluate learning in mathematics.
EDUC 322A.restriction: Restriction: Master of Arts in Teaching Degree students only.

EDUC 322B.name: Curriculum and Methods for Elementary School Mathematics II
EDUC 322B.description: Part two of a course addressing pedagogical methods for elementary mathematics. Lectures, discussions, and exploration of instructional strategies and materials support preservice teacher development in the critical areas of planning, instruction, and assessment for conceptual understanding in mathematics.
EDUC 322B.restriction: Restriction: Master of Arts in Teaching Degree students only.

EDUC 323A.name: Curriculum Methods in Elementary Science
EDUC 323A.description: Prospective elementary teachers learn how to teach science in grades K-8. Covers state science requirements, a variety of teaching methods, and criteria for selecting science curriculum materials.
EDUC 323A.restriction: Restriction: Master of Arts in Teaching Degree students only.

EDUC 323B.name: Curriculum Methods in Elementary Science
EDUC 323B.description: Prospective elementary teachers learn how to teach science in grades K-8. Covers state science requirements, a variety of teaching methods, criteria for selecting science curriculum materials, and how to plan science lessons, units, experiments, projects, and demonstrations.
EDUC 323B.restriction: Restriction: Master of Arts in Teaching Degree students only.

EDUC 325.name: Teaching the Visual and Performing Arts in Elementary School
EDUC 325.description: Introduction to the issues and practices — including student diversity, academic literacy, and interdisciplinary content —  involved in integrating the California visual and performing arts curriculum framework and academic content standards with developmentally appropriate teaching strategies for the elementary classroom. Materials fee.
EDUC 325.restriction: Restriction: Master of Arts in Teaching Degree students only.

EDUC 326.name: Curriculum and Methods for Elementary School Reading
EDUC 326.description: Teaching an integrated reading/language arts program in the elementary classroom. Implementing theories, principles, and methods which are research and reality-based. Creating a child-centered, language-rich program to meet needs of children in multicultural/multilingual settings.
EDUC 326.restriction: Restriction: Master of Arts in Teaching Degree students only.

EDUC 336.name: Methods of Teaching Languages other than English in Secondary Schools
EDUC 336.description: Prepares future teachers of foreign language or primary/home language. Emphasizes hands-on, practical strategies for communication-based instruction and authentic assessment in reading, writing, listening, speaking, and culture.
EDUC 336.restriction: Restriction: Master of Arts in Teaching Degree students only.

EDUC 337.name: Methods of Teaching Social Science in the Secondary School
EDUC 337.description: Theories, strategies, and methodologies related to the teaching of history and social science in the secondary school. Emphasis on the planning, delivery, and assessment of lessons reflecting an understanding of the History-Social Science Framework for California.
EDUC 337.restriction: Restriction: Master of Arts in Teaching Degree students only.

EDUC 338.name: Methods of Teaching English in the Secondary School
EDUC 338.description: Introduction to teaching reading, writing, and speaking skills in secondary school. Emphasis upon integrative approach to teaching literature, composition, and grammar consistent with the California State Framework. Practice in the design of lesson plans that are both integrated and cumulative.
EDUC 338.restriction: Restriction: Master of Arts in Teaching Degree students only.

EDUC 339.name: Methods of Teaching Visual Arts in Secondary Schools
EDUC 339.description: Theory, curriculum, and strategies for teaching visual arts in the secondary school. Emphasis on the planning, delivery, and assessment of lessons consistent with California State Framework and content standards.
EDUC 339.restriction: Restriction: Master of Arts in Teaching Degree students only.

EDUC 340.name: Methods of Teaching Mathematics in Secondary School
EDUC 340.description: Theories, strategies, and methodologies related to the teaching of mathematics in the secondary school. Emphasis on the planning, delivery, and assessment of lessons reflecting an understanding of the Mathematics Framework for California and the recommendations of professional organizations.
EDUC 340.restriction: Restriction: Master of Arts in Teaching Degree students only.

EDUC 341.name: Teaching Science in Secondary School
EDUC 341.description: Prospective secondary science teachers learn how to teach science in grades 7-12. Covers State science requirements, a variety of teaching methods, criteria for selecting science curricular materials, and how to plan science lessons, units, experiments, projects, and demonstrations.
EDUC 341.restriction: Restriction: Master of Arts in Teaching Degree students only.

EDUC 342A.name: Applied Instructional Strategies in Secondary Schools
EDUC 342A.description: Application of pedagogy and research to practice teaching experiences in the secondary schools. A continuation of the methodology course series with an emphasis on the needs of students with culturally diverse backgrounds. Conducted in a five-week format.
EDUC 342A.restriction: Restriction: Master of Arts in Teaching Degree students only. EDUC 342 and EDUC 342A may not both be taken for credit.

EDUC 342B.name: Applied Instructional Strategies in Secondary Schools
EDUC 342B.description: Application of pedagogy and research to practice teaching experiences in the secondary schools. A continuation of the methodology course series with an emphasis on the needs of students with culturally diverse backgrounds. Conducted in a five-week format.
EDUC 342B.restriction: Restriction: Master of Arts in Teaching Degree students only. EDUC 342 and EDUC 342B may not both be taken for credit.

EDUC 346.name: Reading and Writing in Middle School and High School Classrooms
EDUC 346.description: Emphasis is placed upon understanding the literacy processes (listening, speaking, viewing, reading, and writing) as they relate to all Single Subject areas. Teachers are guided to integrate literacy-related strategies with curriculum-based goals supported in the California State Frameworks.
EDUC 346.restriction: Restriction: Master of Arts in Teaching Degree students only.

EDUC 347.name: Culture, Diversity, and Educational Equity
EDUC 347.description: Survey of the history of and social theories about the origins and consequences of U.S. racial, gender, and social inequality, and the effects of poverty and racism on the educational opportunities and outcomes of minority groups in the United States.
EDUC 347.restriction: Restriction: Master of Arts in Teaching Degree students only.

EDUC 348.name: Educational Equity and the Exceptional Learner
EDUC 348.description: Knowledge, skills, and strategies to teach exceptional learners in the general education classroom. Legislation pertaining to the education of exceptional learners. Role of general education teacher in the special education process. Inclusive curriculum to provide equal access to content.
EDUC 348.restriction: Restriction: Master of Arts in Teaching Degree students only.

EDUC 348A.name: Educational Equity and the Exceptional Learner I
EDUC 348A.description: Focuses on knowledge, skills, and strategies needed to teach special populations in general education secondary classrooms. Covers categories and characteristics of disability and exceptionality, state and federal legislation, and the role of general education teachers in the special education process.
EDUC 348A.restriction: Restriction: Master of Arts in Teaching Degree students only. Graduate students only.

EDUC 348B.name: Educational Equity and the Exceptional Learner II
EDUC 348B.description: Emphasizes the use of differentiated instruction to meet special needs and the creation of a positive, inclusive learning environment that provides access to the core curriculum for special needs students.
EDUC 348B.restriction: Restriction: Master of Arts in Teaching Degree students only. Graduate students only.

EDUC 349.name: Theories and Methods of English Language Development Applied to Secondary Students
EDUC 349.description: Theories and methods of English language development and instruction of English language learners, with focus on secondary students. Includes language acquisition theory, language and content, assessment strategies, and preparation of curricula and instruction for grades 7–12 English language learners.
EDUC 349.restriction: Restriction: Master of Arts in Teaching Degree students only.

EDUC 358.name: Media and Information Literacy in the Secondary Classroom
EDUC 358.description: Focuses on how teachers can help their students to become critical, ethical, and effective users of technological resources in the secondary classroom. Students learn tools for evaluating, selecting, and incorporating appropriate learning technologies into the secondary classroom.
EDUC 358.restriction: Restriction: Master of Arts in Teaching Degree students only.

EDUC 359.name: Curriculum and Methods for Elementary Social Science and Information Literacy
EDUC 359.description: Methods of instruction for Social Science at the K–6 level. Includes integration of the use of technology, development of content literacy, and use of evidence to construct arguments.
EDUC 359.restriction: Restriction: Master of Arts in Teaching Degree students only.

EDUC 361.name: The Adolescent Learner
EDUC 361.description: Issues of adolescent development and learning in family, school, and community contexts from biological, psychological, cognitive, and social perspectives. Focuses on how adolescents learn, what motivates them to learn, and how schools and teachers contribute to adolescents’ growth.
EDUC 361.restriction: Restriction: Master of Arts in Teaching Degree students only.

EDUC 362.name: Curriculum and Methods for Elementary Language Arts  and English Language Development
EDUC 362.description: Methods, instructional practices, and assessment strategies for teaching English-Language Arts, with a focus on instructional practices for supporting English Language Learners. Focuses on core language arts topics, including composition of persuasive, expository, and narrative texts
EDUC 362.restriction: Restriction: Master of Arts in Teaching Degree students only.

EDUC 364.name: Instructional Design and Education Technology for the Elementary Classroom
EDUC 364.description: Focuses on how teachers can effectively integrate educational technologies for teaching and learning in the elementary school classroom. Students learn tools for evaluating, selecting, and incorporating appropriate technologies into their classroom activities.
EDUC 364.restriction: Restriction: Master of Arts in Teaching Degree students only.

EDUC 374.name: Learning and Child Development
EDUC 374.description: Issues of child development and learning in family, school, and community contexts from biological, psychological, cognitive, and social perspectives. Focuses on how young children learn and develop, how schools and teachers contribute to children’s growth, and implications for instruction.
EDUC 374.restriction: Restriction: Master of Arts in Teaching Degree students only.

EECS 1.name: Introduction to Electrical Engineering and Computer Engineering
EECS 1.description: Introduction to the fields of Electrical Engineering and Computer Engineering, including possible careers in both traditional and new emerging areas. Background on both the Electrical Engineering and the Computer Engineering majors, curriculum requirements, specializations, and faculty research interests.
EECS 1.restriction: Restriction: Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS 10.name: Computational Methods in Electrical and Computer Engineering
EECS 10.description: An introduction to computers and structured programming. Binary Data Representation. Hands-on experience with a high-level structured programming language. Introduction to algorithm efficiency. Applications of structured programming in solving engineering problems. Programming laboratory.
EECS 10.restriction: Restriction: Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Chemical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS 12.name: Introduction to Programming
EECS 12.description: An introduction to computers and programming. Python programming syntax/style, types. Numbers and sequences. Control flow. I/O and errors/exceptions. Function calling, parameter passing, formal arguments, return values. Variable scoping. Programming laboratory.
EECS 12.restriction: Restriction: Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS 20.name: Computer Systems and C Programming
EECS 20.description: Introduction to computing systems. Data representation and operations. Simple logic design. Basic computer organization. Instruction set architecture and assembly language programming. Introduction to C. Functions and recursion, data structures, pointers. Programming laboratory.
EECS 20.restriction: Restriction: Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS 22.name: Advanced C Programming
EECS 22.description: C language programming concepts. Control flow, function calls, recursion. Basic and composite data types, static and dynamic data structures. Program modules and compilation units. Preprocessor macros. C standard libraries.
EECS 22.restriction: Restriction: Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS 22L.name: Software Engineering Project in C Language
EECS 22L.description: Hands-on experience with the ANSI-C programming language. Medium-sized programming projects, team work. Software specification, documentation, implementation, testing. Definition of data structures and application programming interface. Creation of program modules, linking with external libraries. Rule-based compilation, version control.
EECS 22L.restriction: Restriction: Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS 31.name: Introduction to Digital Systems
EECS 31.description: Digital representation of information. Specification, analysis, design and optimization or combinational and sequential logic, register-transfer components and register-transfer systems with datapaths and controllers. Introduction to high-level and algorithmic state-machines and custom processors.
EECS 31.prereqString: Prerequisite: ICS 31 or EECS 10 or EECS 12 or MAE 10
EECS 31.restriction: Restriction: Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS 31L.name: Introduction to Digital Logic Laboratory
EECS 31L.description: Introduction to common digital integrated circuits: gates, memory circuits, MSI components. Operating characteristics, specifications, applications. Design of simple combinational and sequential digital systems (arithmetic processors game-playing machines). Construction and debugging techniques using hardware description languages and CAD tools.
EECS 31L.prereqString: Prerequisite: EECS 31 and (EECS 10 or EECS 12 or ICS 32)
EECS 31L.restriction: Restriction: Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS 40.name: Object-Oriented Systems and Programming
EECS 40.description: Primitive types and expressions. The class and method definition. Information hiding and encapsulation. Objects and reference. Overloading. Constructors. Inheritance basics. Programming with inheritance. Dynamic binding and polymorphism. Exception handling. An overview of streams and file input/output. Programming laboratory.
EECS 40.restriction: Restriction: Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS 50.name: Discrete-Time Signals and Systems
EECS 50.description: Analysis of discrete-time linear-time-invariant (DTLTI) systems in the time domain and using z-transforms.  Introduction to techniques based on Discrete-Time, Discrete, and Fast Fourier Transforms. Examples of their application to digital signal processing and digital communications.
EECS 50.restriction: Restriction: Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS 55.name: Engineering Probability
EECS 55.restriction: Restriction: Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS 70A.name: Network Analysis I
EECS 70A.description: Modeling and analysis of electrical networks. Basic network theorems. Sinusoidal steady state and transient analysis of RLC networks and the impedance concept.
EECS 70A.prereqString:
Corequisite: MATH 3D
Prerequisite: PHYS 7D and (EECS 10 or EECS 12 or MAE 10 or ICS 31 or CEE 20)
EECS 70A.restriction: Restriction: Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Mechanical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Aerospace Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Civil Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Materials Science and Engr Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS 70B.name: Network Analysis II
EECS 70B.description: Laplace transforms, complex frequency, and the s-plane. Network functions and frequency response, including resonance. Bode plots. Two-port network characterization.
EECS 70B.prereqString:
Corequisite: EECS 70LB
Prerequisite: (BME 60B or EECS 10 or EECS 12 or ICS 31 or CEE 20 or MAE 10) and EECS 70A
EECS 70B.restriction: Restriction: Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Materials Science and Engr Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS 70LA.name: Network Analysis I Laboratory
EECS 70LA.prereqString:
Corequisite: EECS 70A
Prerequisite: PHYS 7D and (EECS 10 or EECS 12 or BME 60B or CEE 20 or MAE 10)
EECS 70LA.restriction: Restriction: Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS 70LB.name: Network Analysis II Laboratory
EECS 70LB.description: Laboratory to accompany EECS 70B.  Materials fee.
EECS 70LB.prereqString:
Corequisite: EECS 70B
Prerequisite: (BME 60B or EECS 10 or EECS 12 or ICS 31 or CEE 20 or MAE 10) and EECS 70A
EECS 70LB.restriction: Restriction: Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS 101.name: Introduction to Machine Vision
EECS 101.description: The use of digital computers for the analysis of visual scenes
EECS 101.restriction: Restriction: Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS 111.name: System Software
EECS 111.description: Multiprogramming, interrupt, processes, kernel, parallelism, critical sections, deadlocks, communication, multiprocessing, multilevel memory management, binding, name management, file systems, protection, resource allocation, scheduling. Experience with concurrent programming, synchronization mechanisms, interprocess communication.
EECS 111.restriction: Restriction: Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS 112.name: Organization of Digital Computers
EECS 112.description: Building blocks and organization of digital computers, the arithmetic, control, and memory units, and input/out devices and interfaces. Microprogramming and microprocessors.
EECS 112.restriction: Restriction: Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS 112L.name: Organization of Digital Computers Laboratory
EECS 112L.description: Specification and implementation of a processor-based system using a hardware description language such as VHDL. Hands-on experience with design tools including simulation, synthesis, and evaluation using testbenches.
EECS 112L.restriction: Restriction: Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS 113.name: Processor Hardware/Software Interfaces
EECS 113.description: Hardware/software interfacing, including memory and bus interfaces, devices, I/O, and compiler code generation/instruction scheduling. Experience microcontroller programming and interfacing. Specific compiler code generation techniques including local variable and register allocations, instruction dependence and scheduling, and code optimization.
EECS 113.restriction: Restriction: Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science and Engineering Majors have second consideration for enrollment.

EECS 114.name: Engineering Data Structures and Algorithms
EECS 114.description: Introduces abstract behavior of classes data structures, alternative implementations, informal analysis of time and space efficiency. Also introduces classic algorithms and efficient algorithm design techniques (recursion, divide-and-conquer, branch-and-bound, dynamic programming).
EECS 114.restriction: Restriction: Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have second consideration for enrollment.

EECS 116.name: Introduction to Data Management
EECS 116.description: Introduction to the design of databases and the use of database management systems (DBMS) for applications. Topics include entity-relationship modeling for design, relational data model, relational algebra, relational design theory, and Structured Query Language (SQL) programming.
EECS 116.prereqString: Prerequisite: ICS 33 or EECS 114. ICS 33 with a grade of C or better
EECS 116.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS 117.name: Parallel Computer Systems
EECS 117.description: General introduction to parallel computing focusing on parallel algorithms and architectures. Parallel models: Flynn's taxonomy, dataflow models. Parallel architectures: systolic arrays, hypercube architecture, shared memory machines, dataflow machines, reconfigurable architectures. Parallel algorithms appropriate to each machine type area also discussed.
EECS 117.prereqString: Prerequisite: EECS 20 and EECS 114 and EECS 112
EECS 117.restriction: Restriction: Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS 118.name: Introduction to Artificial Intelligence
EECS 118.description: Introduction of basic concepts in artificial intelligence. Knowledge representation and reasoning, search, planning, declarative programing, problem solving, and data science.
EECS 118.restriction: Restriction: Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have second consideration for enrollment.

EECS 119.name: VLSI
EECS 119.description: Design techniques for Very Large Scale Integrated (VLSI) systems and chips. Review CMOS and related process technologies
EECS 119.restriction: Restriction: Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have second consideration for enrollment.

EECS 120.name: Fundamentals of Parallel Computing
EECS 120.description: Fundamentals of parallel computing, focusing on parallel algorithms and architectures. Topics include design of parallel and I/O efficient algorithms, basics of parallel machine architectures, and current/emerging programming models (shared memory, distributed memory, and accelerators).
EECS 120.restriction: Restriction: Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS 121.name: System Security
EECS 121.description: Fundamentals and practices of system security. Topics include cryptographic (encryption, decryption, and message authentication), software vulnerabilities (buffer overflow), network security (layer 2-7 attacks and defenses and PKI), web security (XSS and XSRF), and privacy.

EECS 141A.name: Communication Systems I
EECS 141A.description: Introduction to analog communication systems including effects of noise. Modulation-demodulation for AM, DSB-SC, SSB, VSB, QAM, FM, PM, and PCM with application to radio, television, and telephony. Signal processing as applied to communication systems.
EECS 141A.restriction: Restriction: Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS 141B.name: Communication Systems II
EECS 141B.description: Signal space analysis. Optimum receivers for digital communication. Maximum a posteriori and maximum likelihood detection. Matched filter and correlation receiver.  PAM, QAM, PSK, FSK, and MSK and their performance. Introduction to equalization, synchronization, information theory, and error control codes.
EECS 141B.restriction: Restriction: Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS 144.name: Antenna Design for Wireless Communication Links
EECS 144.description: Analysis and synthesis of antennas and antenna arrays.  Adaptive arrays and digital beam forming for advanced wireless links.  Friis transmission formula.  Wireless communication equations for cell-site and mobile antennas, interference, slow and fast fading in mobile communication.

EECS 145.name: Electrical Engineering Analysis
EECS 145.description: Vector calculus, complex functions, and linear algebra with applications to electrical engineering problems.
EECS 145.restriction: Restriction: Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering majors have second consideration for enrollment.

EECS 148.name: Computer Networks
EECS 148.description: Computer network architectures, protocols, and applications.  Internet congestion control, addressing, and routing. Local area networks. Multimedia networking.
EECS 148.restriction: Restriction: Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS 150.name: Continuous-Time Signals and Systems
EECS 150.description: Characteristics and properties of continuous-time (analog) signals and systems. Analysis of linear time-invariant continuous-time systems using differential equation convolutional models. Analysis of these systems using Laplace transforms, Fourier series, and Fourier transforms. Examples from applications to telecommunications.
EECS 150.restriction: Restriction: Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have second consideration for enrollment.

EECS 152A.name: Digital Signal Processing
EECS 152A.description: Nature of sampled data, sampling theorem, difference equations, data holds, z-transform, w-transform, digital filters, Butterworth and Chebychev filters, quantization effects.
EECS 152A.restriction: Restriction: Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS 152B.name: Digital Signal Processing Design and Laboratory
EECS 152B.description: Design and implementation of algorithms on a DSP processor and using computer simulation. Applications in signal and image processing, communications, radar, etc.
EECS 152B.restriction: Restriction: Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS 159A.name: Senior Design Project I
EECS 159A.description: Teaches problem definition, detailed design, integration, and testability with teams of students specifying, designing, building, and testing complex systems. Lectures include engineering values, discussions, and ethical ramifications of engineering decisions.
EECS 159A.prereqString: Prerequisite: EECS 113 or EECS 170C or CS 145
EECS 159A.restriction: Restriction: Seniors only. Computer Science Engineering Majors only. Electrical Engineering Majors only. Computer Engineering Majors only.

EECS 159B.name: Senior Design Project II
EECS 159B.description: Teaches problem definition, detailed design, integration, and testability with teams of students specifying, designing, building, and testing complex systems. Lectures include engineering values, discussions, and ethical ramifications of engineering decisions. Materials fee.
EECS 159B.restriction: Restriction: Computer Science Engineering Majors only. Electrical Engineering Majors only. Computer Engineering Majors only.

EECS 160A.name: Introduction to Control Systems
EECS 160A.description: Modeling, stability, and specifications of feedback control systems. Root locus, Bode plots, Nyquist criteria, and state-space methods for dynamic analysis and design.
EECS 160A.prereqString:
Corequisite: EECS 160LA
Prerequisite: (EECS 10 or EECS 12 or MAE 10 or BME 60B or CEE 20) and EECS 150 and EECS 170B and EECS 170LB
EECS 160A.restriction: Restriction: Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have second consideration for enrollment.

EECS 160LA.name: Control Systems I Laboratory
EECS 160LA.restriction: Restriction: Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have second consideration for enrollment.

EECS 163.name: Power Systems
EECS 163.description: Generation, transmission, and use of electrical energy. Fault calculation, protection, stability, and power flow.
EECS 163.restriction: Restriction: Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS 163L.name: Power Systems Laboratory
EECS 163L.description: Experiments and field trips relevant to studies in power systems. Materials fee.
EECS 163L.restriction: Restriction: Computer Science Engineering Majors only. Electrical Engineering Majors only. Computer Engineering Majors only.

EECS 166A.name: Industrial and Power Electronics
EECS 166A.description: Power switching devices, pulse width modulation (PWM) methods, switching converter topologies, control, and magnetics. Materials fee.
EECS 166A.restriction: Restriction: Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Engineering Majors have second consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have second consideration for enrollment.

EECS 170A.name: Electronics I
EECS 170A.description: The properties of semiconductors, electronic conduction in solids, the physics and operation principles of semiconductor devices such as diodes and transistors, transistor equivalent circuits, and transistor amplifiers.
EECS 170A.prereqString:
Corequisite: PHYS 7E
Prerequisite: PHYS 7D and EECS 70B
EECS 170A.restriction: Restriction: Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have second consideration for enrollment.

EECS 170B.name: Electronics II
EECS 170B.description: Design and analysis of single-stage amplifiers, biasing circuits, inverters, logic gates, and memory elements based on CMOS transistors.
EECS 170B.prereqString:
Corequisite: EECS 170LB
Prerequisite: EECS 70B and EECS 170A and EECS 170LA
EECS 170B.restriction: Restriction: Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Materials Science and Engr Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have second consideration for enrollment.

EECS 170C.name: Electronics III
EECS 170C.description: Principles of operation, design, and utilization of integrated circuit modules, including multi-stage amplifiers, operational amplifiers, and logic circuits.
EECS 170C.prereqString:
Corequisite: EECS 170LC
Prerequisite: EECS 170B and EECS 170LB
EECS 170C.restriction: Restriction: Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Engineering Majors have second consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have second consideration for enrollment.

EECS 170D.name: Integrated Electronic Circuit Design
EECS 170D.description: Design and fabrication of modern digital integrated circuits. Fabrication of CMOS process, transistor-level design simulation, functional characteristics of basic digital integrated circuits, and different logic families including the static and dynamic logic, layout, and extraction of digital circuits.
EECS 170D.restriction: Restriction: Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Engineering Majors have second consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have second consideration for enrollment.

EECS 170E.name: Analog and Communications IC Design
EECS 170E.description: Advanced topics in design of analog and communications integrated circuits. Topics include: implementation of passive components in integrated circuits
EECS 170E.restriction: Restriction: Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Engineering Majors have second consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have second consideration for enrollment.

EECS 170LA.name: Electronics I Laboratory
EECS 170LA.description: Laboratory accompanying EECS 170A to perform experiments on semiconductor material properties, semiconductor device physics and operation principles, and transistor amplifiers to improve experimental skills and to enhance the understanding of lecture materials.
EECS 170LA.prereqString:
Corequisite: EECS 170A and PHYS 7E
Prerequisite: PHYS 7D and EECS 70B
EECS 170LA.restriction: Restriction: Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Materials Science and Engr Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS 170LB.name: Electronics II Laboratory
EECS 170LB.prereqString:
Corequisite: EECS 170B
Prerequisite: EECS 170A and EECS 170LA
EECS 170LB.restriction: Restriction: Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have second consideration for enrollment.

EECS 170LC.name: Electronics III Laboratory
EECS 170LC.description: Laboratory accompanying EECS 170C to provide hands-on training in design of digital/analog circuits/subsystems. Materials fee.
EECS 170LC.prereqString:
Corequisite: EECS 170C
Prerequisite: EECS 170B and EECS 170LB
EECS 170LC.restriction: Restriction: Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Engineering Majors have second consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have second consideration for enrollment.

EECS 174.name: Semiconductor Devices
EECS 174.description: Metal-semiconductor junctions, diodes, bipolar junction transistors, MOS structures, MOSFETs, CMOS technology, LEDs, and laser diodes.
EECS 174.restriction: Restriction: Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have second consideration for enrollment. Materials Science Engineering Majors have second consideration for enrollment.

EECS 176.name: Fundamentals of Solid-State Electronics and Materials
EECS 176.description: Physical properties of semiconductors and the roles materials play in device operation. Topics include: crystal structure, phonon vibrations, energy band, transport phenomenon, optical properties and quantum confinement effect essential to the understanding of electronic, optoelectronic and nanodevices.
EECS 176.restriction: Restriction: Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Materials Science and Engr Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS 179.name: Microelectromechanical Systems (MEMS)
EECS 179.description: Small-scale machines, small-scale phenomena, MEMS fabrication, MEMS CAD tools, MEMS devices and packaging, MEMS testing.
EECS 179.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS 180A.name: Engineering Electromagnetics I
EECS 180A.description: Electrostatics, magnetostatics, and electromagnetic fields: solutions to problems in engineering applications
EECS 180A.restriction: Restriction: Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Biomedical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Materials Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS 180B.name: Engineering Electromagnetics II
EECS 180B.description: Time-varying electromagnetic fields, plane waves, polarization, guidance of waves like rectangular waveguides and microstrips, optical fibers resonant cavities, skin effects and losses, spherical waves, radiation and reception of waves, antenna basics.
EECS 180B.restriction: Restriction: Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have second consideration for enrollment.

EECS 180C.name: Engineering Electromagnetics III
EECS 180C.description: Propagation in anisotropic media. Propagation in ferrites and non-reciprocal devices. Scattering and dispersion. Electromagnetic properties of materials. Scattering of small nanoparticles. Spherical waves. Cross section of large and small objects. Radar equation. Coherent and incoherent radiation.
EECS 180C.restriction: Restriction: Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS 182.name: Monolithic Microwave Integrated Circuit (MMIC) Analysis and Design
EECS 182.description: Design of microwave amplifiers including low-noise amplifiers, multiple stage amplifiers, power amplifiers, and introduction to broadband amplifiers. The goal is to provide the basic knowledge for the design of microwave amplifiers ranging from wireless system to radar system.
EECS 182.restriction: Restriction: Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

EECS 188.name: Optical Electronics
EECS 188.description: Photodiodes and optical detection, photometry and radiometry, geometric optics, lens theory, imaging system, EM wave propagation, optical waveguides and fibers, heterojunction structures, laser theory, semiconductor lasers, and optical transmission system.
EECS 188.restriction: Restriction: Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have second consideration for enrollment.

EECS 195.name: Special Topics in Electrical and Computer Engineering
EECS 195.description: Studies special topics in selected areas of Electrical and Computer Engineering. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

EECS 198.name: Group Study
EECS 198.description: Group study of selected topics in Electrical and Computer Engineering.

EECS 199.name: Individual Study
EECS 199.description: For undergraduate Engineering majors in supervised but independent reading, research, or design. Students taking Individual study for design credit are to submit a written paper to the instructor and to the Undergraduate Student Affairs Office in the School of Engineering.

EECS 199P.name: Individual Study
EECS 199P.description: For undergraduate Engineering majors in supervised but independent reading, research, or design. Students taking individual study for design credit are to submit a written paper to the instructor and to the Student Affairs Office in the School of Engineering.

EECS 202P.name: Techniques in Medical Imaging: X-ray, Nuclear, and NMR Imaging
EECS 202P.description: Ionizing radiation, planar and tomographic radiographic and nuclear imaging, magnetism, NMR, MRI imaging.
EECS 202P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

EECS 203A.name: Digital Image Processing
EECS 203A.description: Pixel-level digital image representation and elementary operations

EECS 203P.name: Digital Image Processing
EECS 203P.description: Pixel-level digital image representation and elementary operations
EECS 203P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

EECS 211.name: Advanced System Software
EECS 211.description: Study of operating systems including interprocess communication, scheduling, resource management, concurrency, reliability, validation, protection and security, and distributed computing support. System software design languages and modeling analysis.

EECS 211P.name: Advanced System Software
EECS 211P.description: Study of operating systems including interprocess communication, scheduling, resource management, concurrency, reliability, validation, protection and security, and distributed computing support. System software design languages and modeling analysis.
EECS 211P.prereqString: Prerequisite: Recommended: Undergraduate-level knowledge of system software (e.g. EECS 111) and organization of digital computers (e.g. UCI EECS 112).
EECS 211P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

EECS 213.name: Computer Architecture
EECS 213.description: Problems in hardware, firmware (microprogram), and software. Computer architecture for resource sharing, real-time applications, parallelism, microprogramming, and fault tolerance. Various architectures based on cost/performance and current technology.

EECS 213P.name: Computer Architecture
EECS 213P.description: Problems in hardware, firmware (microprogram), and software. Computer architecture for resource sharing, real-time applications, parallelism, microprogramming, and fault tolerance. Various architectures based on cost/performance and current technology.
EECS 213P.prereqString: Prerequisite: Recommended: Undergraduate-level knowledge of organization of digital computers (e.g. EECS 112 and EECS 112L).
EECS 213P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

EECS 215.name: Design and Analysis of Algorithms
EECS 215.description: Computer algorithms from a practical standpoint.  Algorithms for symbolic and numeric problems such as sorting, searching, graphs, and network flow.  Analysis includes algorithm time and space complexity.

EECS 215P.name: Design and Analysis of Algorithms
EECS 215P.description: Computer algorithms from a practical standpoint. Algorithms for symbolic and numeric problems such as sorting, searching, graphs, and network flow. Analysis includes algorithm time and space complexity.
EECS 215P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

EECS 216.name: Advanced Application of Algorithms
EECS 216.description: Medium-sized group and individual programming project. Topics include specification requirements documentation, practical implementation of algorithms, and testing/verification of design.
EECS 216.prereqString: Prerequisite: Recommended: Undergraduate course work in engineering data structures and algorithms.

EECS 217.name: VLSI System Design
EECS 217.description: Overview of integrated fabrication, circuit simulation, basic device physics, device layout, timing

EECS 217P.name: VLSI System Design
EECS 217P.description: Overview of integrated fabrication, circuit simulation, basic device physics, device layout, timing
EECS 217P.prereqString: Prerequisite: Recommended: Undergraduate-level knowledge of organization of digital computers (e.g. EECS 112).
EECS 217P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

EECS 220.name: Advanced Digital Signal Processing Architecture
