EECS 220.description: Study the latest DSP architectures for applications in communication (wired and wireless) and multimedia processing. Emphasis given to understanding the current design techniques and to evaluate the performance, power, and application domain of the latest DSP processors.

EECS 220P.name: Advanced Digital Signal Processing Architecture
EECS 220P.description: Study the latest DSP architectures for applications in communication (wired and wireless) and multimedia processing. Emphasis given to understanding the current design techniques and to evaluate the performance, power, and application domain of the latest DSP processors.
EECS 220P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

EECS 221.name: Topics in Computer Engineering
EECS 221.description: New research results in computer engineering.

EECS 222.name: Embedded System Modeling
EECS 222.description: Computational models for embedded systems. System-level specification and description languages. Concepts, requirements, examples. Embedded system models at different levels of abstraction. Modeling of test benches, design under test, IP components. Discrete event simulation, semantics, and algorithms. Formerly EECS 222A.

EECS 223.name: Real-Time Computer Systems
EECS 223.description: Time bases, clock synchronization, real-time communication protocols, specification of requirements, task scheduling. Validation of timelines, real-time configuration management.

EECS 223P.name: Real-Time Computer Systems
EECS 223P.description: Time bases, clock synchronization, real-time communication protocols, specification of requirements, task scheduling. Validation of timelines, real-time configuration management.
EECS 223P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

EECS 224.name: High-Performance Computing
EECS 224.description: Fundamentals of high-performance computing, covering both theory and practice. Topics include performance analysis and tuning, design of parallel and I/O efficient algorithms, basics of parallel machine architectures, and current/emerging programming models (shared memory, distributed memory, and accelerators).

EECS 225.name: Embedded Systems Design
EECS 225.description: Embedded systems design flow and methodology. Design space exploration. Co-design of hardware and software, embedded architecture and network exploration and synthesis. System software/hardware interface generation. Real-time constraints, specification-to-architecture mapping, design tools and methodologies. Formerly EECS 222B.

EECS 226.name: Embedded System Software
EECS 226.description: Embedded system software concepts, requirements, examples, for engineering applications such as multi-media and automotive. Software generation methodology. Algorithmic specification, design constraints. Embedded operating systems. Static, dynamic, real-time scheduling. Input/output, interrupt handling. Code generation, compilation, instruction set simulation. Formerly EECS 222C.

EECS 227.name: Cyber-Physical System Design
EECS 227.description: Model-based design of cyber-physical systems including, e.g., plant, sensing, control, actuation, embedded hardware/software, communication, real-time analysis, various levels of simulation (MILS, SILS, HILS), tools and methodologies for automatic synthesis, and application from various interdisciplinary domains.

EECS 229.name: Low Power SoC Design
EECS 229.description: From an inverter to server centers, low-power design theory and practice in modern systems-on-chip (SoC), energy efficient design time and runtime methods are surveyed at circuit, RTL, and architecture levels. Lab assignments will help students quantify tradeoffs and design practices.

EECS 230.name: Energy Efficiency
EECS 230.description: Green energy sources for production, transmission, storage, and utilization of electricity, with a special focus on solar, wind, and nuclear energy production. Study of newly developed renewable sources of energy including capital cost, product cost, environmental issues, and technical feasibility.

EECS 231.name: Advanced System Security
EECS 231.description: Advanced study about system security. Topics include software vulnerabilities (buffer overflow), vulnerability discovery (fuzzing),  network security, side-channel analysis (power analysis and micro-architecture attacks), machine-learning security, IoT security, and privacy (differential privacy).

EECS 240.name: Random Processes
EECS 240.description: Extensions of probability theory to random variables varying with time. General properties of stochastic processes. Convergence. Estimation, including nonlinear and linear minimum mean square error and maximum likelihood. Spectral density and linear filters. Poisson processes and discrete-time Markov chains.

EECS 240P.name: Random Processes
EECS 240P.description: Extensions of probability theory to random variables varying with time. General properties of stochastic processes. Convergence. Estimation, including nonlinear and linear minimum mean square error and maximum likelihood. Spectral density and linear filters. Poisson processes and discrete-time Markov chains.
EECS 240P.prereqString: Prerequisite: Recommended: Knowledge of engineering probability (e.g. EECS 55).
EECS 240P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

EECS 241A.name: Digital Communications I
EECS 241A.description: Concepts and applications of digital communication systems. Baseband digital transmission of binary, multiamplitude, and multidimensional signals.  Introduction to and performance analysis of different modulation schemes.

EECS 241AP.name: Digital Communications I
EECS 241AP.description: Concepts and applications of digital communication systems. Baseband digital transmission of binary, multiamplitude, and multidimensional signals. Introduction to and performance analysis of different modulation schemes.
EECS 241AP.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

EECS 241B.name: Digital Communications II
EECS 241B.description: Concepts and applications of equalization, multi-carrier modulation, spread spectrum and CDMA. Digital communications through fading memory channels.

EECS 241BP.name: Digital Communications II
EECS 241BP.description: Concepts and applications of equalization, multi-carrier modulation, spread spectrum, and CDMA. Digital communications through fading memory channels.
EECS 241BP.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

EECS 242.name: Information Theory
EECS 242.description: Fundamental capabilities and limitations of information sources and information transmission systems. Analytical framework for modeling and evaluating communication systems: entropy, mutual information asymptotic equipartition property, entropy rates of a stochastic process, data compression, channel capacity, differential entropy, the Gaussian channel.

EECS 243.name: Error Correcting Codes
EECS 243.description: Different techniques for error correcting codes and analyzing their performance. Linear block codes

EECS 244.name: Wireless Communications
EECS 244.description: Introduction to wireless communications systems. Wireless channel modeling. Single carries, spread spectrum, and multi-carrier wireless modulation schemes. Diversity techniques.  Multiple-access schemes. Transceiver design and system level tradeoffs. Brief overview of GSM, CDMA, (IS-95) and 2.5, 3G cellular schemes.

EECS 244P.name: Wireless Communications
EECS 244P.description: Introduction to wireless communications systems. Wireless channel modeling. Single carries, spread spectrum, and multi-carrier wireless modulation schemes. Diversity techniques. Multiple-access schemes. Transceiver design and system level tradeoffs. Brief overview of GSM, CDMA, (IS-95) and 2.5, 3G cellular schemes.
EECS 244P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

EECS 245.name: Space-Time Coding
EECS 245.description: A fundamental study of: Capacity of MIMO Channels, space-time code design criteria, space-time block codes, space-time trellis codes, differential detection for multiple antennas, spatial multiplexing, BLAST.

EECS 247.name: Information Storage
EECS 247.description: Storage architecture, storage network and networking algorithms in data centers, principle of storage devices and non-volatile memory, data consistency, data availability and integrity, power management.

EECS 248A.name: Computer and Communication Networks
EECS 248A.description: Network architecture of the Internet, telephone networks, cable networks, and cell phone networks. Network performance models. Network performance models. Advanced concepts and implementations of flow and congestion control, addressing, internetworking, forwarding, routing, multiple access, streaming, and quality-of-service.

EECS 250.name: Digital Signal Processing I
EECS 250.description: Fundamental principles of digital signal processing, sampling, decimation and interpolation, discrete Fourier transforms and FFT algorithms, transversal and recursive filters, discrete random processes, and finite-word effects in digital filters.

EECS 250P.name: Digital Signal Processing I
EECS 250P.description: Fundamental principles of digital signal processing, sampling, decimation and interpolation, discrete Fourier transforms and FFT algorithms, transversal and recursive filters, discrete random processes, and finite-word effects in digital filters.
EECS 250P.prereqString: Prerequisite: Recommended: Knowledge of digital signal processing (e.g. EECS 152A).
EECS 250P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

EECS 251A.name: Detection, Estimation, and Demodulation Theory
EECS 251A.description: Fundamentals of hypothesis testing and Bayes and Maximum Likelihood Estimation.  ARMA and state variable models for random time series analysis.  Wiener and Kalman filtering and prediction.  Adaptive algorithms for identification and tracking of parameters of time-varying models.

EECS 251B.name: Detection, Estimation, and Demodulation Theory
EECS 251B.description: Fundamentals of hypothesis testing and Bayes and Maximum Likelihood Estimation.  ARMA and state variable models for random time series analysis.  Wiener and Kalman filtering and prediction.  Adaptive algorithms for identification and tracking of parameters of time-varying models.

EECS 260A.name: Linear Systems I
EECS 260A.description: State-space representation of continuous-time and discrete-time linear systems. Controllability, observability, stability. Realization of rational transfer functions.

EECS 261A.name: Linear Optimization Methods
EECS 261A.description: Formulation, solution, and analysis of linear programming and linear network flow problems. Simplex methods, dual ascent methods, interior point algorithms, and auction algorithms. Duality theory and sensitivity analysis. Shortest path, max-flow, assignment, and minimum cost flow problems.

EECS 267A.name: Industrial and Power Electronics
EECS 267A.description: Power switching devices, pulse width modulation (PWM) methods, switching converter topologies, control, and magnetics. Materials fee.

EECS 267B.name: Topics in Industrial and Power Electronics
EECS 267B.description: Practical design of switching converters, electromagnetic compatibility, thermal management, and/or control methods.

EECS 270A.name: Advanced Analog Integrated Circuit Design I

EECS 270AP.name: Advanced Analog Integrated Circuit Design I
EECS 270AP.prereqString: Prerequisite: Recommended: Introductory knowledge of control systems (e.g. EECS 160A) and electronics (e.g. EECS 170C).
EECS 270AP.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

EECS 270B.name: Advanced Analog Integrated Circuit Design II

EECS 270BP.name: Advanced Analog Integrated Circuit Design II
EECS 270BP.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

EECS 270C.name: Design of Integrated Circuits for Broadband Applications
EECS 270C.description: Topics include: broadband standards and protocols

EECS 270E.name: High Frequency (Millimeter-Wave and Terahertz) Circuits
EECS 270E.description: Discussion of the new methodologies, circuits, and systems developed at mm-wave and terahertz frequency ranges due to the growing interest in high speed communication and high frequency signal generation.

EECS 272.name: Topics in Electrical Engineering
EECS 272.description: New research results in electronic system design.

EECS 272P.name: Radio-Frequency Integrated Circuit Design
EECS 272P.prereqString: Prerequisite: EECS 270AP. EECS 270AP with a grade of B or better
EECS 272P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

EECS 277A.name: Advanced Semiconductor Devices I
EECS 277A.description: Advanced complementary metal-oxide-semiconductor field-effect transistors (CMOSFET), device scaling, device modeling and fabrication, equivalent circuits, and their applications for digital, analog, RF.

EECS 277B.name: Advanced Semiconductor Devices II
EECS 277B.description: Metal-semiconductor field-effect transistors (MESFET), heterojunction bipolar transistors (HBT), microwave semiconductor devices, equivalent circuits, device modeling and fabrication, microwave amplifiers, transmitters, and receivers.

EECS 277C.name: Nanotechnology
EECS 277C.description: Fabrication and characterization techniques of electrical circuit elements at the nanometer scale. Quantized conductance, semiconductor quantum dots, single electron transistors, molecular wires, carbon nanotubes, self-assembly of nano-circuit elements, quantum methods of information processing.

EECS 278.name: Micro-System Design
EECS 278.description: Covers the fundamentals of the many disciplines needed for design of Micro-Electro-Mechanical Systems (MEMS): microfabrication technology, structural mechanics on micro-scale, electrostatics, circuit interface, control, computer-aided design, and system integration.

EECS 279.name: Micro-Sensors and Actuators
EECS 279.description: Introduction to the technology of Micro-Electro-Mechanical Systems (MEMS). Fundamental principles and applications of important microsensors, actuation principles on microscale.  Introduction to the elements of signal processing

EECS 280A.name: Advanced Engineering Electromagnetics I
EECS 280A.description: Stationary electromagnetic fields, Maxwell's equations, circuits and transmission lines, plane waves, guided waves, and radiation.

EECS 280B.name: Advanced Engineering Electromagnetics II
EECS 280B.description: Two- and three-dimensional boundary value problems, dielectric waveguides and other special waveguides, microwave networks and antenna arrays, electromagnetic properties of materials, and electromagnetic optics.

EECS 280P.name: Advanced Engineering Electromagnetics I
EECS 280P.description: Stationary electromagnetic fields, Maxwell's equations, circuits and transmission lines, plane waves, guided waves, and radiation.
EECS 280P.prereqString: Prerequisite: Recommended: Knowledge of engineering electromagnetics (e.g. EECS 180A).
EECS 280P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

EECS 282.name: Monolithic Microwave Integrated Circuit (MMIC) Analysis and Design II
EECS 282.description: Design of microwave amplifiers using computer-aided design tools. Covers low-noise amplifiers, multiple stage amplifiers, broadband amplifiers, and power amplifiers. Hybrid circuit design techniques including filters and baluns. Theory and design rules for microwave oscillator design.

EECS 284P.name: RF Antenna Design
EECS 284P.description: Advanced transmission line design, radiation of electromagnetic waves, dipole antennas, antenna arrays, advanced antenna designs, and practical design considerations in communications systems. Course is supplemented by RF design tools and modeling.
EECS 284P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

EECS 285A.name: Optical Communications
EECS 285A.description: Introduction to fiber optic communication systems, optical and electro-optic materials, and high-speed optical modulation and switching devices.

EECS 285B.name: Lasers and Photonics
EECS 285B.description: Covers the fundamentals of lasers and applications, including Gaussian beam propagation, interaction of optical radiation with matters, and concepts of optical gain and feedback. Applications are drawn from diverse fields of optical communication, signal processing, and material diagnosis.
EECS 285B.prereqString: Prerequisite: Undergraduate course work in electromagnetic theory and atomic physics.

EECS 285C.name: Nano Imaging
EECS 285C.description: Theory and practice of modern nanoscale imaging techniques and applications. Traces the development of microscopy from ancient times to modern day techniques used for visualizing the nano-world from atoms to molecules including hands-on experience in the laboratory.

EECS 285P.name: Optical Communications
EECS 285P.description: Introduction to fiber optic communication systems, optical and electro-optic materials, and high-speed optical modulation and switching devices.
EECS 285P.prereqString: Prerequisite: Undergraduate-level Engineering Electromagnetics I (e.g. EECS E80A).
EECS 285P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

EECS 286.name: Fabrication of Biomedical and Wearable Microdevices
EECS 286.description: Covers preliminary details on prototyping and fabrication techniques for biomedical and wearable microdevices. Fabrication and behavior of modern biomed device materials such as hydrogel, PDMS, biopolymer, smart materials, and their uses are introduced.
EECS 286.prereqString: Prerequisite: Required: Knowledge of undergraduate-level basic physics.

EECS 287.name: Micro/Nano Biotechnology and Biosensing: Fundamentals, Designs, and Applications
EECS 287.description: Provides an insight into the current topics in micro/nanoscience,.

EECS 289.name: Bioinstrumentation
EECS 289.description: Introduces instrumentation used in biomedical research, clinical medicine, and health monitoring. Interfacing of bioelectronics and biomedical sensing are taught with the most updated methods. The integration of bioinstrumentation with data science and cloud computing are introduced.

EECS 292.name: Preparation for M.S. Comprehensive Examination
EECS 292.description: Individual reading and preparation for the M.S. comprehensive examination.

EECS 293.name: Preparation for Ph.D. Preliminary Examination
EECS 293.description: Individual reading and preparation for the Ph.D. preliminary examination.

EECS 294.name: Electrical Engineering and Computer Science Colloquium
EECS 294.description: Invited speakers discuss their latest research results in electrical engineering and computer science.

EECS 295.name: Seminars in Engineering
EECS 295.description: Scheduled each year by individual faculty in major field of interest.

EECS 295P.name: Special Topics in Electrical Engineering and Computer Science
EECS 295P.description: Studies in selected areas of Electrical Engineering. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
EECS 295P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

EECS 296.name: Master of Science Thesis Research
EECS 296.description: Individual research or investigation conducted in the pursuit of preparing and completing the thesis required for the M.S. degree in Engineering.

EECS 297.name: Doctor of Philosophy Dissertation Research
EECS 297.description: Individual research or investigation conducted in preparing and completing the dissertation required for the Ph.D. degree in Engineering.

EECS 298.name: Topics in Electrical Engineering and Computer Science
EECS 298.description: Study of Electrical and Computer Engineering concepts.

EECS 299.name: Individual Research
EECS 299.description: Individual research or investigation under the direction of an individual faculty member.

ENGLISH 8.name: Multicultural American Literature
ENGLISH 8.description: Writings from at least two historically underrepresented groups in California and the United States with particular attention to historical conditions of literary production. Considers in-depth how literary works relate to racial constructions, economic conditions, and/or social movements.

ENGLISH 9.name: Shakespeare
ENGLISH 9.description: Plays by William Shakespeare are used to explore the playwright’s poetic gifts,  theatrical imagination, and inquiry into human relationships and the human condition.

ENGLISH 10.name: Topics in English and American Literature
ENGLISH 10.description: Explores the diversity of human expression manifested in selected works of literature. By engaging with substantial literary texts, students will think critically about how meaning is created and how experience is interpreted in literary language.

ENGLISH 10B.name: Topics in English and American Literature
ENGLISH 10B.description: Linked with Writing 39B. Explores the diversity of human expression manifested in selected works of literature. By engaging with substantial literary texts, students think critically about how meaning is created and how experience is interpreted in literary language.

ENGLISH 11.name: Society, Law, and Literature
ENGLISH 11.description: Examines how works of literature represent and influence the relation between law and society. The primary readings will be works of literature, but selections of works of law, politics, and sociology may also be assigned.

ENGLISH 11C.name: Society, Law, and Literature
ENGLISH 11C.description: Linked with Writing 39C. Explores how works of literature represent and influence the relation between law and society. The primary readings are works of literature, but selections of works of law, politics, and sociology may also be assigned.

ENGLISH 12.name: Young Adult Fiction
ENGLISH 12.description: Young adult fiction studied in historical context, including the publishing industry and mass marketing, as well as education and literacy. Primary readings will focus on young adult fiction, but works of history, advertising, and film will also be included.

ENGLISH 15.name: Introductory Seminar in English: Topics in Literary Studies
ENGLISH 15.description: Discussion-based seminar on a faculty-chosen topic that introduces majors and those considering a major in English to interpretive methodologies and critical frameworks that characterize the field of English studies.
ENGLISH 15.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
ENGLISH 15.restriction: Restriction: English Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGLISH 16.name: The Craft of Poetry
ENGLISH 16.description: Reading of selected texts to explore the ways in which these modes formulate experience. Students write several short analytic papers. Requires creative writing.
ENGLISH 16.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

ENGLISH 17.name: The Craft of Fiction
ENGLISH 17.description: Reading of selected texts to explore the ways in which these modes formulate experience. Students write several short analytic papers. Requires creative writing.
ENGLISH 17.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

ENGLISH H80.name: Sanctuary: Medieval and Modern
ENGLISH H80.description: Principles and significance of the practice of legal sanctuary in medieval English history, literature, and religion. Development of modern use of churches and other safe spaces in the American Civil Rights movement, immigrant sanctuary movements, and international asylum.
ENGLISH H80.restriction: Restriction: Campuswide Honors Collegium students only.

ENGLISH H81.name: What is a Person?
ENGLISH H81.description: Contemporary debates about personhood in law, culture, and society. Beginning with the emergence of ideas of personhood in philosophy and theology, and culminating in the study of highly contested cases: slavery, abortion law, animal rights, corporate personhood, and artificial intelligence.
ENGLISH H81.restriction: Restriction: Campuswide Honors Collegium students only.

ENGLISH 100.name: Introduction to Literary Theory
ENGLISH 100.description: Using Plato and Aristotle as points of departure, addresses a range of perspectives and problems in literary theory. To be taken by English majors in the junior year.
ENGLISH 100.prereqString: Prerequisite: Three courses selected from ENGLISH 8, ENGLISH 9, ENGLISH 10, ENGLISH 11, ENGLISH 12, ENGLISH 15, ENGLISH 16, ENGLISH 17, LIT JRN 20, LIT JRN 21.

ENGLISH 101W.name: Undergraduate Seminar in Critical Writing: Topics in Literary History
ENGLISH 101W.description: Each instructor identifies a topic within literary history
ENGLISH 101W.prereqString: Prerequisite: Three courses selected from ENGLISH 8, ENGLISH 9, ENGLISH 10, ENGLISH 11, ENGLISH 12, ENGLISH 15, ENGLISH 16, ENGLISH 17
ENGLISH 101W.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. English Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGLISH 102A.name: Topics in Medieval and Renaissance Literature
ENGLISH 102A.description: Studies of works representative of Medieval and Renaissance literature in English, with attention to literary history, treating at a minimum more than one author and more than one genre.
ENGLISH 102A.prereqString: Prerequisite: Three courses selected from ENGLISH 8, ENGLISH 9, ENGLISH 10, ENGLISH 11, ENGLISH 12, ENGLISH 15, ENGLISH 16, ENGLISH 17. Or LIT JRN 20 and LIT JRN 21 and one course selected from the above list.
ENGLISH 102A.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. English Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGLISH 102B.name: Topics in Restoration and 18th-Century Literature
ENGLISH 102B.description: Studies of works representative of Restoration and 18th-century literature in English, with attention to literary history, treating at a minimum more than one author and more than one genre.
ENGLISH 102B.prereqString: Prerequisite: Three courses selected from ENGLISH 8, ENGLISH 9, ENGLISH 10, ENGLISH 11, ENGLISH 12, ENGLISH 15, ENGLISH 16, ENGLISH 17. Or LIT JRN 20 and LIT JRN 21 and one course selected from the above list.
ENGLISH 102B.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. English Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGLISH 102C.name: Topics in Romantic and 19th-Century Literature
ENGLISH 102C.description: Studies of works representative of Romantic and 19th-century literature in English, with attention to literary history, treating at a minimum more than one author and more than one genre.
ENGLISH 102C.prereqString: Prerequisite: Three courses selected from ENGLISH 8, ENGLISH 9, ENGLISH 10, ENGLISH 11, ENGLISH 12, ENGLISH 15, ENGLISH 16, ENGLISH 17. Or LIT JRN 20 and LIT JRN 21 and one course selected from the above list.
ENGLISH 102C.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. English Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGLISH 102D.name: Topics in 20th-Century Literature
ENGLISH 102D.description: Studies of works representative of 20th-century literature in English, with attention to literary history, treating at a minimum more than one author and more than one genre.
ENGLISH 102D.prereqString: Prerequisite: Three courses selected from ENGLISH 8, ENGLISH 9, ENGLISH 10, ENGLISH 11, ENGLISH 12, ENGLISH 15, ENGLISH 16, ENGLISH 17. Or LIT JRN 20 and LIT JRN 21 and one course selected from the above list.
ENGLISH 102D.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. English Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGLISH 103.name: Topics in Literature, Theory, and Criticism
ENGLISH 103.description: A series of lectures on and discussions of announced topics in literary criticism, theory, history, genres, modes, major authors.
ENGLISH 103.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

ENGLISH 105.name: Multicultural Topics in Literatures in English
ENGLISH 105.description: Focuses on ethnic or minority literatures, or treats issues related to race and cultural identity.
ENGLISH 105.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

ENGLISH 106.name: Advanced Seminar: Topics in English Literature
ENGLISH 106.description: Capstone course. Provides intensive work on a topic within the area of literatures in English with particular attention to the theoretical, critical, or conceptual issues it raises, with the goal of producing a substantive research paper.
ENGLISH 106.prereqString: Prerequisite: (ENGLISH 101W or WRITING 101W) and (ENGLISH 100 and 102A) or (ENGLISH 100 and 102B) or (ENGLISH 100 and 102C) or (ENGLISH 100 and 102D) or (ENGLISH 102A and 102B) or (ENGLISH 102A and 102C) or (ENGLISH 102A and 102D) or (ENGLISH 102B and 102C) or (ENGLISH 102C and 102D) or (ENGLISH 103 and 102A) or (ENGLISH 103 and 102B) or (ENGLISH 103 and 102C) or (ENGLISH 103 and 102D) or (ENGLISH 105 and 102A) or (ENGLISH 105 and 102B) or (ENGLISH 105 and 102C) or (ENGLISH 105 and 102D) or (ENGLISH 100 and 103) or (ENGLISH 103 and 105) or (ENGLISH 100 and 105).
ENGLISH 106.restriction: Restriction: Seniors only. English Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGLISH 160.name: Topics in English Language Film and TV
ENGLISH 160.description: Focuses on the analysis of film and/or television traditions in the English-speaking world, from a historical, theoretical, or comparative perspective.
ENGLISH 160.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

ENGLISH 198.name: Special Topics
ENGLISH 198.description: Directed group study of selected topics as arranged by instructor.

ENGLISH 199.name: Independent Study
ENGLISH 199.description: To be taken only when the materials to be studied lie outside the normal run of departmental offerings, and when the student will have no formal chance to pursue the subject. Research paper required.

ENGLISH 210.name: Studies in Literary History
ENGLISH 210.description: Studies in selected areas of literary history. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

ENGLISH 225.name: Studies in Literary Genres
ENGLISH 225.description: Studies in selected areas of literary genres. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

ENGLISH 230.name: Studies in Major Writers
ENGLISH 230.description: Studies in selected areas of major writers. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

ENGLISH 255.name: Graduate Workshop in Academic Publishing
ENGLISH 255.description: Reading and critique of student-authored essays with the goal of producing a publishable essay. Instructor leads discussion, meets with students individually, and provides an introduction to appropriate venues for publication and the process of submission, peer review, and revision.

ENGLISH 290.name: Reading and Conference
ENGLISH 290.description: Studies in selected areas. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

ENGLISH 291.name: Guided Reading Course
ENGLISH 291.description: Studies in selected areas. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

ENGLISH 299.name: Dissertation Research
ENGLISH 299.description: A units-only course for students in the dissertation phase.

ENGLISH 398.name: Rhetoric/Teaching of Composition
ENGLISH 398.description: Readings, lectures, and internship designed to prepare graduate students to teach composition. Formal instruction in rhetoric and practical work in teaching methods and grading.

ENGLISH 399.name: University Teaching
ENGLISH 399.description: A units-only course for students appointed as teaching assistants or associates.

ENGR 1A.name: General Chemistry for Engineers
ENGR 1A.description: Emphasis on solid-state chemistry. Quantum theory, atomic structure, periodic trends, chemical bonding, molecular orbitals, electronic band structure, gases, liquids, intermolecular forces, unit cells, crystal lattices, phase transformations, and electrochemistry.
ENGR 1A.prereqString: Prerequisite: AP Chemistry or SAT Subject Chemistry or SAT Mathematics or ACT Mathematics. AP Chemistry with a minimum score of 3. SAT Subject Chemistry with a minimum score of 600. SAT Mathematics with a minimum score of 600. ACT Mathematics with a minimum score of 27. A score of 85 or higher on the Engineering Chemistry Placement Exam (fee required) is also accepted.
ENGR 1A.restriction: Restriction: Electrical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Mechanical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Aerospace Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Civil Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Materials Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGR 7A.name: Introduction to Engineering I
ENGR 7A.description: Introduction to engineering disciplines and the design process. Students enrolled in the online lecture also attend a three-hour lab on campus. Materials fee.
ENGR 7A.restriction: Restriction: Lower-division students only. School of Engineering students have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGR 7B.name: Introduction to Engineering II
ENGR 7B.description: Introduction to engineering disciplines and the design process. Students enrolled in the online lecture also attend a three-hour lab on campus. Materials fee.
ENGR 7B.restriction: Restriction: Lower-division students only. School of Engineering students have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGR 30.name: Statics
ENGR 30.description: Addition and resolution of forces, distributed forces, equivalent system of forces centroids, first moments, moments and products on inertia, equilibrium of rigid bodies, trusses, beams, cables.  Course may be offered online.
ENGR 30.prereqString:
Corequisite: MATH 2D
Prerequisite: MATH 2D and PHYS 7C
ENGR 30.restriction: Restriction: School of Engineering students have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGR 54.name: Principles of Materials Science and Engineering
ENGR 54.description: Superconductors to biodegradable polymers. Structure and properties of materials, including metal, ceramics, polymers, semiconductors, composites, traditional materials. Atomic structure, bonding, defects, phase equilibria, mechanical properties, electrical, optical and magnetic properties. Introduction to materials processing and synthesis. Materials fee.
ENGR 54.prereqString: Prerequisite: (ENGR 1A or CHEM 1A or CHEM H2A) and PHYS 7C
ENGR 54.restriction: Restriction: School of Engineering students have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGR 80.name: Dynamics
ENGR 80.description: Introduction to the kinematics and dynamics of particles and rigid bodies. The Newton-Euler, Work/Energy, and Impulse/Momentum methods are explored for ascertaining the dynamics of particles and rigid bodies. An engineering design problem using these fundamental principles is also undertaken.
ENGR 80.restriction: Restriction: Mechanical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Aerospace Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Civil Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Materials Science and Engr Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGR 92.name: Engineering and Computer Educational Laboratory
ENGR 92.description: Comprehensive academic support designed primarily for underrepresented or underprepared students in Engineering, ICS, or selected areas of the physical sciences. Typical program activities: tutoring, study skills, career planning, self-esteem enhancement, library research techniques.

ENGR 93.name: Public and Professional Service in Engineering
ENGR 93.description: Student participation in public and professional service activities related to engineering.

ENGR 98.name: Group Study
ENGR 98.description: Group study of selected topics in engineering.

ENGR 100.name: Special Topics in Fabrication Safety
ENGR 100.description: Hands on training in the safe use of item fabrication: metalworking, woodworking, electronics fabrication, composites, welding, adhesives, water disposal, and others. Safety certification will be granted from this course and is required for access to Engineering School fabrication facilities.
ENGR 100.restriction: Restriction: School of Engineering students have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGR 150.name: Mechanics of Structures
ENGR 150.description: Stresses and strains. Torsion. Bending. Beam deflection.  Shear force and moment distributions in beams. Yielding and buckling of columns. Combined loading. Transformation of stresses and strain. Yielding criteria. Finite elements analysis of frames. Dynamic of two-bar truss.
ENGR 150.prereqString: Prerequisite: (CEE 30 or ENGR 30 or MAE 30) and MATH 3A
ENGR 150.restriction: Restriction: Mechanical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Aerospace Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Chemical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Materials Science and Engr Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGR 165.name: Advanced Manufacturing
ENGR 165.description: Principles in manufacturing processes. All machining requires energy: mechanical (cutting and shaping), heat energy (laser cutting), photochemical (photolithography), chemical energy (electro chemical machining and chemical vapor deposition). These methods and their fundamentals are examined.  Materials fee.
ENGR 165.restriction: Restriction: Seniors only. School of Engineering students only.

ENGR 180.name: Entrepreneurship for Scientists and Engineers
ENGR 180.description: Learn the theory and practice of entrepreneurship and intrapreneurship. Covers positioning an idea, establishing the value propositions and benefits case, going to market strategy, creating an execution plan, and raising funds. Concepts are applied to a real-world venture project.
ENGR 180.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. School of Engineering students have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGR 189.name: Senior Project - Topics Vary
ENGR 189.description: Multidisciplinary group senior project of theoretical or applied nature involving design.

ENGR 190W.name: Communications in the Professional World
ENGR 190W.description: Upper-division technical writing course including the development of presentation skills. Effective communication with a range of audiences. Recognition of ethical and professional responsibilities for engineers.
ENGR 190W.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
ENGR 190W.restriction: Restriction: School of Engineering students only. Graduating seniors with an application on file have first consideration.

ENGR 191.name: Curricular Practical Training
ENGR 191.description: Practical training under an industry mentor in a technical field corresponding to students' area of interest.

ENGR 195.name: Special Topics in Engineering
ENGR 195.description: Studies in selected areas of Engineering. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

ENGR 196W.name: Engineering Thesis
ENGR 196W.description: Preparation of final presentation and paper describing individual research in Engineering completed in one or more quarters of individual study (i.e., ENGR 199).
ENGR 196W.prereqString: Prerequisite: Completion of at least 4 units of Individual Research in Engineering. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

ENGR H196W.name: Honors Thesis
ENGR H196W.description: Preparation of final presentation and paper describing individual research in Engineering. For participants in the Campuswide Honors Program.
ENGR H196W.prereqString: Prerequisite: ENGR H199. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
ENGR H196W.restriction: Restriction: Campuswide Honors Collegium students only.

ENGR 199.name: Individual Study
ENGR 199.description: Supervised independent reading, research, or design for undergraduate Engineering majors. Students taking individual study for design credit are to submit a written paper to the instructor and to the Undergraduate Student Affairs Office in the School of Engineering.
ENGR 199.restriction: Restriction: School of Engineering students only.

ENGR 199P.name: Individual Study
ENGR 199P.description: Supervised independent reading, research, or design for undergraduate Engineering majors. Students taking individual study for design credit are to submit a written paper to the instructor and to the Undergraduate Student Affairs Office in the School of Engineering.

ENGR H199.name: Individual Study for Honors Students
ENGR H199.description: Supervised research in Engineering for participants in the Campuswide Honors Program. Students taking individual study for design credit are to submit a written paper to the instructor and to the Undergraduate Student Affairs Office in the School of Engineering.
ENGR H199.restriction: Restriction: Campuswide Honors Collegium students only.

ENGR 200AP.name: Engineering Leadership and Entrepreneurship: Innovation
ENGR 200AP.description: Teaches concepts on how to develop innovate/disruptive ideas through actual delivery and adoption. Focuses on the critical thinking skills, the process of developing an idea into a product/service, and teaching a framework to foster adoption of the idea and product.
ENGR 200AP.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

ENGR 200BP.name: Engineering Leadership and Entrepreneurship: Build
ENGR 200BP.description: Learn how to build an executable plan to transform an idea into a product. Learn how to construct a go-to market plan, raise funds for building the product, and leverage ecosystem resources to fill in resource gaps.
ENGR 200BP.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

ENGR 200CP.name: Engineering Leadership and Entrepreneurship: Launch
ENGR 200CP.description: Understand how to build an actual product. Learn about prototyping and basic project management skills. Learn a framework on when to pivot for course corrections. Identify how to define outcome metrics and measure progress as the product is launched.
ENGR 200CP.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

ENGR 210P.name: Capstone Project
ENGR 210P.description: Students are required to complete a project that deals with a specific emphasis of their Master of Engineering concentration/specialization.
ENGR 210P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

ENGR 211P.name: M.Eng Proseminar
ENGR 211P.description: Provides students in the Master of Engineering program with information and.
ENGR 211P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

ENGR 265.name: Advanced Manufacturing
ENGR 265.description: Principles in manufacturing processes. All machining requires energy: mechanical (cutting and shaping), heat energy (laser cutting), photochemical (photolithography), chemical energy (electro chemical machining and chemical vapor deposition). These methods and their fundamentals are examined. Materials fee.
ENGR 265.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. School of Engineering students only.

ENGR 280.name: Entrepreneurship for Scientists and Engineers
ENGR 280.description: Learn the theory and practice of entrepreneurship and intrapreneurship. Covers positioning an idea, establishing the value propositions and benefits case, going to market strategy, creating an execution plan, and raising funds. Concepts are applied to a real-world venture project.
ENGR 280.restriction: Restriction: School of Engineering students have first consideration for enrollment. Graduate students only.

ENGR 290.name: Developing Teaching Excellence
ENGR 290.description: Introduces the Scholarship of Teaching and Learning (SoTL) as it applies to Engineering Education. Focuses on how teaching practice can be guided by the research literature on teaching and learning.

ENGR 290P.name: M.Eng Internship
ENGR 290P.description: Students go through practical training under an industry mentor in a technical field corresponding to their area of interest.
ENGR 290P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

ENGR 291.name: Internship
ENGR 291.description: Practical training under an industry mentor in a technical field corresponding to the student's area of interest.

ENGR 295.name: Special Topics in Engineering
ENGR 295.description: Studies in selected areas of Engineering. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

ENGR 296.name: Master of Science Thesis Research
ENGR 296.description: Individual research or investigation conducted in the pursuit of preparing and completing the thesis required for the M.S. in Engineering.

ENGR 297.name: Doctor of Philosophy Dissertation Research
ENGR 297.description: Individual research or or investigation conducted in the pursuit of preparing and completing the dissertation required for the Ph.D. in Engineering.

ENGR 299.name: Individual Research
ENGR 299.description: Individual research or investigation under the direction of an individual faculty.

ENGRCEE 11.name: Methods II: Probability and Statistics
ENGRCEE 11.description: Modeling and analysis of engineering problems under uncertainty. Engineering applications of probability and statistical concepts and methods.
ENGRCEE 11.prereqString: Prerequisite: (ENGRCEE 20 or EECS 10 or EECS 12 or ENGRMAE 10 or I&C SCI 31) and MATH 3A
ENGRCEE 11.restriction: Restriction: Civil Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRCEE 20.name: Introduction to Computational Problem Solving
ENGRCEE 20.description: Introduction to computer programming within a numerical computing environment (MATLAB or similar) including types of data representation, graphical display of data, and development of modular programs with application to engineering analysis and problem solving.
ENGRCEE 20.restriction: Restriction: Civil Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRCEE 21.name: Computational Problem Solving
ENGRCEE 21.description: Engineering analysis and problem solving using MATLAB (or similar), including matrix algebra, solving systems of linear and nonlinear equations, numerical integration of ordinary differential equations (ODEs) and coupled ODEs, and analysis of numerical errors.
ENGRCEE 21.prereqString:
Corequisite: MATH 3D
Prerequisite: (ENGRCEE 20 or BME 60B) and (MATH 3A or I&C SCI 6N)
ENGRCEE 21.restriction: Restriction: Civil Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRCEE 30.name: Statics
ENGRCEE 30.description: Addition and resolution of forces, distributed forces, equivalent system of forces centroids, first moments, moments and products on inertia, equilibrium of rigid bodies, trusses, beams, cables.  Course may be offered online.
ENGRCEE 30.prereqString:
Corequisite: MATH 2D
Prerequisite: MATH 2D and PHYSICS 7C
ENGRCEE 30.restriction: Restriction: School of Engineering students have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRCEE 40.name: Fundamentals of Economic Analysis for Scientists and Engineers
ENGRCEE 40.description: Introduction to microeconomics and cost benefit analysis. Integration of economic, social, and behavioral considerations into the engineering design process. Applications to contemporary problems via case studies.

ENGRCEE 60.name: Contemporary and Emerging Environmental Challenges
ENGRCEE 60.description: Introduces contemporary and emerging environmental challenges, illustrates links between human behavior, environmental policy, and engineering practices, examines policy options in the context of current institutions, and introduces tools and frameworks to reach sound economic, social, and environmental solutions.

ENGRCEE 80.name: Dynamics
ENGRCEE 80.description: Introduction to the kinematics and dynamics of particles and rigid bodies. The Newton-Euler, Work/Energy, and Impulse/Momentum methods are explored for ascertaining the dynamics of particles and rigid bodies. An engineering design problem using these fundamental principles is also undertaken.
ENGRCEE 80.restriction: Restriction: Mechanical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Aerospace Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Civil Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Materials Science and Engr Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRCEE 81A.name: Civil Engineering Practicum I
ENGRCEE 81A.description: Introduction to civil engineering through presentations on structural, environmental, water, and transportation systems. Introduction to graphics. Graphical visualization and communication using hand and computer sketching. Fundamentals of Computer Aided Design (CAD) using AutoCad. Laboratory sessions. Materials fee.
ENGRCEE 81A.restriction: Restriction: Civil Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRCEE 81B.name: Civil Engineering Practicum II
ENGRCEE 81B.restriction: Restriction: Civil Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRCEE 110.name: Methods III:  Modeling, Economics, and Management
ENGRCEE 110.description: Analysis, modeling, and management of civil engineering systems. Statistics and system performance studies, probabilistic models and simulation, basic economics and capital investments, project elements and organization, managerial concepts and network technique, project scheduling. Emphasis on real-world examples. Laboratory sessions.
ENGRCEE 110.restriction: Restriction: Civil Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRCEE 111.name: Methods IV: Systems Analysis and Decision-Making
ENGRCEE 111.description: Analysis and optimization for decision-making in civil and infrastructural systems. Topics include linear programming formulations and solution algorithms, network models, and logistical models. Emphasis is on project-level and managerial decision-making and selection from alternative designs.
ENGRCEE 111.prereqString: Prerequisite: (MATH 3A or I&C SCI 6N) and MATH 3D
ENGRCEE 111.restriction: Restriction: Civil Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRCEE 114.name: GIS for Civil and Environmental Engineering
ENGRCEE 114.description: GIS for CEE provides an introduction to Geographic Information Systems (GIS) and their various applications in civil and environmental engineering. Topics include GIS data formats, data queries, spatial and attribute data, spatial data analysis, coordinate systems, and raster data analysis.

ENGRCEE 121.name: Transportation Systems I: Analysis and Design
ENGRCEE 121.description: Introduction to analysis and design of fundamental transportation system components, basic elements of geometric and pavement design, vehicle flow and elementary traffic, basic foundations of transportation planning and forecasting. Laboratory sessions.
ENGRCEE 121.restriction: Restriction: Civil Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRCEE 122.name: Transportation Systems II: Operations and Control
ENGRCEE 122.description: Introduction to fundamentals of urban traffic engineering, including data collection, analysis, and design. Traffic engineering studies, traffic flow theory, traffic control devices, traffic signals, capacity and level of service analysis of freeways and urban streets. Laboratory sessions.
ENGRCEE 122.restriction: Restriction: Civil Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRCEE 123.name: Transportation Systems III: Planning and Forecasting
ENGRCEE 123.description: Theoretical foundations of transportation planning, design, and analysis methods. Theory and application of aggregate and disaggregate models for land use development, trip generation, destination, mode, and route choice. Transportation network analysis. Planning, design, and evaluation of system alternatives.
ENGRCEE 123.restriction: Restriction: Civil Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRCEE 124.name: Transportation Systems IV: Freeway Operations and Control
ENGRCEE 124.description: Fundamentals of traffic on urban freeways, including data collection analysis, and design. Traffic engineering studies, traffic flow theory, freeway traffic control devices, capacity, and level of service analysis of freeways and highways. Laboratory sessions.
ENGRCEE 124.restriction: Restriction: Civil Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRCEE 125.name: Transportation and the Environment
ENGRCEE 125.description: Analysis of the impacts of motor vehicle transportation on the environment. Introduction to life cycle analysis applied to transportation. Basic economic tools for transportation externalities. Transportation planning, urban form, health, and the environment. Transportation sustainability.
ENGRCEE 125.restriction: Restriction: Civil Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRCEE 130.name: Soil Mechanics
ENGRCEE 130.description: Mechanics of soils, composition and classification of soils, compaction, compressibility and consolidation, shear strength, seepage, bearing capacity, lateral earth pressure, retaining walls, piles.
ENGRCEE 130.prereqString:
Corequisite: ENGRCEE 130L
Prerequisite: ENGRCEE 150 and ENGRCEE 170
ENGRCEE 130.restriction: Restriction: Civil Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRCEE 130L.name: Soil Mechanics Laboratory
ENGRCEE 130L.description: Laboratory procedures of soil testing for engineering problems.  Materials fee.
ENGRCEE 130L.restriction: Restriction: Civil Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRCEE 149.name: Introduction to Earthquake Engineering
ENGRCEE 149.description: Plate tectonics. Structural dynamics. Earthquake magnitude, intensity, and frequency. Seismic damage to structures. Earthquake load prediction including response spectra, normal mode, and direct integration techniques. The basis of building code earthquake load requirements for buildings.
ENGRCEE 149.prereqString: Prerequisite: ENGRCEE 11 and ENGRCEE 20 and ENGRCEE 151A
ENGRCEE 149.restriction: Restriction: Civil Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRCEE 150.name: Mechanics of Materials
ENGRCEE 150.description: Stresses and strains, strain-stress diagrams, axial deformations, torsion, bending and shear stresses in beams, shear force and bending moment diagrams, combined stresses, principal stresses, Mohr's circle, deflection of beams, columns.
ENGRCEE 150.prereqString: Prerequisite: ENGRCEE 30 or ENGRMAE 30 or ENGR 30. ENGRCEE 30 with a grade of C- or better. ENGRMAE 30 with a grade of C- or better. ENGR 30 with a grade of C- or better
ENGRCEE 150.restriction: Restriction: Civil Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRCEE 150L.name: Mechanics of Materials Laboratory
ENGRCEE 150L.description: Experimental methods and fundamentals for mechanics of materials analysis.  Materials fee.
ENGRCEE 150L.restriction: Restriction: Civil Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRCEE 151A.name: Structural Analysis
ENGRCEE 151A.description: Fundamentals of structural analysis and loading. Deformation of statically determinate and indeterminate structures. Influence lines. Structural systems.
ENGRCEE 151A.restriction: Restriction: Civil Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRCEE 151B.name: Structural Timber Design
ENGRCEE 151B.description: Design of timber structures. Beams, columns, beam-columns, roof, and connections.
ENGRCEE 151B.restriction: Restriction: Civil Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRCEE 151C.name: Reinforced Concrete Design
ENGRCEE 151C.description: Ultimate strength design. Design of reinforced concrete beam sections. Design for shear and deflection. Design of columns. Design of isolated and combined footings. Laboratory sessions.   Materials fee.
ENGRCEE 151C.restriction: Restriction: Civil Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRCEE 152.name: Computer Methods in Structural Analysis and Design
ENGRCEE 152.description: Matrix techniques for indeterminate framed structures. Computer implementation using the stiffness method. Software packages for design of reinforced concrete, steel, and/or timber structures.
ENGRCEE 152.restriction: Restriction: Civil Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRCEE 155.name: Structural Steel Design
ENGRCEE 155.description: Design in steel of tension members, beams, columns, welded and bolted connections
ENGRCEE 155.restriction: Restriction: Civil Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRCEE 156.name: Foundation Design
ENGRCEE 156.description: Applications of soil mechanics principles to the analysis and design of shallow foundations, retaining walls, pile foundations, and braced cuts. Design criteria: bearing capacity, working loads and tolerable settlements, structural integrity of the foundation element. Damage from construction operations.
ENGRCEE 156.restriction: Restriction: Civil Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRCEE 160.name: Environmental Processes
ENGRCEE 160.description: Introduction to environmental processes in air and water, mass balances, and transport phenomena. Fundamentals of water-quality engineering including water and wastewater treatment.
ENGRCEE 160.prereqString: Prerequisite: (CHEM 1B or CHEM H2B) and ENGRCEE 170
ENGRCEE 160.restriction: Restriction: Civil Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Chemical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRCEE 162.name: Introduction to Environmental Chemistry
ENGRCEE 162.description: Basic concepts from general, physical, and analytical chemistry as they relate to environmental engineering. Particular emphasis on the fundamentals of equilibrium and kinetics as they apply to acid-base chemistry, gas solubility, and redox reactions. Laboratory sessions.  Materials fee.
ENGRCEE 162.prereqString: Prerequisite: (ENGR 1A or CHEM 1A or CHEM H2A) and (CHEM 1B or CHEM H2B) and (CHEM 1LC or CHEM 1LE or CHEM H2LB or CHEM M2LB) and (CHEM 51A or CHEM H52A)
ENGRCEE 162.restriction: Restriction: Chemical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRCEE 163.name: Wastewater Treatment Process Design
ENGRCEE 163.description: Design of biological treatment processes. Topics include attached and suspended growth, aeration, anaerobic systems, process control, and economics. Design projects included.   Materials fee.
ENGRCEE 163.restriction: Restriction: Civil Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Chemical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRCEE 164.name: Carbon and Energy Footprint Analysis
ENGRCEE 164.description: Process design for wastewater treatment. Mass- and energy-balance analysis applied to water and wastewater treatment systems. Case studies include analysis of water supply, treatment, reclamation, and reuse.
ENGRCEE 164.restriction: Restriction: Civil Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRCEE 165.name: Physical-Chemical Treatment Processes
ENGRCEE 165.description: Theory and dynamics of physical and chemical separation processes in water and wastewater treatment. Topics include coagulation, sedimentation, filtration, gas-transfer, membrane separations, and adsorption.
ENGRCEE 165.restriction: Restriction: Civil Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRCEE 169.name: Environmental Microbiology for Engineers
ENGRCEE 169.description: Fundamental and applied principles of microbiology. Structures and functions of microorganisms, the microbiology of water, wastewater and soil used in environmental engineering, and the impact of microorganisms on human and environmental health.
ENGRCEE 169.restriction: Restriction: Civil Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRCEE 170.name: Introduction to Fluid Mechanics
ENGRCEE 170.prereqString:
Corequisite: MATH 2E and ENGRCEE 20
Prerequisite: PHYSICS 7C
ENGRCEE 170.restriction: Restriction: Civil Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRCEE 171.name: Water Resources Engineering
ENGRCEE 171.description: Principles governing the analysis and design of water resource systems including pressurized pipelines, pipe networks, channels, and ground water. Coverage of fluid mass, momentum and energy conservation, flow resistance, and related laboratory measurements in different systems. Materials fee.
ENGRCEE 171.restriction: Restriction: Chemical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Civil Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRCEE 172.name: Groundwater Hydrology
ENGRCEE 172.description: Topics include conservation of fluid mass, storage properties of porous media, matrix compressibility, boundary conditions, flow nets, well hydraulics, groundwater chemistry, and solute transport. Design projects and computer applications included.
ENGRCEE 172.prereqString: Prerequisite: ENGRCEE 170 or ENGRMAE 130A or CBE 120A
ENGRCEE 172.restriction: Restriction: Civil Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Chemical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRCEE 173.name: Watershed Modeling
ENGRCEE 173.description: Basic principles of hydrologic modeling are practiced. Concepts of watershed delineation, land use change impact, design studies, and GIS tools are discussed. Focus on the USACE (HEC) software tools (HEC-HMS, and HEC-RAS) along with their associated GIS interfaces.
ENGRCEE 173.restriction: Restriction: Civil Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRCEE 176.name: Hydrology
ENGRCEE 176.description: Elements of the hydrologic cycle including precipitation, infiltration, evapotranspiration, ground water, and runoff. Unit Hydrograph theory and routing methods. Introduction to precipitation/runoff relationship and watershed modeling. Statistical methods and flood frequency analysis.
ENGRCEE 176.restriction: Restriction: Civil Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRCEE 178.name: Fluid Mechanics of Open Channels
ENGRCEE 178.description: Fundamentals of fluid motion in open channels. Navier-Stokes equations and one-dimensional momentum and energy principles. Topics include rapidly varied flow, flow resistance and turbulence, gradually varied flow, unsteady flow, and computational methods for channel flow modeling.
ENGRCEE 178.prereqString: Prerequisite: (ENGRCEE 20 or BME 60B or ENGRMAE 10) and (ENGRCEE 170 or ENGRMAE 130A or CBE 120A)
ENGRCEE 178.restriction: Restriction: Civil Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRCEE 181A.name: Senior Design Practicum I
ENGRCEE 181A.description: Team designs land development project including infrastructural, environmental, circulation aspects. Focus on traffic impact studies, design of roads, geometry, signals, geotechnical and hydrological analysis, design of structural elements, economic analysis. Oral/Written interim and final design reports. Laboratory sessions.
ENGRCEE 181A.prereqString: Prerequisite: ENGRCEE 81A and ENGRCEE 81B and ENGRCEE 110 and (ENGRCEE 121 or ENGRCEE 151C or ENGRCEE 162 or ENGRCEE 171). ENGRCEE 181A and ENGRCEE 181B and ENGRCEE 181C must be taken in the same academic year.
ENGRCEE 181A.restriction: Restriction: Seniors only. Civil Engineering Majors only. Environmental Engineering Majors only.

ENGRCEE 181B.name: Senior Design Practicum II
ENGRCEE 181B.description: Team designs land development project including infrastructural, environmental, circulation aspects. Focus on traffic impact studies, design of roads, geometry, signals, geotechnical and hydrological analysis, design of structural elements, economic analysis. Oral/Written interim and final design reports. Laboratory sessions.
ENGRCEE 181B.prereqString:
Corequisite: ENGRCEE 130
Prerequisite: ENGRENGRCEE 181A. CEE 181A and ENGRCEE 181B and ENGRCEE 181C must be taken in the same academic year.
ENGRCEE 181B.restriction: Restriction: Seniors only. Civil Engineering Majors only. Environmental Engineering Majors only.

ENGRCEE 181C.name: Senior Design Practicum III
ENGRCEE 181C.description: Team designs land development project including infrastructural, environmental, circulation aspects. Focus on traffic impact studies, design of roads, geometry, signals, geotechnical and hydrological analysis, design of structural elements, economic analysis. Oral/Written interim and final design reports. Laboratory sessions.
ENGRCEE 181C.prereqString: Prerequisite: ENGRENGRCEE 181B. ENGRCEE 181A and CEE 181B and ENGRCEE 181C must be taken in the same academic year.
ENGRCEE 181C.restriction: Restriction: Seniors only. Civil Engineering Majors only. Environmental Engineering Majors only.

ENGRCEE 195.name: Special Topics in Civil and Environmental Engineering
ENGRCEE 195.description: Studies in selected areas of Civil and Environmental Engineering. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

ENGRCEE 198.name: Group Study
ENGRCEE 198.description: Group study of selected topics in Civil and Environmental Engineering.

ENGRCEE 199.name: Individual Study
ENGRCEE 199.description: For undergraduate Engineering majors in supervised but independent reading, research, or design. Students taking individual study for design credit are to submit a written paper to the instructor and to the Undergraduate Student Affairs Office in the School of Engineering.

ENGRCEE 199P.name: Individual Study
ENGRCEE 199P.description: Supervised independent reading, research, or design for undergraduate Engineering majors. Students taking individual study for design credit are to submit a written paper to the instructor and to the Undergraduate Student Affairs Office in the School of Engineering.

ENGRCEE 214.name: GIS for Civil and Environmental Engineering
ENGRCEE 214.description: GIS for CEE provides an introduction to Geographic Information Systems (GIS) and their various applications in civil and environmental engineering. Topics include GIS data formats, data queries, spatial and attribute data, spatial data analysis, coordinate systems, raster data analysis.

ENGRCEE 220A.name: Travel Demand Analysis I
ENGRCEE 220A.description: Fundamentals of transportation systems analysis. Theoretical aspects of travel demand. Travel behavior. Modeling of performance characteristics and costs of transportation modes. In-depth presentation of travel demand modeling techniques. Development of travel choice models including mode, route, and destination choice. Equilibrium.

ENGRCEE 220B.name: Travel Demand Analysis II
ENGRCEE 220B.description: Methods of discrete choice analysis and their applications in the modeling of transportation systems. Emphasis on the development of a sound understanding of theoretical aspects of discrete choice modeling that are useful in many applications in travel demand analysis.

ENGRCEE 220C.name: Travel Demand Analysis III: Activity-based Approaches
ENGRCEE 220C.description: The methodological underpinnings of activity-based travel demand modeling.  Presents methodologies within the context of a generalization of discrete choice modeling approaches, emphasizing the distinctions that separtate these two approaches and presenting appropriate mathematical and statistical tools to address these distinctions.

ENGRCEE 221A.name: Transportation Systems Analysis I
ENGRCEE 221A.description: Introduction to mathematical methods and models to address logistics and urban transportation problems. Techniques include stochastic models, queueing theory, linear programming, and introductory non-linear optimization.

ENGRCEE 221B.name: Transportation Systems Analysis II
ENGRCEE 221B.description: Advanced mathematical methods and models to address logistics and urban transportation problems. Topics include network flows, advanced optimization techniques, network models, and heuristic algorithms.

ENGRCEE 222.name: Transit Systems Planning
ENGRCEE 222.description: Planning methods for public transportation in urban areas. Technological and operating characteristics of vehicles, facilities, and systems.  Short-range planning techniques: data collection and analysis, demand analysis, mode choice, operational strategies, financial analysis.  Design of systems to improve performance.

ENGRCEE 223.name: Transportation Systems III: Planning and Forecasting
ENGRCEE 223.description: Theoretical foundations of transportation planning, design, and analysis methods. Theory and application of aggregate and disaggregate models for land use development, trip generation, destination, mode, and route choice. Transportation network analysis. Planning, design, and evaluation of system alternatives.

ENGRCEE 224A.name: Transportation Data Analysis I
ENGRCEE 224A.description: Statistical analysis of transportation data sources. Analysis of categorical and ordinal data. Regression and advanced multivariate analysis methods such as discriminant analysis, canonical correlation, and factor analysis. Sampling techniques, sample error and bias, survey instrument design.

ENGRCEE 225B.name: Transportation Planning Models II
ENGRCEE 225B.description: Design and application of comprehensive transportation models. Network development, demand modeling, and equilibrium assignment. Model calibration, validation, prediction, and evaluation. Regional modeling, site impact analysis, and circulation studies. Design of transportation alternatives.

ENGRCEE 226A.name: Traffic Flow Theory I
ENGRCEE 226A.description: Traffic measurement and fundamental speed-density-flow relationships. Kinematic models. Shock waves. Statistical-kinetic theory of traffic. Introductory car-following principles and stability. Gap acceptance. Platoon dispersion.  Two-fluid model. Queueing process. Multi-regime and catastrophe models.  Higher-order continuum models. Microscopic and macroscopic simulation.

ENGRCEE 226B.name: Traffic Flow Theory II
ENGRCEE 226B.description: Advanced mathematical analysis of vehicular flow. Detailed treatise on car-following models. Fourier and Laplace analysis of stability problems. Perturbation analysis. Derivation of macroscopic traffic flow relationships from microscopic considerations. Advanced hydrodynamic theory.

ENGRCEE 228A.name: Urban Transportation Networks I
ENGRCEE 228A.description: Analytical approaches and algorithms to the formulation and solution of the equilibrium assignment problem for transportation networks. Emphasis on user equilibrium (UE) comparison with system optimal, mathematical programming formulation, supply functions, estimation. Estimating origin-destination matrices, network design problems.

ENGRCEE 228B.name: Urban Transportation Networks II
ENGRCEE 228B.description: Advanced analysis, optimization, and modeling of transportation networks. Topics include advanced static and dynamic traffic assignment algorithms, linear and nonlinear multi-commodity network flow optimization, network simplex, and network control problems.

ENGRCEE 229A.name: Traffic Systems Operations and Control I
ENGRCEE 229A.description: Introduction to operation, control, and analysis of arterial and freeway traffic systems.  Control concepts, traffic stream principles, detectors, local controllers, system masters, traffic signal and ramp metering timing principles, traffic measurement technologies, traffic delay principles.

ENGRCEE 229B.name: Traffic Systems Operations and Control II
ENGRCEE 229B.description: Advanced topics related to operation, control, and analysis of arterial and freeway traffic systems. Control concepts, traffic stream principles, detectors, local controllers, system masters, traffic signal and ramp metering timing principles.

ENGRCEE 231.name: Foundation Engineering
ENGRCEE 231.description: Essentials for design and analysis of structural members that transmit superstructure loads to the ground. Topics include subsurface investigations, excavation, dewatering, bracing, footing, mat foundations, piles and pile foundations, caissons and cofferdams, other special foundations.

ENGRCEE 232.name: Geotech Earthquake Engineering
ENGRCEE 232.description: In-situ and laboratory determination of dynamic soil properties, liquefaction of soil, cyclic softening of clays, seismic compression and settlement analyses, ground improvement methods, seismic slope stability, introduction to soil structure interaction.

ENGRCEE 240.name: High Performance Materials
ENGRCEE 240.description: Part I: Linear and nonlinear fracture mechanics, methodology, real-world case studies

ENGRCEE 242.name: Advanced Strength of Materials
ENGRCEE 242.description: Beams on elastic foundations. Combined axial and lateral loads. Curved beams. Unsymmetric bending. Shear center. Stresses and strains. Basic equations for theory of elasticity. Energy principles. Theory of torsion. Combined bending and torsion.

ENGRCEE 247.name: Structural Dynamics
ENGRCEE 247.description: Vibration of discrete and continuous mass elastic systems. Isolation and transmissability. Dynamic recording instruments. Introduction to nonlinear theory of vibration. Response of structures to earthquake, traffic, and wind loads. Response spectra concepts. Normal mode analysis. Numerical integration techniques.

ENGRCEE 249.name: Earthquake Engineering
ENGRCEE 249.description: Earthquake magnitude, intensity, and frequency. Seismic damage to structures. Earthquake load prediction including response spectra, normal mode, and direct integration techniques. The basis of building code earthquake load requirements for buildings. Seismic response of special structures. Lifeline engineering.

ENGRCEE 250.name: Finite Element Method in Structural Engineering
ENGRCEE 250.description: Finite element concepts in structural engineering including variational formulations, shape functions, elements assembly, convergence and computer programming. Stiffness of truss, beam, and frame members, two- and three-dimensional solids, plate and shell elements. Static, vibration, stability, and inelastic analysis.

ENGRCEE 251.name: Performance-Based Structural Engineering
ENGRCEE 251.description: Introduction and implementation of current approaches in performance-based assessment and design of building structures. Emphasis is on applied and evolving methods and tools for exercising performance-based engineering of building structures.

ENGRCEE 252.name: Multiscale Modeling of Materials and Structures
ENGRCEE 252.description: Introduction to modeling materials and structures across length.

ENGRCEE 254.name: Advanced Reinforced Concrete Behavior and Design
ENGRCEE 254.description: Flexural strength of reinforced concrete elements. Flexural ductility of unconfined and confined members with axial loads. Shear and torsional behaviors. Strength of reinforced concrete ductile frames and shear walls. Reinforced concrete detailing.

ENGRCEE 255.name: Advanced Behavior and Design of Steel Structures
ENGRCEE 255.description: Advanced principles of structural steel design. Analysis and design of beam-column members, braced and unbraced frames for buildings, and plate girders. Review of seismic design provisions. Design of connections.

ENGRCEE 258.name: Earthquake Resistant Structural Design
ENGRCEE 258.description: Objectives of seismic design. Cyclic load-distortion characteristics of typical structural elements. Desirable structural form. Ductility and methods of achieving it. Use of energy dissipators. Project involving design of multistory, multibay rigid-jointed plane frame.

ENGRCEE 260.name: Desalination
ENGRCEE 260.description: Introduction of state of technology, costs and benefits, environmental issues, and implementation issues related to desalination. Emphasis on membrane processes and biofouling prevention.

ENGRCEE 261.name: Applied Environmental Microbiology
ENGRCEE 261.description: Microbes in the environment and their impact on human interactions. Microbiological  application in solving environmental engineering problems.

ENGRCEE 262.name: Environmental Chemistry II
ENGRCEE 262.description: Advanced concepts from physical and organic chemistry as they relate to environmental engineering. Emphasis on equilibrium and kinetics as they apply to redox reactions, coordination, absorption, gas phase reactions, and ion exchange.

ENGRCEE 263.name: Advanced Biological Treatment Processes
ENGRCEE 263.description: Analysis of biological processes in natural and engineered systems. Biological treatment processes, both aerobic and anaerobic, with emphasis on suspended growth systems including design consideration. Containment degradation or control covered. Includes laboratory on molecular tools used in wastewater treatment.

ENGRCEE 264.name: Carbon and Energy Footprint Analysis
ENGRCEE 264.description: Process design for wastewater treatment. Mass- and energy- balance analysis applied to water and wastewater treatment systems. Case studies include analysis of water supply, treatment, reclamation, and reuse.

ENGRCEE 265.name: Physical-Chemical Treatment Processes
ENGRCEE 265.description: Theory and dynamics of physical and chemical separation processes in water and wastewater treatment. Topics include coagulation, sedimentation, filtration, gas transfer, membrane separations, and absorption.

ENGRCEE 266.name: Drinking Water and Wastewater Biotechnology
