ENGRCEE 266.description: Water and wastewater microbiology. Engineering principles, molecular aspects, and overview of microorganisms of importance to public health. Topics include aerobic and anaerobic wastewater treatment and disinfection of pathogens in water, wastewaters, and biosolids.

ENGRCEE 269.name: Beach Dynamics
ENGRCEE 269.description: Coastal erosion in California, human and natural influences on southern California beaches, and present-day challenges. Littoral cells and sediment budgets. Water wave theory. Littoral sediment transport and shoreline change modeling. Shoreline stabilization using green and gray infrastructure.

ENGRCEE 270.name: Flood Risk and Modeling
ENGRCEE 270.description: Global and national trends in flooding and related impacts including disasters

ENGRCEE 271.name: Flow in Unsaturated Porous Media
ENGRCEE 271.description: Fluid flow in the unsaturated zone (zone of aeration) of the subsurface. Soil-water physics, flow in regional groundwater systems, miscible displacement, mathematical modeling techniques.

ENGRCEE 272.name: Groundwater Hydrology
ENGRCEE 272.description: Topics include conservation of fluid mass, storage properties or porous media, matrix compressibility, boundary conditions, flow nets, well hydraulics, groundwater chemistry, and solute transport. Includes introduction to advanced topics in porous media. Design projects and computer applications included.

ENGRCEE 273.name: Watershed Modeling
ENGRCEE 273.description: Basic principles of hydrologic modeling are practiced. Concepts of watershed delineation, land use change impact, design studies, and GIS tools are discussed. Focus on the USACE (HEC) software tools (HEC-HMS and HEC-RAS) along with their associated GIS interfaces.

ENGRCEE 276.name: Hydrology
ENGRCEE 276.description: Elements of the hydrologic cycle including precipitation, infiltration, evapotranspiration, ground water, and runoff. Unit Hydrograph theory and routing methods. Introduction to precipitation/runoff relationship and watershed modeling. Statistical methods and flood frequency analysis. Discussion section covers advanced topics.

ENGRCEE 277.name: Hydrologic Transport Fundamentals
ENGRCEE 277.description: Process description, mathematical and numerical modeling of transport processes in surface and ground water. Topics include advection, molecular diffusion, Taylor dispersion, mechanical dispersion in porous media, shear flow dispersion in channels, and turbulent jets and plumes.

ENGRCEE 279.name: Environmental Transport Modeling
ENGRCEE 279.description: Computational modeling of multi-dimensional flow and scalar transport problems in surface and ground water. Topics include mathematical model formulation, numerical method selection, serial and parallel implementation, model verification and validation.

ENGRCEE 281.name: Structural Reliability
ENGRCEE 281.description: Applications of probability theory to reliability analysis of engineering structures. Theory of structural reliability. Estimation of static random loads. Reliability analysis of structural components and system. Monte Carlo simulation.

ENGRCEE 289.name: Analysis of Hydrologic Systems
ENGRCEE 289.description: Application of systems theory in hydrologic, land surface, biogeochemical modeling. Design, identification, and calibration of conceptual models. Principles of dynamic systems, modeling approaches, theory of linear systems, mathematical concepts of differential calculus, theoretical concepts of parameter estimation and optimization theory.

ENGRCEE 290.name: Merging Models and Data
ENGRCEE 290.description: Introduction to optimization and data assimilation methods for model calibration and uncertainty quantification. Local, global and multi-method search. Bayesian analysis using Monte Carlo simulation with Random Walk Metropolis, and adaptive samplers. Filtering methods for recursive inference. Illustration using environmental models.

ENGRCEE 291.name: Hydrologic Remote Sensing
ENGRCEE 291.description: Introduction to principles of remote sensing and application in hydrology. Review of sensor systems, thermal and multispectral image processing, and image classification. Examples from remote sensing of hydrologic processes such as precipitation, soil moisture, and vegetation are covered.

ENGRCEE 292.name: Wavelets in Hydrology, Engineering, and Geoscience
ENGRCEE 292.description: Multiscale analysis of hydrologic, engineering, and earth system processes

ENGRCEE 295.name: Seminars in Engineering
ENGRCEE 295.description: Seminars scheduled each year by individual faculty in major field of interest.

ENGRCEE 296.name: Master of Science Thesis Research
ENGRCEE 296.description: Individual research or investigation conducted in preparation of the thesis required for the M.S. degree in Engineering.

ENGRCEE 297.name: Doctor of Philosophy Dissertation Research
ENGRCEE 297.description: Individual research or investigation conducted in preparation for the dissertation required for the Ph.D. degree in Engineering.

ENGRCEE 298.name: Special Topics in Civil and Environmental Engineering
ENGRCEE 298.description: Presentation of advanced topics and special research areas in civil and environmental engineering.

ENGRCEE 299.name: Individual Research
ENGRCEE 299.description: Individual research or investigation under the direction of an individual faculty member.

ENGRMAE 10.name: Introduction to Engineering Computations
ENGRMAE 10.description: Introduction to the solution of engineering problems through the use of the computer. Elementary programming, numerical analysis, and data visualization with a high-level programming language such as MATLAB.
ENGRMAE 10.prereqString:
Corequisite: MATH 2A
Prerequisite: MATH 2A or MATH 5A
ENGRMAE 10.restriction: Restriction: Mechanical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Aerospace Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Chemical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Materials Science and Engr Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRMAE 30.name: Statics
ENGRMAE 30.description: Addition and resolution of forces, distributed forces, equivalent system of forces centroids, first moments, moments and products on inertia, equilibrium of rigid bodies, trusses, beams, cables.  Course may be offered online.
ENGRMAE 30.prereqString:
Corequisite: MATH 2D
Prerequisite: MATH 2D and PHYSICS 7C
ENGRMAE 30.restriction: Restriction: School of Engineering students have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRMAE 52.name: Computer-Aided Design
ENGRMAE 52.description: Develops skills for interpretation and presentation of mechanical design drawings and the use of CAD in engineering design. An integrated approach to drafting based on sketching, manual drawing, and three-dimensional CAD techniques is presented. Materials fee.
ENGRMAE 52.restriction: Restriction: Mechanical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Materials Science and Engr Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRMAE 57.name: Manufacturing Processes in Engineering
ENGRMAE 57.description: With laboratory. Machines and processes of mechanical manufacturing. Safety and professional procedures emphasized.  Use of measuring instruments, hand tools, lathe, mill, drill press, bandsaw, grinder, welding equipment.
ENGRMAE 57.restriction: Restriction: School of Engineering students have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRMAE 60.name: Electric Circuits
ENGRMAE 60.description: Design and analysis of analog circuits based on lumped circuit elements with emphasis on the use of operational amplifiers. Sinusoidal and transient response. Constructional and laboratory testing of analog circuits, and introduction to data acquisition. Materials fee.
ENGRMAE 60.prereqString:
Corequisite: MATH 3D
Prerequisite: PHYSICS 7D and PHYSICS 7LD
ENGRMAE 60.restriction: Restriction: Mechanical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Aerospace Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Materials Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRMAE 80.name: Dynamics
ENGRMAE 80.description: Introduction to the kinematics and dynamics of particles and rigid bodies. The Newton-Euler, Work/Energy, and Impulse/Momentum methods are explored for ascertaining the dynamics of particles and rigid bodies. An engineering design problem using these fundamental principles is also undertaken.
ENGRMAE 80.restriction: Restriction: Mechanical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Aerospace Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Civil Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Materials Science and Engr Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRMAE 91.name: Introduction to Thermodynamics
ENGRMAE 91.restriction: Restriction: Mechanical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Aerospace Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Civil Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Materials Science and Engr Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRMAE 93.name: Topics in Design Project
ENGRMAE 93.description: Early-stage design/hands-on experience for students, and allows them to participate alongside seniors in the design project.
ENGRMAE 93.restriction: Restriction: Mechanical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Aerospace Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRMAE 106.name: Mechanical Systems Laboratory
ENGRMAE 106.description: Experiments in linear systems, including op-amp circuits, vibrations, and control systems. Emphasis on demonstrating that mathematical models can be useful tools for the analysis and design of electro-mechanical systems.  Materials fee.
ENGRMAE 106.restriction: Restriction: Mechanical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Aerospace Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Civil Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Materials Science and Engr Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRMAE 107.name: Fluid Thermal Science Laboratory
ENGRMAE 107.description: Fluid and thermal engineering laboratory. Experimental analysis of fluid flow, heat transfer, and thermodynamic systems. Probability, statistics, and uncertainly analysis. Report writing is emphasized and a design project is required. Materials fee.
ENGRMAE 107.restriction: Restriction: Mechanical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRMAE 108.name: Aerospace Laboratory
ENGRMAE 108.description: Analytical and experimental investigation in aerodynamics, fluid dynamics, and heat transfer. Emphasis on study of flow over objects and lift and drag on airfoils. Introduction to basic diagnostic techniques. Report writing is emphasized. Design project is required.
ENGRMAE 108.restriction: Restriction: Aerospace Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Mechanical Engineering majors have second consideration for enrollment.

ENGRMAE 110.name: Combustion and Fuel Cell Systems
ENGRMAE 110.description: Fundamentals of gaseous, liquid, and coal-fired combustion and fuel cell systems. Fuels, fuel-air mixing, aerodynamics, and combustion and fuel cell thermodynamics. Operating and design aspects of practical systems including engines, power generators, boilers, furnaces, and incinerators.
ENGRMAE 110.restriction: Restriction: Mechanical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Chemical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRMAE 112.name: Propulsion
ENGRMAE 112.description: Application of thermodynamics and fluid mechanics to basic flow processes and cycle performance in chemical propulsion systems: gas turbines, ramjets, scramjets, and rockets. Introduction to electric and electromagnetic rocket thrusters, nuclear rockets, and solar sails.
ENGRMAE 112.restriction: Restriction: Aerospace Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Mechanical Engineering majors have second consideration for enrollment.

ENGRMAE 113.name: Electric Propulsion
ENGRMAE 113.description: Space propulsion requirements and maneuvers, stressing those best suited to electric propulsion. An introduction to plasma physics. Electrothermal, electromagnetic, and electrostatis accelerators, with emphasis in technologies (ion engines, Hall thrusters, and colloidal thrusters) belonging to the latter family.
ENGRMAE 113.restriction: Restriction: Mechanical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Aerospace Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRMAE 114.name: Fuel Cell Fundamentals and Technology
ENGRMAE 114.restriction: Restriction: Seniors only. Mechanical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Chemical Engineering majors have second consideration for enrollment.

ENGRMAE 115.name: Applied Engineering Thermodynamics
ENGRMAE 115.description: Application of thermodynamic principles to compressible and incompressible processes representative of practical engineering problems
ENGRMAE 115.prereqString: Prerequisite: ENGRMAE 91 or CBE 40B or ENGRMSE 65A
ENGRMAE 115.restriction: Restriction: Mechanical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Materials Science and Engr Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRMAE 117.name: Solar and Renewable Energy Systems
ENGRMAE 117.description: Basic principles, design, and operation of solar and other renewable energy systems including solar photo-voltaic, solar thermal, wind, and PEM fuel cell. Includes power generation and storage, and renewable fuels for transportation and stationary power generation.
ENGRMAE 117.restriction: Restriction: Mechanical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRMAE 118.name: Sustainable Energy Systems
ENGRMAE 118.description: Basic principles, design, and operation of sustainable energy systems including wind, solar photo-voltaic and thermal, hydroelectric, geothermal, oceanic, biomass combustion, advanced coal, and next generation nuclear. Includes power generation, storage, and transmission for stationary power generation.
ENGRMAE 118.restriction: Restriction: Mechanical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Aerospace Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRMAE 119.name: Climate Solutions
ENGRMAE 119.description: Focuses on carbon neutrality and climate stability, addressing.

ENGRMAE 120.name: Heat and Mass Transfer
ENGRMAE 120.description: Fundamentals of heat and mass transfer. Conduction, heat and mass transfer by convection in laminar and turbulent flows, radiation heat transfer, and combined modes of heat and mass transfer. Practical engineering applications.
ENGRMAE 120.restriction: Restriction: Mechanical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Aerospace Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Materials Science and Engr Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRMAE 130A.name: Introduction to Fluid Mechanics
ENGRMAE 130A.prereqString:
Corequisite: ENGRMAE 91
Prerequisite: PHYSICS 7C and MATH 2D and MATH 2E and MATH 3D and (ENGRMAE 30 or ENGRCEE 30 or ENGR 30) and (ENGRMAE 80 or ENGRCEE 80 or ENGR 80). PHYSICS 7C with a grade of C- or better. MATH 2D with a grade of C- or better. MATH 2E with a grade of C- or better. MATH 3D with a grade of C- or better. ENGRMAE 30 with a grade of C- or better. ENGRCEE 30 with a grade of C- or better. ENGR 30 with a grade of C- or better. ENGRMAE 80 with a grade of C- or better. ENGRCEE 80 with a grade of C- or better. ENGR 80 with a grade of C- or better
ENGRMAE 130A.restriction: Restriction: Mechanical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Aerospace Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRMAE 130B.name: Introduction to Viscous and Compressible Flows
ENGRMAE 130B.description: Introduction to the analysis of viscous flows including fully developed laminar and turbulent flow in a pipe, viscous flow over immersed bodies, evaluation of boundary layer characteristics, lift and drag, compressible flow in a duct and normal shock waves.
ENGRMAE 130B.restriction: Restriction: Mechanical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Aerospace Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRMAE 132.name: Computational Fluid Dynamics
ENGRMAE 132.description: Introduction to computational fluid dynamics in simple engineering devices. The numerical simulations will be performed via the widely-used software ANSYS-Fluent. While Fluent is the choice of software, all major CFD packages are based on a similar numerical method.
ENGRMAE 132.prereqString: Prerequisite: ENGRMAE 130B. ENGRMAE 130B with a grade of C- or better
ENGRMAE 132.restriction: Restriction: Aerospace Engineering Majors only. Mechanical Engineering Majors only.

ENGRMAE 135.name: Compressible Flow
ENGRMAE 135.description: Compressibility effects in fluid mechanics. One-dimensional flow with area variation, friction, heat transfer, and shocks. Design of gas supply systems. Two-dimensional flow with oblique shocks and isentropic waves. Supersonic airfoil theory and design, wind tunnel design. Basic diagnostics.
ENGRMAE 135.restriction: Restriction: Mechanical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Aerospace Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRMAE 136.name: Aerodynamics
ENGRMAE 136.description: Analysis of flow over aircraft wings and airfoils, prediction of lift, moment, and drag. Topics: fluid dynamics equations
ENGRMAE 136.restriction: Restriction: Aerospace Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Mechanical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRMAE 145.name: Theory of Machines and Mechanisms
ENGRMAE 145.description: Presents the basic mathematical theory of machines. Focuses on the principles of cam design, gearing and gear train analysis, and the kinematic and dynamic analysis of linkages, together with an introduction to robotics.
ENGRMAE 145.prereqString: Prerequisite: ENGRMAE 52 and (ENGRMAE 80 or ENGRCEE 80 or ENGR 80) and (MATH 3A or I&C SCI 6N)
ENGRMAE 145.restriction: Restriction: Mechanical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Materials Science and Engineering majors have second consideration for enrollment.

ENGRMAE 146.name: Astronautics
ENGRMAE 146.description: Motion in gravitational force fields, orbit transfers, rocketry, interplanetary trajectories, attitude dynamics and stabilization, navigation, reentry, the space environment.
ENGRMAE 146.prereqString: Prerequisite: ENGRMAE 80 or ENGRCEE 80 or ENGR 80
ENGRMAE 146.restriction: Restriction: Aerospace Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRMAE 147.name: Vibrations
ENGRMAE 147.description: Analysis of structural vibrations of mechanical systems. Modeling for lumped and distributed parameter systems. Topics include single and multi-degree of freedom systems, free and forced vibrations, Fourier series, convolution integral, mass/stiffness matrices, and normal modes with design project.
ENGRMAE 147.prereqString: Prerequisite: (ENGR 80 or ENGRCEE 80 or ENGRMAE 80) and MATH 2E and MATH 3D
ENGRMAE 147.restriction: Restriction: Mechanical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Materials Science and Engr Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRMAE 148.name: Mechanics of Smart Structures
ENGRMAE 148.description: Introduction to modeling, numerical simulation, design, and control of axial, torsional, and bending actuators. Fundamentals of shape-changing trusses, frames, and panels. Introduction to the behavior and modeling of smart materials such as shape memory alloys/polymers.

ENGRMAE 150.name: Mechanics of Structures
ENGRMAE 150.description: Stresses and strains. Torsion. Bending. Beam deflection.  Shear force and moment distributions in beams. Yielding and buckling of columns. Combined loading. Transformation of stresses and strain. Yielding criteria. Finite elements analysis of frames. Dynamic of two-bar truss.
ENGRMAE 150.prereqString: Prerequisite: (ENGRCEE 30 or ENGR 30 or ENGRMAE 30) and MATH 3A
ENGRMAE 150.restriction: Restriction: Mechanical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Aerospace Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Chemical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Materials Science and Engr Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRMAE 150L.name: Mechanics of Structures Laboratory
ENGRMAE 150L.description: Experimental techniques for the measurement of mechanical properties of materials and structures. Methods for load, displacement, and strain measurements. Tension, bending, compression tests. Determination of strength, stiffness, toughness for metals, polymers, ceramics, and composites. Deformation of structures. Materials fee.
ENGRMAE 150L.prereqString:
Corequisite: ENGRMAE 150
Prerequisite: ENGRMAE 30 or ENGR 30 or ENGRCEE 30
ENGRMAE 150L.restriction: Restriction: Mechanical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Aerospace Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Materials Science and Engr Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRMAE 151.name: Mechanical Engineering Design
ENGRMAE 151.description: A comprehensive group design project experience that involves identifying customer needs, idea generation, reverse engineering, preliminary design, standards, prototype development, testing, analysis, and redesign of a product involving fluid, thermal, and mechanical components.  Introduces design for manufacturing and the environment. Materials fee.
ENGRMAE 151.prereqString:
Corequisite: ENGRMAE 170
Prerequisite: ENGRMAE 120 and ENGRMAE 145
ENGRMAE 151.restriction: Restriction: Seniors only. Mechanical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Materials Science and Engr Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRMAE 152.name: Introduction to Computer-Aided Engineering
ENGRMAE 152.description: Elements and principles of computer-aided engineering with modern hardware and software are presented with a design focus. Case studies are used to assist in finite-element method techniques. Not offered every year.
ENGRMAE 152.restriction: Restriction: Mechanical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Aerospace Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Materials Science and Engr Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRMAE 153.name: Advanced BIOMEMS Manufacturing Techniques
ENGRMAE 153.description: Introduction to BIOMEMS. Advanced biotechnology/biomedicine equipment based on MEMS and NEMS. Fundamentals of MEMS/NEMS sensing techniques and the biological and physics principles involved and the preferred MEMS and NEMS manufacturing techniques.
ENGRMAE 153.restriction: Restriction: Mechanical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Aerospace Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Biomedical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRMAE 155.name: Composite Materials and Structures
ENGRMAE 155.description: Motivation for composite materials. Different classifications according to the nature of the matrix (PMC, MMC, CMC) and the reinforcement topology (fibers, whiskers, particulates).  Mechanical properties. Failure mechanisms. Designing with composite materials. Advantages and limitations of homogenization techniques for numerical modeling.
ENGRMAE 155.prereqString: Prerequisite: ENGR 54 and (ENGRMAE 150 or ENGRCEE 150 or ENGR 150)
ENGRMAE 155.restriction: Restriction: Mechanical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Aerospace Engineering majors have second consideration for enrollment. Chemical Engineering majors have second consideration for enrollment. Civil Engineering majors have second consideration for enrollment. Materials Science and Engineering majors have second consideration for enrollment.

ENGRMAE 156.name: Mechanical Behavior and Design Principles
ENGRMAE 156.description: Principles governing structure and mechanical behavior of materials, relationship relating microstructure and mechanical response with application to elasticity, plasticity, yielding, necking, creep, and fracture of materials. Introduction to experimental techniques to characterize the properties of materials. Design parameters.
ENGRMAE 156.restriction: Restriction: Mechanical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Materials Science and Engr Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Aerospace Engineering majors have second consideration for enrollment.

ENGRMAE 157.name: Lightweight Structures
ENGRMAE 157.description: Fundamentals of torsion and bending. Analysis and design of thin-wall and composite beams. Stress analysis of aircraft components. Stiffness, strength, and buckling. Introduction to the Finite Element method and its application to plates and shells.
ENGRMAE 157.prereqString: Prerequisite: ENGR 150 or ENGRCEE 150 or ENGRMAE 150
ENGRMAE 157.restriction: Restriction: Aerospace Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Mechanical Engineering majors have second consideration for enrollment. Civil Engineering majors have second consideration for enrollment. Materials Science and Engineering majors have second consideration for enrollment.

ENGRMAE 158.name: Aircraft Performance
ENGRMAE 158.description: Flight theory applied to subsonic propeller and jet aircraft. Nature of aerodynamic forces, drag and lift of wing and fuselage, high-lift devices, level-flight performance, climb and glide performance, range, endurance, take-off and landing distances, static and dynamic stability and control.
ENGRMAE 158.restriction: Restriction: Mechanical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Aerospace Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRMAE 159.name: Aircraft Design
ENGRMAE 159.description: Preliminary design of subsonic general aviation and transport aircraft with emphasis on layout, aerodynamic design, propulsion, and performance. Estimation of total weight and weight distribution, design of wings, fuselage, and tail, selection and location of engines, prediction of overall performance.
ENGRMAE 159.prereqString: Prerequisite: ENGRMAE 112 and ENGRMAE 136 and ENGRMAE 158
ENGRMAE 159.restriction: Restriction: Aerospace Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Mechanical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRMAE 164.name: Air Pollution and Control
ENGRMAE 164.description: Sources, dispersion, and effects of air pollutants. Topics include emission factors, emission inventory, air pollution, meteorology, air chemistry, air quality modeling, impact assessment, source and ambient monitoring, regional control strategies.
ENGRMAE 164.restriction: Restriction: Mechanical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Chemical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRMAE 170.name: Introduction to Control Systems
ENGRMAE 170.description: Feedback control systems. Modeling, stability, and systems specifications. Root locus, Nyquist, and Bode methods of analysis and design.
ENGRMAE 170.prereqString: Prerequisite: (ENGRMAE 80 or ENGRCEE 80 or ENGR 80) and ENGRMAE 106
ENGRMAE 170.restriction: Restriction: Mechanical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Aerospace Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Civil Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Materials Science and Engr Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRMAE 171.name: Digital Control Systems
ENGRMAE 171.description: Methods for analysis and design of discrete-time control systems. Z-transforms, difference equations, discrete Fourier transforms. Sampling theorem and applications.  Z-plane stability, frequency response. Digital controller design. Introduction to digital filters.
ENGRMAE 171.restriction: Restriction: Civil Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Mechanical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRMAE 172.name: Design of Computer-Controlled Robots
ENGRMAE 172.description: Students design a small robotic device and program it to exhibit sentient behaviors. The basic aspects of mechatronic design are covered, including motor and sensor selection, control strategies, and microcomputer programming for the implementation of control paradigms.  Materials fee.
ENGRMAE 172.restriction: Restriction: Mechanical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRMAE 175.name: Dynamics and Control of Aerospace Vehicles
ENGRMAE 175.description: Equations of motion, linearization, stability derivatives, and longitudinal and lateral modes of motion. Handling qualities, sensors and actuators, and effects of various feedbacks on stability and performance. Stability augmentation. Autopilot design.
ENGRMAE 175.restriction: Restriction: Aerospace Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Mechanical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRMAE 182.name: Introduction to Machine Learning
ENGRMAE 182.description: Fundamental principles necessary to understand statistical learning methods. Introduction to the R programming language. Mathematical foundation for various machine learning algorithms. Computer implementation.

ENGRMAE 183.name: Computer-Aided Mechanism Design
ENGRMAE 183.description: Focuses on design of planar, spherical, and spatial mechanisms using computer algebra and graphics. Topics include exact and approximate analytical design techniques. Students are required to use existing software (or develop new algorithms) to design various mechanisms for new applications.
ENGRMAE 183.restriction: Restriction: Mechanical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRMAE 184.name: Fundamentals of Experimental Design
ENGRMAE 184.description: Review of statistics as applied to experimental research. Fundamentals and principles of statistical experimental design and analysis with emphasis on understanding and use of designed experiments, response surfaces, linear regression modeling, and process optimization.
ENGRMAE 184.restriction: Restriction: Mechanical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Aerospace Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRMAE 185.name: Numerical Analysis in Mechanical Engineering
ENGRMAE 185.description: Solution of mechanical-engineering equations by means of numerical methods. Errors in numerical analysis. Nonlinear equation and sets of equations. Numerical differentiation and integration. Ordinary differential equations. Boundary-value problems. Partial differential equations.
ENGRMAE 185.prereqString: Prerequisite: (ENGRMAE 10 or EECS 10 or EECS 12 or BME 60B) and MATH 3D and MATH 2E

ENGRMAE 188.name: Engineering Design in Industry
ENGRMAE 188.description: Principles of engineering design in the context of an industrial application. Local manufacturing firms define an engineering design project to be completed in 10 weeks. Projects include initial brainstorming to final design, with a formal presentation.
ENGRMAE 188.restriction: Restriction: Mechanical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRMAE 189.name: Senior Project - Special Topics
ENGRMAE 189.description: Group or individual senior project of theoretical or applied nature involving design. Materials fee.
ENGRMAE 189.restriction: Restriction: Seniors only. Mechanical Engineering Majors only.

ENGRMAE 193.name: Topics in MAE Design
ENGRMAE 193.description: Provides early-stage design/hands-on experience for upper-division students, and allows them to participate in senior design projects course ENGRMAE 189.
ENGRMAE 193.restriction: Restriction: Aerospace Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Mechanical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ENGRMAE 195.name: Seminars in Engineering
ENGRMAE 195.description: Seminars by individual faculty in major fields of interest. Materials fee.

ENGRMAE 198.name: Group Study
ENGRMAE 198.description: Group study of selected topics in Aerospace and Mechanical Engineering.

ENGRMAE 199.name: Individual Study
ENGRMAE 199.description: For undergraduate Engineering majors in supervised but independent reading, research, or design. Students taking individual study for design credit are to submit a written paper to the instructor and to the Undergraduate Student Affairs Office in the School of Engineering.

ENGRMAE 199P.name: Individual Study
ENGRMAE 199P.description: For undergraduate Engineering majors in supervised but independent reading, research, or design. Students taking individual study for design are to submit a written paper to the instructor and to the Undergraduate Student Affairs Office in the School of Engineering.

ENGRMAE 200A.name: Engineering Analysis I
ENGRMAE 200A.description: Linear algebra, including vector spaces, matrices, linear systems of equations, least squares, and the eigenvalue problem. Ordinary differential equations, including analytical and numerical solution methods, stability, and phase portraits.

ENGRMAE 200B.name: Engineering Analysis II
ENGRMAE 200B.description: Review of ordinary differential equations, including Bessel and Legendre functions. Partial differential equations, including the diffusion equation, Laplace's equation, and the wave equation. Fourier series, Fourier and Laplace transforms and their applications.

ENGRMAE 200P.name: Integrated Thermal-Fluid Science Fundamentals
ENGRMAE 200P.description: The fundamentals of thermodynamics, fluid dynamics, and heat transfer are first.
ENGRMAE 200P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

ENGRMAE 201P.name: Engineering Design and Simulation: Tools and Process
ENGRMAE 201P.description: Practical techniques and use of industry tools that improve the engineering design process by simulating the performance of design options prior to the costly steps of prototyping and manufacturing are covered. Applicable to a wide variety of engineering disciplines.
ENGRMAE 201P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

ENGRMAE 205.name: Perturbation Methods in Engineering
ENGRMAE 205.description: Asymptotic Expansions of integrals. Regular and singular perturbations. Perturbation methods for ordinary and partial differential equations. Matched asymptotic expansions. Multiple-scale asymptotic expansion schemes. Not offered every year.
ENGRMAE 205.prereqString: Prerequisite: ENGRMAE 200A and ENGRMAE 200B. Knowledge of linear differential equations.

ENGRMAE 206.name: Nonlinear Optimization Methods
ENGRMAE 206.description: Numerical methods for constrained and unconstrained optimization. Necessary and sufficient conditions for optimimality. Conjugate gradient, variable metric algorithms. Gradient projection, penalty functions, and Lagrange methods. Not offered every year.

ENGRMAE 209P.name: Energy Efficiency in the Built Environment
ENGRMAE 209P.description: Energy and power for the built environment
ENGRMAE 209P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

ENGRMAE 210.name: Advanced Fundamentals of Combustion
ENGRMAE 210.description: Premixed, nonpremixed, and heterogenous reactions, with emphasis on kinetics, thermal ignition, turbulent flame propogation, detonations, explosions, flammability limits, diffusion flame, quenching, flame stabilization, and particle and spray combustion. Not offered every year.

ENGRMAE 210P.name: Fundamentals and Applications of Combustion
ENGRMAE 210P.description: Premixed, nonpremixed, and heterogenous reactions, with emphasis on kinetics, thermal ignition, turbulent flame propogation, detonations, explosions, flammability limits, diffusion flame, quenching, flame stabilization, and particle and spray combustion.
ENGRMAE 210P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

ENGRMAE 211P.name: Energy Storage Systems and Technology
ENGRMAE 211P.description: Basic principles, design, and operation of energy storage systems and technology including lithium ion battery systems for transportation and stationary applications, for flow batteries (e.g., vanadium redox, sodium sulfur), and for reversible fuel cell electrolyzer systems and hydrogen energy storage.
ENGRMAE 211P.prereqString: Prerequisite: Required: Undergraduate-level knowledge of applied engineering thermodynamics.
ENGRMAE 211P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

ENGRMAE 212.name: Engineering Electrochemistry: Fundamentals and Applications
ENGRMAE 212.description: Introduction to engineering electrochemistry fundamentals and applications. Examine thermodynamics and transport principles in typical electrochemical systems. Electrochemical sensors, batteries, fuel cells, and supercapacitors. Manufacturing aspects will also be covered.

ENGRMAE 212P.name: Engineering Electrochemistry: Fundamentals and Applications
ENGRMAE 212P.description: Introduction to engineering electrochemistry fundamentals and applications. Examine thermodynamics and transport principles in typical electrochemical systems. Electrochemical sensors, batteries, fuel cells, and supercapacitors. Manufacturing aspects are also covered.
ENGRMAE 212P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

ENGRMAE 213.name: Electric Propulsion
ENGRMAE 213.description: Space propulsion requirements and maneuvers, stressing those best suited to electric propulsion. An introduction to plasma physics. Electrothermal, electromagnetic and electrostatic accelerators, with emphasis in technologies (ion engines, Hall thrusters and colloidal thrusters) belonging to the latter family.

ENGRMAE 214C.name: PEM Fuel Cells
ENGRMAE 214C.description: An in-depth introduction to the fundamentals of PEM fuel cells, including thermodynamics, kinetics, and transport in electrochemical systems. Topics of specific interest to mechanical engineers will include water/heat management and dynamic responses.

ENGRMAE 214P.name: Fuel Cell Fundamentals and Technology
ENGRMAE 214P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

ENGRMAE 215.name: Advanced Combustion Technology
ENGRMAE 215.description: Pollutant formation and experimental methods. Formation of gaseous pollutants and soot

ENGRMAE 216.name: Statistical Thermodynamics
ENGRMAE 216.description: Statistics of independent particles, development of quantum mechanical description of atoms and molecules, application of quantum mechanics, evaluation of thermodynamics properties for solids, liquids, and gases, statistical mechanics of dependent particles (ensembles).

ENGRMAE 217.name: Generalized Thermodynamics
ENGRMAE 217.description: Generalized thermodynamics develops the laws of continuum thermodynamics from a set of plausible and intuitive postulates. The postulates are motivated qualitatively by a statistical description of matter and are justified by a posterior success for the resulting theory.

ENGRMAE 217P.name: Generalized Thermodynamics
ENGRMAE 217P.description: Generalized thermodynamics develops the laws of continuum thermodynamics from a set of plausible and intuitive postulates. The postulates are motivated qualitatively by a statistical description of matter and are justified by a posterior success for the resulting theory.
ENGRMAE 217P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

ENGRMAE 218.name: Sustainable Energy Systems
ENGRMAE 218.description: Basic principles, design and operation of sustainable energy systems including wind, solar photo-voltaic and thermal, hydroelectric, geothermal, oceanic, biomass combustion, advanced coal and next generation nuclear.  Includes power generation, storage, and transmission for stationary power generation.

ENGRMAE 218P.name: Sustainable Energy Systems
ENGRMAE 218P.description: Basic principles, design, and operation of sustainable energy systems including wind, solar photo-voltaic and thermal, hydroelectric, geothermal, oceanic, biomass combustion, advanced coal, and next generation nuclear. Includes power generation, storage, and transmission for stationary power generation.
ENGRMAE 218P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

ENGRMAE 219P.name: Solar and Renewable Energy Systems
ENGRMAE 219P.description: Basic principles, design, and operation of solar and other renewable energy systems including solar photo-voltaic, solar thermal, wind, and PEM fuel cell. Includes power generation and storage, and renewable fuels for transportation and stationary power generation.
ENGRMAE 219P.prereqString: Prerequisite: Required: Knowledge of applied engineering thermodynamics.
ENGRMAE 219P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

ENGRMAE 220.name: Conduction Heat Transfer
ENGRMAE 220.description: Steady state and transient conduction heat transfer in one- and multi-dimensional geometries. Analytical methods, exact and approximate. Numerical techniques are also included.

ENGRMAE 221.name: Convective Heat and Mass Transfer
ENGRMAE 221.description: Laminar and turbulent convective heat and mass transfer in external and internal flows. Forced and free convection.  Exact and approximate solutions. Similarity solutions.  Variable properties. Concentration boundary layer theory.  Mass transfer conductance.

ENGRMAE 222.name: Radiative Heat Transfer
ENGRMAE 222.description: Black body radiation.  Radiative transport equations for surfaces separated by non-participating media.  Radiant energy transfer through absorbing, emitting, and scattering media. Radiation-conduction interaction.  Radiation-convection interaction.  Introduction to finite-difference solutions.

ENGRMAE 223A.name: Numerical Methods in Heat, Mass, and Momentum Transport (Laminar Flows) I
ENGRMAE 223A.description: Introduction to the discretization of various types of partial differential equations (parabolic, elliptic, hyperbolic). Finite-volume discretization for one- and two-dimensional flows. Use of a two-dimensional elliptic procedure to predict sample laminar flows.

ENGRMAE 224.name: Advanced Transport Phenomena
ENGRMAE 224.description: Fundamentals of transport phenomena in fluid (gas and liquid), solid, and nano systems. Conservation equations, fundamentals of diffusion, ion transport, dispersion in turbulent/laminar flows, absorption, differential/staged distillation, transport in membranes, and nano/microscale transport phenomena. Not offered every year.

ENGRMAE 227.name: Thermal Resistance Analysis in Microdevices and Nanomaterials
ENGRMAE 227.description: Heat transfer and thermal resistance analysis relevant for microdevices and nanomaterials. Overview of recent progress in nanotechnology and materials science. Thermal modeling strategies for novel electronic devices and energy conversion systems.

ENGRMAE 228.name: Nanoscale Phase Change Transport Physics
ENGRMAE 228.description: Discusses a wide range of phase change processes (i.e., evaporation, boiling, condensation, and freezing) through the use of novel thermal metamaterials with the aim of enhancing phase change performances.
ENGRMAE 228.prereqString: Prerequisite: Undergraduate-level heat transfer is recommended.

ENGRMAE 229P.name: Nanoscale Materials for Modern Electronics
ENGRMAE 229P.description: Introduction to design and synthesis of nanomaterials. Topics include thermal and liquid transport in materials systems, phase change heat transfer physics, and mechanical properties in materials systems.
ENGRMAE 229P.prereqString: Prerequisite: Required: Undergraduate-level knowledge of heat transfer.
ENGRMAE 229P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

ENGRMAE 230A.name: Inviscid Incompressible Fluid Mechanics I
ENGRMAE 230A.description: Equations of motion. Vector notation. Flow kinematics. Potential flow and complex potential. Vorticity and circulation. Bernoulli's theorem. Crocco's theorem. Conformal, Joukowski, and Schwarz-Christoffel transformations.

ENGRMAE 230B.name: Viscous Incompressible Fluid Mechanics II
ENGRMAE 230B.description: Review of mass, momentum, energy equations. Stress tensor, constitutive relations. Laminar flows. Stokes and Oseen flows. Self-similarity. Boundary layer theory: thin-layer approximation, Falkner-Skan, Blasius solutions, integral methods. Jet, wake, cavity flows. Introduction to turbulence: instability, Reynolds averaging, mixing length.

ENGRMAE 231.name: Fundamentals of Turbulence
ENGRMAE 231.description: Phenomenon of turbulence. Reynolds equations. Dynamics of turbulence. Free turbulent shear flows. Wall-bounded turbulent shear flows. Turbulent transport of scalar quantities. Spectral dynamics. Mathematical models of turbulence.

ENGRMAE 233.name: Turbulent Free Shear Flows
ENGRMAE 233.description: Practical and theoretical aspects of turbulent free shear flows. Instability, global scaling laws, mixing, and noise generation in incompressible and compressible shear layers, jets, and wakes. Kelvin-Helmholtz instability, near- and far-field growth rates, effect of compressibility, aeroacoustics of jets.
ENGRMAE 233.prereqString: Prerequisite: ENGRMAE 200B and ENGRMAE 230A and ENGRMAE 230B

ENGRMAE 236.name: Nonequilibrium Gas Dynamics
ENGRMAE 236.description: Molecular description of fluid flow. Boltzmann equation. Chapman-Enskog expansion for flows with translational nonequilibrium. Shock structure. Inviscid flows with chemical and vibrational nonequilibrium. Not offered every year.

ENGRMAE 237.name: Computational Fluid Dynamics
ENGRMAE 237.description: Mathematical, physical, and computational fundamentals of computational fluid dynamics, numerical methods for solving the Euler and Navier-Stokes equations. Topics include: finite-difference and finite-volume discretization, time marching methods, von Neumann analysis, upwinding, flux splitting, TVD, and other high-resolution shock-capturing schemes.

ENGRMAE 239.name: Dynamics of Unsteady Flows
ENGRMAE 239.description: Unsteady potential flow modeling (Kelvin's circulation theorem, unsteady Bernoulli's equation). Theodorsen's frequency response, Wagner's step response, and the Kussner sharp-edged gust. State Space approximations for Unsteady Loads. Vortex Lattice. Flutter.

ENGRMAE 240.name: Inertial Navigation
ENGRMAE 240.description: Provides a basic understanding of 1) theory, operation, and performance characteristics of a strapdown inertial navigation system  (INS), (2) distinction between strap down and gimbaled INS, (3) Kalman filtering theory and its application to strap down INS aiding.

ENGRMAE 241.name: Dynamics
ENGRMAE 241.description: Kinematics and dynamics of three-dimensional motions. Lagrange's equations, Newton-Euler equations. Applications include robot systems and spinning satellites.

ENGRMAE 242.name: Robotics
ENGRMAE 242.description: Spatial rigid-body transformations.  Forward and inverse kinematics. Jacobian of serial and parallel chains.  Screw coordinates and transformations. Rate and static analyses using screw theory. Singularity analysis. Trajectory generation. Not offered every year.

ENGRMAE 244.name: Theoretical Kinematics
ENGRMAE 244.description: Spatial rigid body kinematics is presented with applications to robotics. Orthogonal Matrices, Rodrigues' formula, Quaternions, Plucker coordinates, screw theory, and dual numbers are studied using modern projective geometry and multi-linear algebra. Applications include trajectory planning, inverse kinematics, and workspace analysis.

ENGRMAE 245.name: Spatial Mechanism Design
ENGRMAE 245.description: Fundamental kinematic theory required for planar, spherical, and spatial mechanism design. The focus is on algebraic methods for the exact solution of constraint equations. Not offered every year.

ENGRMAE 247.name: Micro-System Design
ENGRMAE 247.description: Covers the fundamentals of the many disciplines needed for design of Micro-Electro-Mechanical Systems (MEMS): microfabrication technology, structural mechanics on micro-scale, electrostatics, circuit interface, control, computer-aided design, and system integration.

ENGRMAE 247P.name: Micro-System Design
ENGRMAE 247P.description: Covers the fundamentals of the many disciplines needed for design of Micro-Electro-Mechanical Systems (MEMS): microfabrication technology, structural mechanics on micro-scale, electrostatics, circuit interface, control, computer-aided design, and system integration.
ENGRMAE 247P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

ENGRMAE 248.name: Mechanics of Smart Structures
ENGRMAE 248.description: Modeling, numerical simulation, design, and control of axial, torsional, and bending actuators. Structural analysis of shape-changing trusses, frames, and panels. Behavior and modeling of smart materials such as shape memory alloys/polymers.

ENGRMAE 249.name: Micro-Sensors and Actuators
ENGRMAE 249.description: Introduction to the technology of Micro-Electro-Mechanical Systems (MEMS). Fundamental principles and applications of important microsensors, actuation principles on microscale.  Introduction to the elements of signal processing

ENGRMAE 249P.name: Micro-Sensors and Actuators
ENGRMAE 249P.description: Introduction to the technology of Micro-Electro-Mechanical Systems (MEMS). Fundamental principles and applications of important microsensors, actuation principles on microscale. Introduction to the elements of signal processing
ENGRMAE 249P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

ENGRMAE 250.name: Biorobotics
ENGRMAE 250.description: Sensors, actuators, and neural circuits for biological movement control from an engineering perspective.  Current approaches to robotic and mechatronic devices that support and enhance human movement in health and following neurologic injuries like stroke and spinal cord injury.

ENGRMAE 252.name: Fundamentals of Microfabrication
ENGRMAE 252.description: Introduces Engineering and Science students to the science of miniaturization. Different options to make very small machines (micro and nano size) are reviewed, materials choices are discussed, scaling laws are analyzed, and many practical applications are listed.

ENGRMAE 252P.name: Fundamentals of Microfabrication
ENGRMAE 252P.description: Introduces engineering and science students to the science of miniaturization. Different options to make very small machines (micro and nano size) are reviewed, materials choices are discussed, scaling laws are analyzed, and many practical applications are listed.
ENGRMAE 252P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

ENGRMAE 253.name: Advanced BIOMEMS Manufacturing Techniques
ENGRMAE 253.description: Introduction to BIOMEMS. Advanced biotechnology/biomedicine equipment based on MEMS and NEMS. Fundamentals of MEMS/NEMS sensing techniques and the biological and physics principles involved and the preferred MEMS and NEMS manufacturing techniques.

ENGRMAE 254P.name: Mechanics of Solids and Structures
ENGRMAE 254P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

ENGRMAE 255.name: Composite Materials and Structures
ENGRMAE 255.description: Motivation for composite materials. Different classifications according to the nature of the matrix (PMC, MMC, CMC) and the reinforcement topology (fibers, whiskers, particulates). Mechanical properties. Failure mechanisms. Designing with composite materials. Advantages and limitations of homogenization techniques for numerical modeling.

ENGRMAE 256.name: Nanomechanics
ENGRMAE 256.description: Nanoscale materials and the experimental and computational techniques used to measure their properties.  Mechanical behavior is the main focus, but other material properties such as diffusion and electron transport are discussed.

ENGRMAE 257P.name: Fabrication and Characterization of Nanomaterials
ENGRMAE 257P.description: Introduction to nanoscale materials and experimental and computational techniques. Topics materials synthesis techniques, thin film deposition, nanoparticle and nanowire growth, characterization with electrons and X-rays, forces and surface interactions at the nanoscale, structure-property scaling laws, and atomistic/multiscale computer modeling.
ENGRMAE 257P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

ENGRMAE 258.name: Mechanical Behavior of Solids - Continuum Theories
ENGRMAE 258.description: Presents a continuum, macroscopic view of deformation and failure of solids. Covers elasticity, plasticity, visco-elasticity, visco-plasticity, fracture and fatigue. Topics include discussions of physical behavior, mathematical formalism and measurement techniques.

ENGRMAE 259.name: Mechanical Behavior of Solids - Atomistic Theories
ENGRMAE 259.description: Presents atomistic mechanisms that control mechanical behavior of materials. Covers plasticity, dislocation theory, strengthening mechanisms, high-temperature diffusion and gain boundary sliding, shear localization, void formation, ductile rupture, brittle fracture and fatigue.

ENGRMAE 259P.name: Mechanical Behavior of Solids - Atomistic Theories
ENGRMAE 259P.description: Presents atomistic mechanisms that control mechanical behavior of materials. Covers plasticity, dislocation theory, strengthening mechanisms, high-temperature diffusion and gain boundary sliding, shear localization, void formation, ductile rupture, brittle fracture, and fatigue.
ENGRMAE 259P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

ENGRMAE 260.name: Current Issues Related to Air Quality, Climate, and Energy
ENGRMAE 260.description: Current issues related to the atmosphere, climate, and air quality in the context of energy conversion and sustainability. Topics include transportation systems
ENGRMAE 260.prereqString: Prerequisite: ENGRMAE 261 or CHEM 245 or EARTHSS 240

ENGRMAE 270A.name: Linear Systems I
ENGRMAE 270A.description: Input-output and state-space representations of continuous-time linear systems. State transition matrices,  Controllability and observability. Irreducible realizations.  State feedback and observer design.

ENGRMAE 272.name: Robust Control Theory
ENGRMAE 272.description: Methods for control design of systems with uncertainty. Feedback stability and small gain theorem. Multivariable stability margins and multiplier theory. H-infinity-optimal control, linear matrix inequalities. Not offered every year.

ENGRMAE 274.name: Optimal Control
ENGRMAE 274.description: Principles and methods of optimal control. Topics include objectives and issues in controlling nonlinear systems

ENGRMAE 275.name: Nonlinear Feedback Systems
ENGRMAE 275.description: Advanced tools for feedback control system analysis and synthesis. Norms, operators, Lp spaces, contraction mapping theorem, Lyapunov techniques along with their extensions. Circle criterion positivity and passivity. Applications to nonlinear control methods, such as sliding mode or adaptive techniques.

ENGRMAE 276.name: Geometric Nonlinear Control
ENGRMAE 276.description: Using the mathematics of differential geometry, a number of the concepts and results of linear systems theory have been extended to nonlinear systems. Describes these extensions and illustrate their use in nonlinear system analysis and design. Not offered every year.

ENGRMAE 277.name: Learning Control Systems
ENGRMAE 277.description: Supervised learning for classification and regression: perceptrons, support vector machines, feed-forward neural networks, Gaussian processes. Generalization and model selection: cross-validation, regularization, and Bayesian methods. Unsupervised learning: clustering and dimensionality reduction. Learning control systems. Introduction to reinforcement learning.

ENGRMAE 278.name: Parameter and State Estimation
ENGRMAE 278.description: Bayesian and frequentist approaches to parameter and state estimation. Properties of estimators. Linear Gaussian systems and the Kalman Filter. Nonlinear state estimation, extended and unscented Kalman Filters. Introduction to Monte Carlo methods and particle filtering. Application to tracking and navigation.

ENGRMAE 279.name: Special Topics in Mechanical Systems
ENGRMAE 279.description: Selected topics of current interest in mechanical systems. Topics include robotics, kinematics, control, dynamics, and geometric modeling.

ENGRMAE 280.name: Design of Computer-Controlled Robots
ENGRMAE 280.description: The basic aspects of mechatronic design are covered, including motor and sensor selection, control strategies, finite state machines, inertial measurement units, and implementation of advanced feedback control laws. Students work in groups to create their own mechatronic device. Materials fee.

ENGRMAE 284.name: Fundamentals of Experimental Design
ENGRMAE 284.description: Fundamentals and principles of statistical experimental design and analysis. Emphasis addresses understanding and use of designed experiments, response surfaces, linear regression modeling, process optimization, and development of links between empirical and theoretical models.

ENGRMAE 285.name: Engineering Design Under Uncertainty
ENGRMAE 285.description: Introduces students to statistical and ML methods used in engineering design under uncertainty. Students learn how to probabilistically formulate a design problem, translate the formulations into a computer, and systematically find the solution.

ENGRMAE 294.name: Master of Science Thesis Project
ENGRMAE 294.description: Tutorial in which masters-level students taking the comprehensive examination option undertake a masters-level research project.

ENGRMAE 295.name: Special Topics in Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering
ENGRMAE 295.description: Special topics by individual faculty in major fields of interest.

ENGRMAE 295P.name: Special Topics in Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering
ENGRMAE 295P.description: Studies in selected areas of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
ENGRMAE 295P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

ENGRMAE 296.name: Master of Science Thesis Research
ENGRMAE 296.description: Individual research or investigation conducted in the pursuit of preparing and completing the thesis required for the M.S. in Engineering.

ENGRMAE 297.name: Doctor of Philosophy Dissertation Research
ENGRMAE 297.description: Individual research or investigation conducted in the pursuit of preparing and completing the dissertation required for the Ph.D. in Engineering.

ENGRMAE 298.name: Seminars in Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering
ENGRMAE 298.description: Presentation of advanced topics and reports of current research efforts in mechanical engineering. Required of all graduate students in mechanical engineering.

ENGRMAE 299.name: Individual Research
ENGRMAE 299.description: Individual research or investigation under the direction of an individual faculty member.
ENGRMAE 299.restriction: Restriction: Consent of instructor to enroll

EPIDEM 199.name: Undergraduate Research in Epidemiology
EPIDEM 199.description: Provides disciplinary research participation. Original or existing research options provide undergraduates the opportunity for faculty/mentor interactions including access to appropriate facilities. Medical Epidemiology research areas: Cancer, Genetic/Molecular, Environmental, Occupational, Biostatistics, and Infectious Disease.

EPIDEM 200A.name: Principles of Epidemiology
EPIDEM 200A.description: Fundamental principles of epidemiology, biostatistics, and epidemiological research. Topics include research methods of measuring health problems in populations, disease control and prevention in populations, how epidemiology contributes to knowledge of disease etiology, and biostatistical analysis and interpretation of epidemiologic data.

EPIDEM 200B.name: Intermediate Epidemiology
EPIDEM 200B.description: Learn to design and conduct epidemiologic studies using common designs. Determine why bias and measurement error arise in observational studies, and how they influence effect estimates. Perform and interpret epidemiologic data analyses using statistical software.
EPIDEM 200B.prereqString: Prerequisite: PUBHLTH 206A. PUBHLTH 206A with a grade of B or better
EPIDEM 200B.restriction: Restriction: College of Health Sciences students only. Program in Public Health students only. Master of Public Health Degree students only. Graduate students only. Epidemiology Majors only.

EPIDEM 200C.name: Advanced Epidemiologic Methods
EPIDEM 200C.description: Advanced topics in the design and statistical analysis of epidemiologic studies. Topics include simulation methods, counter-matching and multiphase study designs, missing data, and Bayesian analysis. Published simulation studies are discussed and replicated using the R software package.
EPIDEM 200C.prereqString: Prerequisite: EPIDEM 200A and EPIDEM 200B. EPIDEM 200A with a grade of B or better. EPIDEM 200B with a grade of B or better

EPIDEM 201.name: Cancer Epidemiology
EPIDEM 201.description: Concentrates on understanding how epidemiology plays a role in the search for cancer etiology, prevention, control, and treatment
EPIDEM 201.prereqString: Prerequisite: EPIDEM 203 or PUBHLTH 203 or PUBH 206

EPIDEM 202.name: Genetic Epidemiology
EPIDEM 202.description: Concentrates on the role of genetic factors in the etiology of disease in human populations with an objective of disease control and prevention and the role of interactions of genetic factors and environmental exposures in the occurrence of disease.
EPIDEM 202.prereqString: Prerequisite: PUBHLTH 203 or EPIDEM 203 or PUBH 206

EPIDEM 204A.name: Biostatistics I: Introduction to Statistical Methods
EPIDEM 204A.description: Designed to help students develop an appreciation for statistician's view of the research process, emphasizing biomedical research. Instills an understanding of how statistical models are used to yield insights about data that form evidence-based understanding of the world around us.

EPIDEM 204B.name: Biostatistics II: Intermediate Statistical Methods
EPIDEM 204B.description: Intended for graduate students in epidemiology, public health, and clinical research fields. Covers common regression-modeling techniques frequently used in biologic and medical applications.
EPIDEM 204B.prereqString: Prerequisite: EPIDEM 204. EPIDEM 204 with a grade of B or better

EPIDEM 204C.name: Biostatistics III: Advanced Statistical Methods
EPIDEM 204C.description: Intended for graduate students in epidemiology, public health, and related fields.  Introduces statistical methods for analyzing survival and longitudinal/clustered data, and techniques to resolve missing data.
EPIDEM 204C.prereqString: Prerequisite: EPIDEM 204B. EPIDEM 204B with a grade of B or better

EPIDEM 205.name: Environmental Epidemiology
EPIDEM 205.description: Concentrates on epidemiological approaches to the assessment of community environmental hazards

EPIDEM 212.name: Methods for Design and Implementation of Epidemiologic Research
EPIDEM 212.description: Intended for students in epidemiology, public health, and related fields, and covers topics in subject recruitment, data collection, quality assessment and control, and sample-size estimation.
EPIDEM 212.prereqString:
Corequisite: PUBHLTH 206B
Prerequisite: EPIDEM 200A and EPIDEM 204A. EPIDEM 200A with a grade of B or better. EPIDEM 204A with a grade of B or better

EPIDEM 215.name: Introduction to Statistical Genetics
EPIDEM 215.description: Provides students with knowledge of the basic principles, concepts, and methods used in statistical genetic research. Topics include principles of population genetics, and statistical methods for family- and population-based studies.
EPIDEM 215.prereqString: Prerequisite: Two quarters of upper-division or graduate training in statistical methods.

EPIDEM 232.name: Chronic Disease Epidemiology & Prevention
EPIDEM 232.description: Epidemiological aspects of chronic human diseases. Topics include methodologies for quantifying aspects of prevalent chronic diseases including risk factors, identification of susceptible groups, societal burdens, promising future research

EPIDEM 244.name: Toxic Chemicals in Environment
EPIDEM 244.description: Industrial ecology of toxicants and their impacts on environmental quality and human health. Explores theoretical basis of toxicity thresholds and regulatory issues. Uses classic and contemporary research articles to understand the legacy of traditional toxicants, and to identify emerging threats.

EPIDEM 264.name: Introduction to Environmental Health Science
EPIDEM 264.description: Convergence of agents (chemical, physical, biological, or psychosocial) in environment can emerge as diseases influenced by social, political, and economic factors, allowing them to become rooted in society. How these agents from various spheres come together and impact human health.
EPIDEM 264.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Environmental Health Sciences Majors only. Epidemiology Majors only. Public Health Majors only. Environ Health Sci and Policy Majors only.

EPIDEM 269.name: Air Pollution, Climate, and Health
EPIDEM 269.description: Emission of air pollutants into the atmosphere, physical and meteorological processes that affect transport, and influence on global warming. Concepts of how and where people are most exposed, and how exposures and health effects differ in developed and developing regions.

EPIDEM 275.name: Special Topics in Epidemiology
EPIDEM 275.description: Presents various topics and latest research in the broad field of epidemiology.

EPIDEM 280.name: Epidemiology Research Journal Club
EPIDEM 280.description: Research journal club is a group discussion of recent publications in epidemiology and related fields.  Students rotate as lead discussants, guided by faculty.  All attendees are expected to be familiar with the papers at the start of class.

EPIDEM 282.name: Epidemiology Department Seminar
EPIDEM 282.description: A forum for the presentation of recent research to epidemiology students, faculty, and other interested parties. The atmosphere is informal, yet rigorous. Speakers range from graduate students through distinguished visitors from other institutions.

EPIDEM 290.name: Introduction to Biostatistics and Epidemiology for Medical Fellows
EPIDEM 290.description: Prepares medical fellows and other physicians for rotations in research programs. Understanding of basic biostatistics and study design, and interdependencies between the two. Application of principles in evaluation of medical literature for guidance on patient care and public health policy.

EPIDEM 296.name: M.S. Thesis Research and Writing
EPIDEM 296.description: Individual research and study necessary for a graduate student to prepare and complete the thesis required for the Master of Science (M.S.) degree.

EPIDEM 297.name: PhD Degree Dissertation Research & Writing
EPIDEM 297.description: Individual research and study necessary for a graduate student to prepare and complete the dissertation required for the Doctor of Philosophy (Ph.D.) degree.

EPIDEM 399.name: University Supervised Teaching
EPIDEM 399.description: Limited to students with active Teaching Assistant (T.A.) appointments.

EURO ST 9.name: Topics in Europe in the Middle Ages
EURO ST 9.description: Explores the literature, history, and thought of the European Middle Ages. Topics may include understandings of self and community, aristocratic power and courtly life, colonialism, crusading, religious beliefs and persecution, monasticism and reform, university culture, epic literature, and Arthurian romance.

EURO ST 10.name: Topics in Historical Foundations (1500-1800)
EURO ST 10.description: Offers an overview of the European experience from its social, political, and cultural foundations to modern European issues and institutions in a globalized world. Topics include social, political, and cultural history up to the French Revolution.

EURO ST S10.name: Historical Foundations: Europe and the Foundations of the Modern World
EURO ST S10.description: Encompasses a variety of perspectives in the social sciences and the humanities involving crucial developments coming out of Europe from roughly 1500 to 1800, (the Protestant Reformation through the French Revolution), that helped shape the modern (western) world.

EURO ST 11.name: Issues and Institutions in Modern Europe (1789-1945)
EURO ST 11.description: Offers an overview of modern European societies in social, political, and cultural terms. Topics include shifting geopolitical borders, social movements, and various forms of cultural expression (film, art, literature) as they intersect with and shape issues and events after 1800.

EURO ST S11.name: Europe's Futures: 1755-Present
EURO ST S11.description: Introduces students to competing approaches from humanities and social sciences to conceptualizing the future in politics, art, and literature. From the enlightenment to today, investigates the cultural and political context of moments when new ideas emerged to secure Europe's futures.

EURO ST 12.name: What is the Origin of Language?
EURO ST 12.description: Teaches symbol-based logic and universal grammar in human language as tools to investigate the origin of language. Does language originate with reason? Is language inherently universal or diverse? Does it begin as something literal or figurative.

EURO ST 13.name: Topics in Contemporary Europe (1945 – Today)
EURO ST 13.description: Offers a perspective on contemporary politics and social and cultural life of today’s Europe. Introduces students to literature, film, and social theory crises of the contemporary world as they emanated from World War II, such as nationalism and populism.

EURO ST 101A.name: European Studies Core I - Early Europe (Pre-1789)
EURO ST 101A.description: Introduction to multidisciplinary approaches to important themes in European society, culture, art, literature, and politics

EURO ST 101B.name: European Studies Core II: Modern Europe (Post-1789)
EURO ST 101B.description: Multidisciplinary approaches to important themes in modern European society, culture, art, literature, and politics, encouraging students to see points of intersection among disciplines. Possible themes: Subjects, Citizens, and Representation

EURO ST 102.name: Topics in Early European History and Culture: Pre-1789
EURO ST 102.description: Addresses historical and cultural events, issues, and texts (art, literature, music, political theory) from the pre-1789 period in more than one European country.

EURO ST 103.name: Topics in Modern European History and Culture: Post-1789
EURO ST 103.description: Addresses historical and cultural events, issues, and texts (art, literature, music, political theory) from 1789 to present in more than one European country.

EURO ST 190W.name: Senior Seminar in European Studies
EURO ST 190W.description: Capstone research seminar. Students engage in rigorous, in-depth, interdisciplinary exploration of specific topics, periods, or themes, investigating and analyzing the intersection of material and discursive culture in different historical periods and geographical locations.
EURO ST 190W.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
EURO ST 190W.restriction: Restriction: School of Humanities students only.

EURO ST 199.name: Independent Study
EURO ST 199.description: Directed reading and research in consultation with a faculty advisor.  Substantial written work required.

EURO ST 200A.name: Core Seminar I: Foundations of European Thought and Culture
EURO ST 200A.description: Provides a historical, geographical, and methodological overview of foundational texts and issues in European thought and culture. Covering several historical periods between the Middle Ages and the present, students will see how ideas and institutions change over time.

EURO ST 200B.name: Core Seminar II: Theorizing Periods and Movements in European Thought and Culture
EURO ST 200B.description: Periods and movements still form basic units for organizing European thought and theory, even as such categories are problematized. This course will allow for greater focus on a specific time period or constellation of issues around a period or movement.

EURO ST 200C.name: Core Seminar III: European Thought and Culture Beyond Europe
EURO ST 200C.description: Studies the intersection and afterlives of European thought and culture with and in non-European contexts, the way European thought and culture has been translated and transformed, taken up and challenged, in colonial, postcolonial, and other global situations.

EURO ST 201.name: Topics in European Studies
EURO ST 201.description: Seminars on various topics related to European Studies.

EURO ST 299.name: Independent Research
EURO ST 299.description: For students to do independent research with advisors on their master's thesis or master's examination reading lists.
EURO ST 299.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. School of Humanities students only.

FIN 203A.name: Financial Reporting for Management
FIN 203A.description: Financial reporting is concerned with the preparation and public dissemination of financial reports designed to reflect corporate performance and financial condition. Provides a base level of knowledge needed by corporate executives to understand and discuss corporate financial statements.
FIN 203A.restriction: Restriction: Master of Finance Degree students only. Graduate students only.

FIN 209B.name: Investments Management
FIN 209B.description: Introduction to how securities are traded and how their prices are determined. Discussion of different market organizations, including some recently developed online financial markets. Study of pricing models, including Capital Asset, factor models, and Arbitrage Pricing Theory.
FIN 209B.restriction: Restriction: Master of Finance Degree students only. Graduate students only.

FIN 210.name: Foundations of Finance
FIN 210.description: Examines foundations of finance. Teaches tools such as time value of money, capital budgeting techniques, cash flow analysis. Examines foundations of investment management and theory/empirical evidence related to portfolio theory, market efficiency, asset pricing models, factor models, option pricing theory.
FIN 210.restriction: Restriction: Master of Finance Degree students only.

FIN 211.name: Master of Finance ProSeminar
FIN 211.description: Provides students in the Merage School Master of Finance program with information and practical skills for success in the program and for business career planning.
FIN 211.restriction: Restriction: Master of Finance Degree students only.

FIN 240.name: Financial Research Methodology
FIN 240.description: Provides an introduction into the computational research methods necessary in modern finance, such as optimization, simulation methods, and finite difference and finite element methods. Some applications include quadratic programming for portfolio selection and option pricing.
FIN 240.restriction: Restriction: Master of Finance Degree students only.

FIN 241.name: Risk Management
FIN 241.description: Examines modern techniques for managing financial risks, including market, credit, liquidity, and operational risks. Covers measurement techniques for different financial risks and instruments. Discusses how risk measurement tools can be used for management of the risk/return profile of financial institutions.
FIN 241.prereqString: Prerequisite: FIN 249. FIN 249 with a grade of C or better
FIN 241.restriction: Restriction: Master of Finance Degree students only. Graduate students only.

FIN 242.name: Portfolio Management
FIN 242.description: Provides a working understanding of the themes and concepts of portfolio management. Covers several disciplines, such as investment valuation, investment decision-making, investing styles, asset allocation, monitoring and re-balancing portfolios, risk management strategies, performance evaluation, and attribution analysis.
FIN 242.restriction: Restriction: Master of Finance Degree students only.

FIN 243.name: Bonds and Fixed Income
FIN 243.description: Addresses concepts covering a broad spectrum of debt securities with emphasis on qualitative and quantitative analysis of fixed income securities in many areas, including corporate (credit) debt, MBS/ABS, structured debt, and credit derivatives.

FIN 244.name: Multinational Finance
FIN 244.description: Examines the history of the world’s foreign exchange markets, the macroeconomics of foreign exchange, major parity conditions, hedging of currency exposure and international investment. Gives students a basic understanding of foreign exchange market.

FIN 246F.name: Seminar in Management of the Real Estate Enterprise
FIN 246F.description: Capstone seminar. Looks beyond “The Deal” to management of the real estate enterprise itself. Explores aspects of decision-making focused upon strategic objectives: goal setting, legal/tax structures, public vs. closely-held entities, corporate ethics, capital structure, managing growth, diversification, technology. Guest professionals.
FIN 246F.restriction: Restriction: Master of Finance Degree students only. Graduate students only.

FIN 246G.name: Applied Real Estate Security Analysis and Portfolio Management
FIN 246G.description: Provides an understanding of the public real estate investment trust (REIT) market and its place in modern investment strategies, presents methods for analyzing and valuing companies, and introduces basic concepts for constructing and managing a real estate investment portfolio.
FIN 246G.restriction: Restriction: Master of Finance Degree students only. Graduate students only.

FIN 247.name: Cases in Corporate Financial Management
FIN 247.description: Case-based course in corporate finance. Introduces advanced analytical tools and techniques for value-based financial management in a broad range of corporate settings, including financial forecasting, mergers and acquisitions, leveraged buyouts, ownership and control, corporate restructuring, and financial distress.
FIN 247.restriction: Restriction: Master of Finance Degree students only.

FIN 248.name: Corporate Valuation
FIN 248.description: Expands on concepts covered in introductory finance. Combines lectures and cases designed to confront students with real-world problems to enhance their understanding of the value and limitations of finance theory. Focuses on the value of firms/projects in diverse settings.
FIN 248.prereqString: Prerequisite: FIN 210. FIN 210 with a grade of C or better
