FIN 248.restriction: Restriction: Master of Finance Degree students only.

FIN 249.name: Derivatives
FIN 249.description: Covers major derivative instruments that are widely used for hedging, including forward, futures, swaps and options, speculation, and arbitrage. Focuses on understanding the instruments, how to use and price them, basic risk management principles, and how to implement investment strategies.
FIN 249.restriction: Restriction: Master of Finance Degree students only.

FIN 250.name: Mergers and Acquisitions
FIN 250.description: Focuses on mastering mergers and acquisitions concepts and techniques that will enable participants to practically apply them in related fields such as investment banking, consulting, and corporate development. Studies drivers of success in M&A with heavy attention on transactional review.
FIN 250.restriction: Restriction: Master of Finance Degree students only.

FIN 251.name: Behavioral Finance
FIN 251.description: Describes the scientific evidence about where misvaluation comes from, how investors can trade profitably to exploit market inefficiency, how corporate managers should make financing and investment decisions in an inefficient market, and how managers can correct biases to avoid mistakes.
FIN 251.restriction: Restriction: Master of Finance Degree students only.

FIN 252.name: Wealth Management
FIN 252.description: Provides overview of considerations needed to connect singular functional areas that comprise personal and business wealth management, including basic and advanced estate planning, investment management, tax management, life/liability and property/casualty insurance, medical and long‐term care coverage, retirement and philanthropy considerations.

FIN 253.name: Venture Capital and Private Equity
FIN 253.description: Overview of venture capital and private equity, which constitute the “alternative” asset class (as opposed to conventional investments). Many start-up and entrepreneurial firms require substantial capital, and venture capital and private equity organizations finance these high-risk but potentially high-reward companies.
FIN 253.restriction: Restriction: Master of Finance Degree students only.

FIN 254.name: Advanced Derivatives
FIN 254.description: Describes the scientific evidence about where misvaluation come from, how investors can trade profitably to exploit market inefficiency, how corporate managers should make financing and investment decisions in an inefficient market, and how managers can correct their own biases.
FIN 254.prereqString: Prerequisite: FIN 249. FIN 249 with a grade of C or better
FIN 254.restriction: Restriction: Master of Finance Degree students only.

FIN 255.name: Finance Internship
FIN 255.description: Provides students with opportunities to apply knowledge obtained from classroom theory through actual practical work experiences. Also provides knowledge of career opportunities, understanding of finance in business environments, and preparation for the finance profession.
FIN 255.restriction: Restriction: Master of Finance Degree students only.

FIN 290.name: Special Topics in Finance
FIN 290.description: Studies in selected areas of finance. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

FIN 296.name: Master of Finance Capstone
FIN 296.description: Students work in teams on an applied finance project associated with their area of focus to demonstrate knowledge and expertise. The project can involve experiential learning, collaboration with a faculty member, or association with an internship.
FIN 296.restriction: Restriction: Master of Finance Degree students only.

FIN 299.name: Individual Study
FIN 299.description: Individual study under the direction of a select faculty member.

FLM&MDA H80.name: Honors Seminar: Race Sport Media
FLM&MDA H80.description: Honors seminar examining the intersection of race, sports, and media in everyday U.S. popular culture (film, TV, advertising, gaming, social media) and political culture. Materials fee.
FLM&MDA H80.restriction: Restriction: Campuswide Honors Collegium students only.

FLM&MDA 85A.name: Introduction to Film and Visual Analysis
FLM&MDA 85A.description: Introduces the language and techniques of visual and film analysis. Teaches students to analyze the moving image
FLM&MDA 85A.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfaction of the UC Entry Level Writing requirement.

FLM&MDA 85B.name: Broadcast Media History and Analysis
FLM&MDA 85B.description: History of broadcast media from the radio era to the present day, including social, political, institutional, and audience analysis as well as methods of visual and aural analysis of these media.
FLM&MDA 85B.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfaction of the UC Entry Level Writing requirement.

FLM&MDA 85C.name: New Media and Digital Technologies
FLM&MDA 85C.description: The study of digital media, computer-mediated communication, and Internet cultures, from historical and theoretical perspectives.
FLM&MDA 85C.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfaction of the UC Entry Level Writing requirement.

FLM&MDA 101A.name: History of Film I: The Silent Era
FLM&MDA 101A.description: The aesthetic, industrial, and socio-historical developments of cinema in the U.S. and internationally from its invention to the adoption of synchronous sound. Includes early exhibition, developments in narrative and editing, the formation of the studio system, and avant-garde film movements. Materials fee.
FLM&MDA 101A.prereqString: Prerequisite: FLM&MDA 85A. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

FLM&MDA 101B.name: History of Film II: The Studio Era
FLM&MDA 101B.description: The aesthetic, industrial, and socio-historical developments of cinema in the U.S. and internationally from the 1930s through the 1960s. Includes the Hollywood studio system, propaganda films, Italian neorealism, post-war Japanese cinema, and the French New Wave. Materials fee.
FLM&MDA 101B.prereqString: Prerequisite: FLM&MDA 85A. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

FLM&MDA 101C.name: History of Film III: The Contemporary Era
FLM&MDA 101C.description: The aesthetic, industrial, and socio-historical developments of cinema in the U.S. and internationally from the late 1960s to the present. Includes New Hollywood and independent U.S. films, ethnic cinemas, postcolonial cinemas, East-Asian new waves, and digital filmmaking. Materials fee.
FLM&MDA 101C.prereqString: Prerequisite: FLM&MDA 85A and FLM&MDA 101B. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

FLM&MDA 110.name: Film and Media Theory
FLM&MDA 110.description: Survey of major directions in film and media theory. Various theories of mass culture, realism, auteurism, semiotics, feminism, cultural studies, and theories of other media, with an emphasis on developing the student’s ability to analyze and articulate a theoretical argument. Materials fee.
FLM&MDA 110.prereqString: Prerequisite: FLM&MDA 85A and FLM&MDA 85B and FLM&MDA 85C and (FLM&MDA 101A or FLM&MDA 101B or FLM&MDA 101C). Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

FLM&MDA 111.name: Film and Media Theory and Practice
FLM&MDA 111.description: Seminar focusing on issues in film and media production and editing. Reading and exercises to understand aspects of film and media production (montage, sound, film movement, directing, and mise en scène), and how ideology works in tandem with style.
FLM&MDA 111.prereqString: Prerequisite: FLM&MDA 85A and FLM&MDA 85B and FLM&MDA 85C and FLM&MDA 120A and (FLM&MDA 101A or FLM&MDA 101B or FLM&MDA 101C). Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

FLM&MDA 112.name: Genre Study
FLM&MDA 112.description: Critical approaches to the serial productions we call "genre" films such as westerns, weepies, musicals, horror films, and others
FLM&MDA 112.prereqString: Prerequisite: FLM&MDA 85A. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

FLM&MDA 113.name: Narrative/Image
FLM&MDA 113.description: What relations do sound, image, and story assume in film, television, video, and Internet narratives? In what ways do these media interact with and borrow from each other and traditional story-telling media? How have the new media explored non-narrative strategies.
FLM&MDA 113.prereqString: Prerequisite: FLM&MDA 85A. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

FLM&MDA 114.name: Film, Media, and the Arts
FLM&MDA 114.description: A synthetic entity, film draws on both established and popular arts. Looks at visual media's exchanges with "high" and "low" culture, exploring its relation to areas such as photography, music, painting, and architecture.
FLM&MDA 114.prereqString: Prerequisite: FLM&MDA 85A. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

FLM&MDA 115.name: Authorship
FLM&MDA 115.description: Theoretical and analytical discussions of visual media authorship, focusing on case studies of directors, producers, scriptwriters, and film, video, and digital artists.
FLM&MDA 115.prereqString: Prerequisite: FLM&MDA 85A. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

FLM&MDA 117A.name: Introduction to Screenwriting
FLM&MDA 117A.description: Introduction to the technique and format of the screenplay, with a particular focus on its three act structural elements: coverage, treatment, and 60 beat outline. Materials fee.
FLM&MDA 117A.prereqString: Prerequisite: FLM&MDA 85A. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

FLM&MDA 117B.name: Intermediate Screenwriting
FLM&MDA 117B.description: Exercises in the development of screenplays, with emphasis on formal and structural considerations of character development. Students work with the hero structure and other character development methodologies, such as method acting. Materials fee.
FLM&MDA 117B.prereqString: Prerequisite: FLM&MDA 117A. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

FLM&MDA 117C.name: Screenwriting Workshop
FLM&MDA 117C.description: Continuation and intensification of work initiated in 117B. Students complete a full-length screenplay. Concentrates on both practical and technical concerns, addressing pragmatic and aesthetic questions in intensive small-group discussions. Materials fee.
FLM&MDA 117C.prereqString: Prerequisite: FLM&MDA 117B. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

FLM&MDA 118A.name: Writing Television I
FLM&MDA 118A.description: Introduction to the technique and format of the television screenplay. Focuses on character, storytelling, structure, and scene development
FLM&MDA 118A.prereqString: Prerequisite: FLM&MDA 85B. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

FLM&MDA 118B.name: Writing Television II
FLM&MDA 118B.description: Intermediate-level screenwriting class exploring the one-hour television drama format. Students write and workshop an original pilot, continuing work started in 118A, and finish a complete draft of the pilot script.
FLM&MDA 118B.prereqString: Prerequisite: FLM&MDA 118A. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

FLM&MDA 120A.name: Basic Production
FLM&MDA 120A.description: Introduction to the basic apparatus of video/film production. The elementary essentials of production, including the use of camera and lenses, lighting, editing, and sound. Materials fee.
FLM&MDA 120A.prereqString: Prerequisite: FLM&MDA 85A. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

FLM&MDA 120B.name: Intermediate Production
FLM&MDA 120B.description: Students work on individual and group projects, utilizing skills and insights introduced in Film and Media Studies 120A. Materials fee.
FLM&MDA 120B.prereqString: Prerequisite: FLM&MDA 120A. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

FLM&MDA 120C.name: Production Workshop
FLM&MDA 120C.description: As film and video are collaborative media, students form production groups and ultimately produce final 10-15-minute film/video projects. Materials fee.
FLM&MDA 120C.prereqString: Prerequisite: FLM&MDA 120B. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

FLM&MDA 130.name: Multicultural Topics in the Media
FLM&MDA 130.description: Investigation of media representations of gender, race, and sexuality in the United States. Topics include media images of and by one or more minority groups in the United States, including African Americans, Asian Americans, Chicano/Latinos, Native Americans, gays, and lesbians.
FLM&MDA 130.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

FLM&MDA 139W.name: Writing on Film and Media
FLM&MDA 139W.description: Writing on cinema, television, and/or digital culture, emphasizing identification of reliable sources, close readings, addressing academic, professional, and/or popular audiences. Requires at least 4,000 words of assigned composition.
FLM&MDA 139W.prereqString: Prerequisite: FLM&MDA 85A or FLM&MDA 85B or FLM&MDA 85C. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
FLM&MDA 139W.restriction: Restriction: Film and Media Studies Majors only.

FLM&MDA 143.name: Critical Theory of Television
FLM&MDA 143.description: Introduction to critical, theoretical, and scholarly understandings and analyses of television, which offer in-depth analyses of television programming, audience reception practices, and industry strategies of address.
FLM&MDA 143.prereqString: Prerequisite: FLM&MDA 85B. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

FLM&MDA 144.name: Studies in New Media
FLM&MDA 144.description: Advanced analysis of the technologies, texts, theories, and cultures of computers, video games, networks, or platforms.
FLM&MDA 144.prereqString: Prerequisite: FLM&MDA 85C. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

FLM&MDA 145.name: Popular Culture and Media
FLM&MDA 145.description: Considers the forms, ideologies, consumption, and marketing of popular entertainment and technologies. May focus on cultural studies methods, transnational approaches, and synergy between media.
FLM&MDA 145.prereqString: Prerequisite: FLM&MDA 85A. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

FLM&MDA 146.name: Sound Studies
FLM&MDA 146.description: Focuses on the production, theories, and meanings of sound recordings, music, and/or audio technologies. Topics may include the cultures of popular music and audio devices, music television, and theories of film sound.
FLM&MDA 146.prereqString: Prerequisite: FLM&MDA 85A. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

FLM&MDA 150.name: Audiences and Reception
FLM&MDA 150.description: Explores the dynamics of address, interpretation, and appropriation between film and media texts and their viewers. Topics may include reception studies, fandom, audience-defined modes of production, demographics, spectatorial pleasure, and historical approaches to audiences.
FLM&MDA 150.prereqString: Prerequisite: FLM&MDA 85A. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

FLM&MDA 151.name: Documentary and Experimental Film and Media
FLM&MDA 151.description: Examines nonfiction and/or experimental cinemas and media, such as documentary, the historical avant-garde, video art, and activist media. Students consider the specific aesthetics and ideologies of forms distinct from narrative feature films.
FLM&MDA 151.prereqString: Prerequisite: FLM&MDA 85A. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

FLM&MDA 160.name: National/Regional Cinemas and Media
FLM&MDA 160.description: National schools, period styles, or cultural movements beyond U.S. cinema, as defined by national borders or by geographic regions, such as Latin America. May be approached from a comparative perspective.
FLM&MDA 160.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

FLM&MDA 161.name: Global/Transnational Cinemas and Media
FLM&MDA 161.description: Analyzes the multinational production, circulation, and reception of film and media texts beyond singular national borders or specific geographic regions. Topics may include transnational co-productions, exports, and diasporic reception.
FLM&MDA 161.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

FLM&MDA 162.name: US Cinema
FLM&MDA 162.description: Explores the modes of production and distribution, aesthetics, and contexts that have shaped cinema in the United States. Topics may include classical Hollywood, American independent cinema, or periods such as 1970s cinema.
FLM&MDA 162.prereqString: Prerequisite: FLM&MDA 85A. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

FLM&MDA 185.name: Television and New Media
FLM&MDA 185.description: Advanced seminar focusing on special topics in television and new media. Past examples have included courses on media marketing and brand identity
FLM&MDA 185.prereqString: Prerequisite: FLM&MDA 85B or FLM&MDA 85C. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

FLM&MDA 190.name: Special Topics in Film and Modern Media
FLM&MDA 190.description: Special issues concerned with film and media history, theory, and criticism.
FLM&MDA 190.prereqString: Prerequisite: FLM&MDA 85A. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

FLM&MDA 191.name: Special Topics in Critical Practice
FLM&MDA 191.description: Integrates critical analysis, historical, and theoretical methods with creative projects to illuminate film and media production and industries. May include courses in adaptation, writing television, media activism, writing the short film, performance studies, and movie title sequences.
FLM&MDA 191.prereqString: Prerequisite: FLM&MDA 85A. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

FLM&MDA 192.name: Special Topics in Advanced Film Production
FLM&MDA 192.description: Focuses on special topics in production. Culminates in final 6-10-minute group film projects. Topics include producing, acting, and/or directing in short films, experimental films, documentaries, television, and other media.
FLM&MDA 192.prereqString: Prerequisite: FLM&MDA 120A. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

FLM&MDA 193.name: Special Topics in Advanced Screenwriting
FLM&MDA 193.description: Focuses on special topics in screenwriting. Topics include adaptation, alternative screenwriting, writing the first feature, act two construction, and rewriting.
FLM&MDA 193.prereqString: Prerequisite: FLM&MDA 117A or FLM&MDA 118A. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

FLM&MDA 194.name: Special Topics in Interdisciplinary Studies
FLM&MDA 194.description: Interdisciplinary approaches to special issues concerned with film and media history, theory, and criticism.

FLM&MDA 197.name: Professional Internship
FLM&MDA 197.description: Professional internship in the film, broadcast, and/or digital media industries designed to provide students with closely supervised professional experience to enhance their understanding of media from industrial, historical, and critical perspectives. Journal and final report required.

FLM&MDA 198.name: Creative Project
FLM&MDA 198.description: Creative project in screenwriting, filmmaking, videomaking, or Web or internet design intended to provide advanced production and creative writing training beyond the Film and Media Studies 117A-B-C or 120A-B-C series. Final project required.
FLM&MDA 198.prereqString: Prerequisite: (FLM&MDA 85A and FLM&MDA 117A and FLM&MDA 117B and FLM&MDA 117C) or (FLM&MDA 120A and FLM&MDA 120B and FLM&MDA 120C). Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement. Recommended: FLM&MDA 101A.

FLM&MDA 199.name: Directed Research
FLM&MDA 199.description: Directed reading and research under supervision of a faculty member in topic areas not covered by regular course offerings. Final research paper required.
FLM&MDA 199.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

FRENCH 1A.name: Fundamentals of French
FRENCH 1A.description: First quarter of first-year French in a hybrid format. Students are taught to conceptualize in French as they learn to understand, read, write, and speak. Classes are conducted entirely in French.

FRENCH 1AB.name: Intensive Fundamentals of French
FRENCH 1AB.description: Intensive first half of first-year French. Students are taught to conceptualize in French as they learn to read, write, and speak. Students develop an awareness of and sensibility to French and Francophone life and culture through reading, viewing, and discussion.

FRENCH 1ABSP.name: Accelerated Fundamentals of French for Spanish Speakers
FRENCH 1ABSP.description: Accelerated first half of first-year French for Hispanophone students. Teaches conceptualizing in French while learning to read, write, and speak using knowledge of Spanish. Develops awareness of and sensibility to French and Francophone life and culture through reading, viewing, discussing.
FRENCH 1ABSP.prereqString: Prerequisite: Two years of high school Spanish, one semester of college Spanish, or heritage speaker of Spanish.

FRENCH 1B.name: Fundamentals of French
FRENCH 1B.description: First quarter of first-year French in a hybrid format. Students are taught to conceptualize in French as they learn to understand, read, write, and speak. Classes are conducted entirely in French.
FRENCH 1B.prereqString: Prerequisite: FRENCH 1A. FRENCH 1A with a grade of C or better

FRENCH 1BC.name: Intensive Fundamentals of French
FRENCH 1BC.description: Intensive second half of first-year French. Students are taught to conceptualize in French as they learn to read, write, and speak. Students develop an awareness of and sensibility to French and Francophone life and culture through reading, viewing, and discussion.
FRENCH 1BC.prereqString: Prerequisite: FRENCH 1AB or FRENCH 1B or FRENCH S1AB. FRENCH 1AB with a grade of C or better. FRENCH 1B with a grade of C or better. FRENCH S1AB with a grade of C or better. Placement into FRENCH 1BC is also accepted.

FRENCH 1BCSP.name: Accelerated Fundamentals of French for Spanish Speakers
FRENCH 1BCSP.description: Accelerated second half of first-year French for Hispanophone students. Teaches conceptualizing in French while learning to read, write, and speak using knowledge of Spanish. Develops awareness of and sensibility to French and Francophone life and culture through reading, viewing, discussing.
FRENCH 1BCSP.prereqString: Prerequisite: FRENCH 1ABSP or FRENCH 1AB or FRENCH S1AB or FRENCH 1B. FRENCH 1ABSP with a grade of C or better. FRENCH 1AB with a grade of C or better. FRENCH S1AB with a grade of C or better. FRENCH 1B with a grade of C or better. Two years of high school Spanish, one semester of college Spanish, or heritage speaker of Spanish.

FRENCH 1C.name: Fundamentals of French
FRENCH 1C.description: First quarter of first-year French in a hybrid format. Students are taught to conceptualize in French as they learn to understand, read, write, and speak. Classes are conducted entirely in French.
FRENCH 1C.prereqString: Prerequisite: FRENCH 1B. FRENCH 1B with a grade of C or better

FRENCH S1AB.name: Intensive Fundamentals of French
FRENCH S1AB.description: First half of first-year French in an intensified form and hybrid format. Students are taught to conceptualize in French as they learn to understand, read, write, and speak. Classes are conducted entirely in French.

FRENCH S1BC.name: Intensive Fundamentals of French
FRENCH S1BC.description: Second half of first-year French in an intensified form and hybrid format. Students are taught to conceptualize in French as they learn to understand, read, write, and speak. Classes are conducted entirely in French.
FRENCH S1BC.prereqString: Prerequisite: FRENCH S1AB or FRENCH 1B or FRENCH 1AB or FRENCH 1ABSP. FRENCH S1AB with a grade of C or better. FRENCH 1B with a grade of C or better. FRENCH 1AB with a grade of C or better. FRENCH 1ABSP with a grade of C or better

FRENCH 2A.name: Intermediate French
FRENCH 2A.description: Texts of contemporary literary or social interest provide the focus for more advanced conversation, reading, and composition. Classes are conducted entirely in French.
FRENCH 2A.prereqString: Prerequisite: FRENCH 1C or FRENCH 1BC or FRENCH S1BC or FRENCH 1BCSP. FRENCH 1C with a grade of C or better. FRENCH 1BC with a grade of C or better. FRENCH S1BC with a grade of C or better. FRENCH 1BCSP with a grade of C or better. Placement into FRENCH 2A is also accepted.
FRENCH 2A.restriction: Restriction: School of Humanities students have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

FRENCH 2AB.name: Intensive Intermediate French
FRENCH 2AB.description: Intensive first half of second-year French. Texts and films of contemporary literary or social interest provide the focus for more advanced conversation, reading, and composition. Classes are conducted entirely in French.
FRENCH 2AB.prereqString: Prerequisite: FRENCH 1C or FRENCH 1BC or FRENCH S1BC. FRENCH 1C with a grade of C or better. FRENCH 1BC with a grade of C or better. FRENCH S1BC with a grade of C or better. Prior high school or college French is recommended. Placement into French 2AB is also accepted.

FRENCH 2B.name: Intermediate French
FRENCH 2B.description: Texts of contemporary literary or social interest provide the focus for more advanced conversation, reading, and composition. Classes are conducted entirely in French.
FRENCH 2B.prereqString: Prerequisite: FRENCH 2A. FRENCH 2A with a grade of C or better
FRENCH 2B.restriction: Restriction: School of Humanities students have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment. FRENCH 2B and FRENCH S2AB and FRENCH S2BC may not be taken for full credit.

FRENCH 2BC.name: Intensive Intermediate French
FRENCH 2BC.description: Intensive second half of second-year French. Texts and films of contemporary literary or social interest provide the focus for more advanced conversation, reading, and composition. Classes are conducted entirely in French.
FRENCH 2BC.prereqString: Prerequisite: FRENCH S2AB or FRENCH 2AB. FRENCH S2AB with a grade of C or better. FRENCH 2AB with a grade of C or better. Prior high school or college French is recommended. Placement into French 2BC is also accepted.

FRENCH 2C.name: Intermediate French
FRENCH 2C.description: Texts of contemporary literary or social interest provide the focus for more advanced conversation, reading, and composition. Classes are conducted entirely in French.
FRENCH 2C.prereqString: Prerequisite: FRENCH 2B or FRENCH S2AB. FRENCH 2B with a grade of C or better. FRENCH S2AB with a grade of C or better
FRENCH 2C.restriction: Restriction: School of Humanities students have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment. FRENCH 2C and FRENCH S2BC may not be taken for full credit.

FRENCH S2AB.name: Intermediate French
FRENCH S2AB.description: First half of second-year French in an intensified form. Texts of contemporary literary or social interest provide the focus for more advanced conversation, reading, and composition. Classes are conducted entirely in French. Prior high school or college French recommended.
FRENCH S2AB.prereqString: Prerequisite: FRENCH 1C or FRENCH 1BC or FRENCH S1BC. FRENCH 1C with a grade of C or better. FRENCH 1BC with a grade of C or better. FRENCH S1BC with a grade of C or better. Placement into FRENCH S2AB is also accepted.
FRENCH S2AB.restriction: Restriction: FRENCH S2AB and FRENCH 2A and FRENCH 2B may not be taken for full credit.

FRENCH S2BC.name: Intermediate French
FRENCH S2BC.description: Second half of second-year French in an intensified form. Texts of contemporary literary or social interest provide the focus for more advanced conversation, reading, and composition. Classes are conducted entirely in French. Prior high school or college French recommended.
FRENCH S2BC.prereqString: Prerequisite: FRENCH S2AB or FRENCH 2B. FRENCH S2AB with a grade of C or better. FRENCH 2B with a grade of C or better
FRENCH S2BC.restriction: Restriction: FRENCH S2BC and FRENCH 2B and FRENCH 2C may not be taken for full credit.

FRENCH 10.name: French Peer Tutoring
FRENCH 10.description: Tutoring Program in which advanced French students provide assistance to students at a lower level. One hour of tutoring per week.

FRENCH 50.name: Topics in French Culture and the Modern World
FRENCH 50.description: Introductory course for non-majors. Focuses on France's role in the modern world and its cultural connections to Asia, the Middle East, Africa, Europe, and the Americas. Taught in English.

FRENCH 97.name: Fundamentals of French (with Emphasis on Reading)
FRENCH 97.description: Designed primarily for students interested in acquiring a solid reading knowledge of French, and to facilitate the understanding and translating of French texts dealing with a variety of disciplines.

FRENCH 101A.name: Introduction to 19th-Century French Literature
FRENCH 101A.description: Fiction, nonfiction, drama, and poetry of the 19th century studied in relationship to a specific literary or historical problem.

FRENCH 101B.name: Introduction to 18th-Century French Literature
FRENCH 101B.description: Literature and philosophy of the 18th century studied in relationship to a specific literary or historical problem.

FRENCH 101C.name: Introduction to 20th-Century French Literature
FRENCH 101C.description: Literatures of the French-speaking world studied in relationship to a specific literary or historical problem.

FRENCH 102A.name: Grammar and Composition
FRENCH 102A.description: Review of grammar taught in FRENCH 2A-B-C. Students gain facility in writing French and increase reading comprehension. Short texts and films are introduced to generate substantive discussion, and multiple short writing exercises are assigned to solidify skills. Formerly FRENCH 60.

FRENCH 102B.name: Topics in Issues in French and Francophone Culture
FRENCH 102B.description: Investigation of an issue of cultural significance in the francophone world through historical documents, literary works, and newspaper articles. Supplemented with films and/or other elements of popular culture. Multiple short writing assignments to solidify writing skills. Formerly FRENCH 61.

FRENCH 102C.name: Translation
FRENCH 102C.description: Introduction to the theory and practice of translation from French to English and English to French. Many opportunities provided to improve skills in writing and comprehension. Formerly FRENCH 62.

FRENCH 102D.name: Topics in the Work World in French
FRENCH 102D.description: A view into the world of work in French. Areas of study include international relations

FRENCH 102E.name: Advanced French Language and Style
FRENCH 102E.description: Intended for advanced students who wish to improve their expressive capabilities in French. Review of more nuanced grammar points. Emphasis placed on rhetoric, syntax, and precision. Advanced readings increase comprehension. Formerly FRENCH 64.

FRENCH 117.name: Topics in 17th-Century French Literature
FRENCH 117.description: Examines the age of drama and other vibrant forms in French literature of the period.
FRENCH 117.prereqString: Prerequisite: FRENCH 2C or FRENCH 2BC or FRENCH S2BC. FRENCH 2C with a grade of C or better. FRENCH 2BC with a grade of C or better. FRENCH S2BC with a grade of C or better

FRENCH 118.name: Topics in 18th-Century French Literature
FRENCH 118.description: Examines the literature and philosophy of the Enlightenment, the Ancient Régime, Classicism, and/or Revolution.
FRENCH 118.prereqString: Prerequisite: FRENCH 2C or FRENCH 2BC or FRENCH S2BC. FRENCH 2C with a grade of C or better. FRENCH 2BC with a grade of C or better. FRENCH S2BC with a grade of C or better

FRENCH 119.name: Topics in 19th-Century French Literature
FRENCH 119.description: Focuses on the literature of an era that experienced many modernist transformations.
FRENCH 119.prereqString: Prerequisite: FRENCH 2C or FRENCH 2BC or FRENCH S2BC. FRENCH 2C with a grade of C or better. FRENCH 2BC with a grade of C or better. FRENCH S2BC with a grade of C or better

FRENCH 120.name: Topics in 20th-Century French and Francophone Literature
FRENCH 120.description: A study of modern and contemporary literature and culture.
FRENCH 120.prereqString: Prerequisite: FRENCH 2C or FRENCH 2BC or FRENCH S2BC. FRENCH 2C with a grade of C or better. FRENCH 2BC with a grade of C or better. FRENCH S2BC with a grade of C or better

FRENCH 127.name: Topics in Francophone Literature and Culture
FRENCH 127.description: Literature and cultures of the francophone world.

FRENCH 139W.name: Literature and Society
FRENCH 139W.description: In English. Readings of masterpieces of French literature in their social, political, and historical contexts. Requires at least 4,000 words of assigned composition based on French works. Several essays required.
FRENCH 139W.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
FRENCH 139W.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. French Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

FRENCH 140.name: Topics in French Literary Genre
FRENCH 140.description: Examines the development and transformation of a single genre, such as the poem or the novel.
FRENCH 140.prereqString: Prerequisite: FRENCH 2C or FRENCH 2BC or FRENCH S2BC. FRENCH 2C with a grade of C or better. FRENCH 2BC with a grade of C or better. FRENCH S2BC with a grade of C or better

FRENCH 150.name: Topics in French Literature and Culture
FRENCH 150.description: Study of a theme, movement, or problem crucial to understanding French Literature and Culture.

FRENCH 160.name: French Cinema
FRENCH 160.description: Study of a period, movement, or theme in French or Francophone cinema.

FRENCH 170.name: Topics in History and Literature
FRENCH 170.description: Examines the dialogue between historical events and literary texts.

FRENCH 171.name: Politics and Literature
FRENCH 171.description: Examines the role played by politics and ethics in French literature, film, and culture.

FRENCH 180.name: Topics in Theory and Criticism
FRENCH 180.description: Advanced study of theoretical and critical texts.

FRENCH 185.name: Junior/Senior Seminar in French Literature and Culture
FRENCH 185.description: Required intensive writing course for French majors to explore in depth selected topic in French literature and culture. Students complete major independent research project on topic studied, making use of literary and critical materials in their capstone essay.  In French.
FRENCH 185.prereqString: Prerequisite: FRENCH 100A and FRENCH 100B and FRENCH 101A and FRENCH 101B and FRENCH 101C. One course from FRENCH 101A, FRENCH 101B, or FRENCH 101C may be taken as a corequisite.

FRENCH 199.name: Special Studies in French
FRENCH 199.description: A project proposal is prepared by the student and approved by the faculty member who directs the project. Procedure must be completed by the end of the first week of classes.
FRENCH 199.restriction: Restriction: Repeatability: once for M.A. candidates

FRENCH 216.name: Studies in Renaissance Literature
FRENCH 216.description: Advanced study of a topic in the Renaissance period.

FRENCH 217.name: Studies in Seventeenth-Century Literature
FRENCH 217.description: Advanced study of a topic in the 17th century.

FRENCH 218.name: Studies in Eighteenth-Century Literature
FRENCH 218.description: Advanced study of a topic in the 18th century.

FRENCH 219.name: Studies in Nineteenth-Century Literature
FRENCH 219.description: Advanced study of a topic in the 19th century.

FRENCH 220.name: Studies in Twentieth-Century Literature
FRENCH 220.description: Advanced study of a topic in the 20th and 21st century.

FRENCH 225.name: Francophone Literature and Culture
FRENCH 225.description: Studies in different francophone literatures and cultures (of Canada, the Caribbean, West and North Africa, and Southeast Asia).

FRENCH 232.name: Studies in Nonfictional Prose
FRENCH 232.description: Examines non-fictional genres such as the essay and the memoir.

FRENCH 233.name: Studies in Poetry and Poetics
FRENCH 233.description: Examines the genre of poetry and theories of poetry.

FRENCH 250.name: Studies in Theory and Criticism
FRENCH 250.description: Advanced study of a topic in theory and/or criticism.

FRENCH 254.name: History and Literature
FRENCH 254.description: Advanced study of literary works in their historical context.

FRENCH 272.name: Cultural Studies
FRENCH 272.description: Examines the theoretical paradigm of cultural studies.

FRENCH 290.name: Research in French Language and Literature
FRENCH 290.description: A project proposal is prepared by the student and approved by the faculty member who directs the project. Procedure must be completed by the end of the first week of classes.  Limit: Once for M.A. candidates
FRENCH 290.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. French Majors only.

FRENCH 299.name: Dissertation Research
FRENCH 299.description: For graduate students writing a dissertation with a faculty member in French.
FRENCH 299.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. School of Humanities students only.

FRENCH 399.name: University Teaching
FRENCH 399.description: For graduate students completing a course on foreign language pedagogy.
FRENCH 399.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. School of Humanities students only.

GDIM 25.name: Game Design Fundamentals
GDIM 25.description: Explore the fundamentals of game design through the design and play of simple analog game systems. Students explore the principles and usage of game design elements through hands-on projects emphasizing iteration and playtesting in a creative game design community.
GDIM 25.restriction: Restriction: Computer Game Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Game Design and Interactive Media students have first consideration for enrollment. School of ICS majors have second right of consideration

GDIM 27.name: Intermediate Game Design
GDIM 27.description: More advanced study of game design principles and systems design through the study of complex problems and play experiences. Topics include economies, game balancing, level design, prototyping, stat design, playtesting, and design documentation.
GDIM 27.restriction: Restriction: Computer Game Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Game Design and Interactive Media students have first consideration for enrollment. School of ICS majors have second right of consideration.

GDIM 31.name: Introduction to Programming for Games
GDIM 31.description: Learn the fundamentals of programming for games through hands-on exercises in programming languages like C#, Processing, Visual Studio, .NET, and the Unity engine. Students build several small game prototypes. Materials fee.
GDIM 31.restriction: Restriction: Game Design and Interactive Media students have first consideration for enrollment. School of ICS majors have second right of consideration.

GDIM 32.name: Intermediate Programming for Games
GDIM 32.description: Students advance their skills with game programming, building on existing skills developed in Introduction to Programming for Games. Hands-on projects emphasize general procedural and problem-solving skills, as well as furthering knowledge of C# and the Unity3D/Unreal game engines.
GDIM 32.restriction: Restriction: Computer Game Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Game Design and Interactive Media students have first consideration for enrollment. School of ICS majors will have second consideration.

GDIM 33.name: Coding In Game Engines
GDIM 33.description: Introduces students to visual scripting tools in game engines in the context of game design, level, design, and experience design. Students gain fluency in one or more visual scripting languages.
GDIM 33.prereqString: Prerequisite: GDIM 32. GDIM 32 with a grade of C or better
GDIM 33.restriction: Restriction: Computer Game Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Game Design and Interactive Media students have first consideration for enrollment. School of ICS majors have second right of consideration.

GDIM 41.name: Games and Society
GDIM 41.description: The study and critical analysis of computer games as art objects, cultural artifacts, gateways to virtual worlds, educational aids, and tools for persuasion and social change. Emphasis on understanding games in their historical and cultural context.  Materials fee.
GDIM 41.restriction: Restriction: Computer Game Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Game Design and Interactive Media students have first consideration for enrollment. School of ICS majors have second right of consideration.

GDIM 49.name: Special Topics in Games and Society
GDIM 49.description: Studies in selected areas of games and their relationship to society. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
GDIM 49.restriction: Restriction: Computer Game Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Game Design and Interactive Media students have first consideration for enrollment. School of ICS majors have second right of consideration.

GDIM 51.name: Visual Design Fundamentals
GDIM 51.description: The principles, tools, and techniques of visual design for playable media. How do shape, line, color, composition, typography, and time work together to communicate information, emotion, and meaning in interfaces, game worlds, and stories. Materials fee.
GDIM 51.restriction: Restriction: Computer Game Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Game Design and Interactive Media students have first consideration for enrollment. School of ICS majors have second right of consideration.

GDIM 53.name: Roleplaying and Improvisational Play
GDIM 53.description: How do practices of performance, role-playing, and improvisation overlap with contemporary practices of game design? Connecting these forms of play to their contemporary uses within role-playing games, virtual worlds, and playable media more broadly.
GDIM 53.restriction: Restriction: Game Design and Interactive Media students have first consideration for enrollment. School of ICS majors have second right of consideration.

GDIM 55.name: Storytelling for Interactive Media
GDIM 55.description: The history, theory, and practice of interactive storytelling for games and other interactive media. Starting with the emergence of electronic literature and hypertext narratives, students encounter and experience a compressed history of this emergent form through play, analysis, and design. Materials fee.
GDIM 55.restriction: Restriction: Game Design and Interactive Media students have first consideration for enrollment. School of ICS majors have second right of consideration.

GDIM 61.name: Introduction to Game Development
GDIM 61.description: Introduction to the design and development of games. Includes core concepts in software development, team management, leadership, and project management.
GDIM 61.restriction: Restriction: Game Design and Interactive Media students have first consideration for enrollment. School of ICS majors have second right of consideration.

GDIM 127.name: Professional Studio/Practicum
GDIM 127.description: Professional skills are essential in today’s competitive job market. Covers interview techniques, resume building, professional networking, personal brand development, online portfolios, and presentation.
GDIM 127.prereqString: Prerequisite: GDIM 161. GDIM 161 with a grade of C or better
GDIM 127.restriction: Restriction: Seniors only. Game Design and Interactive Media students have first consideration for enrollment. School of ICS majors have second right of consideration.

GDIM 129.name: Special Topics in Advanced Game Design
GDIM 129.description: Studies in selected areas of advanced game design. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
GDIM 129.prereqString: Prerequisite: GDIM 27. GDIM 27 with a grade of C or better
GDIM 129.restriction: Restriction: Game Design and Interactive Media students have first consideration for enrollment. School of ICS majors have second right of consideration.

GDIM 131.name: Data Analytics for Games and Interactive Media
GDIM 131.description: Survey of analysis methods for understanding player data, including playtesting, telemetry data collection and analysis, metrics visualization, and its application in development and business.
GDIM 131.restriction: Restriction: Game Design and Interactive Media students have first consideration for enrollment. School of ICS majors have second right of consideration.

GDIM 139.name: Special Topics in Game Programming
GDIM 139.description: Studies in selected areas of game programming. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
GDIM 139.restriction: Restriction: Game Design and Interactive Media students have first consideration for enrollment. School of ICS majors have second right of consideration.

GDIM 149.name: Special Topics in Games and Society
GDIM 149.description: Studies in selected areas of games and their relationship to society. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
GDIM 149.restriction: Restriction: Game Design and Interactive Media students have first consideration for enrollment. School of ICS majors have second right of consideration.

GDIM 161.name: Multiplayer Game Project
GDIM 161.description: Design and develop a multiplayer game using Unity or similar engine, with a focus on learning to work in a development team, writing design documents, working with platform features and limitations, developing engaging mechanics, playtesting, and post-mortems.
GDIM 161.prereqString: Prerequisite: GDIM 27 and GDIM 33 and GDIM 51 and GDIM 61. GDIM 27 with a grade of C or better. GDIM 33 with a grade of C or better
GDIM 161.restriction: Restriction: Computer Game Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Game Design and Interactive Media students have first consideration for enrollment. School of ICS majors are given second consideration.

GDIM 163.name: Solo Game Project
GDIM 163.description: Students work on their own to design, develop, and playtest a small game from scratch, taking into consideration psychology, narrative, platform features and limitations, marketing, computer science capabilities, human-computer interface principles, industry trends, aesthetic judgment, and other factors.
GDIM 163.prereqString: Prerequisite: GDIM 27 and GDIM 33 and GDIM 51 and GDIM 61. GDIM 27 with a grade of C or better. GDIM 33 with a grade of C or better
GDIM 163.restriction: Restriction: Game Design and Interactive Media students have first consideration for enrollment. School of ICS majors given second consideration.

GDIM 165.name: Games Entrepreneurship
GDIM 165.description: As the audiences for games continue to diversify so have the channels for game publishing and monetization. Explore connections between the business and creative side of games in context like esports, education, indie game development, mobile apps, and AAA studios.
GDIM 165.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. Computer Game Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Game Design and Interactive Media students have first consideration for enrollment. School of ICS majors given second consideration.

GDIM 167A.name: Capstone Game Project I
GDIM 167A.description: Students work in teams to design and implement a unique game or interactive experience. Emphasis on sound, art, and level design, building a community, production values, full utilization of hardware and software platform, and current industry trends.
GDIM 167A.prereqString: Prerequisite: ICS 168 or (GDIM 131 and GDIM 161). GDIM 161 with a grade of C or better
GDIM 167A.restriction: Restriction: Seniors only. Computer Game Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Game Design and Interactive Media students have first consideration for enrollment. School of ICS majors given second right of consideration.

GDIM 167B.name: Capstone Game Project II
GDIM 167B.description: Students continue work in teams to design and implement a unique game or interactive experience. Emphasis on sound, art, and level design, building a community, production values, full utilization of hardware and software platform, and current industry trends.
GDIM 167B.prereqString: Prerequisite: GDIM 167A or ICS 169A. GDIM 167A with a grade of C or better. ICS 169A with a grade of C or better. In Progress grade for GDIM 167A or ICS 169A also accepted.
GDIM 167B.restriction: Restriction: Seniors only. Computer Game Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Game Design and Interactive Media students have first consideration for enrollment. School of ICS majors given second right of consideration.

GEN&SEX 20.name: Introduction to Queer Studies
GEN&SEX 20.description: Study of sexuality from the perspective of lesbian, gay, queer, transgender scholarship spanning humanities, social sciences, and arts.

GEN&SEX 50A.name: Gender and Feminism in Everyday Life
GEN&SEX 50A.description: What is gender? Why does studying it matter? Explores how feminism has understood not only gender as a category of social analysis, but how gender structures personal identities, family, citizenship, work and leisure, social policy, sexuality, and language.

GEN&SEX 50B.name: Gender and Power
GEN&SEX 50B.description: From workplace to home to schools to prisons, how are societal institutions and politics “gendered”? Examines power and inequalities around gender, race, class, and sexuality in national and transnational contexts.

GEN&SEX 50C.name: Gender and Popular Culture
GEN&SEX 50C.description: An investigation of gender, race, and sexuality in film, TV, video, music, and advertising, with attention to the ways that popular culture shapes understandings of technology, national identities, leisure and work, historical memory, international communication, and multicultural representation.

GEN&SEX 60A.name: Gender and Science
GEN&SEX 60A.description: Examines science from a variety of feminist viewpoints in order to explore how science influences everyday life.  Special attention is given to the ways science shapes our understanding of gender, race, and sexuality.

GEN&SEX 60B.name: Gender and Law
GEN&SEX 60B.description: Introduction to the relationship between gender, race, sexuality, and the law.  Critical thinking about how law defines citizenship, political representation, and democracy, focusing on the history of legal reform undertaken in the name of women as a social group.

GEN&SEX 60C.name: Gender and Religion
GEN&SEX 60C.description: Introduces the topic of religion in a feminist context by performing cross-cultural exploration of gender, authority, and faith in various traditions. Study includes (but is not limited to) writings of contemporary Jewish, Christian, and Muslim feminists.

GEN&SEX 100A.name: Feminism and Social Change
GEN&SEX 100A.description: Explores feminist modes of knowledge production in relation to histories and activist practices of various social movements. Examines the kinds of information, research, ideas, theories, and concepts that underlie feminist cultural analysis and social movement organizing.

GEN&SEX 100B.name: Feminist Theory
GEN&SEX 100B.description: Introduction to historical traditions in theory and various conceptual frameworks informing scholarship in gender studies, sexuality studies, and women's studies as a field of critical inquiry.

GEN&SEX 100C.name: Feminist Cultural Studies
GEN&SEX 100C.description: Investigation of the theories and methods that inform the feminist study of culture.  Focuses on the interpretation of the visual arts and literature created by, and predominately for, women.

GEN&SEX 100D.name: Queer Knowledges
GEN&SEX 100D.description: Explores the emergence of historical elaboration of non-normative sexual identities, practices, and communities

GEN&SEX 110A.name: Gender, State, and Nation
GEN&SEX 110A.description: Examination of gender and sexuality in relation to the production of identities created through participation in state and nation. Examines complexity of relationship between feminism and nationalism, feminism and the state.

GEN&SEX 110B.name: Money, Sex, and Power
GEN&SEX 110B.description: Examination of gender and sexuality in relation to the emergence of the modern world, modernity, and capitalism

GEN&SEX 110D.name: The Politics of Health and Medicine
GEN&SEX 110D.description: Focuses on cultural and political-economic analysis and representations of disease both within the U.S. and globally.

GEN&SEX 120A.name: Histories of Sexuality
GEN&SEX 120A.description: Examines the historical production of non-normative sexual and gender identities, bodies, practices, and communities. Explores how past formations inform and shape the present and future.

GEN&SEX 120B.name: Image Problems
GEN&SEX 120B.description: Examination of scholarly approaches to gender stereotypes and politics of representation as they present possibilities for critical analysis and produce problems and limitations

GEN&SEX 120C.name: Practices of Embodiment
GEN&SEX 120C.description: Explores how science, medicine, and law have shaped the understanding of differentiated bodies

GEN&SEX 139.name: Topics in Gender Studies
GEN&SEX 139.description: Various topics in gender studies. Encompasses issues of gender, culture, race and class, including issues of sexualities and social justice.

GEN&SEX 155.name: Topics in Gender and Sexuality Studies
GEN&SEX 155.description: Designed to provide students with an opportunity to conduct advanced work in Gender and Sexuality Studies.

GEN&SEX 157.name: Topics in Queer Studies
GEN&SEX 157.description: Explores issues in queer studies from one or more of the following perspectives:  theoretical, historical, legal, economic, political, sociological, and representation in the arts.

GEN&SEX 165F.name: Gender and Technology
GEN&SEX 165F.description: Using a variety of disciplinary methods, examines how various technological processes and products produce culturally complex meanings associated with gender and technology.

GEN&SEX 167A.name: Militarism and Gender
GEN&SEX 167A.description: Examination of feminist approaches to militarism, war, and political violence

GEN&SEX 170.name: Topics in Gender, Feminism, Literature, and Language
GEN&SEX 170.description: Topics cover issues in language and literature which relate to women or gender, or which are taught from a feminist methodological perspective.

GEN&SEX 171.name: Topics in Gender, Feminism, and History
GEN&SEX 171.description: Topics cover issues in history which relate to women or gender, or which are taught from a feminist methodological perspective.

GEN&SEX 171A.name: Sex and Conquest in Latin America
GEN&SEX 171A.description: Competing ideas of masculinity and femininity, sexual violence, sexual identities, and gendered hierarchies informed how the Spanish engaged in military and religious domination of Mexican and Andean communities, as well as the forms of native resistance throughout colonial Latin America.

GEN&SEX 174.name: Topics in Gender, Feminism, and the Arts
GEN&SEX 174.description: Topics cover issues in the arts which relate to women or gender, or which are taught from a feminist methodological perspective.

GEN&SEX 175.name: Topics in Gender, Feminism, and the Media
GEN&SEX 175.description: Topics cover issues in the media which relate to women or gender, or which are taught from a feminist methodological perspective.

GEN&SEX 180.name: Topics in Gender, Feminism, and Anthropology
GEN&SEX 180.description: Topics cover issues in Anthropology which relate to women or gender, or which are taught from a feminist methodological perspective.

GEN&SEX 181.name: Topics in  Gender, Feminism, and Cognitive Psychology
GEN&SEX 181.description: Topics cover issues in cognitive psychology which relate to women or gender, or which are taught from a feminist methodological perspective.

GEN&SEX 182.name: Topics in Gender, Feminism and Economics
GEN&SEX 182.description: Topics cover issues in economics which relate to women and gender or which are taught from a feminist methodological perspective.

GEN&SEX 183.name: Topics in Gender, Feminism, and Sociology
GEN&SEX 183.description: Topics cover issues in sociology which relate to women or gender, or which are taught from a feminist methodological perspective.

GEN&SEX 184.name: Topics in  Gender, Feminism, and Political Science
GEN&SEX 184.description: Topics cover issues in political science which relate to women or gender, or which are taught from a feminist methodological perspective.

GEN&SEX 185.name: Topics in Gender, Feminism, and Social Sciences
GEN&SEX 185.description: Topics cover issues in social sciences which relate to women or gender, or which are taught from a feminist methodological perspective.

GEN&SEX 187.name: Topics in Gender, Feminism, and Social Ecology
GEN&SEX 187.description: Topics cover issues in social ecology which relate to women or gender, or which are taught from a feminist methodological perspective.

GEN&SEX 188.name: Topics in Gender, Feminism, and Science
GEN&SEX 188.description: Topics cover issues in science which relate to women or gender, or which are taught from a feminist methodological perspective.

GEN&SEX 189.name: Topics in Gender, Feminism, and Interdisciplinary Studies
GEN&SEX 189.description: Topics cover issues in interdisciplinary studies which relate to women or gender, or which are taught from a feminist methodological perspective.

GEN&SEX 190.name: Topics in Sexualities Studies
GEN&SEX 190.description: Topics cover issues in the humanities, social sciences, sciences, and arts that relate to critical inquiry of sexualities.

GEN&SEX 197.name: Senior Seminar in Gender and Sexuality Studies
GEN&SEX 197.description: Students read advanced scholarship in Gender and Sexuality Studies and complete a major seminar paper.
GEN&SEX 197.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Upper-Division Writing requirement.
GEN&SEX 197.restriction: Restriction: Gender and Sexuality Studies Majors only.

GEN&SEX 199.name: Independent Study
GEN&SEX 199.description: Directed reading and research in consultation with a faculty member. Substantial written work required.  Includes independent study, involving 3-12 hours a week.

GEN&SEX 200A.name: Feminist Knowledge and Social Change
GEN&SEX 200A.description: Provides a broad and introductory overview of Women’s Studies and feminist knowledge, including key concepts, theoretical frameworks, disciplinary approaches and methods, and critical debates that have shaped the field.

GEN&SEX 200B.name: Problems in Feminist Research
GEN&SEX 200B.description: Colloquium on analytic approaches to interdisciplinary feminist research in Women’s Studies and exploration of how feminist knowledges are produced in different academic disciplines.

GEN&SEX 201.name: Special Topics in Feminist Studies
GEN&SEX 201.description: Seminars on various topics in feminist studies.

GEN&SEX 210A.name: Topics in Graduate Feminist Theory
GEN&SEX 210A.description: In-depth introduction to various theoretical frameworks that have and continue to inform scholarship in Women's Studies including (but not limited to) identity, representation, and political economy.

GEN&SEX 290.name: Directed Research
GEN&SEX 290.description: Directed graduate study/research in Gender and Sexuality Studies.

GERMAN 1A.name: Fundamentals of German
GERMAN 1A.description: Emphasizes the development of meaningful communicative skills in German for the purposes of interaction with German speakers and beginning study of German. With a learner-centered approach, the courses help students develop speaking, listening, reading, writing, and cultural skills and knowledge.

GERMAN 1AB.name: Intensive German Fundamentals
GERMAN 1AB.description: First half of first-year German in a time-intensive form. Development of meaningful communicative skills for the purposes of interaction with German speakers and beginning study of German. Learner-centered approach develops speaking, listening, reading, writing, and cultural skills and knowledge.  Materials fee.
GERMAN 1AB.restriction: Restriction: GERMAN 1AB and GERMAN 1A and GERMAN 1B and GERMAN S1AB may not be taken for full credit.

GERMAN 1B.name: Fundamentals of German
GERMAN 1B.description: Emphasizes the development of meaningful communicative skills in German for the purposes of interaction with German speakers and beginning study of German. With a learner-centered approach,  students develop speaking, listening, reading, writing, and cultural skills and knowledge.
GERMAN 1B.prereqString: Prerequisite: GERMAN 1A. GERMAN 1A with a grade of C or better. Placement into GERMAN 1B is also accepted.

GERMAN 1BC.name: Intensive German Fundamentals
GERMAN 1BC.description: Second half of first-year German in a time-intensive form. Development of meaningful communicative skills for the purposes of interaction with German speakers and beginning study of German. Learner-centered approach develops speaking, listening, reading, writing, and cultural skills and knowledge. Materials fee.
GERMAN 1BC.prereqString: Prerequisite: GERMAN 1AB or GERMAN 1B or GERMAN S1AB. GERMAN 1AB with a grade of C or better. GERMAN 1B with a grade of C or better. GERMAN S1AB with a grade of C or better. Placement into GERMAN 1BC is also accepted.
GERMAN 1BC.restriction: Restriction: GERMAN 1BC and GERMAN 1B and GERMAN 1C and GERMAN S1AB may not be taken for full credit.

GERMAN 1C.name: Fundamentals of German
GERMAN 1C.description: Emphasizes the development of meaningful communicative skills in German for the purposes of interaction with German speakers and beginning study of German. With a learner-centered approach, students develop speaking, listening, reading, writing, and cultural skills and knowledge.
GERMAN 1C.prereqString: Prerequisite: GERMAN 1B. GERMAN 1B with a grade of C or better. Placement into GERMAN 1C is also accepted.

GERMAN S1AB.name: Fundamentals of German
GERMAN S1AB.description: First half of first-year German in a time-intensive form.  Development of meaningful communicative skills for the purposes of interaction with German speakers and beginning study of German.  Learner-centered approach develops speaking, listening, reading, writing, and cultural skills and knowledge.
GERMAN S1AB.restriction: Restriction: GERMAN S1AB and GERMAN 1A and GERMAN 1B and GERMAN 1AB may not be taken for full credit.

GERMAN S1BC.name: Fundamentals of German
GERMAN S1BC.description: Second half of first-year German in a time-intensive form.  Development of meaningful communicative skills for the purposes of interaction with German speakers and beginning study of German.  Learner-centered approach develops speaking, listening, reading, writing, and cultural skills and knowledge.
GERMAN S1BC.prereqString: Prerequisite: GERMAN 1AB or GERMAN 1B or GERMAN S1AB. GERMAN 1AB with a grade of C or better. GERMAN 1B with a grade of C or better. GERMAN S1AB with a grade of C or better. Placement into GERMAN S1BC is also accepted.
GERMAN S1BC.restriction: Restriction: GERMAN 1BC and GERMAN S1BC and GERMAN 1B and GERMAN 1C may not be taken for full credit.

GERMAN 2A.name: Intermediate German
GERMAN 2A.description: Emphasizes communicative skills for the purposes of interaction with German speakers and intermediate study of German. With a learner-centered approach, helps students develop reading, writing, speaking, listening, grammatical, and cultural skills and knowledge. First-year grammar is reviewed and expanded.
GERMAN 2A.prereqString: Prerequisite: GERMAN 1BC or GERMAN 1C or GERMAN S1BC. GERMAN 1BC with a grade of C or better. GERMAN 1C with a grade of C or better. GERMAN S1BC with a grade of C or better. Placement into GERMAN 2A is also accepted.
GERMAN 2A.restriction: Restriction: School of Humanities students have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

GERMAN 2B.name: Intermediate German
GERMAN 2B.description: Emphasizes communicative skills for the purposes of interaction with German speakers and intermediate study of German. With a learner-centered approach, helps students develop reading, writing, speaking, listening, grammatical, and cultural skills and knowledge. First-year grammar is reviewed and expanded.
GERMAN 2B.prereqString: Prerequisite: GERMAN 2A. GERMAN 2A with a grade of C or better. Placement into GERMAN 2B is also accepted.
GERMAN 2B.restriction: Restriction: School of Humanities students have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

GERMAN 2C.name: Intermediate German
GERMAN 2C.description: Emphasizes communicative skills for the purposes of interaction with German speakers and intermediate study of German. With a learner-centered approach, helps students develop reading, writing, speaking, listening, grammatical, and cultural skills and knowledge. First-year grammar is reviewed and expanded.
GERMAN 2C.prereqString: Prerequisite: GERMAN 2B. GERMAN 2B with a grade of C or better. Placement into GERMAN 2C is also accepted.
GERMAN 2C.restriction: Restriction: School of Humanities students have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

GERMAN 53.name: Advanced Conversation
GERMAN 53.description: Includes reading of political and cultural material. Conducted in German.

GERMAN 97.name: Fundamentals of German (with Emphasis on Reading)
GERMAN 97.description: Primarily for students interested in acquiring a solid reading knowledge of German. Facilitates comprehension and translation of texts in various disciplines. Does not serve as prerequisite for any higher-level German courses or fulfill any undergraduate foreign language requirement.

GERMAN 101.name: Topics in Introduction to German Literature and Culture
GERMAN 101.description: Sample interpretations of texts in their cultural and historical contexts. Introduction to critical language in German.

GERMAN 102.name: Topics in German Culture and Society
GERMAN 102.description: Interdisciplinary introduction to German culture from the perspective of its aesthetic, social, and political aspects. Methodological problems arising from an analysis of culture in its historical context.

GERMAN 103.name: Topics in German Film
GERMAN 103.description: Introduction to the history and interpretation of German film within its cultural and social contexts. Enhances German grammar knowledge and vocabulary and develops sophisticated speaking, writing, and reading skills.

GERMAN 104.name: Topics in German Linguistics
GERMAN 104.description: Introduces German or other Germanic-language linguistic, sociolinguistic, or ethnography-of-communication topics. Taught in German.

GERMAN 105.name: German for Professions
GERMAN 105.description: Explores the structure of German business practices, including in scientific fields and engineering, while developing verbal and written skills important for professional life in Germany. Taught in German.

GERMAN 115.name: Topics in Advanced German for Business and Economics
GERMAN 115.description: Explores the structure of the German economy and business practices while developing advanced verbal and written skills important for professional life in Germany. Taught in German.

GERMAN 120.name: Topics in 20th Century German Literature and Culture
GERMAN 120.description: Individual authors such as Thomas Mann, Brecht, and Kafka, or topics addressing questions of genre and/or social-literary problems.

GERMAN 140W.name: Topics in Literary Theory and Criticism
GERMAN 140W.description: In English. Theoretical dimensions of literary criticism and the German philosophical tradition. Topics have included Marxism, Freudian thought, German Idealist aesthetics, Historicism, twentieth-century hermeneutics, Frankfurt School, and Rezeptionsaesthetik.
GERMAN 140W.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

GERMAN 150.name: German Literature and Culture in Translation
GERMAN 150.description: In English. Major works in Germanic literature and culture in context.

GERMAN 160.name: German Cinema
GERMAN 160.description: Historical, theoretical, and comparative perspectives on German cinema.

GERMAN 160W.name: German Cinema
GERMAN 160W.description: Historical, theoretical, and comparative perspectives on German cinema.
GERMAN 160W.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

GERMAN 170.name: Topics in German Linguistics
GERMAN 170.description: Explores linguistic, sociolinguistic, or ethnography-of-communication topics of German or other Germanic languages (Swedish, Icelandic, Yiddish, and others). Taught in English.

GERMAN 170W.name: Topics in German Linguistics
GERMAN 170W.description: Explores linguistic, sociolinguistic, or ethnography-of-communication topics of German or other Germanic languages (Swedish, Icelandic, Yiddish, and others). Taught in English.
GERMAN 170W.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

GERMAN 197.name: German Internship
GERMAN 197.description: In this internship course, students will engage in professional practice (e.g., Engineering, Business Administration, government) in a German setting and thereby increase their knowledge of German language and culture in a setting beyond the academic classroom.

GERMAN 230.name: Literary and Cultural History
GERMAN 230.description: Topics in literary and cultural history.

GERMAN 290.name: Independent Study
GERMAN 290.description: Counted toward course requirements for the M.A. or Ph.D. A term paper or project is required.
GERMAN 290.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. School of Humanities students only.

GERMAN 298.name: Independent Directed Reading
GERMAN 298.description: For students preparing for doctoral examination.

GERMAN 299.name: Dissertation Research
GERMAN 299.description: For students who have been admitted to doctoral candidacy.
GERMAN 299.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. School of Humanities students only.

GLBLCLT 103A.name: Global Cultures I
GLBLCLT 103A.description: Introduction to the processes by which economies, cultural practices, national entities, groups, individuals, and personal identities have undergone globalization. General background and methodological tools for understanding problems and processes of globalization.

GLBLCLT 103B.name: Global Cultures II
GLBLCLT 103B.description: Introduction to the processes by which economies, cultural practices, national entities, groups, individuals, and personal identities have undergone globalization. Explores how globalization has manifested itself in specific topics, periods, or societies.

GLBLCLT 105.name: Language Origins: Evolution, Genetics, and the Brain
GLBLCLT 105.description: Examines how human language(s) may have originated. Studies pertinent techniques (reconstruction) and addresses related questions, including is our language faculty inborn (i.e., genetically encoded)? Can brain imaging and population genetics research help to unlock this mystery of human evolution?.

GLBLCLT 191.name: Senior Seminar:Topics in Global Cultures
GLBLCLT 191.description: Students explore a topic(s) concerning processes and/or problems of globalization from an interdisciplinary perspective and build on their critical and analytical skills when investigating cultural and other phenomena that cut across national borders. Research assignments, class presentations, final seminar paper.

GLBLCLT 199.name: Independent Study
GLBLCLT 199.description: Directed reading and research in consultation with a faculty advisor. Substantial written work required.

GLBL ME 60A.name: Humanities and Arts: Problems and Methods for Global Middle East Studies
GLBL ME 60A.description: Introduces students to the broad set of humanities and arts approaches to studying the Middle East as a global zone of cultural, political, and economic interaction.

GLBL ME 60B.name: Social Sciences: Problems and Methods for Global Middle East Studies
GLBL ME 60B.description: Introduces students to the broad set of social sciences approaches to studying the Middle East as a global zone of cultural, political, and economic interaction.

GLBL ME 60C.name: Social Ecology and Sciences: Problems and Methods for Global Middle East Studies
GLBL ME 60C.description: Introduces students to the broad set of approaches to studying the Middle East as a global zone of cultural, political, and economic interaction, focusing on the disciplines related to Social Ecology.

GLBL ME 100W.name: Research and Writing for Global Middle East Studies
GLBL ME 100W.description: Research and writing course for Global Middle East Studies majors. The primary focus is to refine the skills necessary for students to engage in independent research and writing in Global Middle East Studies.
GLBL ME 100W.restriction: Restriction: Global Middle East Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

GREEK 1A.name: Classical and Biblical Greek
GREEK 1A.description: Elements of Classical Greek grammar, syntax, and vocabulary.

GREEK 1B.name: Classical and Biblical Greek
GREEK 1B.description: Elements of Classical Greek grammar, syntax, and vocabulary.
GREEK 1B.prereqString: Prerequisite: GREEK 1A. GREEK 1A with a grade of C or better
GREEK 1B.restriction: Restriction: GREEK 1B and GREEK S1AB and GREEK S1BC may not be taken for full credit.

GREEK 1C.name: Classical and Biblical Greek
GREEK 1C.prereqString: Prerequisite: GREEK 1B. GREEK 1B with a grade of C or better

GREEK 99.name: Special Studies in Greek
GREEK 99.description: Lower-division level independent research with Greek faculty.

GREEK 100.name: Topics in  Attic Greek
GREEK 100.description: Selected readings in Attic Greek prose and poetry. Authors may include Xenophon, Lysias, Antiphon, Euripides, and others. Selections from prose and poetry will be read each quarter. Grammar and syntax review included.
GREEK 100.prereqString: Prerequisite: GREEK 1C. GREEK 1C with a grade of C or better. Placement into GREEK 100 is also accepted.

GREEK 103.name: Seminar in Greek Prose
GREEK 103.description: Specialized and focused study of a particular Greek prose author or topic.

GREEK 104.name: Seminar in Greek Poetry
GREEK 104.description: Specialized and focused study of a particular topic or author of Greek poetry.

GREEK 198.name: Directed Group Study
GREEK 198.description: Special topics in Greek culture and civilization through directed reading and research.

HEBREW 1A.name: Fundamentals of Hebrew
HEBREW 1A.description: Designed for students with little or no exposure to Hebrew. May focus on Biblical Hebrew and/or modern Hebrew. Students learn the writing system and basics of grammar via latest pedagogical materials. Topics in Jewish culture are also included.
HEBREW 1A.prereqString: Prerequisite: Placement into HEBREW 1A is also accepted.

HEBREW 10A.name: Hebrew Peer-to-Peer Language Mentor Program
HEBREW 10A.description: Peer-to-Peer Language Mentor Program in which student mentors work with student mentees to increase the language skills of both participants. One hour weekly meetings. HEBREW 10A is for language mentors.

HEBREW 10B.name: Hebrew Peer-to-Peer Language Mentor Program
HEBREW 10B.description: Peer-to-Peer Language Mentor Program in which student mentors work with student mentees to increase the language skills of both participants. One hour weekly meetings. HEBREW 10B is for language mentors.

HEBREW 50.name: Jewish and Israeli Culture
HEBREW 50.description: Examination of subjects relevant to the culture of Israel and Judaism in their historical and modern day contexts through the study of film, literature, religious texts, artistic representations, etc.

HISTORY 5.name: Truth, Lies, and History: The Uses of the Past
HISTORY 5.description: Focuses on how struggles over the meaning of historical events have shaped and continue to shape our understandings of the world. Through guest lectures from history faculty, students explore debates about the meaning of the past.

HISTORY 10.name: The Holocaust
HISTORY 10.description: Introduction to the history of European Jewish communities before the Holocaust

HISTORY 11.name: Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity Since WWII
HISTORY 11.description: Investigates instances of genocide since 1945 (including Cambodia, Bosnia, Rwanda, and others)

HISTORY 12.name: Introductory Topics in History
HISTORY 12.description: Introduces methods and premises of historical study. Topics include introductions to cultural, political, economic, social, and religious history.

HISTORY 15A.name: Native American History
HISTORY 15A.description: An overview of major developments in Indian-white relations from the American Revolution to the present with an emphasis on political and legal history. How tribal sovereignty has been redefined over time is a central theme of the course.

HISTORY 15C.name: Asian American Histories
HISTORY 15C.description: Examines and compares diverse experiences of major Asian American groups since the mid-nineteenth century. Topics include origins of emigration

HISTORY 15D.name: History of Sexuality in the US
HISTORY 15D.description: Explores intertwined histories of sexuality, race, and gender in the US. By examining how different cultures and times viewed sexuality, race and gender, it analyzes relationships between regulation of bodies/behaviors and construction of cultural, economic, and political norms.

HISTORY 15F.name: What to Eat? Immigrants and the Development of American Cuisines
HISTORY 15F.description: Relationship between immigration and changing American foodways

HISTORY 15G.name: Racial Segregation in Modern U.S.
HISTORY 15G.description: Explores the history of racial segregation in the United States from the late 19th century to the present.

HISTORY 16A.name: World Religions I
HISTORY 16A.description: An introduction to the history, doctrine, culture, and writing of Judaism, Christianity, and Islam.

HISTORY 16B.name: World Religions II
HISTORY 16B.description: An introduction to various religious traditions in selected areas of the world—including India and South Asia, East Asia, Africa, and the Americas.

HISTORY 16C.name: Religious Dialogue
HISTORY 16C.description: Lectures and discussion on controversial topics in religion: sexual morality

HISTORY 18A.name: Major Jewish Texts
HISTORY 18A.description: Introduction to the diversity of Jewish cultures from ancient to modern times. Surveys the Jewish experience in various societies and civilizations: ancient Mediterranean, Middle East and North Africa, Europe, and the Americas.

HISTORY 21A.name: World:  Innovations
HISTORY 21A.description: Treats major themes of world historical development through the mid-seventeenth century, focusing on the Eurasian world, but with secondary emphasis on Africa and the Americas.

HISTORY 21B.name: World: Empires and Revolutions
HISTORY 21B.description: Examines three major transformations that made the world of 1870 dramatically different from that of 1650: e.g., the scientific revolution, industrialization, and the formation of modern states and nations.

HISTORY 21C.name: World: Nation, War, and Rights
