HISTORY 21C.description: Considers several major currents of modern history: technological change and its social effects

HISTORY 36A.name: The Formation of Ancient Greek Society: Early Greece
HISTORY 36A.description: A survey of ancient Greek civilization from its origins in the Bronze Age to the mid-Archaic period. Examines political and social history, as well as literature, art, religion, and archaeological remains.

HISTORY 36B.name: The Formation of Ancient Greek Society:  Late Archaic and Classical Greece
HISTORY 36B.description: A survey of ancient Greek civilization from the Late Archaic period to the Classical period. Focuses on major institutions and cultural phenomena as seen through the study of ancient Greek literature, history, archaeology, and religion.

HISTORY 36C.name: The Formation of Ancient Greek Society: Fourth-Century and Hellenistic Greece
HISTORY 36C.description: A survey of ancient Greek civilization from the fourth century BCE through to the Hellenistic period. Focuses on major institutions and cultural phenomena as seen through the study of ancient Greek literature, history, archaeology, and religion.

HISTORY 37A.name: The Formation of Ancient Roman Society: Origins to Roman Republic
HISTORY 37A.description: A survey of the development of Roman civilization from its eighth century BCE beginnings to the civil wars of the first century BCE. Examines political and social history, as well as literature, art, architecture, and religion.

HISTORY 37B.name: The Formation of Ancient Roman Society: Roman Empire
HISTORY 37B.description: A survey of Roman civilization from Augustus’s consolidation of power following the civil wars of the first century BCE to the crisis of the third century CE. Includes social history, literature, art, architecture, and religion.

HISTORY 37C.name: The Formation of Ancient Roman Society: The Fall of Rome
HISTORY 37C.description: A survey of Roman civilization from the crisis of the third century CE to the so-called “fall of Rome” in 476 CE.  Examines political and social history, as well as literature, art, architecture, and religion.

HISTORY 40A.name: Colonial America:  New Worlds
HISTORY 40A.description: Important themes in the social, economic, political, and cultural development in North America that transformed part of the geographical space into the U.S. Topics include Native Americans, European colonization, African enslavement, borderlands, gender, economic stratification, the American Revolution, the Constitution.
HISTORY 40A.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfaction of the UC Entry Level Writing requirement.

HISTORY 40B.name: Nineteenth-Century U.S.: Crisis and Expansion
HISTORY 40B.description: Explores the transformation of American society, economy, and politics during the nineteenth century. Topics include industrial revolution, slavery, antislavery, women's rights, reform movements, Civil War and Reconstruction, immigration and ethnicity, and cultural and social transformation.
HISTORY 40B.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfaction of the UC Entry Level Writing requirement.

HISTORY 40C.name: Modern America:  Culture and Power
HISTORY 40C.description: Important themes in U.S. history in the twentieth and early twenty-first centuries. Topics include corporate capitalism, empire, immigration, race, gender, consumer society, World Wars, Progressiveness, New Deal, Great Society, civil rights, women's movements, Vietnam War, conservative politics, and economic stratification.
HISTORY 40C.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfaction of the UC Entry Level Writing requirement.

HISTORY 50.name: Crises and Revolutions
HISTORY 50.description: Study of turning points in world history, illustrating themes and methods of historical analysis.

HISTORY 60.name: The Making of Modern Science
HISTORY 60.description: Surveys the history of science and mathematics since the Scientific Revolution, examining central developments both chronologically and thematically, as well as investigating their significance for contemporary philosophical debates about the role and status of current scientific theories.

HISTORY 70A.name: Problems in History: Asia
HISTORY 70A.description: An introduction to the historical problems, the issues of interpretation, the primary sources, and the historical scholarship of the history of Asia, with an emphasis on developing skills in historical essay-writing.

HISTORY 70B.name: Problems in History: Europe
HISTORY 70B.description: An introduction to the historical problems, the issues of interpretation, the primary sources, and the historical scholarship of the history of Europe, with an emphasis on developing skills in historical essay-writing.

HISTORY 70C.name: Problems in History: United States
HISTORY 70C.description: An introduction to the historical problems, the issues of interpretation, the primary sources, and the historical scholarship of the history of the United States, with an emphasis on developing skills in historical essay-writing.

HISTORY 70D.name: Problems in History: Latin America
HISTORY 70D.description: An introduction to the historical problems, the issues of interpretation, the primary sources, and the historical scholarship of the history of Latin America, with an emphasis on developing skills in historical essay-writing.

HISTORY 70E.name: Problems in History: Middle East and Africa
HISTORY 70E.description: An introduction to the historical problems, the issues of interpretation, the primary sources, and the historical scholarship of the history of the Middle East and Africa, with an emphasis on developing skills in historical essay-writing.

HISTORY 70F.name: Problems in History: Transregional History
HISTORY 70F.description: An introduction to the historical problems, the issues of interpretation, the primary sources, and the historical scholarship of transregional history, with an emphasis on developing skills in historical essay-writing.

HISTORY 100W.name: Writing About History
HISTORY 100W.description: Specialized courses focusing on history writing and research skills. Each class reflects the instructor's intellectual interests and is conducted as a discussion group. Limited to 18 students. Several short writing assignments and one longer project meeting the upper-division writing requirement.
HISTORY 100W.prereqString: Prerequisite: HISTORY 12 or HISTORY 15A or HISTORY 15C or HISTORY 15D or HISTORY 16A or HISTORY 16B or HISTORY 16C or HISTORY 18A or HISTORY 21A or HISTORY 21B or HISTORY 21C or HISTORY 40A or HISTORY 40B or HISTORY 40C or HISTORY 60 or HISTORY 70A or HISTORY 70B or HISTORY 70C or HISTORY 70D or HISTORY 70E or HISTORY 70F. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
HISTORY 100W.restriction: Restriction: History Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

HISTORY 102B.name: Topics in Environmental History
HISTORY 102B.description: Explores the many historical interfaces between climate change, modes of production, and culture. Topics include the environmental history of warfare, imperialism, and famine in the nineteenth century and the history of environmental thought.

HISTORY 110D.name: Topics in Medieval Europe
HISTORY 110D.description: Theme-based approach to the main social, political, religious, and cultural developments in Europe between the 4th and 15th centuries. Topics include the Crusades, medieval towns, medieval visionaries, and the deadly sins.

HISTORY 112D.name: Topics in Early Modern Europe
HISTORY 112D.description: Theme-based approach to the main social, political, and cultural developments in Europe between the fifteenth and eighteenth centuries.  Topics included Renaissance humanism, Reformation and Counter-Reformation, scientific revolution, court culture and nation building, interactions with non-European peoples, cities and commerce.

HISTORY 114.name: Topics in Modern European History
HISTORY 114.description: Course content changes with instructor. Topics include the Inquisition

HISTORY 120D.name: War and Empire: France and the World in the 20th Century
HISTORY 120D.description: Examines French experience of World War I, the defeat and occupation by Germany in World War II, the violent struggles that came with the loss of the French empire in the 1950s and 1960s, immigration, French responses to globalization.

HISTORY 122B.name: Hitler and the Germans
HISTORY 122B.description: Focuses on Hitler's rise to power and Nazi society. Examines Germany's defeat in World War I

HISTORY 123D.name: Topics in Spanish History
HISTORY 123D.description: Topics include Spain in the nineteenth century, the Spanish Civil War, and dictatorship and democracy in modern Spain.

HISTORY 124B.name: Twentieth-Century Russia
HISTORY 124B.description: Political and social developments in Twentieth-Century Russia.

HISTORY 126B.name: The Era of World War II: 1933-45
HISTORY 126B.description: The era of World War II and its political, social and economic history.

HISTORY 128C.name: Topics in the History of Women in Europe
HISTORY 128C.description: Studies in selected areas of history of European women. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

HISTORY 130C.name: Topics in the Jewish History
HISTORY 130C.description: Studies in selected areas of Jewish history. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

HISTORY 130F.name: Jews and Power
HISTORY 130F.description: Examines the relationship between the Jewish people and political power over a 3500 year period. How have Jews preserved their communal interests and personal safety? How have they defined the proper relationship of the people to political authority.

HISTORY 131A.name: History of Zoroastrianism
HISTORY 131A.description: Reviews major trends in the history of Zoroastrianism.

HISTORY 131B.name: Ancient Persia
HISTORY 131B.description: Survey of the history of Persia in antiquity.

HISTORY 131C.name: Medieval Persia
HISTORY 131C.description: A survey of Persian history in the context of Late Antique and Medieval Islamic history.

HISTORY 131D.name: Modern Iran
HISTORY 131D.description: The history of Iran from the end of the Safavid Empire in the eighteenth century to the present.

HISTORY 132B.name: The Emergence of the Modern Middle East
HISTORY 132B.description: Offers a survey of the history of the Middle East from the 19th century to the present time. Formerly History 133A.

HISTORY 132C.name: Women and Gender in the Middle East
HISTORY 132C.description: Focuses on women and gender in the Middle East from the pre-modern to the contemporary.

HISTORY 132D.name: Armenians and Armenia in Ancient to Early Modern World History
HISTORY 132D.description: A history of Armenia and Armenians from ethnogenesis to the early modern period at the end of the 1700s within a regional and global context. Takes into account interactions and encounters with the empires, and peoples that encompassed their orbit.

HISTORY 132E.name: Armenians and Armenia in Modern World History
HISTORY 132E.description: Covers the most important themes in the history of Armenians and Armenia in the 19th, 20th, and 21st centuries within a regional (i.e., Middle East and Caucasus) and global context.

HISTORY 132H.name: Topics in Middle Eastern History
HISTORY 132H.description: Topics include the cultural, political, intellectual, social, and/or economic histories of one or many regions of the Middle East.

HISTORY 134A.name: Africa: Societies and Cultures
HISTORY 134A.description: Introduction to the variety of cultures, political organizations, social structures, and artistic expressions created by Africans over a broad time span. Indigenous development of African societies in distinct regions of the continent. Issues, themes, processes for understanding history of Africa.

HISTORY 134C.name: Topics in the History of Africa
HISTORY 134C.description: Studies in selected areas of African history. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

HISTORY 134D.name: Topics in South African History
HISTORY 134D.description: Introduction to important historical events and processes in Southern Africa. Focuses on particular themes and explores how those themes change over time. Topics include: changing ideas about race, the development of class structures, identity formation, the role of gender.

HISTORY 134E.name: History of the African Diaspora
HISTORY 134E.description: Examines the causes and consequences of the multiple diasporas of African peoples since the sixteenth century in the Atlantic world, especially the Americas and Europe.

HISTORY 135B.name: Crossing the World's Oceans: From Sail to Steam
HISTORY 135B.description: Explores the basics of oceanography, the evolution of ships and sailing in the ancient Mediterranean world, the North Atlantic, Polynesia, the South China Sea, the Arab Indian Ocean, the global oceanic world, and the discovery of celestial and terrestrial navigation.

HISTORY 135E.name: Topics in the History of Science and Technology
HISTORY 135E.description: Studies in selected areas of science and technological history. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

HISTORY 135G.name: Language Origins: Evolution, Genetics, and the Brain
HISTORY 135G.description: Examines how human language(s) may have originated. Studies pertinent techniques (reconstruction) and addresses related questions, including is our language faculty inborn (i.e., genetically encoded)? Can brain imaging and population genetics research help to unlock this mystery of human evolution?.

HISTORY 136D.name: Topics in the History of Medicine and Health Care
HISTORY 136D.description: Studies in selected areas of Medicine and Health Care history. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

HISTORY 137.name: Surviving Epidemics
HISTORY 137.description: Analyzes diverse social and cultural responses to epidemics from mid-nineteenth century to the present, including incarceration, caregiving, and disability rights. Using interdisciplinary materials and collaborative activities, students interpret strategies and outcomes of Indigenous, racialized, and marginalized communities surviving great illness.
HISTORY 137.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
HISTORY 137.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. Sophomores only.

HISTORY 140B.name: Revolutionary America:  1740-1790
HISTORY 140B.description: An exploration of why 13 continental colonies, whose commercial and cultural connections with Britain far exceed their interaction with one another, resisted imperial reform after 1763 to the point of war in 1775 and independence the following year.

HISTORY 142A.name: California Dreaming: Conquest, Conflict, and Globalization in the Golden State
HISTORY 142A.description: California as a case study of national trends and as a unique setting: its specific problems and culture. Major themes include: colonization, immigration, race relations, agricultural development, industrialization, urbanization, working class movements, social conflict, and political reform.

HISTORY 142B.name: Topics in American Social and Economic History
HISTORY 142B.description: Studies in selected areas of American social and economic history. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

HISTORY 144G.name: Topics in American Cultural and Intellectual History
HISTORY 144G.description: Studies in selected areas of American cultural and intellectual history. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

HISTORY 146H.name: Topics in Women and Gender Relations in the United States
HISTORY 146H.description: Studies in selected areas of women and gender relations in the United States. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

HISTORY 147.name: Education and the American Dream: Historical Perspectives on Democracy and Education
HISTORY 147.description: Examines the relationship between public schooling and the promotion of democratic ideals in American society over the past two centuries.

HISTORY 148B.name: Topics in Multicultural U.S. History
HISTORY 148B.description: Examines the variety of cultural expressions through which the people who came to inhabit the United States historically signify their collective identities.

HISTORY 149.name: Veterans in History and Society
HISTORY 149.description: Explores key concepts, issues, and trends in the interdisciplinary field of veterans studies. Students gain a deep understanding of the ways that social scientists and historians have analyzed the identities, experiences, and worldviews of U.S. military veterans.

HISTORY 150.name: Topics in African American History
HISTORY 150.description: Studies in selected areas of African American history.  Topics addressed vary each quarter.

HISTORY 151B.name: Chicana/Chicano History: Twentieth Century
HISTORY 151B.description: Examines social history of the Southwest with emphasis on Mexican-origin people. Discusses major questions, theory and research methods pertinent to Chicana/Chicano history. Themes explored include: immigration, xenophobia, class struggle, leadership, generational cohorts, unionization, education, barrioization, ethnicity, patriarchy, sexuality.

HISTORY 151C.name: Latinas in the Twentieth Century U.S.
HISTORY 151C.description: Latinas in the U.S. from 1900 to present, offering a diversity of their cultures, regional histories, sexualities, generations, and classes.

HISTORY 151D.name: Latina/Latino Pop:  Latina/Latino Popular Culture
HISTORY 151D.description: With a focus on the politics of language and space/place, prepares students to critically analyze sites of Latina/Latino popular culture including: music, film, performance, sports, media, and varied subcultures.
HISTORY 151D.restriction: Restriction: Chicano/Latino Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment. History Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

HISTORY 152.name: Topics in Asian-American History
HISTORY 152.description: Introduction to important themes in the history of people of Asian ancestry in the United States from the nineteenth century to the present.

HISTORY 152A.name: Asian American Labor
HISTORY 152A.description: Explores history of Asian Americans and work from the nineteenth century to the present. Areas of study include migration, colonialism, family, social organization, and work culture.

HISTORY 154.name: American Urban History
HISTORY 154.description: A study of urban communities in the United States, from colonial times to the present. Traces the impact of industrialization and urbanization on social and cultural life, and investigates the significance of urban life for U.S. democratic culture.

HISTORY 160.name: Sex and Conquest in Latin America
HISTORY 160.description: Competing ideas of masculinity and femininity, sexual violence, sexual identities, and gendered hierarchies informed how the Spanish engaged in military and religious domination of Mexican and Andean communities, as well as the forms of native resistance throughout colonial Latin America.

HISTORY 162.name: Topics in Brazilian History
HISTORY 162.description: Studies in selected areas of Brazilian history. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

HISTORY 163.name: World of Coffee
HISTORY 163.description: History of consumption and production of coffee over the centuries, and coffee's cultural, economic, social, political consequences. Coffee's social life as a drug, symbol of hospitality, religious rite, sociability and bourgeois lifestyle, commodity, source of livelihoods, imperial revenues, corporate profits.

HISTORY 164A.name: Caribbean History: Colonization to Emancipation
HISTORY 164A.description: Exploration of the history of the archipelago from pre-Columbian times to the end of slavery

HISTORY 164B.name: Caribbean History: Emancipation to Independence
HISTORY 164B.description: Post-emancipation and anti-colonial struggles ending with political independence for most of the region. Examines social, political, economic, cultural dimensions of post-emancipation period, including large-scale migration to Central America, the U.S., and Britain

HISTORY 165.name: Race and Empire in Colonial Latin America
HISTORY 165.description: Explores how native people of Latin America with enslaved and free African incorporated and defied Spanish and Portuguese colonization. Focuses on religious adaptions, resistance movements, legal systems, and the emergence of multicultural communities to explain how race shaped European empires.

HISTORY 165A.name: War and Revolution in Colonial Latin America
HISTORY 165A.description: Comparison of how Andeans resurrected the leaders of the Inca, a defeated indigenous empire, to contest the Spanish empire with how enslaved Africans, with their descendants and others, defeated Spanish colonial rule in what would become the Cuban nation.

HISTORY 166.name: U.S. Intervention in Latin America
HISTORY 166.description: Explores political, economic, social, and cultural ties that bind Latin America to the United States. Focuses on U.S. intervention and Latin American response from early nineteenth century to present day. Case studies include Mexico, Guatemala, Cuba, Chile, and Central America.

HISTORY 166B.name: Revolution and Reaction in Cold War Latin America
HISTORY 166B.description: Explores Latin American experiences of revolutionary change and military dictatorship during the Cold War (1945-1990). Pays particular attention to the lives of women, peasants, workers, and the urban middle classes. Case studies include Guatemala, Cuba, Chile, Argentina, Nicaragua, and Mexico.

HISTORY 166C.name: Cuban Society and Revolution
HISTORY 166C.description: Explores the causes, development, and legacy of the 1959 Revolution. Themes include economic dependency, democracy, race, gender, culture, and the always volatile relations between Cuba and the United States.

HISTORY 166D.name: Revolution in Latin America
HISTORY 166D.description: Presents a comparative analysis of the causes, development, and consequences of selected revolutionary movements, focusing on outbreaks in Mexico, Bolivia, Cuba, Chile, Nicaragua, and Grenada.  Explores topics of state formation, economic nationalism, social justice, ethnicity, and role of international affairs.

HISTORY 169.name: Topics in Latin American History
HISTORY 169.description: Studies in selected areas of Latin American history.  Topics addressed vary each quarter.

HISTORY 170A.name: Ancient India
HISTORY 170A.description: Examines the visual and religious history of the region defined as "India" today, but necessarily encompassing modern Bangladesh and Pakistan.  Culminates with the supposed Golden Age of the Gupta empire and its far-reaching legacies.

HISTORY 170B.name: Medieval India
HISTORY 170B.description: Begins with the Gupta period's aesthetic legacies in South Asia's architecture, sculpture, and painting. Explores the dispersal of Islam throughout South Asia, including the Muslim communities of southern India.

HISTORY 171D.name: Chinese History to 1800
HISTORY 171D.description: A survey of the history of China to 1800.

HISTORY 171E.name: Chinese History: 1800-1949
HISTORY 171E.description: An examination of Chinese society and thought from the late-eighteenth century to the 1949 revolution. Focuses on the role of intellectuals

HISTORY 171G.name: Topics in the History of China
HISTORY 171G.description: Topics include the cultural, political, economic, social, intellectual, and religious history of China.

HISTORY 172G.name: Topics in the History of Japan
HISTORY 172G.description: Topics include the cultural, political, economic, social, intellectual and religious history of Japan.

HISTORY 173G.name: Topics in the History of Korea
HISTORY 173G.description: Topics include the cultural, political, economic, social, intellectual, and religious history of Korea.

HISTORY 174G.name: Topics in the History of South Asia
HISTORY 174G.description: Topics include the cultural, political, economic, social, intellectual, and religious history of South Asia.

HISTORY 175G.name: Topics in the History of Southeast Asia
HISTORY 175G.description: Topics include the cultural, political, economic, social, intellectual, and religious history of Southeast Asia.

HISTORY 180.name: Special Studies in Social History
HISTORY 180.description: Studies in selected areas of social history. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

HISTORY 182.name: Special Studies in Intellectual-Cultural History
HISTORY 182.description: Studies in selected areas of intellectual-cultural history. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

HISTORY 183.name: Special Studies in International History
HISTORY 183.description: Studies in selected areas of international history. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

HISTORY 184.name: Special Studies in Comparative History
HISTORY 184.description: Studies in selected areas of comparative history. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

HISTORY 185.name: Special Studies in Social Theory
HISTORY 185.description: Studies in selected areas of social theory. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

HISTORY 190.name: Colloquium
HISTORY 190.description: Specialized courses dealing primarily with close reading and analysis of primary and secondary works
HISTORY 190.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. History Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

HISTORY 193.name: Advanced Research Seminar I
HISTORY 193.description: The first course in a two-quarter advanced research sequence, this course allows upper-division history majors to undertake significant research and writing under close faculty supervision.
HISTORY 193.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
HISTORY 193.restriction: Restriction: History majors only. Upper-division students only.

HISTORY 194.name: Advanced Research Seminar II
HISTORY 194.description: Second course in a two-quarter advanced research sequence. Allows upper division history majors to undertake significant research and writing under close faculty supervision.
HISTORY 194.prereqString: Prerequisite: HISTORY 193. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
HISTORY 194.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. History Majors only.

HISTORY 197.name: Internships in Public History
HISTORY 197.description: Students will sharpen their abilities to research, critically interpret, and present history by “doing history” beyond the formal classroom. Internships, which introduce students to the field of “public history,” include working as archivists, oral historians, project advisers, and exhibit curators.
HISTORY 197.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. History Majors only.

HISTORY 198.name: Directed Group Study
HISTORY 198.description: Special topics through directed reading. Paper required.

HISTORY 199.name: Independent Reading
HISTORY 199.description: Investigation of special topics through directed reading. Paper required.

HISTORY 200.name: History and Theory
HISTORY 200.description: Explores a variety of theoretical issues and methodological concerns that have sparked lively debate in the humanities and social sciences in past decades and which remain of urgent concern to 21st-century historical writing.

HISTORY 202A.name: First-Year Research Seminar
HISTORY 202A.description: Introduction to historical methodologies and preparation for the first-year research paper. Required of all first-year doctoral students and M.A. students.
HISTORY 202A.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. History Majors only.

HISTORY 202B.name: First-Year Research Seminar
HISTORY 202B.description: Research and writing of a paper demonstrating command of historical methods explored in HISTORY 202A. Required of all first-year Ph.D. students and M.A. students.

HISTORY 204A.name: Second-Year Research Seminar
HISTORY 204A.description: Part one of a two-quarter sequence required of all Ph.D. students during the second year of the program
HISTORY 204A.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. History Majors only.

HISTORY 204B.name: Second-Year Research Seminar
HISTORY 204B.description: Part two of a two-quarter sequence required of all Ph.D. students. Taken during the second year of the Ph.D. program
HISTORY 204B.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. History Majors only.

HISTORY 230.name: Topics in European History
HISTORY 230.description: Studies in selected themes and time periods in European history. Topics and period vary.

HISTORY 240.name: Topics in World History
HISTORY 240.description: Studies in selected themes and time periods in world history. Topics and period vary.

HISTORY 250.name: Topics in Latin American History
HISTORY 250.description: Studies in selected themes and time periods in Latin American history. Topics and period vary.

HISTORY 260.name: Topics in American History
HISTORY 260.description: Studies in selected themes and time periods in U.S. history. Topics and period vary.

HISTORY 270.name: Topics in Middle Eastern History
HISTORY 270.description: Studies in selected themes and time periods in Middle Eastern history. Topics and period vary.

HISTORY 280.name: Topics in Asian History
HISTORY 280.description: Studies in selected themes and time periods in Asian history. Topics and period vary.

HISTORY 290.name: Special Topics
HISTORY 290.description: Lectures, readings, and discussion on subjects more limited in scope than those included in the year-long colloquium series.

HISTORY 291.name: Directed Reading
HISTORY 291.description: Reading courses focused on specialized topics.
HISTORY 291.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. History Majors only.

HISTORY 297.name: History Internship
HISTORY 297.description: Limited to History graduate students with Department-approved internships.  Materials fee.
HISTORY 297.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. History Majors only.

HISTORY 298.name: Experimental Group Study
HISTORY 298.description: Open to four or more students.

HISTORY 299.name: Dissertation Research
HISTORY 299.description: Specifically designed for students researching and writing their dissertations.

HUMAN 1A.name: Humanities Core Lecture
HUMAN 1A.description: Through a range of cultural traditions and an interdisciplinary approach to works of literature, history, philosophy, and contemporary media, students are introduced to the humanities.

HUMAN 1AES.name: Humanities Core Writing: Entry Level Writing
HUMAN 1AES.description: A small writing course for Entry Level Writing students exploring the ideas presented in the companion lecture course and illustrated in the literary, historical, philosophical, and media works assigned.

HUMAN 1AS.name: Humanities Core Writing
HUMAN 1AS.description: A small writing course in which students explore the ideas presented in the companion lecture course and illustrated in the literary, historical, philosophical, and media works assigned.
HUMAN 1AS.prereqString:
Corequisite: HUMAN 1A
Prerequisite: Satisfaction of the UC Entry Level Writing requirement.

HUMAN 1B.name: Humanities Core Lecture
HUMAN 1B.description: Through a range of cultural traditions and an interdisciplinary approach to works of literature, history, philosophy, and contemporary media, students are introduced to the humanities.

HUMAN 1BES.name: Humanities Core Writing: Entry Level Writing
HUMAN 1BES.description: A small writing course for Entry Level Writing students exploring the ideas presented in the companion lecture course and illustrated in the literary, historical, philosophical, and media works assigned.
HUMAN 1BES.prereqString:
Corequisite: HUMAN 1B
Prerequisite: HUMAN 1AES. HUMAN 1AES with a grade of C- or better

HUMAN 1BS.name: Humanities Core Writing
HUMAN 1BS.description: A small writing course in which students explore the ideas presented in the companion lecture course and illustrated in the literary, historical, philosophical, and media works assigned.
HUMAN 1BS.prereqString:
Corequisite: HUMAN 1B
Prerequisite: Satisfaction of the UC Entry Level Writing requirement.

HUMAN 1C.name: Humanities Core Lecture
HUMAN 1C.description: Through a range of cultural traditions and an interdisciplinary approach to works of literature, history, philosophy, and contemporary media, students are introduced to the humanities.

HUMAN 1CS.name: Humanities Core Writing
HUMAN 1CS.description: A small writing course in which students explore the ideas presented in the companion lecture course and illustrated in the literary, historical, philosophical, and media works assigned.
HUMAN 1CS.prereqString:
Corequisite: HUMAN 1C
Prerequisite: HUMAN 1AS or HUMAN H1AS or HUMAN 1BS or HUMAN H1BS or HUMAN 1BES. HUMAN 1AS with a grade of C or better. HUMAN H1AS with a grade of C or better. HUMAN 1BS with a grade of C or better. HUMAN H1BS with a grade of C or better. HUMAN 1BES with a grade of C or better

HUMAN B1A.name: Humanities Core Biological Sciences Lecture
HUMAN B1A.description: Through a range of cultural traditions and an interdisciplinary approach to works of literature, history, philosophy, and contemporary media, students are introduced to the humanities.
HUMAN B1A.restriction: Restriction: Lower-division students only. Biological Sciences Majors only.

HUMAN H1AS.name: Humanities Core Writing: Honors
HUMAN H1AS.description: For Campuswide Honors students exploring the ideas presented in the companion lecture course and illustrated in the literary, historical, philosophical, and media works assigned.
HUMAN H1AS.prereqString:
Corequisite: HUMAN 1A
Prerequisite: Satisfaction of the UC Entry Level Writing requirement.
HUMAN H1AS.restriction: Restriction: Campuswide Honors Collegium students only. Lower-division students only.

HUMAN H1BS.name: Humanities Core Writing: Honors
HUMAN H1BS.description: For Campuswide Honors students exploring the ideas presented in the companion lecture course and illustrated in the literary, historical, philosophical, and media works assigned.
HUMAN H1BS.prereqString:
Corequisite: HUMAN 1B
Prerequisite: Satisfaction of the UC Entry Level Writing requirement.
HUMAN H1BS.restriction: Restriction: Campuswide Honors Collegium students only. Lower-division students only.

HUMAN H1CS.name: Humanities Core Writing: Honors
HUMAN H1CS.description: For Campuswide Honors students exploring the ideas presented in the companion lecture course and illustrated in the literary, historical, philosophical, and media works assigned.
HUMAN H1CS.prereqString:
Corequisite: HUMAN 1C
Prerequisite: HUMAN 1AS or HUMAN H1AS or HUMAN 1AES or HUMAN 1BS or HUMAN H1BS or HUMAN 1BES with a grade of C or better.
HUMAN H1CS.restriction: Restriction: Lower-division students only. Campuswide Honors Program students only.

HUMAN 10.name: Masterpieces of Literature
HUMAN 10.description: Students closely read major works of world literature that are significant (1) in their own right, (2) for a specific literary tradition, and (3) because of their reception in other cultural contexts. Literature written in English and English translation.

HUMAN 52.name: Foundations of Bilingual Education and Bilingualism
HUMAN 52.description: Provides a comprehensive overview of current issues in bilingual education and bilingualism. Topics include dimensions of bilingualism, the effects of bilingualism on children's linguistic and cognitive development, bilingual education programs, literacy, special needs, and assessment.

HUMAN H80.name: Exploring Memory
HUMAN H80.description: Questions about human memory are central to a wide range of disciplines. Students will explore how historians, sociologists, social psychologists, legal experts, and neuroscientists understand human memory and apply their findings to understand and shape their own societies.
HUMAN H80.restriction: Restriction: Campuswide Honors Collegium students only.

HUMAN H81.name: The Vietnam War
HUMAN H81.description: Examines the origins, evolution, opposition against, conclusion, and legacy of the United States in the Vietnam War.
HUMAN H81.restriction: Restriction: Campuswide Honors Collegium students only.

HUMAN H83.name: How Nations Remember
HUMAN H83.description: Just like people, nations select and organize what and how they want to remember. Compares how specific historical events (such as slavery and the Holocaust) are memorialized in various countries and represented in public art works, museums, literature, and film.
HUMAN H83.restriction: Restriction: Campuswide Honors Collegium students only.

HUMAN H84.name: Traveling East/West
HUMAN H84.description: Traveling East/West presents a wide range of travel writings by Chinese, Indian, and Euro-American authors in which they contemplate the complexities of cross-cultural encounters and how knowledge about others and knowledge of ourselves are closely intertwined.
HUMAN H84.restriction: Restriction: Campuswide Honors Collegium students only.

HUMAN H120.name: Honors Proseminar
HUMAN H120.description: Interdisciplinary Honors courses organized each year around a single topic problem designed to compare and contrast modes of analysis in history, literary studies, and philosophy.

HUMAN H140.name: Senior Honors Seminar
HUMAN H140.description: Directed by Humanities Honors Thesis Advisor and required of students in Humanities Honors program and Humanities majors in Campuswide Honors Program.  Designed to facilitate exchange of ideas and research strategies among students and begin process of writing senior honors thesis.
HUMAN H140.restriction: Restriction: Humanities Honors students only. Seniors only.

HUMAN H141.name: Senior Honors Thesis
HUMAN H141.description: Directed independent research required of participants in the Humanities Honors Program and Humanities majors in the Campuswide Honors Program.
HUMAN H141.restriction: Restriction: Campuswide Honors Collegium students only. Humanities Honors students only.

HUMAN H142W.name: Senior Honors Colloquium
HUMAN H142W.description: Completion, presentation, and discussion of Senior Honors Theses.
HUMAN H142W.restriction: Restriction: Campuswide Honors Collegium students only. Humanities Honors students only.

HUMAN H145.name: Arts of Contemporary Communication
HUMAN H145.description: A workshop seminar exploring the theory and practice of visual design, data visualization, and oral presentation. Designed to get students to think about, and hone their skills in, effective presentation of information in multiple media.
HUMAN H145.restriction: Restriction: Campuswide Honors Collegium students only. Humanities Honors Program students can enroll as space allows.

HUMAN 175.name: Topics in Humanities and Science
HUMAN 175.description: Interdisciplinary topics exploring the relationship between the humanities and the physical and biological sciences.

HUMAN 195.name: Humanities Out There (H.O.T.)  Practicum
HUMAN 195.description: H.O.T. sponsors tutoring opportunities in local schools and after-school sites for UCI students. Requirements include weekly one-hour training sessions at UCI

HUMAN 198.name: Directed Group Study
HUMAN 198.description: Directed group study on special topics.

HUMAN 199.name: Directed Research
HUMAN 199.description: Directed research for senior Humanities students.

HUMAN 260A.name: Critical Theory Workshop
HUMAN 260A.description: A year-long Critical Theory Workshop, conducted by a team of instructors, conceived as a reading group, and developed with the input of all participants, where significant texts are discussed and analyzed in class.

HUMAN 260B.name: Critical Theory Workshop
HUMAN 260B.description: A year-long Critical Theory Workshop, conducted by a team of instructors, conceived as a reading group, and developed with the input of all participants, where significant texts are discussed and analyzed in class.

HUMAN 260C.name: Critical Theory Workshop
HUMAN 260C.description: A year-long Critical Theory Workshop, conducted by a team of instructors, conceived as a reading group, and developed with the input of all participants, where significant texts are discussed and analyzed in class.

HUMAN 261.name: Race and Justice Studies Writing Seminar
HUMAN 261.description: A required writing-intensive seminar conducted by an instructor affiliated with the Race and Justice Studies emphasis. Students with manuscripts on relevant topics will read and critique peer manuscripts, and revise manuscripts toward completion of articles, dissertation chapters, and other publications.

HUMAN 265A.name: Issues In Latin American Studies I
HUMAN 265A.description: Students discuss significant texts on Latin America from a range of disciplines in the humanities, social sciences, and the arts. This course will meet 3-4 times per quarter throughout the academic year.

HUMAN 265B.name: Issues In Latin American Studies II
HUMAN 265B.description: Students discuss significant texts on Latin America from a range of disciplines in the humanities, social sciences, and the arts. This course will meet 3-4 times per quarter throughout the academic year.

HUMAN 265C.name: Issues In Latin American Studies III
HUMAN 265C.description: Students discuss significant texts on Latin America from a range of disciplines in the humanities, social sciences, and the arts. This course will meet 3-4 times per quarter throughout the academic year.

HUMAN 270.name: Advanced Critical Theory
HUMAN 270.description: Seminars on various topics in critical theory.
HUMAN 270.prereqString: Prerequisite: Students should have taken introductory courses before enrolling in these seminars.

HUMAN 298.name: Humanities Out There (H.O.T.) Practicum
HUMAN 298.description: Individual study with H.O.T. faculty supervisor.

HUMAN 398A.name: Foreign Language Teaching: Approaches and Methods
HUMAN 398A.description: Introduces approaches and methods of foreign language learning and teaching, and the theoretical models of second-language acquisition and teaching. Focus areas include lesson planning, teaching vocabulary, grammar, speaking, reading, writing, listening, culture, task-based teaching, uses of digital media.

HUMAN 398B.name: Foreign Language Teaching: Approaches and Methods
HUMAN 398B.description: Introduces approaches and methods of foreign language learning and teaching, and the theoretical models of second-language acquisition and teaching. Focus areas include lesson planning, teaching vocabulary, grammar, speaking, reading, writing, listening, culture, task-based teaching, uses of digital media.

HUMAN 399.name: University Teaching
HUMAN 399.description: Limited to Teaching Associates in Humanities Core course.

I&C SCI 3.name: Internet Technologies and their Social Impact
I&C SCI 3.description: Examines current Internet technologies and social implications at the individual, group, and societal level. Blogs, wikis, sharing of video, photos, and music, e-commerce, social networking, gaming, and virtual environments. Issues include privacy, trust, identity, reputation, governance, copyright, and malicious behavior.

I&C SCI 4.name: Human Factors for the Web
I&C SCI 4.description: Principles of human-computer interaction in evaluating, designing, and developing information presented on the World Wide Web. User characteristics, usability analysis, navigation and organization. Color, typography, multimedia, information visualization, prototyping, user studies, evaluation strategies. Web accessibility.
I&C SCI 4.restriction: Restriction: May not be taken for credit after IN4MATX 131.

I&C SCI 5.name: Global Disruption and Information Technology
I&C SCI 5.description: Explores how new forms of information technology may support transition to a sustainable civilization. Topics include design and implementation of IT systems, science of global change, online community building, and “green IT”. Activities involve reading, writing, discussion, and final project.

I&C SCI 6B.name: Boolean Logic and Discrete Structures
I&C SCI 6B.prereqString: Prerequisite: High school mathematics through trigonometry.
I&C SCI 6B.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

I&C SCI 6D.name: Discrete Mathematics for Computer Science
I&C SCI 6D.description: Covers essential tools from discrete mathematics used in computer science with an emphasis on the process of abstracting computational problems and analyzing them mathematically. Topics include mathematical induction, combinatorics, and recurrence relations.
I&C SCI 6D.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Engineering majors have second consideration.

I&C SCI 6N.name: Computational Linear Algebra
I&C SCI 6N.description: Matrices and linear transformations, systems of linear equations, determinants, linear vector spaces, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, orthogonal matrices, diagonalization, and least squares. Topics taught primarily from an algorithmic perspective, including computational solutions, applications, and numerical error analysis.
I&C SCI 6N.prereqString: Prerequisite: I&C SCI 31 or I&C SCI 32A or AP Computer Science A. AP Computer Science A with a minimum score of 3
I&C SCI 6N.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

I&C SCI 7.name: Spreadsheets for Problem-Solving
I&C SCI 7.description: Features useful tools for building, solving, analyzing, and visualizing computational models in diverse areas. Covered features include data entry and protection

I&C SCI 10.name: How Computers Work
I&C SCI 10.description: Introduction to digital computer and communication systems. Capabilities and limitations of information technology. Representing information in digital form. Overview of computer organization, internet, operating systems, software. Human-computer interaction and social impact.
I&C SCI 10.restriction: Restriction: May not be taken for credit after I&C SCI 31, I&C SCI 32, I&C SCI 32A, I&C SCI 51, I&C SCI 105, or IN4MATX 43.

I&C SCI 11.name: The Internet and Public Policy
I&C SCI 11.description: How the Internet works. Current public policy issues concerning the Internet. Introductory economics. Communications law. Interactions between information technology, economics, and law. Case studies about Internet and communications policy.

I&C SCI 20.name: Invitation to Computing
I&C SCI 20.description: Foundational principles of computer science for students with no computing background that are interested in a related career. Big ideas of computing explored, including programming through use of sequential, conditional, iterative logic. Good computational practices, problem solving, and organization discussed.

I&C SCI 31.name: Introduction to Programming
I&C SCI 31.description: Introduction to fundamental concepts and techniques for writing software in a high-level programming language. Covers the syntax and semantics of data types, expressions, exceptions, control structures, input/output, methods, classes, and pragmatics of programming.
I&C SCI 31.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

I&C SCI 32.name: Programming with Software Libraries
I&C SCI 32.description: Construction of programs for problems and computing environments more varied than in I&C SCI 31. Using library modules for applications such as graphics, sound, GUI, database, Web, and network programming. Language features beyond those in I&C SCI 31 are introduced as needed.
I&C SCI 32.prereqString: Prerequisite: I&C SCI 31 or CSE 41. I&C SCI 31 with a grade of C or better. CSE 41 with a grade of C or better
I&C SCI 32.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

I&C SCI 32A.name: Python Programming and Libraries (Accelerated)
I&C SCI 32A.description: Introduces Python syntax and semantics for fundamental programming concepts.  Constructing programs for varied problems and environments. Using library modules for applications such as graphics, sound, GUI, database, Web, and network programming. Accelerated course for students with previous programming background.
I&C SCI 32A.prereqString: Prerequisite: AP Computer Science A. AP Computer Science A with a minimum score of 3. Placement via a transfer course in computer programming or equivalent experience may also be accepted upon review.
I&C SCI 32A.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

I&C SCI 33.name: Intermediate Programming
I&C SCI 33.description: Intermediate-level language features and programming concepts for larger, more complex, higher-quality software. Functional programming, name spaces, modules, class protocols, inheritance, iterators, generators, operator overloading, reflection. Analysis of time and space efficiency.
I&C SCI 33.prereqString: Prerequisite: I&C SCI 32 or CSE 42 or I&C SCI 32A. I&C SCI 32 with a grade of C or better. CSE 42 with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 32A with a grade of C or better
I&C SCI 33.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

I&C SCI 45C.name: Programming in C/C++ as a Second Language
I&C SCI 45C.description: An introduction to the lexical, syntactic, semantic, and pragmatic characteristics of the C/C++ languages for experienced programmers. Emphasis on object-oriented programming, using standard libraries, and programming with manual garbage collection.
I&C SCI 45C.prereqString: Prerequisite: I&C SCI 33 or CSE 43 or EECS 40. I&C SCI 33 with a grade of C or better. CSE 43 with a grade of C or better. EECS 40 with a grade of C or better
I&C SCI 45C.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

I&C SCI 45J.name: Programming in Java as a Second Language
I&C SCI 45J.description: An introduction to the lexical, syntactic, semantic, and pragmatic characteristics of the Java language for experienced programmers. Emphasis on object-oriented programming, using standard libraries, and programming with automatic garbage collection.
I&C SCI 45J.prereqString: Prerequisite: I&C SCI 33 or CSE 43. I&C SCI 33 with a grade of C or better. CSE 43 with a grade of C or better
I&C SCI 45J.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. I&C SCI 45J may not be taken for credit after I&C SCI 22, I&C SCI 23, or CSE 23.

I&C SCI 46.name: Data Structure Implementation and Analysis
I&C SCI 46.description: Focuses on implementation and mathematical analysis of fundamental data structures and algorithms. Covers storage allocation and memory management techniques.
I&C SCI 46.prereqString: Prerequisite: CSE 45C or I&C SCI 45C. CSE 45C with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 45C with a grade of C or better
I&C SCI 46.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

I&C SCI 51.name: Introductory Computer Organization
I&C SCI 51.description: Multilevel view, design, and operation of computer system components. Machine-level data and instruction representation. Instruction sets and addressing modes. Memory organization. Laboratory work using low-level programming languages.
I&C SCI 51.prereqString: Prerequisite: I&C SCI 33 and I&C SCI 6B
I&C SCI 51.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment.

I&C SCI 53.name: Principles in System Design
I&C SCI 53.description: Introduces basic principles of system software: operating systems, compilers, and networking. Exposure to the following topics through theoretical and practical programming experiences: linking and loading, process and memory management, concurrency and synchronization, network communication, programming for performance, etc.
I&C SCI 53.prereqString:
Corequisite: I&C SCI 53L
Prerequisite: I&C SCI 46 and I&C SCI 51. I&C SCI 46 with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 51 with a grade of C or better
I&C SCI 53.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

I&C SCI 53L.name: Principles in System Design Laboratory
I&C SCI 53L.description: Required laboratory section and corequisite for I&C SCI 53.
I&C SCI 53L.prereqString:
Corequisite: I&C SCI 53
Prerequisite: I&C SCI 51
I&C SCI 53L.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment.

I&C SCI 60.name: Games and Society
I&C SCI 60.description: The study and critical analysis of computer games as art objects, cultural artifacts, gateways to virtual worlds, educational aids, and tools for persuasion and social change. Emphasis on understanding games in their historical and cultural context.  Materials fee.
I&C SCI 60.restriction: Restriction: Computer Game Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Game Design and Interactive Media students have first consideration for enrollment. School of ICS majors have second right of consideration.

I&C SCI 61.name: Game Design Fundamentals
I&C SCI 61.description: Explore the fundamentals of game design through the design and play of simple analog game systems. Students explore the principles and usage of game design elements through hands-on projects emphasizing iteration and playtesting in a creative game design community.
I&C SCI 61.restriction: Restriction: Computer Game Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Game Design and Interactive Media students have first consideration for enrollment. School of ICS majors have second right of consideration

I&C SCI 62.name: Game Technologies and Interactive Media
I&C SCI 62.description: Technologies for interactive media and game design. Web-based software systems, virtual world platforms, and game engines. Emphasis is on conceptual and architectural aspects of these technologies.
I&C SCI 62.prereqString: Prerequisite: I&C SCI 31 or I&C SCI 32A

I&C SCI 80.name: Special Topics in Information and Computer Science
I&C SCI 80.description: Studies in selected areas of information and computer sciences. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

I&C SCI 90.name: New Students Seminar
I&C SCI 90.description: Introduces students to the Donald Bren School of Information and Computer Sciences. Focuses on advising students making the transition to UCI, community building, and mostly surveying the technical areas within departments in ICS, via talks by faculty on their research.
I&C SCI 90.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment.

I&C SCI 139W.name: Critical Writing on Information Technology
I&C SCI 139W.description: Study and practice of critical writing and oral communication as it applies to information technology. Each student writes assignments of varying lengths, totaling at least 4,000 words.
I&C SCI 139W.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
I&C SCI 139W.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment.

I&C SCI 161.name: Game Engine Lab
I&C SCI 161.description: The use of an open source game or graphics engine in the design and implementation of a computer game. Principles of game engine design. Students work on teams to design, implement, and evaluate new computer games based on an engine.
I&C SCI 161.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment.

I&C SCI 162.name: Modeling and World Building
I&C SCI 162.description: Use of 3D modeling software and related tools to design and create animated, textured models, and expansive virtual worlds incorporating objects, scenes, and venues for activity within game worlds and online environments.
I&C SCI 162.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment.

I&C SCI 163.name: Mobile and Ubiquitous Games
I&C SCI 163.description: Design and technology of mobile games, including mixed reality gaming, urban games, and locative media. Case studies of significant systems. Uses and limitations of location-based technologies. Infrastructures and their relationships to gameplay and design.
I&C SCI 163.prereqString: Prerequisite: I&C SCI 61 and (I&C SCI 10 or I&C SCI 31 or I&C SCI 32A)

I&C SCI 166.name: Game Design
I&C SCI 166.description: Game design takes into consideration psychology, narrative, platform features and limitations, marketing, computer science capabilities, human-computer interface principles, industry trends, aesthetic judgment, and other factors. Students focus on video game design through lectures, readings, presentations, implementation, and play testing.
I&C SCI 166.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Game Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

I&C SCI 167.name: Multiplayer Game Systems
I&C SCI 167.description: Foundations and technologies that enable multiuser, networked, and persistent virtual environments. Emphasis on database design and management, network protocols, and concurrency control to accommodate large numbers of simultaneous users.
I&C SCI 167.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Game Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

I&C SCI 168.name: Multiplayer Game Project
I&C SCI 168.description: Design and develop a multiplayer game using Unity or similar engine, with a focus on learning to work in a development team, writing design documents, working with platform features and limitations, developing engaging mechanics, playtesting, and post-mortems.
I&C SCI 168.prereqString: Prerequisite: GDIM 27 and GDIM 33 and GDIM 51 and GDIM 61. GDIM 27 with a grade of C or better. GDIM 33 with a grade of C or better
I&C SCI 168.restriction: Restriction: Computer Game Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Game Design and Interactive Media students have first consideration for enrollment. School of ICS majors are given second consideration.

I&C SCI 169A.name: Capstone Game Project I
I&C SCI 169A.description: Students work in teams to design and implement a unique game or interactive experience. Emphasis on sound, art, and level design, building a community, production values, full utilization of hardware and software platform, and current industry trends.
I&C SCI 169A.prereqString: Prerequisite: I&C SCI 168 or (GDIM 131 and GDIM 161). GDIM 161 with a grade of C or better
I&C SCI 169A.restriction: Restriction: Seniors only. Computer Game Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Game Design and Interactive Media students have first consideration for enrollment. School of ICS majors given second right of consideration.

I&C SCI 169B.name: Capstone Game Project II
I&C SCI 169B.description: Students continue work in teams to design and implement a unique game or interactive experience. Emphasis on sound, art, and level design, building a community, production values, full utilization of hardware and software platform, and current industry trends.
I&C SCI 169B.prereqString: Prerequisite: GDIM 167A or I&C SCI 169A. GDIM 167A with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 169A with a grade of C or better. In Progress grade for GDIM 167A or I&C SCI 169A also accepted.
I&C SCI 169B.restriction: Restriction: Seniors only. Computer Game Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Game Design and Interactive Media students have first consideration for enrollment. School of ICS majors given second right of consideration.

I&C SCI 192.name: Industrial or Public Sector Field Study
I&C SCI 192.description: Students participate in an off-campus, supervised internship for a minimum of 60 hours. Students apply classroom knowledge through internship projects in the private sector or nonprofit agencies.
I&C SCI 192.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

I&C SCI 193.name: Tutoring in ICS
I&C SCI 193.description: Principles and practice of providing technical assistance to novice learners in information and computer sciences.
I&C SCI 193.restriction: Restriction: ICS Peer Tutoring Program students only.

I&C SCI H197.name: Honors Seminar
I&C SCI H197.description: An overview of computer science and selected recent trends in research. Students attend talks on current faculty research, with opportunities for discussion.
I&C SCI H197.restriction: Restriction: Bren School of ICS Honors students only. Campuswide Honors Collegium students only.

I&C SCI 398A.name: Teaching Assistant Training Seminar
I&C SCI 398A.description: Theories, methods, and resources for teaching computer science at the university level, particularly by teaching assistants. Classroom presentations, working with individuals, grading, motivating students. Participants will give and critique presentations and may be videotaped while teaching.

I&C SCI 398B.name: Advanced Teaching Assistant Seminar
I&C SCI 398B.description: Teaching computer science at the university level, emphasizing issues in teaching an entire course. Course organization, designing examinations and projects, grading, motivating students. Participants will begin to assemble teaching portfolios.

I&C SCI 399.name: University Teaching
I&C SCI 399.description: Involves on-the-job experience for Teaching Assistants.

IN4MATX 12.name: Barter to Bitcoin: Society, Technology and the Future of Money
IN4MATX 12.description: Digital money has captured the broad imagination of speculators, coders, regulators, criminals and the mass media. Course puts this change in context: how do we understand money as a social, political and technological phenomenon?.

IN4MATX 43.name: Introduction to Software Engineering
IN4MATX 43.description: Concepts, methods, and current practice of software engineering. Large-scale software production, software life cycle models, principles and techniques for each stage of development.
IN4MATX 43.prereqString: Prerequisite: I&C SCI 32 or I&C SCI 32A
IN4MATX 43.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

IN4MATX 80.name: Special Topics in Informatics
IN4MATX 80.description: Designed for informatics instructors to pilot new teaching materials and prototype new class. The format of the class is flexible based on the content to be offered in the future.
IN4MATX 80.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment.

IN4MATX H81.name: Ethics, Technology, and Design
IN4MATX H81.description: Provides a critical framework for how and why biases of many kinds are built into everyday digital tools. Reflections on ethics, technology, and design through case studies drawn from machine learning, CS education, engineering, social media, and criminal justice.
IN4MATX H81.restriction: Restriction: Campuswide Honors Collegium students only.

IN4MATX 101.name: Concepts in Programming Languages I
IN4MATX 101.description: In-depth study of several contemporary programming languages stressing variety in data structures, operations, notation, and control. Examination of different programming paradigms, such as logic programming, functional programming and object-oriented programming
IN4MATX 101.prereqString: Prerequisite: (I&C SCI 51 or CSE 31 or EECS 31) and (I&C SCI 46 or CSE 46). I&C SCI 51 with a grade of C or better. CSE 31 with a grade of C or better. EECS 31 with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 46 with a grade of C or better. CSE 46 with a grade of C or better
IN4MATX 101.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

IN4MATX 102.name: Concepts of Programming Language II
IN4MATX 102.description: In-depth study of major programming paradigms: imperative, functional, declarative, object-oriented, and aspect-oriented. Understanding the role of programming languages in software development and the suitability of languages in context. Domain-specific languages. Designing new languages for better software development support.
IN4MATX 102.prereqString: Prerequisite: IN4MATX 101 or COMPSCI 141 or CSE 141
IN4MATX 102.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

IN4MATX 113.name: Requirements Analysis and Engineering
IN4MATX 113.description: Equips students to develop techniques of software-intensive systems through successful requirements analysis techniques and requirements engineering. Students learn systematic process of developing requirements through cooperative problem analysis, representation, and validation.
IN4MATX 113.prereqString: Prerequisite: (I&C SCI 33 or CSE 43) and IN4MATX 43. I&C SCI 33 with a grade of C or better. CSE 43 with a grade of C or better. IN4MATX 43 with a grade of C or better
IN4MATX 113.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

IN4MATX 115.name: Software Testing, Analysis, and Quality Assurance
IN4MATX 115.description: Preparation for developing high-quality software through successful veriﬁcation and validation techniques. Fundamental principles of software testing, implementing software testing practices, ensuring the thoroughness of testing to gain conﬁdence in the correctness of the software.
IN4MATX 115.prereqString: Prerequisite: (I&C SCI 45J or I&C SCI 45C or I&C SCI 46 or CSE 46) and IN4MATX 43. I&C SCI 45J with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 45C with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 46 with a grade of C or better. CSE 46 with a grade of C or better. IN4MATX 43 with a grade of C or better
IN4MATX 115.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

IN4MATX 117.name: Project in Software System Design
IN4MATX 117.description: Specification, design, construction, testing, and documentation of a complete software system. Special emphasis on the need for and use of teamwork, careful planning, and other techniques for working with large systems.
IN4MATX 117.prereqString: Prerequisite: (IN4MATX 43 and I&C SCI 33) or CSE 43
IN4MATX 117.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

IN4MATX 121.name: Software Design: Applications
IN4MATX 121.description: Introduction to application design: designing the overall functionality of a software application. Topics include general design theory, software design theory, and software architecture. Includes practice in designing and case studies of existing designs.
IN4MATX 121.prereqString: Prerequisite: I&C SCI 33 or CSE 43. I&C SCI 33 with a grade of C or better. CSE 43 with a grade of C or better
IN4MATX 121.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

IN4MATX 122.name: Software Design: Structure and Implementation
IN4MATX 122.description: Introduction to implementation design: designing the internals of a software application. Topics include design aesthetics, design implementation, design recovery, design patterns, and component reuse. Includes practice in designing and case studies of existing designs.
IN4MATX 122.prereqString: Prerequisite: (I&C SCI 45J or I&C SCI 46 or IN4MATX 45) and (IN4MATX 101 or COMPSCI 141 or CSE 141)
IN4MATX 122.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

IN4MATX 124.name: Internet Applications Engineering
IN4MATX 124.description: Concepts in Internet applications engineering with emphasis on the Web. Peer-to-Peer and Interoperability. Topics include HTTP and REST, Remote Procedure/Method Calls, Web Services, data representations, content distribution networks, identity management, relevant W3C/IETF standards, and relevant new large-scale computing styles.
IN4MATX 124.prereqString: Prerequisite: (COMPSCI 132 or EECS 148) and I&C SCI 45J
IN4MATX 124.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

IN4MATX 125.name: Computer Game Development
IN4MATX 125.description: Introduction to the principles of interactive 2D and 3D computer game development. Concepts in computer graphics, algorithms, software engineering, art and graphics, music and sound, story analysis, and artificial intelligence are presented and are the basis for student work.
IN4MATX 125.prereqString: Prerequisite: COMPSCI 112 or COMPSCI 171 or IN4MATX 121 or ART 106B or I&C SCI 163 or I&C SCI 166
IN4MATX 125.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

IN4MATX 131.name: Human Computer Interaction
IN4MATX 131.description: Basic principles of human-computer interaction (HCI). Introduces students to user interface design techniques, design guidelines, and usability testing. Students gain the ability to design and evaluate user interfaces and become familiar with some of the outstanding research problems in HCI.
IN4MATX 131.prereqString: Prerequisite: I&C SCI 10 or I&C SCI 31 or I&C SCI 32A or CSE 41 or ENGR 10 or ENGRMAE 10 or EECS 10. I&C SCI 10 with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 31 with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 32A with a grade of C or better. CSE 41 with a grade of C or better. ENGR 10 with a grade of C or better. ENGRMAE 10 with a grade of C or better. EECS 10 with a grade of C or better
IN4MATX 131.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

IN4MATX 132.name: Project in Human-Computer Interaction Requirements and Evaluation
IN4MATX 132.description: Students undertake significant projects in the elicitation and specification of HCI requirements and the thorough evaluation of user interfaces.
IN4MATX 132.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

IN4MATX 133.name: User Interaction Software
IN4MATX 133.description: Introduction to human-computer interaction programming. Emphasis on current tools, standards, methodologies for implementing effective interaction designs. Widget toolkits, Web interface programming, geo-spatial and map interfaces, mobile phone interfaces.
IN4MATX 133.prereqString: Prerequisite: I&C SCI 45J or I&C SCI 45C. I&C SCI 45J with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 45C with a grade of C or better
IN4MATX 133.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

IN4MATX 134.name: Project in User Interaction Software
IN4MATX 134.description: Students complete an end-to-end user interface programming project based on an iterative design paradigm. Topics may include requirements brainstorming, paper prototyping, iterative development, cognitive walk-through, quantitative evaluation, and acceptance testing. Materials fee.
IN4MATX 134.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

IN4MATX 141.name: Information Retrieval
IN4MATX 141.description: An introduction to information retrieval including indexing, retrieval, classifying, and clustering text and multimedia documents.
IN4MATX 141.prereqString: Prerequisite: (I&C SCI 45C or I&C SCI 45J) and (STATS 7 or STATS 67). I&C SCI 45C with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 45J with a grade of C or better
IN4MATX 141.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment.

IN4MATX 143.name: Information Visualization
IN4MATX 143.description: Introduction to interactive visual interfaces for large datasets, and to principles of human visual perception and human computer interaction that inform their design. Various applications for data analysis and monitoring are discussed.
IN4MATX 143.prereqString: Prerequisite: (IN4MATX 131 or IN4MATX 43) and (I&C SCI 31 or I&C SCI 32A or CSE 41). IN4MATX 131 with a grade of C or better. IN4MATX 43 with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 31 with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 32A with a grade of C or better. CSE 41 with a grade of C or better
IN4MATX 143.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment.

IN4MATX 148.name: Project in Ubiquitous Computing
IN4MATX 148.description: Introduction to ubiquitous computing research methods, tools, and techniques. Prototyping, design, and evaluation of physical computing applications, smart environments, embedded systems, and future computing scenarios. Includes hands-on in-class laboratory exercises. Materials fee.
IN4MATX 148.prereqString: Prerequisite: I&C SCI 10 or I&C SCI 31 or CSE 41 or I&C SCI 32A. I&C SCI 10 with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 31 with a grade of C or better. CSE 41 with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 32A with a grade of C or better
IN4MATX 148.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment.

IN4MATX 151.name: Project Management
IN4MATX 151.description: Introduces theoretical and practical aspects of project management. Topics include organizational theory, group behavior, project management skills, case studies, personal and group productivity tools, management of distributed work, stakeholders, consultants, and knowledge management. Students do a project exercise.
IN4MATX 151.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment.

IN4MATX 153.name: Computer Supported Cooperative Work
IN4MATX 153.description: Introduces concepts and principles of collaborative systems. Topics may include shared workspaces, group interaction, workflow, architectures, interaction between social and technical features of group work, and examples of collaborative systems used in real-world settings. Students develop a simple collaborative application.
IN4MATX 153.prereqString: Prerequisite: (IN4MATX 161 or IN4MATX 43) and (I&C SCI 31 or I&C SCI 32A or CSE 41). I&C SCI 31 with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 32A with a grade of C or better. CSE 41 with a grade of C or better
IN4MATX 153.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment.

IN4MATX 161.name: Social Analysis of Computing
IN4MATX 161.description: Introduction of computing as a social process. Examines the social opportunities and problems raised by new information technologies, and the consequences of different ways of organizing. Topics include computing and work life, privacy, virtual communities, productivity paradox, systems risks.
IN4MATX 161.prereqString: Prerequisite: I&C SCI 10 or I&C SCI 31 or I&C SCI 32A or CSE 41 or ENGR 10 or EECS 10 or ENGRMAE 10. I&C SCI 10 with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 31 with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 32A with a grade of C or better. CSE 41 with a grade of C or better. ENGR 10 with a grade of C or better. EECS 10 with a grade of C or better. ENGRMAE 10 with a grade of C or better. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
IN4MATX 161.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment.

IN4MATX 162W.name: Organizational Information Systems
IN4MATX 162W.description: Introduction to role of information systems in organizations, components and structure of organizational information systems, and techniques used in information systems analysis, design, and implementation.
IN4MATX 162W.prereqString: Prerequisite: IN4MATX 161. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

IN4MATX 163.name: Project in the Social and Organizational Impacts of Computing
IN4MATX 163.description: Students undertake projects intended to gather and analyze data from situations in which computers are used, organize and conduct experiments intended to test hypotheses about impacts, and explore the application of concepts learned in previous courses.

IN4MATX 164.name: Children's Learning and Media
IN4MATX 164.description: Examines how popular media may impact how young people learn, develop, and communicate by looking at research related to the impacts of a wide range of popular media including television, video games, digital environments, mobile devices, and other multimedia.
IN4MATX 164.restriction: Restriction: Education Sciences Majors only. Informatics Majors only. Informatics Minors only.

IN4MATX 171.name: Introduction to Medical Informatics
IN4MATX 171.description: Broad overview of medical informatics for students with varied backgrounds. Electronic medical records, online resources, mobile technologies, patient safety, and computational design. Legal, ethical, and public policy issues. Health systems management. Evaluation and fieldwork for health systems.
IN4MATX 171.prereqString: Prerequisite: WRITING 39C or WRITING 30 or WRITING 31 or HUMAN 1C or HUMAN H1C. WRITING 39C with a grade of C or better. WRITING 30 with a grade of C or better. WRITING 31 with a grade of C or better. HUMAN 1C with a grade of C or better. HUMAN H1C with a grade of C or better
IN4MATX 171.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

IN4MATX 172.name: Project in Health Informatics
IN4MATX 172.description: Students undertake significant quarter-long projects related to health informatics. Topics may include field evaluations of health care technologies, prototypes, iterative design, and system implementations.

IN4MATX 190.name: Special Topics in Informatics
IN4MATX 190.description: Studies in selected areas of informatics. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

IN4MATX 191A.name: Senior Design Project
