IN4MATX 191A.description: Group supervised project in which students analyze, specify, design, construct, evaluate, and adapt a significant information processing system. Topics include team management, professional ethics, and systems analysis.
IN4MATX 191A.prereqString: Prerequisite: IN4MATX 113 and IN4MATX 121 and IN4MATX 131 and IN4MATX 151
IN4MATX 191A.restriction: Restriction: Seniors only. Software Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Informatics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

IN4MATX 191B.name: Senior Design Project
IN4MATX 191B.description: Group supervised project in which students analyze, specify, design, construct, evaluate, and adapt a significant information processing system. Topics include team management, professional ethics, and systems analysis.
IN4MATX 191B.prereqString: Prerequisite: IN4MATX 191A. In Progress (IP) grade for IN4MATX 191A is also accepted.

IN4MATX H198.name: Honors Research
IN4MATX H198.description: Directed independent research in Informatics for honors students.
IN4MATX H198.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
IN4MATX H198.restriction: Restriction: Bren School of ICS Honors students only. Campuswide Honors Collegium students only.

IN4MATX 199.name: Individual Study
IN4MATX 199.description: Individual research or investigation under the direction of an individual faculty member.

IN4MATX 201.name: Research Methodology for Informatics
IN4MATX 201.description: Introduction to strategies and idioms of research in Informatics. Includes examination of issues in scientific inquiry, qualitative and quantitative methods, and research design. Both classic texts and contemporary research literature are read and analyzed.

IN4MATX 203.name: Qualitative Research Methods in Information Systems
IN4MATX 203.description: Introduction to qualitative research methods used to study computerization and information systems, such as open-ended interviewing, participant observation, and ethnography. Studies of the methods in practice through examination of research literature.

IN4MATX 205.name: Quantitative Research Methods in Information Systems
IN4MATX 205.description: Quantitative research methods used to study computerization and information systems. Design of instruments, sampling, sample sizes, and data analysis. Validity and reliability. Longitudinal versus cross-sectional designs. Analysis of secondary data. Studies of the methods through examination of research literature.
IN4MATX 205.prereqString: Prerequisite: IN4MATX 251 or IN4MATX 261. Basic knowledge of elementary statistics is also required.

IN4MATX 207S.name: Doctoral Seminar on Research and Writing
IN4MATX 207S.description: Doctoral seminar centered on original research and writing. Provides a chance for doctoral students at all levels to present original work, brainstorm ongoing issues, and learn to provide and receive critical feedback from peers.

IN4MATX 209S.name: Seminar in Informatics
IN4MATX 209S.description: Current research and research trends in informatics. Forum for presentation and criticism by students of research work in progress.

IN4MATX 231.name: User Interface Design and Evaluation
IN4MATX 231.description: Introduction to the design and evaluation of user interfaces, with an emphasis on methodology. Cognitive principles, design life cycle, on-line and off-line prototyping techniques. Toolkits and architectures for interactive systems. Evaluation techniques, including heuristic and laboratory methods.

IN4MATX 232.name: Research in Human-Centered Computing
IN4MATX 232.description: Introduction to contemporary topics in human-computer interaction, including methods, technologies, design, and evaluation. Emerging application domains and their challenges to traditional research methods. Advanced architectures and technologies. Critical issues.
IN4MATX 232.prereqString: Prerequisite: Some familiarity with HCI principles.

IN4MATX 241.name: Introduction to Ubiquitous Computing
IN4MATX 241.description: The "disappearing computer" paradigm. Differences to the desktop computing model: applications, interaction in augmented environments, security, alternate media, small operating systems, sensors, and embedded systems design. Evaluation by project work and class participation.

IN4MATX 242.name: Ubiquitous Computing and Interaction
IN4MATX 242.description: Principles and design techniques for ubiquitous computing applications. Conceptual basis for tangible and embodied interaction. Interaction in virtual and augmented environments. Design methods and techniques. Design case studies. Examination by project work.

IN4MATX 244.name: Introduction to Embedded and Ubiquitous Systems
IN4MATX 244.description: Embedded and ubiquitous system technologies including processors, DSP, memory, and software. System interfacing basics
IN4MATX 244.prereqString: Prerequisite: I&C SCI 51 and COMPSCI 152 and COMPSCI 161 and (I&C SCI 6N or MATH 3A or MATH 6G or I&C SCI 6D). B.S. degree in Computer Science is also accepted.

IN4MATX 251.name: Computer-Supported Cooperative Work
IN4MATX 251.description: The role of information systems in supporting work in groups and organizations. Examines various technologies designed to support communication, information sharing, and coordination. Focuses on behavioral and social aspects of designing and using group support technologies.

IN4MATX 261.name: Social Analysis of Computing
IN4MATX 261.description: The social and economic impacts of computing and information technologies on groups, organizations, and society. Topics include computerization and changes in the character of work, social control and privacy, electronic communities, and risks of safety-critical systems to people.

IN4MATX 263.name: Computerization, Work, and Organizations
IN4MATX 263.description: Selected topics in the influence of computerization and information systems in transforming work and organizations. Theories of organization and organizational change. Processes by which diverse information technologies influence changes in work and organizations over short and long time periods.

IN4MATX 265.name: Theories of Information Society
IN4MATX 265.description: Social and economic conceptions of information technology. Macrosocial and economic conditions that foster changes in information technologies. Social construction of information and computer technology in professional worlds. Theories of information technology and large-scale social change.

IN4MATX 267.name: Digital Media and Society
IN4MATX 267.description: Selected topics in the technological and social aspects of online interactions, and policy including online games, social media, electronic activism, e-commerce, and digital libraries. Media-theoretic approaches to digital technology. Architectures, infrastructure considerations, and their consequences.

IN4MATX 273.name: Information Technology in Global Sustainability
IN4MATX 273.description: Explores the relationship between recent developments in information technology and the global transition to sustainability. Topics include the role of IT systems in the provision of human needs and wants (e.g., smart grids, food systems, and other IT-enabled infrastructure).

IN4MATX 280.name: Overview of Human-Computer Interaction and Design
IN4MATX 280.description: Introduction to human-computer interaction and user-centered design. The material is focused on laying the groundwork for understanding the history, importance, and methods of human-computer interaction and design.

IN4MATX 281.name: User Needs Analysis
IN4MATX 281.description: Understanding the user's context, needs, and preferences. Topics include interviews and observations, modeling the context, flow, culture, space and artifacts involved in an endeavor, ways of aggregating what is found, and presenting these findings to others.

IN4MATX 282.name: Design and Prototyping
IN4MATX 282.description: Introduction to user-centered design and prototyping. Focused on practical methods for interaction design. Topics include the nature of design and the challenges to creating and evaluating good designs, as well specific skills for designing interactive systems.

IN4MATX 283.name: User Experience Evaluation
IN4MATX 283.description: Evaluating prototypes and completed systems. Topics include comparative analysis, laboratory experiments, heuristic evaluation, cognitive walkthroughs, surveys, clickstreams, and help-desk.

IN4MATX 284.name: Advanced Design and Prototyping
IN4MATX 284.description: Develop and communicate interactive technology design prototypes. Moving concepts from brainstorming and paper prototypes to wireframe and limited functionality mock-ups.

IN4MATX 285.name: Interactive Technology Studio
IN4MATX 285.description: Technologies, languages, and skills required for creating prototypes to communicate interactive technology concepts. Topics include HTTP, CSS, CSS scripting, AJAX, Design Patterns, Javascript, Javascript libraries such as jQuery, SQL, MVC, and cloud architectures.

IN4MATX 286.name: Innovations in HCI and Design
IN4MATX 286.description: Recent social and technological developments in human-computer interaction and design. Topics will vary as the field progresses but include novel input techniques, novel platforms, and innovations in theory and methods of design.

IN4MATX 287.name: Capstone Project in HCI and Design
IN4MATX 287.description: Group project that reinforces all concepts learned in this program, including knowing where user experience work is most appropriate and essential, and executing the appropriate steps.

IN4MATX 288.name: Capstone Project and Portfolio
IN4MATX 288.description: Completion of capstone projects and development of portfolios. Ideation, critique, development, and critique.

IN4MATX 289.name: Special Topics in Applying Human-Computer Interaction and Design in Industry
IN4MATX 289.description: Selected topics related to understanding and applying human-computer interaction and design concepts and practices within the User Experience industry. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
IN4MATX 289.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students only. Graduate students only. Human Comp Interact and Design Majors only.

IN4MATX 290.name: Research Seminar
IN4MATX 290.description: Forum for presentation and criticism by students of research work in progress. Presentation of problem areas and related work. Specific goals and progress of research.

IN4MATX 291S.name: Literature Survey in Software Engineering
IN4MATX 291S.description: Reading and analysis of relevant literature in Software Engineering under the direction of a faculty member.

IN4MATX 295.name: Special Topics in Informatics
IN4MATX 295.description: Studies in selected areas of informatics. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

IN4MATX 298.name: Thesis Supervision
IN4MATX 298.description: Individual research or investigation conducted in preparation for the M.S. thesis option or the dissertation requirements for the Ph.D. program.

IN4MATX 299.name: Individual Study
IN4MATX 299.description: Individual research or investigation under the direction of an individual faculty member.

INNO 202.name: Leadership for Entrepreneurs
INNO 202.description: Assists experienced and inexperienced entrepreneurs with some of the challenges of managing others, and helps them build their understanding and skills so they can become more successful managers of people.

INNO 203.name: Financial Accounting for Entrepreneurs
INNO 203.description: Provides the building blocks of financial accounting that are essential to entrepreneurs. Covers financial ratios and statements, including forecasting financial statements, basic transaction analysis, and generally accepted accounting principles.

INNO 205.name: Marketing for Entrepreneurs
INNO 205.description: Develops familiarity with fundamental concepts, theories, and techniques in marketing, and acquaints students with the type of decisions made by marketing managers including customer targeting, product, pricing, placement, promotion, and research.

INNO 209.name: Managerial Finance for Entrepreneurs
INNO 209.description: Provides the building blocks of finance knowledge that are essential to entrepreneurs.  Covers investment and financing decisions, including the time value of money, cash flow creation, cost of capital, and capital budgeting.

INNO 211.name: MIE Pre-Accelerator
INNO 211.description: Prepares students for the New Venture Competition in spring quarter. Students form teams to create a startup, submit concept paper, pitch ideas, and attend workshops throughout the academic year.
INNO 211.restriction: Restriction: Master of Innovation and Entrepreneurship Degree students only. Graduate students only.

INNO 212.name: Business Growth Strategies for Entrepreneurs
INNO 212.description: Focuses on management of growth opportunities in industries where applied innovation, usually in the form of technology, people, or processes, creates distinct competitive advantages.

INNO 214.name: Entrepreneurship
INNO 214.description: Student teams develop a business plan to launch a new venture. Drafts of sections of the plan are due throughout the course.
INNO 214.restriction: Restriction: Master of Innovation and Entrepreneurship Degree students only.

INNO 215.name: Lean Startup
INNO 215.description: Exposes students to an entrepreneurial experience with the same pressures and demands of an early-stage startup to provide a real-world, hands-on learning experience in starting a company.
INNO 215.restriction: Restriction: Master of Innovation and Entrepreneurship Degree students only.

INNO 218.name: Venture Capital for Entrepreneurs
INNO 218.description: Overview of venture capital and private equity, which constitute the alternative asset class (as opposed to conventional investments). Many start-up and entrepreneurial firms require substantial capital, and venture capital and private equity organizations finance these high-risk but potentially high-reward companies.

INNO 252D.name: New Product Development for Entrepreneurs
INNO 252D.description: Designed to introduce the new product development process and techniques to identify markets, develop new product ideas, measure consumer preferences, position and design new products, and test them prior to launch. Evening or weekend course format.

INNO 257.name: Marketing on the Internet for Entrepreneurs
INNO 257.description: Examines impact of the internet on traditional methods of marketing. Discusses how to capitalize on and increase the internet's utility as a tool that can increase marketing effectiveness, efficiency, and competitiveness. Evening or weekend course format.

INNO 275.name: Innovation Internship
INNO 275.description: Students apply innovative and creative knowledge obtained from classroom theory through work experiences. Provides knowledge of career opportunities, an understanding of the role innovation plays in business environments, and preparation to become an entrepreneur.
INNO 275.restriction: Restriction: Master of Innovation and Entrepreneurship Degree students only.

INNO 290.name: Special Topics in Innovation and Entrepreneurship
INNO 290.description: Studies in selected areas of innovation and entrepreneurship. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

INNO 292.name: Business Law for Entrepreneurs
INNO 292.description: Focuses on educating individuals starting, or investing in, a new business in the U.S. Provides an overview to common legal issues faced by entrepreneurs, such as business formation and structure, governance and employment contracts, and intellectual property and taxation.

INNO 294.name: Edge: Innovation in the New Digital Age
INNO 294.description: Explores the strategic and operational issues that business leaders face in adapting to the new business environment, what we call innovating, managing, and competing at the edge.
INNO 294.restriction: Restriction: Master of Innovation and Entrepreneurship Degree students only.

INNO 298.name: Merage Consulting Projects for Entrepreneurs
INNO 298.description: Provides students the opportunity to put into practice concepts, skills, and tools acquired in other parts of the MBA program. Seminars augment internship experiences with analyses of relevant administrative issues.

INNO 299.name: Individual Study
INNO 299.description: Individual study under the direction of a selected faculty member.

INTL ST 1.name: Introduction to Global Studies
INTL ST 1.description: Ongoing historical processes that increase global integration, the social, economic, and political interdependence of different regions, cultures, and peoples. Topics include ancient empires, colonialism, nationalism, industrialization, modern imperialism and warfare, decolonization, global social movements, conflict, inequality, and global governance.
INTL ST 1.restriction: Restriction: International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

INTL ST 11.name: Global Cultures and Society
INTL ST 11.description: Offers a general overview of the rise of global interdependence in political, economic, demographic, and cultural terms. Considers what drove people from relative isolation into intensified intercourse with one another, and investigates the consequences of this shift.
INTL ST 11.restriction: Restriction: Anthropology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

INTL ST 12.name: Global Political Ideologies
INTL ST 12.description: An overview of the major political ideologies shaping the current world order and global conflict. Topics include liberalism, democracy, nationalism, capitalism, communism, socialism, fascism, neoliberalism, clash of civilizations, sectarian violence, populist nationalism, and de-globalization.
INTL ST 12.restriction: Restriction: International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

INTL ST 13.name: Global Economy
INTL ST 13.description: Acquaints students with the fundamental patterns of the global economy. Emphasizes the historical roots and political implications of economic choices.
INTL ST 13.restriction: Restriction: International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

INTL ST 14.name: Introduction to International Relations
INTL ST 14.description: Analysis of political relations between and among nations with emphasis on explanations of conflict and cooperation. The role of ideologies and their relation to international problems are also examined.
INTL ST 14.restriction: Restriction: Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

INTL ST 15.name: Global Political Economy
INTL ST 15.description: The global economy as an integrated system. The rise of world trade, capitalism, national economies, market cycles, competing economic ideologies, development, globalization, transnational labor, multinational corporations, and the role of UN, World Bank, WTO, and the IMF in global governance.
INTL ST 15.restriction: Restriction: International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

INTL ST 16.name: Human Rights and Global Governance
INTL ST 16.description: Historical development of civil, political rights and the rise of human rights in international law. Explores role, and limitations, of the UN, ICJ, and ICC in global governance. Reconceptualizing democracy and political representation in a postnational 21st century.
INTL ST 16.restriction: Restriction: International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

INTL ST 17.name: Global Environmental Issues
INTL ST 17.description: Examines problems such as global climate change, growing human populations, fisheries depletion, ocean acidification, biodiversity loss, deforestation, and food security. Introduces political, social, and economic factors contributing to environmental issues and their disproportional impacts on the world’s poor and minorities.
INTL ST 17.restriction: Restriction: International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

INTL ST 100.name: Global Trials
INTL ST 100.description: Explores landmark legal trials that have impacted both domestic and world affairs.The trials provide a lens through which to explore society at the time, as well as shed light on the historical legacies of current social, political, and legal values.
INTL ST 100.restriction: Restriction: International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Minors have first consideration for enrollment.

INTL ST 101A.name: Global Social Movements
INTL ST 101A.description: The evolution of global social movements over past 250 years. Age of Revolutions in America, France, and Haiti
INTL ST 101A.restriction: Restriction: International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Minors have first consideration for enrollment.

INTL ST 101B.name: Global Cities and Slums
INTL ST 101B.description: Cities as a window into contemporary challenges of the globalized world. Global cities such as Los Angeles, London, and Beijing compared with cities with slums in the global south such as Rio de Janeiro, Johannesburg, and Mumbai.
INTL ST 101B.restriction: Restriction: International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Minors have first consideration for enrollment.

INTL ST 102A.name: Global Refugees and Stateless People
INTL ST 102A.description: Examines the reason behind global refugee crises, and what it means to be a displaced migrant or stateless person in history and in contemporary society. Links case studies about refugees around the world.
INTL ST 102A.restriction: Restriction: International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Minors have first consideration for enrollment.

INTL ST 102B.name: Global Asias and Orientalism
INTL ST 102B.description: Examines how the modern world is divided between East and West in the age of globalization. Through the postcolonial framework of Orientalism, it considers a pluralistic idea of Asia and the current notion of the new world order as one.
INTL ST 102B.restriction: Restriction: International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Minors have first consideration for enrollment.

INTL ST 103A.name: Case Studies in Global and Planetary Health
INTL ST 103A.description: Explores critical global health and planetary health studies, linking past trends to current research of health inequalities. Case studies include maternal-fetal mortality, environmental contamination, disaster preparedness, pharmaceutical development and access, and humanitarian aid interventions.
INTL ST 103A.restriction: Restriction: International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Minors have first consideration for enrollment.

INTL ST 104A.name: Global Trafficking
INTL ST 104A.description: Explores trafficking in different global contexts. Covers sex trafficking, labor trafficking, and organ trafficking. Tracks the use of the concept in policy, human rights, law, humanitarianism, and media. Provides a complex and nuanced understanding of the problem and its solutions.
INTL ST 104A.restriction: Restriction: International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Minors have first consideration for enrollment.

INTL ST 104BW.name: Global Gender and Sexuality
INTL ST 104BW.description: Develops critical insights into gender and sexuality as products of the world around us and as lived experiences across the globe. Topics include agency and resistance, intersectionality, feminisms, colonialism, heteronormativity, gender violence, masculinities, media and popular culture, globalization and migration.
INTL ST 104BW.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
INTL ST 104BW.restriction: Restriction: International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Minors have first consideration for enrollment.

INTL ST 106A.name: Global Political Ecology
INTL ST 106A.description: Introduction to political ecology and critical analysis of the global scale and globalization. Topics include current and historical climate change, fossil fuels, international trade and investment, soil erosion and pollution, deforestation, waste, ocean ecology, water crisis, wars, revolutions, and refugees.
INTL ST 106A.restriction: Restriction: International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Minors have first consideration for enrollment.

INTL ST 106B.name: Global Food Environment
INTL ST 106B.description: Examines the global political ecology of food, focusing on the U.S., China, and Brazil. Topics include the history of agriculture, imperialism/neocolonialism, Malthusianism, migration, agro-industrialization, deforestation, GMOs, agrochemicals, soil and water contamination, land struggles, food security/safety/sovereignty, dietary habits, and climate change.
INTL ST 106B.restriction: Restriction: International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Minors have first consideration for enrollment.

INTL ST 111B.name: World of Coffee
INTL ST 111B.description: History of consumption and production of coffee over the centuries, and coffee's cultural, economic, social, political consequences. Coffee's social life as a drug, symbol of hospitality, religious rite, sociability and bourgeois lifestyle, commodity, source of livelihoods, imperial revenues, corporate profits.

INTL ST 112A.name: International Business
INTL ST 112A.description: Introduction to conducting business in the international arena, decision making in the organization, and globalization of markets and production.  Topics covered range from tax and finance to ethics, marketing, and more.  Continuing corporate regulatory scandals discussed.

INTL ST 115.name: Global Poverty and Inequality in the 21st Century
INTL ST 115.description: Explores a multidisciplinary understanding of poverty and inequality in the 21st century and assesses impact of education, health, technology, and other interventions. Course offered online only.

INTL ST 122.name: Nuclear Environments
INTL ST 122.description: Understanding the impact of the nuclear age on the environment and human health through interrelated developments of nuclear power and nuclear weapons. The early years of weapon development, catastrophic environmental pollution, perils of nuclear power in the U.S. and Russia.

INTL ST 124A.name: Introduction to the Comparative Study of Legal Cultures
INTL ST 124A.description: Traces the anthropological and comparative cultural study of law from the nineteenth century to the present
INTL ST 124A.restriction: Restriction: Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. SocEcol-Urban & Regional Plan Majors have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

INTL ST 130.name: Transnational Gangs
INTL ST 130.description: Examines the internationalization of U.S. domestic street gangs.  The relationship between California gangs Mara Salvatrucha and 18th Street and Mexico/Central American gangs is assessed.  Specified topics include:  mobilization, migration, territorialism, culture, organization, and use of technology.

INTL ST 141B.name: Homeland Security
INTL ST 141B.description: Examines the 9/11 origins of the concept of homeland security

INTL ST 143A.name: Vietnam War
INTL ST 143A.description: Examines social structures and social changes in Vietnamese and U.S. societies through the study of the Vietnam War.

INTL ST 145A.name: International Law
INTL ST 145A.description: Examination of the origin, changing structure, application of international law, and the role of legal norms in regulating the behavior of states and maintaining international order.

INTL ST 146.name: Global Indigeneity
INTL ST 146.description: Situates the interdisciplinary fields of Native American and Indigenous Studies within a transnational context, focusing on the global dimensions of Indigeneity informing local histories, politics, and experiences. Examines settler colonialism, sovereignty, and the enduring legacies of colonialism as global phenomena.
INTL ST 146.restriction: Restriction: International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Minors have first consideration for enrollment.

INTL ST 147CW.name: International Humanitarianism
INTL ST 147CW.description: Examines, analyzes, and evaluates the humanitarian phenomenon, the actors involved in it (including states, international organizations (IOs), and nongovernmental organizations (NGOs)), the rise of a body of international humanitarian law, and the problems and debates associated with international humanitarianism today.
INTL ST 147CW.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

INTL ST 148W.name: Global Futures
INTL ST 148W.description: Develops critical insights into our collective future as it reflects different perspectives of the world. Topics include techno-orientalism, afro-futurism, feminist futures, indigenous cosmology, and environmental concerns.
INTL ST 148W.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
INTL ST 148W.restriction: Restriction: International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Minors have first consideration for enrollment.

INTL ST 150.name: Racism and Global Apartheid
INTL ST 150.description: The concept of race has been used to draw a global color line dividing rich from poor, developed from developing, first from third worlds. Racism is used to justify slavery, colonialism, imperialism, eugenics, genocide, and extreme inequalities produced by globalization.
INTL ST 150.restriction: Restriction: International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

INTL ST 151B.name: Religion and World Politics
INTL ST 151B.description: Examines the relationship between religion and world politics historically and today, focusing on connections with peace/war, democracy, human rights, secularism(s), and globalization. Covers major debates, scholarship, concepts, and theories through class exercises, exams, and essays.
INTL ST 151B.prereqString: Prerequisite: POL SCI 41A or INTL ST 11 or INTL ST 12 or REL STD 5A or REL STD 5B or REL STD 5C

INTL ST 152A.name: Non-Government Organization (NGO) Fundamentals
INTL ST 152A.description: Introduction to non-governmental organizations, including their role in U.S. society and the international community. Explores varying definitions of NGOs and the characteristics held in common by all NGOs.

INTL ST 153F.name: Militarism and Gender
INTL ST 153F.description: Examination of feminist approaches to militarism, war, and political violence

INTL ST 154W.name: Ethics and Justice in International Affairs
INTL ST 154W.description: Analyzes choices regarding the use of force, resolving conflict, and promoting human rights and social justice. Special attention is given to the American experience as a principal case study of ethics and statecraft.
INTL ST 154W.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
INTL ST 154W.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

INTL ST 155.name: Racial Capitalism
INTL ST 155.description: Explores the historical relationship between racism and capitalism. Social movements such as Black Lives Matter highlight the contemporary political economy of racial capitalism, and the relationship between domestic policing and international militarization as twin sides of global racial hegemony.
INTL ST 155.restriction: Restriction: International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Minors have first consideration for enrollment.

INTL ST 157C.name: Comparing European and US Societies
INTL ST 157C.description: Society, culture, institutions of U.S. and European countries. Fertility to football, guns to government, work to welfare, health to housework. Cross-national approaches for understanding the world and thinking critically about taken-for-granted practices. Policies the U.S. might borrow for social issues.

INTL ST 158B.name: Peoples of the Pacific
INTL ST 158B.description: The cultural history and recent developments among the Pacific peoples of Polynesia, Micronesia, Melanesia, New Guinea, and Australia.

INTL ST 158D.name: China in the Global Age
INTL ST 158D.description: Chinese society from 1949 to present. Social change in the context of political control and ideological considerations. Focus on the power structure, political decision processes, and ideological legitimation, and interplay with the Chinese community and its culture.

INTL ST 161A.name: Political Islam
INTL ST 161A.description: Political Islamd is a diverse phenomenon. While noticeable barriers exist to "Islamist democracy," it is the Islamists who will define the political future of much of the Muslim world. Reviews the experience of Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Pakistan, Turkey, and Indonesia.

INTL ST 162B.name: Peoples and Cultures of Post-Soviet Eurasia
INTL ST 162B.description: Examines the cultures and political conflicts of the more than 130 indigenous ethnic groups in the European and Asian territories of the former U.S.S.R. Emphasis is on the theoretical issues of ethnicity, nationalism, and conflict management.

INTL ST 163.name: Global Inequalities
INTL ST 163.description: An examination of various forms of social, economic, and political inequality within and between nations. Different approaches to understanding inequality and the intersections of poverty, race, ethnicity, class, gender, nationality, health, and violence.
INTL ST 163.restriction: Restriction: International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

INTL ST 165.name: Introduction to Contemporary Middle East Politics
INTL ST 165.description: An overview of basic issues that shape the politics of the Middle East and North Africa. Themes include implication of the colonization era, nation-state formation, inter-Arab relations, nationalism, Arab-Israel conflict, Islamic resurgence, and more.

INTL ST 175A.name: U.S. War on Terrorism
INTL ST 175A.description: Analyzes the United States war on terrorism by focusing on terrorism, the U.S. wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, and changes in police powers through the Patriot Act, as well as the political leadership which directs the war.

INTL ST 176C.name: Introduction to Chinese Politics
INTL ST 176C.description: Background to the Chinese revolution, rise of the communist party
INTL ST 176C.restriction: Restriction: Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

INTL ST 177C.name: Revolution in Latin America
INTL ST 177C.description: Presents a comparative analysis of the causes, development, and consequences of selected revolutionary movements, focusing on outbreaks in Mexico, Bolivia, Cuba, Chile, Nicaragua, and Grenada.  Explores topics of state formation, economic nationalism, social justice, ethnicity, and role of international affairs.

INTL ST 177D.name: U.S. Intervention in Latin America
INTL ST 177D.description: Explores political, economic, social, and cultural ties that bind Latin America to the United States. Focuses on U.S. intervention and Latin American response from early nineteenth century to present day. Case studies include Mexico, Guatemala, Cuba, Chile, and Central America.

INTL ST 177E.name: Cuban Society and Revolution
INTL ST 177E.description: Explores the causes, development, and legacy of the 1959 Revolution. Themes include economic dependency, democracy, race, gender, culture, and the always volatile relations between Cuba and the United States.

INTL ST 177G.name: Revolution and Reaction in Cold War Latin America
INTL ST 177G.description: Explores Latin American experiences of revolutionary change and military dictatorship during the Cold War (1945-1990). Pays particular attention to the lives of women, peasants, workers, and the urban middle classes. Case studies include Guatemala, Cuba, Chile, Argentina, Nicaragua, and Mexico.

INTL ST 177I.name: Ancient Civilization of Mexico and the Southwest
INTL ST 177I.description: The prehistory and cultural evolution of the civilization which originated in Mexico, including the Olmecs, Aztecs, Toltecs, Maya, and Zapotec, as well as the Pueblos of the Southwestern U.S. Topics include the origins of food production and of the state.

INTL ST 179.name: Special Topics: Geographic Focus in International Studies
INTL ST 179.description: Studies in selected areas of international studies. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

INTL ST H180.name: International Studies Honors Research Seminar
INTL ST H180.description: Assists students to prepare a thesis prospectus for the Honors Program in International Studies. Students choose a topic, learn writing and research methods, write a prospectus and orally present and defend it, and conduct a literature review.
INTL ST H180.restriction: Restriction: International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Science Honors students only.

INTL ST 183A.name: Global and International Studies Forum
INTL ST 183A.description: A faculty-student forum featuring lectures from a variety of institutions with discussion issues related to Global and International Studies.

INTL ST 183B.name: Seminar in Mediation
INTL ST 183B.description: Student develop mediation skills and refine knowledge in the practice and theory of conflict resolution. Students who complete this course may serve as mediators in the Campus Mediation Program. Course is a prerequisite to completing Indep Study as an intern.
INTL ST 183B.restriction: Restriction: International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment. School of Humanities students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Social Ecology students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Social Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment.

INTL ST 183CW.name: Seminar Conflict Resolution
INTL ST 183CW.description: Designed for seniors who are pursuing the minor in Conflict Resolution and/or International Studies major. Provides a forum in which students will refine skills and theory in the study of cooperation and conflict, from local to global arenas.
INTL ST 183CW.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

INTL ST 183E.name: Conflict Resolution in Cross-Cultural Perspective
INTL ST 183E.description: Examines theories of conflict management. Analyzes how conflict is mitigated in diverse cultures: at the interpersonal level, between groups, and on the international scale. Students discuss readings, hear from conflict management practitioners, and simulate negotiations.

INTL ST 189.name: Special Topics: Global Focus in International Studies
INTL ST 189.description: Studies in selected areas of international studies. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

INTL ST H190.name: Honors Thesis
INTL ST H190.description: Students work with faculty to complete their honors thesis.
INTL ST H190.restriction: Restriction: International Studies Honors students only.

INTL ST 199.name: Individual Study
INTL ST 199.description: Students participate in planned research and study under written contract with a supervising UCI instructor. Students may enroll for only one individual study course each quarter.

INTL ST 201.name: What is Global Studies?
INTL ST 201.description: Introduces graduates to the field of global and international studies. Landmark studies outline the transition from globalization studies to contemporary global studies. Identify complex global issues, underlying processes of globalization, and the impacts they have on people around the world.

INTL ST 202.name: Foundations of European Social Thought
INTL ST 202.description: Provides graduate students with a broad overview of the major landmarks in the development of modern social thought. Introduces key philosophers and theorists Adam Smith, Marx, Durkheim, Weber, Freud, and Du Bois, focusing on the global dimensions of their work.

INTL ST 203.name: Globalizing Social Theory in the Age of Extremes
INTL ST 203.description: Examines important developments in social theory between 1914 and 1991. The overarching goal is to synthesize from these various approaches a critical and transdisciplinary theoretical framework to analyze complex global issues.

INTL ST 204.name: Theories of Globalization
INTL ST 204.description: Theories of globalization engage deep historical transformations, keeping the interrelated dynamics of economics, politics, and culture in focus. Theories examine transformations emanating at transnational and state levels, and from below in the form of social movements led by everyday people.

INTL ST 205.name: Theories from the Global South
INTL ST 205.description: Looking beyond the theoretical traditions of the Euro-American academy scholars can begin to engage important theoretical contributions from the Global South. Explores alternative standpoints and interventions challenging dominant narratives and calling into question taken-for-granted assumptions, categories, concepts, values, and perspectives.

INTL ST 206.name: Engaging Global Issues
INTL ST 206.description: Critical and interdisciplinary works on global issues serve as examples that graduates can use in their own research. Each week focuses on a different example of outstanding global research done by a scholar having an important impact on the field.

INTL ST 207.name: Research Design and Methods
INTL ST 207.description: Fundamentals of empirical research design, strategies for global research, sampling logics, reliability, validity, mixed methods, integrating qualitative and quantitative methods. Introduction to basic data collection methods and examples of more advanced methodological strategies. Research ethics and the IRB review process.

INTL ST 208.name: Grant Writing
INTL ST 208.description: Focuses on production, critique, and revision of student research proposals. A practical seminar designed to improve student proposals, help students through the application processes, and increase students' chances of obtaining support for their research.

INTL ST 210A.name: Proseminar in Global Studies I
INTL ST 210A.description: Year-long intensive introduction to graduate students to a range of topics pertinent to the field of Global Studies. The guest speakers and topics addressed vary each quarter.

INTL ST 210B.name: Proseminar in Global Studies II
INTL ST 210B.description: Year-long intensive introduction to graduate students to a range of topics pertinent to the field of Global Studies. The guest speakers and topics addressed vary each quarter.

INTL ST 210C.name: Proseminar in Global Studies III
INTL ST 210C.description: Year-long intensive introduction to graduate students to a range of topics pertinent to the field of Global Studies. The guest speakers and topics addressed vary each quarter.

INTL ST 260.name: Directed Reading and Research
INTL ST 260.description: Readings focused on specialized topics in consultation with, and with the consent of, a faculty member. Students are expected to produce a paper based on the readings.

INTL ST 290.name: Dissertation Research
INTL ST 290.description: Dissertation research with Global and International Studies faculty.

INTL ST 299.name: Independent Study
INTL ST 299.description: Independent research with Global and International Studies faculty.

IRAN 231A.name: History of Zoroastrianism
IRAN 231A.description: Reviews major trends in the history of Zoroastrianism.

IRAN 231B.name: Ancient Persia
IRAN 231B.description: Survey of the history of Persia in antiquity.

IRAN 231C.name: Medieval Persia
IRAN 231C.description: A survey of Persian history in the context of Late Antique and Medieval Islamic history.

IRAN 255A.name: Ancient India
IRAN 255A.description: Examines the visual and religious history of the region defined as "India" today, but necessarily encompassing modern Bangladesh and Pakistan. Culminates with the supposed Golden Age of the Gupta empire and its far-reaching legacies.

IRAN 255B.name: Medieval India
IRAN 255B.description: Begins with the Gupta period's aesthetic legacies in South Asia's architecture, sculpture, and painting. Explores the dispersal of Islam throughout South Asia, including the Muslim communities of southern India.

IRAN 280.name: Studies in Old Iranian
IRAN 280.description: Studies in grammars and texts of Old Persian and Avestan.

IRAN 281.name: Studies in Middle Iranian
IRAN 281.description: Studies in grammars and texts of Middle Iranian languages (e.g., Middle Persian, Parthian, Sogdian, Bactrian).

IRAN 282.name: Studies in Classical Persian
IRAN 282.description: Studies in the premodern literatures and historical texts of medieval and early modern Persian.

IRAN 290.name: Special Topics in Premodern Iranian Studies
IRAN 290.description: Studies in selected areas of premodern Iranian Studies. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

IRAN 292.name: Seminar in Premodern Iranian Studies
IRAN 292.description: Seminar in selected areas of premodern Iranian Studies. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

IRAN 293.name: Directed Readings in Premodern Iranian Studies
IRAN 293.description: Directed reading on a specific topic agreed upon by student and instructor.

IRAN 294.name: Curatorial Methods
IRAN 294.description: Development of curatorial methodologies with an instructor in conjunction with curatorial internship or practicum.

IRAN 295.name: Special Methods
IRAN 295.description: Reading course focused on the development of particular research skills (e.g. archaeological field methods, numismatics, digital humanities) often in conjunction with a practicum.

IRAN 296.name: Ethics, Law, and Art
IRAN 296.description: Addresses a broad range of ethical and legal issues pertaining to art, ownership, looting and theft, museum policies, and cultural heritage.
IRAN 296.prereqString: Prerequisite: Background in Art History or Legal Studies.

ITALIAN 1A.name: Fundamentals of Italian
ITALIAN 1A.description: First quarter of first-year Italian in a hybrid or online format. Students are taught to conceptualize in Italian as they learn to understand, read, write, and speak. Classes are conducted entirely in Italian.

ITALIAN 1AB.name: Intensive Italian Fundamentals
ITALIAN 1AB.description: First half of first-year Italian in a time-intensive form. Development of meaningful communicative skills for the purposes of interaction with Italian speakers and beginning study of Italian. Learner-centered approach develops speaking, listening, reading, writing, and cultural skills and knowledge.
ITALIAN 1AB.restriction: Restriction: ITALIAN 1AB and ITALIAN 1A and ITALIAN 1B and ITALIAN S1AB may not be taken for full credit.

ITALIAN 1ABSP.name: Accelerated Fundamentals of Italian for Spanish Speakers
ITALIAN 1ABSP.description: Accelerated first half of first-year Italian for Hispanophone students. Teaches conceptualizing in Italian while learning to read, write, and speak using knowledge of Spanish. Develops awareness of and sensibility to Italian life and culture through reading, viewing, and discussing.
ITALIAN 1ABSP.prereqString: Prerequisite: Two years of high school Spanish, one semester of college Spanish, or heritage speaker of Spanish.

ITALIAN 1B.name: Fundamentals of Italian
ITALIAN 1B.description: Second quarter of first-year Italian in a hybrid or online format. Students are taught to conceptualize in Italian as they learn to understand, read, write, and speak. Classes are conducted entirely in Italian.
ITALIAN 1B.prereqString: Prerequisite: ITALIAN 1A. ITALIAN 1A with a grade of C or better. Placement into ITALIAN 1B is also accepted.

ITALIAN 1BC.name: Intensive Italian Fundamentals
ITALIAN 1BC.description: Second half of first-year Italian in a time-intensive form. Development of meaningful communicative skills for the purposes of interaction with Italian speakers and beginning study of Italian. Learner-centered approach develops speaking, listening, reading, writing, and cultural skills and knowledge.
ITALIAN 1BC.prereqString: Prerequisite: ITALIAN 1AB or ITALIAN S1AB or ITALIAN 1B. ITALIAN 1AB with a grade of C or better. ITALIAN S1AB with a grade of C or better. ITALIAN 1B with a grade of C or better. Placement into ITALIAN 1BC is also accepted.
ITALIAN 1BC.restriction: Restriction: ITALIAN 1AB and ITALIAN 1A and ITALIAN 1B and ITALIAN S1AB may not be taken for full credit.

ITALIAN 1BCSP.name: Accelerated Fundamentals of Italian for Spanish Speakers
ITALIAN 1BCSP.description: Accelerated second half of first-year Italian for Hispanophone students. Teaches conceptualizing in Italian while learning to read, write, and speak using knowledge of Spanish. Develops awareness of and sensibility to Italian life and culture through reading, viewing, and discussing.
ITALIAN 1BCSP.prereqString: Prerequisite: ITALIAN 1ABSP or ITALIAN 1AB or ITALIAN S1AB or ITALIAN 1B. ITALIAN 1ABSP with a grade of C or better. ITALIAN 1AB with a grade of C or better. ITALIAN S1AB with a grade of C or better. ITALIAN 1B with a grade of C or better. Two years of high school Spanish, one semester of college Spanish, or heritage speaker of Spanish.

ITALIAN 1C.name: Fundamentals of Italian
ITALIAN 1C.description: Third quarter of first-year Italian in a hybrid or online format. Students are taught to conceptualize in Italian as they learn to understand, read, write, and speak. Classes are conducted entirely in Italian.
ITALIAN 1C.prereqString: Prerequisite: ITALIAN 1B or ITALIAN 1AB or ITALIAN S1AB. ITALIAN 1B with a grade of C or better. ITALIAN 1AB with a grade of C or better. ITALIAN S1AB with a grade of C or better. Placement into ITALIAN 1C is also accepted.

ITALIAN 2A.name: Intermediate Italian
ITALIAN 2A.description: First quarter of second-year Italian in a hybrid format. Students are taught to conceptualize in Italian as they learn to understand, read, write, and speak. Classes are conducted entirely in Italian.
ITALIAN 2A.prereqString: Prerequisite: ITALIAN 1C or ITALIAN 1BC or ITALIAN S1BC or ITALIAN 1BCSP. ITALIAN 1C with a grade of C or better. ITALIAN 1BC with a grade of C or better. ITALIAN S1BC with a grade of C or better. ITALIAN 1BCSP with a grade of C or better. Placement into ITALIAN 2A is also accepted.
ITALIAN 2A.restriction: Restriction: School of Humanities students have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ITALIAN 2B.name: Intermediate Italian
ITALIAN 2B.description: Second quarter of second-year Italian in a hybrid format. Students are taught to conceptualize in Italian as they learn to understand, read, write, and speak. Classes are conducted entirely in Italian.
ITALIAN 2B.prereqString: Prerequisite: ITALIAN 2A. ITALIAN 2A with a grade of C or better. Placement into ITALIAN 2B is also accepted.
ITALIAN 2B.restriction: Restriction: School of Humanities students have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

ITALIAN 2C.name: Intermediate Italian
ITALIAN 2C.description: Third quarter of second-year Italian in a hybrid format. Students are taught to conceptualize in Italian as they learn to understand, read, write, and speak. Classes are conducted entirely in Italian.
ITALIAN 2C.prereqString: Prerequisite: ITALIAN 2B. ITALIAN 2B with a grade of C or better. Placement into 2C is also accepted.
ITALIAN 2C.restriction: Restriction: School of Humanities students have first consideration for enrollment.

ITALIAN 50.name: Topics in Italian Culture
ITALIAN 50.description: Examines Italian culture at home and from abroad, in cinema, literature, and popular culture.

ITALIAN 99.name: Special Studies in Italian
ITALIAN 99.description: Both student and instructor arrive at the theme of the course and the critical approach to be followed in consultation. Intended to offer courses in Italian otherwise unavailable.

ITALIAN 150.name: Topics in Italian Literature and Culture
ITALIAN 150.description: Major themes, periods, and/or movements in Italian literature and culture. Taught in English.

ITALIAN 199.name: Tutorial in Italian Literature and Culture
ITALIAN 199.description: The student must submit a written description of the proposed course to the instructor and the Chair prior to the beginning of the course.

JAPANSE 1A.name: Fundamental Japanese
JAPANSE 1A.description: Students develop listening, speaking, reading, and writing abilities in Japanese for meaningful communication. Content deals with daily life, society, and culture in Japan. Approximately 180 kanji (Chinese characters) are introduced in addition to the hiragana and katakana orthography.
JAPANSE 1A.prereqString: Prerequisite: Placement into JAPANSE 1A is accepted.
JAPANSE 1A.restriction: Restriction: JAPANSE 1A and JAPANSE S1AB may not be taken for full credit.

JAPANSE 1B.name: Fundamental Japanese
JAPANSE 1B.description: Students develop listening, speaking, reading, and writing abilities in Japanese for meaningful communication. Content deals with daily life, society, and culture in Japan. Approximately 180 kanji (Chinese characters) are introduced in addition to the hiragana and katakana orthography.
JAPANSE 1B.prereqString: Prerequisite: JAPANSE 1A or JAPANSE S1AB. JAPANSE 1A with a grade of C or better. JAPANSE S1AB with a grade of C or better. Placement into JAPANSE 1B is also accepted.
JAPANSE 1B.restriction: Restriction: JAPANSE 1B and JAPANSE S1AB and JAPANSE S1BC may not be taken for full credit.

JAPANSE 1C.name: Fundamental Japanese
JAPANSE 1C.description: Students develop listening, speaking, reading, and writing abilities in Japanese for meaningful communication. Content deals with daily life, society, and culture in Japan. Approximately 180 kanji (Chinese characters) are introduced in addition to the hiragana and katakana orthography.
JAPANSE 1C.prereqString: Prerequisite: JAPANSE 1B or JAPANSE S1AB. JAPANSE 1B with a grade of C or better. JAPANSE S1AB with a grade of C or better. Placement into JAPANSE 1C is also accepted.
JAPANSE 1C.restriction: Restriction: JAPANSE 1C and JAPANSE S1BC may not be taken for full credit.

JAPANSE S1AB.name: Fundamentals of Japanese
JAPANSE S1AB.description: First half of first-year Japanese in an intensified form.
JAPANSE S1AB.restriction: Restriction: JAPANSE S1AB and JAPANSE 1A and JAPANSE 1B may not be taken for full credit.

JAPANSE S1BC.name: Fundamentals of Japanese
JAPANSE S1BC.description: Second half of first-year Japanese in an intensified form.
JAPANSE S1BC.prereqString: Prerequisite: JAPANSE S1AB or JAPANSE 1B. JAPANSE S1AB with a grade of C or better. JAPANSE 1B with a grade of C or better. Placement into JAPANSE 1C is also accepted.
JAPANSE S1BC.restriction: Restriction: JAPANSE S1BC and JAPANSE 1B and JAPANSE 1C may not be taken for full credit.

JAPANSE 2A.name: Intermediate Japanese
JAPANSE 2A.description: Japanese listening, speaking, reading, and writing abilities developed for meaningful communication. Content deals with daily life, society, and culture, including social issues in Japan. Approximately 180 kanji (Chinese characters) are introduced in addition to the 180 characters learned in 1A-B-C.
JAPANSE 2A.prereqString: Prerequisite: JAPANSE 1C or JAPANSE S1BC. JAPANSE 1C with a grade of C or better. JAPANSE S1BC with a grade of C or better. Placement into JAPANSE 2A is also accepted.
JAPANSE 2A.restriction: Restriction: JAPANSE 2A and JAPANSE S2AB may not be taken for full credit.

JAPANSE 2B.name: Intermediate Japanese
JAPANSE 2B.description: Japanese listening, speaking, reading, and writing abilities developed for meaningful communication. Content deals with daily life, society, and culture, including social issues in Japan. Approximately 180 kanji (Chinese characters) are introduced in addition to the 180 characters learned in 1A-B-C.
JAPANSE 2B.prereqString: Prerequisite: JAPANSE 2A. JAPANSE 2A with a grade of C or better. Placement into JAPANSE 2B is also accepted.
JAPANSE 2B.restriction: Restriction: JAPANSE 2B and JAPANSE S2AB and JAPANSE S2BC may not be taken for full credit.

JAPANSE 2C.name: Intermediate Japanese
JAPANSE 2C.description: Japanese listening, speaking, reading, and writing abilities developed for meaningful communication. Content deals with daily life, society, and culture, including social issues in Japan. Approximately 180 kanji (Chinese characters) are introduced in addition to the 180 characters learned in 1A-B-C.
JAPANSE 2C.prereqString: Prerequisite: JAPANSE 2B or JAPANSE S2AB. JAPANSE 2B with a grade of C or better. JAPANSE S2AB with a grade of C or better. Placement into JAPANSE 2C is also accepted.
JAPANSE 2C.restriction: Restriction: JAPANSE 2C and JAPANSE S2BC may not be taken for full credit.

JAPANSE S2AB.name: Intermediate Japanese
JAPANSE S2AB.description: First half of second-year Japanese in an intensified form.
JAPANSE S2AB.prereqString: Prerequisite: JAPANSE 1C or JAPANSE S1BC. JAPANSE 1C with a grade of C or better. JAPANSE S1BC with a grade of C or better. Placement into JAPANSE 2A is also accepted.
JAPANSE S2AB.restriction: Restriction: JAPANSE S2AB and JAPANSE 2A and JAPANSE 2B may not be taken for full credit.

JAPANSE S2BC.name: Intermediate Japanese
JAPANSE S2BC.description: Second half of second-year Japanese in an intensified form.
JAPANSE S2BC.prereqString: Prerequisite: JAPANSE S2AB or JAPANSE 2B. JAPANSE S2AB with a grade of C or better. JAPANSE 2B with a grade of C or better. Placement into JAPANSE 2C is also accepted.
JAPANSE S2BC.restriction: Restriction: JAPANSE S2BC and JAPANSE 2B and JAPANSE 2C may not be taken for full credit.

JAPANSE 3A.name: Advanced Japanese
JAPANSE 3A.description: Students are taught to conceptualize in Japanese as they learn to understand, read, write, and speak. Authentic Japanese texts are used. Approximately 360 kanji (Chinese characters) in addition to the 270 characters learned in 1A-B-C and 2A-B-C are introduced.
JAPANSE 3A.prereqString: Prerequisite: JAPANSE 2C or JAPANSE S2BC or placement into JAPANSE 3A. JAPANSE 2C with a grade of C or better. JAPANSE S2BC with a grade of C or better.

JAPANSE 3B.name: Advanced Japanese
JAPANSE 3B.description: Students are taught to conceptualize in Japanese as they learn to understand, read, write, and speak. Authentic Japanese texts are used. Approximately 360 kanji (Chinese characters) in addition to the 270 characters learned in 1A-B-C and 2A-B-C are introduced.
JAPANSE 3B.prereqString: Prerequisite: JAPANSE 3A. JAPANSE 3A with a grade of C or better. Placement into JAPANSE 3B is also accepted.

JAPANSE 3C.name: Advanced Japanese
JAPANSE 3C.description: Students are taught to conceptualize in Japanese as they learn to understand, read, write, and speak. Authentic Japanese texts are used. Approximately 360 kanji (Chinese characters) in addition to the 270 characters learned in first and second year are introduced.
JAPANSE 3C.prereqString: Prerequisite: JAPANSE 3B. JAPANSE 3B with a grade of C or better. Placement into JAPANSE 3C is also accepted.
JAPANSE 3C.restriction: Restriction: Japanese Language Literature Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

JAPANSE 100A.name: Classical Japanese
JAPANSE 100A.description: Introduction to classical Japanese grammar and vocabulary with emphasis on reading and analysis of basic texts.
JAPANSE 100A.prereqString: Prerequisite: JAPANSE 3C. JAPANSE 3C with a grade of C or better

JAPANSE 100B.name: Classical Japanese
JAPANSE 100B.description: Introduction to classical Japanese grammar and vocabulary with emphasis on reading and analysis of basic texts.
JAPANSE 100B.prereqString: Prerequisite: JAPANSE 100A. JAPANSE 100A with a grade of C or better

JAPANSE 101A.name: Fourth Year Japanese
JAPANSE 101A.description: Continued emphasis on comprehension, grammar, and proficiency in reading, composition, and conversation through intensive study and analysis of a variety of texts.

JAPANSE 101B.name: Fourth Year Japanese
JAPANSE 101B.description: Continued emphasis on comprehension, grammar, and proficiency in reading, composition, and conversation through intensive study and analysis of a variety of texts.

JAPANSE 115.name: Japanese Literature: Advanced Texts
JAPANSE 115.description: Designed for students with near-fluency in reading Japanese. Texts include both fiction and nonfiction by important writers, and may be supplemented and contextualized where needed by literary criticism and cultural-studies texts in English.
JAPANSE 115.prereqString: Prerequisite: JAPANSE 101A or JAPANSE 101B or JAPANSE 101C

JAPANSE 180.name: Topics in Japanese Literature
JAPANSE 180.description: Special topics through directed reading in Japanese. Paper required.
JAPANSE 180.prereqString: Prerequisite: JAPANSE 3C. JAPANSE 3C with a grade of C or better

JAPANSE 199.name: Independent Study
JAPANSE 199.description: Investigation of special topics through directed reading in Japanese. Paper required.

JAPANSE 201.name: Readings in Traditional Japanese Prose
JAPANSE 201.description: Close reading of selected premodern prose texts, including tales, journals, travel journals, essays.

JAPANSE 202.name: Readings in Traditional Japanese Poetry or Drama
JAPANSE 202.description: Close reading of selected premodern poetic or dramatic texts.

JAPANSE 203.name: Readings in Modern Japanese Literature
JAPANSE 203.description: Texts include both fiction and nonfiction by important writers, and may be supplemented where needed by literary criticism and cultural-studies texts in English.

JAPANSE 204.name: Readings in Traditional Japanese Literary and Cultural Theory
JAPANSE 204.description: Close reading of selected texts involving literary criticism and/or aesthetics.

JAPANSE 205.name: Readings in Japanese Religion
JAPANSE 205.description: Close readings of selected Japanese religious texts.

JAPANSE 211A.name: Studies in Traditional Japanese Prose
JAPANSE 211A.description: Studies in selected areas of traditional Japanese prose. Topics addressed vary each quarter. Research paper required.

JAPANSE 211B.name: Studies in Traditional Japanese Prose
JAPANSE 211B.description: Studies in selected areas of traditional Japanese prose. Topics addressed vary each quarter. Research paper required.

JAPANSE 212A.name: Studies in Traditional Japanese Poetry or Drama
JAPANSE 212A.description: Studies in selected areas of traditional Japanese poetry or drama. Topics addressed vary each quarter. Research paper required.

JAPANSE 212B.name: Studies in Traditional Japanese Poetry or Drama
JAPANSE 212B.description: Studies in selected areas of traditional Japanese poetry or drama. Topics addressed vary each quarter. Research paper required.

JAPANSE 213A.name: Studies in Modern Japanese Literature
JAPANSE 213A.description: A two-quarter, in-depth look at a major author and/or issue in modern Japanese literature. Seminar format. The first quarter is devoted to reading of the requisite texts

JAPANSE 213B.name: Studies in Modern Japanese Literature
JAPANSE 213B.description: A two-quarter, in-depth look at a major author and/or issue in modern Japanese literature. Seminar format. The first quarter is devoted to reading of the requisite texts

JAPANSE 214.name: Studies in Japanese Literary and Cultural Theory
JAPANSE 214.description: Studies in selected areas of Japanese literary and cultural theory. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

JAPANSE 215.name: Studies in Japanese Religion
JAPANSE 215.description: Studies in selected areas of Japanese religion. Topics addressed vary each quarter. Research paper required.

JAPANSE 230.name: Topics in Japanese Literature and Culture
JAPANSE 230.description: A topical study that addresses important issues in Japanese literature and culture. May focus on a specific writer or writers, or on a specific issue or set of related issues.

JAPANSE 290.name: Independent Study
JAPANSE 290.description: Directed research on topic determined in consultation with faculty member. A term paper or project is required.

JAPANSE 299.name: Dissertation Research
JAPANSE 299.description: For Students who have been admitted to doctoral candidacy.

KOREAN 1A.name: Fundamental Korean
KOREAN 1A.description: Natural approach with emphasis on the four fundamental skills of listening, speaking, reading, and writing for students with no previous background in Korean. Conducted in both English and Korean.
KOREAN 1A.restriction: Restriction: KOREAN 1A and KOREAN 1KA and KOREAN S1AB may not be taken for full credit.

KOREAN 1B.name: Fundamental Korean
KOREAN 1B.description: Natural approach with emphasis on the four fundamental skills of listening, speaking, reading, and writing for students with no previous background in Korean. Conducted in both English and Korean.
KOREAN 1B.prereqString: Prerequisite: KOREAN 1A. KOREAN 1A with a grade of C or better. Placement into KOREAN 1B is also accepted.
KOREAN 1B.restriction: Restriction: KOREAN 1B and KOREAN 1KB and KOREAN S1AB and KOREAN S1BC may not be taken for full credit.

KOREAN 1C.name: Fundamental Korean
KOREAN 1C.description: Natural approach with emphasis on the four fundamental skills of listening, speaking, reading, and writing for students with no previous background in Korean. Conducted in both English and Korean.
KOREAN 1C.prereqString: Prerequisite: KOREAN 1B or KOREAN S1AB. KOREAN 1B with a grade of C or better. KOREAN S1AB with a grade of C or better. Placement into KOREAN 1C is also accepted.
KOREAN 1C.restriction: Restriction: KOREAN 1C and KOREAN 1KC and KOREAN S1BC may not be taken for full credit.

KOREAN 1KA.name: Fundamental Korean for Students with a Previous Background in Korean
KOREAN 1KA.description: Natural approach with emphasis on the four fundamental skills of listening, speaking, reading, and writing for students with a previous background in Korean. Conducted in both English and Korean.
KOREAN 1KA.restriction: Restriction: KOREAN 1KA and KOREAN 1A and KOREAN S1AB may not be taken for full credit.

KOREAN 1KB.name: Fundamental Korean for Students with a Previous Background in Korean
KOREAN 1KB.description: Natural approach with emphasis on the four fundamental skills of listening, speaking, reading, and writing for students with a previous background in Korean. Conducted in both English and Korean.
KOREAN 1KB.prereqString: Prerequisite: KOREAN 1KA. KOREAN 1KA with a grade of C or better. Placement into KOREAN 1KB is also accepted.
KOREAN 1KB.restriction: Restriction: KOREAN 1KB and KOREAN 1B and KOREAN S1AB and KOREAN S1BC may not be taken for full credit.

KOREAN 1KC.name: Fundamental Korean for Students with a Previous Background in Korean
KOREAN 1KC.description: Natural approach with emphasis on the four fundamental skills of listening, speaking, reading, and writing for students with a previous background in Korean. Conducted in both English and Korean.
KOREAN 1KC.prereqString: Prerequisite: KOREAN 1KB. KOREAN 1KB with a grade of C or better. Placement into KOREAN 1KC is also accepted.
KOREAN 1KC.restriction: Restriction: KOREAN 1KC and KOREAN 1C and KOREAN S1BC may not be taken for full credit.

KOREAN S1AB.name: Fundamentals of Korean
KOREAN S1AB.description: First half of first-year Korean in an intensified form.
KOREAN S1AB.prereqString: Prerequisite: Placement into KOREAN 1A or KOREAN 1KA or KOREAN 1B or KOREAN 1KB.
KOREAN S1AB.restriction: Restriction: KOREAN S1AB and KOREAN 1A and KOREAN 1KA and KOREAN 1B and KOREAN 1KB may not be taken for full credit.

KOREAN S1BC.name: Fundamentals of Korean
KOREAN S1BC.description: Second half of first-year Korean in an intensified form.
KOREAN S1BC.prereqString: Prerequisite: KOREAN S1AB or KOREAN 1B or KOREAN 1KB. KOREAN S1AB with a grade of C or better. KOREAN 1B with a grade of C or better. KOREAN 1KB with a grade of C or better. Pacement into KOREAN 1C or KOREAN 1KC is also accepted.
KOREAN S1BC.restriction: Restriction: KOREAN S1BC and KOREAN 1B and KOREAN 1KB and KOREAN 1C and KOREAN 1KC may not be taken for full credit.

KOREAN 2A.name: Intermediate Korean
KOREAN 2A.description: Designed to develop writing and reading skills as well as communicative skills in authentic situations for students without previous initial background in Korean. Students also introduced to aspects of Korean culture as related to lesson topics and basic Chinese characters.
KOREAN 2A.prereqString: Prerequisite: KOREAN 1C or KOREAN S1BC. KOREAN 1C with a grade of C or better. KOREAN S1BC with a grade of C or better. Placement into KOREAN 2A is also accepted.

KOREAN 2B.name: Intermediate Korean
KOREAN 2B.description: Designed to develop writing and reading skills as well as communicative skills in authentic situations for students without previous initial background in Korean. Students also introduced to aspects of Korean culture as related to lesson topics and basic Chinese characters.
KOREAN 2B.prereqString: Prerequisite: KOREAN 2A. KOREAN 2A with a grade of C or better. Placement into KOREAN 2B is also accepted.

KOREAN 2C.name: Intermediate Korean
KOREAN 2C.description: Designed to develop writing and reading skills as well as communicative skills in authentic situations for students without previous initial background in Korean. Students also introduced to aspects of Korean culture as related to lesson topics and basic Chinese characters.
KOREAN 2C.prereqString: Prerequisite: KOREAN 2B. KOREAN 2B with a grade of C or better. Placement into KOREAN 2C is also accepted.

KOREAN 2KA.name: Intermediate Korean for Students with a Previous Background in Korean
KOREAN 2KA.description: Designed to develop writing and reading skills as well as communicative skills in authentic situations for students with previous background in Korean. Students also introduced to aspects of Korean culture as related to lesson topics and basic Chinese characters.
KOREAN 2KA.prereqString: Prerequisite: KOREAN 1KC or KOREAN S1BC. KOREAN 1KC with a grade of C or better. KOREAN S1BC with a grade of C or better. Placement into KOREAN 2KA is also accepted.

KOREAN 2KB.name: Intermediate Korean for Students with a Previous Background in Korean
KOREAN 2KB.description: Designed to develop writing and reading skills as well as communicative skills in authentic situations for students with previous background in Korean. Students also introduced to aspects of Korean culture as related to lesson topics and basic Chinese characters.
KOREAN 2KB.prereqString: Prerequisite: KOREAN 2KA. KOREAN 2KA with a grade of C or better. Placement into KOREAN 2KB is also accepted.

KOREAN 2KC.name: Intermediate Korean for Students with a Previous Background in Korean
KOREAN 2KC.description: Designed to develop writing and reading skills as well as communicative skills in authentic situations for students with previous background in Korean. Students also introduced to aspects of Korean culture as related to lesson topics and basic Chinese characters.
KOREAN 2KC.prereqString: Prerequisite: KOREAN 2KB. KOREAN 2KB with a grade of C or better. Placement into KOREAN 2KC is also accepted.

KOREAN 3A.name: Advanced Korean
KOREAN 3A.description: Focuses on developing advanced reading/writing and translation skills with additional instruction in Chinese characters.
KOREAN 3A.prereqString: Prerequisite: KOREAN 2C or KOREAN 2KC or KOREAN S2BC. KOREAN 2C with a grade of C or better. KOREAN 2KC with a grade of C or better. KOREAN S2BC with a grade of C or better. Placement into KOREAN 3A is also accepted.

KOREAN 3B.name: Advanced Korean
KOREAN 3B.description: Focuses on developing advanced reading, writing, and translation skills.
KOREAN 3B.prereqString: Prerequisite: KOREAN 3A or KOREAN 2C or KOREAN 2KC or KOREAN S2BC. KOREAN 3A with a grade of C or better. KOREAN 2C with a grade of C or better. KOREAN 2KC with a grade of C or better. KOREAN S2BC with a grade of C or better. Placement into KOREAN 3B is also accepted.

KOREAN 3C.name: Advanced Korean
KOREAN 3C.description: Focuses on developing advanced reading, writing, and translation skills.
KOREAN 3C.prereqString: Prerequisite: KOREAN 2C or KOREAN 2KC or KOREAN S2BC or KOREAN 3A or KOREAN 3B. KOREAN 2C with a grade of C or better. KOREAN 2KC with a grade of C or better. KOREAN S2BC with a grade of C or better. KOREAN 3A with a grade of C or better. KOREAN 3B with a grade of C or better. Placement into KOREAN 3C is also accepted.

KOREAN 101A.name: Fourth-Year Korean
KOREAN 101A.description: Continued emphasis on comprehension, grammar, and proficiency in reading, composition, and conversation through intensive study and analysis of a variety of modern texts.
KOREAN 101A.prereqString: Prerequisite: KOREAN 3A or KOREAN 3B or KOREAN 3C. KOREAN 3A with a grade of C or better. KOREAN 3B with a grade of C or better. KOREAN 3C with a grade of C or better

KOREAN 115.name: Korean Literature: Advanced Texts
KOREAN 115.description: Designed for students with near-fluency in reading Korean. Readings include modern Korean literary works (poetry, prose, and drama) by important writers. Emphasis is on the interpretation of the texts and writings that interpret those texts in the original language.
KOREAN 115.prereqString: Prerequisite: KOREAN 101A or KOREAN 101B or KOREAN 101C

KOREAN 199.name: Independent Study
KOREAN 199.description: Investigation of special topics through directed reading in Korean. Paper required.

LATIN 1A.name: Fundamentals of Latin
LATIN 1A.description: Elements of Latin grammar, syntax, and vocabulary.
LATIN 1A.restriction: Restriction: LATIN 1A and LATIN S1AB may not be taken for full credit.

LATIN 1B.name: Fundamentals of Latin
LATIN 1B.description: Elements of Latin grammar, syntax, and vocabulary.
LATIN 1B.prereqString: Prerequisite: LATIN 1A. LATIN 1A with a grade of C or better
LATIN 1B.restriction: Restriction: LATIN 1B and LATIN S1AB and LATIN S1BC may not be taken for full credit.

LATIN 1C.name: Fundamentals of Latin
LATIN 1C.description: Introduction to reading texts, including study of the poetry of Catullus and selected readings.
LATIN 1C.prereqString: Prerequisite: LATIN 1B. LATIN 1B with a grade of C or better
LATIN 1C.restriction: Restriction: LATIN 1C and LATIN S1BC may not be taken for full credit.

LATIN 99.name: Special Studies in Latin
LATIN 99.description: Lower-division level independent research with Latin faculty.

LATIN 100.name: Topics in Classical Latin
LATIN 100.description: Selected readings in Classical Latin prose and poetry. Authors may include Cicero, Caesar, Ovid, Catullus, and others. Selections from prose and poetry will be read each quarter. Grammar and syntax review included.
LATIN 100.prereqString: Prerequisite: LATIN 1C. LATIN 1C with a grade of C or better. Placement into Latin 100 is also accepted.

LATIN 103.name: Seminar in Latin Prose
LATIN 103.description: Specialized and focused study of a particular Latin prose author or topic.

LATIN 104.name: Seminar in Latin Poetry
LATIN 104.description: Specialized and focused study of a particular topic or author in Latin poetry.

LATIN 198.name: Directed Group Study
LATIN 198.description: Special topics in Roman culture and civilization through directed reading and research.

LINGUIS 150.name: Acquisition of Language II
LINGUIS 150.description: Focuses on native language learning, exploring the way in which infants and very young children unconsciously uncover the rich systematic knowledge of their native language. Examines both experimental and computational studies that quantitatively investigate the "how" of language acquisition.
LINGUIS 150.restriction: Restriction: Cognitive Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

LIT JRN 20.name: Introduction to Literary Journalism
LIT JRN 20.description: Reading of selected texts to explore the ways in which literary journalism and related nonfiction modes formulate experience. Students complete a range of writing projects.
LIT JRN 20.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
LIT JRN 20.restriction: Restriction: Literary Journalism Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

LIT JRN 21.name: Reporting for Literary Journalism
LIT JRN 21.description: Instruction and hands-on training in how to interview, report, research, and collect the types of information needed to write literary journalism.
LIT JRN 21.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
LIT JRN 21.restriction: Restriction: Literary Journalism Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

LIT JRN 100.name: Advanced Reporting
LIT JRN 100.description: Practical engagement with advanced reporting techniques of Literary Journalism, emphasizing the importance of thorough and effective research in the production of high-quality journalistic writing. Prepares students to make good decisions about where and how to publish their writing.

LIT JRN 101A.name: Studies in the History, Theory, and Ethics of Literary Journalism
LIT JRN 101A.description: Lectures and discussion on topics that explore the historical and theoretical dimensions of literary journalism, with particular emphasis on the evolution of ethics in the field.
LIT JRN 101A.prereqString: Prerequisite: LIT JRN 21 and LIT JRN 20 and (COM LIT 60A or COM LIT 60C or ENGLISH 8 or ENGLISH 9 or ENGLISH 10 or ENGLISH 11 or ENGLISH 12 or ENGLISH 15 or ENGLISH 16 or ENGLISH 17)

LIT JRN 101BW.name: Literary Journalism Core Writing Workshop
LIT JRN 101BW.description: Writing workshops in announced specialized genres that students will both study and practice. Examples include "The Memoir," "Review Writing," "The Editorial," "Writing Biography," "The Profile," and "Political Writing.".
LIT JRN 101BW.prereqString: Prerequisite: LIT JRN 101A. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
LIT JRN 101BW.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. Students may enroll in one LITJ 101BW course per quarter.

LIT JRN 103.name: Lectures on Topics in Literary Journalism
LIT JRN 103.description: A series of lectures on, and discussions of, announced topics in literary journalism and the literature of fact. Examples include "Travel Literary Journalism"
LIT JRN 103.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

LIT JRN 197.name: Community Reporting
LIT JRN 197.description: Directed group study in which students work with an instructor to report and write about community news in a newsroom-style format.  Students will partner with local publications to pitch, market, and publish their stories.
