LIT JRN 197.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of lower-division writing requirement.

LIT JRN 198.name: Special Topics
LIT JRN 198.description: Directed group study of selected topics.

LIT JRN 199.name: Reading and Conference
LIT JRN 199.description: To be taken only when the materials to be studied lie outside the normal run of departmental offerings.

LPS 29.name: Critical Reasoning
LPS 29.description: Introduction to analysis and reasoning. The concepts of argument, premise, and conclusion, validity and invalidity, consistency and inconsistency. Identifying and assessing premises and inferences. Deductive versus inductive reasoning, and introduction to the probability calculus. Evaluating definitions. Informal fallacies.

LPS 30.name: Introduction to Symbolic Logic
LPS 30.description: An introduction to the symbolism and methods of the logic of statements, including evaluation of arguments by truth tables, the techniques of natural deduction, and semantic tableaux.

LPS 31.name: Introduction to Inductive Logic
LPS 31.description: Philosophical questions concerning the foundations of scientific inference, e.g., the traditional problem of induction, the Goodman paradox, the concept of cause, Mill's method of inductive reasoning, probability calculus, different interpretations of probability, and their interaction in inductive reasoning.

LPS 40.name: The Nature of Scientific Inquiry
LPS 40.description: Investigates the nature, scope, and status of scientific knowledge and the methods used to acquire it. Uses concrete historical examples from a variety of scientific fields to identify distinctive features of the scientific enterprise and explore their significance.

LPS 60.name: The Making of Modern Science
LPS 60.description: Surveys the history of science and mathematics since the Scientific Revolution, examining central developments both chronologically and thematically, as well as investigating their significance for contemporary philosophical debates about the role and status of current scientific theories.

LPS H80.name: Scientific Realism and Instrumentalism
LPS H80.description: Explores competing views of the character and status of theoretical knowledge in science, including challenges to and defenses of the view that contemporary scientific theories offer straightforward and accurate descriptions of how things stand in otherwise inaccessible domains of nature.
LPS H80.restriction: Restriction: Campuswide Honors Collegium students only.

LPS H81.name: What is Space?
LPS H81.description: Historical, philosophical, scientific exploration of the concept of "space." Questions of interest include: What kind of a thing is space? How can we know what space is like? How is space different from time.
LPS H81.restriction: Restriction: Campuswide Honors Collegium students only.

LPS 91.name: The Philosophy of Sex
LPS 91.description: Discusses the origins of biological sex, dynamics of sexual selection, sex differences in humans, and the construction of gender in human societies. Seeks to understand the role social values play in the creation of science.

LPS H91.name: The Philosophy and Biology of Sex
LPS H91.description: Covers the origins of biological sex, dynamics of sexual selection, the evolution and cultural creation of sexual behavior in humans, and the construction of gender in human societies.
LPS H91.restriction: Restriction: Campuswide Honors Collegium students only.

LPS H95.name: Jurisprudence and Constitutional Law
LPS H95.description: Applies competing theories of the nature of law and legal reasoning to evaluate decisions of the U.S. Supreme Court in controversial areas of constitutional law such as free speech, privacy, sexual conduct, affirmative action, and political campaign contributions.
LPS H95.restriction: Restriction: Campuswide Honors Collegium students only.

LPS 100W.name: Writing Philosophy
LPS 100W.description: Discussion of those aspects of writing of special importance in philosophy, e.g., philosophical terminology, techniques for evaluating arguments, philosophical definitions and theories. At least 4,000 words of assigned composition based on philosophical readings.
LPS 100W.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

LPS 104.name: Introduction to Logic
LPS 104.description: Introduction to sentence logic, including truth tables and natural deduction

LPS 105A.name: Elementary Set Theory
LPS 105A.description: An introduction to the basic working vocabulary of mathematical reasoning. Topics include sets, Boolean operations, ordered n-tuples, relations, functions, ordinal and cardinal numbers.

LPS 105B.name: Metalogic
LPS 105B.description: Introduction to formal syntax (proof theory) and semantics (model theory) for first-order logic, including the deduction, completeness, compactness, and Löewenheim-Skolem theorems.
LPS 105B.prereqString: Prerequisite: LSCI 145A or LPS 105A or PHIL 105A

LPS 105C.name: Undecidability and Incompleteness
LPS 105C.description: Introduction to the formal theory of effective processes, including recursive functions, Turing machines, Church's thesis, and proofs of Göedel's incompleteness theorem for arithmetic, and Church's undecidability theorem for first-order logic.
LPS 105C.prereqString: Prerequisite: LSCI 145B or LPS 105B or PHIL 105B

LPS 106.name: Topics in Logic
LPS 106.description: Selected topics in mathematical or philosophical logic.

LPS 108.name: Topics in Induction, Probability, and Decision Theory
LPS 108.description: Selected topics in induction, probability, and decision theory.

LPS 113.name: Topics in Modern Philosophy
LPS 113.description: Focuses on the works of central philosophical figures of modern Philosophy (e.g., Descartes, Leibniz, Hobbes, Locke, Hume, Kant) or on the treatment of one or more central philosophical problems by a number of these figures.

LPS 115.name: Topics in History of Analytic Philosophy
LPS 115.description: Review of central theories or figures in the history of analytic philosophy. Emphasis on writings of Frege, Russell, Schlick, Carnap, and Quine. Topics include the nature of meaning and truth, the synthetic/analytic distinction, and scientific knowledge.

LPS 120.name: Topics in Metaphysics
LPS 120.description: Examines central philosophical questions concerning our own fundamental nature and that of the world around us (e.g., causation and necessity, determination, free will, personal identity, the mind-body problem).

LPS 121.name: Topics in the Theory of Knowledge
LPS 121.description: One or more topics in the theory of knowledge, e.g., the nature of rational justification, of perceptual knowledge, of a priori knowledge.

LPS H123.name: What is Disease?
LPS H123.description: Explores philosophical issues associated with scientific efforts to understand and explain disease.
LPS H123.restriction: Restriction: Campuswide Honors Collegium students only.

LPS H125.name: What Is Time?
LPS H125.description: Engages the question "what is time?" by drawing on physics, philosophy, fiction, film, and psychology. Organized around understanding and addressing the tension between time as represented in physics and our immediate temporal experience.
LPS H125.restriction: Restriction: Campuswide Honors Collegium students only.

LPS 140.name: Topics in Philosophy of Science
LPS 140.description: Selected topics in contemporary philosophy of science, e.g., the status of theoretical entities, the confirmation of theories, the nature of scientific explanation.

LPS 141B.name: Geometry and Spacetime
LPS 141B.description: An examination of the foundations of the special theory of relativity, with emphasis on the geometry of Minkowski spacetime, and its relation to both Euclidean and non-Euclidean (hyperbolic) plane geometries.

LPS 141D.name: Probability and Determinism
LPS 141D.description: An examination of a cluster of interrelated issues concerning probability, determinism, logic, and the foundations of quantum mechanics.

LPS H141.name: Honors Philosophy of Quantum Mechanics
LPS H141.description: An examination of the standard von Neumann-Dirac formulation of quantum mechanics. The quantum measurement problem is discussed along with several proposed solutions, including GRW, many-worlds, man-minds, and Bohm's theory.
LPS H141.restriction: Restriction: Campuswide Honors Collegium students only.

LPS 142W.name: Writing/Philosophy of Biology
LPS 142W.description: Philosophy of biology, e.g., scientific method in biology, the structure of evolutionary theory, teleology, ethics, and evolution. Course work includes one 4,000-word and four 1,000-word papers.
LPS 142W.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

LPS 143.name: Topics in Philosophy of Psychology
LPS 143.description: Selected topics in the philosophy of psychology, e.g., the nature of psychological explanation, reductionism, issues in cognitive, behavioral, and neuroscience.
LPS 143.restriction: Restriction: Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Philosophy Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

LPS 144.name: Topics in Philosophy of Social Science
LPS 144.description: Selected topics in the philosophy of the social sciences, e.g., Is their goal to understand behavior or to predict and control it?

LPS 145.name: Topics in Philosophy of Language
LPS 145.description: Selected topics in the philosophy of language, e.g., the nature of meaning, mechanisms of reference, speech acts.

LPS 147.name: Topics in Philosophy of Mathematics
LPS 147.description: Selected historical and contemporary topics in the philosophy of mathematics, e.g., mathematical truth and ontology, mathematical knowledge, the nature and role of proof, the workings of mathematics in application.

LPS 199.name: Independent Study
LPS 199.description: Independent research with Logic and Philosophy of Science faculty.

LPS 205A.name: Set Theory
LPS 205A.description: The basic working vocabulary of mathematical reasoning. Topics include: sets, Boolean operations, ordered n-tuples, relations, functions, ordinal and cardinal numbers.

LPS 205B.name: Metalogic
LPS 205B.description: Formal syntax (proof theory) and semantics (model theory) for first-order logic, including the deduction, completeness, compactness, and Loewenheim-Skolem theorems.

LPS 205C.name: Undecidability and Incompleteness
LPS 205C.description: Formal theory of effective processes, including recursive function, Turing machines, Church's thesis, proofs of Goedel's incompleteness theorem for arithmetics, and Church's undecidability for first-order logic.

LPS 206.name: Topics in Logic
LPS 206.description: Studies in selected areas of logic. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

LPS 213.name: Topics in Modern Philosophy
LPS 213.description: Studies in selected areas of modern philosophy.  Topics addressed vary each quarter.

LPS 215.name: Topics in Analytic Philosophy
LPS 215.description: Studies in selected areas of analytic philosophy.  Topics addressed vary each quarter.

LPS 220.name: Topics in Metaphysics
LPS 220.description: Studies in selected areas of metaphysics. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

LPS 221.name: Topics in Epistemology
LPS 221.description: Studies in selected areas of epistemology. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

LPS 221A.name: Medical Epistemology
LPS 221A.description: Analysis of epistemological issues concerning medical research and healthcare. Topics may include medical evidence, transmission of medical knowledge in the doctor-patient interaction, medical expertise, epistemology of medical disagreement, classification of illness, well-being, philosophy of pain, or medical decision making.

LPS 232.name: Topics in Political and Social Philosophy
LPS 232.description: Studies in selected areas of political and social philosophy. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

LPS 240.name: Topics in Philosophy of Science
LPS 240.description: Studies in selected areas of philosophy of science. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

LPS 241.name: Topics in Philosophy of Physics
LPS 241.description: Studies in selected areas of philosophy of physics. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

LPS 242.name: Topics in Philosophy of Biology
LPS 242.description: Studies in selected areas of philosophy of biology. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

LPS 243.name: Topics in Philosophy of Psychology
LPS 243.description: Selected topics in the philosophy of psychology, e.g., the nature of psychological explanation, reductionism, issues in cognitive, behavioral, and neuroscience.

LPS 244.name: Topics in Philosophy of Social Science
LPS 244.description: Studies in selected areas of philosophy and social science. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

LPS 245.name: Topics in Philosophy of Language
LPS 245.description: Studies in selected areas of philosophy of language. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

LPS 246.name: Topics in Philosophy of Logic
LPS 246.description: Studies in selected areas of philosophy of logic. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

LPS 247.name: Topics in Philosophy of Mathematics
LPS 247.description: Studies in selected areas of philosophy of mathematics. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

LPS 289.name: Logic and Philosophy of Science Workshop
LPS 289.description: A two- or three-quarter-long workshop on selected topics in logic and philosophy of science.

LPS 298.name: Independent Study
LPS 298.description: Independent research with Logic and Philosophy of Science Faculty.

LPS 299.name: Directed Research
LPS 299.description: Directed study with Logic and Philosophy of Science Faculty.

LPS 399.name: University Teaching
LPS 399.description: Required of and limited to Teaching Assistants.

LSCI 1.name: Languages of the World
LSCI 1.description: The world has over 6,000 languages, with an exuberant variety of sounds, words, grammars. Introduction to a representative (about eight), drawn from every continent. Students not expected to learn these languages, but to explore and study their structure and complexity.

LSCI 3.name: Introduction to Linguistics
LSCI 3.description: Emphasis on the notion that language is a remarkable achievement of the human mind.  Current insights into the nature of language.  Survey of various subfields of linguistics. Introduction to linguistic analysis.

LSCI 10.name: Introduction to Phonology
LSCI 10.description: Basic concepts in phonetic description and phonological analysis.

LSCI 20.name: Introduction to Syntax
LSCI 20.description: Basic concepts in syntactic description and grammatical analysis.

LSCI 43.name: Introduction to Symbolic Logic
LSCI 43.description: An introduction to the symbolism and methods of the logic of statements, including evaluation of arguments by truth tables, the techniques of natural deduction, and semantic tableaux.

LSCI 51.name: Acquisition of Language
LSCI 51.description: What children say, what they mean, and what they understand. Theories about the learning of language by one-, two-, and three-year-olds. Comparison of kinds of data on which these theories are based.

LSCI 51B.name: Foundations of Bilingual Education and Bilingualism
LSCI 51B.description: Provides a comprehensive overview of current issues in bilingual education and bilingualism. Topics include dimensions of bilingualism, the effects of bilingualism on children's linguistic and cognitive development, bilingual education programs, literacy, special needs, and assessment.

LSCI 68.name: Introduction to Language and Culture
LSCI 68.description: Explores what the study of language can reveal about ourselves as bearers of culture. After introducing some basic concepts, examines how cultural knowledge is linguistically organized and how language might shape our perception of the world.

LSCI 102.name: Formal Languages and Automata
LSCI 102.description: Formal aspects of describing and recognizing languages by grammars and automata.  Parsing regular and context-free languages. Ambiguity, nondeterminism. Elements of computability
LSCI 102.prereqString: Prerequisite: (ICS 46 or CSE 46) and MATH 2B and ICS 6B and ICS 6D. ICS 46 with a grade of C or better. CSE 46 with a grade of C or better
LSCI 102.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Cognitive Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Language Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

LSCI 106M.name: Computational Models of Language Learning
LSCI 106M.description: Focuses on using computational models to investigate questions related to language learning. Topics include computational models of language acquisition, principles underlying models of language learning and language change, computational learning theory, and modeling information extraction from language by humans.
LSCI 106M.prereqString: Prerequisite: LSCI 151. LSCI 151 with a grade of A- or better

LSCI 107M.name: Computational Methods for Language Research
LSCI 107M.description: Focuses on computational methods useful for language research. Students become familiar with software and programming languages used for extracting information from electronic datasets and for creating basic simulations of linguistic cognition. No prior programming experience assumed.
LSCI 107M.prereqString: Prerequisite: PSYC 150 or LSCI 155 or PSYC 156A or LSCI 151

LSCI 111.name: Intermediate Phonology
LSCI 111.description: Fundamentals of phonological theory.  Intensive practice in phonological analysis.

LSCI 115.name: Introduction to Phonetics
LSCI 115.description: Introduces students to fundamental concepts of phonetics. The sound systems of selected languages around the world, including that of English, are described in detail. Students are trained to work with speech sound recognition, phonetic transcription, and language sound production.

LSCI 121.name: Intermediate Syntax
LSCI 121.description: Examines various phenomena within a generative theory of syntax, focusing on the nature of syntactic rules, representations, and constraints. Introduces methods of experimental syntax, providing students hands-on opportunity to recognize the connection(s) between theory and experiential results.

LSCI 124.name: Current Topics in Syntactic Theory
LSCI 124.description: Research seminar in syntax.  Intensive study of a small number of well-defined topics which have had significant impact on the development of syntactic theory.

LSCI 141.name: Topics in Philosophy of Language
LSCI 141.description: Selected topics in the philosophy of language, e.g., the nature of meaning, mechanisms of reference, speech acts.

LSCI 142.name: Introduction to Logic
LSCI 142.description: Introduction to sentence logic, including truth tables and natural deduction

LSCI 143.name: Introduction to Formal Semantics
LSCI 143.description: Introduces students to the analytical tools used in the investigation of natural language semantics. Topics include the truth-conditional approach to meaning, compositionality, scope and anaphora, generalized quantifier theory, and intensionality.
LSCI 143.prereqString: Prerequisite: LPS 30 or PHIL 30 or LPS 104 or PHIL 104. LPS 30 with a grade of A- or better. PHIL 30 with a grade of A- or better. LPS 104 with a grade of A- or better. PHIL 104 with a grade of A- or better

LSCI 145A.name: Elementary Set Theory
LSCI 145A.description: An introduction to the basic working vocabulary of mathematical reasoning. Topics include sets, Boolean operations, ordered n-tuples, relations, functions, ordinal and cardinal numbers.

LSCI 145B.name: Metalogic
LSCI 145B.description: Introduction to formal syntax (proof theory) and semantics (model theory) for first-order logic, including the deduction, completeness, compactness, and Löewenheim-Skolem theorems.
LSCI 145B.prereqString: Prerequisite: LSCI 145A or LPS 105A or PHIL 105A

LSCI 145C.name: Undecidability and Incompleteness
LSCI 145C.description: Introduction to the formal theory of effective processes, including recursive functions, Turing machines, Church's thesis, and proofs of Göedel's incompleteness theorem for arithmetic, and Church's undecidability theorem for first-order logic.
LSCI 145C.prereqString: Prerequisite: LSCI 145B or LPS 105B or PHIL 105B

LSCI 151.name: Acquisition of Language II
LSCI 151.description: Focuses on native language learning, exploring the way in which infants and very young children unconsciously uncover the rich systematic knowledge of their native language. Examines both experimental and computational studies that quantitatively investigate the "how" of language acquisition.

LSCI 151B.name: Bilingual Acquisition
LSCI 151B.description: Focuses on different forms of bilingualism, including bilingual first language acquisition, early second language acquisition, and late second language acquisition. Research techniques discussed include theoretical, experimental, and computational methods.
LSCI 151B.prereqString: Prerequisite: LSCI 151 or PSYC 156A. Placement via consent of the instructor is also accepted.

LSCI 151S.name: Second Language Acquisition
LSCI 151S.description: Examines a number of theoretical perspectives that attempt to explain second language learning with a focus on adult learners. How universal constraints, individual differences, and social factors influence the task of learning a second language as an adult.

LSCI 152.name: Acquisition of Language III
LSCI 152.description: Focuses on native language learning, exploring the way in which infants and very young children unconsciously uncover the rich systematic knowledge of their native language. Examines both experimental and computational studies that quantitatively investigate the "how" of language acquisition.

LSCI 155.name: Psychology of Language
LSCI 155.description: Examines language using the tools of experimental psychology. From sounds to words to spoken and written sentences, explores how language is used in real time, and how its use reveals how it is represented in the mind.
LSCI 155.prereqString: Prerequisite: PSYC 7A or PSCI 9 or PSYC 9B or PSCI 11B or LSCI 3
LSCI 155.restriction: Restriction: Cognitive Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Language Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

LSCI 158.name: Language and the Brain
LSCI 158.description: Research analysis on biological bases of human linguistic capacity. Development, focusing on hemispheric specialization, plasticity
LSCI 158.prereqString: Prerequisite: (PSYC 7A or PSB 9 or PSYC 9A or PSB 11A) and (PSYC 9B or PSB 11B or BIOL 35 or BIOL N110 or BIOL N115A)
LSCI 158.restriction: Restriction: Cognitive Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Biological Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

LSCI 164B.name: French Phonetics
LSCI 164B.description: Study of the sound structure of French.  Introduction to elements of general phonetics, contrastive (French/English) phonetics, and French phonetics and phonology.  Designed to help students improve their pronunciation.  Also serves as a preparatory course for language teaching.

LSCI 165B.name: Structure of Japanese
LSCI 165B.description: An overview of the linguistic features of modern Japanese. Provides students with a systematic introduction to the nature and characteristics of the language.

LSCI 165L.name: Language Change, Acquisition, and Complexity
LSCI 165L.description: Focuses on models of language change, acquisition, and complexity, looking at the connections between them to explain empirical data relating to the form of existing languages and how languages change over time. Emphasis is placed on computational and mathematical models.
LSCI 165L.prereqString: Prerequisite: PSYC 156A. PSYC 156A with a grade of A- or better

LSCI 168J.name: Improvisation, Language, and Culture
LSCI 168J.description: Addresses improvisation, both in performance and in everyday life. Examines improvisation as the "flexible regulation" of everyday behavior by exploring different scholarly treatments of language and interaction, and working on developing actual theatrical improvisation skills.

LSCI 168S.name: Language and Social Cognition
LSCI 168S.description: Explores the relationship between language and cognition in social and cultural contexts. The overall goal is to think through how language structure and use impact how individuals perceive, think about, and understand the world around them.
LSCI 168S.restriction: Restriction: Anthropology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

LSCI 172.name: History of English
LSCI 172.description: Traces the history of English from its roots through its earliest written records and into the present, including fundamental changes in morphology, phonology, syntax, semantics, and vocabulary, as well as social, cultural, and historical forces affecting language.

LSCI 175.name: Language Origins: Evolution, Genetics, and the Brain
LSCI 175.description: Examines how human language(s) may have originated. Studies pertinent techniques (reconstruction) and addresses related questions, including is our language faculty inborn (i.e., genetically encoded)? Can brain imaging and population genetics research help to unlock this mystery of human evolution?.

LSCI 176.name: Introduction to Pidgins and Creoles
LSCI 176.description: Explores the linguistic structures of pidgin and creole languages and examines major theories for the surprisingly high degree of similarity found across pidgin and creole languages. Includes sociolinguistic and field methods.

LSCI 182V.name: Language and Literacy
LSCI 182V.description: Addresses the linguistic principles and processes that underlie oral and written language proficiency. Emphasis is on how to use phonology, morphology, orthography, semantics, syntax, and pragmatics to support literacy and oral language development for K-12 students.
LSCI 182V.restriction: Restriction: Language Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Education Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

LSCI 189.name: Special Topics in Applied Language Science: Writing Skills for Language Science

LSCI 195A.name: Language Science Research I
LSCI 195A.description: Provides students with in-depth experience in different facets of research in language science. It includes theoretical, behavioral, computational, and/or applied language science topics and methodologies.
LSCI 195A.prereqString: Prerequisite: Permission of faculty advisor. If this is not the same faculty member as the course instructor, the faculty advisor will coordinate with the course instructor when it comes to assessing the student’s research process at the end of each quarter.

LSCI 195B.name: Language Science Research II
LSCI 195B.description: Provides students with in-depth experience in different facets of research in language science. It includes theoretical, behavioral, computational, and/or applied language science topics and methodologies.
LSCI 195B.prereqString: Prerequisite:  Permission of faculty advisor. If this is not the same faculty member as the course instructor, the faculty advisor will coordinate with the course instructor when it comes to assessing the student’s research process at the end of each quarter.

LSCI 195C.name: Language Science Research III
LSCI 195C.description: Provides students with in-depth experience in different facets of research in language science. It includes theoretical, behavioral, computational, and/or applied language science topics and methodologies.
LSCI 195C.prereqString: Prerequisite: Permission of faculty advisor. If this is not the same faculty member as the course instructor, the faculty advisor will coordinate with the course instructor when it comes to assessing the student’s research process at the end of each quarter.

LSCI 195W.name: Writing Skills for Language Science
LSCI 195W.description: Focuses on written technical communication skills in language science. Topics include the scientific publication process (focusing on research abstracts), how to write for pieces of different lengths, and writing for different audiences.

LSCI 199.name: Independent Study
LSCI 199.description: Independent research with Linguistics faculty. Students may enroll for only one 199 each quarter.

LSCI 201A.name: Language Science Research
LSCI 201A.description: Involves colloquia and scientific reports by faculty, students, and visitors. Students are exposed to current language science research and gain experience in active listening and scientific discourse.
LSCI 201A.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Language Science Majors only.

LSCI 201B.name: Language Science Research
LSCI 201B.description: Involves colloquia and scientific reports by faculty, students, and visitors. Students are exposed to current language science research and gain experience in active listening and scientific discourse.
LSCI 201B.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Language Science Majors only.

LSCI 201C.name: Language Science Research
LSCI 201C.description: Involves colloquia and scientific reports by faculty, students, and visitors. Students are exposed to current language science research and gain experience in active listening and scientific discourse.
LSCI 201C.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Language Science Majors only.

LSCI 202A.name: Skills for Language Science I
LSCI 202A.description: Focuses on computational skills for language science research. Topics include computational literacy, programming languages, and database interfaces that are useful for language science research, allowing for general scripting and file manipulation, and enabling statistical analysis and data visualization.

LSCI 202B.name: Skills for Language Science II
LSCI 202B.description: Introduction to the scientific publication process and practice of scientific writing skills.

LSCI 202C.name: Skills for Language Science III
LSCI 202C.description: Introduction to scientific presentation for audiences of different backgrounds and practice of scientific presentations skills.

LSCI 202D.name: Advanced Skills for Language Science
LSCI 202D.description: Practice of advanced professional writing skills, including writing of grants, journal publications, research profiles, academic CVs, teaching statements, and cover letters. Students bring their own academic material to workshop.
LSCI 202D.prereqString: Prerequisite: LSCI 202A and LSCI 202B and LSCI 202C. LSCI 202A with a grade of B or better. LSCI 202B with a grade of B or better. LSCI 202C with a grade of B or better

LSCI 206C.name: Computational Models of Language Learning
LSCI 206C.description: Focuses on computational models of native language learning, exploring how probabilistic learning and inference fare on difficult case studies within language acquisition. In all cases, grounds the learning models in available empirical data and considers their psychological plausibility.
LSCI 206C.prereqString: Prerequisite: LSCI 251. LSCI 251 with a grade of B- or better

LSCI 209.name: Special Topics in Computational Linguistics
LSCI 209.description: Focuses on ongoing research in linguistics.  Variable units based on course content, as determined by Department.  May be repeated for credit as topic varies.

LSCI 219.name: Special Topics in Phonetics and Phonology

LSCI 248M.name: Modal Logic
LSCI 248M.description: Introduction to modal logic methods and their application.

LSCI 250.name: Psycholinguistics
LSCI 250.description: Examines how language is used in real time, and how its use reveals how it is represented in the mind and the brain.

LSCI 250B.name: Bilingualism
LSCI 250B.description: Examines how bilingualism interfaces with language representation, language use, and language development.

LSCI 250H.name: Heritage Language Acquistion
LSCI 250H.description: Examines how heritage languages are represented in speakers' minds, processed in real time, and acquired.

LSCI 251.name: Language Acquisition
LSCI 251.description: Focuses on native language learning, exploring the way in which infants and very young children unconsciously uncover the rich systematic knowledge of their native language. Examines both experimental and computational studies that quantitatively investigate the "how" of language acquisition.

LSCI 251A.name: Atypical Acquisition
LSCI 251A.description: Focuses on different types of atypical acquisition, including acquisition in special populations and acquisition under atypical circumstances. Research techniques discussed include theoretical, experimental, and computational methods.

LSCI 253M.name: Experimental Methods for Language Research
LSCI 253M.description: Focuses on experimental methods useful for language research. Students become familiar with software and programming languages used for implementing and analyzing behavioral experiments.

LSCI 259.name: Special Topics in Psycholinguistics
LSCI 259.description: Topics in Psycholinguistics. May be repeated for credit as topic varies.

LSCI 265L.name: Language Change, Acquisition, and Complexity
LSCI 265L.description: Focuses on models of language change, acquisition, and complexity, looking at the connections between them to explain empirical data relating to the form of existing languages and how languages change over time. Emphasis is placed on computational and mathematical models.

LSCI 281L.name: Language Learning with Digital Media
LSCI 281L.description: Provides students with a graduate-level introduction to key issues of digital media in second-language teaching and learning.

LSCI 281S.name: Second Language Acquisition and Teaching
LSCI 281S.description: Explores the prevailing paradigms that seek to account for how adults learn second languages (L2s) in instructed settings.

LSCI 289.name: Special Topics in Applied Language Science
LSCI 289.description: Varied topics in applied language science.

LSCI 299.name: Independent Study
LSCI 299.description: Independent study. Research with language science faculty.

M&MG 200A.name: Research in Microbiology and Molecular Genetics
M&MG 200A.description: Individual research supervised by a particular professor.

M&MG 200B.name: Research in Microbiology and Molecular Genetics
M&MG 200B.description: Individual research supervised by a particular professor.

M&MG 200C.name: Research in Microbiology and Molecular Genetics
M&MG 200C.description: Individual research supervised by a particular professor.

M&MG 200R.name: Research in Microbiology and Molecular Genetics for First-Year Students
M&MG 200R.description: Independent research within the laboratories of graduate training faculty in the Department of Microbiology and Molecular Genetics for first-year Ph.D. students.

M&MG 201A.name: Research topics in Microbiology and Molecular Genetics
M&MG 201A.description: Seminars presented by graduate students and faculty of the Department which explore research topics in specialized areas of microbiology and molecular genetics. Opportunity for students to gain experience in the organization, critical evaluation, and oral presentation of current research developments.

M&MG 201B.name: Research topics in Microbiology and Molecular Genetics
M&MG 201B.description: Seminars presented by graduate students and faculty of the Department which explore research topics in specialized areas of microbiology and molecular genetics. Oppurtunity for students to gain experience in the organization, critical evaluation, and oral presentation of current research developments.

M&MG 201C.name: Research topics in Microbiology and Molecular Genetics
M&MG 201C.description: Seminars presented by graduate students and faculty of the Department which explore research topics in specialized areas of microbiology and molecular genetics. Oppurtunity for students to gain experience in the organization, critical evaluation, and oral presentation of current research developments.

M&MG 203A.name: Advanced Studies in Microbiology and Molecular Genetics
M&MG 203A.description: Organized within each laboratory group, one to four hours. Advanced study in areas related to faculty research interests. Involves small group study based on readings, discussions, and guest speakers. May be conducted as journal clubs.

M&MG 203B.name: Advanced Studies in Microbiology and Molecular Genetics
M&MG 203B.description: Organized within each laboratory group, one to four hours. Advanced study in areas related to faculty research interests. Involves small group study based on readings, discussions, and guest speakers. May be conducted as journal clubs.

M&MG 203C.name: Advanced Studies in Microbiology and Molecular Genetics
M&MG 203C.description: Organized within each laboratory group, one to four hours. Advanced study in areas related to faculty research interests. Involves small group study based on readings, discussions, and guest speakers. May be conducted as journal clubs.

M&MG 205A.name: Basic Immunology Core Lectures
M&MG 205A.description: Basic concepts in human immunology including development of the immune system, innate immunity, immunoglobulin structure and genetics, antigen-antibody reactions, the major histocompatibility complex and antigen presentation, T cell and B cell development, initiation of the immune response, effector mechanisms.

M&MG 205B.name: Basic Immunology Core Lectures
M&MG 205B.description: Basic concepts in human immunology incluing development of the immune system, innate immunity, immunoglobulin structure and genetics, antigen-antibody reactions, the major histocompatibility complex and antigen presentation, T cell and B cell development, initiation of the immune response, effector mechanisms.

M&MG 205C.name: Basic Immunology Core Lectures
M&MG 205C.description: Basic concepts in human immunology including development of the immune system, innate immunity, immunoglobulin structure and genetics, antigen-antibody reactions, the major histocompatibility complex and antigen presentation, T cell and B cell development, initiation of the immune response, effector mechanisms.

M&MG 206.name: Regulation of Gene Expression
M&MG 206.description: Aspects of gene expression including the organization of the eukaryotic nucleus in terms of protein-nucleic acid interaction (i.e., chromatin and chromosome structure)

M&MG 210A.name: Medical Microbiology
M&MG 210A.description: Biology of microbial pathogens (viruses, bacteria, fungi, parasites) as foundation for subsequent study of infectious diseases. Topics: molecular basis of microbial pathogenesis

M&MG 210B.name: Medical Immunology
M&MG 210B.description: Cellular and molecular basis of immune response and roles of the immune system in both maintaining health and contributing to disease.

M&MG 215.name: Integrative Immunology
M&MG 215.description: Lectures and student presentations of primary literature. The main goal is to achieve a basic understanding of the cellular and molecular basis of innate and adaptive immunity, and how immune function is coordinated at a systems level.

M&MG 216.name: Pathogenic Microbiology
M&MG 216.description: Biochemical and genetic properties of infectious agents

M&MG 219.name: Medical Virology
M&MG 219.description: Animal viruses as disease causing agents, including mechanisms of infection at both the cellular and organismic levels. Topics include comparative studies of different groups of viruses, viral transformation, and mechanisms of viral gene expression.

M&MG 221.name: Immunopathogenic Mechanisms of Disease
M&MG 221.description: Examination of the mechanisms underlying disease states mediated by immune dysregulation. Topics include mechanisms of immune evasion by cancer, diseases mediated by cytokine dysregulation, role of the microbiome of the GI tract and other disease sites, and adoptive T-cell therapy.

M&MG 222.name: Molecular Pathogenesis of Microbial Infections
M&MG 222.description: Features lectures by faculty on the molecular aspects of microbial pathogenesis, highlighting both microbe and cellular functions. In addition to lectures, students review papers and discuss them. There will be two written exams, one on viruses and one on microbes.

M&MG 225.name: Molecular Mechanisms of Human Disease
M&MG 225.description: Provides an overview of the molecular mechanisms of human diseases, including neurologic, hematologic, neoplastic, and infectious diseases. Students gain an understanding of these mechanisms, as well as models of human diseases.

M&MG 227.name: Immunology Journal Club
M&MG 227.description: Advanced topics in immunology as related to an understanding of human disease.

M&MG 230.name: Topics in Stem Cells
M&MG 230.description: One-hour seminar presentation by participating faculty or guest lecturer and open to the science community, followed by one-hour discussion of the lecture topic or related topic. Students are responsible for presentations and readings.

M&MG 240.name: M.D./PH.D. Tutorial
M&MG 240.description: Explores a variety of topics that impact careers of medical scientists (M.D./Ph.D students). Topics range from scientific, such as recent advances in particular research areas, to ethical problems brought on by increased technology and intervention in the disease process.

M&MG 250.name: Responsible Conduct of Research
M&MG 250.description: Each session includes a formal presentation by faculty/invited speaker followed by a discussion of case studies related to the topic under consideration.

M&MG 270.name: Career Development
M&MG 270.description: Topics include preparation of papers, grants and fellowships, scientific presentations, and curriculum vitae, and career opportunities.

M&MG 280.name: Tutorial in Microbiology and Molecular Genetics
M&MG 280.description: Tutorial in Microbiology and Molecular Genetics. Presented by the department chair

M&MG 292A.name: Scientific Communication
M&MG 292A.description: Small group meetings for graduate students to practice scientific writing, debate, and presentation skills.

M&MG 292B.name: Scientific Communication
M&MG 292B.description: Small group meetings for graduate students to practice scientific writing, debate, and presentation skills.

M&MG 292C.name: Scientific Communication
M&MG 292C.description: Small group meetings for graduate students to practice scientific writing, debate, and presentation skills.

M&MG 298.name: Independent Study
M&MG 298.description: Provided for MSTP students to synthesize the basic science information learned during the basic science years of medical school and learn how to apply that knowledge toward graduate research directed at understanding the basis of human disease.

M&MG 299.name: Dissertation—Microbiology and Molecular Genetics
M&MG 299.description: Course provided for Ph.D. students to prepare and complete the dissertation required for a Ph.D. degree.

MATH 1A.name: Pre-Calculus I
MATH 1A.description: Basic equations and inequalities, linear and quadratic functions, and systems of simultaneous equations.

MATH 1B.name: Pre-Calculus II
MATH 1B.description: Preparation for calculus and other mathematics courses. Exponentials, logarithms, trigonometry, polynomials, and rational functions. Satisfies no requirements other than contribution to the 180 units required for graduation.
MATH 1B.prereqString: Prerequisite: MATH 1A. Placement into MATH 1B via the Calculus Placement exam, or a score of 450 or higher on the Mathematics section of the SAT Reasoning Test.
MATH 1B.restriction: Restriction: MATH 1B may not be taken for credit if taken after MATH 2A.

MATH 2A.name: Single-Variable Calculus I
MATH 2A.description: Introduction to derivatives, calculation of derivatives of algebraic and trigonometric functions
MATH 2A.prereqString: Prerequisite: MATH 1B or AP Calculus AB or SAT Mathematics or ACT Mathematics. MATH 1B with a grade of C or better. AP Calculus AB with a minimum score of 3. SAT Mathematics with a minimum score of 650. ACT Mathematics with a minimum score of 29. Placement via the Calculus Placement exam (fee required) is also accepted.
MATH 2A.restriction: Restriction: School of Physical Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Engineering students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment.

MATH 2B.name: Single-Variable Calculus II
MATH 2B.prereqString: Prerequisite: MATH 2A or MATH 5A or MATH 7A or AP Calculus AB or AP Calculus BC. AP Calculus AB with a minimum score of 4. AP Calculus BC with a minimum score of 3
MATH 2B.restriction: Restriction: School of Physical Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Engineering students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment.

MATH 2D.name: Multivariable Calculus I
MATH 2D.description: Differential and integral calculus of real-valued functions of several real variables, including applications. Polar coordinates.
MATH 2D.prereqString: Prerequisite: MATH 2B or MATH 5B or MATH 7B or AP Calculus BC. AP Calculus BC with a minimum score of 4
MATH 2D.restriction: Restriction: School of Physical Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Engineering students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Undeclared Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

MATH 2E.name: Multivariable Calculus II
MATH 2E.description: The differential and integral calculus of vector-valued functions. Implicit and inverse function theorems. Line and surface integrals, divergence and curl, theorems of Greens, Gauss, and Stokes.
MATH 2E.restriction: Restriction: School of Physical Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Engineering students have first consideration for enrollment.

MATH H2D.name: Honors Multivariable Calculus I
MATH H2D.description: Differential and integral calculus of real-valued functions of several real variables, including applications. Polar coordinates. Covers the same material as MATH 2D-E, but with a greater emphasis on the theoretical structure of the subject matter.
MATH H2D.prereqString: Prerequisite: MATH 2B or MATH 5B or MATH 7B or (AP Calculus BC and (MATH H3A or MATH 3A)). MATH 2B with a grade of A or better. MATH 5B with a grade of A or better. MATH 7B with a grade of A or better. AP Calculus BC with a minimum score of 5. MATH H3A with a grade of B- or better. MATH 3A with a grade of A or better

MATH H2E.name: Honors Multivariable Calculus II
MATH H2E.description: Differential and integral calculus of real-valued functions of several real variables, including applications. Polar coordinates. Covers the same material as MATH 2D-E, but with a greater emphasis on the theoretical structure of the subject matter.
MATH H2E.prereqString: Prerequisite: MATH H2D. MATH H2D with a grade of B- or better

MATH 3A.name: Introduction to Linear Algebra
MATH 3A.description: Systems of linear equations, matrix operations, determinants, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, vector spaces, subspaces, and dimension.
MATH 3A.prereqString: Prerequisite: MATH 2B or MATH 5B or MATH 7B or AP Calculus BC. AP Calculus BC with a minimum score of 4
MATH 3A.restriction: Restriction: School of Physical Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Engineering students have first consideration for enrollment. Undeclared Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

MATH 3D.name: Elementary Differential Equations
MATH 3D.description: Linear differential equations, variation of parameters, constant coefficient cookbook, systems of equations, Laplace transforms, series solutions.
MATH 3D.prereqString: Prerequisite: (MATH 3A or MATH H3A) and (MATH 2D or MATH H2D)
MATH 3D.restriction: Restriction: School of Physical Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Engineering students have first consideration for enrollment.

MATH H3A.name: Honors Introduction to Linear Algebra
MATH H3A.description: Systems of linear equations, matrix operations, determinants, eigenvalues, eigenvectors, vector spaces, subspaces, and dimension.
MATH H3A.prereqString: Prerequisite: MATH 2B or MATH 5B or MATH 7B or AP Calculus BC. MATH 2B with a grade of A or better. MATH 5B with a grade of A or better. MATH 7B with a grade of A or better. AP Calculus BC with a minimum score of 5
MATH H3A.restriction: Restriction: School of Physical Sciences students only. School of Engineering students only. Mathematics Majors only. Undeclared Majors only.

MATH 5A.name: Calculus for Life Sciences I
MATH 5A.description: Differential calculus with applications to life sciences. Exponential, logarithmic, and trigonometric functions. Limits, differentiation techniques, optimization and difference equations.
MATH 5A.prereqString: Prerequisite: MATH 1B or AP Calculus AB or SAT Mathematics or ACT Mathematics. MATH 1B with a grade of C or better. AP Calculus AB with a minimum score of 3. SAT Mathematics with a minimum score of 650. ACT Mathematics with a minimum score of 29. Placement via the Calculus Placement exam (fee required) is also accepted.
MATH 5A.restriction: Restriction: School of Biological Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment.

MATH 5B.name: Calculus for Life Sciences II
MATH 5B.description: Integral calculus and multivariable calculus with applications to life sciences. Integration techniques, applications of the integral, phase plane methods and basic modeling, basic multivariable methods.
MATH 5B.prereqString: Prerequisite: MATH 5A or MATH 2A or MATH 7A or AP Calculus AB or AP Calculus BC. AP Calculus AB with a minimum score of 4. AP Calculus BC with a minimum score of 3
MATH 5B.restriction: Restriction: School of Biological Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. Cannot be taken for credit after MATH 2B.

MATH 7A.name: Single-Variable Calculus I
MATH 7A.description: Introduction to derivatives, calculation of derivatives of algebraic and trigonometric functions
MATH 7A.prereqString: Prerequisite: MATH 1B or AP Calculus AB or SAT Mathematics or ACT Mathematics. MATH 1B with a grade of C or better. AP Calculus AB with a minimum score of 3. SAT Mathematics with a minimum score of 650. ACT Mathematics with a minimum score of 29. Placement via the Calculus Placement exam (fee required) is also accepted.

MATH 7B.name: Single-Variable Calculus II
MATH 7B.prereqString: Prerequisite: MATH 2A or MATH 5A or AP Calculus AB or AP Calculus BC or MATH 7A. AP Calculus AB with a minimum score of 4. AP Calculus BC with a minimum score of 3

MATH 8.name: Explorations in Functions and Modeling
MATH 8.description: Explorations of applications and connections in topics in algebra, geometry, calculus, and statistics for future secondary math educators. Emphasis on nonstandard modeling problems.

MATH 9.name: Introduction to Programming for Numerical Analysis
MATH 9.description: Introduction to computers and programming using Matlab and Mathematica. Representation of numbers and precision, input/output, functions, custom data types, testing/debugging, reading exceptions, plotting data, numerical differentiation, basics of algorithms. Analysis of random processes using computer simulations.
MATH 9.prereqString: Prerequisite: MATH 2A or MATH 5A or MATH 7A or AP Calculus AB or AP Calculus BC. AP Calculus AB with a minimum score of 4. AP Calculus BC with a minimum score of 3
MATH 9.restriction: Restriction: Mathematics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

MATH 10.name: Introduction to Programming for Data Science
MATH 10.description: Intro to algorithms in data science using Python and R. Basic concepts of Python, store, access, and manipulate data in lists
MATH 10.restriction: Restriction: Mathematics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

MATH 13.name: Introduction to Abstract Mathematics
MATH 13.description: Introduction to formal definition and rigorous proof writing in mathematics. Topics include basic logic, set theory, equivalence relations, and various proof techniques such as direct, induction, contradiction, contrapositive, and exhaustion.
MATH 13.prereqString: Prerequisite: MATH 2A or MATH 5A or MATH 7A or ICS 6D
MATH 13.restriction: Restriction: Mathematics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

MATH 105A.name: Numerical Analysis I
MATH 105A.description: Introduction to the theory and practice of numerical computation with an emphasis on solving equations. Solving transcendental equations
MATH 105A.prereqString:
Corequisite: MATH 105LA
Prerequisite: MATH 3A or MATH H3A

MATH 105B.name: Numerical Analysis II
MATH 105B.description: Introduction to the theory and practice of numerical computation with an emphasis on topics from calculus and approximation theory. Lagrange interpolation

MATH 105LA.name: Numerical Analysis Laboratory
MATH 105LA.description: Provides practical experience to complement the theory developed in Mathematics 105A.

MATH 105LB.name: Numerical Analysis Laboratory
MATH 105LB.description: Provides practical experience to complement the theory developed in Mathematics 105B.

MATH 107.name: Numerical Differential Equations
MATH 107.description: Theory and applications of numerical methods to initial and boundary-value problems for ordinary and partial differential equations.
MATH 107.prereqString:
Corequisite: MATH 107L
Prerequisite: MATH 3D and MATH 105B

MATH 107L.name: Numerical Differential Equations Laboratory
MATH 107L.description: Provides practical experience to complement the theory developed in Mathematics 107.

MATH 110A.name: Optimization I
MATH 110A.description: Introduction to optimization, linear search method, trust region method, Newton method, linear programming, linear, and non-linear least square methods.
MATH 110A.restriction: Restriction: Mathematics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

MATH 110B.name: Optimization II
MATH 110B.description: The simplex method, interior point method, penalty barrier method, primal dual method, augmented Lagrangian method, and stochastic gradient method.
MATH 110B.prereqString: Prerequisite: MATH 110A. MATH 110A with a grade of C or better
MATH 110B.restriction: Restriction: Mathematics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

MATH 112A.name: Introduction to Partial Differential Equations and Applications I
MATH 112A.description: Introduction to ordinary and partial differential equations and their applications in engineering and science. Basic methods for classical PDEs (potential, heat, and wave equations). Classification of PDEs, separation of variables and series expansions, special functions, eigenvalue problems.
MATH 112A.prereqString: Prerequisite: (MATH 2E or MATH H2E) and MATH 3D

MATH 112B.name: Introduction to Partial Differential Equations and Applications II
MATH 112B.description: Introduction to partial differential equations and their applications in engineering and science. Basic methods for classical PDEs (potential, heat, and wave equations). Green functions and integral representations, method of characteristics.

MATH 112C.name: Introduction to Partial Differential Equations and Applications III
MATH 112C.description: Nonhomogeneous problems and Green's functions, Sturm-Liouville theory, general Fourier expansions, applications of partial differential equations in different areas of science.

MATH 113A.name: Mathematical Modeling in Biology I
MATH 113A.prereqString: Prerequisite: MATH 2B or MATH 5B or MATH 7B or AP Calculus BC. AP Calculus BC with a minimum score of 4

MATH 113B.name: Mathematical Modeling in Biology II
MATH 113B.prereqString: Prerequisite: MATH 2B or MATH 5B or MATH 7B or AP Calculus BC. AP Calculus BC with a minimum score of 4

MATH 115.name: Mathematical Modeling
MATH 115.description: Mathematical modeling and analysis of phenomena that arise in engineering physical sciences, biology, economics, or social sciences.

MATH 117.name: Dynamical Systems
MATH 117.description: Introduction to the modern theory of dynamical systems including contraction mapping principle, fractals and chaos, conservative systems, Kepler problem, billiard models, expanding maps, Smale's horseshoe, topological entropy.

MATH 118.name: The Theory of Differential Equations
MATH 118.description: Existence and uniqueness of solutions, continuous dependence of solutions on initial conditions and parameters, Lyapunov and asymptotic stability, Floquet theory, nonlinear systems, and bifurcations.

MATH 120A.name: Introduction to Abstract Algebra: Groups
MATH 120A.prereqString: Prerequisite: (MATH 3A or MATH H3A) and MATH 13. MATH 13 with a grade of C or better
MATH 120A.restriction: Restriction: Mathematics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

MATH 120B.name: Introduction to Abstract Algebra: Rings and Fields
MATH 120B.prereqString: Prerequisite: MATH 120A. MATH 120A with a grade of C- or better
MATH 120B.restriction: Restriction: Mathematics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

MATH 120C.name: Introduction to Abstract Algebra: Galois Theory
MATH 120C.description: Galois Theory: proof of the impossibility of certain ruler-and-compass constructions (squaring the circle, trisecting angles)

MATH H120A.name: Honors Introduction to Graduate Algebra I
MATH H120A.description: Introduction to abstract linear algebra, including bases, linear transformation, eigenvectors, canonical forms, inner products, and symmetric operators. Introduction to groups, rings, and fields, including examples of groups, group actions, Sylow theorems, modules over principal ideal domains, polynomials, and Galois groups.
MATH H120A.prereqString: Prerequisite: (MATH 3A or MATH H3A) and MATH 13 and (MATH 120A or MATH 121A). MATH 13 with a grade of A or better. MATH 120A with a grade of A or better. MATH 121A with a grade of A or better

MATH H120B.name: Honors Introduction to Graduate Algebra II
MATH H120B.description: Introduction to abstract linear algebra, including bases, linear transformation, eigenvectors, canonical forms, inner products, and symmetric operators. Introduction to groups, rings, and fields, including examples of groups, group actions, Sylow theorems, modules over principal ideal domains, polynomials, and Galois groups.

MATH H120C.name: Honors Introduction to Graduate Algebra III
MATH H120C.description: Introduction to abstract linear algebra, including bases, linear transformation, eigenvectors, canonical forms, inner products, and symmetric operators. Introduction to groups, rings, and fields, including examples of groups, group actions, Sylow theorems, modules over principal ideal domains, polynomials, and Galois groups.

MATH 121A.name: Linear Algebra I
MATH 121A.description: Introduction to modern abstract linear algebra. Special emphasis on students doing proofs. Vector spaces, linear independence, bases, dimension. Linear transformations and their matrix representations. Theory of determinants.
MATH 121A.prereqString: Prerequisite: (MATH 3A or MATH H3A) and MATH 13. MATH 13 with a grade of C or better
MATH 121A.restriction: Restriction: Mathematics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

MATH 121B.name: Linear Algebra II
MATH 121B.description: Introduction to modern abstract linear algebra. Special emphasis on students doing proofs. Canonical forms
MATH 121B.prereqString: Prerequisite: MATH 121A. MATH 121A with a grade of C or better
MATH 121B.restriction: Restriction: Mathematics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

MATH 130A.name: Probability I
MATH 130A.description: Combinatorial probability, conditional probabilities, independence, discrete and continuous random variables, expectation and variance, common probability distributions.

MATH 130B.name: Probability II
MATH 130B.description: Joint distributions, sums of independent random variables, conditional distributions and conditional expectation, covariances, moment generating functions, limit theorems.

MATH 130C.name: Stochastic Processes
MATH 130C.description: Markov chains, Brownian motion, Gaussian processes, applications to option pricing and Markov chain Monte Carlo methods.

MATH 134A.name: Fixed Income
MATH 134A.description: Overview of interest theory, time value of money, annuities/cash flows with payments that are not contingent, loans, sinking funds, bonds, general cash flow and portfolios, immunization, duration and convexity, swaps.

MATH 134C.name: Mathematical Models for Finance
MATH 134C.description: General properties of options: option contracts (call and put options, European, American and exotic options)
MATH 134C.restriction: Restriction: Mathematics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

MATH 140A.name: Elementary Analysis I
MATH 140A.description: Introduction to real analysis, including convergence of sequence, infinite series, differentiation and integration, and sequences of functions. Students are expected to do proofs.
MATH 140A.prereqString: Prerequisite: (MATH 2D or MATH H2D) and (MATH 3A or MATH H3A) and MATH 13. MATH 13 with a grade of C or better
MATH 140A.restriction: Restriction: Mathematics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

MATH 140B.name: Elementary Analysis II
MATH 140B.description: Introduction to real analysis including convergence of sequences, infinite series, differentiation and integration, and sequences of functions. Students are expected to do proofs.
MATH 140B.prereqString: Prerequisite: MATH 140A. MATH 140A with a grade of C- or better
MATH 140B.restriction: Restriction: Mathematics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

MATH 140C.name: Analysis in Several Variables
MATH 140C.description: Rigorous treatment of multivariable differential calculus. Jacobians, Inverse and Implicit Function theorems.

MATH H140A.name: Honors Introduction to Graduate Analysis I
MATH H140A.description: Construction of the real number system, topology of the real line, concepts of continuity, differential and integral calculus, sequences and series of functions, equicontinuity, metric spaces, multivariable differential and integral calculus, implicit functions, curves and surfaces.
MATH H140A.prereqString: Prerequisite: (MATH 2E or MATH H2E) and (MATH 3A or MATH H3A) and MATH 13 and MATH 121A and MATH 140A. MATH 2E with a grade of A or better. MATH H2E with a grade of A or better. MATH 13 with a grade of A or better. MATH 121A with a grade of A or better. MATH 140A with a grade of A or better

MATH H140B.name: Honors Introduction to Graduate Analysis II
MATH H140B.description: Construction of the real number system, topology of the real line, concepts of continuity, differential and integral calculus, sequences and series of functions, equicontinuity, metric spaces, multivariable differential and integral calculus, implicit functions, curves and surfaces.
MATH H140B.prereqString: Prerequisite: MATH H140A. MATH H140A with a grade of C- or better

MATH H140C.name: Honors Introduction to Graduate Analysis III
MATH H140C.description: Construction of the real number system
MATH H140C.prereqString: Prerequisite: MATH H140B. MATH H140B with a grade of C- or better

MATH 141.name: Introduction to Topology
MATH 141.description: The elements of naive set theory and the basic properties of metric spaces. Introduction to topological properties.

MATH 147.name: Complex Analysis
MATH 147.description: Rigorous treatment of basic complex analysis: analytic functions, Cauchy integral theory and its consequences, power series, residue calculus, harmonic functions, conformal mapping. Students are expected to do proofs.

MATH 150.name: Introduction to Mathematical Logic
MATH 150.description: First order logic through the Completeness Theorem for predicate logic.
MATH 150.prereqString: Prerequisite: MATH 13 or (ICS 6B and ICS 6D). MATH 13 with a grade of C- or better

MATH 161.name: Modern Geometry
MATH 161.prereqString: Prerequisite: MATH 13 or (ICS 6B and ICS 6D). MATH 13 with a grade of C- or better
MATH 161.restriction: Restriction: Mathematics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

MATH 162A.name: Introduction to Differential Geometry I
MATH 162A.description: Applications of advanced calculus and linear algebra to the geometry of curves and surfaces in space.
MATH 162A.prereqString: Prerequisite: (MATH 2E or MATH H2E) and MATH 3D

MATH 162B.name: Introduction to Differential Geometry II
MATH 162B.description: Applications of advanced calculus and linear algebra to the geometry of curves and surfaces in space.
MATH 162B.prereqString: Prerequisite: MATH 162A. MATH 162A with a grade of C- or better

MATH 173A.name: Introduction to Cryptology I
MATH 173A.description: Introduction to some of the mathematics used in the making and breaking of codes, with applications to classical ciphers and public key systems. Includes topics from number theory, probability, and abstract algebra.
MATH 173A.prereqString: Prerequisite: (MATH 2B or MATH 5B or MATH 7B or AP Calculus BC) and (MATH 3A or MATH H3A) and (MATH 13 or (ICS 6B and ICS 6D)). AP Calculus BC with a minimum score of 4

MATH 173B.name: Introduction to Cryptology II
MATH 173B.description: Introduction to some of the mathematics used in the making and breaking of codes, with applications to classical ciphers and public key systems. The mathematics which is covered includes topics from number theory, probability, and abstract algebra.

MATH 175.name: Combinatorics
MATH 175.description: Introduction to combinatorics including basic counting principles, permutations, combinations, binomial coefficients, inclusion-exclusion, derangements, ordinary and exponential generating functions, recurrence relations, Catalan numbers, Stirling numbers, and partition numbers.
MATH 175.prereqString: Prerequisite: (MATH 2B or MATH 5B or MATH 7B or AP Calculus BC) and MATH 13. AP Calculus BC with a minimum score of 4. MATH 13 with a grade of C or better

MATH 176.name: Mathematics of Finance
MATH 176.description: After reviewing tools from probability, statistics, and elementary differential and partial differential equations, concepts such as hedging, arbitrage, Puts, Calls, the design of portfolios, the derivation and solution of the Blac-Scholes, and other equations are discussed.
MATH 176.restriction: Restriction: Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Mathematics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

MATH 180A.name: Number Theory I
MATH 180A.description: Introduction to number theory and applications. Divisibility, prime numbers, factorization. Arithmetic functions. Congruences. Quadratic residue. Diophantine equations. Introduction to cryptography.
MATH 180A.prereqString: Prerequisite: (MATH 3A or MATH H3A) and MATH 13. MATH 13 with a grade of C or better
MATH 180A.restriction: Restriction: Mathematics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

MATH 180B.name: Number Theory II
MATH 180B.description: Introduction to number theory and applications. Analytic number theory, character sums, finite fields, discrete logarithm, computational complexity. Introduction to coding theory. Other topics as time permits.
MATH 180B.restriction: Restriction: Mathematics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

MATH 184.name: History of Mathematics
MATH 184.description: Topics vary from year to year. Some possible topics: mathematics in ancient times
MATH 184.prereqString:
Corequisite: MATH 184L
Prerequisite: MATH 120A and MATH 140A
MATH 184.restriction: Restriction: Mathematics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

MATH 184L.name: History of Mathematics Lesson Lab
MATH 184L.description: Aspiring math teachers research, design, present, and peer review middle school or high school math lessons that draw from history of mathematics topics.

MATH 192.name: Studies in the Learning and Teaching of Secondary Mathematics
MATH 192.description: Focus is on historic and current mathematical concepts related to student learning and effective math pedagogy, with fieldwork in grades 6-14.

MATH 194.name: Problem Solving Seminar
MATH 194.description: Develops ability in analytical thinking and problem solving, using problems of the type found in the Mathematics Olympiad and the Putnam Mathematical Competition. Students taking the course in fall will prepare for and take the Putnam examination in December.

MATH 195W.name: Mathematical Writing
MATH 195W.description: Techniques of mathematical writing and communication. Covers effectively writing mathematical papers, creating effective presentations, and communicating mathematics in a variety of media. Focuses on utilizing LaTeX for typesetting mathematics.
MATH 195W.prereqString: Prerequisite: MATH 120A or MATH 121A or MATH 140A. MATH 120A with a grade of C or better. MATH 121A with a grade of C or better. MATH 140A with a grade of C or better. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
MATH 195W.restriction: Restriction: Mathematics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

MATH 199A.name: Special Studies in Mathematics
MATH 199A.description: Supervised reading. For outstanding undergraduate Mathematics majors in supervised but independent reading or research of mathematical topics.

MATH 199B.name: Special Studies in Mathematics
MATH 199B.description: Supervised reading. For outstanding undergraduate Mathematics majors in supervised but independent reading or research of mathematical topics.

MATH 199C.name: Special Studies in Mathematics
MATH 199C.description: Supervised reading. For outstanding undergraduate Mathematics majors in supervised but independent reading or research of mathematical topics.

MATH 205A.name: Introduction to Graduate Analysis
MATH 205A.description: Construction of the real number system, topology of the real line, concepts of continuity, differential and integral calculus, sequences and series of functions, equicontinuity, metric spaces, multivariable differential and integral calculus, implicit functions, curves and surfaces.
MATH 205A.prereqString: Prerequisite: Recommended: MATH 2E and MATH 3A and MATH 13, or equivalent.

MATH 205B.name: Introduction to Graduate Analysis
MATH 205B.description: Construction of the real number system, topology of the real line, concepts of continuity, differential and integral calculus, sequences and series of functions, equicontinuity, metric spaces, multivariable differential and integral calculus, implicit functions, curves and surfaces.

MATH 205C.name: Introduction to Graduate Analysis
MATH 205C.description: Construction of the real number system, topology of the real line, concepts of continuity, differential and integral calculus, sequences and series of functions, equicontinuity, metric spaces, multivariable differential and integral calculus, implicit functions, curves and surfaces.

MATH 210A.name: Real Analysis
MATH 210A.description: Measure theory, Lebesgue integral, signed measures, Radon-Nikodym theorem, functions of bounded variation and absolutely continuous functions, classical Banach spaces, Lp spaces, integration on locally compact spaces and the Riesz-Markov theorem, measure and outer measure, product measure spaces.

MATH 210B.name: Real Analysis
MATH 210B.description: Measure theory, Lebesgue integral, signed measures, Radon-Nikodym theorem, functions of bounded variation and absolutely continuous functions, classical Banach spaces, Lp spaces, integration on locally compact spaces and the Riesz-Markov theorem, measure and outer measure, product measure spaces.

MATH 210C.name: Real Analysis
MATH 210C.description: Measure theory, Lebesgue integral, signed measures, Radon-Nikodym theorem, functions of bounded variation and absolutely continuous functions, classical Banach spaces, Lp spaces, integration on locally compact spaces and the Riesz-Markov theorem, measure and outer measure, product measure spaces.

MATH 211A.name: Topics in Analysis
MATH 211A.description: Studies in selected areas of Real Analysis, a continuation of MATH 210A-MATH 210B-MATH 210C. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

MATH 218A.name: Introduction to Manifolds and Geometry
MATH 218A.description: General topology and fundamental groups, covering space
MATH 218A.prereqString: Prerequisite: Recommended: MATH 140C and MATH 121B, or equivalent.

MATH 218B.name: Introduction to Manifolds and Geometry
MATH 218B.description: General topology and fundamental groups, covering space

MATH 218C.name: Introduction to Manifolds and Geometry
MATH 218C.description: General topology and fundamental groups, covering space

MATH 220A.name: Analytic Function Theory
MATH 220A.description: Standard theorems about analytic functions. Harmonic functions. Normal families. Conformal mapping.

MATH 220B.name: Analytic Function Theory
MATH 220B.description: Standard theorems about analytic functions. Harmonic functions. Normal families. Conformal mapping.

MATH 220C.name: Analytic Function Theory
MATH 220C.description: Standard theorems about analytic functions. Harmonic functions. Normal families. Conformal mapping.

MATH 222A.name: Several Complex Variables and Complex Geometry
MATH 222A.description: Several Complex variables, d-bar problems, mappings, Kaehler geometry, de Rham and Dolbeault Theorems, Chern Classes, Hodge Theorems, Calabi conjecture, Kahler-Einstein geometry, Monge-Ampere.

MATH 225A.name: Introduction to Numerical Analysis and Scientific Computing
MATH 225A.description: Introduction to fundamentals of numerical analysis from an advanced viewpoint. Error analysis, approximation of functions, nonlinear equations.
MATH 225A.prereqString: Prerequisite: Recommended: MATH 3D and MATH 105B and MATH 140A and MATH 121A and MATH 112A, or equivalent.

MATH 225B.name: Introduction to Numerical Analysis and Scientific Computing
MATH 225B.description: Introduction to fundamentals of numerical analysis from an advanced viewpoint. Numerical linear algebra, numerical solutions of differential equations

MATH 225C.name: Introduction to Numerical Analysis and Scientific Computing
MATH 225C.description: Introduction to fundamentals of numerical analysis from an advanced viewpoint. Numerical linear algebra, numerical solutions of differential equations
MATH 225C.prereqString: Prerequisite: Recommended: MATH 3D and MATH 105B and MATH 140A and MATH 121A and MATH 112A, or equivalent.

MATH 226A.name: Computational Differential Equations
MATH 226A.description: Finite difference and finite element methods. Quick treatment of functional and nonlinear analysis background: weak solution, Lp spaces, Sobolev spaces. Approximation theory. Fourier and Petrov-Galerkin methods
MATH 226A.prereqString: Prerequisite: Recommended: MATH 3D and MATH 112A and (MATH 140B or MATH 105B), or equivalent.

MATH 226B.name: Computational Differential Equations
MATH 226B.description: Finite difference and finite element methods. Quick treatment of functional and nonlinear analysis background: weak solution, Lp spaces, Sobolev spaces. Approximation theory. Fourier and Petrov-Galerkin methods
MATH 226B.prereqString: Prerequisite: Recommended: MATH 3D and MATH 112A and (MATH 140B or MATH 105B), or equivalent.

MATH 226C.name: Computational Differential Equations
MATH 226C.description: Finite difference and finite element methods. Quick treatment of functional and nonlinear analysis background: weak solution, Lp spaces, Sobolev spaces. Approximation theory. Fourier and Petrov-Galerkin methods
MATH 226C.prereqString: Prerequisite: Recommended: MATH 3D and MATH 112A and (MATH 140B or MATH 105B), or equivalent.

MATH 227A.name: Mathematical and Computational Biology
MATH 227A.description: Analytical and numerical methods for dynamical systems, temporal-spatial dynamics, steady state, stability, stochasticity. Application to life sciences: genetics, tissue growth and patterning, cancers, ion channels gating, signaling networks, morphogen gradients. Analytical methods.
MATH 227A.prereqString: Prerequisite: Recommended: MATH 2A and MATH 2B and MATH 3A, or equivalent.

MATH 227B.name: Mathematical and Computational Biology
MATH 227B.description: Analytical and numerical methods for dynamical systems, temporal-spatial dynamics, steady state, stability, stochasticity. Application to life sciences: genetics, tissue growth and patterning, cancers, ion channels gating, signaling networks, morphogen gradients. Numerical simulations.

MATH 227C.name: Mathematical and Computational Biology
MATH 227C.description: Analytical and numerical methods for dynamical systems, temporal-spatial dynamics, steady state, stability, stochasticity. Application to life sciences: genetics, tissue growth and patterning, cancers, ion channels gating, signaling networks, morphogen gradients. Probabilistic methods.

MATH 230A.name: Algebra
MATH 230A.description: Elements of the theories of groups, rings, fields, modules. Galois theory. Modules over principal ideal domains. Artinian, Noetherian, and semisimple rings and modules.
MATH 230A.prereqString: Prerequisite: Recommended: MATH 120A and MATH 121A and MATH 121B, or equivalent.

MATH 230B.name: Algebra
MATH 230B.description: Elements of the theories of groups, rings, fields, modules. Galois theory. Modules over principal ideal domains. Artinian, Noetherian, and semisimple rings and modules.

MATH 230C.name: Algebra
MATH 230C.description: Elements of the theories of groups, rings, fields, modules. Galois theory. Modules over principal ideal domains. Artinian, Noetherian, and semisimple rings and modules.

MATH 232A.name: Algebraic Number Theory
MATH 232A.description: Algebraic integers, prime ideals, class groups, Dirichlet unit theorem, localization, completion, Cebotarev density theorem, L-functions, Gauss sums, diophantine equations, zeta functions over finite fields. Introduction to class field theory.

MATH 232B.name: Algebraic Number Theory
MATH 232B.description: Algebraic integers, prime ideals, class groups, Dirichlet unit theorem, localization, completion, Cebotarev density theorem, L-functions, Gauss sums, diophantine equations, zeta functions over finite fields. Introduction to class field theory.

MATH 232C.name: Algebraic Number Theory
MATH 232C.description: Algebraic integers, prime ideals, class groups, Dirichlet unit theorem, localization, completion, Cebotarev density theorem, L-functions, Gauss sums, diophantine equations, zeta functions over finite fields. Introduction to class field theory.

MATH 233A.name: Algebraic Geometry
MATH 233A.description: Basic commutative algebra and classical algebraic geometry. Algebraic varieties, morphisms, rational maps, blow ups. Theory of schemes, sheaves, divisors, cohomology. Algebraic curves and surfaces, Riemann-Roch theorem, Jacobians, classification of curves and surfaces.

MATH 233B.name: Algebraic Geometry
MATH 233B.description: Basic commutative algebra and classical algebraic geometry. Algebraic varieties, morphisms, rational maps, blow ups. Theory of schemes, sheaves, divisors, cohomology. Algebraic curves and surfaces, Riemann-Roch theorem, Jacobians, classification of curves and surfaces.

MATH 233C.name: Algebraic Geometry
