MGMTMBA 200.description: Focuses on the strategic and organizational challenges that a rapidly changing environment poses to the firm’s management and frames them according to Merage’s strategic emphasis on analytical decision making, innovation, and information technology.
MGMTMBA 200.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Business Administration Majors only.

MGMTMBA 201A.name: Business Analytics: Decision-Making
MGMTMBA 201A.description: Methods of statistical inference, emphasizing applications to administrative and management decision problems. Topics include classical estimation and hypothesis testing, regression, correlation, analysis of variance, decision analysis, and forecasting.
MGMTMBA 201A.prereqString: Prerequisite: Courses in basic statistics with probability.
MGMTMBA 201A.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Business Administration Majors only.

MGMTMBA 201B.name: Management Science
MGMTMBA 201B.description: An introduction to computer-based models for decision making. Topics include optimization (linear programming, integer programming, network flow models) and computer simulation. Uses spreadsheets extensively, including Excel built-in and add-in packages.
MGMTMBA 201B.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Business Administration Majors only.

MGMTMBA 202.name: Organizational Leadership for Management
MGMTMBA 202.description: Develops a better understanding of the causes and consequences of individual and group behavior, and the frameworks by which to analyze and understand complex organizations
MGMTMBA 202.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Business Administration Majors only.

MGMTMBA 203A.name: Financial Reporting
MGMTMBA 203A.description: Involves the development, analysis, and interpretation of financial accounting information for external reporting purposes.
MGMTMBA 203A.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Business Administration Majors only.

MGMTMBA 203B.name: Driving Profitability Through Management Accounting
MGMTMBA 203B.description: Teaches core skills for making vital strategic and tactical decisions (e.g., outsourcing
MGMTMBA 203B.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Master of Business Admin Degree students only.

MGMTMBA 204A.name: Microeconomics for Management in the Digital Age
MGMTMBA 204A.description: Provides basic tools for analyzing economic decisions of consumers and firms. Topics include demand and supply analysis, production and cost theory, perfect competition, monopoly, market failures, and introductory game theory.
MGMTMBA 204A.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Business Administration Majors only.

MGMTMBA 205.name: Marketing Principles
MGMTMBA 205.description: Introduction to the field of marketing. Objectives  include developing familiarity with fundamental concepts, theories, and techniques in marketing, and acquainting students with the type of decisions made by marketing managers including customer targeting, product, pricing, distribution, promotion, and research.
MGMTMBA 205.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Business Administration Majors only.

MGMTMBA 207.name: Competing with Digital: Technology, Analytics, and Platforms
MGMTMBA 207.description: Focuses on the technological and managerial issues surrounding the development and use of IT in organizations. Examines role of technology in organizations, how technology can be used to execute an organization's business strategy and to enable new, innovative business strategies.
MGMTMBA 207.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Business Administration Majors only.

MGMTMBA 208.name: Operational Excellence: Processes, Models, and Analytics
MGMTMBA 208.description: Introduction to strategic and tactical issues in production and operations management. A blend of quantitative and qualitative considerations. Topics include product planning, process design, capacity management, production planning, inventory control, distribution management, just-in-time manufacturing, quality management.
MGMTMBA 208.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Business Administration Majors only.

MGMTMBA 209A.name: Managerial Finance
MGMTMBA 209A.description: Introduces students to financial theory and concepts.  The main topics covered are time value of money, valuation of stocks and bonds, capital budgeting, portfolio theory, capital structure choice.
MGMTMBA 209A.prereqString: Prerequisite: MGMTMBA 201A and MGMTMBA 203A and MGMTMBA 204A
MGMTMBA 209A.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Business Administration Majors only.

MGMTMBA 209B.name: Investments
MGMTMBA 209B.description: Foundations of investment management. Theory and empirical evidence related to portfolio theory, market efficiency, asset pricing models, factor models, and option pricing theory. Students are expected to combine market research results and electronic information sources to create optimal investment strategies.
MGMTMBA 209B.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Master of Business Admin Degree students only.

MGMTMBA 210.name: Strategy: Foundations and Dynamics
MGMTMBA 210.description: Provides conceptual frameworks and techniques to analyze and develop firm strategies. Through case analysis and discussion, helps improve strategic thinking by developing frameworks by which to assess, evaluate, and respond to different business situations.
MGMTMBA 210.prereqString: Prerequisite: MGMTMBA 200 and MGMTMBA 202 and MGMTMBA 205 and MGMTMBA 209A
MGMTMBA 210.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Business Administration Majors only.

MGMTMBA 211.name: MBA Proseminar
MGMTMBA 211.description: Provides students in the Merage School Full-time MBA Program with information and practical skills for success in the MBA program, and for business career planning.
MGMTMBA 211.restriction: Restriction: Master of Business Admin Degree students only. Graduate students only.

MGMTMBA 213.name: New Venture Management
MGMTMBA 213.description: Teaches students how to launch and manage a new business by providing an overview of the start-up process, including how to identify new business opportunities and how to develop a sound operating model, value new ventures, and understand capital financing.
MGMTMBA 213.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Master of Business Admin Degree students only.

MGMTMBA 214.name: Entrepreneurship: Planning the New Venture
MGMTMBA 214.description: Project course in which student teams develop a business plan to launch a new venture. The final business plan is presented to an expert panel.
MGMTMBA 214.prereqString: Prerequisite: (MGMTMBA 202 or MGMT FE 202) and (MGMTMBA 205 or MGMT FE 205) and (MGMTMBA 210 or MGMT FE 210)
MGMTMBA 214.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Master of Business Admin Degree students only.

MGMTMBA 217.name: Competitive Intelligence
MGMTMBA 217.description: The course focuses on how to design a competitive intelligence program which is a core foundation upon which competitive strategies and execution tactics are developed, assessed, and modified.
MGMTMBA 217.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Master of Business Admin Degree students only.

MGMTMBA 218.name: Business Dynamics
MGMTMBA 218.description: Enhances students' analytical skills by analyzing complex challenges that businesses face and to quickly implement a winning response.
MGMTMBA 218.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Master of Business Admin Degree students only.

MGMTMBA 220.name: Organizational Change
MGMTMBA 220.description: Focuses on the implementation of change, including identifying the features of successful change in organizations of varying sizes and configurations, with an emphasis on the reasons why individuals resist or embrace change.
MGMTMBA 220.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Master of Business Admin Degree students only.

MGMTMBA 225.name: Negotiations
MGMTMBA 225.description: Using a combination of theory and practice via negotiation simulations, students expand their repertoire of negotiating skills and develop their ability to analyze different negotiation situations and contexts.
MGMTMBA 225.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Master of Business Admin Degree students only.

MGMTMBA 228.name: International Management
MGMTMBA 228.description: Introduction to the effects of different national cultures, political and economic systems on the assumptions, expectations, organizational practices, and organizational forms needed  to conduct cross-national organizational work.
MGMTMBA 228.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Master of Business Admin Degree students only.

MGMTMBA 231A.name: Financial Statement Analysis and Valuation I
MGMTMBA 231A.description: Develops skills essential to using financial statements for business analysis by examining financial information quality, profitability and risk analysis, earnings management, revenue recognition, asset recognition and valuation, and how financial reporting is related to the business environment and managerial incentives.
MGMTMBA 231A.prereqString: Prerequisite: MGMTMBA 203A or MGMT FE 203A. MGMTMBA 203A with a grade of C or better. MGMT FE 203A with a grade of C or better
MGMTMBA 231A.restriction: Restriction: Master of Business Admin Degree students only. Graduate students only.

MGMTMBA 244.name: Multinational Finance
MGMTMBA 244.description: Focuses on financial issues facing multinational corporations, the most important of which is the management of foreign exchange risk. Other topics include investments and financing decisions in international capital markets.
MGMTMBA 244.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Master of Business Admin Degree students only.

MGMTMBA 245.name: FinTech and the Digital Economy for Business
MGMTMBA 245.description: Provides working knowledge of the role of IT-enabled innovation in financial markets to help students acquire an understanding of broad economic issues that are of wide applicability in many areas of FinTech. Both qualitative analysis and quantitative applications are explored.
MGMTMBA 245.restriction: Restriction: Master of Business Admin Degree students only.

MGMTMBA 247.name: Venture Capital and Private Equity
MGMTMBA 247.description: Geared to students who are seeking a career in finance and/or in working with venture capital firms, private equity/buyout firms, investment banks, commercial lenders, mezzanine fund investors, corporate finance, and entrepreneurial firms.
MGMTMBA 247.restriction: Restriction: Master of Business Admin Degree students only.

MGMTMBA 248.name: Corporate Valuation
MGMTMBA 248.description: Studies cases that expand concepts covered in the introductory corporate finance course and focuses on estimating the value of firms and projects in diverse settings.
MGMTMBA 248.prereqString: Prerequisite: (MGMTMBA 209A or MGMT FE 209A) and (MGMTMBA 209B or MGMT FE 209B)
MGMTMBA 248.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Master of Business Admin Degree students only.

MGMTMBA 250.name: Consumer Behavior
MGMTMBA 250.description: Examines the consumer decision-making process with an emphasis on application of concepts and research findings from behavioral sciences for solution of marketing problems. Includes models of consumer decision-making, information processing theories, and sociological influences on consumer decision-making.
MGMTMBA 250.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Master of Business Admin Degree students only.

MGMTMBA 251A.name: Marketing Research
MGMTMBA 251A.description: Covers conducting marketing research to generate consumer insights that will drive sales, market share, and profitability and/or realize other quantitative objectives. Discusses problem formulation, data collection, statistical analyses, formulating managerial recommendations, implementation, and how research is used by companies.
MGMTMBA 251A.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Master of Business Admin Degree students only.

MGMTMBA 252D.name: New Product Development
MGMTMBA 252D.description: Designed to introduce the new product development process and techniques to identify markets, develop new product ideas, measure consumer preferences, position and design new products, as well as test them prior to launch. Analytical thinking and techniques are emphasized.
MGMTMBA 252D.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Master of Business Admin Degree students only.

MGMTMBA 254.name: Global Marketing
MGMTMBA 254.description: Provides an understanding of the problems and perspectives of marketing across national boundaries, and develops analytical abilities for structuring and controlling marketing programs related to overseas business. Financial, legal, and cultural barriers to international marketing are emphasized.
MGMTMBA 254.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Master of Business Admin Degree students only.

MGMTMBA 262.name: Managing Nonprofits
MGMTMBA 262.description: Focuses on the similarities and differences between for-profit and nonprofit organizations, with emphasis on the management of nonprofits.  Topics include: marketing, fundraising, staffing, management/director relationships, use of volunteers, and emerging career opportunities.
MGMTMBA 262.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Master of Business Admin Degree students only.

MGMTMBA 263.name: Economics of Information
MGMTMBA 263.description: Provides students with an understanding of fundamental economic principles governing information technology industries. Particularly, implications for optimal pricing strategies, determinants/consequences of market structure, and the role and rationale for government intervention and the implications for business strategy.
MGMTMBA 263.restriction: Restriction: Master of Business Admin Degree students only. Graduate students only.

MGMTMBA 270.name: Data Camp for Managers
MGMTMBA 270.description: Provides an overview of R for basic data analytics and visualization with hands-on training using Data Camp. This project is meant to foreshadow the analysis that students will be doing in their electives.
MGMTMBA 270.restriction: Restriction: Master of Business Admin Degree students only. Graduate students only.

MGMTMBA 274.name: Data and Programming for Analytics
MGMTMBA 274.description: Challenges and teaches students to handle data that come in a variety of forms and sizes. Guides students through the whole data management process, from initial data acquisition to final data analysis.
MGMTMBA 274.restriction: Restriction: Master of Business Admin Degree students only. Graduate students only.

MGMTMBA 276.name: Analytics and Technology Consulting
MGMTMBA 276.description: Focuses on elements of analytics and personalized engagement. Students work on a project using a real-life business problem and data to get hands-on understanding.
MGMTMBA 276.restriction: Restriction: Master of Business Admin Degree students only. Graduate students only.

MGMTMBA 279.name: Digital Strategies and Markets
MGMTMBA 279.description: Examines how online social media are impacting organizations and markets. Topics include collective intelligence, online social influence, social networks, and social media monetization. The target audience consists of students interested in IT consulting, competitive strategy, marketing, and entrepreneurship.
MGMTMBA 279.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Master of Business Admin Degree students only.

MGMTMBA 283.name: Decision Analysis
MGMTMBA 283.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Master of Business Admin Degree students only.

MGMTMBA 285.name: Supply Chain Analytics
MGMTMBA 285.description: Introduces students to the use of advanced analytics and data-driven methods to successfully manage uncertainty in supply chains, meeting customer needs in the most timely and cost effective manner, and driving business disruptions through innovations.
MGMTMBA 285.restriction: Restriction: Master of Business Admin Degree students only. Graduate students only.

MGMTMBA 287.name: Project Management
MGMTMBA 287.description: Examines the fundamental components of project management and its role in the modern corporation. Emphasis on how to initiate, implement, control, and terminate a project. Use of computer package for project management.
MGMTMBA 287.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Master of Business Admin Degree students only.

MGMTMBA 288.name: Predictive Analytics for Business
MGMTMBA 288.description: Deals with predicting entities, such as demand for a product or service (forecasting) and predicting membership of known groups (classification). Blends methodologies of forecasting and data mining and focuses on the application of these methods to managerial problems and decision-making.
MGMTMBA 288.restriction: Restriction: Master of Business Admin Degree students only. Graduate students only.

MGMTMBA 290.name: Field Studies in Management
MGMTMBA 290.description: Each quarter a number of special topic seminars are offered in the 290 series.  Examples of possible topics include Communication in Organizations, Power and Authority in Organizations, International Management, Health Care Administration, Real Estate Development.
MGMTMBA 290.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Master of Business Admin Degree students only.

MGMTMBA 292.name: Business Law
MGMTMBA 292.description: Detailed study from a business viewpoint of contract theories, assignments, delegation of duties, third-party beneficiary contracts, defenses to consensual contracts, types of conditions, methods of excusing conditions, remedies, and types of damages.
MGMTMBA 292.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Master of Business Admin Degree students only.

MGMTMBA 293.name: Biotech Management
MGMTMBA 293.description: Taught jointly by Bio Sci and Merage School faculty, the course addresses fundamental aspects within, and associated with, the biotechnology industry. Curriculum is focused largely on management issues, including finance, product development, pharmaceuticals, project management, regulatory affairs, and ethics.
MGMTMBA 293.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Biotechnology Majors only.

MGMTMBA 294.name: Edge
MGMTMBA 294.description: Edge explores the crucial roles of external forces - globalization, technology, shifting demographics - as transformative catalysts for change - opening markets, erasing boundaries, and transforming industries. This course prepares future business leaders to innovate and compete successfully.
MGMTMBA 294.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Master of Business Admin Degree students only.

MGMTMBA 295B.name: Miicromarketing with Digital Footprints
MGMTMBA 295B.description: How businesses use digital footprints from household data and point-of-purchase data to customize product offerings and delivery, store locations, advertising, and promotions to households and neighborhoods with the highest market potential. Hands-on experience with Geographic Information System (GIS) mapping software.
MGMTMBA 295B.restriction: Restriction: Master of Business Admin Degree students only. Graduate students only.

MGMTMBA 298.name: Merage Consulting Projects
MGMTMBA 298.description: Provides students the opportunity to put into practice concepts, skills, and tools acquired in other parts of the M.B.A. program. Seminars augment internship experiences with analyses of relevant administrative issues.

MGMTMBA 299.name: Individual Study
MGMTMBA 299.description: Individual study under the direction of the selected faculty member.

MGMTPHD 291.name: Ph.D. Special Topics Seminar
MGMTPHD 291.description: Each quarter a number of special topic seminars are offered in the 291 series for Ph.D. students. Examples include topics such as methods seminar, experimental design, qualitative research, structural equation modeling.

MGMTPHD 292.name: Pre-Colloquium Seminar
MGMTPHD 292.description: Seeks to facilitate discussion of upcoming Colloquium research papers increasing the likelihood that Ph.D. students are active participants in all of the Colloquia. Active participation enhances exposure of Ph.D. students to visiting scholars.
MGMTPHD 292.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Management Majors only.

MGMTPHD 297A.name: Doctoral Proseminar
MGMTPHD 297A.description: Analysis of the central theories and theoretical controversies in the field of management. Examination of the formal education for managerial careers and exploration of issues relating to professional careers in research and scholarship in the field of management.

MGMTPHD 297B.name: University Teaching
MGMTPHD 297B.description: Designed to prepare students for teaching career

MGMTPHD 297D.name: Philosophy of Science
MGMTPHD 297D.description: Provides exposure to fundamental issues regarding how knowledge is created, defended, and replaced both in the natural and social sciences. Covers current debates on the meaning of the term “scientific” and the validity of the scientific method.

MGMTPHD 297F.name: Doctoral Research Methods
MGMTPHD 297F.description: An introduction to the fundamentals of social science research: theory development, research design, methods, data management, and writing for scholarly publications
MGMTPHD 297F.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Management Majors only.

MGMTPHD 297H.name: Experimental Design
MGMTPHD 297H.description: Advanced course provides experience in planning and implementing an experiment or quasi-experiment, including choice of topic, study design, data analysis, and manuscript preparation.  Data analysis topics include ANOVA, ANCOVA, repeated measures, logistic regression, chi-square, and tests of mediation.

MGMTPHD 297I.name: Applied Multivariate Statistics
MGMTPHD 297I.description: Provides an overview of the most common techniques for multivariate analysis: principal component analysis, factor analysis, cluster analysis, MANOVA, regression with continuous variables, and regression with discrete variables.

MGMTPHD 297K.name: Advanced Qualitative Methods: Analyzing Qualitative Data
MGMTPHD 297K.description: Introduction to the theory and practice of analyzing qualitative data. Students must have already learned about data collection and research design for qualitative research and must have qualitative data they can analyze.

MGMTPHD 297L.name: Writing for Scholarly Publication
MGMTPHD 297L.description: Introduces methods for planning and carrying out scholarly writing.

MGMTPHD 297M.name: SAS Boot Camp
MGMTPHD 297M.description: Teaches basics of SAS programming for empirical research. No prior knowledge of SAS or other computer programming language is required. Provides knowledge and tools to replicate an empirical study and learn how to perform very advanced data procedures.

MGMTPHD 297Q.name: Game-Theoretic Models for Management Research
MGMTPHD 297Q.description: Introduces some classic game-theoretic models for management research. It is about modeling strategic interactions between business competitors and/or partners in an analytical framework.  Various applications will be discussed, e.g., pricing strategies, business alliances, e-commerce, negotiations, and contracts, etc.

MGMTPHD 297R.name: Theories of Power and Empowerment
MGMTPHD 297R.description: Studies different ways of thinking about power and its uses. Explores theories of power that inform various notions of empowerment, including resistance, participatory democracy, and workplace empowerment.

MGMTPHD 297T.name: Decision Theory
MGMTPHD 297T.description: Decision theories and preference models: How models are elicited or theories are experimentally tested, relevance to different management research areas, alternative theories, applications in management practice, and interpretations for the general public.

MGMTPHD 297U.name: Foundational Theories of Organizations
MGMTPHD 297U.description: Covers major economic and sociological perspectives guiding the study of organizations (i.e., transaction cost economics, agency theory, institutional theories, organizational ecology, network and diffusion theories, behavioral theories, resource dependence), and examines how different theoretical perspectives are tested.

MGMTPHD 297V.name: Information, Psychology, and Social Processes
MGMTPHD 297V.description: In the marketplace for ideas, which succeed and which fail? How do ideas and information spread between individuals, and how do populations of ideas evolve? This course reviews recent research on these issues and applications to business.

MGMTPHD 297W.name: Establishing Your Academic Career
MGMTPHD 297W.description: Overview of the best practices for succeeding in an academic career. Presenting oneself in conversation, in written documents, in research talks, and in teaching.

MGMTPHD 299.name: Individual Directed Study
MGMTPHD 299.description: Individual study under the direction of a selected faculty member.

MOL BIO 200A.name: Research in Molecular Biology and Biochemistry
MOL BIO 200A.description: Individual research with Molecular Biology and Biochemistry faculty.

MOL BIO 200B.name: Research in Molecular Biology and Biochemistry
MOL BIO 200B.description: Individual research with Molecular Biology and Biochemistry faculty.

MOL BIO 200C.name: Research in Molecular Biology and Biochemistry
MOL BIO 200C.description: Individual research with Molecular Biology and Biochemistry faculty.

MOL BIO 200R.name: Research in Developmental & Cell Biology for First-year Students
MOL BIO 200R.description: Independent research within the laboratories of graduate training faculty in the Department of Molecular Biology and Biochemistry for first-year Ph.D. students.

MOL BIO 201A.name: Seminars in Molecular Biology & Biochemistry
MOL BIO 201A.description: Presentation of research from department laboratories or, when pertinent, of other recent developments.

MOL BIO 201B.name: Seminars in Molecular Biology & Biochemistry
MOL BIO 201B.description: Presentation of research from department laboratories or, when pertinent, of other recent developments.

MOL BIO 201C.name: Seminars in Molecular Biology & Biochemistry
MOL BIO 201C.description: Presentation of research from department laboratories or, when pertinent, of other recent developments.

MOL BIO 202A.name: Tutorial in Molecular Biology and Biochemistry
MOL BIO 202A.description: Tutorials in the area of research of a particular professor which relate current research to the literature. May be conducted as journal clubs.

MOL BIO 202B.name: Tutorial in Molecular Biology and Biochemistry
MOL BIO 202B.description: Tutorials in the area of research of a particular professor which relate current research to the literature.  May be conducted as journal clubs.

MOL BIO 202C.name: Tutorial in Molecular Biology and Biochemistry
MOL BIO 202C.description: Tutorials in the area of research of a particular professor which relate current research to the literature. May be conducted as journal clubs.

MOL BIO 203.name: Nucleic Acid Structure and Function
MOL BIO 203.description: Structure and chemistry of nucleic acids. Relationship between these properties and the mechanisms of fundamental processes such as replication and repair, RNA-mediated catalysis, formation and regulation of higher order chromatin structure and recombination.
MOL BIO 203.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI 98 and BIO SCI 99 and CHEM 51A and CHEM 51B and CHEM 51C

MOL BIO 204.name: Protein Structure and Function
MOL BIO 204.description: The structure and properties of proteins, enzymes, and their kinetic properties.
MOL BIO 204.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI 98 and BIO SCI 99 and CHEM 51C

MOL BIO 205.name: Molecular Virology
MOL BIO 205.description: Primary research data on the major DNA and RNA viruses emphasizing strategies of regulation of gene expression. Utilization of viruses as molecular biological tools. Graduate-level knowledge of the biochemistry and molecular biology of macromolecules is required.
MOL BIO 205.prereqString: Prerequisite: MOL BIO 203 and MOL BIO 204

MOL BIO 211.name: Structural Biology
MOL BIO 211.description: Basic principles of magnetic resonance, Xray crystallography, and CryoEM toward the determination of high-resolution biomolecular structures.

MOL BIO 213.name: Literature in Nucleic Acid Structure and Function
MOL BIO 213.description: Exploration and critical analysis of recent primary scientific literature in structure, properties, and biological mechanisms involving nucleic acids.

MOL BIO 214.name: Literature in Protein Structure and Function
MOL BIO 214.description: Exploration and critical analysis of recent primary scientific literature in structure and properties of proteins, enzymes, and their kinetic properties.

MOL BIO 215.name: Integrative Immunology
MOL BIO 215.description: Lectures and student presentations of primary literature. The main goal is to achieve a basic understanding of the cellular and molecular basis of innate and adaptive immunity, and how immune function is coordinated at a systems level.

MOL BIO 217A.name: Principles of Cancer Biology I
MOL BIO 217A.description: Oncogenes and tumor suppressor genes are studied from molecular viewpoints. Also studies their role in cancer
MOL BIO 217A.prereqString: Prerequisite: MOL BIO 203 and MOL BIO 204

MOL BIO 217B.name: Principles of Cancer Biology II
MOL BIO 217B.description: Topics include cancer cell growth and metastasis, chemical carcinogenesis, and cancer genetics and epidemiology. Designed for graduate students interested in cancer research. Format includes lectures and student-led discussions.
MOL BIO 217B.prereqString: Prerequisite: MOL BIO 203 and MOL BIO 204

MOL BIO 218.name: Clinical Cancer
MOL BIO 218.description: Designed to acquaint students in basic life science with clinical cancer.

MOL BIO 220.name: Structure & Synthesis of Biological Macromolecules Journal Club
MOL BIO 220.description: Advanced topics in macromolecular struture and synthesis as related to biological problems.

MOL BIO 221.name: Advanced Topics in Immunology
MOL BIO 221.description: Literature-based, interactive discussions focused on review of seminal historic and recent immunology literature. Student responsibilities include reading, critical evaluation, and discussion of manuscripts.

MOL BIO 221L.name: Advanced Immunology Laboratory
MOL BIO 221L.description: An advanced course in immunology for graduate students enrolled in the Biotechnology master's program. Emphasis is placed on learning modern techniques in immunology such as ELISAs, western blotting, immunofluorescent staining assays.

MOL BIO 223.name: Introduction to Computational Biology
MOL BIO 223.description: The use of theories and methods based on computer science, mathematics, and physics in molecular biology and biochemistry. Basics in biomolecular modeling. Analysis of sequence and structural data of biomolecules. Analysis of biomolecular functions.

MOL BIO 227.name: Immunlology Journal Club
MOL BIO 227.description: Advanced topics in immunology as related to an understanding of human disease.

MOL BIO 229.name: Research-in-Progress Seminars
MOL BIO 229.description: Two half-hour presentations by graduate students and postdoctorals to the department on their current research projects.

MOL BIO 235.name: Literature in Chemical and Structural Biology
MOL BIO 235.description: Exploration and critical analysis of recent primary scientific literature in chemical and structural biology.

MOL BIO 243.name: Topics in Stem Cells
MOL BIO 243.description: Presentation by participating faculty or guest lecturer that is open to the science community, followed by discussion of the lecture topic or a related topic. Students are responsible for presentations and readings.

MOL BIO 244.name: Principles of Genomics
MOL BIO 244.description: A survey course of the principal subfields of genomics and their applications to biological and health sciences that will cover genome assembly and annotation, genome structure, comparative genomics, population genomics, functional genomics, and medical genomics.

MOL BIO 248.name: Metallobiochemistry
MOL BIO 248.description: A review of the biochemistry of metallic elements emphasizing: methods for studying metals in biological systems

MOL BIO 250.name: Advanced Topics in Biotechnology - Nucleic Acids
MOL BIO 250.description: Supplements laboratory curriculum with scientific background behind experimental methods. Format consists of lectures and the presentation and analysis of relevant papers from the scientific literature.
MOL BIO 250.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Biotechnology Majors only.

MOL BIO 250L.name: Biotechnology Laboratory - Nucleic Acids
MOL BIO 250L.description: Nucleic acid techniques and recombinant DNA technology. Extraction and purification of nucleic acids, cloning and subcloning, PCR, site-directed mutagenesis, nucleic acid hybridization, additional associated procedures. Students must demonstrate accurate documentation of data (laboratory notebook) detailing experience and results.
MOL BIO 250L.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Biotechnology Majors only.

MOL BIO 251.name: Advanced Topics in Biotechnology - Protein Purification and Characterization
MOL BIO 251.description: Supplements laboratory curriculum with scientific background behind experimental methods. Format consists of lectures and the presentation and analysis of relevant papers from the scientific literature.
MOL BIO 251.prereqString:
Corequisite: MOL BIO 251L
Prerequisite: MOL BIO 250L and MOL BIO 250
MOL BIO 251.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Biotechnology Majors only.

MOL BIO 251L.name: Biotechnology Laboratory - Protein Purification and Characterization
MOL BIO 251L.description: Major techniques of handling proteins and antibodies. Protein engineering, expression and large-scale purification of recombinant proteins from bacteria, HPLC, antibody purification, western blotting, additional associated procedures. Students must demonstrate accurate documentation of data (laboratory notebook) detailing experience and results.
MOL BIO 251L.prereqString:
Corequisite: MOL BIO 251
Prerequisite: MOL BIO 250L and MOL BIO 250
MOL BIO 251L.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Biotechnology Majors only.

MOL BIO 252L.name: Biotechnology Management Laboratory
MOL BIO 252L.description: Overview of current methods in biotechnology, designed specifically for biotechnology graduate students. Organized into four distinct sections (nucleic acids, proteins, virology, and immunology). Students must demonstrate accurate documentation of data (laboratory notebooks) detailing experience and results.
MOL BIO 252L.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Biotechnology Majors only.

MOL BIO 253.name: Biotech Management
MOL BIO 253.description: Taught jointly by Bio Sci and Merage School faculty, the course addresses fundamental aspects within, and associated with, the biotechnology industry. Curriculum is focused largely on management issues, including finance, product development, pharmaceuticals, project management, regulatory affairs, and ethics.
MOL BIO 253.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Biotechnology Majors only.

MOL BIO 253L.name: Stem Cell Laboratory
MOL BIO 253L.description: Designed to prepare M.S. Biotechnology program students for a career in stem cell research. Laboratory training utilizes tissue culture, mouse and human embryonic stem cells, and is enhanced with didactic material and discussion.
MOL BIO 253L.prereqString: Prerequisite: MOL BIO 250L and MOL BIO 251L
MOL BIO 253L.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Biotechnology Majors only.

MOL BIO 268.name: Seminar in Systems Microbiology Research
MOL BIO 268.description: A research and journal club seminar that covers topics on bacteria and phage using approaches and principles from biology, engineering, and physics.
MOL BIO 268.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. Graduate students only.

MOL BIO 270.name: Science Communication Skills
MOL BIO 270.description: Development of effective communication skills, oral and written presentations. Topics range from the art of creating keynote slides to strategically crafting a personal story, culminating in a live presentation to an invited audience.

MOL BIO 291.name: Graduate School Fundamentals
MOL BIO 291.description: Lectures and discussions providing basic skills needed for success in Ph.D. graduate studies. Topics include formulating a hypothesis, experimental design, literature review, grant writing, oral communication, biostatistics, time management, and professional development.
MOL BIO 291.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Cellular and Molecular Biosci Majors only.

MOL BIO 292A.name: Scientific Communication
MOL BIO 292A.description: Small group meetings for graduate students to practice scientific writing, debate, and presentation skills.

MOL BIO 292B.name: Scientific Communication
MOL BIO 292B.description: Small group meetings for graduate students to practice scientific writing, debate, and presentation skills.

MOL BIO 292C.name: Scientific Communication
MOL BIO 292C.description: Small group meetings for graduate students to practice scientific writing, debate, and presentation skills.

MOL BIO 293A.name: Cancer Biology Journal Club
MOL BIO 293A.description: Focuses on molecular mechanisms that underlie the development and progression of cancers. Covers a variety of cancer-related research areas, such as cell cycle control, apoptosis, DNA repair, metastasis, angiogenesis, and others.

MOL BIO 293B.name: Cancer Biology Journal Club
MOL BIO 293B.description: Focuses on molecular mechanisms that underlie the development and progression of cancers. Covers a variety of cancer-related research areas, such as cell cycle control, apoptosis, DNA repair, metastasis, angiogenesis, and others.

MOL BIO 293C.name: Cancer Biology Journal Club
MOL BIO 293C.description: Focuses on molecular mechanisms that underlie the development and progression of cancers. Covers a variety of cancer-related research areas, such as cell cycle control, apoptosis, DNA repair, metastasis, angiogenesis, and others.

MOL BIO 295.name: Biomedical Research Methods
MOL BIO 295.description: Lectures and interactive discussions of research methods in modern biomedical science. Each week will focus on a different class of techniques, including molecular, biochemical, immunological, genomic, bioinformatics, microscopy, cancer biology, genome editing. One hour per week, grading based on attendance.
MOL BIO 295.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Cellular and Molecular Biosci Majors only.

MPAC 200A.name: Intermediate Accounting Intensive I
MPAC 200A.description: Designed to provide students with technical U.S. accounting theory and principles background necessary for graduate work in accounting. Current international accounting convergence issues and standards will be discussed on emerging topics.

MPAC 200B.name: Foundations of Taxation Intensive
MPAC 200B.description: Provides students with the basic concepts of federal income taxation applicable to all taxpayers. Specifically, principles of taxation for individuals, corporations, and partnerships are discussed.

MPAC 200C.name: Intermediate Accounting Intensive II and Special Topics
MPAC 200C.description: Designed to provide students with the technical U.S. accounting theory and principles background necessary for graduate work in accounting. Current international accounting convergence issues and standards will be discussed on emerging topics.

MPAC 200D.name: Auditing Intensive
MPAC 200D.description: Designed to provide students with an understanding of the fundamental principles, processes, and ethical considerations involved in the performance of a financial statement audit under U.S. auditing standards.

MPAC 230.name: Emerging Topics in Accounting
MPAC 230.description: Provides students with information and practical skills for success in the program and for professional accounting and business career planning, and with discussions of current issues confronting the accounting profession.

MPAC 231A.name: Financial Statement Analysis and Forecasting
MPAC 231A.description: Develops skills to analyze corporate financial reports. Topics include profitability, risk analysis, cash flow analysis, revenue and asset recognition, and forecasting. The skills are useful for students to evaluate financial reporting quality, detect earnings management, and predict firms' financial performance.

MPAC 231B.name: Advanced Financial Statement Analysis
MPAC 231B.description: Develops skills to analyze corporate financial reports with a focus on liabilities, stockholders' equity, and valuation. Topics include forecasting financial statements, cash flows- and earnings-based equity, and valuation models, accounting analysis of mergers and acquisitions, lease pensions, and derivatives.

MPAC 232.name: Taxes and Business Strategy
MPAC 232.description: Develops a student's ability to identify, understand, and evaluate tax-planning opportunities. The focus is on tax planning concepts and the effects of taxes on business decisions rather than on detailed tax rules, compliance, or legal research.

MPAC 233.name: Non-for-Profit Accounting
MPAC 233.description: Focuses on the accounting and reporting for governmental and non-for-profit entities. Topics include preparation of fund basis financial statements and related reporting and auditing issues. Use of non-financial performance measures for non-for-profit entities is also discussed.

MPAC 234.name: Accounting Policy and Research
MPAC 234.description: Considers issues in contemporary accounting standard setting and regulation by examining academic accounting research of the various issues. Enables students to develop their knowledge and better appreciate current debates in accounting.

MPAC 235.name: Advanced Managerial Accounting
MPAC 235.description: Design of cost information and systems used to plan and control organizational activities

MPAC 236.name: Forensic Accounting
MPAC 236.description: Elective course focuses on the principles, and application of forensic accounting.  Topics include the identification, detection, and prevention of fraud, valuations, damage calculations, and litigation support. The role of forensic accountants in the legal system will also be discussed.

MPAC 237.name: International Accounting
MPAC 237.description: An online course. A comprehensive study of differences between US GAAP and International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS).

MPAC 238.name: Advanced Auditing and Assurance Services
MPAC 238.description: Designed to provide advanced coverage of topics and emerging issues in auditing and assurance services. Provides a deeper understanding of the fundamental concepts of auditing, assurance services, and developing hot-topics within the auditing profession.
MPAC 238.prereqString: Prerequisite: Intermediate accounting and basic auditing.

MPAC 239.name: Ethics in Accounting and Business
MPAC 239.description: Designed to introduce students to the intellectual principles of ethical decision making by emphasizing the theories of ethics and their application in the business, and specifically, accounting professions. MPAC capstone course with a final comprehensive exam for the program.

MPAC 241.name: Accounting Internship
MPAC 241.description: Provides students with the opportunity to apply accounting knowledge through actual work experiences. The internship experience will provide students with knowledge of career opportunities, an understanding of how accounting plays in today’s business environment, and prepare students for success.

MPAC 290.name: Special Topic Seminars
MPAC 290.description: Studies in selected area of Accounting. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

MPAC 291.name: Professional Research and Communication
MPAC 291.description: Combines research of the professional accounting literature on a range of technical topics with a written communication and oral presentations of the findings.

MPAC 299.name: Individual Study
MPAC 299.description: Individual study under the direction of a selected faculty member.

MSE 60.name: Laboratory in Synthesis and Characterization of Materials
MSE 60.description: Synthesis and characterization of ceramic, polymer, and semiconductor materials. Connect the process, structure, properties, and performance to materials science knowledge in a hands-on laboratory setting. Materials fee.
MSE 60.restriction: Restriction: Materials Science and Engr Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

MSE 69.name: Electronic and Optical Properties in Materials
MSE 69.description: Covers the electronic, optical, and dielectric properties of crystalline and amorphous materials to provide a foundation of the underlying physical principles governing the properties of existing and emerging electronic and photonic materials.
MSE 69.prereqString: Prerequisite: PHYS 7D and PHYS 7E and (MATH 3A or ICS 6N) and MATH 3D and ENGR 54
MSE 69.restriction: Restriction: Materials Science and Engr Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

MSE 141.name: Nano-Scale Materials and Applications
MSE 141.description: Overview of the chemistry, physics, and applications of nanometer-scale materials. Explore the effects of composition, bonding, and confinement on physical properties of nanomaterials, their chemical syntheses, and their device physics in electronic, optoelectronic, and energy technologies.
MSE 141.prereqString: Prerequisite: (ENGR 1A or CHEM 1A or CHEM H2A) and ENGR 54 and MSE 69
MSE 141.restriction: Restriction: Biomedical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Chemical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Materials Science and Engr Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

MSE 151.name: Polymeric Materials
MSE 151.description: An introduction to physical aspects of polymers, including polymer molecular size and configuration, solution and bulk phase structural properties, mechanical properties including viscoelasticity and rheology, polymer synthesis methods, characterization techniques, processing methods, and examples from existing and emerging polymeric materials.
MSE 151.prereqString: Prerequisite: ENGR 54 and (MSE 165A or CBE 40C or MAE 91)
MSE 151.restriction: Restriction: Materials Science and Engr Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

MSE 155.name: Mechanical Behavior and Design Principles
MSE 155.description: Principles governing structure and mechanical behavior of materials, relationship relating microstructure and mechanical response with application to elasticity, plasticity, yielding, necking, creep, and fracture of materials. Introduction to experimental techniques to characterize the properties of materials. Design parameters.
MSE 155.restriction: Restriction: Mechanical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Materials Science and Engr Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Aerospace Engineering majors have second consideration for enrollment.

MSE 155L.name: Mechanical Behavior Laboratory
MSE 155L.description: Introduction to experimental techniques to characterize mechanical properties of materials. Emphasis on correlations between property and microstructure. Experiments include: plastic stability in tension, effect of grain size on flow stress, microstructural engineering.  Materials fee.
MSE 155L.restriction: Restriction: Materials Science and Engr Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

MSE 158.name: Ceramic Materials for Sustainable Energy
MSE 158.description: A technical elective for students interested in materials. Topics covered include structure and properties of ceramic materials, and design for sustainable energy applications.
MSE 158.restriction: Restriction: Materials Science and Engr Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Chemical Engineering majors have second consideration for enrollment.

MSE 163.name: Computer Techniques in Experimental Research
MSE 163.description: Principles and practical guidelines of automated materials testing. Computer fundamentals, programming languages, data acquisition and control hardware, interfacint techniques, programming strategies, data analysis, data storage, safeguard procedures.
MSE 163.restriction: Restriction: Materials Science and Engr Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Chemical Engineering majors have second consideration for enrollment.

MSE 164.name: X-ray Diffraction, Electron Microscopy, and Microanalysis
MSE 164.description: Material characterization using X-ray diffraction and scanning electron microscopy (SEM). Topics include X-ray diffraction and analysis
MSE 164.restriction: Restriction: Materials Science and Engr Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

MSE 164L.name: X-ray Diffraction, Electron Microscopy, and Microanalysis Lab
MSE 164L.description: Material characterization using X-ray diffraction and scanning electron microscopy (SEM). Topics include X-ray diffraction and analysis
MSE 164L.restriction: Restriction: Materials Science and Engr Majors only.

MSE 165A.name: Thermodynamics of Materials
MSE 165A.description: Treatment of the laws of thermodynamics and their application in understanding properties and equilibrium states of engineering materials. Develops relationships pertaining to multiphase equilibrium and presents graphical constructions for interpretation of phase diagrams. Statistical thermodynamics in relation to materials phenomena.
MSE 165A.restriction: Restriction: Materials Science and Engr Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

MSE 165B.name: Diffusion and Heat Transport in Materials
MSE 165B.description: Examines how kinetics affect materials development, behavior, and processing. Highlights the ways in which kinetics and diffusion are key to designing materials processing and heat treating strategies, with examples in various applied topics.
MSE 165B.prereqString: Prerequisite: ENGR 54 and (MSE 165A or CBE 40C or MAE 91). ENGR 54 with a grade of C- or better. MSE 165A with a grade of C- or better
MSE 165B.restriction: Restriction: Materials Science and Engr Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

MSE 165C.name: Materials Kinetics and Phase Transformations
MSE 165C.description: Treatment of the kinetics of solid-state reactions and reactions at interfaces. Thermodynamics and kinetics of phase transformations, including solidification processes, diffusional and diffusionless phase transformations.
MSE 165C.prereqString: Prerequisite: ENGR 54 and (MSE 165B or (CBE 120B and CBE 120C) or MAE 120). MSE 165B with a grade of C- or better
MSE 165C.restriction: Restriction: Materials Science and Engr Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

MSE 165CL.name: Laboratory in Materials Kinetics and Phase Transformations
MSE 165CL.description: Covers topics of practical application of the kinetics of solid state reactions, reactions at interfaces, and the thermodynamics and kinetics of phase transformations to common materials systems.
MSE 165CL.prereqString: Prerequisite: ENGR 54 and (MSE 165B or (CBE 120B and CBE 120C) or MAE 120). MSE 165B with a grade of C- or better
MSE 165CL.restriction: Restriction: Materials Science and Engr Majors only.

MSE 171.name: Green Engineering: Theory and Practice
MSE 171.description: Methods and impacts of selecting alternative technologies, processes, materials, chemicals, to reduce pollution, waste, and use of toxic substances, thereby creating “green,” environmentally responsible, sustainable solutions. Topics include environmental regulations, recycling, life-cycle assessment, economic analysis, design, green chemistry, and toxicology.
MSE 171.restriction: Restriction: Seniors only. Materials Science and Engr Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

MSE 173.name: Fundamentals of Materials Processing: How are Materials Processed to Make Things?
MSE 173.description: An in-depth knowledge of manufacturing processes with focus on the fundamentals of materials processing (heat flow, mass flow, fluid flow, etc.). Processing fundamentals that apply to the three main classes of engineering materials: metals, ceramics, and polymers.
MSE 173.restriction: Restriction: Materials Science and Engr Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

MSE 174.name: Composite Materials Design
MSE 174.description: Introduction to fiber-reinforced composites for mechanical applications. Properties of reinforcing fibers. Manufacture of fibers and composites. Micromechanics of fiber composites. Strength criteria and failure modes. Macromechanics in design of laminated composite structures.

MSE 175.name: Design Failure Investigation
MSE 175.description: Survey of mechanisms by which devices fail, including overload, fatigue, corrosion, and wear. Use of fractography and other evidence to interpret failure modes and specify design/manufacturing changes. Students redesign failed parts or structures based on actual parts and/or case histories.
MSE 175.restriction: Restriction: Materials Science and Engr Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Chemical Engineering majors have second consideration for enrollment.

MSE 176.name: Surface and Adhesion Science
MSE 176.description: Structure, thermodynamics of, kinetics, and reactions on surfaces. Surface electronic and mechanical properties and characterization of all classes of materials including metals, semiconductors, ceramics, polymers, and soft materials. Adhesion between different materials is also addressed.
MSE 176.prereqString: Prerequisite: (CBE 110 or MSE 165C) and (MSE 141 or MSE 69)
MSE 176.restriction: Restriction: Chemical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Materials Science and Engr Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

MSE 189A.name: Senior Design Project I
MSE 189A.description: Group supervised senior design projects that deal with materials selection in engineering design and that involve case studies in ethics, safety, design, failure modes, new products, and patents. Activities conclude with a presentation of the projects. Materials fee.
MSE 189A.prereqString: Prerequisite: ENGR 54 and MSE 155 and MSE 60 and MSE 165C
MSE 189A.restriction: Restriction: Seniors only. Materials Science and Engr Majors only. MSE 189A, MSE 189B, and MSE 189C must be taken in the same academic year.

MSE 189B.name: Senior Design Project II
MSE 189B.description: Group supervised senior design projects that deal with materials selection in engineering design and that involve case studies in ethics, safety, design, failure modes, new products, and patents. Activities conclude with a presentation of the projects. Materials fee.
MSE 189B.restriction: Restriction: Seniors only. Materials Science and Engr Majors only. MSE 189A, MSE 189B, and MSE 189C must be taken in the same academic year.

MSE 189C.name: Senior Design Project III
MSE 189C.description: Group supervised senior design projects that deal with materials selection in engineering design and that involve case studies in ethics, safety, design, failure modes, new products, and patents. Activities conclude with a presentation of the projects. Materials fee.
MSE 189C.restriction: Restriction: Seniors only. Materials Science and Engr Majors only. MSE 189A, MSE 189B, and MSE 189C must be taken in the same academic year.

MSE 190.name: Materials Selection and Design
MSE 190.restriction: Restriction: Materials Science and Engr Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

MSE 191.name: Materials Outreach
MSE 191.description: Demonstrates major concepts in Materials Science and Engineering. Concepts of materials engineering covered include deformation in crystalline solids, effects of heat treatment on mechanical properties, thermal barrier materials, composites design, mechanical behavior of polymers, superconductivity in ceramics.
MSE 191.restriction: Restriction: Materials Science and Engr Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

MSE 195.name: Special Topics in Materials Science and Engineering
MSE 195.description: Studies in selected areas of Materials Science and Engineering. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

MSE 198.name: Group Study
MSE 198.description: Group study of selected topics in engineering.

MSE 199.name: Individual Study
MSE 199.description: Supervised independent reading, research, or design for undergraduate Engineering majors. Students taking individual study for design credit are to submit a written paper to the instructor and to the Undergraduate Student Affairs Office in the School of Engineering.
MSE 199.restriction: Restriction: Materials Science and Engr Majors only.

MSE 199P.name: Individual Study
MSE 199P.description: Supervised independent reading, research, or design for undergraduate Engineering majors. Students taking individual study for design credit are to submit a written paper to the instructor and to the Undergraduate Student Affairs Office in the School of Engineering.

MSE 200.name: Crystalline Solids: Structure, Imperfections, and Properties
MSE 200.description: Principles and concepts underlying the study of advanced materials including alloys, composites, ceramics, semiconductors, polymers, ferroelectrics, and magnetics. Crystal structure and defects, surface and interface properties, thermodynamics and kinetics of phase transformations, and material processing, related to fundamental material properties.

MSE 201A.name: Critical Analysis and Technical Communication I
MSE 201A.description: Develop an understanding of the process to conduct research. Topics include performing analytical analysis of the scientific literature, formation of a hypothesis, defining investigations to validate hypothesis, communicating analysis in written form, writing a research proposal.

MSE 201B.name: Critical Analysis and Technical Communication II
MSE 201B.description: Develop oral presentation skills and skills to understand significance of published research.  Topics include performing critical and analytical analysis of the scientific literature, connecting core course content with experimental/theoretical methods in the scientific literature, and communicating analysis in oral form.

MSE 205.name: Materials Physics
MSE 205.description: Covers the electronic, optical, and dielectric properties of crystalline materials to provide a foundation of the underlying physical principles of governing the properties of existing and emerging electronic and photonic materials.

MSE 241.name: Nano-Scale Materials and Applications
MSE 241.description: Overview of the chemistry, physics, and applications of nanometer-scale materials. Explore the effects of composition, bonding, and confinement on physical properties of nanomaterials, their chemical syntheses, and their device physics in electronic, optoelectronic, and energy technologies.

MSE 249.name: Special Topics in Materials Science and Engineering
MSE 249.description: Studies in selected areas of Materials Science and Engineering. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

MSE 254.name: Polymer Science and Engineering
MSE 254.description: An introduction to physical aspects of polymers, including configuration and conformation of polymer chains and characterization techniques

MSE 255A.name: Design with Ceramic Materials
MSE 255A.description: Dependence of ceramic properties on bonding, crystal structure, defects, and microstructure. Ceramic manufacturing technology. Survey of physical properties. Strength, deformation, and fracture of ceramics. Mechanical design with brittle, environment-sensitive materials exhibiting time-dependent strengths.

MSE 256A.name: Mechanical Behavior of Engineering Materials
MSE 256A.description: Principles governing structure and mechanical behavior of materials, relationship relating microstructure and mechanical response with application to elasticity, plasticity, creep, and fatigue, study of rate-controlling mechanisms and failure modes, fracture of materials.

MSE 256B.name: Fracture of Engineering Materials
MSE 256B.description: Fracture mechanics and its application to engineering materials. Elastic properties of cracks, the stress intensity factor, the crack tip plastic zone, the J integral approach, fracture toughness testing, the crack tip opening displacement, fracture at high temperatures, fatigue crack growth.

MSE 259.name: Transmission Electron Microscopy
MSE 259.description: The theory and operation of the transmission electron microscope (TEM), including the basic construction, electron optics, electron diffraction and reciprocal space, formation of image and electron diffraction information, microanalysis, and specimen preparation.

MSE 262.name: Grain Boundaries and Interfaces in Nanocrystalline Materials
MSE 262.description: Structure and character of grain boundaries and interfaces in solids including nanocrystalline materials. Role of grain boundaries in chemical segregation, fracture, deformation, creep, conductivity, diffusion, and grain growth. Experimental techniques and computational methods used to characterize and model grain boundaries.

MSE 264.name: Scanning Electron Microscopy
MSE 264.description: The theory and operation of the scanning electron microscope (SEM) and X-ray microanalysis. Topics covered include the basic design and electron optics, electron beam - specimen interactions, image formation and interpretation, X-ray spectrometry, and other related topics and techniques.

MSE 265.name: Phase Transformations
MSE 265.description: Advanced thermodynamics and kinetics of phase transformations and phase transitions.

MSE 267.name: Seminar in Systems Microbiology Research
MSE 267.description: A research and journal club seminar that covers topics on bacteria and phage using approaches and principles from biology, engineering, and physics.
MSE 267.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. Graduate students only.

MSE 271.name: Green Engineering: Theory and Practice
MSE 271.description: Methods and impacts of selecting alternative technologies, processes, materials, chemicals, to reduce pollution, waste, and use of toxic substances, thereby creating “green,” environmentally responsible, sustainable solutions. Topics include environmental regulations, recycling, life-cycle assessment, economic analysis, design, green chemistry, and toxicology.

MSE 273.name: Electroceramics & Solid State Electrochemical Systems
MSE 273.description: Theory, underlying principles, experimental techniques, and applications of electroceramics and solid-state electrochemical systems. Links solid state physics, atomic structure, thermodynamics, defect chemistry, and transport processes to electrical properties of ceramics - spanning from insulators to fast-ion conductors and HT superconductors.

MSE 276.name: Surface and Adhesion Science
MSE 276.description: Structure, thermodynamics of, kinetics, and reactions on surfaces. Surface electronic and mechanical properties and characterization of all classes of materials including metals, semiconductors, ceramics, polymers, and soft materials. Adhesion between different materials is also addressed.

MSE 295.name: Seminar in Engineering
MSE 295.description: Seminars by individual faculty in major fields of interest.

MSE 296.name: Master of Science Thesis Research
MSE 296.description: Individual research or investigation conducted in preparation for the thesis required for the M.S. degree in Engineering.

MSE 297.name: Doctor of Philosophy Dissertation Research
MSE 297.description: Individual research or investigation conducted in preparation for the dissertation required for the Ph.D. degree in Engineering.

MSE 298.name: Seminars in Materials Science and Engineering
MSE 298.description: Presentation of advanced topics and reports of current research efforts in Materials Science and Engineering.

MSE 299.name: Individual Research
MSE 299.description: Individual research or investigation under the direction of an individual faculty member.

MUSIC 3.name: Introduction to Music
MUSIC 3.description: Introduction to musical concepts and active listening skills. Students develop musical understanding through critical readings, selected repertoire, fundamental concepts related to rhythm, pitch, and genre.  Students apply those concepts to music from a wide range of historical and cultural origins.

MUSIC 4.name: Introduction to Opera
MUSIC 4.description: Introduces students with no musical background to the dramatic and performance conventions of opera, and suggests ways of developing a critical stance vis-a-vis the social, political, gender-related and moral conflicts that are presented by composers and librettists.

MUSIC 5.name: Popular Music in the United States
MUSIC 5.description: Examines the cultural, social, political, and economic dimensions of popular music in the United States over the last century and a half, with an emphasis on matters related to class, race, ethnicity, and gender.

MUSIC 8.name: The Beatles and the Sixties
MUSIC 8.description: Through a study of the music of the Beatles, students are introduced to selected broader historical and cultural themes (e.g., race and music, gender and music, music and the counterculture) while developing an understanding of the basic elements of music.

MUSIC 9.name: Rock: The Early Years
MUSIC 9.description: Surveys the social and cultural fabric of the post-World War II United States (from the late 1940s through the early 1970s) as seen through the prism of music - rock and roll music.

MUSIC 10.name: Piano for Majors
MUSIC 10.description: For Music majors with little or no piano experience. Provides the necessary background for realizing keyboard exercises required in the theory and harmony courses, and develops skills to play and sight-read simple music from different periods.
MUSIC 10.restriction: Restriction: Music Majors only. Music - Performance Majors only.

MUSIC 15A.name: Musicianship I
MUSIC 15A.description: Interval and chord quality identification, melodic and harmonic dictation, tonal and chromatic sight-singing, and rhythmic reading and dictation.
MUSIC 15A.restriction: Restriction: Music Majors only. Music - Performance Majors only.

MUSIC 15B.name: Musicianship II
MUSIC 15B.description: Interval and chord quality identification, melodic and harmonic dictation, tonal and chromatic sight-singing, and rhythmic reading and dictation.
MUSIC 15B.prereqString:
Corequisite: MUSIC 16B
Prerequisite: MUSIC 15A and MUSIC 16A. MUSIC 15A with a grade of C- or better. MUSIC 16A with a grade of C- or better
MUSIC 15B.restriction: Restriction: Music Majors only. Music - Performance Majors only.

MUSIC 15C.name: Musicianship III
MUSIC 15C.description: Interval and chord quality identification, melodic and harmonic dictation, tonal and chromatic sight-singing, and rhythmic reading and dictation.
MUSIC 15C.prereqString:
Corequisite: MUSIC 16C
Prerequisite: MUSIC 15B and MUSIC 16B. MUSIC 15B with a grade of C- or better. MUSIC 16B with a grade of C- or better
MUSIC 15C.restriction: Restriction: Music Majors only. Music - Performance Majors only.

MUSIC 16A.name: Music Theory
MUSIC 16A.description: Review of music fundamentals.  Triad and seventh chords, musical texture, chord spacing, embellishing tones, and introduction to diatonic harmony.  Part-writing and model composition with tonic, dominant seventh, and subdominant harmonies.
MUSIC 16A.restriction: Restriction: Music Majors only. Music - Performance Majors only.

MUSIC 16B.name: Music Theory
MUSIC 16B.description: Introduction to phrase structure.  Part-writing and harmonization with predominants, linear dominants, 6/4 embellishing chords, leading-tone and other diatonic seventh chords.  Advanced meters and rhythmic-metric dissonance. Diatonic sequence.  Introduction to tonicization and modulation through motion to V and III.
MUSIC 16B.prereqString:
Corequisite: MUSIC 15B
Prerequisite: MUSIC 15A and MUSIC 16A. MUSIC 15A with a grade of C- or better. MUSIC 16A with a grade of C- or better
MUSIC 16B.restriction: Restriction: Music Majors only. Music - Performance Majors only.

MUSIC 16C.name: Music Theory
MUSIC 16C.description: Tonicization and modulation to closely related keys.  Simple binary and ternary forms.  Voice-leading reductions and simple forms.  Diatonic sequence with seventh chords.  Introduction to chromatic harmony I: modal exchange and mixture chords, the Neapolitan and augmented sixth chords.
MUSIC 16C.prereqString:
Corequisite: MUSIC 15C
Prerequisite: MUSIC 15B and MUSIC 16B. MUSIC 15B with a grade of C- or better. MUSIC 16B with a grade of C- or better
MUSIC 16C.restriction: Restriction: Music Majors only. Music - Performance Majors only.

MUSIC 16D.name: Theory/Musicianship
MUSIC 16D.description: Extended homophonic and contrapuntal formal designs (continuous variations, rondo form, sonata form, invention, fugue). Embellishing chromatic chords, dominant prolongation, modulations to foreign keys, extended harmonies, chromatic sequence, chromatic voice-leading and symmetrical divisions of the octave.
MUSIC 16D.prereqString: Prerequisite: MUSIC 15C and MUSIC 16C. MUSIC 15C with a grade of C- or better. MUSIC 16C with a grade of C- or better
MUSIC 16D.restriction: Restriction: Music Majors only. Music - Performance Majors only.

MUSIC 21A.name: Keyboard Skills
MUSIC 21A.description: Designed to develop the foundational skills of sight-reading, harmonization, transposition, improvisation, figured bass realization, and score reading.
MUSIC 21A.restriction: Restriction: Lower-division students only. Music Majors only. Music - Performance Majors only.

MUSIC 21B.name: Keyboard Skills
MUSIC 21B.description: Designed to develop the foundational skills of sight-reading, harmonization, transposition, improvisation, figured bass realization, and score reading.
MUSIC 21B.restriction: Restriction: Lower-division students only. Music Majors only. Music - Performance Majors only.

MUSIC 21C.name: Keyboard Skills
MUSIC 21C.description: Designed to develop the foundational skills of sight-reading, harmonization, transposition, improvisation, figured bass realization, and score reading.
MUSIC 21C.restriction: Restriction: Lower-division students only. Music Majors only. Music - Performance Majors only.

MUSIC 25.name: Fundamentals of Music
MUSIC 25.description: Gain comprehensive insight into the fundamental concepts of music theory, including notation, harmony, and score analysis. Designed for students of all levels to improve their understanding of how music is composed, performed, and heard. Formerly MUSIC 25A.

MUSIC 40B.name: History of European Music: From the Renaissance through the Baroque
MUSIC 40B.description: An introduction to the analysis of musical styles and forms, to the sources for constructing music history and reconstructing historical music, and to J.S. Bach.
MUSIC 40B.prereqString: Prerequisite: MUSIC 16C. MUSIC 16C with a grade of C- or better
MUSIC 40B.restriction: Restriction: Music Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Music - Performance Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

MUSIC 40C.name: History of European Music: Hasse to Mahler
MUSIC 40C.description: An introduction to the analysis of musical styles and forms, and to the sources for constructing music history and reconstructing historical music, to Richard Wagner.
MUSIC 40C.prereqString: Prerequisite: MUSIC 40B. MUSIC 40B with a grade of D or better. Recommended: MUSIC 16D
MUSIC 40C.restriction: Restriction: Music Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Music - Performance Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

MUSIC 40D.name: 20th Century Music
MUSIC 40D.description: Survey of principal composers, movements, and compositional techniques of Western art music of the modern era.
MUSIC 40D.prereqString: Prerequisite: MUSIC 16C. MUSIC 16C with a grade of C- or better
MUSIC 40D.restriction: Restriction: Music Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Music - Performance Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

MUSIC 41.name: Major Composer
MUSIC 41.description: Study of the works of an important composer with emphasis on their significance in historical and social contexts. Composers selected represent a wide variety of historical periods, nationalities, and stylistic orientations.

MUSIC 42.name: Music and Gender
MUSIC 42.description: Explores various intersections between music and gender. Examines ways in which gender and sexuality have played a vital role in the creation, dissemination, and consumption of music ranging from medieval Christian mysticism to contemporary hip-hop artists.

MUSIC 44.name: Classical Music in Society
MUSIC 44.description: Examines some ways in which classical music has played an integral role in aspects of society. Studies pieces from different cultural, political, and historical contexts in order to understand how musical meaning is created and interpreted.

MUSIC 45.name: History of Film Music
MUSIC 45.description: Course provides an overview of film music history. Special emphasis will be placed on developing an analytic vocabulary for musical elements and cultivating an understanding of how music can function within a film.

MUSIC 46.name: Music in Multimedia
MUSIC 46.description: Students explore intersections between music and other media forms through creating multimedia projects, readings, lectures, and discussion. Students produce music, edit video, increase media literacy, and study theories behind how music communicates meaning.

MUSIC 47.name: Introductory Topics in Music Technology
MUSIC 47.description: Introductory topics in electronic music, digital audio, and other aspects of music technology.

MUSIC 48.name: Introductory Topics in Music and Culture
MUSIC 48.description: Examines music and musical practices in different historical periods, societies, and cultural settings.

MUSIC 51.name: Music Technology and Computers
MUSIC 51.description: A study of the influence of technology on the musical culture and aesthetics from the 20th century to the present, with particular emphasis on the role of the computer. Work includes lectures, readings, listenings, discussions, demonstrations, writing, and experimentation.

MUSIC 70.name: Guitar, Lute, and Other Plucked Instruments for Music Majors

MUSIC 78.name: History of Jazz
MUSIC 78.description: Development of jazz from African and African American folk origins through blues, early jazz, swing, bebop, "cool" jazz, fusion, free jazz, and contemporary trends.
MUSIC 78.restriction: Restriction: Music Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Music - Performance Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

MUSIC H80.name: Experiments in Music
MUSIC H80.description: Scientists explain the cognition of music using experimental methodology
MUSIC H80.restriction: Restriction: Campuswide Honors Collegium students only.

MUSIC 82A.name: MAHUR-Pish Radif: Introduction to Classical Persian Music
MUSIC 82A.description: Survey of art music in Iran and basic structures of classical Persian music, with emphasis on MAHUR modal system and different instruments of classical Persian music. No musical experience required, but interest in vocal music is strongly recommended.

MUSIC 82B.name: HOMAYUN-Pish Radif: Introduction to Classical Persian Music
MUSIC 82B.description: Survey of art music in Iran and basic structures of classical Persian music, with emphasis on HOMAYUN modal system and famous musicians and performers of classical Persian music. No musical experience required, but interest in vocal music is strongly recommended.

MUSIC 82C.name: SHUR-Pish Radif: Introduction to Classical Persian Music
MUSIC 82C.description: Survey of art music in Iran and basic structures of classical Persian music, with emphasis on the SHUR modal system and different poetic rhythms in classical Persian music. No musical experience required, but interest in vocal music is strongly recommended.

MUSIC 122A.name: Piano Literature
MUSIC 122A.description: Survey of stringed keyboard literature from the English Virginalists through twentieth-century composers.  Historical, formal, and stylistic considerations of music presented. Performances by class participants and occasional outside guests.
MUSIC 122A.prereqString: Prerequisite: MUSIC 16A and MUSIC 16B and MUSIC 16C
MUSIC 122A.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. Music Majors only. Music - Performance Majors only.

MUSIC 122B.name: Piano Literature
MUSIC 122B.description: Survey of stringed keyboard literature from the English Virginalists through twentieth-century composers.  Historical, formal, and stylistic considerations of music presented. Performances by class participants and occasional outside guests.
MUSIC 122B.prereqString: Prerequisite: MUSIC 16A and MUSIC 16B and MUSIC 16C
MUSIC 122B.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. Music Majors only. Music - Performance Majors only.

MUSIC 122C.name: Piano Literature
MUSIC 122C.description: Survey of stringed keyboard literature from the English Virginalists through twentieth-century composers.  Historical, formal, and stylistic considerations of music presented. Performances by class participants and occasional outside guests.
MUSIC 122C.prereqString: Prerequisite: MUSIC 16A and MUSIC 16B and MUSIC 16C
MUSIC 122C.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. Music Majors only. Music - Performance Majors only.

MUSIC 126.name: Piano Pedagogy
MUSIC 126.description: The materials and methods of piano instruction are examined and evaluated.
MUSIC 126.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. Music Majors only. Music - Performance Majors only.

MUSIC 131.name: Post-Tonal Theory
MUSIC 131.description: Significant harmonic, rhythmic, and structural practices since 1900. Analysis and written work exploring free atonality and serialism
MUSIC 131.restriction: Restriction: Music Majors only. Music - Performance Majors only.

MUSIC 132.name: Jazz Theory
MUSIC 132.description: Study of jazz harmony and melody construction in improvisation.  Covered topics include terminology, chord symbols, notation, voicings, and scales as commonly used in jazz and popular  music.  Issues regarding tonality and ramifications of the blue scale are also examined.
MUSIC 132.restriction: Restriction: Music Majors only. Music - Performance Majors only.

MUSIC 136.name: Instrumentation
MUSIC 136.description: Ranges and capabilities of modern orchestral instruments. Exercise in writing for various combinations of wind, string, and percussion instruments and for full orchestra.
MUSIC 136.restriction: Restriction: Music Majors only. Music - Performance Majors only.

MUSIC 140.name: Topics in Medieval Music
MUSIC 140.prereqString: Prerequisite: MUSIC 40B. MUSIC 40B with a grade of D or better. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
MUSIC 140.restriction: Restriction: Music Majors only. Music - Performance Majors only.

MUSIC 141.name: Topics in Renaissance Music
MUSIC 141.prereqString: Prerequisite: MUSIC 40B. MUSIC 40B with a grade of D or better. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
MUSIC 141.restriction: Restriction: Music Majors only. Music - Performance Majors only.

MUSIC 142.name: Topics in Baroque Music
MUSIC 142.prereqString: Prerequisite: MUSIC 40B. MUSIC 40B with a grade of D or better. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
