PATH 200R.description: Independent research within the laboratories of graduate training faculty in Experimental Pathology for first-year Ph.D. students.

PATH 203A.name: Advanced Studies in Experimental Pathology
PATH 203A.description: A tutorial course for Ph.D. students in Experimental Pathology entailing attendance at Departmental seminars and critical reading of the scientific literature.

PATH 203B.name: Advanced Studies in Experimental Pathology
PATH 203B.description: A tutorial course for Ph.D. students in Experimental Pathology entailing attendance at Departmental seminars and critical reading of the scientific literature.

PATH 203C.name: Advanced Studies in Experimental Pathology
PATH 203C.description: A tutorial course for Ph.D. students in Experimental Pathology entailing attendance at Departmental seminars and critical reading of the scientific literature.

PATH 204A.name: Experimental Pathology Research Seminar
PATH 204A.description: Seminar series for graduate students in Experimental Pathology. Students attend seminars and, beginning in their third year of graduate study, present one formal seminar on their graduate research.

PATH 204B.name: Experimental Pathology Research Seminar
PATH 204B.description: Seminar series for graduate students in Experimental Pathology. Students attend seminars and, beginning in their third year of graduate study, present one formal seminar on their graduate research.

PATH 204C.name: Experimental Pathology Research Seminar
PATH 204C.description: Seminar series for graduate students in Experimental Pathology. Students attend seminars and, beginning in their third year of graduate study, present one formal seminar on their graduate research.

PATH 221.name: Immunopathogenic Mechanisms of Disease
PATH 221.description: Examination of the mechanisms underlying disease states mediated by immune dysregulation. Topics include mechanisms of immune evasion by cancer, diseases mediated by cytokine dysregulation, role of the microbiome of the GI tract and other disease sites, and adoptive T-cell therapy.

PATH 225.name: Molecular Mechanisms of Human Disease
PATH 225.description: Provides an overview of the molecular mechanisms of human diseases, including neurologic, hematologic, neoplastic, and infectious diseases. Students gain an understanding of these mechanisms, as well as models of human diseases.

PATH 227.name: Experimental Pathology Journal Club
PATH 227.description: Graduate-level course, which is open to all years, will involve the reading and discussion of papers, preferably written by the invited seminar speaker. Discussions will cover advanced topics in experimental pathology as related to an understanding of human disease.

PATH 240.name: Neuropathology
PATH 240.description: Covers genetic and molecular mechanisms of neurological diseases. A grounding in neuroanatomy and prior or simultaneous enrollment in Anatomy 210A or the equivalent is strongly recommended. Resident physicians and clinical fellows can audit the course.

PATH 292A.name: Scientific Communication
PATH 292A.description: Small group meetings for graduate students to practice scientific writing, debate, and presentation skills.

PATH 292B.name: Scientific Communication
PATH 292B.description: Small group meetings for graduate students to practice scientific writing, debate, and presentation skills.

PATH 292C.name: Scientific Communication
PATH 292C.description: Small group meetings for graduate students to practice scientific writing, debate, and presentation skills.

PATH 299.name: Dissertation in Experimental Pathology
PATH 299.description: Provided for the preparation and completion of the dissertation required for the Ph.D. degree.

PED GEN 200A.name: Introduction to Medical Genetics and Cytogenetics
PED GEN 200A.description: Covers current concepts regarding mitosis, meiosis, the cell cycle, and chromosome ultrastructure and function. Clinical disorders caused by chromosomal aneuploidy, duplication, and deletion, and principles of Mendelian, chromosomal, and multifactorial and nontraditional inheritance are presented and illustrated.

PED GEN 200B.name: Genetic Screening, Prenatal Development, and Human Teratology
PED GEN 200B.description: Principles and techniques of prenatal, neonatal, and carrier screening. Infertility, pregnancy, and delivery. Normal and abnormal prenatal growth and development. Reproductive and fetal effects of drugs, radiation, infections, and other environmental factors.
PED GEN 200B.restriction: Restriction: Medical students only. Genetic Counseling Majors only.

PED GEN 200C.name: Human Genetic Disorders
PED GEN 200C.description: Inheritance, diagnosis, natural history, management, and counseling considerations for commonly encountered genetic diseases, birth defects, and dysmorphic syndromes.
PED GEN 200C.restriction: Restriction: Medical students only. Genetic Counseling Majors only.

PED GEN 200D.name: Disorders due to Inborn Errors of Metabolism
PED GEN 200D.description: Aspects of biochemistry and metabolism are reviewed with special emphasis on genetic abnormalities which lead to inborn errors of metabolism. Diagnostic procedures, heterozygote detection, treatment, counseling issues, and prenatal diagnosis are reviewed.

PED GEN 200E.name: Molecular Genetics, Gene Mapping, and Genetic Linkage
PED GEN 200E.description: Derivation of different types of DNA probes and DNA libraries, restriction endonuclease polymorphisms, assignment of genes to chromosomes, and genetic linkage.  Emphasis on the use of recombinant DNA technologies and genetic analysis for diagnosis of human genetic disease.
PED GEN 200E.prereqString: Prerequisite: PED GEN 200A and PED GEN 200D

PED GEN 200F.name: Quantitative Genetics
PED GEN 200F.description: Quantitative aspects of human genetics, including population studies, segregation analysis, linkage, mapping, and genetic risk determination.

PED GEN 200G.name: Hereditary Cancer Counseling
PED GEN 200G.description: Issues in genetic counseling for cancer. Cancer biology
PED GEN 200G.restriction: Restriction: Medical students only. Genetic Counseling Majors only.

PED GEN 200H.name: Genetic Counselin Research Design
PED GEN 200H.description: Quantitative and qualitative methods for genetic counseling research. Reference management

PED GEN 200L.name: Cytogenetics Laboratory
PED GEN 200L.description: Practicum introducing methods of specimen collection, short-term lymphocyte and bone marrow culture, long-term fibroblast and amniocyte culture, harvesting and slide preparation, chromosome staining, microphotography, and darkroom techniques. Microscopic chromosome analysis, photographic karyotyping, and appropriate use of cytogenetic nomenclature are emphasized.

PED GEN 201A.name: Introduction to Genetic Counseling
PED GEN 201A.description: Through directed readings, observing patient evaluations, role-playing, and conducting intake interviews, students are introduced to the process of diagnosis, management, and counseling for genetic disease. Psychosocial issues, interviewing techniques, pedigree construction, clinical photography, and various other skills are addressed.
PED GEN 201A.restriction: Restriction: Medical students only. Genetic Counseling Majors only.

PED GEN 201B.name: Clinical Rotation I
PED GEN 201B.description: Provides extensive supervised experience in history taking, interviewing, and psychosocial assessment in the clinical genetics setting. Students independently perform telephone, office, and home-visit intake interviews, participate in counseling, and present cases at patient management conferences.
PED GEN 201B.restriction: Restriction: Medical students only. Genetic Counseling Majors only.

PED GEN 201C.name: Clinical Rotation II
PED GEN 201C.description: Provides further supervised experience in genetic counseling, case management, clinic administration and organization, and the use of community resources. Emphasis is on sharpening counseling skills and on developing a professional identity and code of ethics.
PED GEN 201C.restriction: Restriction: Medical students only. Genetic Counseling Majors only.

PED GEN 201D.name: Prenatal Diagnosis Counseling
PED GEN 201D.description: A practicum with extensive supervised experience in prenatal diagnosis counseling which provides the student with the opportunity to conduct genetic counseling sessions semi-independently and to further develop clinical skills.
PED GEN 201D.prereqString: Prerequisite: PED GEN 200A and PED GEN 200B and PED GEN 200C
PED GEN 201D.restriction: Restriction: Medical students only. Genetic Counseling Majors only.

PED GEN 202A.name: Counseling in Human Genetics: Theory and Methods
PED GEN 202A.description: Theoretical approaches, counseling models and methods, and bio-psychosocial assessment strategies are examined in the context of genetic counseling. Contract-setting, working alliance, the use of self and evaluation methods. Beginning counseling and peer supervision skills are practiced in class.
PED GEN 202A.restriction: Restriction: Medical students only. Genetic Counseling Majors only.

PED GEN 202B.name: Community Resources
PED GEN 202B.description: Lectures, guest speakers, and community visits acquaint genetic counselors with public and private health care and funding agencies, parent support and advocacy groups, and other resources to assist individuals and families confronted with genetic disorders, developmental disabilities, and birth defects.
PED GEN 202B.restriction: Restriction: Medical students only. Genetic Counseling Majors only.

PED GEN 202C.name: Ethical Issues in Human Genetics
PED GEN 202C.description: Explores major social, legal, and ethical issues in genetic counseling including those arising in genetic screening, prenatal diagnosis, informed consent, privacy and confidentiality, rights of the disabled, new genetic and reproductive technologies, treatment, and access to services.
PED GEN 202C.restriction: Restriction: Medical students only. Genetic Counseling Majors only.

PED GEN 203A.name: Counseling in Human Genetics: Putting Thought to Practice
PED GEN 203A.description: Builds upon the skills learned in previous courses emphasizing advanced counseling methods such as listening, empathy, and collaboration. The counselor's own self-awareness, ethical behaviors, and limits are explored. Individual, team, and group exercises are performed.
PED GEN 203A.restriction: Restriction: Medical students only. Genetic Counseling Majors only.

PED GEN 204A.name: Professional Skills Development
PED GEN 204A.description: Hones and augments existing competencies in genetic counseling through ongoing clinical experiences. Develops skills using computers for genetics applications, provision of community and professional education, and clinic administration. Further experience in genetics laboratories or specialty clinics may be elected.

PED GEN 204B.name: Professional Skills Development
PED GEN 204B.description: Hones and augments existing competencies in genetic counseling through ongoing clinical experiences. Develops skills using computers for genetics applications, provision of community and professional education, and clinic administration. Further experience in genetics laboratories or specialty clinics may be elected.

PED GEN 204C.name: Professional Skills Development
PED GEN 204C.description: Hones and augments existing competencies in genetic counseling through ongoing clinical experiences. Develops skills using computers for genetics applications, provision of community and professional education, and clinic administration. Further experience in genetics laboratories or specialty clinics may be elected.

PED GEN 295.name: Master's Thesis and Research Writing
PED GEN 295.description: Under the supervision of one or more faculty members, the student designs and conducts a research project or completes a case report. A problem in the cytogenetics, biochemical, clinical, psychosocial, or behavioral areas of medical genetics may be investigated.

PERSIAN 1A.name: Fundamentals in Persian
PERSIAN 1A.description: Designed for students with little or no exposure to Persian. Students learn the modern writing system and grammar of Persian. Facilitates basic reading, writing, and speaking skills and fosters college-level literacy in Persian culture.
PERSIAN 1A.restriction: Restriction: PERSIAN 1A and PERSIAN S1AB may not be taken for full credit.

PERSIAN 1B.name: Fundamentals in Persian
PERSIAN 1B.description: Designed for students with little or no exposure to Persian. Students learn the modern writing system and grammar of Persian. Facilitates basic reading, writing, and speaking skills and fosters college-level literacy in Persian culture.
PERSIAN 1B.prereqString: Prerequisite: PERSIAN 1A. PERSIAN 1A with a grade of C or better. Placement into PERSIAN 1B is also accepted.
PERSIAN 1B.restriction: Restriction: PERSIAN 1B and PERSIAN S1AB and PERSIAN S1BC may not be taken for full credit.

PERSIAN 1C.name: Fundamentals in Persian
PERSIAN 1C.description: Designed for students with little or no exposure to Persian. Students learn the modern writing system and grammar of Persian. Facilitates basic reading, writing, and speaking skills and fosters college-level literacy in Persian culture.
PERSIAN 1C.prereqString: Prerequisite: PERSIAN 1B or PERSIAN S1AB. PERSIAN 1B with a grade of C or better. PERSIAN S1AB with a grade of C or better. Placement into PERSIAN 1C is also accepted.
PERSIAN 1C.restriction: Restriction: PERSIAN 1C and PERSIAN S1BC may not be taken for full credit.

PERSIAN 2A.name: Intermediate Persian
PERSIAN 2A.description: Designed for students to advance their Persian language skills from introductory to intermediate level. Student will advance their understanding of grammar and syntax. Facilitates intermediate-level reading, writing, and speaking skills. Fosters college-level cultural literacy.
PERSIAN 2A.prereqString: Prerequisite: PERSIAN 1C or PERSIAN S1BC. PERSIAN 1C with a grade of C or better. PERSIAN S1BC with a grade of C or better. Placement into PERSIAN 2A is also accepted.
PERSIAN 2A.restriction: Restriction: School of Humanities students have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PERSIAN 2B.name: Intermediate Persian
PERSIAN 2B.description: Designed for students to advance their Persian language skills from introductory to intermediate level. Students will advance their understanding of grammar and syntax. Facilitates intermediate-level reading, writing, and speaking skills. Fosters college-level cultural literacy.
PERSIAN 2B.prereqString: Prerequisite: PERSIAN 2A. PERSIAN 2A with a grade of C or better. Placement into PERSIAN 2B is also accepted.
PERSIAN 2B.restriction: Restriction: School of Humanities students have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PERSIAN 2C.name: Intermediate Persian
PERSIAN 2C.description: Designed for students to advance their Persian language skills from introductory to intermediate level. Students will advance their understanding of grammar and syntax. Facilitates intermediate-level reading, writing, and speaking skills. Fosters college-level cultural literacy.
PERSIAN 2C.prereqString: Prerequisite: PERSIAN 2B. PERSIAN 2B with a grade of C or better. Placement into PERSIAN 2C is also accepted.
PERSIAN 2C.restriction: Restriction: School of Humanities students have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PERSIAN 10A.name: Persian Peer-to-Peer Language Mentor Program
PERSIAN 10A.description: Peer-to-Peer Language Mentor Program in which student mentors work with student mentees to increase the language skills of both participants. One hour weekly meetings. PERSIAN 10A is for language mentors.

PERSIAN 10B.name: Persian Peer-to-Peer Language Mentor Program
PERSIAN 10B.description: Peer-to-Peer Language Mentor Program in which student mentors work with student mentees to increase the language skills of both participants. One hour weekly meetings. PERSIAN 10B is for language mentees.

PERSIAN 50.name: Persian Culture
PERSIAN 50.description: Study of varied topics in Persian culture, area studies, and society, both in the present and in historical perspective. Topics are not normally repeated for a two-year period.

PERSIAN 150.name: Topics in Advanced Persian Culture
PERSIAN 150.description: In-depth examination of major works in premodern and modern Persian literature and/or the arts, with specific emphasis upon historical and cultural context and relevant societal issues and trends. Course is conducted in English.

PERSIAN 165A.name: Modern Iran: Cinema and the City
PERSIAN 165A.description: Exploring modern Iran through film, literature, photography, travel writing, and philosophy and social science texts that introduce students to important concepts in post-colonial studies, social thought, war culture, religion, and media as experienced through the paradigm of a non-Western modernity.

PHARM 241.name: Advanced Topics in Pharmacology
PHARM 241.description: Application of pharmacological principles in disease therapy.  Advanced pharmacological mechanisms and in-depth study of drug action.  Discussion of several major drug classes/therapeutic strategies:  molecular mechanisms of action, physiological consequences of administration, and clinical use.

PHARM 251.name: Experimental Pharmacology
PHARM 251.description: Introduction to the concepts and techniques used in pharmacological science. Molecular biology, quantitative and biochemical pharmacology, fluorescent probes, behavior, genetics, animal handling, anatomical and receptor binding analysis, methods for ion channel study, the absorption, distribution, metabolism and elimination of drugs.

PHARM 254.name: Introduction to Pharmacology
PHARM 254.description: Ligand-gated ion channels, G protein-coupled receptors, receptor tyrosine kinases, ligand-regulated transcription factors, their signaling mechanisms, trafficking, macromolecular complexes, and physiological responses.

PHARM 255.name: Neuropharmacology
PHARM 255.description: Mechanisms underlying chemical signaling processes in the brain and periphery. Molecular biology, signal transduction, transmitter synthesis, and inactivation of major neurotransmitter systems. Drugs that act on these major neurotransmitters.

PHARM 256.name: Experimental Design for Pharmacologists
PHARM 256.description: Population and sample statistics, hypothesis testing, analysis of variance, nonparametric statistics, experimental design, power, and the use of statistical computer software.

PHARM 257.name: Ethics in Research
PHARM 257.description: Ethical conduct in research including data handling, authorship, conflict of interest, animal rights, handling of misconduct.

PHARM 270.name: Applied Pharmacology
PHARM 270.description: One week (five days, 40 hours) in-residence course offered on the UCI campus. Introduction to pharmacological techniques and current research problems

PHARM 271.name: Principles of Pharmacology
PHARM 271.description: Principles of pharmacology: pharmacodynamics, pharmacokinetics, pharmacogenetics, drug interactions, and toxicity.

PHARM 272.name: Receptors and Drug Targets
PHARM 272.description: Molecular basis of drug-receptor interaction. Receptor properties including gene and protein structure, signaling mechanisms, trafficking and physiological effects: G-protein linked receptors, ligand-gated ion channels, receptor tyrosine kinases, nuclear receptors, and ligand regulated transcription factors.

PHARM 274.name: Research Techniques in Pharmacology
PHARM 274.description: Experimental techniques and model systems used in pharmacological research. Receptor analysis, bioassay, molecular biology, in vitro pharmacology, biochemical pharmacology, imaging, electrophysiology, in vivo pharmacology, disease models.

PHARM 276.name: Experimental Design and Data Analysis
PHARM 276.description: Experimental design, data analysis and interpretation. Population and sample statistics, hypothesis testing, analysis of variance, nonparametric statistics, and power calculations.

PHARM 277.name: Ethics in Scientific Research
PHARM 277.description: Ethical conduct in research including data handling, authorship, conflict of interest, animal rights, and handling of misconduct.

PHARM 278.name: Concepts in Drug Discovery
PHARM 278.description: Critical steps involved in discovery and optimization of a new drug. Target selection, relationship of molecular structure to pharmacological activities, screening methods, strategies to identify lead compounds, and preclinical characterization necessary for development of the drug for clinical trials.

PHARM 279.name: Special Topics in Pharmacology
PHARM 279.description: Topics of current interest in pharmacology

PHARM 280.name: Master's Project in Pharmacology
PHARM 280.description: Capstone research paper on topic of interest in pharmacology.

PHARM 281.name: Neuropharmacology
PHARM 281.description: Autonomic and central nervous system pharmacology, including major drug classes and therapeutic uses. Mechanisms underlying chemical signaling processes in the brain and peripheral nervous system, including neurotransmitter synthesis, inactivation, and receptor action.

PHARM 282.name: Behavioral Pharmacology
PHARM 282.description: Pharmacology of integrative function and behavior. Drug treatment of pain. Mechanisms of reward, addiction, and drugs of abuse.

PHARM 283.name: Cardiovascular Pharmacology
PHARM 283.description: Basic understanding of drugs used in the prevention and treatment of cardiovascular disease. Mechanisms of action, clinical and adverse effects.

PHARM 284.name: Endocrine, Respiratory, and Gastrointestinal Pharmacology
PHARM 284.description: Basic understanding of drugs used in endocrine, respiratory, and gastrointestinal conditions, including hormone replacement, contraceptives, and drugs for diabetes, asthma, obesity, ulcer, and gastric reflux. Mechanisms of drug action, clinical and adverse effects.

PHARM 298.name: Seminar
PHARM 298.description: Presentation and discussion of current problems and methods in teaching and research in pharmacology, toxicology, and therapeutics.

PHARM 299.name: Research
PHARM 299.description: Independent research with Pharmacology and Toxicology faculty.

PHILOS 1.name: Introduction to Philosophy
PHILOS 1.description: A selection of philosophical problems, concepts, and methods, e.g., free will, cause and substance, personal identity, the nature of philosophy itself. Materials fee.

PHILOS 2.name: Puzzles and Paradoxes
PHILOS 2.description: Introduction to the formal tools needed to comprehend and evaluate philosophical arguments and theoretical reasoning in general.

PHILOS 3.name: Technology and Society
PHILOS 3.description: A study of the nature of technology, its relation to human values, the philosophical assumptions in its development, and the philosophical implications of technology.

PHILOS 4.name: Introduction to Ethics
PHILOS 4.description: Selected topics from the history of ethics, e.g., the nature of the good life and the moral justification of conduct.

PHILOS 5.name: Contemporary Moral Problems
PHILOS 5.description: Selected moral issues of current interest, e.g., abortion, sexual morality, euthanasia, capital punishment, reverse discrimination, civil disobedience, or violence.

PHILOS 7.name: Introduction to Existentialism
PHILOS 7.description: An analysis of themes in phenomenology and existentialism and their philosophical origins, e.g., consciousness, self and other, freedom and individuality.

PHILOS 10.name: History of Ancient Philosophy
PHILOS 10.description: Examination of the central philosophical themes developed by the pre-Socratics, Socrates, Plato, Aristotle, the Stoics, the Epicureans, and the Skeptics.

PHILOS 11.name: History of Medieval Philosophy
PHILOS 11.description: A study of some of the major theological and philosophical texts from the Medieval period.

PHILOS 12.name: History of Modern Philosophy
PHILOS 12.description: A study of major developments in western philosophy from Descartes to Kant with readings from Descartes, Leibniz, Locke, Berkeley, Hume, and Kant.

PHILOS 13.name: History of Contemporary Philosophy
PHILOS 13.description: A study of recent philosophical developments in Anglo-American and Continental philosophy with readings from such figures as Russell, Moore, Wittgenstein, Quine, Heidegger, and Sartre.

PHILOS 21.name: Philosophy and Religion
PHILOS 21.description: Examines the intersection of religion and philosophy from a standpoint that does not presuppose previous academic study of either.  Both Western and Eastern traditions and perspectives may be explored.

PHILOS 22.name: Introduction to Law and Society
PHILOS 22.description: What constitutes a legal system? What does it mean for a society to have a system as a part of the social fabric. Examines the social status of law and its use as a tool for fashioning society.

PHILOS 29.name: Critical Reasoning
PHILOS 29.description: Introduction to analysis and reasoning. The concepts of argument, premise, and conclusion, validity and invalidity, consistency and inconsistency. Identifying and assessing premises and inferences. Deductive versus inductive reasoning, and introduction to the probability calculus. Evaluating definitions. Informal fallacies.

PHILOS 30.name: Introduction to Symbolic Logic
PHILOS 30.description: An introduction to the symbolism and methods of the logic of statements, including evaluation of arguments by truth tables, the techniques of natural deduction, and semantic tableaux.

PHILOS 31.name: Introduction to Inductive Logic
PHILOS 31.description: Philosophical questions concerning the foundations of scientific inference, e.g., the traditional problem of induction, the Goodman paradox, the concept of cause, Mill's method of inductive reasoning, probability calculus, different interpretations of probability, and their interaction in inductive reasoning.

PHILOS 40.name: Special Topics in Philosophy
PHILOS 40.description: Lectures on selected topics at the lower-division level.

PHILOS 91.name: The Philosophy of Sex
PHILOS 91.description: Discusses the origins of biological sex, dynamics of sexual selection, sex differences in humans, and the construction of gender in human societies. Seeks to understand the role social values play in the creation of science.

PHILOS 100W.name: Writing Philosophy
PHILOS 100W.description: Discussion of those aspects of writing of special importance in philosophy, e.g., philosophical terminology, techniques for evaluating arguments, philosophical definitions and theories. At least 4,000 words of assigned composition based on philosophical readings.
PHILOS 100W.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

PHILOS 101.name: Introduction to Metaphysics
PHILOS 101.description: A study of one or more of the problems of "first philosophy," e.g., substance, free will, causation, abstract entities, identity.

PHILOS 102W.name: Introduction to the Theory of Knowledge
PHILOS 102W.description: A study of one or more of the basic issues in epistemology, e.g., the role of perception in the acquisition of knowledge, the nature of evidence, the distinction between belief and knowledge, and the nature of truth and certainty.
PHILOS 102W.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

PHILOS 103.name: Introduction to Moral Philosophy
PHILOS 103.description: A study of one or more of the problems of contemporary moral philosophy, e.g., the nature of justice, liberalism versus conservatism, happiness and its relation to virtue and right conduct, the objectivity of moral standards.

PHILOS 104.name: Introduction to Logic
PHILOS 104.description: Introduction to sentence logic, including truth tables and natural deduction

PHILOS 105A.name: Elementary Set Theory
PHILOS 105A.description: An introduction to the basic working vocabulary of mathematical reasoning. Topics include sets, Boolean operations, ordered n-tuples, relations, functions, ordinal and cardinal numbers.

PHILOS 105B.name: Metalogic
PHILOS 105B.description: Introduction to formal syntax (proof theory) and semantics (model theory) for first-order logic, including the deduction, completeness, compactness, and Löewenheim-Skolem theorems.
PHILOS 105B.prereqString: Prerequisite: LSCI 145A or LPS 105A or PHILOS 105A

PHILOS 105C.name: Undecidability and Incompleteness
PHILOS 105C.description: Introduction to the formal theory of effective processes, including recursive functions, Turing machines, Church's thesis, and proofs of Göedel's incompleteness theorem for arithmetic, and Church's undecidability theorem for first-order logic.
PHILOS 105C.prereqString: Prerequisite: LSCI 145B or LPS 105B or PHILOS 105B

PHILOS 106.name: Topics in Logic
PHILOS 106.description: Selected topics in mathematical or philosophical logic.

PHILOS 108.name: Topics in Induction, Probability, and Decision Theory
PHILOS 108.description: Selected topics in induction, probability, and decision theory.

PHILOS 110.name: Topics in Ancient Philosophy
PHILOS 110.description: Selected topics from the writings of Plato and Aristotle, e.g., Aristotle's criticisms of Plato's metaphysics, ethics, or politics.

PHILOS 111.name: Topics in Medieval Philosophy
PHILOS 111.description: Studies of some of the major issues of concern to Medieval philosophers, e.g., universals, the nature and existence of God, faith, and reason.

PHILOS 113.name: Topics in Modern Philosophy
PHILOS 113.description: Focuses on the works of central philosophical figures of modern Philosophy (e.g., Descartes, Leibniz, Hobbes, Locke, Hume, Kant) or on the treatment of one or more central philosophical problems by a number of these figures.

PHILOS 114.name: Topics in Nineteenth-Century Philosophy
PHILOS 114.description: Studies of some of the major figures after Kant (e.g., Hegel, Nietzsche, Marx, Kierkegaard), especially in German idealism and social thought.

PHILOS 115.name: Topics in History of Analytic Philosophy
PHILOS 115.description: Review of central theories or figures in the history of analytic philosophy. Emphasis on writings of Frege, Russell, Schlick, Carnap, and Quine. Topics include the nature of meaning and truth, the synthetic/analytic distinction, and scientific knowledge.

PHILOS 117.name: Topics in Asian Philosophy
PHILOS 117.description: Selected topics in the philosophies of Asia, e.g. Jainism, Buddhism, Yoga, Vedanta, Confucianism, Taoism, and Shinto.

PHILOS 120.name: Topics in Metaphysics
PHILOS 120.description: Examines central philosophical questions concerning our own fundamental nature and that of the world around us (e.g., causation and necessity, determination, free will, personal identity, the mind-body problem).

PHILOS 121.name: Topics in the Theory of Knowledge
PHILOS 121.description: One or more topics in the theory of knowledge, e.g., the nature of rational justification, of perceptual knowledge, of a priori knowledge.

PHILOS 121A.name: Medical Epistemology
PHILOS 121A.description: Analysis of epistemological issues concerning medical research and health care. Topics may include medical evidence, transmission of medical knowledge, medical expertise, the epistemology of medical disagreement, classification of illnesses, well-being, philosophy of pain, and medical decision making.

PHILOS 122.name: Topics in Philosophy of Mind
PHILOS 122.description: Selected topics involving the concept of mind, e.g., the relation between mind and body, the self, personal identity, consciousness, the unconscious.

PHILOS 123.name: Topics in Philosophy of Religion
PHILOS 123.description: Critical examination of concepts involved in the theological literature, e.g., the nature and existence of God, miracles, the problem of evil, divine command theories in ethics.

PHILOS 124.name: Topics in Feminist Epistemology
PHILOS 124.description: Investigates the nature of knowledge from a feminist standpoint. Emphasizes the relevance of the knower’s gender and social situatedness in knowledge practices against a traditional account of knowledge as a detached activity of an independent, neutral subject.

PHILOS 131A.name: Applied Ethics
PHILOS 131A.description: Topics may include capital punishment, world hunger, obligations to future generations, environmental ethics, animal rights, economic justice, sexual morality, affirmative action, racism and sexism, or legalization of drugs.

PHILOS 131C.name: Medical Ethics
PHILOS 131C.description: Analysis of moral issues concerning health care. Topics may include just allocation of scarce medical resources, the doctor/patient relationship, genetic engineering, surrogate motherhood, abortion, euthanasia, or social policy concerning AIDS.

PHILOS 132.name: Topics in Political and Social Philosophy
PHILOS 132.description: Selected topics in social and political philosophy, e.g., the functions of government, the justification of political authority, the nature of democracy, the varieties of liberty, and social justice. Readings from classical and contemporary sources.

PHILOS 133.name: Topics in Philosophy of Law
PHILOS 133.description: Selected topics concerning legal systems and the concept of law, e.g., the nature and purpose of law, the nature of authority, the relationship between law and morality, law and political-economic systems.

PHILOS 134.name: Topics in Philosophy of Gender and Race
PHILOS 134.description: Controversies about race and racism, and sex and sexism, continue to play an important role in the public domain. Explores philosophical questions relating to gender and race.

PHILOS 140.name: Topics in Philosophy of Science
PHILOS 140.description: Selected topics in contemporary philosophy of science, e.g., the status of theoretical entities, the confirmation of theories, the nature of scientific explanation.

PHILOS 141B.name: Geometry and Spacetime
PHILOS 141B.description: An examination of the foundations of the special theory of relativity, with emphasis on the geometry of Minkowski spacetime, and its relation to both Euclidean and non-Euclidean (hyperbolic) plane geometries.

PHILOS 141D.name: Probability and Determinism
PHILOS 141D.description: An examination of a cluster of interrelated issues concerning probability, determinism, logic, and the foundations of quantum mechanics.

PHILOS 142W.name: Writing/Philosophy of Biology
PHILOS 142W.description: Philosophy of biology, e.g., scientific method in biology, the structure of evolutionary theory, teleology, ethics, and evolution. Course work includes one 4,000-word and four 1,000-word papers.
PHILOS 142W.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

PHILOS 143.name: Topics in Philosophy of Psychology
PHILOS 143.description: Selected topics in the philosophy of psychology, e.g., the nature of psychological explanation, reductionism, issues in cognitive, behavioral, and neuroscience.
PHILOS 143.restriction: Restriction: Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Philosophy Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PHILOS 144.name: Topics in Philosophy of Social Science
PHILOS 144.description: Selected topics in the philosophy of the social sciences, e.g., Is their goal to understand behavior or to predict and control it?

PHILOS 145.name: Topics in Philosophy of Language
PHILOS 145.description: Selected topics in the philosophy of language, e.g., the nature of meaning, mechanisms of reference, speech acts.

PHILOS 147.name: Topics in Philosophy of Mathematics
PHILOS 147.description: Selected historical and contemporary topics in the philosophy of mathematics, e.g., mathematical truth and ontology, mathematical knowledge, the nature and role of proof, the workings of mathematics in application.

PHILOS 150.name: Phenomenology
PHILOS 150.description: A study of the foundations of phenomenology in Husserl and its background in Bolzano, Frege, Brentano, Meinong, Kant, and Descartes.

PHILOS 162.name: Social Ontology
PHILOS 162.description: Examines how things in one’s social environment exist. Such things are compared and contrasted to others in what might be regarded as the given, natural environment. Topics discussed include natural kinds

PHILOS 163.name: Social Epistemology
PHILOS 163.description: Social epistemology is specifically concerned with questions concerning knowledge and justification that arise in a social context. Topics discussed include testimony, experts, disagreement, group knowledge, feminist epistemology, legal epistemology, and epistemology of education.

PHILOS 164.name: Well-Being
PHILOS 164.description: Examines what it is that makes a life good (or bad) for the person who lives it. Topics include hedonism, desire-satisfaction theories of well-being (as well as other such theories), the notion of harm, the possibility of posthumous harm.

PHILOS 165.name: Philosophy of Action
PHILOS 165.description: Philosophy of action is specifically concerned with questions concerning the nature of acting, and related phenomena such as intending, willing, trying, and trusting. It deals both with individual and group action and their moral and epistemological  underpinnings.

PHILOS 190.name: Special Topics in Philosophy
PHILOS 190.description: Lectures on selected topics to be given by regular faculty and visiting faculty.

PHILOS 199.name: Directed Special Studies
PHILOS 199.description: Independent study on a research topic supervised by a faculty member.

PHILOS 199H.name: Honors Directed Special Studies
PHILOS 199H.description: Independent study on a research topic supervised by a faculty member, with the objective of preparing the Department of Philosophy honors paper.

PHILOS 200.name: Special Topics in Philosophy
PHILOS 200.description: Seminars on selected topics to be given by regular faculty and visiting faculty.

PHILOS 201.name: First-Year Seminar
PHILOS 201.description: An examination of some standard works in the history of philosophy, value theory, metaphysics, or epistemology
PHILOS 201.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Philosophy Majors only. Logic and Philosophy of Sci Majors only.

PHILOS 205A.name: Set Theory
PHILOS 205A.description: The basic working vocabulary of mathematical reasoning. Topics include: sets, Boolean operations, ordered n-tuples, relations, functions, ordinal and cardinal numbers.

PHILOS 205B.name: Metalogic
PHILOS 205B.description: Formal syntax (proof theory) and semantics (model theory) for first-order logic, including the deduction, completeness, compactness, and Loewenheim-Skolem theorems.

PHILOS 205C.name: Undecidability and Incompleteness
PHILOS 205C.description: Formal theory of effective processes, including recursive function, Turing machines, Church's thesis, proofs of Goedel's incompleteness theorem for arithmetics, and Church's undecidability for first-order logic.

PHILOS 206.name: Topics in Logic
PHILOS 206.description: Studies in selected areas of logic. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

PHILOS 210.name: Topics in Ancient Philosophy
PHILOS 210.description: Studies in selected areas of ancient philosophy.  Topics addressed vary each quarter.

PHILOS 212.name: Topics in Renaissance Philosophy
PHILOS 212.description: Studies in selected areas of renaissance philosophy.  Topics addressed vary each quarter.

PHILOS 213.name: Topics in Modern Philosophy
PHILOS 213.description: Studies in selected areas of modern philosophy.  Topics addressed vary each quarter.

PHILOS 215.name: Topics in Analytic Philosophy
PHILOS 215.description: Studies in selected areas of analytic philosophy.  Topics addressed vary each quarter.

PHILOS 218.name: Topics in Contemporary Philosophy
PHILOS 218.description: Studies in selected areas of contemporary philosophy. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

PHILOS 220.name: Topics in Metaphysics
PHILOS 220.description: Studies in selected areas of metaphysics. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

PHILOS 221.name: Topics in Epistemology
PHILOS 221.description: Studies in selected areas of epistemology. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

PHILOS 221A.name: Medical Epistemology
PHILOS 221A.description: Analysis of epistemological issues concerning medical research and healthcare. Topics may include medical evidence, transmission of medical knowledge in the doctor-patient interaction, medical expertise, epistemology of medical disagreement, classification of illness, well-being, philosophy of pain, or medical decision making.

PHILOS 222.name: Topics in Mind and Action
PHILOS 222.description: Studies in selected areas of mind and action. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

PHILOS 230.name: Topics in Ethics
PHILOS 230.description: Studies in selected areas of ethics. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

PHILOS 232.name: Topics in Political and Social Philosophy
PHILOS 232.description: Studies in selected areas of political and social philosophy. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

PHILOS 240.name: Topics in Philosophy of Science
PHILOS 240.description: Studies in selected areas of philosophy of science. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

PHILOS 241.name: Topics in Philosophy of Physics
PHILOS 241.description: Studies in selected areas of philosophy of physics. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

PHILOS 242.name: Topics in Philosophy of Biology
PHILOS 242.description: Studies in selected areas of philosophy of biology. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

PHILOS 243.name: Topics in Philosophy of Psychology
PHILOS 243.description: Selected topics in the philosophy of psychology, e.g., the nature of psychological explanation, reductionism, issues in cognitive, behavioral, and neuroscience.

PHILOS 244.name: Topics in Philosophy of Social Science
PHILOS 244.description: Studies in selected areas of philosophy and social science. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

PHILOS 245.name: Topics in Philosophy of Language
PHILOS 245.description: Studies in selected areas of philosophy of language. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

PHILOS 246.name: Topics in Philosophy of Logic
PHILOS 246.description: Studies in selected areas of philosophy of logic. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

PHILOS 247.name: Topics in Philosophy of Mathematics
PHILOS 247.description: Studies in selected areas of philosophy of mathematics. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

PHMD 200A.name: Interprofessional Clinical Foundations I
PHMD 200A.description: The first course in a four-part series that covers interprofessional patient communication, medical interviewing, physical examination, and health promotion. Direct instruction in professionalism, diversity, social determinants of health, kindness, mindfulness, well-being, epidemiology, and biostatistics.
PHMD 200A.restriction: Restriction: Doctor of Pharmacy students have first consideration for enrollment. Graduate students only.

PHMD 200B.name: Interprofessional Clinical Foundations II
PHMD 200B.description: The second course in four-part series that covers interprofessional communication, medical interviewing, physical examination, and health promotion. Direct instruction in professionalism, diversity, social determinants of health, kindness, mindfulness, well-being, epidemiology, and biostatistics.
PHMD 200B.restriction: Restriction: Doctor of Pharmacy students have first consideration for enrollment. Graduate students only.

PHMD 200C.name: Interprofessional Clinical Foundations III
PHMD 200C.description: The third course in a four-part series that covers interprofessional communication, medical interviewing, physical examination, and health promotion. Direct instruction in professionalism, diversity, social determinants of health, kindness, mindfulness, well-being, epidemiology, and biostatistics.
PHMD 200C.restriction: Restriction: Doctor of Pharmacy students have first consideration for enrollment. Graduate students only.

PHMD 200D.name: Interprofessional Clinical Foundations IV
PHMD 200D.description: The fourth course in a four-part series that covers interprofessional communication, medical interviewing, physical examination, and health promotion. Direct instruction in professionalism, diversity, social determinants of health, kindness, mindfulness, well-being, epidemiology, and biostatistics.
PHMD 200D.prereqString: Prerequisite: PHMD 200A and PHMD 200B and PHMD 200C
PHMD 200D.restriction: Restriction: Doctor of Pharmacy students have first consideration for enrollment. Graduate students only.

PHMD 201A.name: Principles of Pharmacy Practice I
PHMD 201A.description: The first of a four-part series that covers the function and role of the health care team, Pharmacist Patient Care Process, immunization certification, communication and documentation, informatics, patient safety, interviewing, active listening, management/leadership, careers, resiliency, and student wellness.
PHMD 201A.restriction: Restriction: Doctor of Pharmacy students have first consideration for enrollment. Graduate students only.

PHMD 201B.name: Principles of Pharmacy Practice II
PHMD 201B.description: The second of a four-part series that covers the function and roles of the health care team, Pharmacist Patient Care Process, immunization certification, communication and documentation, informatics, patient safety, interviewing, active listening, management/leadership, careers, resiliency, and student wellness.
PHMD 201B.restriction: Restriction: Doctor of Pharmacy students have first consideration for enrollment. Graduate students only.

PHMD 201C.name: Principles of Pharmacy Practice III
PHMD 201C.description: The third of a four-part series that covers the function and role of the health care team, Pharmacist Patient Care Process, immunization certification, communication and documentation, informatics, patient safety, interviewing, active listening, management/leadership, careers, resiliency, and student wellness.
PHMD 201C.restriction: Restriction: Doctor of Pharmacy students have first consideration for enrollment. Graduate students only.

PHMD 201D.name: Principles of Pharmacy Practice IV
PHMD 201D.description: The fourth of a four-part series that covers the function and role of the health care team, Pharmacist Patient Care Process, immunization certification, communication and documentation, informatics, patient safety, interviewing, active listening, management/leadership, careers, resiliency, and student wellness.
PHMD 201D.prereqString: Prerequisite: PHMD 201A and PHMD 201B and PHMD 201C
PHMD 201D.restriction: Restriction: Doctor of Pharmacy students have first consideration for enrollment. Graduate students only.

PHMD 202A.name: Self Care I: Conventional and Complementary
PHMD 202A.description: Educates pharmacy students about healthy lifestyle choices, the importance of mental and physical health, and self-care. Provides students with methods and techniques for dealing with the stressors of a professional educational environment and life challenges.
PHMD 202A.restriction: Restriction: Doctor of Pharmacy students have first consideration for enrollment. Graduate students only.

PHMD 202B.name: Self Care II: Conventional and Complementary
PHMD 202B.description: The study of nonprescription products, complementary/alternative medicine, and non-pharmacological interventions for select self-treatable medical conditions commonly encountered by the pharmacist. Emphasis on the pharmacist's consultant role in product selection and non-pharmacological recommendations.
PHMD 202B.restriction: Restriction: Doctor of Pharmacy students have first consideration for enrollment. Graduate students only.

PHMD 202C.name: Self Care III: Conventional and Complementary
PHMD 202C.description: Relates to patients' ability to care for themselves with emphasis on the pharmacist's consultant role and continues to explore self-treatable medical conditions commonly encountered by pharmacists, including non-pharmacologic interventions, nonprescription medications, and complementary/alternative products to treat them.
PHMD 202C.restriction: Restriction: Doctor of Pharmacy students have first consideration for enrollment. Graduate students only.

PHMD 203A.name: Pharmacotherapy Principles to Practice I: Central Nervous System
PHMD 203A.description: Integrates principles of biomedical and pharmaceutical sciences with evidence-based traditional and non-traditional therapies for management and prevention of disease. Topics include clinical chemistry, clinical toxicology, interprofessional health care, and public health. Covers the central nervous system.
PHMD 203A.restriction: Restriction: Doctor of Pharmacy students have first consideration for enrollment. Graduate students only.

PHMD 203B.name: Pharmacotherapy Principles to Practice II: Immunology
PHMD 203B.description: Integrates principles of biomedical and pharmaceutical sciences with evidence-based traditional and non-traditional therapies for management and prevention of disease. Topics include clinical chemistry, clinical toxicology, interprofessional health care, and public health. Covers the immune system.
PHMD 203B.restriction: Restriction: Doctor of Pharmacy students have first consideration for enrollment. Graduate students only.

PHMD 203C.name: Pharmacotherapy - Principles to Practice III: Cardiovascular and Respiratory Systems
PHMD 203C.description: Integrates principles of biomedical and pharmaceutical sciences with evidence-based traditional and non-traditional therapies for management and prevention of disease. Topics include clinical chemistry, clinical toxicology, interprofessional health care, and public health. Covers the cardiovascular and respiratory systems.
PHMD 203C.restriction: Restriction: Doctor of Pharmacy students have first consideration for enrollment. Graduate students only.

PHMD 203D.name: Pharmacotherapy - Principles to Practice IV: Endocrine System
PHMD 203D.description: Integrates principles of biomedical and pharmaceutical sciences with evidence-based traditional and non-traditional therapies for management and prevention of disease. Topics include clinical chemistry, clinical toxicology, interprofessional health care, and public health. Covers the endocrine system.
PHMD 203D.restriction: Restriction: Doctor of Pharmacy students have first consideration for enrollment. Graduate students only.

PHMD 203E.name: Pharmacotherapy - Principles to Practice V: Gastrointestinal System, Dermatologic, and Opthalmologic Disorders
PHMD 203E.description: Integrates principles of biomedical and pharmaceutical sciences with evidence-based traditional and non-traditional therapies for management and prevention of disease. Topics include clinical chemistry, clinical toxicology, interprofessional health care, and public health. Covers gastrointestinal, dermatologic, and opthalmologic disorders.
PHMD 203E.restriction: Restriction: Doctor of Pharmacy students have first consideration for enrollment. Graduate students only.

PHMD 203F.name: Pharmacotherapy - Principles to Practice VI: Infectious Diseases
PHMD 203F.description: Integrates principles of biomedical and pharmaceutical sciences with evidence-based traditional and non-traditional therapies for management and prevention of disease. Topics include clinical chemistry, clinical toxicology, interprofessional health care, and public health. Covers gastrointestinal, dermatologic, and opthalmologic disorders.
PHMD 203F.restriction: Restriction: Doctor of Pharmacy students have first consideration for enrollment. Graduate students only.

PHMD 203G.name: Pharmacotherapy - Principles to Practice VII: Hematology and Oncologic Disorders
PHMD 203G.description: Integrates principles of biomedical and pharmaceutical sciences with evidence-based traditional and non-traditional therapies for management and prevention of disease. Topics include clinical chemistry, clinical toxicology, interprofessional health care, and public health. Covers hematology and oncologic disorders.
PHMD 203G.restriction: Restriction: Doctor of Pharmacy students have first consideration for enrollment. Graduate students only.

PHMD 203H.name: Pharmacotherapy - Principles to Practice VIII: Special Population and Nutritional Disorders
PHMD 203H.description: Integrates principles of biomedical and pharmaceutical sciences with evidence-based traditional and non-traditional therapies for management and prevention of disease. Topics include clinical chemistry, clinical toxicology, interprofessional health care, and public health. Covers special population and nutritional disorders.
PHMD 203H.restriction: Restriction: Doctor of Pharmacy students have first consideration for enrollment. Graduate students only.

PHMD 204A.name: Information Analytics and Numeracy I: Biostatistics
PHMD 204A.description: Exposure to basic statistics and techniques that are commonly found in the medical and pharmacy literature, covering descriptive and inferential statistics. Students learn to choose the most appropriate statistical parametric and non-parametric tests and interpret findings from the literature.
PHMD 204A.restriction: Restriction: Doctor of Pharmacy students have first consideration for enrollment. Graduate students only.

PHMD 204B.name: Information Analytics and Numeracy II: Drug Information, Research Methods, and Literature Analysis
PHMD 204B.description: Addresses development of knowledge, skills, and attitudes required for biomedical inquiry and discovery, including methods for data retrieval, analysis, interpretation, and synthesis.
PHMD 204B.restriction: Restriction: Doctor of Pharmacy students have first consideration for enrollment. Graduate students only.

PHMD 204C.name: Information Analytics and Numeracy III: Epidemiology
PHMD 204C.description: Covers distribution of disease and health in groups of people and the factors that influence the distribution, including evaluation of therapeutic and diagnostic treatments and delivery of health care services.
PHMD 204C.restriction: Restriction: Doctor of Pharmacy students have first consideration for enrollment. Graduate students only.

PHMD 205A.name: Molecular Basis of Health and Disease I: Microbiology and Immunology
PHMD 205A.description: Principles of medical microbiology, immunology, virology, and parasitology.  Introduction to classification, morphology, and physiology of microorganisms, particularly those that cause human pathology - bacteria, viruses, fungi, protozoans, parasite, and worms - and the body's immune response.
PHMD 205A.restriction: Restriction: Doctor of Pharmacy students have first consideration for enrollment. Graduate students only.

PHMD 205B.name: Molecular Basis of Health and Disease II: Microbiology and Immunology
PHMD 205B.description: Principles of medical microbiology, immunology, virology, and parasitology. Introduction to classification, morphology, and physiology of microorganisms, particularly those that cause human pathology - bacteria, viruses, fungi, protozoans, parasite, and worms - and the body's immune response.
PHMD 205B.restriction: Restriction: Doctor of Pharmacy students have first consideration for enrollment. Graduate students only.

PHMD 205C.name: Molecular Basis of Health and Disease III: Clinical Chemistry
PHMD 205C.description: Emphasis on normal human physiology and pathology as it related to clinical chemistry and assessment of disease states with the context of the Pharmacist Patient Care Process. Alterations of clinical chemistry results due to drug therapy are covered.
PHMD 205C.restriction: Restriction: Doctor of Pharmacy students have first consideration for enrollment. Graduate students only.

PHMD 210.name: Principles of Pharmacology
PHMD 210.description: Provides an overview of the basic principles of pharmacology, covering pharmacodynamics - effects of drugs on the body - and pharmacokinetics - the process by which a drug is absorbed, distributed, metabolized, and excreted by the body.
PHMD 210.prereqString: Prerequisite: PHMD 220 and PHMD 277A and PHMD 277B
PHMD 210.restriction: Restriction: Doctor of Pharmacy students have first consideration for enrollment. Graduate students only.

PHMD 211.name: Principles of Public Health
PHMD 211.description: Covers the framework, principles, and core responsibilities of public health research and practice from multidisciplinary perspectives. It also provides the necessary foundation for further studies using crosscutting approaches essential for public health practice.
PHMD 211.restriction: Restriction: Doctor of Pharmacy students have first consideration for enrollment. Graduate students only.

PHMD 212.name: Principles of Pharmacogenomics
PHMD 212.description: Walks students through the basics of genetics and genomics. Particular emphasis is placed on the use of genetics or genetic testing to assist in patient treatment regimens and evaluation of disease.
PHMD 212.restriction: Restriction: Doctor of Pharmacy students have first consideration for enrollment. Graduate students only.

PHMD 213.name: Pharmaceutical Biochemistry
PHMD 213.description: Topics include the biological, chemical and cellular roles of carbohydrates, lipids, proteins, nucleic acids, hormones, enzymes and vitamins. In addition, the chemical and cellular basis of digestion, intermediary metabolism, biological oxidation and metabolic antagonism are discussed.
PHMD 213.restriction: Restriction: Doctor of Pharmacy students have first consideration for enrollment. Graduate students only.

PHMD 214.name: Pharmacy Law and Ethics
PHMD 214.description: An introduction to California and federal legal requirements that impact pharmacy practice, emphasizing the legal and ethical principles applied by pharmacists in their decision-making. Explores approaches for resolving ethical dilemmas in patient care.
PHMD 214.restriction: Restriction: Doctor of Pharmacy students have first consideration for enrollment. Graduate students only.

PHMD 215.name: Health Policy and Pharmacoeconomics
PHMD 215.description: Introduces students to the organization, financing, and delivery of health care services in the U.S. The relationship of providers, patients, payers, etc., are analyzed. Management and research principles utilized to manage drug therapy are introduced.
PHMD 215.restriction: Restriction: Doctor of Pharmacy students have first consideration for enrollment. Graduate students only.

PHMD 216.name: Clinical Toxicology
PHMD 216.description: Fundamentals of pharmacology and mechanisms of action are reinforced and applied to learn the clinical effects of acute/chronic exposure derived from environmental, dietary, occupational and pharmaceutical sources. Students focus on information literacy skills and clinical management of poisonings.
PHMD 216.restriction: Restriction: Doctor of Pharmacy students have first consideration for enrollment. Graduate students only.

PHMD 220.name: Medical Physiology with Anatomic Correlates
PHMD 220.description: Concepts of physiology and mechanisms of body function at various levels of organization from cellular to organ systems. Emphasis on quantitative understanding of various body processes. Human anatomy is integrated with physiological concepts. Anatomic-physiologic relationships facilitated through virtual labs.
PHMD 220.restriction: Restriction: Doctor of Pharmacy students have first consideration for enrollment. Graduate students only.

PHMD 274A.name: Pharmaceutics I
PHMD 274A.description: The first in a foundational series designed to develop an understanding of the science behind drug formulation, mechanisms, pharmacokinetics and interconnections with the Pharmacist Patient Care Process.
PHMD 274A.restriction: Restriction: Doctor of Pharmacy students have first consideration for enrollment. Graduate students only.

PHMD 274B.name: Pharmaceutics II
PHMD 274B.description: The second course in a foundational series designed to develop an understanding of the science behind drug formulation, mechanisms, pharmacokinetics and interconnections with the pharmacist patient care process. Topics include drug substances, dosage forms, and therapeutic effects. Includes laboratory.
PHMD 274B.restriction: Restriction: Doctor of Pharmacy students have first consideration for enrollment. Graduate students only.

PHMD 274C.name: Pharmaceutics III
PHMD 274C.description: The final course in a foundational series designed to develop an understanding of the science behind drug formulation, mechanisms, pharmacokinetics,and interconnections with the Pharmacist Patient Care Process. In laboratory, students perform pharmacokinetic modeling, drug screening, and comprehensive therapeutic efficacy.
PHMD 274C.restriction: Restriction: Doctor of Pharmacy students have first consideration for enrollment. Graduate students only.

PHMD 277A.name: Medicinal Chemistry I
PHMD 277A.description: Application of organic chemistry, biochemistry, molecular biology, physical chemistry, pharmacology, and physiology to understand the theory and mechanics of modern day medicinal chemistry. Topics include receptor-protein structure, dynamics, and interactions
PHMD 277A.restriction: Restriction: Doctor of Pharmacy students have first consideration for enrollment. Graduate students only.

PHMD 277B.name: Medicinal Chemistry II
PHMD 277B.description: Walks students through medicinal chemistry, broadly defined. Students utilize the knowledge gained in organic chemistry, biochemistry, molecular biology, physical chemistry, pharmacology and physiology in an integrated fashion as applied to modern medicinal chemistry. Continuation of Medicinal Chemistry I.
PHMD 277B.restriction: Restriction: Doctor of Pharmacy students have first consideration for enrollment. Graduate students only.

PHMD 280A.name: Scholarly Project I
PHMD 280A.description: Provides students an opportunity to develop independent thinking, with particular focus on maturing analytical skills. Students are encouraged to develop an independent project, with a mentor, to study pharmacy-related aspects of multiple areas. First phase identifies project focus.
PHMD 280A.restriction: Restriction: Doctor of Pharmacy students have first consideration for enrollment. Graduate students only.

PHMD 280B.name: Scholarly Project II
PHMD 280B.description: Provides students an opportunity to develop independent thinking, with particular focus on maturing analytical skills. Students develop an independent project, with a mentor, to study pharmacy-related aspects of multiple areas. Phase 2 focuses on final evaluation of project.
PHMD 280B.restriction: Restriction: Doctor of Pharmacy students have first consideration for enrollment. Graduate students only.

PHMD 290.name: Doctor of Pharmacy Epilogue
PHMD 290.description: Reinforces and assesses student pharmacist’s performance on cumulative learning outcomes
PHMD 290.restriction: Restriction: Doctor of Pharmacy students have first consideration for enrollment. Graduate students only.

PHMD 298.name: Research Seminar
PHMD 298.description: Designed to engage students and expose them to seminar speakers that come to discuss research or case studies in pharmaceutical sciences and pharmacy.
PHMD 298.restriction: Restriction: Doctor of Pharmacy students have first consideration for enrollment. Graduate students only.

PHRMSCI 1.name: New Student Seminar
PHRMSCI 1.description: Weekly meetings consisting of presentations by faculty, professional staff, and Peer Academic Advisors provide information about the Pharmaceutical Sciences major, campus resources, learning skills, and special programs and opportunities.
PHRMSCI 1.restriction: Restriction: Pharmaceutical Sciences Majors only. New students only.

PHRMSCI 3.name: Professional Development and Careers in the Pharmaceutical Sciences
PHRMSCI 3.description: Designed to help Pharmaceutical Science majors select a career track and prepare for graduate program applications and careers in industry.
PHRMSCI 3.restriction: Restriction: Juniors only. Pharmaceutical Sciences Majors only.

PHRMSCI 42.name: Life 101
PHRMSCI 42.description: Covers the latest scientific work on the impact of nutrition, exercise, and lifestyle choices on mental and physical health. Motivates students to make positive changes by fostering personal growth.

PHRMSCI 76.name: Ethical Conduct of Research
PHRMSCI 76.description: Covers the ethical responsibilities of biomedical scientists. Topics include, as discussions and case studies, the high standards of science, the responsible conduct of research, animal experimentation, and clinical trials as they relate to the pharmaceutical sciences.

PHRMSCI H80.name: Drugs and Society
PHRMSCI H80.description: Where drugs come from, how drugs work, how and why people abuse drugs, the costs of drug abuse on society, which drugs are commonly abused, and how drug abuse can be prevented and treated. Course intended for non-science majors.
PHRMSCI H80.prereqString: Prerequisite: Recommended: High school chemistry and biology.
PHRMSCI H80.restriction: Restriction: Campuswide Honors Collegium students only.

PHRMSCI 90.name: Speaking about Science
PHRMSCI 90.description: Students learn to effectively prepare and present public speeches and slide presentations. Included are storytelling, informative, commemorative, and persuasive speeches, and scientific presentation. Evaluating speeches and strategies to reduce speaker apprehension is also covered.
PHRMSCI 90.restriction: Restriction: Pharmaceutical Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PHRMSCI 120.name: Human Physiology
PHRMSCI 120.description: Covers the function of the human body. All major organ systems are discussed. Designed to prepare students for healthcare careers, such as medicine, pharmacy, dentistry, and for research careers which require basic knowledge of how the human body functions.

PHRMSCI 120L.name: Human Physiology Lab
PHRMSCI 120L.description: Designed to complement PHRMSCI 120. Computer-based lab simulations are used to study the function of the human body. Class physically meet for review sessions and exams.
PHRMSCI 120L.prereqString:
Corequisite: PHRMSCI 120
Prerequisite: BIO SCI E109

PHRMSCI 122L.name: Medical Microbiology Laboratory
PHRMSCI 122L.description: An introduction to the structure, metabolism, cultivation, isolation, classification, and identification of the major groups of bacteria. Additional focus on identification of infection and use of antibiotics in diseased patients.
PHRMSCI 122L.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI 99 and CHEM 51C. CHEM 51C with a grade of C- or better

PHRMSCI 142.name: Healthspan Sciences
PHRMSCI 142.description: Covers the complex and multi-factorial process of aging and increases the understanding of factors that contribute to enhanced lifespan, including basic principles of health and wellness and scientifically proven interventions, both pharmacological and non-pharmacological.
PHRMSCI 142.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI 98 and BIO SCI 99 and PHRMSCI 120

PHRMSCI 155.name: Neuropsychopharmacology
PHRMSCI 155.description: Mechanisms underlying chemical signaling processes in the nervous system. Fundamental knowledge for understanding the cellular and molecular actions of drugs and their mechanisms of action on synaptic transmission. Applied neuropsychopharmacology including major drug classes and therapeutic uses.
PHRMSCI 155.prereqString: Prerequisite: PHRMSCI 170A. PHRMSCI 170A with a grade of C- or better

PHRMSCI 163.name: Pharmacogenomics and Epigenetics
PHRMSCI 163.description: Survey of the genetic and epigenetic basis of inter-subject variability in response to drugs. Covers drug efficacy, safety, and need for their optimization in pharmacotherapy. Emphasizes genetic mechanisms of polymorphisms in the pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics of representative therapeutic drugs.

PHRMSCI 170A.name: Molecular Pharmacology I
PHRMSCI 170A.description: Molecular basis of drug-receptor action at the molecular and cellular levels. Structure-function of drug targets emphasizing enzymes, ion channels, and membrane transport proteins. Understanding how the drugs' mechanisms of action contribute to the development of more efficacious and safer drugs.
PHRMSCI 170A.restriction: Restriction: Pharmaceutical Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PHRMSCI 170B.name: Molecular Pharmacology II
PHRMSCI 170B.description: Introductory survey covering the molecular mechanisms of drugs that target the nervous system, such as anxiolytics, antidepressants, antipsychotics, hypnotics, muscle relaxants, and recreational drugs

PHRMSCI 171.name: Physical Biochemistry
PHRMSCI 171.description: Thermodynamics and kinetic fundamentals as applied to problems relevant to pharmaceutical sciences such as receptor/enzyme-ligand interactions. Fundamentals of biophysical methods used in the pharmaceutical sciences including structure determination and biomolecular spectroscopy.
PHRMSCI 171.prereqString: Prerequisite: MATH 2B and PHYSICS 3C and (CHEM 1C or CHEM H2C) and BIO SCI 99
PHRMSCI 171.restriction: Restriction: Pharmaceutical Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PHRMSCI 172.name: Topics in Pharmaceutical Sciences
PHRMSCI 172.description: Presents information about various fields of research, study, careers, and graduate school opportunities in pharmaceutical sciences. Taught by guest lecturers from various disciplines including 199 research course faculty. Helps Pharmaceutical Sciences students select electives appropriate to their future goals.

PHRMSCI 173.name: Pharmacotherapy
PHRMSCI 173.description: An exploration of the clinical application of medications to selected disease states. Focus is on an understanding of underlying principles of pharmacology and how this knowledge can be applied to treatment of diseases.

PHRMSCI 174.name: Biopharmaceutics and Nanomedicine
PHRMSCI 174.description: Introduces theories and tools of new drug formulations. Particularly new novel therapeutics based on biological materials, pathological characteristics utilized to achieve the maximum efficacy and specificity, and drug delivery systems based on emerging nanotechnology are extensively discussed.
PHRMSCI 174.restriction: Restriction: Pharmaceutical Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PHRMSCI 174L.name: Biopharmaceutics and Nanomedicine Lab
PHRMSCI 174L.description: Introduction to cancer drug screening using cellular models, and confirmation of comprehensive therapeutic efficacy using a live animal model. Includes basic cell culture, cytotoxicity assays, cell analysis, drug circulation test, and tumor eradication and imaging experiments. Materials fee.

PHRMSCI 175.name: Drug Discovery Computing Techniques
PHRMSCI 175.description: Techniques used in computer-aided drug discovery, including theory behind these techniques and practical applications. Topics include scientific computing
PHRMSCI 175.prereqString: Prerequisite: CSE 41 or I&C SCI 31. CSE 42 or I&C SCI 32 is recommended.

PHRMSCI 177.name: Medicinal Chemistry
PHRMSCI 177.description: An introduction of the basics of drug activity and mechanisms. Strategies used to identify lead compounds such as natural product chemistry, combinatorial chemistry, molecular modeling, and high-through put screening.  Relationship of molecular structure to pharmacological activity.
PHRMSCI 177.prereqString: Prerequisite: CHEM 51A and CHEM 51B and CHEM 51C and (BIO SCI 98 or CHEM 128)
PHRMSCI 177.restriction: Restriction: Pharmaceutical Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PHRMSCI 177L.name: Medicinal Chemistry Laboratory
PHRMSCI 177L.description: An introduction of the basics of drug activity and mechanisms. Strategies used to identify lead compounds such as natural product chemistry, combinatorial chemistry, molecular modeling, and high-through put screening.  Relationship of molecular structure to pharmacological activity. Materials fee.
PHRMSCI 177L.prereqString:
Corequisite: PHRMSCI 177 or CHEM 177.
Prerequisite: CHEM 51A and CHEM 51B and CHEM 51C and BIO SCI 100 and (BIO SCI 98 or CHEM 128)
PHRMSCI 177L.restriction: Restriction: Pharmaceutical Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PHRMSCI 179.name: Emerging Technologies in Pharmaceutical Sciences and Medicine
PHRMSCI 179.description: Introduces emerging, ground-breaking technologies in pharmaceutical sciences and medicine, including pharmacogenomics, genome editing, and stem cell and engineered T cell therapies. Explores these novel technologies with both their underlying theories and forward-thinking applications.

PHRMSCI 197.name: Professional Internship
PHRMSCI 197.description: Provides students with opportunity to develop leadership and professional skills necessary for competitive placement in their chosen industry. Students gain new and field-specific skills outside the classroom environment while participating in a supervised internship for a total of 100 hours.

PHRMSCI 198.name: Independent Study in Pharmaceutical Sciences
PHRMSCI 198.description: Students interested in independent study should arrange with a faculty member to sponsor and supervise such work. A time commitment of three hours per week per unit is expected. A written report is required at the end of each quarter.

PHRMSCI 199.name: Undergraduate Research
PHRMSCI 199.description: Original research in the laboratory of Pharmaceutical Sciences faculty. Attendance at regular research group meetings is also generally expected, and a quarterly written report is required. Strongly recommended for students considering research careers and/or graduate degree programs.

PHRMSCI H199.name: Honors Research in Pharmaceutical Sciences
PHRMSCI H199.description: Undergraduate honors research in Pharmaceutical Sciences. A student time commitment of 10-15 hours per week is required.

PHRMSCI 223.name: Biological Macromolecules
PHRMSCI 223.description: Introduction to nucleic acid and protein structure, dynamics, and function. Topics include analytical methods, molecular evolution, folding, and catalysis.

PHRMSCI 250A.name: Current Topics in Pharmaceutical Sciences
PHRMSCI 250A.description: Intended to expose students to the primary literature and current research in the field of Pharmaceutical Sciences. Students analyze and present information for discussion. Guest speakers from academia and industry may participate throughout the quarter.
PHRMSCI 250A.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Math and Computational Biology Majors only.

PHRMSCI 250B.name: Current Topics in Pharmaceutical Sciences
PHRMSCI 250B.description: Intended to expose students to the primary literature and current research in the field of Pharmaceutical Sciences. Students analyze and present information for discussion. Guest speakers from academia and industry may participate throughout the quarter.
PHRMSCI 250B.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Math and Computational Biology Majors only.

PHRMSCI 250C.name: Current Topics in Pharmaceutical Sciences
PHRMSCI 250C.description: Intended to expose students to the primary literature and current research in the field of Pharmaceutical Sciences. Students analyze and present information for discussion. Guest speakers from academia and industry may participate throughout the quarter.
PHRMSCI 250C.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Math and Computational Biology Majors only.

PHRMSCI 263.name: Pharmacogenomics and Epigenetics
PHRMSCI 263.description: Survey of the genetic and epigenetic basis of inter-subject variability in response to drugs. Covers drug efficacy, safety, and the need for their optimization in pharmacotherapy.Emphasizes genetic mechanisms of polymorphisms in the pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics of representative therapeutic drugs.

PHRMSCI 264.name: The RNA World: From Discovery to Mechanism
PHRMSCI 264.description: Provides a comprehensive understanding of RNA in biology. Use of knowledge gained in organic chemistry, biochemistry, genomics, and molecular biology to understand how RNA is integrated into contemporary biology.

PHRMSCI 265.name: New Frontiers in Chemical and Synthetic Biology
PHRMSCI 265.description: Explores new developments in chemical and synthetic biology that span the areas of chemistry, molecular biology, genetics, bioengineering, systems biology, and computational genomics.

PHRMSCI 270.name: Advanced Pharmacology
PHRMSCI 270.description: Provides a mechanism-based overview of pharmacology with strong emphasis on clinical application of pharmacology. Students learn the most recent advances in pharmacology as they relate to drug discovery, development, and clinical application.

PHRMSCI 272.name: Special Topics in Pharmaceutical Sciences
PHRMSCI 272.description: Reserved for current topics of particular interest in areas of pharmaceutical sciences that are not covered by other courses. The subject will vary from year to year, highlighting, for example, significant emerging fields or highly specialized but vital research areas.

PHRMSCI 275.name: Drug Discovery Computing Techniques
PHRMSCI 275.description: Techniques used in computer-aided drug discovery, including theory behind these techniques and practical applications. Topics include scientific computing

PHRMSCI 277.name: Medicinal Chemistry
PHRMSCI 277.description: Fundamentals of medicinal chemistry covering diverse aspects of drug design, discovery, synthesis, and development. Molecular basis of drug action with an emphasis on the structure-to-function continuum.

PHRMSCI 279.name: Emerging Technologies in Pharmaceutical Sciences and Medicine
PHRMSCI 279.description: Introduces emerging, ground-breaking technologies in pharmaceutical sciences and medicine, including pharmacogenomics, genome editing, and stem cell and engineered T cell therapies. Explores these novel technologies with both their underlying theories and forward-thinking applications.

PHRMSCI 298.name: Research Seminar
PHRMSCI 298.description: Presentation and discussion of current problems and methods in teaching and research in pharmaceutical sciences.

PHRMSCI 299.name: Graduate Research
PHRMSCI 299.description: Supervised original research or investigation under the direction of an individual faculty member.

PHY SCI 5.name: California Teach 1: Introduction to Science and Mathematics Teaching
PHY SCI 5.description: First in a series for students interested in becoming middle or high school teachers of mathematics or science. Students gain an understanding of effective, research-based teaching strategies. Includes supervised field experience in a K-12 classroom.
PHY SCI 5.restriction: Restriction: School of Physical Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Biological Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Engineering students have first consideration for enrollment.

PHY SCI 80.name: Skills Development
PHY SCI 80.description: Undergraduates identify, cultivate, and practice relevant soft skills applicable to careers in mathematics and science. The focus is on career readiness, how to market oneself to future employers, and what to expect from the professional world.
PHY SCI 80.prereqString: Prerequisite:  Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
PHY SCI 80.restriction: Restriction: School of Physical Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment.

PHY SCI 105.name: California Teach 2: Middle School Science and Mathematics Teaching
