PHY SCI 105.description: Second in a series for students interested in becoming middle or high school teachers of mathematics or science. Students gain an understanding of effective, research-based teaching strategies for grades 6-8. Includes supervised field experience in a middle school classroom.
PHY SCI 105.restriction: Restriction: School of Physical Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Biological Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Engineering students have first consideration for enrollment.

PHY SCI 139W.name: Technical Writing and Communication Skills
PHY SCI 139W.description: Workshop in writing technical reports, journal articles, proposals. Oral presentations. Communicating with the public. May not be used in satisfaction of any School or departmental requirement.
PHY SCI 139W.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
PHY SCI 139W.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. School of Physical Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment.

PHY SCI 220.name: Science Communication Skills
PHY SCI 220.description: Development of effective communication skills, oral and written presentations. Topics range from the art of creating keynote slides to strategically crafting a personal story, culminating in a live presentation to an invited audience.

PHYSICS 2.name: Introduction to Mathematical Methods for Physics
PHYSICS 2.description: Provides the applied mathematics and problem solving/presentation skills necessary for success in an introductory physics sequence. Focuses on practical exercises in problem solving. Covers kinematics in one and two dimensions in detail. Additional topics include vectors, differentiation, and integration.
PHYSICS 2.restriction: Restriction: PHYSICS 2 may not be taken for credit if taken after PHYSICS 7C.

PHYSICS 3A.name: Basic Physics I
PHYSICS 3A.restriction: Restriction: PHYSICS 3A may not be taken for credit if taken after PHYSICS 7C.

PHYSICS 3B.name: Basic Physics II
PHYSICS 3B.prereqString: Prerequisite: PHYSICS 3A or AP Physics C: Mechanics. AP Physics C: Mechanics with a minimum score of 5

PHYSICS 3C.name: Basic Physics III
PHYSICS 3C.prereqString:
Corequisite: MATH 2B or MATH 5B, or a score of 4 or higher on the AP Calculus BC exam. 
Prerequisite: PHYSICS 3A or AP Physics C: Mechanics. AP Physics C: Mechanics with a minimum score of 5

PHYSICS 3LB.name: Basic Physics Laboratory
PHYSICS 3LB.description: Practical applications of electronics and classical physics to biology. Goals include skill to use oscilloscope and other basic instrumentation. Materials fee.

PHYSICS 3LC.name: Basic Physics Laboratory
PHYSICS 3LC.description: Practical applications of physics to medical imaging.  Topics include optics, radioactivity, and acoustics. Materials fee.

PHYSICS 7C.name: Classical Physics
PHYSICS 7C.description: Topics include force, energy, momentum, rotation, and gravity.
PHYSICS 7C.prereqString:
Corequisite: MATH 2B
Prerequisite: Recommended: PHYS 2 or (MATH 2D and (CHEM 1C or CHEM H2C or CHEM M3C) or CHEM M2C) or AP Physics C: Mechanics or AP Physics C: Electricity and Magnetism or SAT Mathematics or ACT Mathematics or passing score on self-assessment test. PHYS 2 with a grade of C or better. AP Physics C: Mechanics with a minimum score of 4. AP Physics C: Electricity and Magnetism with a minimum score of 4. SAT Mathematics with a minimum score of 650. ACT Mathematics with a minimum score of 27. Students are recommended to take a self-assessment test provided by the UCI Department of Physics and Astronomy. If the student can fairly easily answer at least 75 percent of the questions with a calculator, but no other help, then the student is ready to take Physics 7C and should enroll in it if they have completed one year of high school physics and are Math 2B ready (or have credit for Math 2B).
PHYSICS 7C.restriction: Restriction: Some offerings restricted to Physics Majors.

PHYSICS 7D.name: Classical Physics
PHYSICS 7D.prereqString:
Corequisite: PHYSICS 7LD and MATH 2D
Prerequisite: PHYSICS 7C and (MATH 2B or AP Calculus BC). AP Calculus BC with a minimum score of 4
PHYSICS 7D.restriction: Restriction: Physics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PHYSICS 7E.name: Classical Physics
PHYSICS 7E.restriction: Restriction: Physics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PHYSICS 7LC.name: Classical Physics Laboratory
PHYSICS 7LC.description: Experiments related to lecture topics in Physics 7C. Materials fee.
PHYSICS 7LC.restriction: Restriction: Physics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PHYSICS 7LD.name: Classical Physics Laboratory
PHYSICS 7LD.restriction: Restriction: Physics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PHYSICS 12.name: Science Fiction and Science Fact
PHYSICS 12.description: An introduction to fundamental physics principles, the scientific process, and the mathematical language of science, used to analyze topics drawn from superheroes, science fiction works, and current science news to distinguish science fiction and science fact.

PHYSICS 14.name: Energy and the Environment
PHYSICS 14.description: The physics of society’s energy production and consumption, and of their influences on the environment. Topics include fossil and renewable energy resources

PHYSICS 15.name: Physics of Music
PHYSICS 15.description: Introduces basic physical principles underlying generation and properties of music, including basic properties of sound waves, musical scales and temperament, musical instruments, and acoustics of music halls.  No mathematics background required, but high school algebra is recommended.

PHYSICS 17.name: Physics of Athletics
PHYSICS 17.description: Introduces basic physical principles behind motion. Examples are drawn from a range of athletic endeavors (such as ice skating, baseball, diving, and dance). No mathematics background required, but high school algebra is recommended.

PHYSICS 18.name: How Things Work
PHYSICS 18.description: Survey of the physical basis of modern technology, with an emphasis on electronics and materials. Topics include power generation and distribution, communication (radio, TV, telephone, computers, tape recorders, CD players), imaging (optics, x-rays, MRI), and modern materials (alloys, semiconductors, superconductors).

PHYSICS 19.name: Great Ideas of Physics
PHYSICS 19.description: Introduces non-science majors to physics, examining important breakthroughs and controversies. Potential topics: Einstein's Relativity

PHYSICS 20A.name: Introduction to Astronomy
PHYSICS 20A.description: History of astronomy. Underlying physics. Objects in the solar system and how they are studied. Properties of stars: their formation, structure, and evolution. Pulsars and black holes. Galaxies and quasars.

PHYSICS 20B.name: Cosmology: Humanity's Place in the Universe
PHYSICS 20B.description: An overview of the origin, evolution, and ultimate fate of the Universe. Galaxies and dark matter. The Big Bang and dark energy.  Ancient world models.

PHYSICS 20D.name: Space Science
PHYSICS 20D.description: Space exploration. Human missions to the moon, Mars, and beyond. Space stations, observatories, and deep-space probes. Robots and drones on distant worlds. Propulsion mechanisms, rockets, space flight, and the dangers of solar radiation.

PHYSICS 20E.name: Life in the Universe
PHYSICS 20E.description: An overview of the scientific quest to discover life elsewhere in the universe. Topics include the origin of life on Earth, Mars, extra-solar planets, interstellar travel, and extra-terrestrial intelligence.

PHYSICS 21.name: Special Topics in Physics
PHYSICS 21.description: Topics addressed vary each quarter. Past topics have included physics and music, Newton, planetary science. Lectures on areas of special interest in physics used to introduce students to scientific method, fundamental laws of science, qualitative and quantitative analysis of data.

PHYSICS 50.name: Introductory Mathematical Physics
PHYSICS 50.description: Introduction to math methods for upper-division physics. Taylor and Fourier series
PHYSICS 50.restriction: Restriction: Physics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PHYSICS 52A.name: Fundamentals of Experimental Physics
PHYSICS 52A.description: Optics: lenses, mirrors, polarization, lasers, optical fibers, interference, spectra. Materials fee.
PHYSICS 52A.restriction: Restriction: Physics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PHYSICS 52B.name: Fundamentals of Experimental Physics
PHYSICS 52B.description: Circuits: oscilloscope, meters, DC and AC circuits. Materials fee.
PHYSICS 52B.restriction: Restriction: Physics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PHYSICS 52C.name: Fundamentals of Experimental Physics
PHYSICS 52C.description: Data analysis: random and systematic errors, curve fitting
PHYSICS 52C.restriction: Restriction: Physics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PHYSICS 53.name: Introduction to Programming and Numerical Analysis
PHYSICS 53.restriction: Restriction: Physics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PHYSICS 60.name: Thermal Physics
PHYSICS 60.description: Introduction to thermodynamics and systems of many particles. Topics include first and second laws of thermodynamics, ideal gas laws, kinetic theory, heat engines and refrigerators, thermodynamic potentials, phase transitions, dilute solutions, chemical equilibrium, and basic statistical distributions.

PHYSICS 61C.name: Introduction to Astrophysics
PHYSICS 61C.description: Introduction to fundamental topics in astrophysics, including stellar structure and evolution

PHYSICS H80.name: Impact of World War I on Science
PHYSICS H80.description: Introduction to science in 1914 and WWI. Participants in groups of two or three will pick a preferred science
PHYSICS H80.restriction: Restriction: Campuswide Honors Collegium students only.

PHYSICS H90.name: The Idiom and Practice of Science
PHYSICS H90.description: A series of fundamental and applied scientific problems of social relevance. Possible topics include Newton's Law, calculus, earthquake physics, and radiation.
PHYSICS H90.restriction: Restriction: Campuswide Honors Collegium students only.

PHYSICS 99.name: Current Topics in Physics
PHYSICS 99.description: Designed to introduce undergraduate students to current topics in physics. Focus is discussion of selected readings on current research issues.

PHYSICS 100.name: Computational Methods
PHYSICS 100.description: Mathematical and numerical analysis using Mathematica and C programming, as applied to problems in physical science.
PHYSICS 100.prereqString:
Corequisite: MATH 2E
Prerequisite: MATH 3A or MATH H3A

PHYSICS 106W.name: Advanced Data Acquisition, Analysis, and Scientific Writing
PHYSICS 106W.description: Introduces modern practical laboratory techniques for developing data interface devices, acquiring and analyzing data, and writing up results in manuscript format. Experiments include interfacing with instruments through software and hardware development, PID controller, Fourier analysis, and lock-in amplifier.

PHYSICS 112A.name: Electromagnetic Theory
PHYSICS 112A.description: Electric, magnetic, and gravitational fields and potentials

PHYSICS 112B.name: Electromagnetic Theory
PHYSICS 112B.description: Electric, magnetic, and gravitational fields and potentials

PHYSICS 113A.name: Quantum Mechanics
PHYSICS 113A.description: The wave function and its interpretation

PHYSICS 113B.name: Quantum Mechanics
PHYSICS 113B.prereqString: Prerequisite: PHYSICS 111B and PHYSICS 112B and PHYSICS 113A

PHYSICS 113C.name: Quantum Mechanics
PHYSICS 113C.description: Symmetries and conservation laws in quantum mechanics
PHYSICS 113C.prereqString: Prerequisite: PHYSICS 111B and PHYSICS 112B and PHYSICS 113B

PHYSICS 115A.name: Statistical Physics
PHYSICS 115A.description: Microscopic theory of temperature, heat, and entropy
PHYSICS 115A.prereqString: Prerequisite: PHYSICS 50 and (PHYSICS 60 or CHEM 1C or ENGRMAE 91)

PHYSICS 116.name: Relativity and Black Holes
PHYSICS 116.description: Introduces students to both special and general relativity

PHYSICS 120.name: Electronics for Scientists
PHYSICS 120.description: Applications of modern semiconductor devices to physical instrumentation. Characteristics of semiconductor devices, integrated circuits, analog and digital circuits. Materials fee.

PHYSICS 121W.name: Advanced Laboratory
PHYSICS 121W.description: Experiments in atomic, condensed matter, nuclear, particle, and plasma physics. Introduction to instrumentation and a first experience in the research laboratory.
PHYSICS 121W.prereqString: Prerequisite: (PHYSICS 51B or PHYSICS 61B or PHYSICS 61C) and (PHYSICS 52C or PHYSICS 193) and (PHYSICS 194 or EDUC 143BW)

PHYSICS 133.name: Introduction to Condensed Matter Physics
PHYSICS 133.description: Phenomena of solids and their interpretation in terms of quantum theory.

PHYSICS 134A.name: Physical and Geometrical Optics
PHYSICS 134A.description: Focuses on the practical aspects of optics and optical engineering, starting at the fundamentals. Topics include geometrical optics, ray tracing, polarization optics, interferometers, and diffractive optics.

PHYSICS 135.name: Plasma Physics
PHYSICS 135.description: Basic concepts, orbits, kinetic and fluid equations, Coulomb collisions, fluctuations, scattering, radiation.

PHYSICS 136.name: Introduction to Particle Physics
PHYSICS 136.description: Experimental techniques and theoretical concepts of high-energy phenomena: accelerators and detectors

PHYSICS 137.name: Introduction to Cosmology
PHYSICS 137.description: Solution of the differential equations governing the expansion of the Universe. Observational determinations of the parameters governing the expansion. Big Bang inflation, primordial nucleosynthesis, and cosmic microwave background. Dark matter, dark energy, and large-scale structure of the Universe.

PHYSICS 138.name: Astrophysics of Galaxies
PHYSICS 138.description: Introduction to the solar neighborhood, Milky Way, and other galaxies. Interstellar medium. Star formation. Stellar populations. Evolution of spiral, elliptical, and irregular galaxies. Supermassive black holes, quasars, and active galaxies. Galaxies as probes of the expansion rate of the Universe.

PHYSICS 139.name: Observational Astrophysics
PHYSICS 139.description: Telescopes and astronomical observations, imaging with CCD detectors and image processing techniques. Photometry and spectroscopy of stars, galaxies, and quasars. Advanced imaging techniques such as deconvolution, adaptive optics, and interferometry.
PHYSICS 139.prereqString:
Corequisite: PHYSICS 194
Prerequisite: PHYSICS 52A and PHYSICS 52B and PHYSICS 52C and (PHYSICS 53 or I&C SCI 45C or EECS 12)

PHYSICS 144.name: Stellar Astrophysics
PHYSICS 144.prereqString: Prerequisite: (PHYSICS 51A or PHYSICS 61A) and PHYSICS 111A and PHYSICS 112A

PHYSICS 145.name: High-Energy Astrophysics
PHYSICS 145.description: Production of radiation by high-energy particles, white dwarfs, neutron stars, and black holes. Evolution of galactic nuclei, radio galaxies, quasars, and pulsars.  Cosmic rays and the cosmic background radiation.
PHYSICS 145.prereqString: Prerequisite: (PHYSICS 51A or PHYSICS 61A) and PHYSICS 111A and PHYSICS 112A

PHYSICS 146A.name: Biophysics of Molecules and Molecular Machines
PHYSICS 146A.description: Physical concepts and experimental and computational techniques used to study the structure and function of biological molecules and molecular machines with examples from enzyme action, protein folding, molecular motors, photobiology, chemotaxis, and vision.

PHYSICS 146B.name: Biophysics of Molecules and Molecular Machines
PHYSICS 146B.description: Physical concepts and experimental and computational techniques used to study the structure and function of biological molecules and molecular machines with examples from enzyme action, protein folding, molecular motors, photobiology, chemotaxis, and vision.

PHYSICS 147B.name: Techniques in Medical Imaging I: X-ray, Nuclear, and NMR Imaging
PHYSICS 147B.description: Ionizing radiation, planar and tomographic radiographic and nuclear imaging, magnetism, NMR, MRI imaging.

PHYSICS 147C.name: Techniques in Medical Imaging II: Ultrasound, Electrophysiological, Optical
PHYSICS 147C.description: Sound and ultrasound, ultrasonic imaging, physiological electromagnetism, EEG, MEG, ECG, MCG, optical properties of tissues, fluorescence and bioluminescence, MR impedance imaging, MR spectroscopy, electron spin resonance and ESR imaging.

PHYSICS 150.name: Special Topics in Physics and Astronomy
PHYSICS 150.description: Current topics in physics.  Includes topics from nano-science, biological sciences, astrophysics, and the common use of estimation across subdisciplines within physics.

PHYSICS 191.name: Field Experience in Physics Education
PHYSICS 191.description: Students develop and perform physics assemblies at neighboring public schools.
PHYSICS 191.prereqString: Prerequisite: PHYSICS 7C and PHYSICS 7D and PHYSICS 7E

PHYSICS 192.name: Tutoring in Physics
PHYSICS 192.description: Formalizes the already existing free tutoring for the lower-division physics courses that is provided by the Society of Physics Students (SPS). Includes instructions on tutoring techniques.
PHYSICS 192.restriction: Restriction: Society of Physics Students (SPS) tutoring program students only.

PHYSICS 193.name: Research Methods
PHYSICS 193.description: Explores tools of inquiry for developing and implementing science research projects.  Students undertake independent projects requiring data collection, analysis, and modeling, and the organization and presentation of results.  Additional topics include ethical issues and role of scientific literature.
PHYSICS 193.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI 14 or PHY SCI 5

PHYSICS 194.name: Research Communication for Physics Majors
PHYSICS 194.description: Students learn the fundamentals of communicating about research. Topics include preparing abstracts, proposals, and literature reviews. Provides preparation for presentation of independent research projects in PHYSICS 121 and PHYSICS 196.
PHYSICS 194.prereqString: Prerequisite: PHYSICS 61A or PHYSICS 51A. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

PHYSICS 195.name: Undergraduate Research
PHYSICS 195.description: Independent research under the guidance of a Physics faculty member.
PHYSICS 195.restriction: Restriction: Juniors only. Physics Majors only.

PHYSICS 196A.name: Thesis in Physics I
PHYSICS 196A.description: Independent research for seniors conducted under the guidance of a faculty member. Students’ research results are discussed in oral presentations, and a written proposal, progress report, and thesis are submitted.

PHYSICS 196B.name: Thesis in Physics II
PHYSICS 196B.description: Independent research for seniors conducted under the guidance of a faculty member. Students’ research results are discussed in oral presentations, and a written proposal, progress report, and thesis are submitted.

PHYSICS 196C.name: Thesis in Physics III
PHYSICS 196C.description: Independent research for seniors conducted under the guidance of a faculty member. Students’ research results are discussed in oral presentations, and a written proposal, progress report, and thesis are submitted.

PHYSICS H196A.name: Honors Thesis in Physics I
PHYSICS H196A.description: Independent research for seniors conducted under the guidance of a faculty member. Students’ research results are discussed in oral presentations, and a written proposal, progress report, and thesis are submitted.
PHYSICS H196A.restriction: Restriction: Physics Majors only. Campuswide Honors Collegium students only. Honors Program in Physics students only.

PHYSICS H196B.name: Honors Thesis in Physics II
PHYSICS H196B.description: Independent research for seniors conducted under the guidance of a faculty member. Students’ research results are discussed in oral presentations, and a written proposal, progress report, and thesis are submitted.
PHYSICS H196B.restriction: Restriction: Physics Majors only. Campuswide Honors Collegium students only. Honors Program in Physics students only.

PHYSICS H196C.name: Honors Thesis in Physics III
PHYSICS H196C.description: Independent research for seniors conducted under the guidance of a faculty member. Students’ research results are discussed in oral presentations, and a written proposal, progress report, and thesis are submitted.
PHYSICS H196C.restriction: Restriction: Physics Majors only. Campuswide Honors Collegium students only. Honors Program in Physics students only.

PHYSICS 199.name: Readings on Special Topics
PHYSICS 199.description: Readings in selected areas of Physics. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

PHYSICS 206.name: Advanced Data Acquisition and Analysis
PHYSICS 206.description: Introduces students to a variety of practical laboratory techniques, including lock-in, boxcar, coincidence counting, noise filtering, PID control, properties of common transducers, computer interfacing to instruments, vacuum technology, laboratory safety, basic mechanical design, and shop skills. Materials fee.

PHYSICS 207.name: Applied Physical Chemistry
PHYSICS 207.description: Introduction to fundamental concepts in molecular structure and reactivity: theory of bonding, valence and molecular orbitals

PHYSICS 208.name: Math Methods
PHYSICS 208.description: Applications of mathematics to physical and chemical problems. Calculus of special functions, complex variables and vectors

PHYSICS 214C.name: Many Body Theory
PHYSICS 214C.description: Application of field theory methods, perturbative and non-perturbative, to many particle systems
PHYSICS 214C.prereqString: Prerequisite: PHYSICS 214A and PHYSICS 215A and PHYSICS 215B

PHYSICS 220.name: Electronics for Scientists
PHYSICS 220.description: Applications of modern semiconductor devices to physical instrumentation. Characteristics of semiconductor devices, integrated circuits, analog and digital circuits.

PHYSICS 222.name: Continuum Mechanics
PHYSICS 222.description: Introduction to the continuum limit and stress and strain tensors. Hydrodynamics of perfect fluids

PHYSICS 223.name: Machine Learning and Statistics
PHYSICS 223.description: Theory and practice of machine learning and statistics for physics and astronomy. Topics include: clustering, dimensionality reduction, Bayesian statistics, Markovchains, variational inference, supervised and unsupervised learning, neural networks and modern deep learning architectures. Familiarity with python numerical programing assumed.

PHYSICS 228.name: Electromagnetism
PHYSICS 228.description: Maxwell’s equations, electrodynamics, electromagnetic waves and radiation, wave propagation in media, interference and quantum optics, coherent and incoherent radiation, with practical applications in interferometry, lasers, waveguides, and optical instrumentation.

PHYSICS 229A.name: Computational Methods
PHYSICS 229A.description: Mathematical and numerical analysis using Mathematica and C programming, as applied to problems in physical science.

PHYSICS 230A.name: Biophysics of Molecules and Molecular Machines
PHYSICS 230A.description: Physical concepts and experimental and computational techniques used to study the structure and function of biological molecules and molecular machines with examples from enzyme action, protein folding, molecular motors, photobiology, chemotaxis, and vision.

PHYSICS 230B.name: Biophysics of Molecules and Molecular Machines
PHYSICS 230B.description: Physical concepts and experimental and computational techniques used to study the structure and function of biological molecules and molecular machines with examples from enzyme action, protein folding, molecular motors, photobiology, chemotaxis, and vision.

PHYSICS 234A.name: Elementary Particle Physics
PHYSICS 234A.description: Overview of Standard Model theory and phenomenology. Electromagnetic, strong and weak forces, quark model, interactions with matter, particle detectors and accelerators.

PHYSICS 234B.name: Advanced Elementary Particle Physics
PHYSICS 234B.description: SU(3)xSU(2)xU(1) model of strong, weak, and electromagnetic interactions. K-meson system and CP violation, neutrino masses and mixing, grand-unified theories, supersymmetry, introduction to cosmology and its connection to particle physics.

PHYSICS 234C.name: Advanced Elementary Particle Physics
PHYSICS 234C.description: SU(3)xSU(2)xU(1) model of strong, weak, and electromagnetic interactions. K-meson system and CP violation, neutrino masses and mixing, grand-unified theories, supersymmetry, introduction to cosmology and its connection to particle physics.

PHYSICS 235A.name: Quantum Field Theory
PHYSICS 235A.description: Canonical quantization, scalar field theory, Feynman diagrams, tree-level quantum electrodynamics.

PHYSICS 235B.name: Advanced Quantum Field Theory
PHYSICS 235B.description: Pathintegral techniques, loop diagrams, regularization and renormalization, anomalies.

PHYSICS 238A.name: Condensed Matter Physics
PHYSICS 238A.prereqString: Prerequisite: PHYSICS 133 and (PHYSICS 214A or CHEM 232A) and (PHYSICS 215B or CHEM 231B)

PHYSICS 239A.name: Plasma Physics
PHYSICS 239A.description: Basic concepts, orbits, kinetic and fluid equations, Coulomb collisions, fluctuations, scattering, radiation.

PHYSICS 239B.name: Plasma Physics
PHYSICS 239B.description: Magnetic confinement, MHD equilibrium and stability, collisional transport.

PHYSICS 239C.name: Plasma Physics
PHYSICS 239C.description: Linear waves and instabilities, uniform un-magnetized and magnetized plasmas, non-uniform plasmas.

PHYSICS 240A.name: Galactic Astrophysics
PHYSICS 240A.description: The morphology, kinematics, and evolution of our Milky Way and other galaxies.  Topics include stellar formation and stellar evolution, end states of stars (supernovae, neutron stars), the distribution of stars, interstellar gas and mass in galaxies. The Local Group.

PHYSICS 240B.name: Cosmology
PHYSICS 240B.description: An introduction to modern cosmology set within the context of general relativity.  Topics include the expansion history of the Universe, inflation, the cosmic microwave background, density fluctuations, structure formation, dark matter, dark energy, and gravitational lensing.

PHYSICS 240C.name: Radiative Processes in Astrophysics
PHYSICS 240C.description: Exploration of radiation mechanisms (electron scattering, synchrotron emission, collisional excitation, and more) and radiative transfer through matter including absorption and emission. Includes such observational astrophysics topics as spectroscopic study of atoms and nuclei, X-rays, and cosmic rays.

PHYSICS 241A.name: Solar System and Extrasolar Planets
PHYSICS 241A.description: Formation, evolution, and habitability of planetary systems. Observational and theoretical study of the origin and evolution of the Solar System, present day dynamical state of the Solar System (asteroids, Kuiper Belt Objects, Oort cloud), planetary atmospheres, processes governing planetary climate.

PHYSICS 241B.name: Stellar Astrophysics
PHYSICS 241B.description: Physics of stellar interiors and equations of stellar structure. Stellar atmospheres and absorption processes. Introduction to stellar winds. Thermonuclear reactions, nucleosynthesis, and solar neutrinos. Binary stars and mass accretion. White dwarfs, supernovae, neutron stars, and black holes.

PHYSICS 241C.name: Extragalactic Astrophysics
PHYSICS 241C.description: The physics and phenomenology of galaxies

PHYSICS 241D.name: Early Universe Physics
PHYSICS 241D.description: Includes a thorough quantum treatment of the generation of perturbations during inflation and various topics related to kinetic theory in an expanding Universe. Other topics include the astrophysics and cosmology of weakly interacting particles.

PHYSICS 242.name: Astro Fundamentals
PHYSICS 242.description: Introduction to topics in astrophysics including measurement of stellar properties, stellar structure and evolution, stellar remnants and supernovae, the interstellar medium, exoplanets, gravitational lensing, galactic structure, extragalactic distance measurements, and the expanding universe.

PHYSICS 246.name: Special Topics in Astrophysics
PHYSICS 246.description: Outlines and emphasizes a subarea of astrophysics that is undergoing rapid development.

PHYSICS 247.name: Special Topics in Particle Physics
PHYSICS 247.description: Current topics in particle non-accelerator-based research fields.

PHYSICS 248.name: Special Topics in Condensed Matter Physics
PHYSICS 248.description: Outlines and emphasizes a subarea of condensed matter physics that is undergoing rapid development.

PHYSICS 249.name: Special Topics in Plasma Physics
PHYSICS 249.description: Outlines and emphasizes a subarea of plasma physics that is undergoing rapid development.

PHYSICS 250.name: Physics and Astronomy Communications Skills
PHYSICS 250.description: Fundamentals of effectively communicating research through written and oral platforms. Topics include writing compelling proposals and journal articles for peer review, and the development of engaging oral presentations of science results and significance to a wide range of audiences.

PHYSICS 255.name: General Relativity
PHYSICS 255.description: An introduction to Einstein’s theory of gravitation. Tensor analysis, Einstein’s field equations, astronomical tests of Einstein’s theory, gravitational waves.

PHYSICS 260A.name: Seminar in Condensed Matter Physics
PHYSICS 260A.description: Seminar designed to acquaint students with recent advances in solid state physics. Lecturers from the Department of Physics and Astronomy (both faculty and graduate students), other UCI departments, and other institutions.

PHYSICS 260B.name: Seminar in Condensed Matter Physics
PHYSICS 260B.description: Seminar designed to acquaint students with recent advances in solid state physics. Lecturers from the Department of Physics and Astronomy (both faculty and graduate students), other UCI departments, and other institutions.

PHYSICS 260C.name: Seminar in Condensed Matter Physics
PHYSICS 260C.description: Seminar designed to acquaint students with recent advances in solid state physics. Lecturers from the Department of Physics and Astronomy (both faculty and graduate students), other UCI departments, and other institutions.

PHYSICS 261A.name: Seminar in Plasma Physics
PHYSICS 261A.description: Advanced topics in plasma physics:  wave propagation, nonlinear effects, kinetic theory and turbulence, stability problems, transport coefficients, containment, and diagnostics. Applications to controlled fusion and astrophysics.

PHYSICS 261B.name: Seminar in Plasma Physics
PHYSICS 261B.description: Advanced topics in plasma physics:  wave propagation, nonlinear effects, kinetic theory and turbulence, stability problems, transport coefficients, containment, and diagnostics. Applications to controlled fusion and astrophysics.

PHYSICS 261C.name: Seminar in Plasma Physics
PHYSICS 261C.description: Advanced topics in plasma physics:  wave propagation, nonlinear effects, kinetic theory and turbulence, stability problems, transport coefficients, containment, and diagnostics. Applications to controlled fusion and astrophysics.

PHYSICS 263A.name: Seminar in Particle Physics
PHYSICS 263A.description: Discussion of advanced topics and reports of current research results in theoretical and experimental particle physics and cosmic rays.

PHYSICS 263B.name: Seminar in Particle Physics
PHYSICS 263B.description: Discussion of advanced topics and reports of current research results in theoretical and experimental particle physics and cosmic rays.

PHYSICS 263C.name: Seminar in Particle Physics
PHYSICS 263C.description: Discussion of advanced topics and reports of current research results in theoretical and experimental particle physics and cosmic rays.

PHYSICS 265A.name: Seminar in Astrophysics
PHYSICS 265A.description: Acquaints students with current research in astrophysics. Lecturers from the Department of Physics and Astronomy and from other institutions.

PHYSICS 265B.name: Seminar in Astrophysics
PHYSICS 265B.description: Acquaints students with current research in astrophysics. Lecturers from the Department of Physics and Astronomy and from other institutions.

PHYSICS 265C.name: Seminar in Astrophysics
PHYSICS 265C.description: Acquaints students with current research in astrophysics. Lecturers from the Department of Physics and Astronomy and from other institutions.

PHYSICS 266.name: Current Topics in Chemical, Applied, and Materials Physics
PHYSICS 266.description: The subjects covered vary from year to year.  Connection between fundamental principles and implementations in practice in science, industry, and technology.

PHYSICS 268.name: Seminar in Systems Microbiology Research
PHYSICS 268.description: A research and journal club seminar that covers topics on bacteria and phage using approaches and principles from biology, engineering, and physics.
PHYSICS 268.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. Graduate students only.

PHYSICS 269.name: Seminar in Teaching Physics
PHYSICS 269.description: Techniques for effective teaching.  Covers active listening and student engagement, problem-solving skills, peer instruction and collaborative learning, and evaluation.  Required of all new Teaching Assistants.

PHYSICS 273.name: Technical Communication Skills
PHYSICS 273.description: Development of effective communication skills, oral and written presentations, through examples and practice.

PHYSICS 291.name: Research Seminar
PHYSICS 291.description: Detailed discussion of research problems of current interest in the Department.  Format, content, and frequency of the course are variable.

PHYSICS 295.name: Experimental Research
PHYSICS 295.description: With the approval of a faculty member, a student may pursue a research program in experimental physics.  Typical areas include astrophysics, condensed matter physics, elementary particle physics, and plasma physics.
PHYSICS 295.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. School of Physical Sciences students only.

PHYSICS 296.name: Theoretical Research
PHYSICS 296.description: With approval of a faculty member, a student may pursue a research program in theoretical physics. Typical areas include astrophysics, condensed matter physics, elementary particle physics, and plasma physics.
PHYSICS 296.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. School of Physical Sciences students only.

PHYSICS 298.name: Physics Colloquium
PHYSICS 298.description: Seminar held each week, in which a current research topic is explored. Frequently, off-campus researchers are invited to present the seminar, and on occasion a faculty member or researcher from the Department will speak.
PHYSICS 298.restriction: Restriction: School of Physical Sciences students only.

PHYSICS 299.name: Reading of Special Topic
PHYSICS 299.description: With special consent from a faculty member who will agree to supervise the program, a student may receive course credit for individual study of some area of physics.

PHYSICS 395.name: Laboratory Teaching
PHYSICS 395.description: Required of and limited to teaching assistants of undergraduate laboratory courses. Designed to teach the  necessary skills required of teaching assistants for these courses.

PHYSICS 399.name: University Teaching
PHYSICS 399.description: Required of and limited to Teaching Assistants.

PHYSIO 200.name: Research in Physiology and Biophysics
PHYSIO 200.description: Individual research directed toward doctoral dissertation and supervised by a particular professor.

PHYSIO 200R.name: Research in Physiology and Biophysics for First-Year Students
PHYSIO 200R.description: Independent research within the laboratories of graduate training faculty in the Department of Physiology and Biophysics for first-year Ph.D. students.

PHYSIO 201.name: Introduction to Physiology Research
PHYSIO 201.description: Introduction to research in physiology and related sciences. Concentrates on techniques emphasized in the various laboratories of the Department of Physiology and Biophysics.

PHYSIO 206A.name: Introduction to Medical Physiology
PHYSIO 206A.description: Vertebrate physiology with emphasis on humans and on the relationship between the function of normal tissues and the processes of disease. Fundamental principles of physiology and the interrelationships which control organ function.

PHYSIO 206B.name: Introduction to Medical Physiology
PHYSIO 206B.description: Vertebrate physiology with emphasis on humans and on the relationship between the function of normal tissues and the processes of disease. Fundamental principles of physiology and the interrelationships which control organ function.

PHYSIO 212.name: Medical Immunology
PHYSIO 212.description: One of the cornerstones of the MS1 Molecular Basis of Medicine block. Includes temporal coordination of lecture material, regular course director meetings, and combined exams with PHYSIO 544: Medical Immunology.

PHYSIO 215.name: Integrative Immunology
PHYSIO 215.description: Provides an introduction to immunology, but focuses on providing in-depth analysis of selected topics within the broader field of immunology, including relevant research techniques, while improving critical thinking skills.

PHYSIO 232.name: The Physiology of Ion Channels
PHYSIO 232.description: Discusses how ion channels work (molecular/structural biophysics level) and what ion channels do in diverse cell types (cell physiology level).

PHYSIO 252.name: Introduction to Proteomics
PHYSIO 252.description: Introduces students to concepts and methods of proteomics including protein identification, expression proteomics, and protein-protein interactions.

PHYSIO 272.name: Eye: Health and Disease
PHYSIO 272.description: Introduces the anatomic and physiological basis of vertebrate vision and disease states in which the structure and function of the eye is disrupted with emphasis on current and developing research areas.

PHYSIO 290.name: Topics in Physiology
PHYSIO 290.description: Contemporary research problems in physiology. Students review research articles in current literature and present ideas contained therein, focusing on groundbreaking discoveries and methodologies. Students present results of their own research and attend presentations given by other students and departmental researchers.

PHYSIO 292A.name: Scientific Communication
PHYSIO 292A.description: Small group meetings for graduate students to practice scientific writing, debate, and presentation skills.

PHYSIO 292B.name: Scientific Communication
PHYSIO 292B.description: Small group meetings for graduate students to practice scientific writing, debate, and presentation skills.

PHYSIO 292C.name: Scientific Communication
PHYSIO 292C.description: Small group meetings for graduate students to practice scientific writing, debate, and presentation skills.

PHYSIO 299.name: Dissertation in Physiology and Biophysics
PHYSIO 299.description: Preparation and completion of the dissertation required for the Ph.D.

POL SCI 10A.name: Probability and Statistics in Political Science I
POL SCI 10A.description: Introduction to the variety of statistical applications in the social sciences.  Descriptive statistics.  Measures of central tendency and dispersion.  Percentile ranks.  Standardization and normal approximation.  Basic probability theory focuses on application to statistical inference and binomial distribution.  Laboratory required.

POL SCI 10B.name: Probability and Statistics in Political Science II
POL SCI 10B.description: Introduction to statistical inference, sampling distribution, standard error.  Hypothesis tests for proportions and means. Inferential techniques for nominal variables including chi-square, study measures of strengths, significance of relationships between variables, assumptions, data requirements, and types of error in significance tests.

POL SCI 10C.name: Probability and Statistics in Political Science III
POL SCI 10C.description: Focus on correlation, regression, and control for effects of variables.  One-way and two-way factorial analysis of variance.  A priori and a posteriori comparisons.  Introduction to repeated measures design and non-parametric statistics. Discusses use of statistics in newspapers and popular magazines.

POL SCI 11A.name: Introduction to Political Science: Political Analysis
POL SCI 11A.description: Presents various modes of understanding politics. Emphasis on basic approaches to political analysis, their uses in constructing theories, and their application to particular national political systems.

POL SCI 11C.name: Introduction to Political Science: Micropolitics
POL SCI 11C.description: Introduction to political behavior of individuals and groups within national systems. Three questions addressed: How do individuals come to understand the political world? How do individuals behave within this world? How do groups and individuals engage in the political process.

POL SCI 21A.name: Introduction to American Government
POL SCI 21A.description: Introduction to American political processes and institutions. Topics include elections, political participation, parties, interest groups, the Presidency, Congress, the bureaucracy, and the judiciary.

POL SCI 31A.name: Introduction to Political Theory
POL SCI 31A.description: Types of questions:  What is politics?  What are the theoretical and philosophical bases for different types of political arrangements?  How do these perspectives get translated into reality?  Among others, the works of Rousseau, Locke, Mill, and Marx are read.

POL SCI 32A.name: Dilemmas of Diversity
POL SCI 32A.description: Focuses on racial, ethnic, and gender diversity, multiculturalism, and their impact on our social and political ideals. Traces the sources of ideas about difference, equality, and toleration, and examines tensions that occur when forms of identity conflict with one another.

POL SCI 41A.name: Introduction to International Relations
POL SCI 41A.description: Analysis of political relations between and among nations with emphasis on explanations of conflict and cooperation. The role of ideologies and their relation to international problems are also examined.
POL SCI 41A.restriction: Restriction: Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

POL SCI 44B.name: Global Political Ideologies
POL SCI 44B.description: An overview of the major political ideologies shaping the current world order and global conflict. Topics include liberalism, democracy, nationalism, capitalism, communism, socialism, fascism, neoliberalism, clash of civilizations, sectarian violence, populist nationalism, and de-globalization.
POL SCI 44B.restriction: Restriction: International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

POL SCI 45A.name: Human Rights and Global Governance
POL SCI 45A.description: Historical development of civil, political rights and the rise of human rights in international law. Explores role, and limitations, of the UN, ICJ, and ICC in global governance. Reconceptualizing democracy and political representation in a postnational 21st century.
POL SCI 45A.restriction: Restriction: International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

POL SCI 49.name: Lower-Division Special Topics in International Relations
POL SCI 49.description: Studies in selected areas of international relations. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

POL SCI 51A.name: Introduction to Politics Around the World
POL SCI 51A.description: Introduces comparative politics. Compares political systems in a variety of countries. Includes elections, parties, parliaments, presidents, protest movements, and other aspects of national politics. Addresses how to make meaningful comparisons across countries.

POL SCI 61A.name: Introduction to Race and Ethnicity in Political Science
POL SCI 61A.description: Examines major theories that attempt to explain the roles of race and ethnicity in U.S. politics.

POL SCI 71A.name: Introduction to Law
POL SCI 71A.description: An introduction to the study of judicial politics.  Questions include:  what is law?

POL SCI H80.name: Globalization and Human Security
POL SCI H80.description: Emerging issues of human security in the globalized world, including personal human security, physical integrity, human trafficking, global climate change, food. Challenges of these complex human security problems for a multi-scalar system (international, national, local).
POL SCI H80.restriction: Restriction: Campuswide Honors Collegium students only.

POL SCI 120.name: Public Opinion
POL SCI 120.description: Theories concerning sources of public opinion, processes by which it is altered, organization of citizens’ belief systems, and role of public opinion in government policy. Students analyze survey data as a research project.
POL SCI 120.restriction: Restriction: Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

POL SCI 121A.name: The American Presidency
POL SCI 121A.description: Presents a comprehensive survey of the American presidency and considers the question of political power.
POL SCI 121A.restriction: Restriction: Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

POL SCI 121C.name: U.S. Elections and Voting Behavior
POL SCI 121C.description: Examines how voters evaluate political parties, candidates, and issues in electoral campaigns to reach their decisions. Numerous controversies concerning the degree of issue voting, sophistication of candidate evaluations, and the decline of political parties are discussed.
POL SCI 121C.restriction: Restriction: Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

POL SCI 121F.name: Presidents Since World War II
POL SCI 121F.description: Reviews the actions and character of presidents from Harry Truman through Bill Clinton.  Each week a different president is examined from a variety of perspectives.  Students are expected to write a substantial original research paper.
POL SCI 121F.restriction: Restriction: Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

POL SCI 121G.name: American Public Policy
POL SCI 121G.description: Focuses on the development and implementation of public policy in the United States. Lectures cover theoretical models of the policy process as well as significant problems facing contemporary American decision-makers.

POL SCI 121HW.name: Writing for the President of the United States
POL SCI 121HW.description: Imagines how White House staffers can help presidents with clear, focused, and effective writing. Through a variety of formats, students study, hone, and practice writing skills that will prove useful- in and out of the White House.

POL SCI 122A.name: American Metropolitan Politics
POL SCI 122A.description: Explores the politics of urban and suburban America, including the policy making process
POL SCI 122A.restriction: Restriction: Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

POL SCI 122B.name: California Politics
POL SCI 122B.description: Examines the structure and function of California government, traces historical development of political power, with constantly changing casts of power-brokers and seekers. Explores California exceptionalism and the roles played by the electorate, legislature, executive, and organized interests in policy making.
POL SCI 122B.restriction: Restriction: Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

POL SCI 122BW.name: California Politics
POL SCI 122BW.description: Examines the structure and function of California government, traces historical development of political power, with constantly changing casts of power-brokers and seekers. Explores California exceptionalism and the roles played by the electorate, legislature, executive, and organized interests in policy making.
POL SCI 122BW.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division writing requirement.
POL SCI 122BW.restriction: Restriction: Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

POL SCI 123B.name: Representation
POL SCI 123B.description: Deals with classical theories of representation: issues of racial and political representation in U.S. legislatures and city councils
POL SCI 123B.prereqString: Prerequisite: SOC SCI 3A or SOC SCI 10A or SOC SCI 10B
POL SCI 123B.restriction: Restriction: Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

POL SCI 124A.name: The Politics of Protest
POL SCI 124A.description: Examines the Civil Rights, Black Power, and women’s movements in relationship to the Asian American movement. Uses social movement theories to illuminate the cases, and the cases to critique and revise the theories.

POL SCI 124B.name: Latinos in U.S. Politics
POL SCI 124B.description: Comparing the political issues facing Latino groups by examining their migration histories, voting behavior, nonelectoral participation, and policy issues.  Latino issues are examined on the national, state, and local levels, including formal representation, immigration, affirmative action, and language policy.

POL SCI 124C.name: Comparative Minority Politics
POL SCI 124C.description: Examines the political experiences of Blacks, Latinos, and Asian Americans in the United States from roughly 1950 to the present. Focuses on how each group has pursued political empowerment via both conventional political channels and social movements.

POL SCI 124E.name: African American Politics
POL SCI 124E.description: Examines politics of African Americans in order to gain a broader perspective of the American political process. Major developments in African American politics (including the civil rights movement, Black presidential bids), continuing problem of racism, responsiveness of key governing institutions.

POL SCI 125A.name: The United States Congress
POL SCI 125A.description: Does the Congress do a good job of representing the American citizenry? Is it the most appropriate mechanism for the creation, resolution, and implementation of public policy.
POL SCI 125A.restriction: Restriction: Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

POL SCI 125CW.name: Constitutional Convention
POL SCI 125CW.description: Analyzes the Constitution, its amendments, and periods of Constitutional reform as a foundation for a critical evaluation of the Constitution with an eye both to necessary reforms and to elements of the Constitution that should be maintained.
POL SCI 125CW.prereqString: Prerequisite: POL SCI 21A. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

POL SCI 126C.name: U.S. Immigration Policy
POL SCI 126C.description: Examines selected immigration policy debates since the nineteenth century, rationale and consequences of immigration law since 1965, problems of administration, implementation and enforcement, impact of immigration policy on foreign relations, and contemporary debate regarding the future of U.S. policy.

POL SCI 126D.name: Urban Politics and Policy
POL SCI 126D.description: Examines economic limits of cities and welfare policy. Addresses such issues as why are the poor concentrated in the central cities? Which anti-poverty programs will work best in cities? Which level of government can best combat poverty in the U.S.
POL SCI 126D.restriction: Restriction: Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

POL SCI 126F.name: Politics of Animal Rights
POL SCI 126F.description: Examines animal rights/welfare movement’s efforts to transform moral, practical, and legal standing of nonhuman animals in contemporary U.S. Explores intersection of racism, sexism, and speciesism informed by theories of race and ethnicity, including Asian American Studies.
POL SCI 126F.restriction: Restriction: Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Asian American Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

POL SCI 128BW.name: Political Ideologies: The Way We View Our World
POL SCI 128BW.description: Politics has become divisive and ideological. But ideologies are poorly understood and have become mere labels for identifying friends and enemies. Course analyzes the nature of ideology, focusing on liberalism, conservatism, fascism, socialism, and contemporary "liberation" ideologies.
POL SCI 128BW.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

POL SCI 128C.name: Political Psychology
POL SCI 128C.description: Examination of how psychological theory and research may be used to better understand political thought and behavior. Drawing on theories of learning, cognition, and personality, discusses such topics as the formation of political attitudes, and the process of political decision-making.
POL SCI 128C.restriction: Restriction: Majors only. POL SCI 128C may not be taken for credit if taken after POL SCI 137C.

POL SCI 129.name: Special Topics in American Politics and Society
POL SCI 129.description: Studies in selected areas of American politics and society. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
POL SCI 129.restriction: Restriction: Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

POL SCI 130A.name: Game Theory and Politics I
POL SCI 130A.description: Introduction to game theory and a survey of its political applications. Examples of topics covered include voting in small committees, legislatures, and mass elections
POL SCI 130A.restriction: Restriction: Social Policy/Public Service Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Sociology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

POL SCI 130B.name: Game Theory and Politics II
POL SCI 130B.description: More advanced game theory and its political applications, beginning where Game Theory and Politics I ends.  Examples of topics covered include revolutions
POL SCI 130B.restriction: Restriction: Social Policy/Public Service Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

POL SCI 131C.name: Modern Political Theory
POL SCI 131C.description: Examines major thinkers and intellectual movements in the political thought of the 17th and 18th centuries.
POL SCI 131C.restriction: Restriction: Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

POL SCI 131F.name: Twentieth Century Political Theory
POL SCI 131F.description: Examines major thinkers and intellectual movements in the political thought of the 20th Century.

POL SCI 134F.name: Social and Political Theory
POL SCI 134F.description: Focus is on recent major work in social and political theory. An in-depth analysis of a relatively small body of writing. Authors discussed include Jurgen Habermas, Anthony Giddens, and Richard Rorty.
POL SCI 134F.restriction: Restriction: Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

POL SCI 135A.name: Origins of Liberalism
POL SCI 135A.description: Examines the ideals, social forces, and historical events that gave rise to liberal political theory. Topics include patriarchal authority, the divine right of kings, religious toleration, slavery, colonialism, political economy, the evolution of law, and tensions between liberty and equality.
POL SCI 135A.restriction: Restriction: Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

POL SCI 135B.name: Just War Revisited
POL SCI 135B.description: Examines the evolution of the doctrine of the just war across the history of Western political thought, the importance of changes in the doctrine and whether it applies today

POL SCI 136B.name: Cannibals and Conquistadores: The Philosophy of the Other
POL SCI 136B.description: Examines critically the notion of the "other" by looking at the philosophical challenges difference poses in the context of the European discovery of the New World. Seeks to understand the naissance of the concept of human rights and tolerance.

POL SCI 136BW.name: Cannibals and Conquistadores: The Philosophy of the Other
POL SCI 136BW.description: Examines critically the notion of the "other" by looking at the philosophical challenges difference poses in the context of the European discovery of the New World. Seeks to understand the naissance of the concept of human rights and tolerance.
POL SCI 136BW.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

POL SCI 136E.name: France and You: Trans-Atlantic Problems and Partnerships - Past, Present, Future
POL SCI 136E.description: Co-taught by professors from UC and Sciences Po, French and UCI students are brought together in a virtual classroom. Students engage in joint projects on issues of global import: democratic fragility, race relations, international security, and climate change.

POL SCI 137BW.name: Types of Political Representation
POL SCI 137BW.description: Political representation plays an important role in democratic systems, but is elusive once examined closely.  Students delve into the concept and relate different views to political life. Half of the course is spent on writing instruction.
POL SCI 137BW.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
POL SCI 137BW.restriction: Restriction: Recommended: Upper-Division students. Political Science majors have first consideration for enrollment.

POL SCI 138A.name: The Moral of the Story: Introductory Seminar in Ethics
POL SCI 138A.description: Introduces major theories and classic texts in ethics, from Plato and Aristotelian virtue ethics to utilitarianism and Kant and contemporary moral psychology.

POL SCI 138AW.name: Moral of the Story: Introduction to Ethics
POL SCI 138AW.description: Focuses on how we learn about ethics from stories, in the form of fables, bedtime stories, religious stories, soap operas, television, and movies as adults. Students bring in stories that informed their own ethical development.
POL SCI 138AW.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

POL SCI 138CW.name: Ethics of Difference
POL SCI 138CW.description: Examines differences traditionally judged politically salient—race, ethnicity, religion, gender. Personal interviews with an elderly person encourage students to understand the social construction of difference and to reexamine their own attitudes by putting themselves in the place of another.
POL SCI 138CW.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
POL SCI 138CW.restriction: Restriction: Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

POL SCI 138DW.name: The Moral Life During War
POL SCI 138DW.description: Can people keep their humanity during war? What does the term humanity signify when simply surviving requires faith, courage, and desperation? When facing wartime brutality, must we abrogate morality? What does it mean to compose a moral life during war?.
POL SCI 138DW.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
POL SCI 138DW.restriction: Restriction: Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

POL SCI 139.name: Special Topics in Political Theory and Methods
POL SCI 139.description: Studies in selected areas of political theory and methods. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
POL SCI 139.restriction: Restriction: Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

POL SCI 141B.name: International Political Economy
POL SCI 141B.description: Examination of problems in global political-economic relations through competing conceptual lenses or grand theories: mercantilism, liberalism, and Marxism. Surveys North-North and North-South issues relating power and wealth.

POL SCI 141C.name: International Political Economy of East Asia
POL SCI 141C.description: Integration of theoretical perspectives in international political economy with the study of economic development in East Asia, with special emphasis on regional integration.

POL SCI 141E.name: US Foreign Policy Toward Asia
POL SCI 141E.description: U.S. policy toward the countries of East Asia: bilateral and regional security relationships, U.S. economic relations with the major Asian countries, the development of regional institutions, and human rights.

POL SCI 142B.name: The International Relations of East Asia
POL SCI 142B.description: Surveys various aspects of relations between the nations of East Asia. Topics include the historical development of the region
POL SCI 142B.restriction: Restriction: Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

POL SCI 142D.name: U.S. Foreign Policy I: Globalism and Cold War
POL SCI 142D.description: Looks at changing international perspectives, policy responses, and military strategies of presidential administrations from Truman to Reagan. In assessing the motives and objectives of U.S. foreign policy leaders during the “Cold War” era, the concept of “national interest” is examined.
POL SCI 142D.restriction: Restriction: Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

POL SCI 142G.name: US Coercive Diplomacy
POL SCI 142G.description: Examines the theory of compellence and the U.S. practice of coercive diplomacy - the power to change behavior of other governments. Specific case examples: the Cuban missile crisis, bombing of North Vietnam, the Nicaraguan Contras, Desert Shield/Desert Storm, and Libya.
POL SCI 142G.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

POL SCI 142H.name: Human Rights and Foreign Policy
POL SCI 142H.description: Analyzes theories, patterns, and cases of human rights foreign policy. How do countries pursue the values and standards of human rights in their foreign relations. How does the U.S. fit into worldwide trends? Examines historical and contemporary cases.
POL SCI 142H.restriction: Restriction: Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

POL SCI 142J.name: U.S. Intervention in Latin America
POL SCI 142J.description: Explores political, economic, social, and cultural ties that bind Latin America to the United States. Focuses on U.S. intervention and Latin American response from early nineteenth century to present day. Case studies include Mexico, Guatemala, Cuba, Chile, and Central America.

POL SCI 143G.name: Homeland Security
POL SCI 143G.description: Examines the 9/11 origins of the concept of homeland security

POL SCI 144A.name: Approaches to International Relations
POL SCI 144A.description: Reviews theoretical and methodological approaches to the study of international relations using contending perspectives to analyze power and influence, capabilities, interdependence, reciprocity, international regimes, anarchy, cooperation, imperialism, and hegemony.
POL SCI 144A.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

POL SCI 145A.name: Ethics in an Age of Terror and Genocide
POL SCI 145A.description: Original sources document personal impact of wars on genocides, from World War II to the Bosnian and Rwandan genocides and current wars in Iraq and Afghanistan. Students train for and conduct personal interviews with someone who lived through a war.

POL SCI 146B.name: Religion and World Politics
POL SCI 146B.description: Examines the relationship between religion and world politics historically and today, focusing on connections with peace/war, democracy, human rights, secularism(s), and globalization. Covers major debates, scholarship, concepts, and theories through class exercises, exams, and essays.
POL SCI 146B.prereqString: Prerequisite: POL SCI 41A or INTL ST 11 or INTL ST 12 or REL STD 5A or REL STD 5B or REL STD 5C

POL SCI 147CW.name: International Humanitarianism
POL SCI 147CW.description: Examines, analyzes, and evaluates the humanitarian phenomenon, the actors involved in it (including states, international organizations (IOs), and nongovernmental organizations (NGOs)), the rise of a body of international humanitarian law, and the problems and debates associated with international humanitarianism today.
POL SCI 147CW.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

POL SCI 147D.name: International Organizations
POL SCI 147D.description: Active learning course that examines origins, decision-making processes, activities, and evolution of leading international organizations (e.g. U.N., NATO, EU, AU, WTO, World Bank, IMF). Activities include drafting reforms, applying theory, assessing dysfunctions, and participating in U.N. negotiation simulations.
POL SCI 147D.restriction: Restriction: Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

POL SCI 147E.name: Critical Investigations into Humanitarianism in Africa
POL SCI 147E.description: Explores the complex phenomenon of aid to Africa (emergency and development aid), and the representational, cultural, historical, and other reasons why some participants and many observers critique it. Students occasionally engage with peers and faculty in African institutions.

POL SCI 149.name: Special Topics in International Relations
POL SCI 149.description: Studies in selected areas of international relations. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
POL SCI 149.restriction: Restriction: Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

POL SCI 151B.name: Introduction to Chinese Politics
POL SCI 151B.description: Background to the Chinese revolution, rise of the communist party
POL SCI 151B.restriction: Restriction: Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

POL SCI 151C.name: Chinese Politics: Policy, Leadership, and Change
POL SCI 151C.description: Examines major policies from 1949 to the present, and considers the changing role of the Communist Party and its shifting treatment of various social groups
POL SCI 151C.restriction: Restriction: Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

POL SCI 151H.name: Voting and Political Manipulation
POL SCI 151H.description: Introduction to social choice and cooperative games. Topics include majority rule, types of voting methods, apportionment and proportional representation, agenda manipulation, coalition formation, voting power, political consequences of electoral laws.
POL SCI 151H.restriction: Restriction: Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

POL SCI 152F.name: West European Politics
POL SCI 152F.description: Explores four main themes: (1) thinking scientifically about politics
POL SCI 152F.restriction: Restriction: Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

POL SCI 152K.name: Immigration Politics in Western Europe
POL SCI 152K.description: Examines immigration politics in Western Europe, analyzing trends and policy from the postwar period through to today. Topics include citizenship, immigrant integration, asylum, the far-right, and a rotating focus on contemporary issues, e.g., terrorism, Islamophobia.

POL SCI 153B.name: Canadian Politics
POL SCI 153B.description: Addresses the basic structures and processes of contemporary Canadian government and politics. Additional topics may include regionalism, federalism, western alienation and oil, Canadian solutions to social welfare policy questions, developments in Quebec, and other issues associated with French-English relations.
POL SCI 153B.restriction: Restriction: Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

POL SCI 153E.name: Human Rights
POL SCI 153E.description: Examines the causes and consequences of human rights violations with a focus on Latin America. What are human rights? When and where are they violated? What political mechanisms are available to deal with human rights problems? How effective are they.
POL SCI 153E.restriction: Restriction: Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

POL SCI 153G.name: Cuban Society and Revolution
POL SCI 153G.description: Explores the causes, development, and legacy of the 1959 Revolution. Themes include economic dependency, democracy, race, gender, culture, and the always volatile relations between Cuba and the United States.

POL SCI 154C.name: Comparative Politics: Four Nations, Three Continents
POL SCI 154C.description: Studies four countries in a comparative fashion: their respective political histories and cultural traditions
POL SCI 154C.restriction: Restriction: Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

POL SCI 154F.name: Peoples and Cultures of Post-Soviet Eurasia
POL SCI 154F.description: Examines the cultures and political conflicts of the more than 130 indigenous ethnic groups in the European and Asian territories of the former U.S.S.R. Emphasis is on the theoretical issues of ethnicity, nationalism, and conflict management.

POL SCI 154G.name: Conflict Resolution in Cross-Cultural Perspective
POL SCI 154G.description: Examines theories of conflict management. Analyzes how conflict is mitigated in diverse cultures: at the interpersonal level, between groups, and on the international scale. Students discuss readings, hear from conflict management practitioners, and simulate negotiations.

POL SCI 154J.name: Jews and Power
POL SCI 154J.description: Examines the relationship between the Jewish people and political power over a 3500 year period. How have Jews preserved their communal interests and personal safety? How have they defined the proper relationship of the people to political authority.

POL SCI 154KW.name: US Government in Comparative Perspective
POL SCI 154KW.description: Introduction to the United States in comparative perspective, covering general features of the United States and other countries, such as institutional design and policy choices. Addresses the debates about American exceptionalism and American decline.
POL SCI 154KW.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
POL SCI 154KW.restriction: Restriction: Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

POL SCI 155C.name: Organizations
POL SCI 155C.description: How bureaucracies, formal organizations, and voluntary associations work, how/why they grow, and where they are going. History and structure of organizational rationality
POL SCI 155C.restriction: Restriction: Sociology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

POL SCI 156A.name: Political Participation
POL SCI 156A.description: The ways in which people in various political systems take part in politics, especially in activities directed toward affecting outcomes.  Who is active, what they do, why they do it, and what difference it makes.

POL SCI 156D.name: Protests, Movements, and Revolutions
POL SCI 156D.description: A survey of models of collective action drawn from sociology, economics, psychology, and political science. Focus on areas such as social movements, strikes, crowd psychology, cults, fads, fashions, public opinion, and symbolic and mythical elements in collective culture.
POL SCI 156D.prereqString: Prerequisite: SOCIOL 1 or POL SCI 11A or ECON 1
POL SCI 156D.restriction: Restriction: Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Sociology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

POL SCI 157B.name: International Divided Cities
POL SCI 157B.description: Investigates urban divisions in international cities where deep-seated nationalistic ethnic differences create pressures for intergroup conflicts, autonomy, or territorial separation, and can incite violence. Urban political polarization as it is manifest in the urban setting.

POL SCI 158D.name: Introduction to Contemporary Middle East Politics
POL SCI 158D.description: An overview of basic issues that shape the politics of the Middle East and North Africa. Themes include implication of the colonization era, nation-state formation, inter-Arab relations, nationalism, Arab-Israel conflict, Islamic resurgence, and more.

POL SCI 159.name: Special Topics in Comparative Politics
POL SCI 159.description: Studies in selected areas of comparative politics. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
POL SCI 159.restriction: Restriction: Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

POL SCI 169.name: Special Topics in Race and Ethnicity Politics
POL SCI 169.description: Studies in selected areas of race and ethnicity. Topics vary each quarter.
POL SCI 169.restriction: Restriction: Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

POL SCI 171AW.name: Law and Society
POL SCI 171AW.description: Law and its various roles in society. The nature and meaning of law
POL SCI 171AW.prereqString: Prerequisite: POL SCI 71A. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
POL SCI 171AW.restriction: Restriction: Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

POL SCI 171CW.name: Comparative Constitutional Politics
POL SCI 171CW.description: Examines the impact of constitutional courts on politics and policy-making in Canada, France, Germany, and the United States. Cases may focus on the constitutional politics of free speech, abortion, rights to property, and the conduct of foreign relations.
POL SCI 171CW.prereqString: Prerequisite: POL SCI 71A. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
POL SCI 171CW.restriction: Restriction: Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

POL SCI 171D.name: American Constitutional Law
POL SCI 171D.description: American constitutional interpretation of cases involving separation of powers, federal-state relations, rights of property, free expression, privacy, criminal due process, political participation, and equality. Includes legal research methods, development of judicial review, legal reasoning, and impact of Supreme Court decisions.
POL SCI 171D.restriction: Restriction: Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

POL SCI 171F.name: Law in the Twenty-First Century
POL SCI 171F.description: Examines the complex relationship between law, the social sciences, and modern society.  Lectures explore such issues as the interplay between technology and constitutional rights, the impact of science on law, and the evolving roles of attorneys and judges.
POL SCI 171F.restriction: Restriction: Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

POL SCI 171G.name: Legal Implications of the Drug Trade
POL SCI 171G.description: Examines United States policy to combat domestic and international narcotics trafficking. Analyzes the national drug policy and program implementation by federal and state agencies. Considers the effects of these policies on our individual constitutional rights and the criminal justice system.

POL SCI 172A.name: International Law
POL SCI 172A.description: Examination of the origin, changing structure, application of international law, and the role of legal norms in regulating the behavior of states and maintaining international order.

POL SCI 174A.name: Civil Liberties
POL SCI 174A.description: Political analysis of selected Supreme Court cases involving claims under the Bill of Rights and the Fourteenth Amendment. Topics include:  race, sex, and other forms of discrimination
POL SCI 174A.restriction: Restriction: Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

POL SCI 174C.name: U.S. Supreme Court
POL SCI 174C.description: Overview and analysis of the role played by the U.S. Supreme Court in the American political system. Judicial review, appointment of justices, judicial activism and judicial restraint, process of case selection, court deliberation, land decision-making, impact of Supreme Court decisions.
POL SCI 174C.restriction: Restriction: Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

POL SCI 174CW.name: U.S. Supreme Court
POL SCI 174CW.description: Overview and analysis of the role played by the U.S. Supreme Court in the American political system. Judicial review, appointment of justices, judicial activism and judicial restraint, process of case selection, court deliberation, land decision-making, impact of Supreme Court decisions.
POL SCI 174CW.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
POL SCI 174CW.restriction: Restriction: Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

POL SCI 175.name: The Bill of Rights in Film
POL SCI 175.description: Focuses on ways American cinema has portrayed, represented, and analyzed U.S. Bills of Rights. Juxtaposes cinematic presentations on specific Bill of Rights clauses, treating films as cultural texts, with pertinent judicial decisions and more scholarly appraisals of those same provisions.

POL SCI 179.name: Special Topics in Public Law
POL SCI 179.description: Studies in selected areas of public law. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
POL SCI 179.restriction: Restriction: Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

POL SCI H180D.name: Honors Seminar in Political Science
POL SCI H180D.description: Course for students enrolled in the Honors Program in Political Science.
POL SCI H180D.prereqString: Prerequisite: Only open to students in the Political Science Honors Program.

POL SCI H182A.name: Honors Thesis Workshop
POL SCI H182A.description: A weekly seminar/workshop to facilitate the exchange of ideas and research strategies among students and to review their progress in writing the thesis.
POL SCI H182A.restriction: Restriction: Open only to students in the Political Science Senior Thesis program.

POL SCI 190.name: Senior Thesis
POL SCI 190.description: Thesis research with Political Science faculty.

POL SCI 190W.name: Senior Thesis
POL SCI 190W.description: Thesis research with Political Science faculty.
