POL SCI 190W.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

POL SCI 197.name: Field Study
POL SCI 197.description: Field study with Political Science faculty.

POL SCI 198.name: Directed Group Study
POL SCI 198.description: Directed group study with Political Science faculty.

POL SCI 199.name: Independent Study
POL SCI 199.description: Independent study or research with a Political Science faculty member.

POL SCI 209A.name: Study of Democracy Colloquium
POL SCI 209A.description: Skills critical to professional success. Students learn and practice professional presentation skills, develop substantive knowledge in the field by attending talks and panels, and interact with scholars and professionals in the field.
POL SCI 209A.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. POL SCI 209A may not be taken for credit if taken after SOCIOL 229.

POL SCI 209B.name: Study of Democracy Colloquium
POL SCI 209B.description: This colloquium teaches students skills critical to professional success. Students learn and practice professional presentation skills and develop substantive knowledge in the field by attending talks and panels and interacting with scholars and professionals in the field.
POL SCI 209B.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. POL SCI 209B may not be taken for credit if taken after SOCIOL 229 Democracy.

POL SCI 209C.name: Study of Democracy Colloquium
POL SCI 209C.description: This colloquium teaches students skills critical to professional success. Students learn and practice professional presentation skills and develop substantive knowledge in the field by attending talks and panels and interacting with scholars and professionals in the field.
POL SCI 209C.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. POL SCI 209C may not be taken for credit if taken after SOCIOL 229 Democracy.

POL SCI 210A.name: Colloquium
POL SCI 210A.description: Doctoral training requires more than learning substantive debates and research methods

POL SCI 210B.name: Colloquium
POL SCI 210B.description: Doctoral training requires more than learning substantive debates and research methods

POL SCI 210C.name: Colloquium
POL SCI 210C.description: Doctoral training requires more than learning substantive debates and research methods

POL SCI 212A.name: Public Opinion
POL SCI 212A.description: Introduction to the study of U.S. public opinion. Provides an overview of the theories regarding opinion formation, the methodologies employed, and the role of public opinion in democratic governments.

POL SCI 212B.name: Ethics Workshop
POL SCI 212B.description: Students find an important question in ethics, search literature to assess topic's importance, post question to be researched, propose method of analysis and type of data, analyze data, and note how their works contribute to knowledge in the field.

POL SCI 219.name: Special Topics in Politics and Society
POL SCI 219.description: Current research in politics and society.

POL SCI 221A.name: Public Policy
POL SCI 221A.description: Explores different approaches to public policy analysis, the diverse conceptions of the goals and objectives that should be served by policy, and the appropriate role of the policy analyst.  Policy consequences are traced to indirect and subtle incentives and disincentives.

POL SCI 223A.name: Theories of Power and Empowerment
POL SCI 223A.description: Studies different ways of thinking about power and its uses. Explores theories of power that inform various notions of empowerment, including resistance, participatory democracy, and workplace empowerment.

POL SCI 229.name: Special Topics in American Politics
POL SCI 229.description: Current research in American Politics. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

POL SCI 231A.name: Political Epistemology
POL SCI 231A.description: Focuses on fundamental issues of knowledge in the study of politics, especially interconnections and tensions between politics and knowledge.  Counts as the Field Seminar in Political Theory.

POL SCI 231B.name: Theories of Textual Interpretation
POL SCI 231B.description: Examination of different theories of textual interpretation, including Straussian, hermeneutical, poststructuralist, feminist, postcolonial, and critical race theories. Key questions include: How does one go about the task of interpreting texts? What makes one interpretation better or more insightful than another.

POL SCI 238D.name: The Moral Life During War
POL SCI 238D.description: Can people keep their humanity during war? What does the term humanity signify when simply surviving requires faith, courage, and desperation? When facing wartime brutality must we abrogate morality? What does it mean to compose a moral life during war?.
POL SCI 238D.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

POL SCI 239.name: Special Topics in Political Theory
POL SCI 239.description: Current research in political theory. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

POL SCI 241B.name: Seminar in International Relations Theory
POL SCI 241B.description: Overview of the major theories guiding research and scholarship in international relations.  Focus on major conceptual approaches (realism, neoliberalism, marxism) and levels of analysis (systemic, state, and subnational), as well as on methodological/epistemological debates engulfing the field.

POL SCI 241E.name: Research Design in International Relations
POL SCI 241E.description: Surveys research design primarily through substantive readings in international relations. The purpose is to familiarize students with choices/dilemmas relevant to IR-specific research. Students at various stages in the graduate program and with different methodological orientations are welcome.

POL SCI 249.name: Special Topics in International Relations
POL SCI 249.description: Current research in international relations. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

POL SCI 252.name: Introduction to Voting Theory
POL SCI 252.description: Introduction to voting models. Substantive topics include majority rule, voting methods and their properties, apportionment and proportional representation, agenda manipulation, coalition formation, voting power, political consequences of electoral laws.

POL SCI 252G.name: Theories and Practice of Migration and Citizenship
POL SCI 252G.description: Examines theories of migration and citizenship. In examining these themes, the course includes discussion of theory development, multi-method testing, and case study comparison with a focus on Western Europe and other advanced democratic receiving states.

POL SCI 254A.name: Introduction to Game Theory
POL SCI 254A.description: Introduction to non-cooperative games.  The prisoner's dilemma, Nash equilibrium, sequential games, subgame perfection. Applications include collective action, agenda-setter models, spatial competition of political parties, models of revolution and arms race.

POL SCI 259.name: Special Topics in Comparative Politics
POL SCI 259.description: Current research in comparative politics. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

POL SCI 260B.name: Political Participation
POL SCI 260B.description: Examines theoretical approaches to the explanation of the pattern of participation and consideration of the results of empirical studies of such activity by mass publics (mainly in Europe and North America).  Addresses issues in both comparative politics and political behavior.

POL SCI 273A.name: Advanced Qualitative Methods: Analyzing Qualitative Data
POL SCI 273A.description: Introduction to the theory and practice of analyzing qualitative data. Students must have already learned about data collection and research design for qualitative research and must have qualitative data they can analyze.

POL SCI 276.name: Predictive Models in Social Sciences
POL SCI 276.description: Basic numeracy (logarithms, fixed-exponent and exponential formats, graphing). Models based on ignorance and logical constraints. Logical quantitative models (how things should be) to complement and guide statistical analysis (how things are).

POL SCI 285A.name: Introduction to Political Psychology I
POL SCI 285A.description: Reviews theoretical questions regarding the relationship between the analytical and normative and the polity. Considers relationships between the analytical and normative concerns of psychology and political science, addressing empirical literatures on political socialization, ideology and public opinion, identity and nationality.

POL SCI 290.name: Dissertation Research
POL SCI 290.description: Dissertation research with Political Science faculty.

POL SCI 299.name: Independent Study
POL SCI 299.description: Independent research with Political Science faculty.

PORTUG 121.name: Topics in Luso-Brazilian Literature
PORTUG 121.description: In English. Contextualized study of a major author, current, or genre in Brazilian, Portuguese, and/or Lusophone African literature. Examples: Gender, Race, and Sexualities in Postcolonial Lusophone Literatures

PORTUG 243.name: Studies in Luso-Brazilian Literature and Culture
PORTUG 243.description: Critical analysis of selected literary works from Portugal and/or Brazil. Contextualizes the works within their historical and literary specificity, and discusses pertinent theoretical issues raised by them. Taught in Portuguese.

PSCI 9.name: Introduction to Psychology
PSCI 9.description: Introduction to field of psychology, addressing the application of scientific methods to the study of human development, learning, memory, problem solving, perception, biological mechanisms, emotions and motivation, personality, psychopathology, and effects of diverse social and cultural contexts on human behavior.
PSCI 9.restriction: Restriction: Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Public Health Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Public Health Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Urban Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment. PSCI 9 and PSYCH 7A may not be taken for credit if taken concurrently with or after PSCI 11A, PSCI 11B, PSCI 11C, PSYCH 9A, PSYCH 9B, or PSYCH 9C.

PSCI 11A.name: Psychology Fundamentals
PSCI 11A.description: Designed to provide freshman with an in-depth survey of general psychology. Topics include biological bases of behavior, sensation, perception, cognition, development, personality, psychopathology, and social psychology.
PSCI 11A.restriction: Restriction: Lower-division students only. Cognitive Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. PSCI 9 and PSYCH 7A may not be taken for credit if taken after PSCI 11A, PSCI 11B, PSCI 11C, PSYCH 9A, PSYCH 9B, or PSYCH 9C.

PSCI 11B.name: Psychology Fundamentals
PSCI 11B.description: Designed to provide freshmen with an in-depth survey of general psychology. Topics include biological bases of behavior, sensation, perception, cognition, development, personality, psychopathology, and social psychology.
PSCI 11B.restriction: Restriction: Lower-division students only. Cognitive Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Public Health Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Public Health Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Urban Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 11C.name: Psychology Fundamentals
PSCI 11C.description: Designed to provide freshman with an in-depth survey of general psychology. Topics include biological bases of behavior, sensation, perception, cognition, development, personality, psychopathology, and social psychology.
PSCI 11C.restriction: Restriction: Lower-division students only. Cognitive Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Public Health Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Public Health Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Urban Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 100.name: Special Topics in Social Behavior
PSCI 100.description: Course content varies with interest of instructor.
PSCI 100.prereqString: Prerequisite: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11C or PSYC 7A or PSYC 9C
PSCI 100.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 101D.name: Life Span Developmental Psychology
PSCI 101D.description: Addresses the major issues, concepts, and methods of life span developmental psychology. The fundamental theories, distinctive methods, and the physical, perceptual, cognitive, social, motivational, and emotional development for each developmental phase of the life course are considered.
PSCI 101D.prereqString: Prerequisite: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11B or PSYC 7A or PSYC 9B
PSCI 101D.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 102C.name: Abnormal Psychology
PSCI 102C.description: Survey of disorders organized by the diagnostic categories of the American Psychiatric Association. Interdisciplinary orientation combines environmental, psychological, and organic perspectives on etiology and treatment.
PSCI 102C.prereqString: Prerequisite: (PSCI 9 or PSCI 11C or PSYC 7A or PSYC 9C) and SE 10
PSCI 102C.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 103H.name: Health Psychology
PSCI 103H.description: Theory and research are considered as they contribute to an understanding of the role of psychological processes in health and illness. The distinction between prevention and treatment of illness is established, and a variety of psychosocial interventions are elaborated.
PSCI 103H.prereqString: Prerequisite: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11C or PSYC 7A or PSYC 9C
PSCI 103H.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 104S.name: Social Animal: An Introduction to Social Psychology
PSCI 104S.description: Theories and research exploring social behavior and social influences on behavior. Topics include methods of social research, attitude formation and change, social perception, the social self, stereotypes and prejudice, conformity, obedience, altruism, aggression, interpersonal relationships and love, and group behavior.
PSCI 104S.prereqString: Prerequisite: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11C or PSYC 7A or PSYC 9C
PSCI 104S.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 110D.name: Infant Development
PSCI 110D.description: Study of human development from conception through the first two years of life, covering processes and events in the domains of physical, social, and cognitive development.
PSCI 110D.prereqString: Prerequisite: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11B or PSYC 7A or PSYC 9B
PSCI 110D.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 111D.name: Child Development
PSCI 111D.description: Examines social, emotional, and intellectual growth and development between the ages of 2 and 12 years.
PSCI 111D.prereqString: Prerequisite: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11B or PSYC 7A or PSYC 9B
PSCI 111D.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 111W.name: Advanced Research Methods
PSCI 111W.description: For students planning to conduct senior research projects or apply to graduate school in social research fields. Topics include reviewing literature, preparing a research proposal, protecting human subjects, citing scholarly work, building measures, estimating sample size, interview and presentation skills.
PSCI 111W.prereqString: Prerequisite: SE 10 and SE 13. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

PSCI 112D.name: Adolescent Development
PSCI 112D.description: Examines current research on the biological, social, and cultural contexts of adolescent development. Topics include the impacts of puberty, adolescents' decision-making competencies, changes in family and peer relationships, identity development, and psychosocial problems such as depression and problem behavior.
PSCI 112D.prereqString: Prerequisite: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11B or PSYC 7A or PSYC 9B
PSCI 112D.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 113D.name: Adult Development
PSCI 113D.description: Examines why and how we change (with attention to gains as well as losses) from ages 18-65 and the nature and sources of continuity over time. Topics include physical and intellectual functioning, personality, coping strategies, and social roles and relationships.
PSCI 113D.prereqString: Prerequisite: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11B or PSYC 7A or PSYC 9B
PSCI 113D.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 115D.name: Cognitive Development
PSCI 115D.description: Examines theories on nature of cognitive development. Discusses behaviorist theories on role of the environment including those of Vygotsky and Piaget, and recent evidence from cognitive psychologists stressing the importance of knowledge and skills within specific domains.
PSCI 115D.prereqString: Prerequisite: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11B or PSYC 7A or PSYC 9B
PSCI 115D.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 116D.name: Human Development and Cross-Cultural Perspectives
PSCI 116D.description: Human development in diverse cultures (e.g., Asian, American, and African). Special emphasis on East-West contrasts and when East meets West (i.e., Asian-American experiences). Topics include parenting, family relations, language and cognition, schooling and academic achievement, and morality.
PSCI 116D.prereqString: Prerequisite: (PSCI 9 or PSCI 11B or PSYC 7A or PSYC 9B) and SE 10
PSCI 116D.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 117D.name: The Psychology of Gender
PSCI 117D.description: Discussion of gender identity development and examination of gender differences and similarities across the life span. Consideration of the biology and psychology of gender in relation to physical, behavioral, personality, and intellectual capabilities.
PSCI 117D.prereqString: Prerequisite: PSCI 9 or PSYC 9B or PSCI 11B or PSYC 7A
PSCI 117D.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 118D.name: Human Sexuality
PSCI 118D.description: A broad survey of human sexuality encompassing genetic factors, physiological and anatomical development, customary and atypical forms of behavior, reproductive processes, and cultural determinants.
PSCI 118D.prereqString: Prerequisite: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11B or PSYC 7A or PSYC 9B
PSCI 118D.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 121D.name: Work and Family
PSCI 121D.description: Effects of employment and unemployment on mental health and marital quality
PSCI 121D.prereqString: Prerequisite: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11C or PSYC 7A or PSYC 9C
PSCI 121D.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 126D.name: Development of Motivation Across the Lifespan
PSCI 126D.description: Introduces major concepts in life-span development of motivation and self-regulation, and discusses exemplar empirical findings pertaining to these concepts during the various phases of life. Students participate in discussion, present findings from research articles, and write a paper.
PSCI 126D.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors only. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors only. Social Ecology Majors only.

PSCI 127D.name: Attachment Relationships
PSCI 127D.description: Students learn about the development of attachment-related needs throughout development, as well as the links between attachment and emotion, psychopathology and treatment. Lectures emphasize classic as well as cutting-edge research and are supplemented by primary source readings.
PSCI 127D.prereqString: Prerequisite: PSCI 9 or PSYC 7A or PSCI 11A or PSYC 9A or PSCI 11B or PSYC 9B
PSCI 127D.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 136H.name: Behavioral Medicine
PSCI 136H.description: Examines biobehavioral aspects of health and illness, focusing on how stress contributes to or exacerbates disease processes. Background information on psychosomatic medicine and stress models and detailed examination of specific organ systems emphasizing the reactivity of these systems to stress.
PSCI 136H.prereqString: Prerequisite: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11C or PSYC 7A or PSYC 9C
PSCI 136H.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Public Health Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 137H.name: Human Stress
PSCI 137H.description: Stress as a multidisciplinary topic. Biological, psychological, and sociological approaches to adaptation-related disorders. Effects of acute and chronic stress on emotions, physiology, and behavior. Methods of stress assessment, stress reduction, and intervention.
PSCI 137H.prereqString: Prerequisite: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11C or PSYC 7A or PSYC 9C
PSCI 137H.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Public Health Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 138H.name: Child Health Psychology
PSCI 138H.description: Exploration of psychological antecedents, concomitants, and consequences of medical illnesses in children. Children's beliefs about health, illness, and medication
PSCI 138H.prereqString: Prerequisite: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11C or PSYC 9C or PSYC 7A. Recommended: SE 10.
PSCI 138H.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Public Health Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 139H.name: Clinical Sport Psychology
PSCI 139H.description: An interdisciplinary introduction to clinical sport psychology, that includes, among other things, an introduction to psychopathology in sport
PSCI 139H.prereqString: Prerequisite: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11C or PSYC 7A or PSYC 9C
PSCI 139H.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 140H.name: The Hardiness Approach to Stress Management
PSCI 140H.description: New development within psychology involving a combination of motivations and skills that extensive research has shown enhances performance, conduct, morale, stamina, and health. Combines study of hardiness research with strategies for improvement of personal hardiness through a series of exercises.
PSCI 140H.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 141H.name: Clinical Health Psychology
PSCI 141H.description: Behavioral role in etiology, treatment, and prevention of certain diseases. Behavioral intervention including biofeedback, stress-, pain-management, health habit counseling, and other skills to assist patients make cognitive, emotional, and behavioral changes needed to cope with disease or achieve better health.
PSCI 141H.prereqString: Prerequisite: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11C or PSYC 7A or PSYC 9C
PSCI 141H.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Public Health Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Public Health Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 142H.name: Introduction to Interdisciplinary Salivary Bioscience
PSCI 142H.description: Introduction to the integration of salivary analytes into developmental, social, behavioral, and health sciences. Lectures cover theoretical perspectives
PSCI 142H.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors only. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors only. Social Ecology Majors only.

PSCI 143H.name: The Science and Practice of Wellness and Resilience
PSCI 143H.description: Wellness is a common, but elusive goal. Covers the history, theory, psychology, and behavioral science behind skills for wellness and resilience. Provides opportunities to practice the strategies to help further understanding of the behavioral nature of each of the areas.
PSCI 143H.prereqString: Prerequisite: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11C or PSYC 7A or PSYC 9C
PSCI 143H.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors only. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors only. Social Ecology Majors only.

PSCI 150C.name: Clinical Psychology
PSCI 150C.description: Overview of theories, assessment techniques, research methodologies, and intervention approaches in clinical psychology. Psychodynamic, behavioral, humanistic, and cognitive perspectives are examined along with ethical and professional issues.
PSCI 150C.prereqString: Prerequisite: (PSCI 9 or PSCI 11C or PSYC 7A or PSYC 9C) and PSCI 102C
PSCI 150C.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 152C.name: Clinical Child Psychology
PSCI 152C.description: Examines research and theory concerning childhood psychopathology behavior disorders. Diagnosis and assessment, early identification of high-risk children, fears and phobias, antisocial behavior, childhood psychoses, autism, depression, attention deficit/hyperactivity disorders, and ethical and policy implications of identifying children who are different.
PSCI 152C.prereqString: Prerequisite: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11C or PSYC 7A or PSYC 9C
PSCI 152C.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 153C.name: Developmental Psychopathology
PSCI 153C.description: Research and theory of origins, course, and outcomes of disordered behavior. Continuity and change in patterns of behavior
PSCI 153C.prereqString: Prerequisite: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11C or PSYC 7A or PSYC 9C. Recommended: SE 10.
PSCI 153C.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 154C.name: Cognitive Behavior Therapy
PSCI 154C.description: Presentation of principles and procedures of therapeutic interventions based on cognitive-behavior methods. Cognitive factors in learning, emotional arousal, psychological disorder, and psychotherapy reviewed. Introduces the application of cognitive behavioral methods to problems of depression, anxiety, anger, pain, and impulsivity.
PSCI 154C.prereqString: Prerequisite: PSCI 9 or (PSCI 11A and PSCI 11C) or PSYC 7A or (PSYC 9A and PSYC 9C)
PSCI 154C.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 155C.name: Child Therapies
PSCI 155C.description: Examines research methodologies, empirical data, and implications of diverse intervention strategies. Primary topics include psychotherapy process and outcome, family therapies, behavioral intervention, cognitive behavior modification, pediatric psychopharmacology, and ethical and social policy implications of intervening in other people's lives.
PSCI 155C.prereqString: Prerequisite: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11C or PSYC 7A or PSYC 9C
PSCI 155C.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 156C.name: Forensic Psychology: Advanced Seminar
PSCI 156C.description: Focuses on the psychology of criminal offending, particularly violent behavior. Examines violence, sexual offending, and mental disorder related to crime with regard to clinical assessment and treatment
PSCI 156C.prereqString: Prerequisite: (PSCI 9 or PSCI 11C or PSYC 7A or PSYC 9C) and PSCI 102C and (PSCI 178S or CLS C149)
PSCI 156C.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 159C.name: Clinical Neuropsychology
PSCI 159C.description: Introduces key concepts and case studies in clinical neuropsychology. Instruction focuses on neuropsychological concepts underlying brain-behavior relationships and their assessment in clinical case examples
PSCI 159C.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors only. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors only. Social Ecology Majors only.

PSCI 160C.name: Clinical Neuroscience
PSCI 160C.description: An introduction to the neuroclinical bases of human behavior, including neuropsychological approaches to mental disorders. Also includes case formulations, research articles, therapeutic approaches, and other discussions related to select psychopathology and other neurobehavioral topics.
PSCI 160C.prereqString: Prerequisite: PSCI 9 or PSYC 7A or PSCI 11A or PSYC 9A or BIOL 99
PSCI 160C.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Biological Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 161C.name: Forensic Psychology
PSCI 161C.description: Forensic psychology is the interface between clinical psychology and the law. Emphasizes clinically relevant legal topics (insanity defense
PSCI 161C.prereqString: Prerequisite: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11B or PSCI 11C
PSCI 161C.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 162C.name: Psychodynamic Studies
PSCI 162C.description: Introduction to contemporary psychodynamic studies. Emphasis on clinical concepts associated with psychodynamic psychotherapy, including unconscious determinants of behavior, typical defenses, life experiences, and techniques. Exploration of links between psychodynamic-oriented psychotherapy and other disciplines (e.g., psychology, music, medicine, neuroscience, film).
PSCI 162C.prereqString: Prerequisite: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11C or PSYC 7A or PSYC 9C
PSCI 162C.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 163C.name: Human  Neuropsychology
PSCI 163C.description: A survey of human brain disorders using a clinical case study approach to illustrate fundamental issues in studying brain and behavior. Topics include sensory deficits, attentional neglect, amnesia, cortical organization, clinical psychopathology, and more.
PSCI 163C.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIOL N110 or BIOL N115A or PSYC 9A or PSCI 11A
PSCI 163C.restriction: Restriction: School of Biological Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. Cognitive Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 164C.name: Addiction
PSCI 164C.description: Designed for those with an interest in the nature and treatment of addiction. Focuses on the etiology and treatment of addiction, but does not prepare students to treat substance abuse disorders.
PSCI 164C.prereqString: Prerequisite: PSCI 11A and PSCI 11B and PSCI 11C and PSCI 102C
PSCI 164C.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 165C.name: Adult Psychopathology
PSCI 165C.description: Advanced course in abnormal psychology, focusing on adult psychopathology. Covers historical and fundamental issues about psychiatric disorders, clinical research on disorders of anxiety, PTSD, mood, psychoses, personality, and dementia, and their biopsychosocial features, and attends to assessment and treatment.
PSCI 165C.prereqString: Prerequisite: PSCI 102C. Equivalent to PSCI 102C is also accepted.
PSCI 165C.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 166S.name: Chicano/Latino Families
PSCI 166S.description: Introduction to the research, literature, and issues surrounding the topic of Chicano/Latino families including cultural history, contemporary issues, organization of family, traditions, lifestyles, values, beliefs, generational differences, gender issues, ethnic identity, evolution of demographic patterns, current economic and political standings.

PSCI 170S.name: Personality
PSCI 170S.description: Comparison of the major theories of personality. Provides a frame of reference for understanding lifestyles, development, maturity, and psychopathology. Emerging research themes are used to identify promising lines of personality theorizing.
PSCI 170S.prereqString: Prerequisite: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11C or PSYC 7A or PSYC 9C
PSCI 170S.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. Sophomores only. Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 171S.name: Environmental Psychology
PSCI 171S.description: Impact of the physical environment on individual and group behavior. Three basic concerns examined: (a) environmental determinants of behavior at the individual and interpersonal level
PSCI 171S.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 173S.name: Social Relationships
PSCI 173S.description: Examines major issues, concepts, and methods in the scientific study of social relationships. Topics include relationship formation and dissolution, friendships and love relationships, loneliness, bereavement, societal influences on close relationships, significance of close relationships for health and well-being.
PSCI 173S.prereqString: Prerequisite: (PSCI 9 or PSCI 11C or PSYC 7A or PSYC 9C) and SE 10
PSCI 173S.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 174S.name: Error and Bias in Social Judgement
PSCI 174S.description: Examines how people encode, reason about, and remember social information and explores how biases and shortcomings in social perception, judgment, and memory are central to understanding both effective social functioning and many forms of maladaptive behavior and social conflict.
PSCI 174S.prereqString: Prerequisite: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11C or PSYC 7A or PSYC 9C
PSCI 174S.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 176S.name: Motivation
PSCI 176S.description: History, major theories, methods, and applications of motivational psychology, with emphasis on European approaches. Origins of the field in personality, learning, cognition, and activation research. Recent innovations in motivational and volitional self-recognition. Current approaches, major debates, empirical research programs.
PSCI 176S.prereqString: Prerequisite: (PSCI 9 or PSCI 11C or PSYC 7A or PSYC 9C) and PSCI 101D and (PSCI 104S or UPPP 151)
PSCI 176S.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 178S.name: Violence in Society
PSCI 178S.description: Current theory and research on aggression
PSCI 178S.prereqString: Prerequisite: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11C or PSYC 7A or PSYC 9C
PSCI 178S.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. SocEcol-Urban & Regional Plan Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 179S.name: Cultural Psychology
PSCI 179S.description: An examination of culture's influence on human minds. Topics include culture's impact on perception, cognition, motivation, emotion, moral reasoning, communication, and health. Addresses cultural psychology's methods, history, and place within psychology and related fields.
PSCI 179S.prereqString: Prerequisite: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11B or PSCI 11C or PSYC 7A or PSYC 9B or PSYC 9C
PSCI 179S.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 183S.name: Social Epidemiology
PSCI 183S.description: Overviews evidence linking environmental factors to mental and physical disorders including such variables as socioeconomic status, income inequality, work stress, job loss, social capital, location, and other demographic characteristics. Measurement and research design issues of both individual and aggregate levels.
PSCI 183S.prereqString: Prerequisite: (PSCI 9 or PSCI 11C or PSYC 7A or PSYC 9C) and SE 10 and SE 13
PSCI 183S.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Public Health Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Public Health Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 184S.name: Positive Psychology
PSCI 184S.description: The field of positive psychology focuses on what is right and positive about people and institutions. Introduces findings associated with human strengths and positive emotions, and provides clinical and personal applications and implications.
PSCI 184S.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 185S.name: Industrial-Organizational Psychology
PSCI 185S.description: Examines the application of social psychology to organizational settings. Topics include motivation of workers, group decision-making, leadership styles, career management, and organizational development.
PSCI 185S.prereqString: Prerequisite: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11A or PSCI 11B or PSCI 11C or PSYC 7A or PSYC 9A or PSYC 9B or PSYC 9C
PSCI 185S.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 187S.name: Psychology of Inequality
PSCI 187S.description: Focuses on the psychological dimensions of poverty, wealth, and economic inequality.
PSCI 187S.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 188S.name: Evolutionary Psychology
PSCI 188S.description: Understanding our evolutionary origins is critical to truly understanding the complexities of human psychology. Explores how Darwinian principles, applied to both genes and culture, can help us understand not just how the mind works, but why.
PSCI 188S.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 190.name: Applied Statistics in Social and Behavioral Research
PSCI 190.description: Covers statistical techniques used to describe and make generalizations about phenomena represented by data. Hands-on experience in data analysis and interpretation using statistical software (SPSS, STATA) is emphasized. Topics include data visualization, ANOVA, multiple regression, and categorical data analyses.
PSCI 190.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Urban Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 192B.name: The Science and Practice of Compassion
PSCI 192B.description: Explores the latest scientific research on compassion and its correlates, and considers practical strategies for increasing compassion in everyday life. Students discover how cutting-edge research is yielding insights into kindness, empathy, altruism, and compassion.
PSCI 192B.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 192Q.name: Chicano/Latino Social Psychology
PSCI 192Q.description: Examines theories, research, and major issues of relevance to understanding social psychological processes in Chicano/Latino populations. Topics include social development, cultural orientations, gender and sexuality, close relationships, happiness and well-being, stereotyping, prejudice and discrimination, and mental and physical health.
PSCI 192Q.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
PSCI 192Q.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Chicano/Latino Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 192S.name: Health and the Latino Paradox
PSCI 192S.description: Examines research and theories concerning the physical and mental health of U.S. Latino populations. Contemporary accounts, health care implications, and new directions for understanding sources of risks and resilience for health in Latino populations are evaluated and discussed.
PSCI 192S.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
PSCI 192S.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Chicano/Latino Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 192T.name: Cognition and Learning in Educational Settings
PSCI 192T.description: Foundational concepts in cognition and development as applied to student learning. Primary topics include historical behaviorism, basic cognitive structure and processes, complex cognition, cognitive development, and motivation.
PSCI 192T.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Education Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 192U.name: Psychology of Learning, Abilities, and Intelligence
PSCI 192U.description: Overview of classic positions on the mind, human abilities, and intelligence, especially as related to academic achievement. Contrasting views: psychometric versus information processing
PSCI 192U.prereqString: Prerequisite: PSYC 7A or PSCI 9 or PSCI 11A or PSCI 11B or PSCI 11C
PSCI 192U.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Education Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 192V.name: Language and Literacy
PSCI 192V.description: Addresses the linguistic principles and processes that underlie oral and written language proficiency. Emphasis is on how to use phonology, morphology, orthography, semantics, syntax, and pragmatics to support literacy and oral language development for K-12 students.
PSCI 192V.restriction: Restriction: Language Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Education Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 192X.name: Introduction to Positive Psychology in Education
PSCI 192X.description: Positive psychology is a recent focus area within the field of psychology that explores what is positive, creative, and fulfilling in human behavior. It is the scientific study of well-being and flourishing.
PSCI 192X.restriction: Restriction: Education Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 193B.name: Juvenile Delinquency
PSCI 193B.description: Patterns of delinquent behavior, theories that explain behavior, current research aimed at enhancing exploratory power. Attempts to prevent and control delinquency are put in historical perspective. Development of the current juvenile justice system and evolution of modern juvenile law.
PSCI 193B.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. SocEcol-Urban & Regional Plan Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 193C.name: Social Control of Delinquency
PSCI 193C.description: Assumes familiarity with theories of delinquency, the juvenile justice system, and elements of juvenile law. Explores socio-historical origins and evolution of juvenile justice, current research and policy on delinquency prevention and treatment, and future directions of law, policy, and practice.
PSCI 193C.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 193E.name: Psychology and the Law
PSCI 193E.description: Psychological assumptions of the American legal system and mental health aspects of provision of criminal justice services. Civil commitment, insanity defense, competence to stand trial, jury selection, eyewitness identification. Use of police, courts, correctional institutions in prevention of behavior disorder.
PSCI 193E.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. SocEcol-Urban & Regional Plan Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 193F.name: Family Law
PSCI 193F.description: Examines legal issues surrounding marriage, cohabitation, divorce, child custody and support, adoption, and the rights of parents and children in the family context. The findings of social science research are used to illuminate the legal issues.
PSCI 193F.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 193G.name: Eyewitness Testimony
PSCI 193G.description: Faulty eyewitness testimony is a major cause of wrongful convictions. Covers the fast-growing topic of eyewitness testimony and memory for real-world events, both how psychologists study eyewitness capacity, and how the legal system has dealt with eyewitness issues.
PSCI 193G.restriction: Restriction: Seniors only. Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSCI 196.name: Research Seminar in Psychological Science
PSCI 196.description: Special topics research seminar. Content varies with interest of instructor. Capstone seminar for students who have conducted research with, or have a background in, the research topics of the PSCI faculty member offering this seminar in a given quarter.

PSCI C200.name: Evidence-Based Treatments
PSCI C200.description: Presents empirically-supported treatment approaches and professional strategies for the practice of them. Covers cognitive-behavior therapy, acceptance and commitment therapy, dialectical behavior therapy, mindfulness meditation, exposure and response prevention, parent-child interaction therapy and their application to various clinical disorders.

PSCI P200.name: Introduction to Legal and Forensic Psychology
PSCI P200.description: Familiarizes students with the interrelated fields of psychology, law, and forensic studies. Emphasizes clinically relevant legal topics (insanity defense
PSCI P200.restriction: Restriction: Master of Legal & Forensic Psy Degree students only.

PSCI C201.name: Clinical Assessment and Interviewing
PSCI C201.description: Prepares students to conduct clinical interviews, which are the building blocks for psychotherapy and clinical research. Develops basic skills of interviewing and covers how to conduct the Structured Clinical Interview for DSM-5 Disorders and how to make differential diagnoses.

PSCI P201.name: Research Methods in Psychology
PSCI P201.description: In-depth examination of the conceptualization of research problems and linkages between theory and the design of appropriate strategies for empirical research in psychological science. Topics include experimental and quasi-experimental designs, reliability and validity of measurement and non-experimental procedures.
PSCI P201.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Psychological Science Majors only. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors only.

PSCI C202.name: Cognitive and Neuropsychological Assessment
PSCI C202.description: Provides empirical background and introductory skills for students to begin supervised cognitive and neuropsychological assessment practice in a professional, ethical, competent, culturally sensitive manner. Administration, scoring, and interpreting standardized cognitive assessment measures and neuropsychological assessment measures. Neuropsychological disorders and anomalies.

PSCI P202.name: Data Analysis and Statistics
PSCI P202.description: Statistical techniques to facilitate inferences in psychological research, including fundamentals of statistical inference and methods for analyzing data.
PSCI P202.restriction: Restriction: Master of Legal & Forensic Psy Degree students only.

PSCI C203.name: Professional Issues and Ethics in Clinical Psychology
PSCI C203.description: Examines professional guidelines and ethical principles in clinical psychology research, assessment, and treatment, with an emphasis on the American Psychological Association Code of Ethics for Psychologists. Helps students develop awareness of ethical issues arising in clinical research and practice.

PSCI P203.name: Big Data Analytics for the Social Sciences I
PSCI P203.description: A practical lecture and lab course for learning how to engage with big data in various forms and use data science techniques (e.g., data reduction, NLP) to analyze and visualize data for research purposes.
PSCI P203.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Psychological Science Majors only. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors only.

PSCI C204.name: Practicum in Clinical Psychology
PSCI C204.description: Clinical work at on-campus or off-campus clinical practice sites, such as hospitals and clinics, supervised by a licensed clinical psychologist, in addition to the students’ faculty advisor.

PSCI P204.name: Adolescence
PSCI P204.description: Considers pubertal and cognitive changes and their social consequences

PSCI C205.name: History and Systems
PSCI C205.description: Surveys ideas of major figures in the history of psychology, from pre-Socratic Greek philosophers to psychologists active prior to the middle of the 20th century. Provides an appreciation of the forces (intellectual, cultural, scientific) that have shaped modern psychology.

PSCI P206.name: Big Data Analytics for the Social Sciences II
PSCI P206.description: A practical lecture and lab course for learning how to engage with big data in various forms and use data science techniques (e.g., data reduction, NLP) to analyze and visualize data for research purposes.
PSCI P206.prereqString: Prerequisite: SE 264A and SE 264B and PSCI P203
PSCI P206.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Psychological Science Majors only. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors only.

PSCI P208.name: Research Methods
PSCI P208.description: In-depth examination of issues relevant to designing and evaluating research in psychological science. Topics address casual inference, ethical issues surrounding the responsible conduct of research, experimental and quasi-experimental designs, reliability and validity of measurement, and non-experimental procedures.
PSCI P208.restriction: Restriction: Master of Legal & Forensic Psy Degree students only.

PSCI P209A.name: Applied Psychological Research
PSCI P209A.description: Focuses on scientific and professional issues in the field of psychology. Topics include communication skills

PSCI P210.name: The New Statistics and Open Science
PSCI P210.description: Introduces the fundamentals of research design and methodology from the perspective of the new statistics and open science. With this introduction, students should be better able to design and conduct their own research.
PSCI P210.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Psychological Science Majors only. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors only.

PSCI P213.name: Stigma, Discrimination, and Health
PSCI P213.description: Introduces concepts related to stigma and discrimination and presents an overview of selected theoretical and empirical topics in the psychology of stigma, discrimination, and health for investigating and explaining health inequities among marginalized populations across the life-span.
PSCI P213.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Psychological Science Majors only. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors only.

PSCI C214.name: Clinical Psychology Research Designs and Methods
PSCI C214.description: Reviews major issues in conducting scientific research and important methodological issues in psychological clinical science.

PSCI P214.name: Seminar in Social Psychology
PSCI P214.description: Presents an overview of selected theoretical and empirical topics in social psychology including social influence and conformity, altruism and aggression, persuasion and attitude change, self and social perception, and social cognition.

PSCI C215.name: Evidence-Based Psychological Treatments II
PSCI C215.description: Examines theory, research, and application in family, couple, and child therapy using culturally and developmentally sensitive principles. Students are exposed to theoretical frameworks guiding approaches to the treatment of the family system using readings, lectures, and activities.
PSCI C215.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Psychological Science Majors only.

PSCI P215.name: Psychology and Law
PSCI P215.description: An interdisciplinary approach to research in psychology, law, and/or criminology. Examines how psychology is applied to the civil and criminal justice systems, how case law shapes this application, and how legal decisions affect the direction of psychological research.
PSCI P215.restriction: Restriction: Master of Legal & Forensic Psy Degree students only.

PSCI C216.name: Adult Psychopathology
PSCI C216.description: Explores the antecedents, characteristics, course, outcomes, and options for the prevention or management of various forms of psychopathology and behavior disorder. Focuses on psychological and biobehavioral mechanisms that influence the development, expression, and amelioration of maladaption.
PSCI C216.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Psychological Science Majors only.

PSCI P216.name: Psychological Wellbeing and Health
PSCI P216.description: Explores how positive traits, states, and positive behaviors interact with physical health. Discussion focuses on critical assessment of the positive health field, as well as how wellness can be measured and maximized.
PSCI P216.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Psychological Science Majors only.

PSCI C217.name: Psychological Assessment
PSCI C217.description: Familiarizes students with psychological assessments in intelligence, clinical diagnosis, personality, and neuropsychological functioning. Exposure to administering, scoring, and interpreting assessments. Special focus on psychometrics (e.g., reliability and validity), test construction, and ethical responsibilities.

PSCI P217.name: Life-Span Development
PSCI P217.description: Introduces the major concepts of life-span development and discusses those with regard to some key topics of developmental psychology. For example, change and continuity, evolutionary and inherited nature, culture, society, and family-based nurture, and their dynamic interaction.

PSCI P218.name: Infancy
PSCI P218.description: Covers development from conception through the second year. Focus is on research and theory concerning infants' physical, social, cognitive, perceptual, emotional, and language development. Also covers transition to parenthood and family context of infant development.

PSCI P219.name: Forensic Neuropsychology
PSCI P219.description: Introduces key concepts in clinical neuropsychology as applied in legal/forensic settings. Instruction focuses on neuropsychological concepts underlying brain-behavior relationships and their assessment in forensic case examples
PSCI P219.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Legal and Forensic Psychology Majors only.

PSCI P220.name: Developmental Psychology: Theories and History
PSCI P220.description: Examines key concepts, theories, and the historical and philosophical roots of research in human life span development. Focuses on biological and environmental causation, universalism and cultural relativism, continuity and change.

PSCI P221.name: Critical Perspectives in Diversity Science
PSCI P221.description: Presents an overview of psychology as a science of diversity, theories and methodologies that challenge mainstream psychology’s epistemological foundations, assumptions, and practices. Some topics include conceptualizations of diversity, positionality in research, and methodologies that facilitate transformative justice for oppressed communities.

PSCI P222.name: Forensic Assessment
PSCI P222.description: Explores the various ways in which clinical psychology is relevant to the law, and how forensic psychologists can meaningfully contribute to the adjudicatory process. Examines legal, scientific, and ethical issues that arise when psychologists are involved in legal proceedings.
PSCI P222.restriction: Restriction: Master of Legal & Forensic Psy Degree students only.

PSCI P223.name: Cross-Cultural Developmental Psychology
PSCI P223.description: Examines human development in diverse cultures (e.g., Asian, American, and African). Cultural diversity within the U.S. and acculturation of various ethnic groups is also discussed. Topics include parenting, family relations, language, and cognition, schooling and academic achievement, and morality.

PSCI P224.name: Children and the Law
PSCI P224.description: Examines how psychology research and practice can inform several areas of law and social policy affecting children, adolescents, and families. Topics include education, mental health, reproductive rights, and delinquency.
PSCI P224.restriction: Restriction: Master of Legal & Forensic Psy Degree students only.

PSCI P226.name: Emotion in Psychology
PSCI P226.description: Covers original and recent theories of emotions and how they guide current research.  Specific topics include neuroantomical structure of emotion, life-span emotional development, and health and emotion.

PSCI P231.name: Professional Issues in Psychology
PSCI P231.description: Examines a variety of issues related to the professional socialization and development of graduate students in psychology. Topics include the publication process, sources of research funding, alternative employment options, competitiveness on the job market, and the academic career route.

PSCI P234.name: Childhood
PSCI P234.description: Provides graduate students with an overview of traditional and emerging theories, models, and research designed to understand children's development in the domains of cognitive, social, and emotional functioning.

PSCI P235.name: Social Health Psychology
PSCI P235.description: Enables students to critically evaluate research related to social health psychology. Offers a deeper understanding of the potential physiological mechanisms underpinning the impact of social psychological factors on health and well-being.
PSCI P235.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Psychological Science Majors only. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors only.

PSCI P238.name: Child Psychopathology
PSCI P238.description: Examination of etiology, classification, and developmental pathways of disorders, as well as risk and resilience factors, during the childhood/adolescent years. Discussion of genetic influences and contextual risk factors as well as internalizing and externalizing disorders.

PSCI P242.name: Legal Reasoning and Jurisprudence
PSCI P242.description: Overview of the law and legal process as well as the history and assumptions underlying modern legal reasoning. Issues related to procedure and evidence as well as key jurisprudential perspectives are discussed.
PSCI P242.restriction: Restriction: Master of Legal & Forensic Psy Degree students only.

PSCI P246.name: Affective Neuroscience
PSCI P246.description: Provides an overview of the emerging field of affective neuroscience. Emphasis is placed on mapping affective experience and behavior to brain function, including cross-level integration of anatomical, chemical, fMRI, and electrical data.

PSCI P247.name: EEG Methods
PSCI P247.description: Provides an in-depth training of the electroencephalogram (EEG) methodology with a specific focus on the event-related potential technique. Emphasis is on learning how to use this methodology and how to analyze data, with a focus on emotional stimuli.

PSCI P249.name: Advanced Social Psychology
PSCI P249.description: Conveys an appreciation of the flavors of contemporary social psychology, an understanding of empirical approaches to problems in this area, and a sense of the array of theoretical orientations in the field.

PSCI P250.name: Emotion, Reasoning, and Memory
PSCI P250.description: Examines research and theory on emotion from the perspective of cognitive psychology. Topics include the effects of emotions on attention, memory, and problem solving

PSCI P251.name: Clinical Interviewing and Treatment in a Forensic Setting
PSCI P251.description: Students receive an introduction to clinical interviewing, learn details of strategic, solution-focused therapy, and think critically about issues that come at the interaction of psychology and the law. Students are not "license-eligible" at end of this course.
PSCI P251.restriction: Restriction: Master of Legal & Forensic Psy Degree students only.

PSCI P252.name: Law and Behavior: Compliance and Enforcement
PSCI P252.description: Provides sophisticated insight into the different ways through which law shapes behavior. Addresses both the economic amoral rational choice theories, as well as ideas from social psychology, criminology, and sociology about the moral, social, and and unconscious dimensions of compliance.
PSCI P252.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Psychological Science Majors only. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors only.

PSCI P253.name: Master of Legal and Forensic Psychology Capstone
PSCI P253.description: Focuses on macro-level writing topics such as developing a meaningful research question, conducting a thorough review of relevant literature, and presenting a clear and convincing research-based argument.

PSCI P254.name: Mental Health and the Law
PSCI P254.description: Explores the history of criminalization of persons with mental illness. Topics include challenges and needs of persons with mental illness
PSCI P254.restriction: Restriction: Master of Legal & Forensic Psy Degree students only. Graduate students only.

PSCI P255.name: Violence, Anger, and Psychopathology
PSCI P255.description: Overviews the prevalence of violence as a criminal and public health problem. Topics include violence within families and intimate partner relationships, traumatic origins of violence, the development of a violence-prone personality, the association of anger and violence with psychopathology.
PSCI P255.restriction: Restriction: Master of Legal & Forensic Psy Degree students only. Graduate students only.

PSCI P256.name: Family and the Law
PSCI P256.description: Examines sociological and legal perspectives on the relationship between family life and law, with a focus on three distinct but sometimes interconnected domains: the child welfare system, the criminal justice system, and the immigration system.
PSCI P256.restriction: Restriction: Master of Legal & Forensic Psy Degree students only. Graduate students only.

PSCI P258.name: Health Psychology
PSCI P258.description: Interdisciplinary exploration of emerging fields of health psychology and behavioral medicine. Topics: role of stress in development/treatment of medical problems

PSCI P260.name: Technology and Health
PSCI P260.description: Explores the growing intersection of health and technology, including electronic Health (“eHealth”), mobile health (“mHealth”), and digital health and medicine. Specifically, it focuses on the implications and uses of technologies for behavioral and emotional health, and behavioral change.

PSCI P261.name: Intensive Longitudinal Data Analysis
PSCI P261.description: Fundamentals of Intensive Longitudinal Study designs, gain first-hand experience collecting ILD using web and/or mobile-based platforms, and learn.

PSCI P262.name: Interpersonal Processes and Health
PSCI P262.description: Examines traditions of research linking interpersonal processes to emotional or physical health. Topics include: role of social support in ameliorating stress, effects of social control on health-compromising behaviors, adverse effects of social relationships on health, causes of deficient social relationships.

PSCI P263.name: Eyewitness Testimony
PSCI P263.description: Examines the evidence that shows that faulty eyewitness memory is the major cause of wrongful convictions. Explores what the legal system thinks of eyewitness testimony and how the legal system has dealt with eyewitness issues.

PSCI P264.name: Intensive Writing Workshop
PSCI P264.description: Offers an intensive writing workshop for graduate students with instruction targeting academic writing, peer review, and publishing. Also covers techniques for translating research to a broader audience in the form of opinion, position, and policy papers.
PSCI P264.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Psychological Science Majors only. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors only.

PSCI P265.name: Memory and the Law
PSCI P265.description: Examines the controversial topic of repressed memory, or perception and memory of real-world events.

PSCI P266.name: Psychology and the Law
PSCI P266.description: Overview of how psychology is applied to the civil and criminal justice systems, how case law shapes this application, and how legal decisions affect the direction of psychological research. Interdisciplinary approach to research in psychology, law, and/or  criminology.

PSCI P268.name: Coping with Stressful Life Events
PSCI P268.description: Explores how individuals cope with serious life crises (e.g., illness, bereavement), life transitions, and daily stressors. Considers how such events impact on people's cognitions, emotions, and health, and the role of others in the coping process.

PSCI P271.name: Human Evolution and Behavior
PSCI P271.description: Covers theories and empirical research concerning the evolutionary origins of human behaviors and their variations. An interdisciplinary course emphasizing both evolutionary psychology (e.g., mating strategies, kinship, and parenting) and molecular evolution (i.e., evolution of genes for various behaviors).

PSCI P273.name: Biobehavioral Aspects of Health and Illness
PSCI P273.description: Examines the behavior-physiology interactions of some major bodily systems: the nervous, cardiovascular, gastrointestinal, and endocrine systems. Analysis of normal and abnormal states of these systems as they relate to tissue injury, disease, and rehabilitation.

PSCI P275.name: Special Topics in Psychological Science
PSCI P275.description: Topics covered vary with interests of instructor.

PSCI P276.name: Meta Analysis
PSCI P276.description: The process of synthesizing results from a number of studies that address a common research question is often referred to as meta-analysis. Explores the meta-analysis process from the coding of retrieved studies to the final research synthesis.

PSCI P280A.name: Interdisciplinary Salivary Bioscience
PSCI P280A.description: Theory and research on the integration of salivary analytes into developmental, social, behavioral, and health sciences. Topics include oral fluid as biological specimens

PSCI P280B.name: Interdisciplinary Salivary Bioscience Lab
PSCI P280B.description: Laboratory sequel to the P280A seminar. Provides laboratory-based hands-on experience integrating salivary analytes into developmental, social, behavioral, and health sciences that also includes supervised training on sample processing.

PSCI P281.name: Race and the Law
PSCI P281.description: Explores how race and other markers of social identity shape outcomes within the criminal justice system. Students examine how race, ethnicity, and national origin intersect with rules governing the policing, trials, and punishment.
PSCI P281.restriction: Restriction: Master of Legal & Forensic Psy Degree students only.

PSCI P282.name: Salivary Bioscience Data Analysis
PSCI P282.description: A salivary bioscience statistical research working group. Students conduct guided data analyses with salivary biomarker data. Special topics related to salivary bioscience analytic strategies and the interpretation and dissemination of research findings are discussed.

PSCI P283H.name: Psychoneuroimmunology
PSCI P283H.description: Introduces students to the field of psychoneuroimmunology and helps them develop the conceptual and methodological skills necessary for designing and interpreting research on the bidirectional relationship between the immune system and psychological processes.

PSCI P284.name: Health and Emotion
PSCI P284.description: Overview of research focused on understanding how emotional processes influence physical health. Provides students with a deeper understanding of how emotions play into the health of others as well.

PSCI P285.name: Anger: A Turbulent Emotion
PSCI P285.description: Provides an enriched perspective on anger beginning with its understanding in classical antiquity. Topics include developmental processes and trauma, anger physiology and neuroscience, anger-related physical health impairments, and the involvement of anger in psychopathology and violence.

PSCI P286.name: Motivation
PSCI P286.description: Introduces major concepts of motivational psychology, theory, and history. Application of motivational concepts to phenomena from social psychology and affective science. Development of own research proposal in a motivational framework and/or conceptualizing or expanding an ongoing or planned research project.

PSCI P288.name: Human Neuropsychology
PSCI P288.description: Focuses on clinical, neuroanatomical, and neuropathological studies that have contributed to our understanding of brain-behavior relationships in the context of normal brain function and disease-associated neuropsychiatric syndromes.

PSCI P289.name: The Teaching of Psychology
PSCI P289.description: Provides students with the theory and skills needed to teach undergraduate psychology courses. Covers research on theories and methods of teaching, curriculum design, and evaluation. Students also gain practical experience preparing and presenting material.
PSCI P289.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Psychological Science Majors only. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors only.

PSCI P290.name: Research in Developmental Psychology
PSCI P290.description: Introduces graduate students to research conducted by individual faculty members in the area of developmental psychology. This is accomplished by having students involve themselves in the conceptualization, strategy, and implementation of the faculty member's research.

PSCI P291.name: Research in Health Psychology
PSCI P291.description: Introduces graduate students to research conducted by individual faculty members in the area of health psychology. This is accomplished by having students involve themselves in the conceptualization, strategy, and implementation of the faculty member's research.

PSCI P292.name: Research in Psychopathology and Behavior Disorder
PSCI P292.description: Introduces graduate students to research conducted by individual faculty members in the area of psychopathology and behavior disorder.
