This is accomplished by having students involve themselves in the conceptualization, strategy, and implementation of the faculty member's research.

PSCI P293.name: Research in Social and Personality Psychology
PSCI P293.description: Introduces graduate students to research conducted by individual faculty members in the area of social and personality psychology. This is accomplished by having students involve themselves in the conceptualization, strategy, and implementation of the faculty member's research.

PSCI P294A.name: Research Directions in Psychological Science I
PSCI P294A.description: Introduces students to the current research of faculty, graduate students, and visitors to the Department of Psychological Science. Includes examination of contemporary research issues and controversies, as well as issues related to students' development as professionals.

PSCI P294B.name: Research Directions in Psychological Science II
PSCI P294B.description: Introduces students to the current research of faculty, graduate students, and visitors to the Department of Psychological Science. Includes examination of contemporary research issues and controversies, as well as issues related to students' development as professionals.

PSCI P294C.name: Research Directions in Psychological Science III
PSCI P294C.description: Introduces students to the current research of faculty, graduate students, and visitors to the Department of Psychological Science. Includes examination of contemporary research issues and controversies, as well as issues related to students' development as professionals.

PSCI P295.name: Research in Psychology and Law
PSCI P295.description: Introduces graduate students to research conducted by individual faculty members in the area of psychology and law. This is accomplished by having students involve themselves in the conceptualization, strategy, and implementation of the faculty member's research.

PSCI P296.name: Doctoral Dissertation Research and Writing
PSCI P296.description: Dissertation research with Psychological Science faculty.

PSCI P298.name: Directed Studies in Psychological Science
PSCI P298.description: Directed study with Psychological Science faculty.

PSCI P299.name: Independent Studies in Psychological Science
PSCI P299.description: Independent research with Psychological Science faculty.

PSYCH 7A.name: Introduction to Psychology
PSYCH 7A.description: Introduction to field of psychology, addressing the application of scientific methods to the study of human development, learning, memory, problem solving, perception, biological mechanisms, emotions and motivation, personality, psychopathology, and effects of diverse social and cultural contexts on human behavior.
PSYCH 7A.restriction: Restriction: Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Public Health Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Public Health Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Urban Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment. PSCI 9 and PSYCH 7A may not be taken for credit if taken concurrently with or after PSCI 11A, PSCI 11B, PSCI 11C, PSYCH 9A, PSYCH 9B, or PSYCH 9C.

PSYCH 9A.name: Psychology Fundamentals
PSYCH 9A.description: Designed to provide freshman with an in-depth survey of general psychology. Topics include biological bases of behavior, sensation, perception, cognition, development, personality, psychopathology, and social psychology.
PSYCH 9A.restriction: Restriction: Lower-division students only. Cognitive Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. PSCI 9 and PSYCH 7A may not be taken for credit if taken after PSCI 11A, PSCI 11B, PSCI 11C, PSYCH 9A, PSYCH 9B, or PSYCH 9C.

PSYCH 9B.name: Psychology Fundamentals
PSYCH 9B.description: Designed to provide freshmen with an in-depth survey of general psychology. Topics include biological bases of behavior, sensation, perception, cognition, development, personality, psychopathology, and social psychology.
PSYCH 9B.restriction: Restriction: Lower-division students only. Cognitive Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Public Health Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Public Health Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Urban Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSYCH 9C.name: Psychology Fundamentals
PSYCH 9C.description: Designed to provide freshman with an in-depth survey of general psychology. Topics include biological bases of behavior, sensation, perception, cognition, development, personality, psychopathology, and social psychology.
PSYCH 9C.restriction: Restriction: Lower-division students only. Cognitive Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Public Health Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Public Health Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Urban Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSYCH 10A.name: Probability and Statistics in Psychology I
PSYCH 10A.description: An introduction to probability and statistics. Emphasis on thorough understanding of the probabilistic basis of statistical inference. Examples drawn primarily from psychology.
PSYCH 10A.restriction: Restriction: Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSYCH 10B.name: Probability and Statistics in Psychology II
PSYCH 10B.description: An introduction to probability and statistics. Emphasis on thorough understanding of the probabilistic basis of statistical inference. Examples drawn primarily from psychology.
PSYCH 10B.restriction: Restriction: Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSYCH 10C.name: Probability and Statistics in Psychology III
PSYCH 10C.description: An introduction to probability and statistics. Emphasis on thorough understanding of the probabilistic basis of statistical inference. Examples drawn primarily from psychology.
PSYCH 10C.restriction: Restriction: Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSYCH 14M.name: MATLAB Programming
PSYCH 14M.description: MATLAB is a mathematical software package for solving quantitative problems often encountered in experimental psychology. Topics include rudiments of programming, statistical analysis of data, matrix algebra, signal processing, graphic visualization, and simulated models of cognitive and perceptual processes.
PSYCH 14M.restriction: Restriction: Cognitive Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSYCH 14P.name: Scientific Python for Research
PSYCH 14P.description: Introduces Python for data analysis and modeling encountered in cognitive science and neuroscience. Topics include data structures, execution control, graphic visualization, and interaction with sound and display interfaces. Application in statistical analysis, model simulation, and stimulus presentation and experimental control.
PSYCH 14P.restriction: Restriction: Cognitive Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSYCH 21A.name: Adolescent Psychology
PSYCH 21A.description: Focuses on psychosocial dynamics of today's adolescents in America emphasizing the quest for identity, independence, values, and sexual orientation. The influence of society, family, school, and peers is analyzed. Strategies for helping troubled adolescents are discussed.

PSYCH 46A.name: Introduction to Human Memory
PSYCH 46A.description: Covers the core concepts of modern research and theorizing about human memory, including structural subdivisions (e.g., perceptual memory, short-term memory, long-term memory), different measures of memory (e.g., recall, reorganization), and some practical applications of memory research (e.g., mnemonics).

PSYCH 56L.name: Acquisition of Language
PSYCH 56L.description: What children say, what they mean, and what they understand. Theories about the learning of language by one-, two-, and three-year-olds. Comparison of kinds of data on which these theories are based.

PSYCH 78A.name: Self-Identity and Society
PSYCH 78A.description: Studies sociological contributions to theory and research in social psychology, with focus on the social influences on personality, attitudes, beliefs, and behavior

PSYCH 89.name: Special Topics in Lower-Division Psychology
PSYCH 89.description: Studies in selected areas of psychology at the lower-division level. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

PSYCH H101A.name: Honors Seminar in Psychology and Cognitive Sciences I
PSYCH H101A.description: Focuses on the research activities and honors thesis research projects of each student and the research of various Cognitive Sciences faculty. Students discuss their research interests in the early and later stages of their projects. Research projects and write-ups required.
PSYCH H101A.restriction: Restriction: Cognitive Sciences Honors students only. Psychology Honors students only.

PSYCH H101B.name: Honors Seminar in Psychology and Cognitive Sciences II
PSYCH H101B.description: Focuses on the research activities and honors thesis research projects of each student and the research of various Cognitive Sciences faculty. Students discuss their research interests in the early and later stages of their projects. Research projects and write-ups required.
PSYCH H101B.restriction: Restriction: Cognitive Sciences Honors students only. Psychology Honors students only.

PSYCH H101C.name: Honors Seminar in Psychology and Cognitive Sciences III
PSYCH H101C.description: Focuses on the research activities and honors thesis research projects of each student and the research of various Cognitive Sciences faculty. Students discuss their research interests in the early and later stages of their projects. Research projects and write-ups required.
PSYCH H101C.restriction: Restriction: Cognitive Sciences Honors students only. Psychology Honors students only.

PSYCH 111BW.name: Honors Advanced Experimental Psychology
PSYCH 111BW.description: Design and analysis of multivalent, factorial, and correlational studies. Students prepare proposals for independent research.
PSYCH 111BW.prereqString:
Corequisite: PSYCH H111B
Prerequisite: PSYCH H111A and (PSYC H11A or PSYCH 112A). Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
PSYCH 111BW.restriction: Restriction: Psychology Majors only. Social Science Honors students only.

PSYCH H111A.name: Honors Experimental Psychology
PSYCH H111A.description: Emphasis on design of experiments and analysis of results. Experiments are conducted in laboratory sections.
PSYCH H111A.prereqString: Prerequisite: ((PSYCH 9A and PSYCH 9B and PSYCH 9C) or (PSY BEH 11A and PSY BEH 11B and PSY BEH 11C)) and ((PSYCH 10A and 10B and 10C) or (MATH 2A and MATH 2B and (MATH 7 or STATS 7))).
PSYCH H111A.restriction: Restriction: Psychology and Cognitive Sciences Honors Program students only.

PSYCH H111B.name: Honors Advanced Experimental Psychology Laboratory
PSYCH H111B.description: Design and analysis of multivalent, factorial, and correlational studies. Students prepare proposals for independent research.

PSYCH H111C.name: Honors Research in Experimental Psychology
PSYCH H111C.description: Each student conducts a research project in experimental psychology. The projects are discussed in a seminar format. Written reports on each project are submitted at the end of the quarter.
PSYCH H111C.restriction: Restriction: Psychology Majors only. Social Science Honors students only.

PSYCH 112A.name: Experimental Psychology
PSYCH 112A.description: Emphasis on design of experiments and analysis of results. Experiments are conducted in laboratory sections.
PSYCH 112A.prereqString:
Corequisite: PSYCH 112LA
Prerequisite: ((PSYCH 9A and PSYCH 9B and PSYCH 9C) or (PSY BEH 11A and PSY BEH 11B and PSY BEH 11C)) and ((PSYCH 10A and PSYCH 10B and PSYCH 10C) or (MATH 2A and MATH 2B and (MATH 7 or STATS 7)) )
PSYCH 112A.restriction: Restriction: Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSYCH 112BW.name: Advanced Experimental Psychology
PSYCH 112BW.description: Design and analysis of multivalent, factorial, and correlational studies. Students prepare proposals for independent research.
PSYCH 112BW.prereqString: Prerequisite: PSYCH 112A and PSYCH 112LA. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
PSYCH 112BW.restriction: Restriction: Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSYCH 112C.name: Research in Experimental Psychology
PSYCH 112C.description: Each student conducts a research project in experimental psychology. The projects are discussed in a seminar format. Written reports on each project are submitted at the end of the quarter.
PSYCH 112C.prereqString:
Corequisite: PSYCH 112LC
Prerequisite: PSYCH 112B and PSYCH 112LB
PSYCH 112C.restriction: Restriction: Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSYCH 112LA.name: Experimental Psychology Laboratory
PSYCH 112LA.description: Required laboratory section and co-requisite for Psych 112A.
PSYCH 112LA.restriction: Restriction: Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSYCH 112LB.name: Advanced Experimental Psychology Laboratory
PSYCH 112LB.description: Required laboratory section for PSYCH 112B and PSYCH 112BW.
PSYCH 112LB.restriction: Restriction: Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSYCH 112LC.name: Research in Experimental Psychology
PSYCH 112LC.description: Required laboratory section and co-requisite for PSYCH 112C.

PSYCH 112LM.name: Research Methods in Psychology Laboratory
PSYCH 112LM.description: Required laboratory section and co-requisite for PSYCH 112M.
PSYCH 112LM.restriction: Restriction: Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSYCH 112LP.name: Research in Perception and Psychophysics Laboratory
PSYCH 112LP.description: Required laboratory section and co-requisite for COGS 112P.
PSYCH 112LP.restriction: Restriction: Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSYCH 112LR.name: Cognitive Robotics Laboratory
PSYCH 112LR.description: Required laboratory section and corequisite for PSYCH 112R.
PSYCH 112LR.restriction: Restriction: Cognitive Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSYCH 112M.name: Research Methods in Psychology
PSYCH 112M.description: Research methods in psychology for majors who wish to fulfill this requirement separately from upper-division writing. Covers both experimental and descriptive research methods, analysis of results, and reading the psychological literature. Research experience is provided in laboratory sections.
PSYCH 112M.prereqString:
Corequisite: PSYCH 112LM
Prerequisite: (PSYCH 9A and PSYCH 9B and PSYCH 9C) or (PSY BEH 11A and PSY BEH 11B and PSY BEH 11C) and (PSYCH 10C or SOC SCI 10C or ANTHRO 10C or POL SCI 10C or SOCIOL 10C) or (MATH 2B and STATS 7)
PSYCH 112M.restriction: Restriction: Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSYCH 112P.name: Research in Perception and Psychophysics
PSYCH 112P.description: Introduction to design and practice of experiments: students perform auditory, visual, tactile, or other experiments. Emphasis on methodology, finding and reading previous research, generating research ideas, statistical analysis.
PSYCH 112P.prereqString:
Corequisite: COGS 112LP
Prerequisite: (PSYCH 9A and PSYCH 9B and PSYCH 9C) or (PSCI 11A and PSCI 11B and PSCI 11C) and (PSYCH 10C or SOC SCI 10C or ANTHRO 10C or POL SCI 10C or SOCIOL 10C) or (MATH 2B and STATS 7)
PSYCH 112P.restriction: Restriction: Cognitive Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSYCH 112R.name: Cognitive Robotics
PSYCH 112R.description: Introduces concepts on experimental design, embodiment, robot construction, and computer programming. Concepts of embodied intelligence and case studies of cognitive robotics are covered in lecture. Simple robots are constructed and programmed to carry out different behavioral experiments in lab.
PSYCH 112R.prereqString:
Corequisite: PSYCH 112LR
Prerequisite: (PSYCH 9A and PSYCH 9B and PSYCH 9C) or (PSCI 11A and PSCI 11B and PSCI 11C) and (PSYCH 10C or SOC SCI 10C or ANTHRO 10C or POL SCI 10C or SOCIOL 10C) or (MATH 2B and STATS 7)
PSYCH 112R.restriction: Restriction: Cognitive Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSYCH 119.name: Special Topics in Research Methodologies
PSYCH 119.description: Studies in selected areas of research methodologies. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
PSYCH 119.restriction: Restriction: Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSYCH 120A.name: Abnormal Psychology
PSYCH 120A.description: Introduction to psychopathology and behavioral deviations, and the concepts of theories regarding these conditions.
PSYCH 120A.prereqString: Prerequisite: PSYCH 7A or PSCI 9 or PSYCH 9C or PSCI 11C
PSYCH 120A.restriction: Restriction: Cognitive Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSYCH 120D.name: Developmental Psychology
PSYCH 120D.description: A general introduction to the study of the physical, intellectual, social, and emotional development of the child from birth to adulthood.
PSYCH 120D.prereqString: Prerequisite: PSYCH 7A or PSCI 9 or PSYCH 9A or PSCI 11A
PSYCH 120D.restriction: Restriction: Cognitive Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Nursing Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSYCH 120H.name: History of Psychology
PSYCH 120H.description: A history of the development of various schools and systems of psychological thought.
PSYCH 120H.prereqString: Prerequisite: (PSYCH 7A or PSCI 9) or (PSYCH 9A or PSCI 11A) and (PSYCH 9B or PSCI 11B) and (PSYCH 9C or PSCI 11C)
PSYCH 120H.restriction: Restriction: Cognitive Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSYCH 120P.name: Personality Theories
PSYCH 120P.description: A survey of the evolution of personality theory during this century. An overview of major perspectives in the field, with special attention to Freud, Jung, and Adler.
PSYCH 120P.prereqString: Prerequisite: PSYCH 7A or PSCI 9 or PSYCH 9C or PSCI 11C
PSYCH 120P.restriction: Restriction: Cognitive Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSYCH 121M.name: Theories of Motivation
PSYCH 121M.description: Factors affecting the behavioral performance of organisms. A survey of theoretical and empirical approaches to the physiological, psychological, and social factors which generate behavior.
PSYCH 121M.prereqString: Prerequisite: (PSYCH 7A or PSCI 9) or (PSYCH 9A or PSCI 11A) and (PSYCH 9B or PSCI 11B) and (PSYCH 9C or PSCI 11C)
PSYCH 121M.restriction: Restriction: Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSYCH 121S.name: Psychology of Sleep and Consciousness
PSYCH 121S.description: Covers the physiology, neurochemistry, and neuroanatomy associated with sleep, contemporary sleep theory, REM and NREM, phenomenology, sleep disorders, examination of differences between conscious and unconscious cognitive function, the history of sleep and dream theories from ancient time to present day.
PSYCH 121S.restriction: Restriction: Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSYCH 122C.name: Clinical Psychology
PSYCH 122C.description: Provides overview of the clinical psychology field including theories and techniques used in counseling and testing.
PSYCH 122C.restriction: Restriction: Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSYCH 122I.name: Organizational/Industrial Psychology
PSYCH 122I.description: Introduction to applied psychology in organizations, including personnel testing, selection, training and evaluation, job and classification analysis, job satisfaction and motivation, organizational development, leadership, market research, and consumer psychology. Potential ethical problems are discussed.
PSYCH 122I.prereqString: Prerequisite: (PSYCH 7A or PSY BEH 9) or (PSYCH 9A or PSY BEH 11A) or (PSYCH 9B or PSY BEH 11B) or (PSYCH 9C or PSY BEH 11C)
PSYCH 122I.restriction: Restriction: Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSYCH 122P.name: Clinical Psychophysiology
PSYCH 122P.description: Psychophysiology investigates the relationships between physiological processes and psychological phenomena. Technologies examined include reaction times, heart rate variability, EEGs, ERPs, magnetoencephalography, and eye tracking. Applications include diagnosis, the longitudinal assessment, and the identification of individuals at risk of disease onset.
PSYCH 122P.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI N110 or BIO SCI N115A or PSYCH 9A or PSCI 11A

PSYCH 123P.name: Topics in Philosophy of Psychology
PSYCH 123P.description: Selected topics in the philosophy of psychology, e.g., the nature of psychological explanation, reductionism, issues in cognitive, behavioral, and neuroscience.
PSYCH 123P.restriction: Restriction: Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Philosophy Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSYCH 124S.name: Sports Psychology
PSYCH 124S.description: Discusses the field of sports psychology with an emphasis on clinical practice including motivation, goal setting, performance skills, and mental skills. Discusses and utilizes a wide range of techniques designed to enhance performance and manage problems among athletes.
PSYCH 124S.prereqString: Prerequisite: (PSYCH 7A or PSY BEH 9) or (PSYCH 9C or PSY BEH 11C)
PSYCH 124S.restriction: Restriction: Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSYCH 124V.name: Psychology of Violence
PSYCH 124V.description: Discusses the psychology of violence and aggression with an emphasis on understanding the psychological, social, and physiological roots of violent and aggressive behavior. Psychological treatment techniques and strategies for prevention of aggressive and violent behavior are also discussed.
PSYCH 124V.prereqString: Prerequisite: (PSYCH 7A or PSY BEH 9) or (PSYCH 9C or PSY BEH 11C)
PSYCH 124V.restriction: Restriction: Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSYCH 129.name: Special Topics in General Psychology
PSYCH 129.description: Studies in selected areas of general psychology. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
PSYCH 129.restriction: Restriction: Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSYCH 130A.name: Perception and Sensory Processes
PSYCH 130A.description: A general introduction to the scientific study of sensory processes and perceptual phonomena, with special emphasis in the visual systems.
PSYCH 130A.prereqString: Prerequisite: (PSYCH 7A or PSY BEH 9) or (PSYCH 9A or PSY BEH 11A)
PSYCH 130A.restriction: Restriction: Cognitive Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSYCH 131A.name: Vision
PSYCH 131A.description: Visual perception and the anatomy and physiology of the visual system. Topics include the retina and the visual pathway
PSYCH 131A.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Cognitive Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. School of Biological Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment.

PSYCH 131B.name: Hearing
PSYCH 131B.description: Auditory perception, the anatomy and physiology of the auditory system, and the physics of sound. Topics include neural transduction of sound, sensitivity, sound localization, complex sound perception, and hearing loss.
PSYCH 131B.prereqString: Prerequisite: (PSYCH 9A or PSY BEH 11A) and (PSYCH 9B or PSY BEH 11B)
PSYCH 131B.restriction: Restriction: Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Cognitive Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSYCH 135M.name: The Mind/Body Problem
PSYCH 135M.description: What is consciousness and what is matter and how are the two related? How can brains have minds? This multidisciplinary course draws on information from the fields of computer vision, artificial intelligence, cognition, neurophysiology, philosophy, and psychophysics.
PSYCH 135M.restriction: Restriction: Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSYCH 139.name: Special Topics in Perception and Sensory Processes
PSYCH 139.description: Studies in selected areas of perception and sensory processes. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
PSYCH 139.restriction: Restriction: Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSYCH 140C.name: Cognitive Science
PSYCH 140C.description: Introduction to the investigations of the structure and function of the mind, from viewpoints of computation, neuroscience, philosophy, and cognitive psychology. Topics include perception, attention, knowledge representations, learning and memory, action, reasoning, and language.
PSYCH 140C.prereqString: Prerequisite: (PSYCH 7A or PSY BEH 9) and (PSYCH 9A or PSY BEH 11A) and (PSYCH 9B or PSY BEH 11B)
PSYCH 140C.restriction: Restriction: Cognitive Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSYCH 140J.name: Judgment and Decision Making
PSYCH 140J.description: The psychology of human decision making. Theories, models, experiments, and data that inform how people make choices, judgments, and other decisions. Topics include optimality and bias, mental simulation, learning and feedback, expertise, emotional effects, and group decision making.
PSYCH 140J.restriction: Restriction: Cognitive Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSYCH 140L.name: Principles of Learning Theory
PSYCH 140L.description: Investigation of the learning and memory processes of human and animals.  Basic experimental approaches to learning and memory, empirical results, and theoretical interpretations of the evidence are discussed.
PSYCH 140L.prereqString: Prerequisite: (PSYCH 7A or PSY BEH 9) or (PSYCH 9A or PSY BEH 11A)
PSYCH 140L.restriction: Restriction: Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Cognitive Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSYCH 140M.name: Human Memory
PSYCH 140M.description: Developments in the area of memory
PSYCH 140M.prereqString: Prerequisite: (PSYCH 7A or PSY BEH 9) or (PSYCH 9B or PSY BEH 11B)
PSYCH 140M.restriction: Restriction: Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Cognitive Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSYCH 143P.name: Human Problem Solving
PSYCH 143P.description: Modern developments in the psychology of human problem solving. Topics include concept identification, arithmetic, sets, logic puzzles, story problems, group problem solving, and theorem proving.
PSYCH 143P.prereqString: Prerequisite: (PSYCH 7A or PSY BEH 9) or (PSYCH 9B or PSY BEH 11B)
PSYCH 143P.restriction: Restriction: Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Cognitive Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSYCH 146MW.name: Writing about Memory
PSYCH 146MW.description: Covers a broad range of texts, literary, philosophical, and scientific, each probing the nature of memory and its meaning in human life. Readings are drawn from across many disciplines and many perspectives.
PSYCH 146MW.prereqString: Prerequisite: PSYCH 7A or PSYCH 9B or PSY BEH 9 or PSY BEH 11B. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
PSYCH 146MW.restriction: Restriction: Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSYCH 149.name: Special Topics in Cognition and Learning
PSYCH 149.description: Studies in selected areas of cognition and learning. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
PSYCH 149.restriction: Restriction: Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSYCH 150.name: Psychology of Language
PSYCH 150.description: Examines language using the tools of experimental psychology. From sounds to words to spoken and written sentences, explores how language is used in real time, and how its use reveals how it is represented in the mind.
PSYCH 150.prereqString: Prerequisite: PSYCH 7A or PSCI 9 or PSYCH 9B or PSCI 11B or LSCI 3
PSYCH 150.restriction: Restriction: Cognitive Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Language Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSYCH 156A.name: Acquisition of Language II
PSYCH 156A.description: Focuses on native language learning, exploring the way in which infants and very young children unconsciously uncover the rich systematic knowledge of their native language. Examines both experimental and computational studies that quantitatively investigate the "how" of language acquisition.
PSYCH 156A.restriction: Restriction: Cognitive Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSYCH 157M.name: Computational Methods for Language Research
PSYCH 157M.description: Focuses on computational methods useful for language research. Students become familiar with software and programming languages used for extracting information from electronic datasets and for creating basic simulations of linguistic cognition. No prior programming experience assumed.
PSYCH 157M.prereqString: Prerequisite: PSYCH 150 or LSCI 155 or PSYCH 156A or LSCI 151

PSYCH 159.name: Special Topics in Language
PSYCH 159.description: Studies in selected areas of language sciences. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
PSYCH 159.restriction: Restriction: Cognitive Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSYCH 160A.name: Introduction to Cognitive Neuroscience
PSYCH 160A.description: Introduction to the neural basis of human perceptual, motor, and cognitive abilities. Topics include sensory perception, motor control, memory, language, attention, emotion, frontal lobe function, functional brain imaging, and neuropsychological disorders.
PSYCH 160A.prereqString: Prerequisite: (PSYCH 7A or PSY BEH 9) and (PSYCH 9A or PSY BEH 11A) and (PSYCH 9B or PSY BEH 11B)
PSYCH 160A.restriction: Restriction: Cognitive Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSYCH 160D.name: Brain Disorders and Behavior
PSYCH 160D.description: Examines the localization of human brain functions and the effects of neurological disorders on psychological functions such as perception, motor control, language, memory, and decision-making.
PSYCH 160D.prereqString: Prerequisite: (PSYCH 7A or PSY BEH 9) ( or (PSYCH 9A or PSY BEH 11A) and (PSYCH 9B or PSY BEH 11B)) or BIO SCI 35 or BIO SCI N110 or BIO SCI N115A
PSYCH 160D.restriction: Restriction: Cognitive Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Biological Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSYCH 160H.name: History of Cognitive Neuroscience
PSYCH 160H.description: Studies of the human mind from ancient cultures to the innovation of modern methods of brain imaging. Logic of valid and invalid brain hypothesis are examined. Recurring theme is the competition between holistic and localized views of brain function.
PSYCH 160H.prereqString: Prerequisite: PSYCH 9A or PSY BEH 11A or PSYCH 7A or PSY BEH 9
PSYCH 160H.restriction: Restriction: Cognitive Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSYCH 161.name: Language and the Brain
PSYCH 161.description: Research analysis on biological bases of human linguistic capacity. Development, focusing on hemispheric specialization, plasticity
PSYCH 161.prereqString: Prerequisite: (PSYCH 7A or PSY BEH 9 or PSYCH 9A or PSY BEH 11A) and (PSYCH 9B or PSY BEH 11B or BIO SCI 35 or BIO SCI N110 or BIO SCI N115A)
PSYCH 161.restriction: Restriction: Cognitive Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Biological Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSYCH 161H.name: Hearing and the Brain
PSYCH 161H.description: An overview of brain mechanisms of hearing, including perception of simple sounds, speech, and music. Begins with sound itself, and looks at processing by the ear, auditory pathways, auditory cortex, and beyond. Also auditory development, learning, and clinical issues.
PSYCH 161H.prereqString: Prerequisite: PSYCH 160A or BIO SCI 93 or BIO SCI H93
PSYCH 161H.restriction: Restriction: Cognitive Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Biological Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSYCH 162N.name: Human  Neuropsychology
PSYCH 162N.description: A survey of human brain disorders using a clinical case study approach to illustrate fundamental issues in studying brain and behavior. Topics include sensory deficits, attentional neglect, amnesia, cortical organization, clinical psychopathology, and more.
PSYCH 162N.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI N110 or BIO SCI N115A or PSYCH 9A or PSCI 11A
PSYCH 162N.restriction: Restriction: School of Biological Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. Cognitive Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSYCH 169.name: Special Topics in Cognitive Neuroscience
PSYCH 169.description: Studies in selected areas of cognitive neuroscience. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
PSYCH 169.restriction: Restriction: Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSYCH 173A.name: Psychological Anthropology
PSYCH 173A.description: Cultural differences and similarities in personality and behavior.  Child-rearing practices and consequent adult personality characteristics, biocultural aspects of child development and attachment, culture and behavior evolutionary models, politically linked personality, cognitive anthropology, psychology of narrative forms, comparative national character studies.
PSYCH 173A.prereqString: Prerequisite: ANTHRO 2A or PSYCH 7A or (PSYCH 9A and PSYCH 9B and PSYCH 9C) or (PSY BEH 11A and PSY BEH 11B and PSY BEH 11C)
PSYCH 173A.restriction: Restriction: Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSYCH 174E.name: African American Psychology
PSYCH 174E.description: Historical overview of the development of black psychology and the African American frame of reference. Topics include personality development, psychological assessment, issues in education, black mental health, and the role of the African American psychologist in the community.

PSYCH 174H.name: Chicano/Latino Families
PSYCH 174H.description: Introduction to the research, literature, and issues surrounding the topic of Chicano/Latino families including cultural history, contemporary issues, organization of family, traditions, lifestyles, values, beliefs, generational differences, gender issues, ethnic identity, evolution of demographic patterns, current economic and political standings.

PSYCH 176A.name: Political Psychology
PSYCH 176A.description: Examination of how psychological theory and research may be used to better understand political thought and behavior. Drawing on theories of learning, cognition, and personality, discusses such topics as the formation of political attitudes, and the process of political decision-making.
PSYCH 176A.restriction: Restriction: Majors only. POL SCI 128C may not be taken for credit if taken after POL SCI 137C.

PSYCH 177D.name: Deviance
PSYCH 177D.description: Perspectives on deviance and criminality in behavior, institution, community, and myth. The suitability of contemporary theories of deviant behavior.
PSYCH 177D.restriction: Restriction: Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Sociology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSYCH 177F.name: Forensic Psychology: Advanced Seminar
PSYCH 177F.description: Focuses on the psychology of criminal offending, particularly violent behavior. Examines violence, sexual offending, and mental disorder related to crime with regard to clinical assessment and treatment
PSYCH 177F.prereqString: Prerequisite: (PSCI 9 or PSCI 11C or PSYCH 7A or PSYCH 9C) and PSCI 102C and (PSCI 178S or CRM/LAW C149)
PSYCH 177F.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSYCH 178N.name: Social Psychology of Networks
PSYCH 178N.description: Review of network methods used in small group and organizational research. Discussion of social psychological literature relevant to the network of study of cognitive social structure, exchange/communication, identity negotiation, and social control. Case study of network datasets exemplifies research issues.
PSYCH 178N.restriction: Restriction: Sociology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSYCH 179.name: Special Topics in Interdisciplinary Studies
PSYCH 179.description: Studies in selected areas of interdisciplinary studies. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
PSYCH 179.restriction: Restriction: Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PSYCH 198.name: Directed Group Study
PSYCH 198.description: Directed study with Cognitive Sciences faculty.

PSYCH 199.name: Independent Study
PSYCH 199.description: Independent research with Cognitive Sciences faculty.

PSYCH 231P.name: Topics in Philosophy of Psychology
PSYCH 231P.description: Selected topics in the philosophy of psychology, e.g., the nature of psychological explanation, reductionism, issues in cognitive, behavioral, and neuroscience.

PSYCH 245M.name: Computational Models of Language Learning
PSYCH 245M.description: Focuses on computational models of native language learning, exploring how probabilistic learning and inference fare on difficult case studies within language acquisition. In all cases, grounds the learning models in available empirical data and considers their psychological plausibility.
PSYCH 245M.prereqString: Prerequisite: LSCI 251. LSCI 251 with a grade of B- or better

PUBHLTH 1.name: Principles of Public Health
PUBHLTH 1.description: Introduces the major concepts and principles of public health and the determinants of health status in communities. Emphasizes the ecological model that focuses on the linkages and relationships among multiple natural and social determinants affecting health.
PUBHLTH 1.restriction: Restriction: Nursing Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Public Health Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Public Health Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PUBHLTH 2.name: Case Studies in Public Health Practice
PUBHLTH 2.description: Presents case studies in various themes of public health practice to demonstrate how the principles of public health were established and continue to evolve.
PUBHLTH 2.restriction: Restriction: Public Health Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Public Health Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PUBHLTH 7A.name: Public Health Statistics I
PUBHLTH 7A.description: Introduces the development and application of statistical reasoning and methods in addressing, analyzing, and solving problems in public health, health care, and biomedical, clinical, and population-based research and practice.
PUBHLTH 7A.restriction: Restriction: Public Health Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Public Health Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PUBHLTH 7B.name: Public Health Statistics II
PUBHLTH 7B.description: Introduces the development and application of statistical reasoning and methods in addressing, analyzing, and solving problems in public health, health care, and biomedical, clinical, and population-based research and practice.
PUBHLTH 7B.restriction: Restriction: Public Health Majors only. Public Health Sciences Majors only. Public Health Policy Majors only.

PUBHLTH 10.name: Special Topics in Public Health
PUBHLTH 10.description: Introduction to emerging topics in public health. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

PUBHLTH 30.name: Introduction to Urban Environmental Health
PUBHLTH 30.description: Study of natural and physical components of earth's environmental problems due to human activities. Topics include global air, water, soil, biodiversity, rainforests, energy, demographics, agriculture, and urbanization. Theme is sustainability. Integrated into the science are social, legal, and economic considerations.

PUBHLTH 60.name: Environmental Quality and Health
PUBHLTH 60.description: Overviews how pollution in the environment affects human health. Topics are toxicology, epidemiology, risk assessment, water, food, air, radiation, pesticides, solid and hazardous waste. Included are interdisciplinary elements of environmental regulations, education, and consumer protection.

PUBHLTH 80.name: AIDS Fundamentals
PUBHLTH 80.description: Considers the biological and sociological bases of the AIDS epidemic. Topics include the history of AIDS, current medical knowledge, transmission, risk reduction, and how the community can respond.

PUBHLTH 90.name: Natural Disasters
PUBHLTH 90.description: Natural disasters are natural Earth processes that adversely affect humans. Topics include tectonics, earthquakes, tsunami, volcanoes, landslides, severe weather, flooding, coastal processes, wildfire, related topics, and use of GIS for hazard and risk assessment.

PUBHLTH 91.name: Disparities in Health Care
PUBHLTH 91.description: Student participatory course practicing initiation, planning, and coordination of various speakers on the subject of Disparities in Health Care.

PUBHLTH 100.name: Special Topics in Public Health
PUBHLTH 100.description: Studies in selected areas of public health. Topics addressed vary each quarter. Course may be offered online when topic is Public Health in the Corporate World.

PUBHLTH 101.name: Introduction to Epidemiology
PUBHLTH 101.description: The distribution of disease and injury across time, space, and populations. Covers basic concepts and methods of descriptive epidemiology including the natural history of disease, data, and indices of health.
PUBHLTH 101.prereqString: Prerequisite: STATS 7 or STATS 8 or PUBHLTH 7 or PUBHLTH 7A
PUBHLTH 101.restriction: Restriction: Public Health Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Public Health Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PUBHLTH 102.name: Social Epidemiology
PUBHLTH 102.description: Overviews evidence linking environmental factors to mental and physical disorders including such variables as socioeconomic status, income inequality, work stress, job loss, social capital, location, and other demographic characteristics. Measurement and research design issues of both individual and aggregate levels.
PUBHLTH 102.prereqString: Prerequisite: (PSCI 9 or PSCI 11C or PSYCH 7A or PSYCH 9C) and SOCECOL 10 and SOCECOL 13
PUBHLTH 102.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Public Health Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Public Health Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PUBHLTH 105.name: Introduction to Medical Informatics
PUBHLTH 105.description: Broad overview of medical informatics for students with varied backgrounds. Electronic medical records, online resources, mobile technologies, patient safety, and computational design. Legal, ethical, and public policy issues. Health systems management. Evaluation and fieldwork for health systems.
PUBHLTH 105.prereqString: Prerequisite: WRITING 39C or WRITING 30 or WRITING 31 or HUMAN 1C or HUMAN H1C. WRITING 39C with a grade of C or better. WRITING 30 with a grade of C or better. WRITING 31 with a grade of C or better. HUMAN 1C with a grade of C or better. HUMAN H1C with a grade of C or better
PUBHLTH 105.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

PUBHLTH 106.name: Project in Health Informatics
PUBHLTH 106.description: Students undertake significant quarter-long projects related to health informatics. Topics may include field evaluations of health care technologies, prototypes, iterative design, and system implementations.

PUBHLTH 107.name: Epidemiology of Drug Use and Misuse
PUBHLTH 107.description: Applies epidemiologic concepts to the use and misuse of licit/illicit substances. Emphasizes descriptive aspects of drug use and determinants of progressing from experimental use to misuse. Assesses subgroups of abusers, risk factors, trends, and surveillance techniques for estimating drug prevalence.
PUBHLTH 107.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. Public Health Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Public Health Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PUBHLTH 115.name: Community, Social Justice, and Health Equity Research for Action
PUBHLTH 115.description: Focuses on community as a unit of identity, community, well-being, and social justice perspectives and initiatives to promote community health. Addresses community change and improvements in community well-being, with a focus on health equity research for action.
PUBHLTH 115.prereqString: Prerequisite: PUBHLTH 1 or PUBHLTH 2 or CHC/LAT 61 or CHC/LAT 62 or CHC/LAT 63

PUBHLTH 119.name: Special Topics in Epidemiology and Genetics
PUBHLTH 119.description: Studies in selected areas of epidemiology and genetics. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

PUBHLTH 120.name: Nutrition and Global Health
PUBHLTH 120.description: Global issues related to nutrition and public health. Evaluation of nutritional risk factors associated with the development of chronic diseases and the role of nutritional medicine in prevention. Topics include food safety, communicable diseases, supplements, and regulatory issues.
PUBHLTH 120.restriction: Restriction: Public Health Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Public Health Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PUBHLTH 121.name: Introduction to Complementary and Alternative Medicine
PUBHLTH 121.description: Examines health and disease in contemporary American culture/society with definitions, models, and practices of what has come to be known as "orthodox" or "conventional" medicine. Selected "alternative" or "complementary" modes of promoting health and well-being including homeopathy, herbology, and chiropractic.
PUBHLTH 121.restriction: Restriction: Public Health Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Public Health Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PUBHLTH 122.name: Health Policy
PUBHLTH 122.description: Considers social and economic aspects of health and disease in the United States.  What are the proper roles of the individual, community, and government in improving health and health care?  International comparisons will be made wherever possible.
PUBHLTH 122.restriction: Restriction: Public Health Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Public Health Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Urban Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PUBHLTH 125.name: Foundations of Community Health
PUBHLTH 125.description: A social ecological framework for understanding community health is presented. Measures of individual and community health are compared, and the influence of personal and environmental factors on individual, group, and population health is examined. Community health promotion strategies are discussed.
PUBHLTH 125.restriction: Restriction: Public Health Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Public Health Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Urban Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PUBHLTH 126.name: Public Health Law: Fundamentals in Action
PUBHLTH 126.description: Addresses the relationship of U.S. public health law to health systems at the individual and population levels. Examines legislative and judicial concepts and how they are applied to disease prevention strategies, health services, management, and policy.

PUBHLTH 127.name: Public Health Programs for the Corporate World
PUBHLTH 127.description: International perspective on workplace health promotion. Strategies for developing programs to improve employee health and to decrease risks of chronic degenerative diseases. Case studies include assessment of employee health, program design, implementation, and evaluation. Emphasis on disease prevention.

PUBHLTH 129.name: Public Health Administration
PUBHLTH 129.description: Examines historical aspects of public health administration including policies, procedures, trends, and development of organizations. Addresses information and skills necessary to succeed in public health leadership roles. Discusses strategic planning, collaborations, and ethical considerations for successful management in public health.
PUBHLTH 129.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. Public Health Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Public Health Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PUBHLTH 132.name: American Public Policy
PUBHLTH 132.description: Focuses on the development and implementation of public policy in the United States. Lectures cover theoretical models of the policy process as well as significant problems facing contemporary American decision-makers.

PUBHLTH 135.name: Medical Sociology
PUBHLTH 135.description: Current problems in U.S. health-care system and proposals for reform. Examines  financial barriers to access
PUBHLTH 135.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. Sociology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PUBHLTH 138.name: Tobacco Control Policy
PUBHLTH 138.description: Examines the challenges that governments encounter in regulating the marketing, sales and acquisition, and use of tobacco products. Students assess the supply and demand for tobacco from the perspectives of the industry and consumer.
PUBHLTH 138.restriction: Restriction: Public Health Majors only. Public Health Sciences Majors only. Public Health Policy Majors only.

PUBHLTH 139.name: Special Topics in Health Policy and Administration
PUBHLTH 139.description: Studies in selected areas of health policy and administration. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
PUBHLTH 139.restriction: Restriction: Public Health Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Public Health Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PUBHLTH 141.name: Clinical Health Psychology
PUBHLTH 141.description: Behavioral role in etiology, treatment, and prevention of certain diseases. Behavioral intervention including biofeedback, stress-, pain-management, health habit counseling, and other skills to assist patients make cognitive, emotional, and behavioral changes needed to cope with disease or achieve better health.
PUBHLTH 141.prereqString: Prerequisite: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11C or PSYCH 7A or PSYCH 9C
PUBHLTH 141.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Public Health Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Public Health Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PUBHLTH 144.name: Health Behavior Theory
PUBHLTH 144.description: Introduces theoretical perspectives from the social sciences to understand health behavior from the vantage point of individuals, their interpersonal contacts, communities, and ecological contexts. Application of theory to public health problems is a central focus.
PUBHLTH 144.restriction: Restriction: Public Health Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Public Health Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PUBHLTH 146.name: Health Promotion Programs
PUBHLTH 146.description: Examines ecological perspectives of health promotion programs and risk factors related to mortality/morbidity.  Analyzes effectiveness of health promotion strategies and issues in the existing healthcare systems in light of sociocultural beliefs and economical/political conditions.
PUBHLTH 146.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. Public Health Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Public Health Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PUBHLTH 147.name: Drug Abuse and Its Prevention
PUBHLTH 147.description: Theoretical and practical underpinnings of drug abuse and its prevention at the individual and population levels. Students practice developing drug abuse prevention schemes for specific populations. Recent developments in pharmacological and biobehavioral theories of drug dependence are explored.
PUBHLTH 147.restriction: Restriction: Public Health Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Public Health Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PUBHLTH 148.name: Public Health Communication
PUBHLTH 148.description: Theoretical underpinnings and practical applications of communication sciences in public health practice. Techniques of effective communication, including fear appeal and deterrence
PUBHLTH 148.restriction: Restriction: Public Health Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Public Health Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PUBHLTH 150.name: Public Health and Wellness
PUBHLTH 150.description: Presents information about wellness from both science and policy perspectives in order to demonstrate the role of wellness in public health. Emphasizes the conditions that create wellness in the individual, the community, the nation, and the world.
PUBHLTH 150.restriction: Restriction: Public Health Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Public Health Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PUBHLTH 159.name: Special Topics in Social and Behavioral Health Science
PUBHLTH 159.description: Studies in selected areas of social and behavioral health sciences. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

PUBHLTH 161.name: Environmental Geology
PUBHLTH 161.description: Introduction to geologic principles and applications to environmental problems. Topics include: tectonic processes, earth materials, soils, river processes, groundwater, the coastal environment, slope failures, seismic hazards, mineral resources, and land-use evaluation based on geologic conditions. Examples from case studies.
PUBHLTH 161.restriction: Restriction: Public Health Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Public Health Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PUBHLTH 163.name: Introduction to Environmental Health Science
PUBHLTH 163.description: Focuses on processes of exposure to environmental toxins/agents and their impact to human health and the environment. Media transport, exposure assessment, susceptibility, behavior, and health effect of several toxins are discussed.
PUBHLTH 163.restriction: Restriction: Public Health Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Public Health Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PUBHLTH 167.name: Air Pollution, Climate, and Health
PUBHLTH 167.description: Introduction to how air pollutants are emitted into the atmosphere, how people are most exposed to air pollutants in developed and developing areas, physical and meteorological processes that affect transport, and the influence of air pollutants on global warming.
PUBHLTH 167.restriction: Restriction: Public Health Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Public Health Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PUBHLTH 168.name: Nuclear Environments
PUBHLTH 168.description: Understanding the impact of the nuclear age on the environment and human health through interrelated developments of nuclear power and nuclear weapons. The early years of weapon development, catastrophic environmental pollution, perils of nuclear power in the U.S. and Russia.

PUBHLTH 170.name: Introduction to Global Health
PUBHLTH 170.description: Provides a foundational interdisciplinary understanding of global health issues and their importance to various societal goals, including poverty reduction, economic productivity, and peace promotion. Covers major communicable and non-communicable diseases and demographic patterns of disease burden.

PUBHLTH 171.name: Human Exposure to Environmental Contaminants
PUBHLTH 171.description: Introduces origins of human's realization that chemicals in the environment may adversely affect health. Introduces the theory and principles of exposure assessment. Covers estimation of exposure, variability of measures, the way exposure assessment is incorporated into the risk-assessment paradigm.

PUBHLTH 172.name: Climate Change and Disaster Management
PUBHLTH 172.description: Examines the social, economic, environmental, and health impacts of anthropogenic climate change through engaged learning that integrates practice and theory.

PUBHLTH 173.name: Health and Global Environmental Change
PUBHLTH 173.description: Overview of scientific underpinnings of global environmental change and human health consequences. Provides  an understanding of the fundamental dependency of human health on global environmental integrity. Encourages disciplinary cross-fertilization through interaction of students in environmental, health, and policy sciences.
PUBHLTH 173.prereqString: Prerequisite: One upper-division course in environmental science, public health, environmental policy, and/or environmental management.
PUBHLTH 173.restriction: Restriction: Public Health Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Public Health Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PUBHLTH 174.name: Global Health Ethics
PUBHLTH 174.description: Provides a foundation for understanding and application of key issues.

PUBHLTH 176.name: War and Public Health
PUBHLTH 176.description: Explores how war impacts public health both globally and domestically in the United States. Focus on the link between war and the burden that it ultimately places on physical, mental, environmental, and societal health as well as on health systems.

PUBHLTH 177.name: Global Health Policy and Diplomacy
PUBHLTH 177.description: Fundamental principles and consequences of global health policy and diplomacy, including governance structure, functions, analysis, advocacy, and outcomes. Emphasizes practical application of multilateral policies for global health security and responses to transnational threats such as pandemics, climate, pollution, and migration.

PUBHLTH 179.name: Special Topics in Environmental and Global Health Science
PUBHLTH 179.description: Studies in selected areas of environmental and global health sciences. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

PUBHLTH 180.name: Epidemiology of Infectious Disease
PUBHLTH 180.description: Examines the distribution of infectious disease and the health and disease risk among human populations. Introduces basic methods for infectious disease epidemiology. Case studies of important diseases, including HIV and malaria, are conducted.

PUBHLTH 181.name: Infectious Disease Dynamics
PUBHLTH 181.description: Learn how the immune system interacts with infectious diseases, in particular with viral infections. An introduction to basic virology and immunology, it concentrates on the way in which the immune system is critical to the prevention of infections.

PUBHLTH 182.name: Evolutionary and Ecological Principles in Medicine
PUBHLTH 182.description: Explore the dynamics of populations on an ecological, epidemiological, and medical level. Considers the dynamics of competition, predation, and parasitism
PUBHLTH 182.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI 93 or BIO SCI H93

PUBHLTH 189.name: Special Topics in Infectious Diseases
PUBHLTH 189.description: Studies in selected areas of infectious diseases. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
PUBHLTH 189.restriction: Restriction: Public Health Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Public Health Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PUBHLTH 190.name: Geographic Information Systems for Public Health
PUBHLTH 190.description: Provides a broad introduction to the use of Geographic Information Systems software to carry out projects for visualizing and analyzing spatial data to address significant issues of health care and policy-planning.

PUBHLTH 191A.name: Seminar: Advances and Challenges in Public Health
PUBHLTH 191A.description: Forum for exploring recent advances and challenges in all disciplines of public health research and practice. Features case studies exemplifying the integration of core competencies with cross-cutting interdisciplinary themes of public health.

PUBHLTH 191B.name: Seminar: Advances and Challenges in Public Health
PUBHLTH 191B.description: Forum for exploring recent advances and challenges in all disciplines of public health research and practice. Features case studies exemplifying the integration of core competencies with cross-cutting interdisciplinary themes of public health.

PUBHLTH 191C.name: Seminar: Advances and Challenges in Public Health
PUBHLTH 191C.description: Forum for exploring recent advances and challenges in all disciplines of public health research and practice. Features case studies exemplifying the integration of core competencies with cross-cutting interdisciplinary themes of public health.

PUBHLTH H192A.name: Public Health Honors Seminar and Thesis I
PUBHLTH H192A.description: Provides an opportunity for selected students to pursue advanced work in research and earn Public Health Honors. Students will conduct their honors research project with faculty through lectures, guest speakers, creating timelines and assignments.
PUBHLTH H192A.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Public Health Policy Majors only. Public Health Sciences Majors only.

PUBHLTH H192B.name: Public Health Honors Seminar and Thesis II
PUBHLTH H192B.description: Students initiate and complete data collection for the honors thesis. In addition, students begin data analysis and summarize results at a class symposium at the end of the quarter. A faculty mentor provides supervision and feedback on thesis chapters.
PUBHLTH H192B.restriction: Restriction: Public Health Policy Majors only. Public Health Sciences Majors only.

PUBHLTH H192C.name: Public Health Honors Seminar and Thesis III
PUBHLTH H192C.description: Students write their honors research project (PUBHLTH H192A-PUBHLTH H192B) and prepare an oral report to be presented at a class symposium at the end of the quarter. A faculty mentor provides supervision and feedback on thesis chapters.
PUBHLTH H192C.restriction: Restriction: Public Health Policy Majors only. Public Health Sciences Majors only.

PUBHLTH 193.name: Ethics and Responsible Conduct of Research in Public Health
PUBHLTH 193.description: Issues of scientific integrity and satisfies the requirements for training in public health ethics. Includes guidelines for responsible conduct of research, federal and international codes, administrative review and approval, conflict of interest, and privacy and safety of research participants.  Course may be offered online.
PUBHLTH 193.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. Public Health Sciences Majors only. Public Health Policy Majors only.

PUBHLTH 194A.name: Clinical and Translational Research Preparatory I
PUBHLTH 194A.description: Provides training for students with an interest in clinical and translational research in the health care setting. Cultivates skills for study design, research literature review, ethics, responsible conduct of research, and cultural competence while emphasizing professionalism and personal responsibility.
PUBHLTH 194A.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI 99 and BIO SCI 194S and CHEM 1C and CHEM 1LC and CHEM 1LD. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

PUBHLTH 194B.name: Clinical and Translational Research Preparatory II
PUBHLTH 194B.description: Provides opportunities for students to participate in clinical and translational research through rotations in at least two health care settings. Builds on preparation through the first course (194A) in the sequence to support exploration of various research topics.
PUBHLTH 194B.prereqString: Prerequisite: PUBHLTH 194A. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

PUBHLTH 194C.name: Clinical and Translational Research Preparatory III
PUBHLTH 194C.description: Provides opportunities for students to work closely in a particular clinical and translational research setting. Builds on preparation through the didactic instruction presented in first course of the sequence (194A) to support deeper engagement on a particular research topic.
PUBHLTH 194C.prereqString: Prerequisite: PUBHLTH 194B. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

PUBHLTH 194D.name: Clinical and Translational Research Preparatory IV
PUBHLTH 194D.description: Provides opportunities for students to participate in clinical and translational research through placement in a research laboratory. This course is a continuation of 194C in which students have the opportunity to participate in a permanent research rotation.

PUBHLTH 195W.name: Public Health Practicum and Culminating Experience
PUBHLTH 195W.description: Provides direct opportunities for Public Health majors to observe and participate in public health activities and/or research
PUBHLTH 195W.prereqString: Prerequisite: PUBHLTH 1 and PUBHLTH 2. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
PUBHLTH 195W.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. Public Health Sciences Majors only. Public Health Policy Majors only.

PUBHLTH 196A.name: Clinical and Translational Research Preparatory I - Community-Based Research and Evaluation
PUBHLTH 196A.description: Provides training for students with an interest in clinical and translational research in a community-based setting. Cultivates skills for study design, research literature review, ethics, responsible conduct of research, and cultural competence while emphasizing professionalism and personal responsibility.

PUBHLTH 196B.name: Clinical and Translational Research Preparatory II - Community-Based Research and Evaluation
PUBHLTH 196B.description: Provides the unique opportunity for students to participate in research in two or more community-based settings. Builds on preparation through PUBHLTH 196A to support exploration of various research topics.

PUBHLTH 196C.name: Clinical and Translational Research Preparatory III - Community-Based Research and Evaluation III
PUBHLTH 196C.description: Final course in the 196 series where students have the unique opportunity to participate in permanent research rotation. Instructs students how to design, perform, interpret, and discuss independent research in a collaborative atmosphere.

PUBHLTH 197.name: Field Studies in Public Health
PUBHLTH 197.description: For students who may either accompany faculty members on field trips or engage in post-practicum work at a field agency.

PUBHLTH 198.name: Directed Studies
PUBHLTH 198.description: Student participation in a series of research-related activities performed in an individual or small-group setting under the guidance of a faculty advisor.

PUBHLTH 199.name: Undergraduate Research
PUBHLTH 199.description: Original research with Public Health faculty. Attendance at regular research group meetings is also generally expected, and a quarterly written report is required. Strongly recommended for students considering research careers and/or graduate degree programs.

PUBHLTH 200.name: Foundations of Public Health
PUBHLTH 200.description: Presents the overarching framework, principles, and core responsibilities of public health research and practice from a multidisciplinary perspective. Provides necessary foundation for further studies toward advanced cross-cutting approaches essential for public health practice.
PUBHLTH 200.restriction: Restriction: College of Health Sciences students only. Program in Public Health students only. Master of Public Health Degree students only. Graduate students only. Public Health Majors only.

PUBHLTH 204.name: Biostatistics I: Introduction to Statistical Methods
PUBHLTH 204.description: Designed to help students develop an appreciation for statistician's view of the research process, emphasizing biomedical research. Instills an understanding of how statistical models are used to yield insights about data that form evidence-based understanding of the world around us.

PUBHLTH 204B.name: Biostatistics II: Intermediate Statistical Methods
PUBHLTH 204B.description: Intended for graduate students in epidemiology, public health, and clinical research fields. Covers common regression-modeling techniques frequently used in biologic and medical applications.
PUBHLTH 204B.prereqString: Prerequisite: EPIDEM 204. EPIDEM 204 with a grade of B or better

PUBHLTH 204C.name: Biostatistics III: Advanced Statistical Methods
PUBHLTH 204C.description: Intended for graduate students in epidemiology, public health, and related fields.  Introduces statistical methods for analyzing survival and longitudinal/clustered data, and techniques to resolve missing data.
PUBHLTH 204C.prereqString: Prerequisite: EPIDEM 204B. EPIDEM 204B with a grade of B or better

PUBHLTH 206A.name: Principles of Epidemiology
PUBHLTH 206A.description: Fundamental principles of epidemiology, biostatistics, and epidemiological research. Topics include research methods of measuring health problems in populations, disease control and prevention in populations, how epidemiology contributes to knowledge of disease etiology, and biostatistical analysis and interpretation of epidemiologic data.

PUBHLTH 206B.name: Intermediate Epidemiology
PUBHLTH 206B.description: Learn to design and conduct epidemiologic studies using common designs. Determine why bias and measurement error arise in observational studies, and how they influence effect estimates. Perform and interpret epidemiologic data analyses using statistical software.
PUBHLTH 206B.prereqString: Prerequisite: PUBHLTH 206A. PUBHLTH 206A with a grade of B or better
PUBHLTH 206B.restriction: Restriction: College of Health Sciences students only. Program in Public Health students only. Master of Public Health Degree students only. Graduate students only. Epidemiology Majors only.

PUBHLTH 206C.name: Advanced Epidemiologic Methods
PUBHLTH 206C.description: Advanced topics in the design and statistical analysis of epidemiologic studies. Topics include simulation methods, counter-matching and multiphase study designs, missing data, and Bayesian analysis. Published simulation studies are discussed and replicated using the R software package.
PUBHLTH 206C.prereqString: Prerequisite: EPIDEM 200A and EPIDEM 200B. EPIDEM 200A with a grade of B or better. EPIDEM 200B with a grade of B or better

PUBHLTH 207A.name: Probability and Statistics in Public Health
PUBHLTH 207A.description: An introduction to probability and statistical methods, using examples in public health. Topics include descriptive statistics, laws of probability, discrete and continuous probability distributions, estimation, confidence intervals, hypothesis testing, and power calculations for one- and two-sample comparisons.
PUBHLTH 207A.prereqString: Prerequisite: PUBHLTH 206A. PUBHLTH 206A with a grade of B or better
PUBHLTH 207A.restriction: Restriction: Program in Public Health students only. Master of Public Health Degree students only. Graduate students only. Public Health Majors only.

PUBHLTH 207B.name: Analysis of Public Health Data Using Statistical Software
PUBHLTH 207B.description: Overview of common statistical methods in public health and how to implement them in R. Topics include linear regression, ANOVA, the Kruskal-Wallis test, logistic regression, missing data and censoring, Kaplan-Meier survival curves, log-rank tests, and Cox regression.
PUBHLTH 207B.prereqString: Prerequisite: PUBHLTH 207A. PUBHLTH 207A with a grade of B or better
PUBHLTH 207B.restriction: Restriction: Program in Public Health students only. Master of Public Health Degree students only. Graduate students only. Public Health Majors only.

PUBHLTH 208.name: Advances in Social Epidemiology
PUBHLTH 208.description: Advances understanding of social distribution and social determinants of disease through multiple risk factor models and mechanisms that emphasize developmental and socio-environmental risk factors on mental and physical health across the life span.

PUBHLTH 209.name: Methods of Demographic Analysis
PUBHLTH 209.description: Introduces basic demographic methods used in social science and public health research. Topics include sources and limitations of demographic data

PUBHLTH 210.name: Theory-Driven Secondary Data Analysis
PUBHLTH 210.description: Learn how to develop and test theoretically-driven research questions in secondary data sources. Logic of theory building and testing, how to conduct statistical analyses on testable research questions, and interpret results. There is also a lab component.
PUBHLTH 210.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Environmental Health Sciences Majors only. Epidemiology Majors only. Public Health Majors only.

PUBHLTH 211A.name: Latinos/Latinas and Medical Care: Contemporary Issues
PUBHLTH 211A.description: Introduction to medical anthropological and social science perspectives on Latinos/Latinas in relation to a number of health and medically-related issues, i.e., immigration, gender, reproduction, culture, social structure, political economy, sexuality, utilization of medical services, and health beliefs.

PUBHLTH 211B.name: Latinos/Latinas and Medical Care: Contemporary Issues
PUBHLTH 211B.description: Introduction to medical anthropological and social science perspectives on Latinos/Latinas in relation to a number of health and medically-related issues, i.e., immigration, gender, reproduction, culture, social structure, political economy, sexuality, utilization of medical services, and health beliefs.

PUBHLTH 213.name: Epidemiology in Global Health
PUBHLTH 213.description: Examines major topics in epidemiology and global health. Research topics within these two disciplines are focused on resource-poor communities, with an application to the global world.
PUBHLTH 213.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Environmental Health Sciences Majors only. Epidemiology Majors only. Public Health Majors only.

PUBHLTH 219.name: Special Topics in Biostatistics, Epidemiology, and Health Informatics
PUBHLTH 219.description: Current research in biostatistics, epidemiology, and health informatics. Topics vary from quarter to quarter.

PUBHLTH 222.name: Health Policy and Management
PUBHLTH 222.description: Multidisciplinary inquiry into theory and practice concerned with delivery, quantity, costs of health care for individuals and populations. Explores managerial and policy concerns regarding structure, process, outcomes of health services including the costs, financing, organization, outcomes, and accessibility of care.
PUBHLTH 222.restriction: Restriction: Master of Public Health Degree students have first consideration for enrollment. Master of Public Policy Degree students have first consideration for enrollment. Graduate students only. Public Health Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Urban and Regional Planning Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

PUBHLTH 223.name: Risk Communication
PUBHLTH 223.description: Examines theory and research related to the communication of scientific information in risk communication contexts, risk perceptions, and behavior as related to decision-making under risk.

PUBHLTH 239.name: Special Topics in Health Policy and Management
PUBHLTH 239.description: Current research in health policy and management. Topics vary from quarter to quarter.

PUBHLTH 241.name: Environmental Policy and Global Sustainability
PUBHLTH 241.description: Organized around four transcendent questions: does the world value sustainability, what challenges must be met to move toward it, what are the roots of inequality, and is capitalism compatible with sustainability.

PUBHLTH 242.name: Theories of Health Communication
PUBHLTH 242.description: Explores the concepts, constructs, and theories of communication in health and risk contexts. Examines interpersonal, family, organizational, and mediated communicative processes about health care and conditions from a global perspective.

PUBHLTH 244.name: Health Behavior Theory
PUBHLTH 244.description: Introduces the field of Health Behavior and segues into major theoretical perspectives. Focus on health behavior change from the vantage point of individual health behavior and theoretical abstraction. Explores how to relate theory to behavior-change intervention programs.
PUBHLTH 244.restriction: Restriction: Master of Public Health Degree students only. Graduate students only. Public Health Majors only.

PUBHLTH 245.name: Health Promotion Planning
