PUBHLTH 245.description: Introduces strategic planning integral to intervention planning in public health practice and research, emphasizing the fundamental domains of social and behavioral health science and practices. Students develop an intervention plan for a specific health problem, health behavior, and target population.

PUBHLTH 246.name: Social Research Methods
PUBHLTH 246.description: An interactive graduate seminar covering topics related to the research process and study design. Begins with conceptualizing research questions, hypotheses, and then turns to topics in measurement and concludes with experimental, quasi-experimental, and observational study designs.

PUBHLTH 247.name: Program Evaluation
PUBHLTH 247.description: Introduces methods, tools, and procedures for systematic investigation of the effectiveness of programs in health and social services for disease intervention, prevention, and health promotion. Includes development of program evaluation plans, logic models, contextual frameworks, study designs, and data analyses.

PUBHLTH 248.name: Fundamentals of Maternal and Child Health - Programs, Problems, and Policy
PUBHLTH 248.description: Overview of issues facing women, children, and families from a public health perspective.  Discusses role of socio-economic, political, biological, environmental factors on population health. Studies historical foundations and current factors impacting Maternal Child Health programs and legislation in the US.

PUBHLTH 250.name: Health Status and Care Disparities
PUBHLTH 250.description: Expert health care providers present viewpoints and interdisciplinary strategies for addressing sociocultural, economic, gender, age, and other disparities in population health status and care provision.

PUBHLTH 251.name: Models of Practice and Intervention at the Community Level
PUBHLTH 251.description: Examines and critiques current models, frameworks, theories for.

PUBHLTH 259.name: Special Topics in Social and Behavioral Health Sciences
PUBHLTH 259.description: Current research in Social and Behavioral Health Sciences. Topics vary from quarter to quarter.

PUBHLTH 260.name: Human Exposure Modeling
PUBHLTH 260.description: Explores the basic principles and methods in estimating human exposure to environmental pollutants. Topics include source emissions, spatial/temporal aspects of human exposures, air pollution exposure modeling, time-activity patterns, micro-environmental exposure assessment, the uncertainty/variability analysis.

PUBHLTH 264.name: Introduction to Environmental Health Science
PUBHLTH 264.description: Convergence of agents (chemical, physical, biological, or psychosocial) in environment can emerge as diseases influenced by social, political, and economic factors, allowing them to become rooted in society. How these agents from various spheres come together and impact human health.
PUBHLTH 264.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Environmental Health Sciences Majors only. Epidemiology Majors only. Public Health Majors only. Environ Health Sci and Policy Majors only.

PUBHLTH 269.name: Air Pollution, Climate, and Health
PUBHLTH 269.description: Emission of air pollutants into the atmosphere, physical and meteorological processes that affect transport, and influence on global warming. Concepts of how and where people are most exposed, and how exposures and health effects differ in developed and developing regions.

PUBHLTH 272.name: Occupational Health Psychology
PUBHLTH 272.description: Introduction to psychological and social factors in the workplace that affect health and productivity. Goal is to support redesign of the workplace and social situations that can reduce stress-related illness risks, and increase humane forms of productivity and competence development.

PUBHLTH 275.name: Environmental Modeling and Risk Management
PUBHLTH 275.description: Surveys the general principles, basic mathematical methods, and practices of environmental modeling and human health risk assessment. Topics include advection-dispersion models, risk management, and risk perception. Students conduct an original risk assessment as a final group project.

PUBHLTH 277A.name: Target Organ Toxicology I
PUBHLTH 277A.description: Mechanistic analysis of responses occurring in various organ systems of experimental animals and humans exposed to environmental and occupational chemicals and radiation. Review distinctive cellular and tissue structure and physiological function of the various organ systems.

PUBHLTH 277B.name: Target Organ Toxicology II
PUBHLTH 277B.description: Mechanistic analysis of responses occurring in various organ systems of experimental animals and humans exposed to environmental and occupational chemicals and radiation. Review of distinctive cellular and tissue structure and physiological function of the various organ systems.

PUBHLTH 278.name: Industrial Toxicology
PUBHLTH 278.description: Analysis of responsibilities toxicologists have in industry, including product safety, generating material safety, data sheets, animal testing, ecotoxicological testing, risk/hazard communication, and assisting industrial hygienists and occupational physicians

PUBHLTH 279.name: Special Topics in Environmental & Occupational Health
PUBHLTH 279.description: Current research in environmental and occupational health. Topics vary from quarter to quarter.

PUBHLTH 280.name: Global Burden of Disease
PUBHLTH 280.description: Introduces composite measures of disease burden, including Disability Adjusted Life Years and their use in prioritizing disease burden at local, regional, and global levels. Focuses on WHO's landmark assessments and introduces DISMOD software for specific analyses.

PUBHLTH 281.name: Infectious Disease Epidemiology
PUBHLTH 281.description: Geographical distribution of infectious diseases and the health and disease risk in diverse human populations. Introduces basic methods for infectious disease epidemiology and case studies of important diseases. Includes surveillance, outbreak investigation, emerging pathogens, traditional and molecular epidemiology.

PUBHLTH 282.name: Climate Change and Global Health
PUBHLTH 282.description: Designed for students to examine major topics in climate change and global health. Draws heavily on the literature in order to develop an understanding of micro- and macro-level impacts and drivers with regard to climate change and health.
PUBHLTH 282.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Environmental Health Sciences Majors only. Epidemiology Majors only. Public Health Majors only.

PUBHLTH 283.name: Geographic Information Systems for Public Health
PUBHLTH 283.description: Provides a broad introduction to the use of Geographic Information Systems software to carry out projects for visualizing and analyzing spatial data to address significant issues of health care and policy-planning.

PUBHLTH 286.name: Advanced Geographic Information Systems and Spatial Epidemiology
PUBHLTH 286.description: Students expand their current knowledge of the ArcGIS software to develop advanced geographic-related research questions, learn how to apply spatial epidemiologic methods to public health data, and integrate their skills in a GIS project of their design.

PUBHLTH 287.name: Qualitative Research Methods in Public Health
PUBHLTH 287.description: General introduction to qualitative research methods for investigating public health questions at various scales from community level to global populations. Emphasizes systematic approaches to the collection, analysis, interpretation of qualitative data.

PUBHLTH 288.name: Research Proposal Writing in Global Health
PUBHLTH 288.description: Overview of financial support for research in global health and disease prevention. Collaborative agreements, guidelines for proposal writing, team building, budgeting, peer-review process, and transitioning from proposal to research project implementation.

PUBHLTH 289.name: Special Topics in Global Health and Disease Prevention
PUBHLTH 289.description: Current research in global health and disease prevention. Topics vary from quarter to quarter.

PUBHLTH 290.name: Special Topics in Public Health
PUBHLTH 290.description: Studies in selected areas of public health. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

PUBHLTH 291A.name: Seminar: Advances and Challenges in Public Health
PUBHLTH 291A.description: Forum for exploring recent advances and challenges in all disciplines of public health research and practice.  Features case studies exemplifying the integration of core competencies with cross-cutting interdisciplinary themes of public health.

PUBHLTH 291B.name: Seminar: Advances and Challenges in Public Health
PUBHLTH 291B.description: Forum for exploring recent advances and challenges in all disciplines of public health research and practice.  Features case studies exemplifying the integration of core competencies with cross-cutting interdisciplinary themes of public health.

PUBHLTH 291C.name: Seminar: Advances and Challenges in Public Health
PUBHLTH 291C.description: Forum for exploring recent advances and challenges in all disciplines of public health research and practice.  Features case studies exemplifying the integration of core competencies with cross-cutting interdisciplinary themes of public health.

PUBHLTH 292.name: Ethics and Responsible Conduct of Research in Public Health
PUBHLTH 292.description: Issues of scientific integrity and satisfies the requirements for training in public health ethics. Includes guidelines for responsible conduct of research, federal and international codes, administrative review and approval, conflict of interest, and privacy and safety of research participants.

PUBHLTH 293.name: Foundations of Clinical and Translational Science
PUBHLTH 293.description: Introduces rationale and imperative for clinical translational science and various approaches being developed to speed-up discoveries and their transformation into health care practices. Compares and contrasts current impediments to clinical research with the potential and transformative power of translational science.

PUBHLTH 294.name: Research Communication in Public Health
PUBHLTH 294.description: Strategies for effective writing and oral presentation of research characteristics and results to various audiences. Includes exercises in writing for the public, for scholarly journals, and at conferences.

PUBHLTH 295.name: Graduate Practicum and Culminating Experience in Public Health
PUBHLTH 295.description: Provides opportunities for hands-on experience for graduate students at agencies or organizations engaged in public health practice. Students are matched with placement sites based on academic preparation and students' career goals. The practicum report is integrated into the culminating experience.
PUBHLTH 295.prereqString: Prerequisite: PUBHLTH 200 and PUBHLTH 244 and PUBHLTH 222 and PUBHLTH 264 and PUBHLTH 207A. PUBHLTH 200 with a grade of B or better. PUBHLTH 244 with a grade of B or better. PUBHLTH 222 with a grade of B or better. PUBHLTH 264 with a grade of B or better. PUBHLTH 207A with a grade of B or better
PUBHLTH 295.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Public Health Majors only.

PUBHLTH 296.name: Doctoral Dissertation Research and Writing
PUBHLTH 296.description: Dissertation research with Public Health faculty.
PUBHLTH 296.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Public Health Majors only.

PUBHLTH 297.name: Research Design and Proposal Writing
PUBHLTH 297.description: Evaluate strengths of research findings based on methods used by researchers to develop research proposals. Components such as collaborative agreements, guidelines for proposal writing, budgeting, peer-review process, and transitioning from proposal to research project implementation are addressed.
PUBHLTH 297.restriction: Restriction: College of Health Sciences students only. Program in Public Health students only. Master of Public Health Degree students only. Graduate students only. Public Health Majors only.

PUBHLTH 298.name: Directed Studies in Public Health
PUBHLTH 298.description: Directed study with Public Health faculty.

PUBHLTH 299.name: Independent Study in Public Health
PUBHLTH 299.description: Independent research with Public Health faculty.

REL STD 5A.name: World Religions I
REL STD 5A.description: An introduction to the history, doctrine, culture, and writing of Judaism, Christianity, and Islam.

REL STD 5B.name: World Religions II
REL STD 5B.description: An introduction to various religious traditions in selected areas of the world—including India and South Asia, East Asia, Africa, and the Americas.

REL STD 5C.name: Religious Dialogue
REL STD 5C.description: Lectures and discussion on controversial topics in religion: sexual morality

REL STD 17.name: An Economic Approach to Religion
REL STD 17.description: Introduction to how basic economic concepts such as demand, supply, consumption, production, competition, free-riding, innovation, regulation, and rent-seeking can be applied to understand observed religious behavior.

REL STD 21.name: Philosophy and Religion
REL STD 21.description: Examines the intersection of religion and philosophy from a standpoint that does not presuppose previous academic study of either.  Both Western and Eastern traditions and perspectives may be explored.

REL STD 61.name: Gender and Religion
REL STD 61.description: Introduces the topic of religion in a feminist context by performing cross-cultural exploration of gender, authority, and faith in various traditions. Study includes (but is not limited to) writings of contemporary Jewish, Christian, and Muslim feminists.

REL STD 90.name: Aspects of Religion
REL STD 90.description: A presentation of selected issues in the study of religion.

REL STD 100.name: Topics in the Study of Religion
REL STD 100.description: The intersection of religious belief and practices with selected subjects of continuing interest.

REL STD 103.name: Topics in the Philosophy of Religion
REL STD 103.description: Critical examination of philosophical concepts in religious scripture and theology, e.g., the nature and existence of God, miracles, the problem of evil, and divine command theories in ethics. May include any religious tradition.

REL STD 110.name: Thinking about Religion: Theories and Methodologies
REL STD 110.description: A survey and investigation of the major thinkers, theories, and methodologies in the study of religions. Designed to develop the student's ability to analyze and articulate theoretical arguments
REL STD 110.prereqString: Prerequisite: (REL STD 5A or HISTORY 16A) and (REL STD 5B or HISTORY 16B) and (REL STD 5C or HISTORY 16C)
REL STD 110.restriction: Restriction: Religious Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

REL STD 110W.name: Thinking about Religion: Theories and Methodologies
REL STD 110W.description: A survey and investigation of the major thinkers, theories, and methodologies in the study of religions. Designed to develop the student's ability to analyze and articulate theoretical arguments in writing
REL STD 110W.prereqString: Prerequisite: (REL STD 5A or HISTORY 16A) and (REL STD 5B or HISTORY 16B) and (REL STD 5C or HISTORY 16C). Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
REL STD 110W.restriction: Restriction: Religious Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

REL STD 115.name: Religion and World Politics
REL STD 115.description: Examines the relationship between religion and world politics historically and today, focusing on connections with peace/war, democracy, human rights, secularism(s), and globalization. Covers major debates, scholarship, concepts, and theories through class exercises, exams, and essays.
REL STD 115.prereqString: Prerequisite: POL SCI 41A or INTL ST 11 or INTL ST 12 or REL STD 5A or REL STD 5B or REL STD 5C

REL STD 120.name: Topics in Asian Religious Traditions
REL STD 120.description: Studies involving (but not limited to) Hinduism, Buddhism, Confucianism, Jainism, Sikhism, Daoism, Shinto or Shamanism, including both elite and doctrinal aspects and forms of more popular religiosity.

REL STD 122.name: Ancient India
REL STD 122.description: Examines the visual and religious history of the region defined as "India" today, but necessarily encompassing modern Bangladesh and Pakistan.  Culminates with the supposed Golden Age of the Gupta empire and its far-reaching legacies.

REL STD 123.name: Medieval India
REL STD 123.description: Begins with the Gupta period's aesthetic legacies in South Asia's architecture, sculpture, and painting. Explores the dispersal of Islam throughout South Asia, including the Muslim communities of southern India.

REL STD 124.name: Topics in Modern Indian Religion
REL STD 124.description: Topics in religions of the Indian subcontinent including, but not confined to, Hinduism, Jainism, Sikhism, Islam, and Buddhism from the founding of the Mughal Empire in 1526 to the creation of the several modern states of the Indian subcontinent.

REL STD 130.name: Jewish, Islamic, and Middle Eastern Religious Traditions
REL STD 130.description: Character and evolution of Egyptian, Jewish, Zoroastrian, Muslim, and other religious communities of the region from their formative periods to the present era.

REL STD 130F.name: Jews and Power
REL STD 130F.description: Examines the relationship between the Jewish people and political power over a 3500 year period. How have Jews preserved their communal interests and personal safety? How have they defined the proper relationship of the people to political authority.

REL STD 131A.name: History of Zoroastrianism
REL STD 131A.description: Reviews major trends in the history of Zoroastrianism.

REL STD 140.name: Early Western Religious Traditions
REL STD 140.description: Religious perspectives of the Mediterranean and European regions from the earliest times to approximately 1500 C.E.

REL STD 150.name: Religion in the Americas
REL STD 150.description: Religious belief and social context in North and South America from the earliest human societies to the present.

REL STD 160.name: Diaspora Religions
REL STD 160.description: Examination of what happens to belief and practice as religious communities are scattered geographically.

REL STD 170.name: Topics in Comparative Studies in Religion
REL STD 170.description: Literary, historical, or philosophical comparison of selected religious and quasi-religious traditions, their beliefs and practices.

REL STD 199.name: Independent Study
REL STD 199.description: Directed reading and research in consultation with a faculty member.  Substantial written work required.

ROTC 10L.name: Military Science-Basic Leadership Laboratory
ROTC 10L.description: Provides hands-on and practical military science material covered in the corresponding military science courses.

ROTC 11.name: Military Science - Personal Development
ROTC 11.description: Focuses on life skills such as physical fitness, nutrition, and time management while providing an introduction to military knowledge, customs, and skills.

ROTC 12.name: Military Science - Leadership I
ROTC 12.description: Focuses on the fundamentals of leadership, Army leadership values, ethics, coaching, and mentoring techniques.

ROTC 13.name: Applied Leadership in Small Unit Operations
ROTC 13.description: Focuses on leadership at the tactical level and includes instruction in fundamental military skills such as map reading, land navigation, squad and platoon operations, and resource planning techniques.

ROTC 21.name: Leadership and Ethics
ROTC 21.description: Explores the dimensions of creative and innovative tactical leadership strategies and styles by examining team dynamics and two historical leadership theories that form the basis of the Army leadership requirements model.

ROTC 22.name: Team Leadership II
ROTC 22.description: Explores team dynamics and two historical leadership theories that form the basis of the Army leadership requirements model.

ROTC 23.name: Tactical Leadership II
ROTC 23.description: Examines the challenges of leading tactical teams in the OE. Highlights dimensions of terrain analysis, patrolling, and operation orders.

ROTC 100L.name: Military Science-Advanced Leadership Laboratory
ROTC 100L.description: Provides hands-on and practical exercises for the military science material covered in the corresponding military science courses as well as leader training through practical application of the Leadership Development Program.

ROTC 131.name: Adaptive Team Leadership I
ROTC 131.description: Challenges cadets to study, practice, and evaluate adaptive leadership skills as they are presented with challenging scenarios related to squad tactical operations. Cadets receive systematic and specified feedback on their leadership attributes and core leader competencies.
ROTC 131.prereqString:
Corequisite: ROTC 100L
Prerequisite: ROTC 11 and ROTC 12 and ROTC 13 and ROTC 21 and ROTC 22 and ROTC 23
ROTC 131.restriction: Restriction: For students with a service obligation to the U.S. Army.

ROTC 132.name: Adaptive Team Leadership II
ROTC 132.description: Provides cadets systematic and specific feedback on their leadership attributes and core leader competencies. Based on such feedback, as well as their own self-evaluations, cadets continue to develop their leadership and critical thinking abilities.
ROTC 132.prereqString:
Corequisite: ROTC 100L
Prerequisite: ROTC 11 and ROTC 12 and ROTC 13 and ROTC 21 and ROTC 22 and ROTC 23
ROTC 132.restriction: Restriction: For students with a service obligation to the U.S. Army.

ROTC 133.name: Tactical Leadership III
ROTC 133.description: Uses increasingly intense situational leadership challenges to build cadet awareness and skills in leading small units. Skills in decision-making, persuading, and motivating team members when "under fire" are explored, evaluated, and developed.
ROTC 133.prereqString:
Corequisite: ROTC 100L
Prerequisite: ROTC 11 and ROTC 12 and ROTC 13 and ROTC 21 and ROTC 22 and ROTC 23
ROTC 133.restriction: Restriction: For students with a service obligation to the U.S. Army.

ROTC 141.name: Leadership III
ROTC 141.description: Transitions the focus of student learning from being trained, mentored, and evaluated as a cadet to learning how to train, mentor, and evaluate cadets. Cadets begin to learn the duties and responsibilities of an Army staff officer.
ROTC 141.prereqString:
Corequisite: ROTC 100L
Prerequisite: ROTC 131 and ROTC 132 and ROTC 133
ROTC 141.restriction: Restriction: For students with a service obligation to the U.S. Army.

ROTC 142.name: Developmental Leadership II
ROTC 142.description: Requires students to continue to train, mentor, and evaluate underclass cadets. Cadets learn to safely conduct training by understanding and employing the Composite Risk Management Process and the Comprehensive Soldier Fitness (CSF) program.
ROTC 142.prereqString:
Corequisite: ROTC 100L
Prerequisite: ROTC 131 and ROTC 132 and ROTC 133 and ROTC 141
ROTC 142.restriction: Restriction: For students with a service obligation to the U.S. Army.

ROTC 143.name: Officership
ROTC 143.description: Explores the dynamics of leading in the complex situations of current military operations in the OE. Cadets examine differences in customs and courtesies, military law, principles of war, and rules of engagement in the face of international terrorism.
ROTC 143.prereqString:
Corequisite: ROTC 100L
Prerequisite: ROTC 131 and ROTC 132 and ROTC 133 and ROTC 141 and ROTC 142
ROTC 143.restriction: Restriction: For students with a service obligation to the U.S. Army.

ROTC 151.name: Military History
ROTC 151.description: Develops an understanding of the role military officers have played in the defense of our country and the advancement of its military.

ROTC 152.name: United States Military History-1865 to 1945
ROTC 152.description: Examines the evolution of the American military establishment and the progression of military professionalism in terms of social, political, economic, military, and technological developments from the end of the Civil War through World War II.

ROTC 153.name: United States Military History-1945 to 2001
ROTC 153.description: Examines the evolution of the American military establishment and the progression of military professionalism in terms of social, political, economic, military, and technological developments from the Cold War to the War on Terrorism.

ROTC 197.name: Military Science Independent Studies
ROTC 197.description: Provides intensive, individual study with scheduled meetings to be arranged between Cadre and student. Assigned reading and tangible evidence of mastery of subject matter required.

RUSSIAN 1A.name: Fundamentals of Russian
RUSSIAN 1A.description: Focuses on reading, comprehension, basic composition, and conversation skills, and gives the student an initial exposure to the Russian cultural scene.

RUSSIAN 1B.name: Fundamentals of Russian
RUSSIAN 1B.description: Focuses on reading, comprehension, basic composition, and conversation skills, and gives the student an initial exposure to the Russian cultural scene.
RUSSIAN 1B.prereqString: Prerequisite: RUSSIAN 1A. RUSSIAN 1A with a grade of C or better. Placement into RUSSIAN 1B is also accepted.

RUSSIAN 1C.name: Fundamentals of Russian
RUSSIAN 1C.description: Focuses on reading, comprehension, basic composition, and conversation skills, and gives the student an initial exposure to the Russian cultural scene.
RUSSIAN 1C.prereqString: Prerequisite: RUSSIAN 1AB or RUSSIAN 1B. RUSSIAN 1AB with a grade of C or better. RUSSIAN 1B with a grade of C or better. Placement into RUSSIAN 1C is also accepted.

RUSSIAN 2A.name: Intermediate Russian
RUSSIAN 2A.description: Students read simple passages from contemporary Russian literary texts and newspapers. Development of oral skills and exposure to Russian culture continue.
RUSSIAN 2A.prereqString: Prerequisite: RUSSIAN 1BC or RUSSIAN 1C. RUSSIAN 1BC with a grade of C or better. RUSSIAN 1C with a grade of C or better. Placement into RUSSIAN 2A is also accepted.
RUSSIAN 2A.restriction: Restriction: School of Humanities students have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

RUSSIAN 2B.name: Intermediate Russian
RUSSIAN 2B.description: Students read simple passages from contemporary Russian literary texts and newspapers. Development of oral skills and exposure to Russian culture continue.
RUSSIAN 2B.prereqString: Prerequisite: RUSSIAN 2A. RUSSIAN 2A with a grade of C or better. Placement into RUSSIAN 2B is also accepted.
RUSSIAN 2B.restriction: Restriction: School of Humanities students have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

RUSSIAN 2C.name: Intermediate Russian
RUSSIAN 2C.description: Students read simple passages from contemporary Russian literary texts and newspapers. Development of oral skills and exposure to Russian culture continue.
RUSSIAN 2C.prereqString: Prerequisite: RUSSIAN 2B. RUSSIAN 2B with a grade of C or better. Placement into RUSSIAN 2C is also accepted.
RUSSIAN 2C.restriction: Restriction: School of Humanities students have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

RUSSIAN 50.name: Topics in Russian Culture
RUSSIAN 50.description: Study of varied topics in Russian culture, area studies, and society, both in the present and in historical perspective.

RUSSIAN 150.name: Topics in Russian Literature
RUSSIAN 150.description: Examines major themes in Russian literature, film, and other media from the eighteenth to twenty-first centuries. Taught in English.

RUSSIAN 190.name: Topics in Russian Language Through Film
RUSSIAN 190.description: Uses Russian films of the late 20th century to enhance students' language skills and deepen their cultural knowledge. Work involves intensive conversation, reading and listening comprehension, and the acquisition of written skills and grammatical accuracy. Conducted primarily in Russian.

RUSSIAN 199.name: Independent Study
RUSSIAN 199.description: Independent study under direct faculty supervision.

SOC SCI 1A.name: Principles in the Social Sciences
SOC SCI 1A.description: Introduction to various disciplines within the social sciences. Provides an interdisciplinary perspective on understanding human behavior and social institutions, including interpersonal, economic, and cultural activities.

SOC SCI H1E.name: Honors: Critical Issues on the Social Sciences
SOC SCI H1E.description: Major themes, methods, and works in the social sciences from an interdisciplinary perspective. Each quarter focuses on a different topic. Weekly seminars emphasizing development of critical thinking skills and quantitative analysis through written work are integral to the course.
SOC SCI H1E.restriction: Restriction: Campuswide Honors Collegium students only.

SOC SCI H1F.name: Honors: Critical Issues on the Social Sciences
SOC SCI H1F.description: Major themes, methods, and works in the social sciences from an interdisciplinary perspective. Each quarter focuses on a different topic. Weekly seminars emphasizing development of critical thinking skills and quantitative analysis through written work are integral to the course.
SOC SCI H1F.prereqString: Prerequisite: SOC SCI H1E or SOCECOL H20A
SOC SCI H1F.restriction: Restriction: Campuswide Honors Collegium students only.

SOC SCI H1G.name: Honors: Critical Issues on the Social Sciences
SOC SCI H1G.description: Major themes, methods, and works in the social sciences from an interdisciplinary perspective. Each quarter focuses on a different topic. Weekly seminars emphasizing development of critical thinking skills and quantitative analysis through written work are integral to the course.
SOC SCI H1G.prereqString: Prerequisite: SOC SCI H1F or SOCECOL H20B
SOC SCI H1G.restriction: Restriction: Campuswide Honors Collegium students only.

SOC SCI 2A.name: Introduction to Social Science Analysis
SOC SCI 2A.description: Introduction to social science research and analytical models. Theory construction and use of research methods in an interdisciplinary context.  Discussion of the application of social science research to public policy.  Computer laboratories develop creative thinking, graphing, and data presentation skills.
SOC SCI 2A.restriction: Restriction: School of Social Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment.

SOC SCI 3A.name: Computer-Based Research in the Social Sciences
SOC SCI 3A.description: Focuses on the data manipulation, data visualization, and information searching techniques. Hands-on experience in hypothesis testing, mapping, graphics, and data arrays.
SOC SCI 3A.restriction: Restriction: School of Social Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment.

SOC SCI 4A.name: Introduction to Global Studies
SOC SCI 4A.description: Ongoing historical processes that increase global integration, the social, economic, and political interdependence of different regions, cultures, and peoples. Topics include ancient empires, colonialism, nationalism, industrialization, modern imperialism and warfare, decolonization, global social movements, conflict, inequality, and global governance.
SOC SCI 4A.restriction: Restriction: International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

SOC SCI 5A.name: Introduction to Human Geography
SOC SCI 5A.description: Human behavior in a geographical context. Spatial patterns and organization of the cultural, social, and economic activities of man as imposed on and influenced by the earth's physical setting.

SOC SCI 5B.name: Introduction to Physical Geography
SOC SCI 5B.description: An introduction to the physical world we live in. Distribution and dynamics of the earth's air, water, and solid crust. Concepts and principles from climatology and geology. Selected examples from North America and beyond.

SOC SCI 5D.name: US & World Geography
SOC SCI 5D.description: Survey of general geographical principles and facts on a world scale, as well as introduction to the broad regional and resource geography of the U.S., emphasizing in particular the interactions of physical and cultural factors.

SOC SCI 10A.name: Probability and Statistics in Social Sciences I
SOC SCI 10A.description: Introduction to the variety of statistical applications in the social sciences. Descriptive statistics. Measures of central tendency and dispersion. Percentile ranks. Standardization and normal approximation. Basic probability theory focuses on application to statistical inference and binomial distribution. Laboratory required.
SOC SCI 10A.restriction: Restriction: Lower-division students only. Social Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. SOC SCI 10A may not be taken for credit if taken after or concurrently with ECON 15A.

SOC SCI 10B.name: Probability and Statistics in Social Sciences II
SOC SCI 10B.description: Introduction to statistical inference, sampling distribution, standard error.  Hypothesis tests for proportions and means. Inferential techniques for nominal variables including chi-square, study measures of strengths, significance of relationships between variables, assumptions, data requirements, and types of error in significance tests.
SOC SCI 10B.restriction: Restriction: School of Social Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment.

SOC SCI 10C.name: Probability and Statistics in Social Sciences III
SOC SCI 10C.description: Focus on correlation, regression, and control for effects of variables. One-way and two-way factorial analysis of variance. A priori and a posteriori comparisons.  Introduction to repeated measures design and non-parametric statistics. Discuss use of statistics in newspapers and popular magazines.
SOC SCI 10C.restriction: Restriction: School of Social Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment.

SOC SCI 11A.name: Barter to Bitcoin: Society, Technology and the Future of Money
SOC SCI 11A.description: Digital money has captured the broad imagination of speculators, coders, regulators, criminals and the mass media. Course puts this change in context: how do we understand money as a social, political and technological phenomenon?.

SOC SCI 12.name: Global Political Ideologies
SOC SCI 12.description: An overview of the major political ideologies shaping the current world order and global conflict. Topics include liberalism, democracy, nationalism, capitalism, communism, socialism, fascism, neoliberalism, clash of civilizations, sectarian violence, populist nationalism, and de-globalization.
SOC SCI 12.restriction: Restriction: International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

SOC SCI 15.name: Global Political Economy
SOC SCI 15.description: The global economy as an integrated system. The rise of world trade, capitalism, national economies, market cycles, competing economic ideologies, development, globalization, transnational labor, multinational corporations, and the role of UN, World Bank, WTO, and the IMF in global governance.
SOC SCI 15.restriction: Restriction: International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

SOC SCI 16.name: Human Rights and Global Governance
SOC SCI 16.description: Historical development of civil, political rights and the rise of human rights in international law. Explores role, and limitations, of the UN, ICJ, and ICC in global governance. Reconceptualizing democracy and political representation in a postnational 21st century.
SOC SCI 16.restriction: Restriction: International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

SOC SCI 17.name: Global Environmental Issues
SOC SCI 17.description: Examines problems such as global climate change, growing human populations, fisheries depletion, ocean acidification, biodiversity loss, deforestation, and food security. Introduces political, social, and economic factors contributing to environmental issues and their disproportional impacts on the world’s poor and minorities.
SOC SCI 17.restriction: Restriction: International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

SOC SCI 20.name: Model United Nations
SOC SCI 20.description: Focuses on simulations of the foreign policy pursuits of selected countries in the international community. Emphasis placed on understanding the rules of debate, as well as the policy positions of the student's selected country in the United Nations.

SOC SCI 40.name: Social Policy and Public Service
SOC SCI 40.description: An introduction to the basic theories and principles of public policy. Students examine various influences on the development of public policy and the principle actors in the process, and learn to identify tools and techniques employed in policy making.

SOC SCI 66.name: Introduction to Gangs
SOC SCI 66.description: Introduces students to street gang subculture and explores risk factors associated with gang membership. Students develop a working definition for street gang and understand the difference between social and legal definitions. Also explores the connection between prison and street gangs.

SOC SCI 70C.name: Comparing Cultures
SOC SCI 70C.description: Introduces students to the scope of cross-cultural comparisons by analyzing the theories, methodologies, and facts utilized by anthropologists, sociologists, social psychologists, political scientists, and historians in comparing cultures.

SOC SCI 78A.name: Asian American Histories
SOC SCI 78A.description: Examines and compares diverse experiences of major Asian American groups since the mid-nineteenth century. Topics include origins of emigration

SOC SCI 78B.name: Asian American Communities
SOC SCI 78B.description: Examines the renewal of Asian immigration following World War II. Explores contemporary Asian American populations and communities in the U.S., and the impact of contemporary Asian immigration on the U.S. political economy and social order.

SOC SCI 78C.name: Asian Americans and Race
SOC SCI 78C.description: Analyzes the Asian American experience in comparative perspective, which includes comparisons of different ethnic and racial groups, and across gender and class. Possible topics include labor, economy, politics, migration, nation, popular culture, gender, family, sexuality, and multiraciality.

SOC SCI 89.name: Special Topics in Social Sciences
SOC SCI 89.description: Studies in selected areas of Social Sciences. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

SOC SCI 102A.name: Introduction to Geographic Information Systems in Social Sciences
SOC SCI 102A.description: Hands-on laboratory course introduces students to the fundamentals of Geographic Information Systems (GIS) technology using social science applications.  Students learn to organize, manipulate, and display spatial data leading to the design of their own GIS research project.
SOC SCI 102A.restriction: Restriction: School of Social Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment.

SOC SCI 102B.name: Intermediate Geographic Information Systems in Social Sciences
SOC SCI 102B.description: Expands Geographic Information Systems (GIS) skills to more advanced theories and concepts in the spatial analysis of social science issues and particularly to analyzing and interpreting spatial data.  Students develop and complete a GIS research project of their own choosing.
SOC SCI 102B.restriction: Restriction: School of Social Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment.

SOC SCI 103A.name: Game Theory and Politics I
SOC SCI 103A.description: Introduction to game theory and a survey of its political applications. Examples of topics covered include voting in small committees, legislatures, and mass elections
SOC SCI 103A.restriction: Restriction: Social Policy/Public Service Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Sociology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

SOC SCI 103B.name: Game Theory and Politics II
SOC SCI 103B.description: More advanced game theory and its political applications, beginning where Game Theory and Politics I ends.  Examples of topics covered include revolutions
SOC SCI 103B.restriction: Restriction: Social Policy/Public Service Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

SOC SCI 115D.name: International Business
SOC SCI 115D.description: Introduction to conducting business in the international arena, decision making in the organization, and globalization of markets and production.  Topics covered range from tax and finance to ethics, marketing, and more.  Continuing corporate regulatory scandals discussed.

SOC SCI 119.name: Special Topics in Geography
SOC SCI 119.description: Studies in selected areas of geography. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

SOC SCI 120.name: Transnational Gangs
SOC SCI 120.description: Examines the internationalization of U.S. domestic street gangs.  The relationship between California gangs Mara Salvatrucha and 18th Street and Mexico/Central American gangs is assessed.  Specified topics include:  mobilization, migration, territorialism, culture, organization, and use of technology.

SOC SCI 121T.name: Voting and Political Manipulation
SOC SCI 121T.description: Introduction to social choice and cooperative games. Topics include majority rule, types of voting methods, apportionment and proportional representation, agenda manipulation, coalition formation, voting power, political consequences of electoral laws.
SOC SCI 121T.restriction: Restriction: Business Economics Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

SOC SCI 132.name: Veterans in History and Society
SOC SCI 132.description: Explores key concepts, issues, and trends in the interdisciplinary field of veterans studies. Students gain a deep understanding of the ways that social scientists and historians have analyzed the identities, experiences, and worldviews of U.S. military veterans.

SOC SCI 133.name: Veterans’ Transitions
SOC SCI 133.description: Provides veteran and non-veteran students with a comprehensive and academically rigorous overview of the ways and means through which diverse communities of veterans have made and continue to make the complex and multi-faceted transition from active military.

SOC SCI 134W.name: Veterans’ Voices
SOC SCI 134W.description: Uses the medium of academic writing to develop a broad understanding and appreciation for the wide range of worldviews, priorities, and values embodied in the creative production and activism of diverse U.S. military veterans.

SOC SCI 152A.name: Non-Government Organization (NGO) Fundamentals
SOC SCI 152A.description: Introduction to non-governmental organizations, including their role in U.S. society and the international community. Explores varying definitions of NGOs and the characteristics held in common by all NGOs.

SOC SCI 152C.name: American Public Policy
SOC SCI 152C.description: Focuses on the development and implementation of public policy in the United States. Lectures cover theoretical models of the policy process as well as significant problems facing contemporary American decision-makers.

SOC SCI 163A.name: Urban America
SOC SCI 163A.description: Students examine the historical, social, political, and economic factors that contributed to the construction of the American urban context, one that is poverty concentrated and racially/ethnically segregated. Students also critically assess the consequence of growing up in America's urban neighborhoods.

SOC SCI 164.name: Chicanx/Latinx Education
SOC SCI 164.description: Provides a historical and empirical overview of educational issues affecting diverse Latinx low-income, immigrant, and U.S. born student populations enrolled in American schools. Examines policies and issues such as DACA, generation, culture, racism, and gender on educational mobility.

SOC SCI 164B.name: Domestic Gangs
SOC SCI 164B.description: Examines the history and development of California street gangs and the role of historical events in that development. Students will be able to contrast and compare gang cohort behaviors between some of the major gangs in California.
SOC SCI 164B.restriction: Restriction: School of Social Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment.

SOC SCI 164C.name: Prison Gangs
SOC SCI 164C.description: Examines the growth and spread of prison gangs throughout the country. Relationships between prison and street gangs, and possible relationships with foreign drug trafficking organizations studied. Violence examined as the standard to establish dominance in and out of prison.
SOC SCI 164C.restriction: Restriction: School of Social Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment.

SOC SCI 164D.name: Juvenile Gangs
SOC SCI 164D.description: Examines risk factors that can be used to predict gang membership. Compares generational with non-generational gangs and develops a working sociological definition that can be used to identify street gangs. Myths about juveniles, street gangs.
SOC SCI 164D.restriction: Restriction: School of Social Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment.

SOC SCI 165.name: Chicano/Latino Families
SOC SCI 165.description: Introduction to the research, literature, and issues surrounding the topic of Chicano/Latino families including cultural history, contemporary issues, organization of family, traditions, lifestyles, values, beliefs, generational differences, gender issues, ethnic identity, evolution of demographic patterns, current economic and political standings.

SOC SCI 168B.name: Immigration and Inequality
SOC SCI 168B.description: Explores immigration, ethnicity, and inequality as interconnected social forces. International migration, propelled by global inequalities, plays a central role in the formation of multinational societies, shapes inter-group relations and patterns of ethnic inequality, and transforms the immigrants themselves.

SOC SCI 170A.name: Research Methods in the Social Sciences
SOC SCI 170A.description: Examines how interdisciplinary social science research questions are formulated and studies several research methods including: experimental method, quasi-experimental methods, survey research, field research, evaluation research, and meta-analysis. Parametric and non-parametric statistical methods are illustrated using the SPSS program.
SOC SCI 170A.prereqString: Prerequisite: SOC SCI 1A and SOC SCI 2A and SOC SCI 3A and (SOC SCI 10A or STATS 7)
SOC SCI 170A.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. School of Social Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment.

SOC SCI 172AW.name: American Culture
SOC SCI 172AW.description: A survey of the historical development of dominant American culture and society
SOC SCI 172AW.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
SOC SCI 172AW.restriction: Restriction: School of Social Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment.

SOC SCI 172D.name: Law in the Twenty-First Century
SOC SCI 172D.description: Examines the complex relationship between law, the social sciences, and modern society.  Lectures explore such issues as the interplay between technology and constitutional rights, the impact of science on law, and the evolving roles of attorneys and judges.
SOC SCI 172D.restriction: Restriction: Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

SOC SCI 173L.name: Latinos in a Global Society
SOC SCI 173L.description: Examines interconnections between diverse Latino groups in the U.S. and the effects of globalization on their social, cultural, and political realities. Topics include immigration, demographics, socioeconomic differentiation, familial relations, political protest/resistance, law and policy, and links to "homeland" issues.

SOC SCI 173N.name: Revolution in Latin America
SOC SCI 173N.description: Presents a comparative analysis of the causes, development, and consequences of selected revolutionary movements, focusing on outbreaks in Mexico, Bolivia, Cuba, Chile, Nicaragua, and Grenada.  Explores topics of state formation, economic nationalism, social justice, ethnicity, and role of international affairs.

SOC SCI 177B.name: Asian American Women
SOC SCI 177B.description: Examines the representations and experiences of Asian American women from diverse perspectives. Explores the commonalities and differences among various groups of Asian American women, with particular focus on history, culture, values, and family roles.

SOC SCI 178C.name: Korean American Studies
SOC SCI 178C.description: Explores the factors that have distinctly shaped the Korean American experience, including patterns of racial domination, the profile of immigrant flow, immigrant roles in the urban political economy, politics in Korea, and the role of the church.

SOC SCI 178D.name: Vietnamese American Studies
SOC SCI 178D.description: Studies the resettlement of Vietnamese in the United States following their exodus from Southeast Asia. Topics include the Vietnam War, the 1975 evacuation, boat and land refugees, the shaping of Vietnamese communities, and Vietnamese American literature.

SOC SCI 178E.name: Japanese American Studies
SOC SCI 178E.description: Studies the settlement of Japanese in Hawaii and the continental United States since the late 19th century. Topics include sugar plantations, development of rural Japanese America, World War II internment, post-War community development, and persistence of Japanese American identity.

SOC SCI 178F.name: South Asian American Studies
SOC SCI 178F.description: Examines and compares the experiences of South Asian immigrants in the U.S. over time. Looks at the economic, political, and social positions of the immigrants, with special emphasis on religious changes and the changes in the second and later generations.
SOC SCI 178F.restriction: Restriction: Asian American Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Policy/Public Service Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

SOC SCI 178H.name: Southeast Asian American Studies
SOC SCI 178H.description: Analyzes experiences of refugees and immigrants from Southeast Asia, which may include those from Cambodia, Laos, Vietnam, and the Philippines. Examines political and economic factors for their exodus and how they reconstruct their identities, histories, and communities.

SOC SCI 178J.name: Chinese American Studies
SOC SCI 178J.description: Analyzes the experiences of Chinese in the United States. Immigration, Chinese exclusion, racial and gender identity. Historical overview and contemporary issues covered.

SOC SCI 178K.name: Filipina/Filipino American Studies
SOC SCI 178K.description: Explores the experience of Filipina/Filipino Americans from the era of Spanish colonization of the Philippines to present-day community formations in the United States, with special emphasis on the 20th century. Topics include colonialism, nation, migration, gender, and culture.

SOC SCI 179.name: Special Topics in Asian American Studies
SOC SCI 179.description: Studies in selected areas of Asian American Studies. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

SOC SCI 181A.name: Ethical Leadership
SOC SCI 181A.description: Explores historical and contemporary theories of ethical and unethical leadership.  Examines models of "good leadership" such as cardinal and monastic virtues
SOC SCI 181A.restriction: Restriction: School of Social Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment.

SOC SCI 183A.name: Global and International Studies Forum
SOC SCI 183A.description: A faculty-student forum featuring lectures from a variety of institutions with discussion issues related to Global and International Studies.

SOC SCI 183B.name: Seminar in Mediation
SOC SCI 183B.description: Student develop mediation skills and refine knowledge in the practice and theory of conflict resolution. Students who complete this course may serve as mediators in the Campus Mediation Program. Course is a prerequisite to completing Indep Study as an intern.
SOC SCI 183B.restriction: Restriction: International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment. School of Humanities students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Social Ecology students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Social Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment.

SOC SCI 183CW.name: Seminar Conflict Resolution
SOC SCI 183CW.description: Designed for seniors who are pursuing the minor in Conflict Resolution and/or International Studies major. Provides a forum in which students will refine skills and theory in the study of cooperation and conflict, from local to global arenas.
SOC SCI 183CW.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

SOC SCI 183E.name: Conflict Resolution in Cross-Cultural Perspective
SOC SCI 183E.description: Examines theories of conflict management. Analyzes how conflict is mitigated in diverse cultures: at the interpersonal level, between groups, and on the international scale. Students discuss readings, hear from conflict management practitioners, and simulate negotiations.

SOC SCI 184A.name: Sage Leader Research I
SOC SCI 184A.description: Participants in the SAGE Scholars Program learn to define leadership concepts, discover various leadership styles, and develop strong leadership and communication skills resulting in strengthened ability to contribute to and interact with UCI and the Orange County community.
SOC SCI 184A.restriction: Restriction: SAGE Scholars Program students only.

SOC SCI 184B.name: Sage Leader Research II
SOC SCI 184B.description: Provides a survey of contemporary topics and challenges in the fields of management and leadership. Case studies and text by leading authors are used to analyze key leadership issues in twenty-first century, with particular emphasis on current events.
SOC SCI 184B.restriction: Restriction: SAGE Scholars Program students only.

SOC SCI 184GW.name: Media Writing
SOC SCI 184GW.description: Designed to teach reporting and news writing basics.  Students learn how to gather and organize information, ask effective questions, develop story ideas, research facts, and write stories on deadline.
SOC SCI 184GW.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
SOC SCI 184GW.restriction: Restriction: International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

SOC SCI 185W.name: People in Society
SOC SCI 185W.description: Through readings about people in distinctly different societies throughout history, students learn concepts that cross the boundaries of the social science disciplines. Such themes as democracy, elitism, power, social class, and gender are the basis for discussion and writing.
SOC SCI 185W.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
SOC SCI 185W.restriction: Restriction: School of Social Sciences students only.

SOC SCI 187.name: Twenty-First-Century Graduate Education
SOC SCI 187.description: Graduate and professional education in twenty-first century United States. Examines  strategies for admission to postbaccalaureate programs and success in graduate study culture. Introduction to processes including planning and preparation, school selection, entrance examination preparation, submission of applications, writing personal statements.

SOC SCI 188A.name: Introduction to Contemporary Middle East Politics
SOC SCI 188A.description: An overview of basic issues that shape the politics of the Middle East and North Africa. Themes include implication of the colonization era, nation-state formation, inter-Arab relations, nationalism, Arab-Israel conflict, Islamic resurgence, and more.

SOC SCI 188K.name: Political Islam
SOC SCI 188K.description: Political Islamd is a diverse phenomenon. While noticeable barriers exist to "Islamist democracy," it is the Islamists who will define the political future of much of the Muslim world. Reviews the experience of Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Pakistan, Turkey, and Indonesia.

SOC SCI 189.name: Special Topics in Social Sciences
SOC SCI 189.description: Studies in selected areas of social sciences. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
SOC SCI 189.restriction: Restriction: School of Social Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment.

SOC SCI H190A.name: Honors Research Workshop
SOC SCI H190A.description: Student develops a 10–15-page prospectus of research for the honors thesis which includes: the research question, literature review, methods of investigation, and bibliography. Student selects a faculty mentor who will supervise thesis research and writing in winter and spring.
SOC SCI H190A.restriction: Restriction: Social Science Majors only. Social Policy/Public Service Majors only. Social Science Honors students only.

SOC SCI H190B.name: Honors Thesis Research
SOC SCI H190B.description: The student initiates and completes data collection for the honors thesis. A faculty mentor provides supervision and feedback on thesis chapters.
SOC SCI H190B.prereqString: Prerequisite: SOC SCI H190A or SPPS H190A

SOC SCI H190C.name: Honors Thesis
SOC SCI H190C.description: The student completes, with the approval of the faculty mentor, an honors thesis containing: statement of the problem, literature review, research hypotheses, methods of investigation, results, discussion, and bibliography.
SOC SCI H190C.prereqString: Prerequisite: SOC SCI H190B or SPPS H190B. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

SOC SCI 191.name: Graduate-Mentored Study in the Social Sciences
SOC SCI 191.description: Offers a hands-on research experience while increasing awareness of the various disciplines in the social sciences and of the requirements of graduate school.  Features graduate-mentored study under the supervision of the Associate Dean.
SOC SCI 191.prereqString: Prerequisite: Identification of a graduate student (who is in good standing) as a mentor.

SOC SCI 193A.name: Field Studies in Social Policy and Public Service
SOC SCI 193A.description: Advanced training in qualitative and ethnographic research centered on community service. Students pursue field studies at nonprofit agencies (200 hours) to understand current social problems in underrepresented and underserved communities. Through field placement, students apply theory to practice.
SOC SCI 193A.prereqString: Prerequisite: SOC SCI 70C or SOCIOL 63. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
SOC SCI 193A.restriction: Restriction: Social Policy/Public Service Majors only.

SOC SCI 193B.name: Field Studies in Social Policy and Public Service
SOC SCI 193B.description: Advanced training in qualitative and ethnographic research centered on community service. Students pursue field studies at nonprofit agencies (200 hours) to understand current social problems in underrepresented and underserved communities. Through field placement, students apply theory to practice.

SOC SCI 193C.name: Field Studies in Social Policy and Public Service
SOC SCI 193C.description: Advanced training in qualitative and ethnographic research centered on community service. Students pursue field studies at nonprofit agencies (200 hours) to understand current social problems in underrepresented and underserved communities. Through field placement, students apply theory to practice.

SOC SCI 193CW.name: Field Studies in Social Policy and Public Service
SOC SCI 193CW.description: Advanced training in qualitative and ethnographic research centered on community service. Students pursue field studies at nonprofit agencies (200 hours) to understand current social problems in underrepresented and under-served communities. Through field placement, students apply theory to practice.

SOC SCI 194A.name: Public Service Internship
SOC SCI 194A.description: Introduces the role of etiquette and leadership in the professional environment. With a two-unit (50 hours) or four-unit (100 hours) credit option, students intern at a nonprofit agency exploring their roles as community leaders and improving their professional skills.
SOC SCI 194A.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
SOC SCI 194A.restriction: Restriction: Social Policy/Public Service Majors only.

SOC SCI 194C.name: Management and Leadership Practicum-Social Science
SOC SCI 194C.description: Social Sciences Academic Resource Center (SSARC) Resource Mangers (RMs) report directly to the Director and Associate Director, serving as frontline resource consultants, assisting visitors with resume development, graduate and professional school planning, internship placement, and professional development.

SOC SCI 195A.name: Educational Policy Field Studies
SOC SCI 195A.description: Integrates academic course work with experiential learning

SOC SCI 195B.name: Educational Policy Field Studies
SOC SCI 195B.description: Integrates academic course work with experiential learning

SOC SCI 195C.name: Educational Policy Field Studies
SOC SCI 195C.description: Integrates academic course work with experiential learning

SOC SCI 196.name: Global Connect
SOC SCI 196.description: Identifies factors of change that influence the twenty-first century. Students serve as mentors at high schools to introduce globalization issues through workshops and lectures. Students must submit an application and have a 3.0 or higher overall GPA.

SOC SCI 197.name: Professional Internship
SOC SCI 197.description: Students apply classroom knowledge through research projects in nonprofit agencies (local, state, and government) and the private sector. They pose solutions to agency-posed questions. Students gain field experience through 50 hours (for 2 units) or 100 (for 4 units).
SOC SCI 197.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
SOC SCI 197.restriction: Restriction: School of Social Sciences students only.

SOC SCI 198.name: Directed Group Study
SOC SCI 198.description: Directed study with Social Science faculty.

SOC SCI 199.name: Individual Study
SOC SCI 199.description: Opportunities to do research and learn new skills outside the normal classroom environment. Students participate in planned research and study activities under a written contract with a supervising UCI instructor. Students may enroll for only one 199 each quarter.

SOC SCI 211A.name: Mathematical Behavioral Sciences Colloquium
SOC SCI 211A.description: Weekly reports and colloquia by faculty, students, and visitors.

SOC SCI 211B.name: Mathematical Behavioral Sciences Colloquium
SOC SCI 211B.description: Weekly reports and colloquia by faculty, students, and visitors.

SOC SCI 211C.name: Mathematical Behavioral Sciences Colloquium
SOC SCI 211C.description: Weekly reports and colloquia by faculty, students, and visitors.

SOC SCI 253K.name: Race and Justice Studies Writing Seminar
SOC SCI 253K.description: A required writing-intensive seminar conducted by an instructor affiliated with the Race and Justice Studies emphasis. Students with manuscripts on relevant topics will read and critique peer manuscripts, and revise manuscripts toward completion of articles, dissertation chapters, and other publications.

SOC SCI 254A.name: Transnational Migration
SOC SCI 254A.description: Examines borders and boundaries as material and semiotic constructs. Drawing upon an array of literatures, but loosely situated in U.S. geo/biopolitics, explores transformative troublings of places, spaces, borders, and bodies of all sorts.

SOC SCI 272A.name: Origin and Evolution of Marxist Social Thought
SOC SCI 272A.description: Focuses on the genesis and evolution of Marxist social thought The "systemic" method of Marx and Engels to questions of economic production and reproduction is compared and contrasted with modern world-system grand visions, feminist-theoretic approaches, and postmodern critiques.
SOC SCI 272A.prereqString: Prerequisite: Undergraduate course in political theory or equivalent.

SOC SCI 290.name: Dissertation Research
SOC SCI 290.description: Dissertation research with Social Science faculty.

SOC SCI 299.name: Independent Study
SOC SCI 299.description: Independent research with Social Science faculty.

SOCECOL 1.name: Introduction to Social Ecology
SOCECOL 1.description: Introduction to the ecological paradigm through a consideration of the classic and recent works in human, cultural, and social ecology. Emphasis on the use of the ecological paradigm as an aid in analyzing societal problems and prescribing for their amelioration.

SOCECOL 10.name: Research Design
SOCECOL 10.description: An introduction to the logic behind and methods of designing and conducting research studies in Social Ecology. Topics include how to measure variables of interest, identifying causal relationships, sampling, survey research methods, experiments, quasi-experimental designs, and ethics in research.
SOCECOL 10.restriction: Restriction: School of Social Ecology students only. Environmental Science and Policy Majors only.

SOCECOL 13.name: Statistical Analysis in Social Ecology
SOCECOL 13.description: Introduction to the techniques of statistical analysis in Social Ecology. Topics include probability, statistical inference, significance testing, univariate descriptive statistics, and multivariate analysis from an interdisciplinary perspective.
SOCECOL 13.restriction: Restriction: School of Social Ecology students have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Science and Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment. No credit for SOCECOL 13 if taken concurrently with or after PSYCH 10A, SOCIOL 10A, POL SCI 10A, SOC SCI 10A, STATS 7, STATS 8, STATS 67, EDUC 15

SOCECOL H20A.name: Honors: Critical Issues on the Social Sciences
SOCECOL H20A.description: Major themes, methods, and works in the social sciences from an interdisciplinary perspective. Each quarter focuses on a different topic. Weekly seminars emphasizing development of critical thinking skills and quantitative analysis through written work are integral to the course.
SOCECOL H20A.restriction: Restriction: Campuswide Honors Collegium students only.

SOCECOL H20B.name: Honors: Critical Issues on the Social Sciences
SOCECOL H20B.description: Major themes, methods, and works in the social sciences from an interdisciplinary perspective. Each quarter focuses on a different topic. Weekly seminars emphasizing development of critical thinking skills and quantitative analysis through written work are integral to the course.
SOCECOL H20B.prereqString: Prerequisite: SOC SCI H1E or SOCECOL H20A
SOCECOL H20B.restriction: Restriction: Campuswide Honors Collegium students only.

SOCECOL H20C.name: Honors: Critical Issues on the Social Sciences
SOCECOL H20C.description: Major themes, methods, and works in the social sciences from an interdisciplinary perspective. Each quarter focuses on a different topic. Weekly seminars emphasizing development of critical thinking skills and quantitative analysis through written work are integral to the course.
SOCECOL H20C.prereqString: Prerequisite: SOC SCI H1F or SOCECOL H20B
SOCECOL H20C.restriction: Restriction: Campuswide Honors Collegium students only.

SOCECOL 74A.name: Moral Development and Just Communities
SOCECOL 74A.description: A three-quarter sequence exploring interpersonal, personal, and social issues based on principles of fairness and justice. Both the living environment of a University residence hall and selected institutions of society are analyzed in terms of moral development theory.

SOCECOL 74B.name: Moral Development and Just Communities
SOCECOL 74B.description: A three-quarter sequence exploring interpersonal, personal, and social issues based on principles of fairness and justice. Both the living environment of a University residence hall and selected institutions of society are analyzed in terms of moral development theory.

SOCECOL 74C.name: Moral Development and Just Communities
SOCECOL 74C.description: A three-quarter sequence exploring interpersonal, personal, and social issues based on principles of fairness and justice. Both the living environment of a University residence hall and selected institutions of society are analyzed in terms of moral development theory.

SOCECOL 100.name: Special Topics in Social Ecology
SOCECOL 100.description: Special topics courses are offered from time to time. In general they will focus on a topic from interdisciplinary perspectives. Course content varies with the interest of the instructor.
SOCECOL 100.restriction: Restriction: School of Social Ecology students only.

SOCECOL 104W.name: Community Archiving in Social Ecology
SOCECOL 104W.description: Students are trained in community archiving, oral history, and ethnography in order to produce material for submission to a student-initiated Social Ecology community archive housed in the UC Irvine Special Collections section of the UC Irvine libraries.
SOCECOL 104W.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement. Field Study authorization required for enrollment.
SOCECOL 104W.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. School of Social Ecology students only.

SOCECOL 106W.name: Building, Analyzing, and Sustaining a Digital Media Archive
SOCECOL 106W.description: Students are trained in contributing to and managing a digital media archive. Provided an opportunity to use resources in the archive to develop policy proposals to solve real-world problems at the intersection of crime, law, and society.
SOCECOL 106W.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement. Authorization for field study.
SOCECOL 106W.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. School of Social Ecology students have first consideration for enrollment.

SOCECOL 111W.name: Advanced Research Methods
SOCECOL 111W.description: For students planning to conduct senior research projects or apply to graduate school in social research fields. Topics include reviewing literature, preparing a research proposal, protecting human subjects, citing scholarly work, building measures, estimating sample size, interview and presentation skills.
SOCECOL 111W.prereqString: Prerequisite: SOCECOL 10 and SOCECOL 13. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

SOCECOL 118.name: Domestic Violence
SOCECOL 118.description: General perspectives about domestic violence and theoretical accounts about what causes such behavior.
SOCECOL 118.restriction: Restriction: Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

SOCECOL 119.name: Violence in Intimate Relationships
SOCECOL 119.description: Responses to various forms of domestic violence, such as intimate partner violence and child abuse. Covers barriers to reporting to the police, and prosecutors and courts. Human services, such as safety planning for victims, treatment programs, and restorative justice approaches.

SOCECOL E127.name: Nuclear Environments
SOCECOL E127.description: Understanding the impact of the nuclear age on the environment and human health through interrelated developments of nuclear power and nuclear weapons. The early years of weapon development, catastrophic environmental pollution, perils of nuclear power in the U.S. and Russia.

SOCECOL 183A.name: Global and International Studies Forum
SOCECOL 183A.description: A faculty-student forum featuring lectures from a variety of institutions with discussion issues related to Global and International Studies.

SOCECOL 183B.name: Seminar in Mediation
SOCECOL 183B.description: Student develop mediation skills and refine knowledge in the practice and theory of conflict resolution. Students who complete this course may serve as mediators in the Campus Mediation Program. Course is a prerequisite to completing Indep Study as an intern.
SOCECOL 183B.restriction: Restriction: International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment. School of Humanities students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Social Ecology students have first consideration for enrollment. School of Social Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment.

SOCECOL 183CW.name: Seminar Conflict Resolution
SOCECOL 183CW.description: Designed for seniors who are pursuing the minor in Conflict Resolution and/or International Studies major. Provides a forum in which students will refine skills and theory in the study of cooperation and conflict, from local to global arenas.
SOCECOL 183CW.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

SOCECOL 186A.name: Senior Seminar on Global Sustainability I
SOCECOL 186A.description: Students attend weekly seminar to discuss current issues in global sustainability. Weekly attendance at Global Sustainability Forum is also required. Seminar utilized to analyze forum presentations.  Prepare bibliography.
SOCECOL 186A.restriction: Restriction: Seniors only. Global Sustainability Minors have first consideration for enrollment.

SOCECOL 186B.name: Senior Seminar on Global Sustainability II
SOCECOL 186B.description: Students attend weekly seminar to discuss current issues in global sustainability. Weekly attendance at Global Sustainability Forum is also required. Seminar utilized to analyze forum presentations.  Prepare research proposal.
SOCECOL 186B.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI 191A or SOCECOL 186A or EARTHSS 190A

SOCECOL 186CW.name: Writing/Senior Seminar on Global Sustainability III
SOCECOL 186CW.description: Students attend weekly seminar to discuss current issues in global sustainability.  Weekly attendance at Global Sustainability Forum also is required.  Seminar utilized to analyze Forum presentations and to prepare senior research paper.  Prepare/write research paper under direction of faculty member.
SOCECOL 186CW.prereqString: Prerequisite: BIO SCI 191B or EARTHSS 190B or SOCECOL 186B. BIO SCI 191B or EARTHSS 190B or SOCECOL 186B. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

SOCECOL 189.name: Global Service Scholars Advanced Seminar
SOCECOL 189.description: For students who are accepted into the Global Service Scholars Program. Provides advanced training in empathy and compassion, and prepares students for their summer international field experience.

SOCECOL 190.name: Applied Statistics in Social and Behavioral Research
SOCECOL 190.description: Covers statistical techniques used to describe and make generalizations about phenomena represented by data. Hands-on experience in data analysis and interpretation using statistical software (SPSS, STATA) is emphasized. Topics include data visualization, ANOVA, multiple regression, and categorical data analyses.
SOCECOL 190.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Urban Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

SOCECOL H190A.name: Honors Research
SOCECOL H190A.description: Independent work on an individual research project in addition to participation in a mini proseminar in which faculty discuss their ongoing research.  Students prepare a written proposal for a research project.

SOCECOL H190B.name: Honors Research
SOCECOL H190B.description: Independent work on an individual research project in a addition to participation in a mini proseminar in which faculty discuss their ongoing research. Students prepare a  written proposal for a research project.

SOCECOL H190W.name: Honors Research
SOCECOL H190W.description: Students write up their honors research project (H190A-B) and prepare an oral report which is presented at the honors seminar.
SOCECOL H190W.prereqString: Prerequisite: SOCECOL H190B. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

SOCECOL 194W.name: Naturalistic Field Research
SOCECOL 194W.description: Introduction to alternative models of experiential learning and to various methods of observation, assessment, and evaluation. Introduction to the nature of organizations and ethical issues that emerge from research and intervention in natural settings.
SOCECOL 194W.prereqString: Prerequisite: SOCECOL 10. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
SOCECOL 194W.restriction: Restriction: School of Social Ecology students only.

SOCECOL 195.name: Field Study
SOCECOL 195.description: Community engagement to facilitate civic education through field research experience, social intervention, and professionalization. Small group instruction, discussion, writing, and presentations synthesizing students’ experiences in the field with theory, paradigms, and ideas learned about in their course work.
SOCECOL 195.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. School of Social Ecology students only.

SOCECOL 195A.name: Advanced Field Study
SOCECOL 195A.description: While completing 10 hours of field work per week, students become acquainted with the goals and activities of their placement and will work closely with the placement supervisor and AFS instructor to identify the scope of a research project.
SOCECOL 195A.prereqString: Prerequisite: SOCECOL 10 and SOCECOL 13. Acceptance to Advanced Field Study required.
SOCECOL 195A.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. School of Social Ecology students only.

SOCECOL 195B.name: Advanced Field Study
SOCECOL 195B.description: While completing 10 hours of field work per week, students implement their research project through data collection and observations which allow them to reflect on, apply, and synthesize their academic training through observations and experiences at the placement.
SOCECOL 195B.prereqString: Prerequisite: SOCECOL 195A. Acceptance to Advanced Field Study required.
SOCECOL 195B.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. School of Social Ecology students only.

SOCECOL 195CW.name: Advanced Field Study
SOCECOL 195CW.description: While completing 10 hours per week of field work, students write and finalize their AFS Client Project in consultation with the placement and the FS instructor, and make a final written and oral presentation to the placement and invited guests.
SOCECOL 195CW.prereqString: Prerequisite: SOCECOL 195B. Acceptance to Advanced Field Study required. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
SOCECOL 195CW.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. School of Social Ecology students only.

SOCECOL 195W.name: Field Study Writing Seminar
