SOCECOL 195W.description: Community engagement to promote civic education through field research experience, and the opportunity to study social issues and the environments where they occur. Develop discipline-specific writing and communication skills, methodology, and integrate information from multiple sources.   Course may be offered online.
SOCECOL 195W.prereqString: Prerequisite: SOCECOL 10. Cumulative UC GPA of 2.0. Authorization is required. Successful completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
SOCECOL 195W.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. Environmental Science and Policy Majors only. Psychological Science Majors only. Criminology, Law and Society Majors only. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors only. Social Ecology Majors only. Urban Studies Majors only.

SOCECOL 198.name: Directed Studies
SOCECOL 198.description: Directed study with Social Ecology faculty.

SOCECOL 199.name: Special Studies
SOCECOL 199.description: Special Studies with Social Ecology faculty.

SOCECOL 200.name: Seminar in Social Ecology
SOCECOL 200.description: Students are introduced to the classic and contemporary literature of human and social ecology and are expected to use the ecological paradigm to analyze social phenomena of interest to the differing subprograms.

SOCECOL 264A.name: Data Analysis
SOCECOL 264A.description: Provides an appreciation and understanding of statistics necessary to conduct applied research. Topics include approaches to and presentation of data, robust statistics, standardization techniques, multivariate regression, and analysis of variance.

SOCECOL 264B.name: Data Analysis
SOCECOL 264B.description: Provides an appreciation and understanding of statistics necessary to conduct applied research. Topics include approaches to and presentation of data, robust statistics, standardization techniques, multivariate regression, and analysis of variance.

SOCECOL 266D.name: Analysis of Survival Data
SOCECOL 266D.description: Provides an introduction to survival analysis methods for the analysis of change in discrete dependent variables. Focuses on data collection strategies for obtaining longitudinal data and continuous-time hazards models. Communicates the variety and power of multivariate hazard models.

SOCECOL 272A.name: Structural Equation Modeling I
SOCECOL 272A.description: The general structural equation model is developed including path models, recursive and nonrecursive structural models, multiple indicator models, and confirmatory factor models. Use of LISREL and other software for estimating model parameters is covered.

SOCECOL 272B.name: Structural Equation Modeling II: Longitudinal and Advanced Topics
SOCECOL 272B.description: Provides hands-on experience with longitudinal and advanced structural equation models and is of interest to students from a range of disciplines. Topics covered include confirmatory factor, latent growth curve, general growth mixture, and multi-level modeling.

SOCECOL 275.name: Special Topics in Social Ecology
SOCECOL 275.description: Topics covered vary with interests of the instructor.

SOCECOL 291.name: Program Evaluation
SOCECOL 291.description: Students are introduced to the use of research techniques and statistical methods in assessing the effectiveness of social programs. Different evaluative models are discussed using examples of actual program evaluations.

SOCECOL 295.name: Masters Thesis Research & Writing
SOCECOL 295.description: Independent research with Social Ecology faculty.

SOCECOL 296.name: Doctoral Dissertation Research & Writing
SOCECOL 296.description: Dissertation research with Social Ecology faculty.

SOCECOL 298.name: Directed Studies
SOCECOL 298.description: Directed study with Social Ecology faculty.

SOCECOL 299.name: Independent Study
SOCECOL 299.description: Independent study with Social Ecology faculty.

SOCIOL 1.name: Introduction to Sociology
SOCIOL 1.description: Considers major sociological concepts, theories, and research findings illuminating processes of interpersonal interaction, social differentiation and stratification, integration and conflict, and change, with attention to variation in class, race/ethnic, gender, multicultural, and cross-national perspectives and experiences.

SOCIOL 2.name: Globalization and Transnational Sociology
SOCIOL 2.description: Examines globalization and international issues from the perspective of sociology and related fields. Issues include economic globalization and global inequality, international environmental problems, international politics, trends in global culture, and global conflict.

SOCIOL 3.name: Social Problems
SOCIOL 3.description: Focuses on how institutional and organizational features of societies generate problems for people. Particular attention directed at a set of problems related to political and economic inequality: poverty, racism, sexism, urban and population problems, the environment, the criminal justice system.

SOCIOL 10A.name: Probability and Statistics
SOCIOL 10A.description: An introduction to probability and statistics. Emphasis on a thorough understanding of the probabilistic basis of statistical inference. Emphasizes examples from sociology, anthropology, and related social science disciplines.
SOCIOL 10A.restriction: Restriction: Anthropology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Sociology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

SOCIOL 10B.name: Probability and Statistics
SOCIOL 10B.description: An introduction to probability and statistics. Emphasis on a thorough understanding of the probabilistic basis of statistical inference. Emphasizes examples from sociology, anthropology, and related social science disciplines.
SOCIOL 10B.restriction: Restriction: Anthropology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Sociology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

SOCIOL 10C.name: Probability and Statistics
SOCIOL 10C.description: An introduction to probability and statistics. Emphasis on a thorough understanding of the probabilistic basis of statistical inference. Emphasizes examples from sociology, anthropology, and related social science disciplines.
SOCIOL 10C.restriction: Restriction: Anthropology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Sociology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

SOCIOL 19.name: Special Topics: Methods
SOCIOL 19.description: Studies in selected areas of methods. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

SOCIOL 29.name: Special Topics: Theory
SOCIOL 29.description: Studies in selected areas of theory. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

SOCIOL 31.name: Self-Identity and Society
SOCIOL 31.description: Studies sociological contributions to theory and research in social psychology, with focus on the social influences on personality, attitudes, beliefs, and behavior

SOCIOL 39.name: Special Topics: Social Psychology
SOCIOL 39.description: Studies in selected areas of social psychology. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

SOCIOL 41.name: Small Group Dynamics
SOCIOL 41.description: Deals with models for understanding behavior in small groups, including coalition formation, socialization, group norms and decision rules, leadership, conformity, group structure, and communication processes.
SOCIOL 41.restriction: Restriction: Sociology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

SOCIOL 43.name: City and Community
SOCIOL 43.description: Examines nature, causes, and consequences of urbanization along with changing scale and complexity, demographic/ecological city growth patterns, quality of life in urban areas, processes of decision-making, and bearing of sociological investigation on public policy concerns in contemporary urban society.

SOCIOL 44.name: Births, Deaths, and Migration
SOCIOL 44.description: Introduction to the analysis of human population including fertility, mortality dispersion, sex distribution. Attention is focused on the effects of these variables on, e.g., over-population, social disorganization, and the stability of social institutions.

SOCIOL 49.name: Special Topics: Structures
SOCIOL 49.description: Studies in selected areas of structures. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

SOCIOL 51.name: Asian American Family & Community
SOCIOL 51.description: Briefly examines the history of different Asian American groups and provides an in-depth analysis of issues related to family composition, mate selection, changing gender roles, and intergenerational conflict.

SOCIOL 56.name: Religion and Society
SOCIOL 56.description: A critical and personal examination of the varieties of religious and spiritual experiences human beings are undergoing in contemporary society. The role of conscious understanding and unconscious conditioning regarding religion and spirituality.
SOCIOL 56.restriction: Restriction: Sociology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

SOCIOL 59.name: Special Topics: Social Institutions and Culture
SOCIOL 59.description: Studies in selected areas of social institutions and culture. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

SOCIOL 62.name: Families and Intimate Relations
SOCIOL 62.description: Sociological theories/research on marriage, kinship, intimacy, and divorce. Emphasis on comparing family patterns in different social classes, ethnic groups, and societies, and on relating family life to the economy and other social institutions. Topics include gender roles, child-rearing, historical change.  Materials fee.

SOCIOL 63.name: Race and Ethnicity
SOCIOL 63.description: Focuses on racial and ethnic relations in the United States and compares them with those found in other societies. Analyzes the conditions that favor either cooperation and integration or rivalry, tension, and conflict. Appraises strategies for reducing and resolving conflicts.

SOCIOL 64.name: Sociology of Sexuality
SOCIOL 64.description: Provides an introduction to and overview of the sociology of sex and sexuality. Considers the social meanings of sex and sexuality, the social contexts of sex and sexuality, and the social regulations of sex and sexuality.

SOCIOL 68.name: Gender and Race Inequality in the Workplace
SOCIOL 68.description: Analysis of current state and trends in major inequality measures including the wage gap, occupational segregation, and access to managerial positions. Theories that purport to explain such differences, and the related empirical evidence, are also covered.

SOCIOL 68A.name: Ethnic and Immigrant America
SOCIOL 68A.description: Focusing on Asian, Latino, and Black immigrant groups, examines the second generation's experience of straddling two cultures and growing up American. Covers topics such as assimilation, bilingualism, race relations, education, bicultural conflicts, interracial marriage, and multiracial identities.

SOCIOL 69.name: Special Topics: Age, Gender, Race, and Ethnicity
SOCIOL 69.description: Studies in selected areas of age, gender, race, and ethnicity. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

SOCIOL 79.name: Special Topics: Societies and Social Inequality
SOCIOL 79.description: Studies in selected areas of societies and social inequality. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

SOCIOL 110.name: Research Methods
SOCIOL 110.description: Methods of data collection and analysis used by sociologists. Experimental methods, surveys, and interviews, field research and participant observation, demographic methods, historical and comparative approaches.
SOCIOL 110.restriction: Restriction: Sociology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

SOCIOL 119.name: Special Topics: Methods
SOCIOL 119.description: Studies in selected areas of methods. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
SOCIOL 119.restriction: Restriction: Sociology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

SOCIOL 120.name: Sociological Theory
SOCIOL 120.description: What a theory of society is and is not. Historical and contemporary models, perspectives, and schools.
SOCIOL 120.restriction: Restriction: Sociology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

SOCIOL 120W.name: Sociological Theory
SOCIOL 120W.description: What a theory of society is and is not. Historical and contemporary models, perspectives, and schools.
SOCIOL 120W.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
SOCIOL 120W.restriction: Restriction: Sociology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

SOCIOL 129.name: Special Topics: Theory
SOCIOL 129.description: Studies in selected areas of theory. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
SOCIOL 129.restriction: Restriction: Sociology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

SOCIOL 134.name: Game Theory and Politics I
SOCIOL 134.description: Introduction to game theory and a survey of its political applications. Examples of topics covered include voting in small committees, legislatures, and mass elections
SOCIOL 134.restriction: Restriction: Social Policy/Public Service Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Sociology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

SOCIOL 135.name: Social Psychology of Networks
SOCIOL 135.description: Review of network methods used in small group and organizational research. Discussion of social psychological literature relevant to the network of study of cognitive social structure, exchange/communication, identity negotiation, and social control. Case study of network datasets exemplifies research issues.
SOCIOL 135.restriction: Restriction: Sociology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

SOCIOL 136.name: Religious Traditions of Asian Americans
SOCIOL 136.description: Studies the religious traditions of Asian Americans, focusing on the transplantation of religious institutions, establishment of sacred spaces, celebration of religious holidays, socialization of children, as well as birth, marriage, gender relations, death, family.

SOCIOL 138.name: Business Decisions
SOCIOL 138.description: Surveys normative and descriptive models of decision-making behavior, with an emphasis on organizational and policy contexts. Topics include rational choice theory, biases and heuristics, framing effects, and overconfidence. Management fads, panics, and herd behavior are also discussed.
SOCIOL 138.prereqString: Prerequisite: (ANTHRO 10A and ANTHRO 10B and ANTHRO 10C) or (SOCIOL 10A and SOCIOL 10B and SOCIOL 10C) or (SOC SCI 10A and SOC SCI 10B and SOC SCI 10C) or (MATH 2A and MATH 2B and (STATS 7 or MGMT 7)) or (STATS 120A and STATS 120B and STATS 120C) or (ECON 15A and ECON 15B)
SOCIOL 138.restriction: Restriction: Sociology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

SOCIOL 139.name: Special Topics: Social Psychology
SOCIOL 139.description: Studies in selected areas of social psychology. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
SOCIOL 139.restriction: Restriction: Sociology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

SOCIOL 141.name: Organizations
SOCIOL 141.description: How bureaucracies, formal organizations, and voluntary associations work, how/why they grow, and where they are going. History and structure of organizational rationality
SOCIOL 141.restriction: Restriction: Sociology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

SOCIOL 142.name: White-Collar Crime
SOCIOL 142.description: Examines criminal activity in business and corporate enterprise, organizations, and the professions. Theories regarding the causes and control of white-collar and corporate crime are covered as well as the numerous definitions of these terms.
SOCIOL 142.restriction: Restriction: Sociology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

SOCIOL 143.name: Social Networks and Social Support
SOCIOL 143.description: Examines the manner in which behaviors/attitudes of individuals are affected by their network ties to others. How are peoples' opportunities and well-being increased/decreased by their social networks? May include studies in mental/physical health, job seeking, separation and loss, and aging.
SOCIOL 143.restriction: Restriction: Sociology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

SOCIOL 144.name: Politics, Power, and Society
SOCIOL 144.description: Includes an examination of the major theoretical approaches to political sociology, and the application of these ideas to the politics of advanced capitalist societies. Also considers stability and change in power structures.
SOCIOL 144.restriction: Restriction: Sociology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

SOCIOL 149.name: Special Topics: Structures
SOCIOL 149.description: Studies in selected areas of structures. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
SOCIOL 149.restriction: Restriction: Sociology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

SOCIOL 150.name: Sociological Lens on Religion
SOCIOL 150.description: Examines the effects of religious beliefs, belonging, and institutions on social dynamics, including class, gender, and racial stratification, politics, and social movements. Additional topics: the sociological significance of conversion, commitment, and secularization/sacralization.
SOCIOL 150.restriction: Restriction: Sociology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

SOCIOL 151.name: Social Inequalities and Health
SOCIOL 151.description: Introduces ways in which social inequalities produce health disparities. Begins with general perspectives on social causation of health, and then considers how particular individual attributes (e.g., gender, SES, race/ethnicity, nativity) and social contexts (e.g., neighborhoods) can get “under the skin.”.

SOCIOL 154.name: Medical Sociology
SOCIOL 154.description: Current problems in U.S. health-care system and proposals for reform. Examines  financial barriers to access
SOCIOL 154.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. Sociology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

SOCIOL 154W.name: Medical Sociology
SOCIOL 154W.description: Current problems in U.S. health-care system and proposals for reform. Examines  financial barriers to access
SOCIOL 154W.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
SOCIOL 154W.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. Sociology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

SOCIOL 155B.name: Baseball and Society
SOCIOL 155B.description: An examination of baseball's role in American social life over the last 150 years. Issues of fraternal organizations, national development, capitalism, rationalization, race and ethnicity, gender, economic organization, labor relations, and politics are discussed.
SOCIOL 155B.restriction: Restriction: Sociology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

SOCIOL 155BW.name: Baseball and Society
SOCIOL 155BW.description: An examination of baseball's role in American social life over the last 150 years. Issues of fraternal organizations, national development, capitalism, rationalization, race and ethnicity, gender, economic organization, labor relations, and politics are discussed.
SOCIOL 155BW.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
SOCIOL 155BW.restriction: Restriction: Sociology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

SOCIOL 156.name: Deviance
SOCIOL 156.description: Perspectives on deviance and criminality in behavior, institution, community, and myth. The suitability of contemporary theories of deviant behavior.
SOCIOL 156.restriction: Restriction: Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Sociology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

SOCIOL 157A.name: Sociology of Education
SOCIOL 157A.description: Focuses on education’s role in creating and redressing inequality, and in shaping how we understand our place in society. Education from cross-national and historical perspectives, and education as a vehicle for examining and solving social problems.  Course may be offered online.

SOCIOL 157AW.name: Sociology of Education
SOCIOL 157AW.description: Focuses on education’s role in creating and redressing inequality, and in shaping how we understand our place in society. Education from cross-national and historical perspectives, and education as a vehicle for examining and solving social problems.

SOCIOL 157C.name: Comparing European and US Societies
SOCIOL 157C.description: Society, culture, institutions of U.S. and European countries. Fertility to football, guns to government, work to welfare, health to housework. Cross-national approaches for understanding the world and thinking critically about taken-for-granted practices. Policies the U.S. might borrow for social issues.

SOCIOL 158C.name: Money, Work, and Social Life
SOCIOL 158C.description: Sociological perspective on issues related to money and work. Consumption practices and lifestyles, jobs and organizations, issues of money in intimate relations, marriage, and households, illegal work, discrimination, economic globalization are discussed.
SOCIOL 158C.restriction: Restriction: Sociology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

SOCIOL 158CW.name: Money, Work, and Social Life
SOCIOL 158CW.description: Sociological perspective on issues related to money and work. Consumption practices and lifestyles, jobs and organizations, issues of money in intimate relations, marriage, and households, illegal work, discrimination, economic globalization are discussed.
SOCIOL 158CW.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
SOCIOL 158CW.restriction: Restriction: Sociology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

SOCIOL 159.name: Special Topics: Social Institutions and Culture
SOCIOL 159.description: Studies in selected areas of social institutions and culture. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
SOCIOL 159.restriction: Restriction: Sociology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

SOCIOL 161.name: Sociology of Sex and Gender
SOCIOL 161.description: Explores complex processes contributing to social construction of gender and sexuality in the U.S. with focus on intersection of gender, race, ethnicity, sexuality, and class

SOCIOL 161W.name: Sociology of Sex and Gender
SOCIOL 161W.description: Explores complex processes contributing to social construction of gender and sexuality in the U.S. with focus on intersection of gender, race, ethnicity, sexuality, and class
SOCIOL 161W.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

SOCIOL 164.name: Sociology of Aging
SOCIOL 164.description: Introduction to sociology of age, aging, and the aged. Problems posed by aging population. Life course transitions and how social organizations influence the life course. Addresses work, health, and family in later life.
SOCIOL 164.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. Sociology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

SOCIOL 164W.name: Sociology of Aging
SOCIOL 164W.description: Introduction to sociology of age, aging, and the aged. Problems posed by aging population. Life course transitions. How social organizations influence the life course. Work, health, family in later life.
SOCIOL 164W.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
SOCIOL 164W.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. Sociology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

SOCIOL 166.name: Immigration and Inequality
SOCIOL 166.description: Explores immigration, ethnicity, and inequality as interconnected social forces. International migration, propelled by global inequalities, plays a central role in the formation of multinational societies, shapes inter-group relations and patterns of ethnic inequality, and transforms the immigrants themselves.

SOCIOL 167A.name: Racial and Ethnic Relations in the United States
SOCIOL 167A.description: Examines central questions and issues in the field of race and ethnicity
SOCIOL 167A.restriction: Restriction: Chicano/Latino Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Sociology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

SOCIOL 167AW.name: Racial and Ethnic Relations in the United States
SOCIOL 167AW.description: Examines central questions and issues in the field of race and ethnicity
SOCIOL 167AW.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
SOCIOL 167AW.restriction: Restriction: Chicano/Latino Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Sociology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

SOCIOL 169.name: Special Topics in Age, Gender, Race, and Ethnicity
SOCIOL 169.description: Studies in selected areas of age, gender, race, and ethnicity. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
SOCIOL 169.restriction: Restriction: Sociology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

SOCIOL 170A.name: Vietnam War
SOCIOL 170A.description: Examines social structures and social changes in Vietnamese and U.S. societies through the study of the Vietnam War.

SOCIOL 170B.name: U.S. War on Terrorism
SOCIOL 170B.description: Analyzes the United States war on terrorism by focusing on terrorism, the U.S. wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, and changes in police powers through the Patriot Act, as well as the political leadership which directs the war.

SOCIOL 171.name: Environment and Society
SOCIOL 171.description: Examines society's changing relationship to the natural world. Delineates different models of "nature" and then explores their institutional roots, the social responses they have generated, and their implications for social inequality.
SOCIOL 171.restriction: Restriction: Sociology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

SOCIOL 172.name: Revolution and Social Transformation in China
SOCIOL 172.description: Introduces the major political events in Mao’s communist revolution and the social transformations afterward. Helps students understand the historic and political landscape from which China is now departing.
SOCIOL 172.restriction: Restriction: Sociology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

SOCIOL 172A.name: Chicanx/Latinx Education
SOCIOL 172A.description: Provides a historical and empirical overview of educational issues affecting diverse Latinx low-income, immigrant, and U.S. born student populations enrolled in American schools. Examines policies and issues such as DACA, generation, culture, racism, and gender on educational mobility.

SOCIOL 173.name: Social Inequality
SOCIOL 173.description: Sources, functions, and dynamics of the unequal distribution of wealth, prestige, knowledge, and power in American and other societies.
SOCIOL 173.restriction: Restriction: Sociology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

SOCIOL 173W.name: Social Inequality
SOCIOL 173W.description: Sources, functions, and dynamics of the unequal distribution of wealth, prestige, knowledge, and power in American and other societies.
SOCIOL 173W.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

SOCIOL 174.name: Protests, Movements, and Revolutions
SOCIOL 174.description: A survey of models of collective action drawn from sociology, economics, psychology, and political science. Focus on areas such as social movements, strikes, crowd psychology, cults, fads, fashions, public opinion, and symbolic and mythical elements in collective culture.
SOCIOL 174.prereqString: Prerequisite: SOCIOL 1 or POL SCI 11A or ECON 1
SOCIOL 174.restriction: Restriction: Political Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Sociology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

SOCIOL 175B.name: China in the Global Age
SOCIOL 175B.description: Chinese society from 1949 to present. Social change in the context of political control and ideological considerations. Focus on the power structure, political decision processes, and ideological legitimation, and interplay with the Chinese community and its culture.

SOCIOL 176.name: International Divided Cities
SOCIOL 176.description: Investigates urban divisions in international cities where deep-seated nationalistic ethnic differences create pressures for intergroup conflicts, autonomy, or territorial separation, and can incite violence. Urban political polarization as it is manifest in the urban setting.

SOCIOL 177.name: Immigration and Social Policy
SOCIOL 177.description: Explains how people decide to migrate and how they are incorporated into a host society (both historically and currently), examines the effects of immigration on the U.S., analyzes how the framing of immigration shapes the discourse about the issue.
SOCIOL 177.restriction: Restriction: Sociology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

SOCIOL 177C.name: Undocumented Immigrant Experiences
SOCIOL 177C.description: Examines the experiences of undocumented immigrants and the policies that structure their educational, economic, social, and political participation.

SOCIOL 177W.name: Immigration and Social Policy
SOCIOL 177W.description: Explains how people decide to migrate and how they are incorporated into a host society (both historically and currently), examines the effects of immigration on the U.S., analyzes how the framing of immigration shapes the discourse about the issue.
SOCIOL 177W.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
SOCIOL 177W.restriction: Restriction: Sociology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

SOCIOL 179.name: Special Topics: Societies and Social Inequality
SOCIOL 179.description: Studies in selected areas of societies and social inequality. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
SOCIOL 179.restriction: Restriction: Sociology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

SOCIOL 180A.name: Sociology Majors Seminar
SOCIOL 180A.description: Students learn sociology by doing it. A modest-sized research project is planned and implemented by each student.

SOCIOL 180AW.name: Sociology Majors Seminar
SOCIOL 180AW.description: Students learn sociology by doing it. A modest-sized research project is planned and implemented by each student.
SOCIOL 180AW.prereqString: Prerequisite: SOCIOL 110. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

SOCIOL 188BW.name: Honors Research and Thesis
SOCIOL 188BW.description: Focuses on the design and implementation of individual research projects undertaken by senior Sociology majors. Writing projects consist of a proposal and paper on some empirical research.
SOCIOL 188BW.prereqString: Prerequisite: SOCIOL H188A. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

SOCIOL H188A.name: Honors Research and Thesis
SOCIOL H188A.description: Focuses on the design and implementation of individual research projects undertaken by senior Sociology majors. Writing projects consist of a proposal and paper on some empirical research.

SOCIOL 189.name: Special Topics: Honors Sequence
SOCIOL 189.description: Independent honors research with Social Sciences faculty.
SOCIOL 189.restriction: Restriction: Sociology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

SOCIOL 202A.name: Proseminar I in Sociology
SOCIOL 202A.description: Introduces first-year graduate students in Sociology to the current research interests of Sociology faculty, as well as to other aspects of graduate life at UCI and to the profession of sociology more generally.

SOCIOL 202B.name: Proseminar II in Sociology
SOCIOL 202B.description: Focus is on second-year research projects, design, development, data gathering, analysis, and preparing oral and written presentations of the results. Students learn analytic and writing skills, gain experience with research processes, and become socialized about professional standards, customs, and institutions.

SOCIOL 210A.name: Classical Social Theory
SOCIOL 210A.description: Examines the development of classical sociological theory through the writings of Karl Marx, Emile Durkheim, Max Weber, Georg Simmel, and George Herbert Mead.

SOCIOL 210B.name: Contemporary Social Theory
SOCIOL 210B.description: Familiarizes students with 20th-century developments in social thought that have influenced sociological research, suggesting "what is living and what is dead" in the "classics" and offering an overview of the main outlines of recent sociological theorizing.

SOCIOL 211A.name: Sociology of Gender
SOCIOL 211A.description: An introduction to the sociology of gender in the U.S. and globally. The social construction of gender and sexuality

SOCIOL 212.name: Network Theory
SOCIOL 212.description: An introduction to theoretical work in the field of social networks. Topics include baseline models, homphily, and propinquity, exchange and power, balance theory, diffusion and social influence, equivalence, and cohesion. Deductive use of theory to make novel predictions is emphasized.

SOCIOL 219.name: Special Topics: Theory
SOCIOL 219.description: Studies in selected areas of theory. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

SOCIOL 220A.name: Research Design
SOCIOL 220A.description: Data collection, organization, and analysis in ethnographic or quasi-experimental settings, including interviewing, participant observations, behavior observations, and questionnaires. Research design issues include sampling, longitudinal research, and comparative research. Emphasis on the integration of qualitative and quantitative data.

SOCIOL 221A.name: Graduate Statistics I
SOCIOL 221A.description: Statistics with emphasis on applications in sociology and anthropology. Examines exploratory uses of statistical tools in these fields as well as univariate, bivariate, and multivariate applications in the context of the general linear model.

SOCIOL 221B.name: Graduate Statistics II
SOCIOL 221B.description: Statistics with emphasis on applications in sociology and anthropology. Examines exploratory uses of statistical tools in these fields as well as univariate, bivariate, and multivariate applications in the context of the general linear model.

SOCIOL 221C.name: Graduate Statistics III
SOCIOL 221C.description: Statistics with emphasis on applications in sociology and anthropology. Examines exploratory uses of statistical tools in these fields as well as univariate, bivariate, and multivariate applications in the context of the general linear model.

SOCIOL 222A.name: Comparative and Historical Sociological Methods
SOCIOL 222A.description: Topics include the logic of comparative and historical analysis techniques and the examination of exemplar works in representative problem areas.

SOCIOL 224.name: Interview Methods
SOCIOL 224.description: Hands-on introduction to the use of interviews in social scientific research. Topics include when to use interviews and/or focus groups

SOCIOL 226A.name: Methods of Demographic Analysis
SOCIOL 226A.description: Introduces basic demographic methods used in social science and public health research. Topics include sources and limitations of demographic data

SOCIOL 227A.name: Seminar Ethnographic & Qualitative Field Methods
SOCIOL 227A.description: Comprehensive and critical discussion of the traditions of qualitative fieldwork

SOCIOL 227B.name: Seminar Ethnographic & Qualitative Field Methods
SOCIOL 227B.description: Comprehensive and critical discussion of the traditions of qualitative fieldwork

SOCIOL 229.name: Special Topics: Methods
SOCIOL 229.description: Studies in selected areas of methods. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

SOCIOL 230A.name: Race and Ethnicity
SOCIOL 230A.description: An examination of central questions and issues in the field of race and ethnicity through a critical analysis and discussion of the principal theoretical perspectives and paradigms that have framed much of the scholarship in the area.

SOCIOL 232.name: Inequality
SOCIOL 232.description: Theoretical and empirical approaches to the study of social and economic inequality, with special attention to race/ethnicity, class, and gender.

SOCIOL 234.name: Ethnic America
SOCIOL 234.description: Examines critically the meaning and measurement of ethnicity, race, and nation in sociological theory and research. Theories of ethnicity are explored, along with empirical studies of the construction of ethnic and pan-ethnic identities in historical and contemporary contexts.

SOCIOL 235.name: Poverty and Development
SOCIOL 235.description: Examines competing conceptualizations, methods of measurement, and poverty alleviation strategies widely used in developing countries. Focuses on poverty conceptualized as economic deprivation, well-being, vulnerability, and social exclusion.

SOCIOL 237.name: Educational Inequality
SOCIOL 237.description: Focuses on macro-level explanations of inequality of schooling, particularly in the U.S. context. Explores traditional models, such as conflict, functionalism, status-attainment, cultural reproduction, and newer synthetic accounts. Emphasis on higher education access and the intersection of education and work.

SOCIOL 239.name: Special Topics: Social Inequality
SOCIOL 239.description: Studies in selected areas of social inequality. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

SOCIOL 240A.name: Social Movements
SOCIOL 240A.description: A survey of the field of Social Movements, oriented around critical themes in the major theoretical traditions and contemporary exemplars.

SOCIOL 241A.name: Political Sociology
SOCIOL 241A.description: Begins with an examination of the three major orientations to the State (Pluralist, Elitist, and Class). Next considers current topics in political sociology including the Welfare State, the New Deal, political behavior, social movements, participation, and democracy.

SOCIOL 242.name: Sociology of Culture
SOCIOL 242.description: Major perspectives in the sociology of culture. Topics include the role of cultural dynamics in the reproduction of inequality, collective action, political and organizational decision making, emotional experience, and the social impacts of new technologies.

SOCIOL 249.name: Special Topics: Political Sociology and Social Movements
SOCIOL 249.description: Studies in selected areas of political sociology and social movements. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

SOCIOL 252A.name: Global Urbanization
SOCIOL 252A.description: Examines the spread of cities worldwide in the 20th century. What are the political and economic causes of this process? What are the social-cultural, political, and economic effects? How is contemporary urbanization linked to global restructuring of other kinds.

SOCIOL 259.name: Special Topics: Global Studies and Comparative Development
SOCIOL 259.description: Studies in selected areas of global studies and comparative development. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

SOCIOL 262A.name: Population
SOCIOL 262A.description: Introduces the interrelationships between population and social organization. Considers measurement and explanation of historical and contemporary trends in birth rates, death rates, migration, and marriage and divorce. Case material is drawn primarily from the U.S. and other industrialized nations.

SOCIOL 264.name: Immigrant America
SOCIOL 264.description: The study of the causes and consequences of international migration has become one of the most vital fields of sociological theory and research. Examines principal theoretical perspectives and empirical research on contemporary immigration flows and the processes of incorporation.

SOCIOL 265.name: DASA Research Design
SOCIOL 265.description: Data collection, organization, and analysis in population studies and demography. Research design issues include sampling, longitudinal research, and comparative research.

SOCIOL 268.name: Crimmigration
SOCIOL 268.description: Examines the criminalization of immigration, with an emphasis on U.S. enforcement procedures and outcomes. Analyzes the devolution of federal immigration law to local authorities, the rise in immigrant detention and deportation, and the militarization of the U.S.-Mexico border.

SOCIOL 269.name: Special Topics: Social Demography
SOCIOL 269.description: Studies in selected areas of social demography. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

SOCIOL 279.name: Special Topics: Social Organizations and Institutions
SOCIOL 279.description: Studies in selected areas of social organizations and institutions. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

SOCIOL 280.name: Analysis of Social Network Data
SOCIOL 280.description: Overview and application of methods for analyzing social network data. Topics include: data structures, visualization, graph theory, centrality, subgroups, positions, blockmodels, local properties, and statistical models. Social network analysis software is used to analyze a range of examples.

SOCIOL 281.name: Introduction to Social Networks
SOCIOL 281.description: Provides a broad overview of the history, concepts, and applications of social networks. Students have the opportunity to delve deeply into applications of the network approach in their individual areas of interest.

SOCIOL 282.name: Theorizing Illegality and the Experiences of Undocumented Immigrants
SOCIOL 282.description: Examines theories of illegality and citizenship, historical and contemporary undocumented immigrant experiences, and methodological concerns in this area of study.

SOCIOL 289.name: Special Topics
SOCIOL 289.description: Studies in selected areas of Social Sciences. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

SPANISH 1A.name: Fundamentals of Spanish
SPANISH 1A.description: First quarter of Fundaments of Spanish that helps students develop basic reading, listening, speaking, and writing skills in Spanish. Delivered in a hybrid format.

SPANISH 1AB.name: Fundamentals Intensive Spanish
SPANISH 1AB.description: An intensive, proficiency-oriented, and task-based approach, designed to develop basic oral communicative abilities in Spanish.  Reading and writing skills, along with an an introduction to Hispanic cultures.
SPANISH 1AB.restriction: Restriction: SPANISH 1AB and SPANISH 1A and SPANISH 1B and SPANISH S1AB may not be taken for full credit.

SPANISH 1B.name: Fundamentals of Spanish
SPANISH 1B.description: Communicative approach with emphasis on conversational skills: the students and their environment, their experiences, and their opinions about issues.  Reading and writing skills also introduced.
SPANISH 1B.prereqString: Prerequisite: SPANISH 1A. SPANISH 1A with a grade of C or better. Placement into SPANISH 1B is also accepted.
SPANISH 1B.restriction: Restriction: SPANISH 1B and SPANISH 1AB and SPANISH S1AB may not be taken for full credit.

SPANISH 1C.name: Fundamentals of Spanish
SPANISH 1C.description: Communicative approach with emphasis on conversational skills: the students and their environment, their experiences, and their opinions about issues.  Reading and writing skills also introduced.
SPANISH 1C.prereqString: Prerequisite: SPANISH 1AB or SPANISH 1B or SPANISH S1AB. SPANISH 1AB with a grade of C or better. SPANISH 1B with a grade of C or better. SPANISH S1AB with a grade of B or better. Placement into SPANISH 1C is also accepted.
SPANISH 1C.restriction: Restriction: SPANISH 1C and SPANISH S1BC may not be taken for full credit.

SPANISH S1AB.name: Fundamentals of Spanish
SPANISH S1AB.description: First half of first-year Spanish in an intensified form. Communicative approach with emphasis on conversational skills.
SPANISH S1AB.restriction: Restriction: SPANISH S1AB and SPANISH 1A and SPANISH 1B and SPANISH 1AB may not be taken for full credit.

SPANISH S1BC.name: Fundamentals of Spanish
SPANISH S1BC.description: Second half of first-year Spanish in an intensified form. Communicative approach with emphasis on conversational skills.
SPANISH S1BC.prereqString: Prerequisite: SPANISH S1AB or SPANISH 1A or SPANISH 1B. SPANISH S1AB with a grade of C or better. SPANISH 1A with a grade of C or better. SPANISH 1B with a grade of C or better. Placement into SPANISH 1B or SPANISH 1C is also accepted.
SPANISH S1BC.restriction: Restriction: SPANISH S1BC and SPANISH 1B and SPANISH 1C and SPANISH 1AB may not be taken for full credit.

SPANISH 2A.name: Intermediate Spanish
SPANISH 2A.description: Conversation, reading, and composition skills are developed using texts of literary and social interest. Emphasis on grammar review.
SPANISH 2A.prereqString: Prerequisite: SPANISH 1C or SPANISH S1BC. SPANISH 1C with a grade of C or better. SPANISH S1BC with a grade of C or better. Placement into SPANISH 2A is also accepted.
SPANISH 2A.restriction: Restriction: School of Humanities students have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

SPANISH 2AB.name: Intermediate Intensive Spanish
SPANISH 2AB.description: Intensive intermediate course designed to improve student's abilities in reading, writing, speaking, and comprehension, including a thorough introduction to Hispanic cultures. Grammatical component of the language is gradually reviewed and tested.
SPANISH 2AB.prereqString: Prerequisite: SPANISH 1C or SPANISH S1BC. SPANISH 1C with a grade of C or better. SPANISH S1BC with a grade of C or better. Placement into SPANISH 2A is also accepted.

SPANISH 2B.name: Intermediate Spanish
SPANISH 2B.description: Second quarter of Intermediate Spanish that helps students further develop their reading, listening, speaking, and writing skills in Spanish and a cultural understanding of the Spanish-speaking world. Delivered in a hybrid format.
SPANISH 2B.prereqString: Prerequisite: SPANISH 2A. SPANISH 2A with a grade of C or better. Placement into SPANISH 2B is also accepted.
SPANISH 2B.restriction: Restriction: School of Humanities students have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

SPANISH 2C.name: Intermediate Spanish
SPANISH 2C.description: Third quarter of Intermediate Spanish that helps students further develop their reading, listening, speaking, and writing skills in Spanish and a cultural understanding of the Spanish-speaking world. Delivered in a hybrid format.
SPANISH 2C.prereqString: Prerequisite: SPANISH 2AB or SPANISH 2B or SPANISH S2AB. SPANISH 2AB with a grade of C or better. SPANISH 2B with a grade of C or better. SPANISH S2AB with a grade of B or better. Placement into SPANISH 2C is also accepted.
SPANISH 2C.restriction: Restriction: School of Humanities students have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

SPANISH S2AB.name: Intermediate Spanish
SPANISH S2AB.description: First half of second-year Spanish in an intensified form. Conversation, reading, and composition skills are developed using texts of literary and social interest. Emphasis on grammar review.
SPANISH S2AB.prereqString: Prerequisite: SPANISH 1C or SPANISH S1BC. SPANISH 1C with a grade of C or better. SPANISH S1BC with a grade of C or better. Placement into SPANISH 2A is also accepted.

SPANISH S2BC.name: Intermediate Spanish
SPANISH S2BC.description: Second half of second-year Spanish in an intensified form. Conversation, reading, and composition skills are developed using texts of literary and social interest. Emphasis on grammar review.
SPANISH S2BC.prereqString: Prerequisite: SPANISH 2B or SPANISH S2AB or SPANISH 2A. SPANISH 2B with a grade of C or better. SPANISH S2AB with a grade of C or better. SPANISH 2A with a grade of B or better. Placement into SPANISH 2B or SPANISH 2C is also accepted.
SPANISH S2BC.restriction: Restriction: SPANISH S2BC and SPANISH 2B and SPANISH 2C and SPANISH 2AB and SPANISH 2 may not be taken for full credit.

SPANISH 3.name: US Latino Communities
SPANISH 3.description: Focuses on intermediate to advanced grammar and composition. Emphasis is placed on key elements of grammar, which constitutes about 70 percent of the curriculum, and composition writing, which constitutes the remaining 30 percent.
SPANISH 3.prereqString: Prerequisite: SPANISH 2C or SPANISH S2BC. SPANISH 2C with a grade of C or better. SPANISH S2BC with a grade of C or better. Placement into SPANISH 3 is also accepted.

SPANISH 3H.name: Heritage Spanish: Latinidades en California
SPANISH 3H.description: Designed for students who grew up speaking Spanish in their homes and who need additional practice writing in Spanish. Delivered in a hybrid format.

SPANISH 50.name: Latin America, U.S. Latino, and Iberian Cultures
SPANISH 50.description: Introduction (for non-majors) to the culture of the Spanish- and Portuguese-speaking worlds (Europe, Latin America, U.S., Africa).  May focus on any time period.  Taught in english.

SPANISH 60E.name: Mexico and Central America: A Survey
SPANISH 60E.description: Panoramic view of Mexico and Central America examining key texts throughout history. Shows the richness of the culture, and an appraisal of various forms of representation, including images, chronicles, novels, essays, poems, and  a film. Taught in English.

SPANISH 60S.name: Mexico and Central America: A Survey
SPANISH 60S.description: Panoramic view of Mexico and Central America examining key texts throughout history. Shows the richness of the culture, and an appraisal of various forms of representation, including images, chronicles, novels, essays, poems, and a film. Taught in Spanish.
SPANISH 60S.prereqString: Prerequisite: Placement into SPANISH 2A or higher via Spanish Placement Test B is required.

SPANISH 61.name: The Culture of the Visual Image in Latin America
SPANISH 61.description: A survey of visual forms of expression which have endured through more than five centuries of pre-colonial, colonial, and independent Latin America. Forms to be treated in the class include painting, monuments, sculpture, urban planning, graffiti, comics, and photography.

SPANISH 62.name: Latinx, Multilingualism, and Social Justice
SPANISH 62.description: Explores the role of multilingualism (Spanish, indigenous languages, Latino English) in Latinx social justice movements in the United States with an emphasis on California. Course is taught in English.

SPANISH 97.name: Fundamentals of Spanish (with Emphasis on Reading)
SPANISH 97.description: Designed for students interested in acquiring a solid reading knowledge of Spanish, and to facilitate the understanding and translating of Spanish texts covering a variety of disciplines.  Does not fulfill any undergraduate foreign language requirement.  Taught in English.
SPANISH 97.prereqString: Prerequisite: Does not serve as prerequisite for any higher-level Spanish courses.

SPANISH 101A.name: Introduction to Iberian Literature and Culture
SPANISH 101A.description: Introduction to the major authors and movements of Iberian literature and culture from the Middle Ages to the present.
SPANISH 101A.prereqString: Prerequisite: SPANISH 3 or SPANISH 3H. Placement into SPANISH 101A is also accepted.

SPANISH 101B.name: Introductory Studies to Latin American Literature and Culture
SPANISH 101B.description: A historical overview of Latin American literature and culture mainly focused on canonical texts. Topics include colonialism and postcolonialism, the nation, indigenismo, gender, and literary movements. Also introduces literary analysis, research methods, and cultural critique.
SPANISH 101B.prereqString: Prerequisite: SPANISH 3 or SPANISH 3H. Placement into SPANISH 101A is also accepted.

SPANISH 104.name: Writing in Spanish
SPANISH 104.description: Focuses on the use of writing as a medium to encourage critical thinking and the practical analysis of literary texts, as well as the study of historical and social issues in the Spanish-speaking world.
SPANISH 104.prereqString: Prerequisite: SPANISH 3 or SPANISH 3H. Placement into SPANISH 101A is also accepted.

SPANISH 105.name: Spanish Communication
SPANISH 105.description: Designed to help students develop Spanish oral skills by exposing them to different verbal Spanish language registers. Special emphasis placed on abilities essential to professional or academic careers. Intended for Spanish majors as an important component of their overall education.
SPANISH 105.prereqString: Prerequisite: SPANISH 3 or SPANISH 3H. Placement into SPANISH 101A is also accepted.

SPANISH 107.name: Advanced Spanish Grammar
SPANISH 107.description: Designed for students who have demonstrated a substantial level of proficiency in their studies of the Spanish language. Takes thorough approach to advanced grammatical problems, in order to assist students in their mastery of the elements of the Spanish language.
SPANISH 107.prereqString: Prerequisite: SPANISH 3 or SPANISH 3H. Placement into SPANISH 101A is also accepted.

SPANISH 110A.name: Topics in Peninsular Literature and Cultures
SPANISH 110A.description: Topics in Peninsular literature and cultures.
SPANISH 110A.prereqString: Prerequisite: SPANISH 3 or SPANISH 3H. Placement into SPANISH 101A is also accepted.

SPANISH 110B.name: Topics in Latin American Literature and Cultures
SPANISH 110B.description: Topics in Latin American literature and cultures.
SPANISH 110B.prereqString: Prerequisite: SPANISH 3 or SPANISH 3H. Placement into SPANISH 101A is also accepted.

SPANISH 110C.name: U.S. Latino Literature and Cultures
SPANISH 110C.description: Focuses on aspects of literature, art, cultural production, and history of the multifaceted Latino cultures that have developed within the United States.  Focuses on one group, such as Caribbean Americans, Chicanos, Central Americans, or a comparative perspective of several groups.

SPANISH 113A.name: Spanish Phonetics
SPANISH 113A.description: Introduction to fundamental notions of Spanish phonetics. Particular attention paid to problems of pronunciation that arise in native and non-native speakers of Spanish due to interference between Spanish and English. Phonology (the system that underlies phonetics) and Spanish dialectology included.
SPANISH 113A.prereqString: Prerequisite: SPANISH 3 or SPANISH 3H. Placement into SPANISH 101A is also accepted.

SPANISH 113B.name: Introduction to Spanish Linguistics
SPANISH 113B.description: Introduces students to the scientific study of the Spanish language with a focus on its sound system, word components, word order as well as second language acquisition and language variation. Class is delivered in a hybrid format.
SPANISH 113B.prereqString: Prerequisite: SPANISH 3 or SPANISH 3H. Placement into SPANISH 101A is also accepted.

SPANISH 119.name: Textual Analysis and Interpretation
SPANISH 119.description: Focus on analysis and interpretation of literary texts. Emphasis on narrative, poetry, theater/performance, and visual media. Introduces students to major currents in theoretical thought, such as cultural studies, postmodernism, and others. Oral presentations and short essays required. Taught in Spanish.
SPANISH 119.prereqString: Prerequisite: SPANISH 3 or SPANISH 3H. Placement into SPANISH 101A is also accepted.

SPANISH 121.name: Topics in Golden Age Literature and Culture
SPANISH 121.description: Golden Age Literature in Spain, including the Renaissance and Baroque periods. Works of poetry, narrative, and theater. Historical and cultural background.
SPANISH 121.prereqString: Prerequisite: SPANISH 3 or SPANISH 3H. Placement into SPANISH 101A is also accepted.

SPANISH 122.name: Topics in 18th and 19th Century Spanish Literature and Culture
SPANISH 122.description: The main literary and ideological trends in 18th and 19th century Spain, including the enlightenment, romanticism, realism, and naturalism.
SPANISH 122.prereqString: Prerequisite: SPANISH 3 or SPANISH 3H. Placement into SPANISH 101A is also accepted.

SPANISH 123.name: Topics in 20th and 21st Century Spanish Literature and Culture
SPANISH 123.description: 20th century Spanish authors. Works of poetry, narrative, or theater. Historical context of the period and principles of literary theory.
SPANISH 123.prereqString: Prerequisite: SPANISH 3 or SPANISH 3H. Placement into SPANISH 101A is also accepted.

SPANISH 130C.name: Topics in Latin American Literature and Culture of the 20th Century
SPANISH 130C.description: Topics in Latin American literature and culture of the 20th century.
SPANISH 130C.prereqString: Prerequisite: SPANISH 3 or SPANISH 3H. Placement into SPANISH 101A is also accepted.

SPANISH 140.name: Topics in Chicano Literature and Culture
SPANISH 140.description: Studies in selected areas of Chicano/Latino Studies. Topics addressed vary each quarter. Taught in English.

SPANISH 150.name: Topics in Literature in Translation
SPANISH 150.description: Study of texts by modern and contemporary Peninsular, Latin American, and/or U.S. Latino writers in translation. Taught in English. Not applicable toward Spanish major or minor requirements.

SPANISH 160.name: Topics in Luso-Hispanic Film Studies
SPANISH 160.description: Study of Peninsular, Latin-American, and/or U.S. Latino film. Taught in English or Spanish.
SPANISH 160.prereqString: Prerequisite: SPANISH 3 or SPANISH 3H. Placement into SPANISH 101A is also accepted.

SPANISH 185.name: Selected Topics in Peninsular Literature and Culture
SPANISH 185.description: Selection of representative topics in Spanish and/or Portuguese literature and culture.
SPANISH 185.prereqString: Prerequisite: SPANISH 3 or SPANISH 3H. Placement into SPANISH 101A is also accepted.

SPANISH 186.name: Selected Topics in Latin American Literature and Culture
SPANISH 186.description: Selection of representative topics in the history of Latin American literature and culture.
SPANISH 186.prereqString: Prerequisite: SPANISH 3 or SPANISH 3H. Placement into SPANISH 101A is also accepted.

SPANISH 187.name: Selected Topics in Spanish Linguistics
SPANISH 187.prereqString: Prerequisite: SPANISH 3 or SPANISH 3H. Placement into SPANISH 101A is also accepted.

SPANISH 190.name: Colloquium
SPANISH 190.description: Specialized, discussion-based course dealing primarily with a research topic that reflects the instructor's current intellectual interests. Required oral presentation(s) and final research paper. Limited to 15 students.
SPANISH 190.restriction: Restriction: Upper-division students only. Spanish Majors only.

SPANISH 201.name: History of the Spanish Language
SPANISH 201.description: Diachronic survey of phonological changes from Latin to Old Spanish to Modern Spanish. Focuses in Castilian including Romance languages and other peninsula dialects for comparative purposes. Morphological changes.

SPANISH 204.name: Spanish in Contact
SPANISH 204.description: Sociohistorical and linguistic overview of Spanish in contact with Basque, Catalan, English, German, American Indian, and African languages in Spain, Latin America, and the United States. Examines theories about language contact, and linguistic changes in Spanish phonology and grammar.

SPANISH 205.name: Spanish Dialectology
SPANISH 205.description: Phonological, morphological, and syntactic variations in Spanish as spoken in the Hispanic world, from synchronic and diachronic points of view.  The study of Spanish as spoken in the United States.

SPANISH 214.name: Topics in Golden Age Literature and Culture
SPANISH 214.description: Topics in Golden Age literature and culture.

SPANISH 219.name: Topics  in Nineteenth Century
SPANISH 219.description: Topics in nineteenth-century Spanish literature and culture.

SPANISH 220.name: Topics in Twentieth Century
SPANISH 220.description: Topics in twentieth-century Spanish literature and culture.

SPANISH 221.name: Topics in Iberian Studies
SPANISH 221.description: Cross-cultural connections and interactions between different ethnicities in the Iberian Peninsula.

SPANISH 235.name: Topics in Trans-Oceanic Studies
SPANISH 235.description: Focuses on meaningful connections between different geographical and cultural areas.

SPANISH 239A.name: Topics in Literary Theory I
SPANISH 239A.description: Traces the development of Western literary critical principles from Aristotle to the twentieth century through selected readings of key figures in intellectual history (Aristotle, St. Augustine, Descartes, Kant, Hegel, Marx, Nietzsche, William James, Freud).

SPANISH 239B.name: Topics in Literary Theory II
SPANISH 239B.description: Study of major critical movements of the twentieth century, from Modernism's varied trends to those of the Postmodern/Postcolonial period. Emphasis on the development of prior critical discourses as well as revisionary theories.

SPANISH 239C.name: Special Topics in Theory
SPANISH 239C.description: Focus on issues related to critical theory, theory of literature, cultural criticism and visual arts as they pertain specifically to Latin America, Spain, Portugal, and Brazil. Topics vary. Examples: Latin American cultural studies

SPANISH 270.name: Creative Writing Workshop in Spanish/English
SPANISH 270.description: Discussion of theory and practice of creative writing.  Focus on critical analysis of participant's work in progress.  Texts may be written in Spanish and/or English and may be written in poetry or prose format.

SPANISH 299.name: Dissertation Research
SPANISH 299.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. School of Humanities students only.

SPPS 40.name: Social Policy and Public Service
SPPS 40.description: An introduction to the basic theories and principles of public policy. Students examine various influences on the development of public policy and the principle actors in the process, and learn to identify tools and techniques employed in policy making.

SPPS 70A.name: Race and Ethnicity
SPPS 70A.description: Focuses on racial and ethnic relations in the United States and compares them with those found in other societies. Analyzes the conditions that favor either cooperation and integration or rivalry, tension, and conflict. Appraises strategies for reducing and resolving conflicts.

SPPS 101A.name: Immigration, Nation, and Media
SPPS 101A.description: Examines media shapes and reflects public opinion on immigration and its representation of immigrants, citizens, and ideas about the nation, and who belongs and who is a potential threat

SPPS H190A.name: Honors Research Workshop
SPPS H190A.description: Student develops a 10–15-page prospectus of research for the honors thesis which includes: the research question, literature review, methods of investigation, and bibliography. Student selects a faculty mentor who will supervise thesis research and writing in winter and spring.
SPPS H190A.restriction: Restriction: Social Science Majors only. Social Policy/Public Service Majors only. Social Science Honors students only.

SPPS H190B.name: Honors Thesis Research
SPPS H190B.description: The student initiates and completes data collection for the honors thesis. A faculty mentor provides supervision and feedback on thesis chapters.
SPPS H190B.prereqString: Prerequisite: SSCI H190A or SPPS H190A

SPPS H190C.name: Honors Thesis
SPPS H190C.description: The student completes, with the approval of the faculty mentor, an honors thesis containing: statement of the problem, literature review, research hypotheses, methods of investigation, results, discussion, and bibliography.
SPPS H190C.prereqString: Prerequisite: SSCI H190B or SPPS H190B. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

SPPS 193A.name: Field Studies in Social Policy and Public Service
SPPS 193A.description: Advanced training in qualitative and ethnographic research centered on community service. Students pursue field studies at nonprofit agencies (200 hours) to understand current social problems in underrepresented and underserved communities. Through field placement, students apply theory to practice.
SPPS 193A.prereqString: Prerequisite: SSCI 70C or SOCL 63. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
SPPS 193A.restriction: Restriction: Social Policy/Public Service Majors only.

SPPS 193B.name: Field Studies in Social Policy and Public Service
SPPS 193B.description: Advanced training in qualitative and ethnographic research centered on community service. Students pursue field studies at nonprofit agencies (200 hours) to understand current social problems in underrepresented and underserved communities. Through field placement, students apply theory to practice.

SPPS 193C.name: Field Studies in Social Policy and Public Service
SPPS 193C.description: Advanced training in qualitative and ethnographic research centered on community service. Students pursue field studies at nonprofit agencies (200 hours) to understand current social problems in underrepresented and underserved communities. Through field placement, students apply theory to practice.

SPPS 193CW.name: Field Studies in Social Policy and Public Service
SPPS 193CW.description: Advanced training in qualitative and ethnographic research centered on community service. Students pursue field studies at nonprofit agencies (200 hours) to understand current social problems in underrepresented and under-served communities. Through field placement, students apply theory to practice.

STATS 5.name: Seminar in Data Science
STATS 5.description: An introduction to the field of Data Science
STATS 5.restriction: Restriction: Information Computer Science Majors only.

STATS 7.name: Basic Statistics
STATS 7.description: Introduces basic inferential statistics including confidence intervals and hypothesis testing on means and proportions, t-distribution, Chi Square, regression and correlation. F-distribution and nonparametric statistics included if time permits.
STATS 7.restriction: Restriction: STATS 7 may not be taken for credit concurrently with or after STATS 110, STATS 111, STATS 112.

STATS 8.name: Introduction to Biological Statistics
STATS 8.description: Introductory statistical techniques used to collect and analyze experimental and observational data from health sciences and biology. Includes exploration of data, probability and sampling distributions, basic statistical inference for means and proportions, linear regression, and analysis of variance.
STATS 8.restriction: Restriction: STATS 8 may not be taken for credit concurrently with or after STATS 110, STATS 111, STATS 112.

STATS 67.name: Introduction to Probability and Statistics for Computer Science
STATS 67.description: Introduction to the basic concepts of probability and statistics with discussion of applications to computer science.
STATS 67.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Computer Science Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. STATS 67 may not be taken for credit concurrently with or after STATS 120B.

STATS 68.name: Statistical Computing and Exploratory Data Analysis
STATS 68.description: Introduces key concepts in statistical computing. Techniques such as exploratory data analysis, data visualization, simulation, and optimization methods, will be presented in the context of data analysis within a statistical computing environment.

STATS 110.name: Statistical Methods for Data Analysis I
STATS 110.description: Introduction to statistical methods for analyzing data from experiments and surveys. Methods covered include two-sample procedures, analysis of variance, simple and multiple linear regression.
STATS 110.prereqString: Prerequisite: STATS 7 or STATS 8 or AP90 or (STATS 120A and STATS 120B and STATS 120C). AP90 with a minimum score of 3
STATS 110.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students only.

STATS 111.name: Statistical Methods for Data Analysis II
STATS 111.description: Introduction to statistical methods for analyzing data from surveys or experiments. Emphasizes application and understanding of methods for categorical data including contingency tables, logistic and Poisson regression, loglinear models.

STATS 112.name: Statistical Methods for Data Analysis III
STATS 112.description: Introduction to statistical methods for analyzing longitudinal data from experiments and cohort studies. Topics covered include survival methods for censored time-to-event data, linear mixed models, non-linear mixed effects models, and generalized estimating equations.

STATS 115.name: Introduction to Bayesian Data Analysis
STATS 115.description: Basic Bayesian concepts and methods with emphasis on data analysis. Special emphasis on specification of prior distributions. Development for one-two samples and on to binary, Poisson, and linear regression. Analyses performed using free OpenBugs software.

STATS 120A.name: Introduction to Probability and Statistics I
STATS 120A.description: Introduction to basic principles of probability and statistical inference. Axiomatic definition of probability, random variables, probability distributions, expectation.
STATS 120A.prereqString: Prerequisite: MATH 2A and MATH 2B and (MATH 2D or MATH 4)
STATS 120A.restriction: Restriction: Data Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics majors have second consideration.

STATS 120B.name: Introduction to Probability and Statistics II
STATS 120B.description: Introduction to basic principles of probability and statistical inference. Point estimation, interval estimating, and testing hypotheses, Bayesian approaches to inference.
STATS 120B.restriction: Restriction: Data Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics majors have second consideration.

STATS 120C.name: Introduction to Probability and Statistics III
STATS 120C.description: Introduction to basic principles of probability and statistical inference. Linear regression, analysis or variance, model checking.
STATS 120C.prereqString: Prerequisite: STATS 120B and (MATH 3A or MATH 6G or I&C SCI 6N)
STATS 120C.restriction: Restriction: Data Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Quantitative Economics majors have second consideration.

STATS 140.name: Multivariate Statistical Methods
STATS 140.description: Theory and application of multivariate statistical methods. Topics include statistical inference for the multivariate normal model and its extensions to multiple samples and regression, use of statistical packages for data visualization and reduction, discriminant analysis, cluster analysis, and factor analysis.
STATS 140.prereqString: Prerequisite: STATS 120C and (MATH 3A or I&C SCI 6N)

STATS 170A.name: Project in Data Science I
STATS 170A.description: Problem definition and analysis, data representation, algorithm selection, solution validation, and results presentation. Students do team projects and lectures cover analysis alternatives, project planning, and data analysis issues. First quarter emphasizes approach selection, project planning, and experimental design.
STATS 170A.prereqString: Prerequisite: STATS 68 and STATS 112 and IN4MATX 43 and COMPSCI 122A and COMPSCI 161 and COMPSCI 178
STATS 170A.restriction: Restriction: Seniors only. Data Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

STATS 170B.name: Project in Data Science II
STATS 170B.description: Problem definition and analysis, data representation, algorithm selection, solution validation, and results presentation. Students do team projects and lectures cover analysis alternatives, project planning, and data analysis issues. Second quarter emphasizes project execution and analysis, and presentation of results.
STATS 170B.prereqString: Prerequisite: STATS 170A. In Progress (IP) grade for STATS 170A is also accepted.
STATS 170B.restriction: Restriction: Seniors only. Data Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

STATS 199.name: Individual Study
STATS 199.description: Individual research or investigations under the direction of an individual faculty member.

STATS 200A.name: Intermediate Probability and Statistical Theory
STATS 200A.description: Basics of probability theory, random variables and basic transformations, univariate distributions—discrete and continuous, multivariate distributions.

STATS 200AP.name: Intermediate Probability and Statistical Theory I
STATS 200AP.description: Fundamental probability and distribution theory needed for statistical inference. Topics include axiomatic foundations of probability theory, discrete and continuous distributions, expectation and moment generating functions, multivariate distributions, transformations, sampling distributions, and limit theorems.
STATS 200AP.prereqString: Prerequisite:  Knowledge of basic statistics and linear algebra

STATS 200B.name: Intermediate Probability and Statistical Theory
STATS 200B.description: Random samples, transformations, limit laws, normal distribution theory, introduction to stochastic processes, data reduction, point estimation (maximum likelihood).

STATS 200BP.name: Intermediate Probability and Statistical Theory II
STATS 200BP.description: Fundamental theory and methods for statistical inference. Topics include data reduction (sufficient, ancillary, and complete statistics), estimation (method of moments, maximum likelihood estimators, Bayes estimators), evaluating methods (mean squared error, best unbiased estimators, asymptotic evaluations), hypothesis testing, and confidence intervals.
STATS 200BP.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students only. Graduate students only.

STATS 200C.name: Intermediate Probability and Statistical Theory
STATS 200C.description: Interval estimation, hypothesis testing, decision theory and Bayesian inference, basic linear model theory.

STATS 201.name: Statistical Methods for Data Analysis I
STATS 201.description: Introduction to statistical methods for analyzing data from experiments and surveys. Methods covered include two-sample procedures, analysis of variance, simple and multiple linear regression.
STATS 201.restriction: Restriction: STATS 201 cannot be taken for credit after taking STATS 210.

STATS 202.name: Statistical Methods for Data Analysis II
STATS 202.description: Introduction to statistical methods for analyzing data from surveys or experiments. Emphasizes application and understanding of methods for categorical data including contingency tables, logistic and Poisson regression, loglinear models.

STATS 203.name: Statistical Methods for Data Analysis III
STATS 203.description: Introduction to statistical methods for analyzing longitudinal data from experiments and cohort studies. Topics covered include survival methods for censored time-to-event data, linear mixed models, non-linear mixed effects models, and generalized estimating equations.

STATS 205.name: Introduction to Bayesian Data Analysis
STATS 205.description: Basic Bayesian concepts and methods with emphasis on data analysis.  Special emphasis on specification of prior distributions.  Development for one-two samples and on to binary, Poisson and linear regression.  Analyses performed using free OpenBugs software.
STATS 205.prereqString: Prerequisite: STATS 120C. Recommended: STATS 201 or STATS 210.

STATS 205P.name: Bayesian Data Analysis
STATS 205P.description: Covers basic Bayesian concepts and methods with emphasis on data analysis. Special emphasis on specification of prior distributions. Development of methods and theory for one and two samples, binary, Poisson, and linear regression.
STATS 205P.prereqString: Prerequisite: STATS 200AP and STATS 200BP and STATS 210P
STATS 205P.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students only. Graduate students only.

STATS 210.name: Statistical Methods I: Linear Models
STATS 210.description: Statistical methods for analyzing data from surveys and experiments. Topics include randomization and model-based inference, two-sample methods, analysis of variance, linear regression and model diagnostics.
STATS 210.prereqString: Prerequisite: Knowledge of basic statistics, calculus, linear algebra.

STATS 210A.name: Statistical Methods I: Linear Models
STATS 210A.description: Statistical methods for analyzing data from surveys and experiments. Topics include randomization and model-based inference, two-sample methods, analysis of variance, linear regression, and model diagnostics.
STATS 210A.prereqString: Prerequisite:  Knowledge of basic statistics (at the level of STATS 7), calculus, and linear algebra.

STATS 210B.name: Statistical Methods II: Categorical Data
STATS 210B.description: Introduction to statistical methods for analyzing discrete and non-normal outcomes. Emphasizes the development and application of methods for categorical data, including contingency tables, logistic and Poisson regression, loglinear models.
STATS 210B.prereqString: Prerequisite: STATS 210. May not be taken for graduate credit by Ph.D. students in Statistics.

STATS 210C.name: Statistical Methods III: Longitudinal Data
STATS 210C.description: Introduction to statistical methods for analyzing longitudinal outcomes. Emphasizes the development and application of regression methods for correlated and censored outcomes. Methods for continuous and discrete correlated outcomes, as well as censored outcomes, are covered.
STATS 210C.prereqString: Prerequisite: STATS 210B. May not be taken for graduate credit by Ph.D. students in Statistics.

STATS 210P.name: Statistical Methods I
STATS 210P.description: Statistical methods for analyzing data from multi-variable observational studies and experiments. Topics include model selection and model diagnostics for simple and multiple linear regression and generalized linear models.
STATS 210P.prereqString: Prerequisite: STATS 200AP and STATS 200BP. Required: Knowledge of basic statistics and linear algebra.
STATS 210P.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students only. Graduate students only.

STATS 211.name: Statistical Methods II: Generalized Linear Models
STATS 211.description: Development of the theory and application of generalized linear models. Topics include likelihood estimation and asymptotic distributional theory for exponential families, quasi-likelihood and mixed model development. Emphasizes methodological development and application to real scientific problems.

STATS 211P.name: Statistical Methods II
STATS 211P.description: Statistical methods for designing experiments, visualizing, and analyzing experimental and observational data using generalized regression models, multivariate analysis, and methods suitable for dependent data.
STATS 211P.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students only. Graduate students only.

STATS 212.name: Statistical Methods III: Methods for Correlated Data
STATS 212.description: Development and application of statistical methods for analyzing corrected data. Topics covered include repeated measures ANOVA, linear mixed models, non-linear mixed effects models, and generalized estimating equations.  Emphasizes both theoretical development and application of the presented methodology.

STATS 220A.name: Advanced Probability and Statistics Topics
STATS 220A.description: Advanced topics in probability and statistical inference including measure theoretic probability, large sample theory, decision theory, resampling and Monte Carlo methods, nonparametric methods.

STATS 220B.name: Advanced Probability and Statistics Topics
STATS 220B.description: Advanced topics in probability and statistical inference, including measure theoretic probability, large sample theory, decision theory, resampling and Monte Carlo methods, nonparametric methods.

STATS 225.name: Bayesian Statistical Analysis
