STATS 225.description: Introduction to the Bayesian approach to statistical inference. Topics include univariate and multivariate models, choice of prior distributions, hierarchical models, computation including Markov chain Monte Carlo, model checking, and model selection.

STATS 226.name: Advanced Topics in Modern Bayesian Statistical Inference
STATS 226.description: Modern Bayesian Statistics: selected topics from theory of Markov chains, application of theory to modern methods of Markov chain Monte Carlo sampling

STATS 230.name: Statistical Computing Methods
STATS 230.description: Numerical computations and algorithms with applications in statistics. Topics include optimization methods including the EM algorithm, random number generation and simulation, Markov chain simulation tools, and numerical integration.
STATS 230.prereqString: Prerequisite: Two quarters of upper-division or graduate training in probability and statistics.

STATS 235.name: Modern Data Analysis Methods
STATS 235.description: Introduces selected modern tools for data analysis. Emphasizes use of computational and resampling techniques for data analyses when the data do not conform to standard toolbox of regression models and/or complexity of modeling problem threatens validity of standard methods.
STATS 235.prereqString: Prerequisite: STATS 120C and STATS 205 and (STATS 201 or STATS 210)

STATS 240.name: Multivariate Statistical Methods
STATS 240.description: Theory and application of multivariate statistical methods. Topics include statistical inference for the multivariate normal model and its extensions to multiple samples and regression, use of statistical packages for data visualization and reduction, discriminant analysis, cluster analysis, and factor analysis.
STATS 240.prereqString: Prerequisite: STATS 120C and (MATH 3A or I&C SCI 6N)

STATS 240P.name: Multivariate Statistical Methods
STATS 240P.description: Theory and application of multivariate statistical methods. Topics include statistical inference for the multivariate normal model and its extensions to multiple samples and regression, use of statistical packages for data visualization and dimension reduction, discriminant analysis, cluster analysis, factor analysis.
STATS 240P.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students only. Graduate students only.

STATS 245.name: Time Series Analysis
STATS 245.description: Statistical models for analysis of time series from time and frequency domain perspectives. Emphasizes theory and application of time series data analysis methods. Topics include ARMA/ARIMA models, model identification/estimation, linear operators, Fourier analysis, spectral estimation, state space models, Kalman filter.

STATS 245P.name: Time Series Analysis
STATS 245P.description: Statistical models for time series. Topics include linear models for trends
STATS 245P.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students only. Graduate students only.

STATS 250.name: Biostatistics
STATS 250.description: Statistical methods commonly used to analyze data arising from clinical studies. Topics include analysis of observational studies and randomized clinical trials, techniques in the analysis of survival and longitudinal data, approaches to handling missing data, meta-analysis, nonparametric methods.

STATS 255.name: Statistical Methods for Survival Data
STATS 255.description: Statistical methods for analyzing survival data from cohort studies. Topics include parametric and nonparametric methods, the Kaplan-Meier estimator, log-rank tests, regression models, the Cox proportional hazards model and accelerated failure time models, efficient sampling designs, discrete survival models.
STATS 255.prereqString:
Corequisite: STATS 202 or STATS 211.
Prerequisite: STATS 210

STATS 257.name: Introduction to Statistical Genetics
STATS 257.description: Provides students with knowledge of the basic principles, concepts, and methods used in statistical genetic research. Topics include principles of population genetics, and statistical methods for family- and population-based studies.
STATS 257.prereqString: Prerequisite: Two quarters of upper-division or graduate training in statistical methods.

STATS 260.name: Inference with Missing Data
STATS 260.description: Statistical methods and theory useful for analysis of multivariate data with partially observed variables. Bayesian and likelihood-based methods developed. Topics include EM-type algorithms, MCMC samplers, multiple imputation, and general location model. Applications from economics, education, and medicine are discussed.

STATS 262.name: Theory and Practice of Sample Surveys
STATS 262.description: Basic techniques and statistical methods used in designing surveys and analyzing collected survey data. Topics include simple random sampling, ratio and regression estimates, stratified sampling, cluster sampling, sampling with unequal probabilities, multistage sampling, and methods to handle nonresponse.

STATS 262P.name: Theory and Practice of Sample Survey
STATS 262P.description: Basic techniques and statistical methods for designing surveys and analyzing collected survey data. Topics include simple random sampling, ratio and regression estimates, stratified sampling, cluster sampling, sampling with unequal probabilities, multistage sampling, and methods to handle nonresponse.
STATS 262P.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students only. Graduate students only.

STATS 265.name: Causal Inference
STATS 265.description: Various approaches to causal inference focusing on the Rubin causal model and propensity-score methods. Topics include randomized experiments, observational studies, non-compliance, ignorable and non-ignorable treatment assignment, instrumental variables, and sensitivity analysis. Applications from economics, politics, education, and medicine.

STATS 270.name: Stochastic Processes
STATS 270.description: Introduction to the theory and application of stochastic processes. Topics include Markov chains, continuous-time Markov processes, Poisson processes, and Brownian motion. Applications include Markov chain Monte Carlo methods and financial modeling (for example, option pricing).

STATS 270P.name: Stochastic Processes
STATS 270P.description: Introduction to the theory and application of stochastic processes. Topics include Poisson processes, Markov chains, continuous-time Markov processes, and Brownian motion. Applications include Markov chain Monte Carlo methods and financial modeling (e.g. option pricing).
STATS 270P.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students only. Graduate students only.

STATS 275.name: Statistical Consulting
STATS 275.description: Training in collaborative research and practical application of statistics. Emphasis on effective communication as it relates to identifying scientific objectives, formulating a statistical analysis plan, choice of statistical methods, and interpretation of results and their limitations to non-statisticians.
STATS 275.prereqString: Prerequisite: STATS 203 or STATS 212 or STATS 210C. STATS 203 with a grade of B or better. STATS 212 with a grade of B or better. STATS 210C with a grade of B or better

STATS 280.name: Seminar in Statistics
STATS 280.description: Periodic seminar series covering topics of current research in statistics and its application.

STATS 281A.name: Introduction to Probability and Statistics I
STATS 281A.description: Introduction to basic principles of probability and statistical inference. Axiomatic definition of probability, random variables, probability distributions, expectation.

STATS 281B.name: Introduction to Probability and Statistics II
STATS 281B.description: Introduction to basic principles of probability and statistical inference. Point estimation, interval estimating, and testing hypotheses, Bayesian approaches to inference.

STATS 281C.name: Introduction to Probability and Statistics III
STATS 281C.description: Introduction to basic principles of probability and statistical inference. Contingency table analysis, linear regression, analysis of variance, model checking.

STATS 295.name: Special Topics in Statistics
STATS 295.description: Studies in selected areas of statistics. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

STATS 298.name: Thesis Supervision
STATS 298.description: Individual research or investigation conducted in preparation for the M.S. thesis option or the dissertation requirements for the Ph.D. program.

STATS 299.name: Individual Study
STATS 299.description: Individual research or investigation under the direction of an individual faculty member.

SWE 211.name: Software Engineering
SWE 211.description: Study of the concepts, methods, and tools for the analysis, design, construction, and measurement of complex software-intensive systems. Underlying principles emphasized. State-of-the-art software engineering and promising research areas covered, including project management.

SWE 212.name: Analysis of Programming Languages
SWE 212.description: Concepts in modern programming languages, their interaction, and the relationship between programming languages and methods for large-scale, extensible software development. Empirical analysis of programming language usage.

SWE 213.name: Requirements Engineering and Specification
SWE 213.description: Rigorous techniques in requirements engineering - the requirements definition phase of software development - with a focus on modeling and specification. Topics include notations and models for requirements specification

SWE 214.name: Program Analysis
SWE 214.description: Covers principles and concepts of automated program analysis. Topics include program representations
SWE 214.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Graduate students only.

SWE 215.name: Software Analysis and Testing
SWE 215.description: Studies techniques for developing confidence in software from traditional testing schemes to integrated, multitechnique analytic approaches. Considers strengths and weaknesses and explores opportunities for synergistic technique application. Emphasis is on approaches integrated into the software process.

SWE 221.name: Software Architecture
SWE 221.description: Study of the concepts, representation techniques, development methods, and tools for architecture-centric software engineering. Topics include domain-specific software architectures, architectural styles, architecture description languages, software connectors, and dynamism in architectures.

SWE 225.name: Information Retrieval, Filtering, and Classification
SWE 225.description: Algorithms for the storage, retrieval, filtering, and classification of textual and multimedia data. The vector space model, Boolean and probabilistic queries, and relevance feedback. Latent semantic indexing
SWE 225.prereqString: Prerequisite: CS 161 and CS 171 and (ICS 6N or MATH 3A or MATH 6G)

SWE 233.name: Intelligent User Interfaces
SWE 233.description: Explores example software systems and their underlying concepts that leverage computing to empower and augment human individuals in their activities. Topics span the fields of user interface design, human-computer interaction, software engineering, and cognitive computing.

SWE 234.name: Human Aspects of Software Engineering
SWE 234.description: Selected topics about the cooperative and human aspects of software engineering from the perspective that software engineering is inherently an endeavor involving human stakeholders. Topics may include but are not limited to collaboration, trust, emotion, language, gender, and software tools.
SWE 234.restriction: Restriction: School of Info & Computer Sci students have first consideration for enrollment. Graduate students only.

SWE 241P.name: Applied Data Structures and Algorithms
SWE 241P.description: Exploration of strategies to tackle computational problems whose solutions include well-known algorithms and data structures. Topics include sorting, searching, indexing, among others.
SWE 241P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Software Engineering Degree students only.

SWE 242P.name: Network Programming
SWE 242P.description: Exploration of networking principles and concepts for the development of distributed software. Topics include programming against well-known network protocols, ports and sockets, and network APIs.
SWE 242P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Software Engineering Degree students only.

SWE 243P.name: Database Programming
SWE 243P.description: Exploration of software development with substantial reliance on a database for storage and retrieval of data. Topics include relational databases, structured query language, relational database management systems, APIs and libraries for database programming, among others.
SWE 243P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Software Engineering Degree students only.

SWE 244P.name: Concurrent Programming
SWE 244P.description: Exploration of concepts and mechanisms for the development of concurrent software.  Topics include threads, locks, race conditions, and deadlocks, among others.
SWE 244P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Software Engineering Degree students only. Graduate students only.

SWE 245P.name: GUI Programming
SWE 245P.description: Exploration of interactive software with substantial graphical user interface elements.  Topics include libraries and frameworks for GUI programming, layout design and alternatives, event-driven programming, among others.
SWE 245P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Software Engineering Degree students only. Graduate students only.

SWE 246P.name: Mobile Programming
SWE 246P.description: Exploration of contemporary libraries and frameworks for construction of mobile applications. Topics include emulators, mobile development standards and patterns, energy consumption issues, screen layout, among others.
SWE 246P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Software Engineering Degree students only. Graduate students only.

SWE 247P.name: Applied Information Retrieval
SWE 247P.description: Exploration of principles and concepts for textual information retrieval. Topics include tokenization, inverted indexes, scored retrieval, and precision and recall.
SWE 247P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Software Engineering Degree students only. Graduate students only.

SWE 248P.name: Neural Network Programming
SWE 248P.description: Exploration of the concepts, terminology, and processes for training and using deep neural networks for classification problems. Topics include tensors and tensor operations, gradient-based optimization, feature engineering and learning, and workflow of learning systems.
SWE 248P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Software Engineering Degree students only. Graduate students only.

SWE 249P.name: Applied Data Analytics
SWE 249P.description: Exploration of the concepts, terminology, and processes used in supervised and unsupervised learning for classification and clustering, from a software engineering perspective. Topics include K-Nearest Neighbors, Logistic Regression, Random Forests, Support Vector Machines, K-Means, and model assessment.
SWE 249P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Software Engineering Degree students only.

SWE 250P.name: Web Programming
SWE 250P.description: Exploration of the concepts, terminology, and popular frameworks for developing full-stack web applications. Students develop simple applications using multiple development stacks, and deploy them on the cloud.
SWE 250P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Software Engineering Degree students only.

SWE 261P.name: Software Testing and Debugging
SWE 261P.description: Designed to teach students how to ensure high-quality software by means of testing, debugging, and other quality assurance activities. Students learn a combination of both theoretical and practical skills, including hands-on experience with modern tools and approaches.
SWE 261P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Software Engineering Degree students only. Graduate students only.

SWE 262P.name: Programming Styles
SWE 262P.description: Designed to teach students the various ways software can be decomposed and put back together. Students are exposed to a variety of different programming styles and composition mechanisms.
SWE 262P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Software Engineering Degree students only. Graduate students only.

SWE 263P.name: User Experience and Interaction
SWE 263P.description: Provides an introduction to the basic principles of human-computer interaction (HCI) and the pragmatic aspects of usability engineering. Topics include the fundamentals of interaction, user experience, design for usability, and evaluation of products for their usability.
SWE 263P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Software Engineering Degree students only. Graduate students only.

SWE 264P.name: Distributed Software Architecture
SWE 264P.description: Study of software system architectures and architectural styles for large-scale distributed applications, and contemporary technologies and standards for their construction. Topics include client-server, peer-to-peer, publish-subscribe, REST, cloud computing, content distribution networks, scalability, latency, caching, and security, among others.
SWE 264P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Software Engineering Degree students only.

SWE 265P.name: Reverse Engineering and Modeling
SWE 265P.description: Introduces theories, concepts, representations, techniques, and case studies in understanding large-scale, complex software systems. Topics include static and dynamic modeling notations, manual and (semi-)automated reverse engineering techniques, APIs, patterns, and styles. A significant, hands-on project is included.
SWE 265P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Software Engineering Degree students only. Graduate students only.

SWE 266P.name: Software Security and Dependability
SWE 266P.description: Principles and concepts for the design and construction of secure software. Topics include common types of software security vulnerabilities, methods for detecting vulnerabilities, design and process methodologies to improve security of software, and techniques for assessing security properties of software.
SWE 266P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Software Engineering Degree students only. Graduate students only.

SWE 271P.name: Career and Entrepreneurship
SWE 271P.description: Teaches practical skills for spoken, written, and electronic communication in a range of business and technical contexts, including promoting project ideas and portfolio development. Students practice their skills in classroom presentations and written exercises.
SWE 271P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Software Engineering Degree students only. Graduate students only.

SWE 272P.name: Project Management
SWE 272P.description: Provides an introduction to project management in software engineering from several perspectives. Topics include team behavior
SWE 272P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Software Engineering Degree students only. Graduate students only.

SWE 275P.name: Curricular Practical Training
SWE 275P.description: Mandatory internship in which students individually work at an outside organization to gain experience with the challenges involved in the practice of software engineering.
SWE 275P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Software Engineering Degree students only. Graduate students only.

SWE 276P.name: Capstone Project in Software Engineering
SWE 276P.description: Quarter-long software-intensive project focusing on the design and implementation of a novel software system. Students are expected to bring to bear the concepts acquired during the program.
SWE 276P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Software Engineering Degree students only. Graduate students only.

SWE 290.name: Research Seminar
SWE 290.description: Forum for presentation and criticism by students of research work in progress. Presentation of problem areas and related work. Specific goals and progress of research.

SWE 290P.name: Advisement
SWE 290P.description: Mandatory weekly meetings with a faculty advisor.
SWE 290P.restriction: Restriction: Master of Software Engineering Degree students only. Graduate students only.

SWE 295.name: Special Topics in Software Engineering
SWE 295.description: Studies in selected areas of software engineering. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

SWE 298.name: Thesis Supervision
SWE 298.description: Individual research or investigation conducted in preparation for the M.S. thesis option or the dissertation requirements for the Ph.D. program.

SWE 299.name: Individual Study
SWE 299.description: Individual research or investigation under the direction of an individual faculty member.

UCDC 170.name: Washington DC Internship
UCDC 170.description: Supervised internship (20-40 hours per week) in Washington DC government, nonprofit, or private institution consistent with student's interest.
UCDC 170.prereqString:
Corequisite: UCDC 180
Prerequisite: Selected for Washington DC Center Program.

UCDC 180.name: Washington-Themed Seminar
UCDC 180.description: UCDC core course (multiple topics offered each quarter). Enhances students' experiential learning and imparts knowledge and skills to help them transition into public service/private sector positions. One core course per quarter mandatory for all participants in Washington DC Center Program.
UCDC 180.prereqString: Prerequisite: Selected for Washington DC Center Program.

UCDC 190.name: Washington DC Elective
UCDC 190.description: Studies in selected areas related to the UC Washington, DC Center Program (UCDC).
UCDC 190.prereqString: Prerequisite: Selected for Washington DC Center Program.

UNI AFF 1A.name: Student Participation
UNI AFF 1A.description: Campus projects with a University department to enrich academic growth and development as well as academic growth and development of UCI. Includes 30 hours per quarter working on proposed project under faculty/staff supervision. Paper required.
UNI AFF 1A.prereqString: Prerequisite: Project must be approved by a Student Affairs Department head and the instructor.

UNI AFF 1B.name: Student Participation
UNI AFF 1B.description: Campus projects with a University department to enrich academic growth and development as well as academic growth and development of UCI. Includes 30 hours per quarter working on proposed project under faculty/staff supervision. Paper required.

UNI AFF 1C.name: Student Participation
UNI AFF 1C.description: Campus projects with a University department to enrich academic growth and development as well as academic growth and development of UCI. Includes 30 hours per quarter working on proposed project under faculty/staff supervision. Paper required.

UNI STU 1.name: Freshman Experience
UNI STU 1.description: An introduction to the freshman experience provides an overview of the University's aims and resources and exploration of developmental theories and skills necessary for academic success. Attention is also paid to questions of personal development and major choice.  Materials fee.

UNI STU 3.name: Mini-Seminars
UNI STU 3.description: Designed primarily for freshmen as introduction to scholarly inquiry. Each section is taught by a faculty member from one of the academic disciplines and presents interesting and challenging topics representing the instructor's interest. Students participate in discussions, presentations, and projects.

UNI STU 6.name: University Studies International Village Seminar
UNI STU 6.description: Seminars held in International Village that are specifically designed to either (a) introduce visiting international students to the U.S. and/or local area and institutions or (b) engage both international and U.S. students in discussion of topics of international interest.

UNI STU 7.name: UTeach: Student-Taught Seminar
UNI STU 7.description: Student-taught seminar courses on selected topics. Topics vary each year according to the interest of the students teaching the classes.

UNI STU 10.name: Introduction to Civic and Community Engagement and Community Research
UNI STU 10.description: Provides a foundation for understanding the role of public scholarship, civic engagement, and social action, and the relationship between service learning and engaged citizenship. Introduces key theoretical and research methodologies on the traditions and innovations of civic and community engagement.

UNI STU 13C.name: Introduction to Global Sustainability III
UNI STU 13C.description: Introduces Earth as a system and living planet. Examines physical and biological resources as well as energy, water, climate, and ecosystems. Introduces and applies analytic lens of environmental, social, and economic sustainability to examine human impacts and resource use.

UNI STU H30A.name: Critical Analysis of Health Science Literature
UNI STU H30A.description: Focuses on evaluation of scientific literature. Aspects of scientific inquiry include scientific method, scientific research design, statistical analysis, and publication processes. Addresses why scientific inquiry cannot be separated from sociocultural influences and concerns. Examples drawn from research on health-related issues.
UNI STU H30A.restriction: Restriction: Campuswide Honors Collegium students only.

UNI STU H30B.name: Environmental Issues Affecting the Sustainability of Societies I
UNI STU H30B.description: Focuses on several environmental challenges facing the world today, and explores the problem, possible solutions, and their scientific, technical, and social constraints. Models for systems, their assumptions, predictive uncertainty, and interpretation, play a large role.
UNI STU H30B.prereqString: Prerequisite: UNI STU H30A. UNI STU H30A with a grade of C or better
UNI STU H30B.restriction: Restriction: Campuswide Honors Collegium students only.

UNI STU H30C.name: Environmental Issues Affecting the Sustainability of Societies II
UNI STU H30C.description: Focuses on how we can use Earth’s resources, e.g., food and water, in a more sustainable way, exploring their scientific, technical, and social constraints.
UNI STU H30C.prereqString: Prerequisite: UNI STU H30B. UNI STU H30B with a grade of C or better
UNI STU H30C.restriction: Restriction: Campuswide Honors Collegium students only.

UNI STU H30D.name: Social Science Perspectives on the Sustainability of Societies
UNI STU H30D.description: Introduces the perspectives of social science using examples from different countries to explore how social issues regarding sustainability are influenced by a society’s changing economic and political institutions, and how economic, political, and other social choices affect their sustainability.
UNI STU H30D.prereqString: Prerequisite: EARTHSS H30C. EARTHSS H30C with a grade of C or better
UNI STU H30D.restriction: Restriction: Campuswide Honors Collegium students only.

UNI STU H30E.name: Cities: Focal Point for Sustainability Problems and Solutions I
UNI STU H30E.description: Explores the nature of cities, focusing on the challenges facing cities today, their possible solutions, and the technical and social constraints on those solutions.
UNI STU H30E.restriction: Restriction: Campuswide Honors Collegium students only.

UNI STU H30F.name: Cities: Focal Point for Sustainability Problems and Solutions II
UNI STU H30F.description: Explores the nature of cities, focusing on the challenges facing cities today, their possible solutions, and the technical and social constraints on those solutions.
UNI STU H30F.restriction: Restriction: Campuswide Honors Collegium students only.

UNI STU 43.name: Topics in Illuminations
UNI STU 43.description: This course connects students to Illuminations, the Chancellor’s Arts and Culture Initiative. Students will attend five Illuminations-sponsored events and engage in brief preparatory and reflective activities in response to these events.

UNI STU 45.name: Graduate School Opportunities and Preparation
UNI STU 45.description: Explores the opportunities associated with graduate school by considering a wide range of disciplines and career paths. Reviews professional and academic paths in graduate school and the ways to prepare for a chosen path.

UNI STU H80.name: Neurodivergent
UNI STU H80.description: Examines the evolution of the diagnosis of autism through history. Deep inquiry of the neuroscience, etiology, and genetics of neurodivergent individuals as well as a review of the validity of the varied treatments will inform critical thinking.
UNI STU H80.restriction: Restriction: Campuswide Honors Collegium students only.

UNI STU 83.name: Pathways to University Success
UNI STU 83.description: Helps first-year students transition to UC Irvine and promotes a successful University experience. Students learn about academic resources and programs that support acclimation to the campus and enhance academic development through lectures, discussions, and a range of co-curricular activities.

UNI STU 84.name: Bridges to University Success
UNI STU 84.description: Helps first-year students transition to UC Irvine and promotes a successful University experience. Students learn about academic resources/programs that support acclimation to the campus and enhance academic development through lectures, writing laboratories, discussions, and a range of co-curricular activities.

UNI STU 85A.name: Leading from Within
UNI STU 85A.description: Students examine characteristics and behaviors of effective leaders. Study the history and theoretical framework for understanding effective leadership. In addition, examine their own leadership strengths and weakness and become familiar with the theory behind and use of comprehensive self-assessment tools.

UNI STU 85B.name: Leading Others
UNI STU 85B.description: Students examine best practices within a team environment. They learn goal setting, diagnosing performance problems, designing solutions, and recognizing relevant differences in culture, priorities, and values within a team through lectures, writing, discussions, and practical activities.

UNI STU 85C.name: Leading Change
UNI STU 85C.description: Focused on a global viewpoint, students learn the theoretical framework behind innovation and change management. Develop innovative solutions to real-world challenges, design strategies to bring an expansive vision into fruition, and learn to communicate a vision and strategies.

UNI STU 93.name: Strategies for Success
UNI STU 93.description: Designed to develop good study skills in technical fields and the participation of students as active learners in their education. Topics include time management, analytical thinking, text analysis, academic survival strategies, and goal setting.

UNI STU 100.name: Doing Research in the Community
UNI STU 100.description: Critically reimagines the research endeavor and its participants/outcomes. Grapples with methods, values, and relationships involved in research. Explores alternative conceptions of research

UNI STU 110.name: Philanthropy in the Community
UNI STU 110.description: Introduces the role of community engagement, social action and philanthropy. Examines theories and practices of philanthropy, and strategies for social change. Involves hand-on engagement with philanthropy in the form of students making decisions about the distribution of a real fund.

UNI STU 170.name: Advanced Internship in Undergraduate Education
UNI STU 170.description: Advanced interns have a year's internship experience and return to contribute to Undergraduate Education programs in a leadership position. Students work three-five hours per week in a DUE office to coordinate or lead less-experienced interns and/or events.
UNI STU 170.prereqString: Prerequisite: UNI AFF 1A and UNI AFF 1B and UNI AFF 1C

UNI STU 175.name: Methods and Application in Small Group Instruction
UNI STU 175.description: Explores various theories and methods of learning and development and their practical application in small group settings. Peer tutors receive instruction in the design, implementation, and evaluation of an effective learning environment for undergraduate students.
UNI STU 175.restriction: Restriction: Learning and Academic Resource Center employed tutors only.

UNI STU 176.name: Pedagogy of Small Group Facilitation - LAs
UNI STU 176.description: Overview and readings in evidence-based instruction for undergraduate learning assistants. LAs receive instruction, training, and feedback on effective small group facilitation and active learning. To be taken while serving as a learning assistant in a course.

UNI STU H176A.name: Campuswide Honors Thesis Seminar
UNI STU H176A.description: Supports the honors thesis research activities of Campuswide Honors Program students. Students set research goals, discuss, and develop their research interests.
UNI STU H176A.restriction: Restriction: Campuswide Honors Collegium students only.

UNI STU H176C.name: Campuswide Honors Thesis Seminar
UNI STU H176C.description: Supports the honors thesis research activities of Campuswide Honors Program students. Students work with each other to improve both written and spoken presentations of their results.
UNI STU H176C.prereqString:
Corequisite: Students must sign up separately for 8 units of independent study with faculty mentors.
Prerequisite: UNI STU H176A
UNI STU H176C.restriction: Restriction: Campuswide Honors Collegium students only.

UNI STU 181.name: Internship in Civic and Community Engagement
UNI STU 181.description: Provides an opportunity to extend learning into a community-based setting addressing important social, environmental, and public issues. The internship project has a creative and scholarly component where students initiate their own action or inquiry experience.

UNI STU 190.name: Teaching Seminar: Theory and Practice
UNI STU 190.description: For students selected to be discussion leaders for University Studies 2. Models of teaching, developmental theory applied to college freshmen, curriculum development. Practice of teaching techniques and group management skills.

UNI STU 192.name: Group Project for Discussion Leaders
UNI STU 192.description: For discussion leaders for University Studies 2. Weekly discussion group training for leading effective groups in addition to evaluations of weekly discussion sections and completion of a special project on issues of freshman development.  Materials fee.

UNI STU 193.name: Internship
UNI STU 193.description: Enables students from all majors to receive credit for an approved internship on or off-campus.  Internship sites may be public or private, for profit or non-profit agencies, organizations, companies, or corporations offering paid or unpaid learning experiences.

UNI STU 196.name: Directed Studies in Undergraduate Education
UNI STU 196.description: Students do directed study (research, readings, etc.) on a topic related to Undergraduate Education under the supervision of one of the faculty who serve as Deans or Faculty Directors in the Division of Undergraduate Education.

UNI STU 197A.name: UTeach Special Study
UNI STU 197A.description: Students accepted to teach a UTeach course in spring quarter enroll in Special or Independent Study with their faculty mentor during the preceding fall quarter to develop their detailed course syllabus.

UNI STU 197B.name: UTeach: Teaching Theory and Practice
UNI STU 197B.description: Students accepted to teach a UTeach course in spring quarter enroll during the winter to develop their teaching skills in preparation for teaching the following quarter.

UNI STU 197C.name: UTeach: Teaching Practicum
UNI STU 197C.description: Students selected to teach in the UTeach Program teach their courses and meet weekly in a seminar to continue to develop and enhance their teaching skills.

UNI STU 197D.name: Study Abroad Experiential Learning
UNI STU 197D.description: Study abroad on an approved program. Complete critical reflection (written paper, blog, etc.) submitted no later than the end of the quarter following the completion of the study abroad program. Enroll while studying abroad or the quarter immediately following return.

UNI STU 197E.name: Reflections While Abroad
UNI STU 197E.description: For students while they are studying abroad

UNI STU 197F.name: Internship Plus
UNI STU 197F.description: Provides training and development of career readiness competencies in parallel with a student’s internship experience. Internship sites may be public or private, for profit or non-profit agencies, organizations, companies, or corporations offering paid or unpaid learning experiences.

UNI STU 198.name: Mentored Learning Assistant Field Work
UNI STU 198.description: Oversight of trained learning assistants by the course instructor, including training in the discipline and responsibilities associated with supporting active group work. Instructor mentors LAs in how assisting small groups supports their career goals.

UNI STU 231.name: NIH Fellowship Writing Skills
UNI STU 231.description: Designed for graduate students in biomedical science departments who are preparing to write applications for NRSA (F30/F31) fellowships from the NIH. It involves a mixture of lectures, panel discussions, and peer review of writing samples.

UNI STU 296.name: Graduate Legal Studies
UNI STU 296.description: Monthly faculty/student colloquium to present and discuss socio-legal related research/issues. Course convened by Law School faculty with other faculty participation. Required for PLGS students enrolled in Law portion of degree.
UNI STU 296.restriction: Restriction: Graduate students only. Law students only.

UNI STU 297.name: California Community College Internship
UNI STU 297.description: The California Community College Internship offers graduate students the opportunity to learn about faculty life, governance, and teaching at local community colleges. Structures fieldwork for students to participate in and reflect on the educational mission of community colleges.
UNI STU 297.restriction: Restriction: MFA or Doctoral students who have advanced to candidacy.

UNI STU 390A.name: Advanced Pedagogy and Academic Job Preparation
UNI STU 390A.description: Focuses on advanced pedagogical research and practices. Students design and implement an integrated curriculum in the context of the TA Professional Development Program. Prepare for the academic job market by developing application materials and reviewing Pedagogical Fellow applicants.
UNI STU 390A.restriction: Restriction: Must be a pedagogical fellow.

UNI STU 390B.name: Advanced Pedagogy and Academic Job Preparation
UNI STU 390B.description: Focuses on advanced pedagogical research and practices. Students design and implement an integrated curriculum in the context of the TA Professional Development Program. Prepare for the academic job market by developing application materials and reviewing Pedagogical Fellow applicants.
UNI STU 390B.restriction: Restriction: Must be a pedagogical fellow.

UNI STU 390C.name: Advanced Pedagogy and Academic Job Preparation
UNI STU 390C.description: Focuses on advanced pedagogical research and practices. Students design and implement an integrated curriculum in the context of the TA Professional Development Program. Prepare for the academic job market by developing application materials and reviewing Pedagogical Fellow applicants.
UNI STU 390C.restriction: Restriction: Must be a pedagogical fellow.

UNI STU 390X.name: Developing Teaching Excellence
UNI STU 390X.description: An introduction to evidence-based instructional design and methods, specifically for higher education courses. Students practice, observe, and design instruction based on pedagogical literature. Meets most of the requirements for the Certificate in Teaching Excellence Program.

UNI STU 390Z.name: Advanced Course Design for Instructors of Record
UNI STU 390Z.description: Confirmed instructors of record who have earned the Certificate in Teaching Excellence design their course (syllabus, lesson plans, activities, assessments, assignments) using best practices in pedagogy. By the end of the course, participants have their full course mapped.
UNI STU 390Z.prereqString: Prerequisite: Certificate of Teaching Excellence required, proof of instructor of record appointment required.

UNI STU 395.name: Seminar for Teaching as Research
UNI STU 395.description: Preparation and implementation of a teaching as research project in higher education. Participants learn research, experimental design, human subjects, and statistical analysis.

UPPP 4.name: Introduction to Urban Studies
UPPP 4.description: Introduces the substantive areas, concepts, and tools in the field of urban studies.  Acquaints students with physical, environmental, social, economic, and political dimensions of cities.  Examines the challenges facing cities, including poverty, sustainability, development, globalization, and others.
UPPP 4.restriction: Restriction: School of Social Ecology students have first consideration for enrollment. Urban Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

UPPP 5.name: Introduction to Urban Planning and Policy
UPPP 5.description: Introduces students to the basic issues in urban planning and public policy.

UPPP 8.name: Introduction to Environmental Analysis and Design
UPPP 8.description: Overview of general concepts, theoretical principles, and analytical techniques for investigating environmental systems. Integrates tools from natural and social sciences to analyze contemporary environmental challenges such as pollution, resource acquisition, facility and ecosystem design, impact assessments, formulation of environmental policy.

UPPP 40.name: Urban Sociology
UPPP 40.description: Overview of theoretical, substantive, and policy issues in urban sociology.  History of urbanization, the school of human ecology, and recent trends regarding urbanism.  Time is devoted to understanding the causes and possible solutions to urban problems.

UPPP 100.name: Special Topics in Urban Studies
UPPP 100.description: Course content varies with interest of the instructor.
UPPP 100.restriction: Restriction: Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Urban Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

UPPP 101.name: History of Cities
UPPP 101.description: Surveys the global and historical co-evolution of cities and social institutions, including religion, the economy, governance, the arts, technology, and family life.

UPPP 102.name: Urban Inequality
UPPP 102.description: Examines structural inequality and the influence that urbanization has in affecting race, ethnic, and class relations. Explores how race/ethnicity, class, urban space, housing, economic development, public education, and land policy intersect in cities, both historically and today.
UPPP 102.restriction: Restriction: Public Health Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Urban Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

UPPP 103.name: Comparative Approaches to Urban Regions
UPPP 103.description: An introduction to comparative urbanization in developing countries. Introduces students to the geography, history, and theories of urbanization, and then reviews urban planning, public policy, and governance.
UPPP 103.restriction: Restriction: Public Health Policy Majors only. Social Ecology Majors only. Urban Studies Majors only.

UPPP 104.name: Urban America
UPPP 104.description: Students examine the historical, social, political, and economic factors that contributed to the construction of the American urban context, one that is poverty concentrated and racially/ethnically segregated. Students also critically assess the consequence of growing up in America's urban neighborhoods.

UPPP 107.name: Urban and Regional Planning
UPPP 107.description: Important substantive areas, concepts, tools in the field of urban and regional planning. Topics include: forces that have historically guided and are currently guiding U.S. urbanization
UPPP 107.restriction: Restriction: Environmental Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Earth System Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Urban Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

UPPP 108.name: Cities and Transportation
UPPP 108.description: The relationship between urban areas and transportation systems. Economic analysis of cities, transportation and urban form, highway congestion, environmental impacts of transportation, public transit, land use and transportation, and political influences on transportation planning.
UPPP 108.restriction: Restriction: Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Urban Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

UPPP 109.name: Housing and Urban Development Policy
UPPP 109.description: Surveys public policy issues and develops analytic techniques in the areas of housing and urban development. Examines a range of policy topics including housing assistance to low- and moderate-income families, housing finance system, incentives for economic development, and neighborhood preservation.
UPPP 109.prereqString: Prerequisite: Recommended: Previous course work in economics.
UPPP 109.restriction: Restriction: Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Urban Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

UPPP 110.name: Urban Economic Development Policy
UPPP 110.description: Theoretical and practical perspectives on local economic development policy.  Integrates economic, planning, and political perspectives. Overview of economic role of cities and metropolitan areas. Specific development issues include: link between taxes, regulation, job growth
UPPP 110.restriction: Restriction: Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Urban Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

UPPP 111.name: Climate Solutions
UPPP 111.description: Focuses on carbon neutrality and climate stability, addressing.

UPPP 112.name: Foundations of Community Health
UPPP 112.description: A social ecological framework for understanding community health is presented. Measures of individual and community health are compared, and the influence of personal and environmental factors on individual, group, and population health is examined. Community health promotion strategies are discussed.
UPPP 112.restriction: Restriction: Public Health Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Public Health Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Urban Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

UPPP 113.name: Poverty and Change in Developing Countries
UPPP 113.description: Focuses on poverty in developing countries.  Analyzes the magnitude and changing nature of poverty in the global south. Critically examines poverty conceptualized in terms of economic deprivation, well-being, and social exclusion.
UPPP 113.restriction: Restriction: Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Urban Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

UPPP 114W.name: Advanced Research Methods
UPPP 114W.description: For students planning to conduct senior research projects or apply to graduate school in social research fields. Topics include reviewing literature, preparing a research proposal, protecting human subjects, citing scholarly work, building measures, estimating sample size, interview and presentation skills.
UPPP 114W.prereqString: Prerequisite: SE 10 and SE 13. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

UPPP 115.name: Global Poverty and Inequality in the 21st Century
UPPP 115.description: Explores a multidisciplinary understanding of poverty and inequality in the 21st century and assesses impact of education, health, technology, and other interventions. Course offered online only.

UPPP 117.name: Environmental Justice
UPPP 117.description: Engages students to critically analyze and evaluate environmental problems, environmental responses, and planning and policy debates regarding "environmental justice" - essentially the race, class, and equity implications of environmental problems and policies.

UPPP 118.name: Gentrification
UPPP 118.description: Gentrification is a complex process that changes the makeup of neighborhoods and fuels political and policy conflicts. Students are provided with tools to understand the process and conceive of policies to ensure more inclusive and equitable cities.

UPPP 120.name: Introduction to GIS for Planning and Policy
UPPP 120.description: Provides hands-on experience creating, visualizing, and interpreting spatial data, with a focus on Geographic Information Systems (GIS) applications for urban planning and public policy.

UPPP 125.name: Advanced Geographic Information Systems (GIS)
UPPP 125.description: Provides hands-on experience using geoprocessing to analyze spatial data and using maps to visualize and communicate findings, with a focus on Geographic Information Systems (GIS) applications for urban planning and public policy.
UPPP 125.prereqString: Prerequisite: UPPP 120. UPPP 120 with a grade of C or better
UPPP 125.restriction: Restriction: Urban Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

UPPP 127.name: Spatial Analysis Project
UPPP 127.description: As the capstone in the Geographic Information Systems (GIS) degree specialization, students are guided through the process of applying their GIS skills to designing and conducting an original spatial research project, focusing on research design and research methods.
UPPP 127.prereqString: Prerequisite: UPPP 125 and UPPP 120. UPPP 125 with a grade of C or better. UPPP 120 with a grade of C or better

UPPP 129.name: American Public Policy
UPPP 129.description: Focuses on the development and implementation of public policy in the United States. Lectures cover theoretical models of the policy process as well as significant problems facing contemporary American decision-makers.

UPPP 130.name: Cities and Food
UPPP 130.description: Explores the role of cities in transforming global diets: how urbanization has shaped what and how we eat, and what the co-evolution of diets and city life portend for the future.

UPPP 131.name: Environmental Sustainability I
UPPP 131.description: Provides an introduction to sustainability from different points of view
UPPP 131.restriction: Restriction: Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Urban Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

UPPP 132.name: Environmental Sustainability II
UPPP 132.description: Investigates how sustainability can be implemented in a variety of contexts including water, energy, non-renewable resources, biodiversity, and urban policy, and also how it could be measured.
UPPP 132.restriction: Restriction: Environmental Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Earth System Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Urban Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

UPPP 133.name: Environmental Law and Policy
UPPP 133.description: Environmental law as a combination of traditional legal principles and newly created statutes, rules, and decisions applied to environmental protection. Investigates roles of courts, legislature, executive branch and administrative agencies, and private citizens attempting to regulate environmental quality.
UPPP 133.restriction: Restriction: Criminology, Law and Society Majors only. Urban Studies Majors only.

UPPP 139.name: Water Resource Policy
UPPP 139.description: Examination of contemporary water problems worldwide, with particular attention to the competing water demands in the western U.S., and water demand by the poor in developing countries. History and analysis of U.S. water policies at local, state, and federal levels.
UPPP 139.restriction: Restriction: Environmental Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Earth System Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Urban Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

UPPP 142.name: Environmental Hazards in an Urbanizing World
UPPP 142.description: Development patterns, including urbanization, can contribute to environmental hazard severity. Humans can plan, mitigate, and prepare to reduce costly hazard losses. Students learn about environmental hazards and human response to these threats.

UPPP 145.name: Environmental Governance
UPPP 145.description: How should the environment be managed and who should be responsible? What is effective environmental management, and for whom? These questions are answered by exploring traditional and emerging theoretical frameworks and applying them to real world environmental challenges.

UPPP 146.name: Principles of Economics for Planning and Policy
UPPP 146.description: Provides an introduction into economics for planning and policy students.

UPPP 152.name: Cultural Ecology and Environmental Design
UPPP 152.description: Introduction to cultural ecology and environmental and architectural design. Addresses the understanding of people’s relationships with their built environments, the basic elements of architecture, architectural analysis, and cultural analysis are covered. Examines values in design and design for multicultural societies.
UPPP 152.restriction: Restriction: Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Urban Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

UPPP 153.name: Elements of Environmental Design
UPPP 153.description: Basic elements of environmental design such as scale, proportion, rhythm, color, sound, lighting, surfaces, texture, architectural definition of spaces, volumes, massing volumetric analysis, solids and voids, and cultural aspects of design. Excitement and creativity in design, imageability.
UPPP 153.restriction: Restriction: Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Urban Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

UPPP 155.name: Urban Design Principles
UPPP 155.description: Introduction to principles of urban design and its applications.  Study of contemporary and traditional theories of urban design formulated to improve physical characteristics of built environment to facilitate an enhanced quality of life.  A variety of case studies are discussed.
UPPP 155.restriction: Restriction: Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Urban Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

UPPP 166.name: Urban Politics and Policy
UPPP 166.description: Examines why and how urban policies are enacted and carried out in contemporary U.S. cities and regions. Topics include evolution and organization of city governments and policymaking over the past century

UPPP 167.name: Public Policy and Governance
UPPP 167.description: Exposes students to best practices that assure effective planning and implementation of policies and programs in government, business, and nonprofit sectors. Includes guest lecturers who are proven leaders in four principal institutions of community: business, education, government, and non-profit.
UPPP 167.restriction: Restriction: Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Urban Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

UPPP 170.name: Health Policy
UPPP 170.description: Considers social and economic aspects of health and disease in the United States.  What are the proper roles of the individual, community, and government in improving health and health care?  International comparisons will be made wherever possible.
UPPP 170.restriction: Restriction: Public Health Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Public Health Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Urban Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

UPPP 172.name: Latino Metropolis
UPPP 172.description: Explores the processes of Latino urbanization in the United States and the spatialization of Latino identities, particularly in the context of Southern California with selected comparisons drawing from other cities.

UPPP 177.name: Chicano Movement
UPPP 177.description: Explores the history of Mexicans in the U.S. with particular attention paid to their integration into the U.S. capitalist economy.  Examines this economic history and the Chicano movement, "El Movimiento," within the wide context of socio-economic change.
UPPP 177.restriction: Restriction: Chicano/Latino Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Urban Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

UPPP 178.name: International Divided Cities
UPPP 178.description: Investigates urban divisions in international cities where deep-seated nationalistic ethnic differences create pressures for intergroup conflicts, autonomy, or territorial separation, and can incite violence. Urban political polarization as it is manifest in the urban setting.

UPPP 190.name: Applied Statistics in Social and Behavioral Research
UPPP 190.description: Covers statistical techniques used to describe and make generalizations about phenomena represented by data. Hands-on experience in data analysis and interpretation using statistical software (SPSS, STATA) is emphasized. Topics include data visualization, ANOVA, multiple regression, and categorical data analyses.
UPPP 190.restriction: Restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Criminology, Law and Society Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Urban Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

UPPP 202.name: History of Urban Planning
UPPP 202.description: Introduction to the historical roots and fundamental perspectives of urban and regional planning.  Exploration of the significant historical phases and personalities which have shaped the profession.  The roles and responsibilities, the limitations and potential, of urban planning.

UPPP 203.name: Theoretical Foundations of Planning
UPPP 203.description: Intellectual excursion into central themes in policy and planning, including philosophy of the market, institutionalization of space, hypostatizations of policy, constructions of communities, logics of spatial analysis. Objective is engagement of the professional in thoughtful reflections on practice and institutions.

UPPP 204.name: Plan Development and Communication
UPPP 204.description: Graphic representation and communication of physical place characteristics, design and physical planning ideas, and concepts using a variety of graphic techniques of free hand drawing, sketching, orthographic representations, scale drawings, 3D representations, maps, photo-documentation, and various media.
UPPP 204.restriction: Restriction: Urban and Regional Planning Majors only.

UPPP 205.name: Environmental Economics and Policy
UPPP 205.description: Provides a broad introduction to environmental economics and to environmental policy.  Environmental problems facing the United States and Europe are analyzed, and whenever possible, the environmental problems facing developing countries.

UPPP 206.name: Microeconomic Analysis for Urban Planning
UPPP 206.description: Provides students with a working knowledge of basic microeconomic concepts.  Emphasizes applications related to urban planning and policy analysis.  Topics covered include demand analysis, firm behavior, market structure, public goods, externalities, and the role of economics in land markets.

UPPP 207.name: Land-Use Law
UPPP 207.description: Investigates legal and institutional frameworks for development control. Review of constitutional issues implicated in land-use regulation. Traces development control historically and analyzes contemporary approaches to land-use control which reflect environmental and economic development concerns.

UPPP 209.name: Qualitative Research Methods: Overview
UPPP 209.description: Introduction to fundamentals of “qualitative” research and non-positivistic inquiry. Formulation of research questions, selection of method, data collection techniques, and analysis (briefly). Overview of selected methods from ethnography, naturalistic field research, phenomenology, ethnoarchaeology, critical approaches, and others.

UPPP 210.name: Practice Experience
UPPP 210.description: Provides Master of Urban and Regional Planning students an opportunity to link classroom knowledge with real planning situations through a 10-week unpaid practice experience.
UPPP 210.restriction: Restriction: Urban and Regional Planning Majors only.

UPPP 212.name: Transportation Planning and Policy
UPPP 212.description: Introduces current topics in transportation planning. Includes an analysis of the economic role of transportation in urban areas, land-use impacts of transportation projects, traffic congestion, air quality, alternatives to the automobile, and other transportation topics.

UPPP 213.name: Advanced Qualitative Methods: Analyzing Qualitative Data
UPPP 213.description: Introduction to the theory and practice of analyzing qualitative data. Students must have already learned about data collection and research design for qualitative research and must have qualitative data they can analyze.

UPPP 214.name: Quantitative Analysis for Planners
UPPP 214.description: Introduces students to the basic statistical concepts used to address issues of public concern.  Prepares students to perform, interpret, and evaluate quantitative data analyses commonly used in professional studies.

UPPP 215.name: Analytical Methods for Planning
UPPP 215.description: Emphasizes the development of analytical techniques proven useful in the fields of management and administration.  Topics include multiple regression, cost-benefit analysis and discounting, decision trees, and other techniques useful for the purposes of community analysis and planning.

UPPP 216.name: Statistics and Methods for Public Policy
UPPP 216.description: Introductory course with focus on gaining a sound understanding of what constitutes credible evidence in support of policy arguments and management decisions.

UPPP 219.name: Information and Public Policy
UPPP 219.description: Evaluates strengths and weaknesses of qualitative and quantitative methods and the data used in making public policy claims. Looks at the bases of certain widely accepted measures of poverty, growth, environmental quality, and the like.
UPPP 219.restriction: Restriction: Public Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

UPPP 220.name: Qualitative Methods: Fieldwork and Data Collection
UPPP 220.description: Covers fieldwork, data collections techniques, and related issues for anti-positivistic research. Data collection techniques include observation, physical traces, participation, in-depth interview. Data checks include veracity, detail, completeness, rigor.

UPPP 221.name: Public Policy
UPPP 221.description: Explores different approaches to public policy analysis, the diverse conceptions of the goals and objectives that should be served by policy, and the appropriate role of the policy analyst.  Policy consequences are traced to indirect and subtle incentives and disincentives.

UPPP 224.name: Environmental Politics and Policy
UPPP 224.description: Reviews and critiques literature on discussion topics including: the nature and effectiveness of environmental movements and policies

UPPP 225.name: Qualitative Methods for Public Policy
UPPP 225.description: Fieldwork, data collections techniques, and related issues for anti-positivistic research. Data collection techniques include observation, physical traces, participation, in-depth interview. Data checks include veracity, detail, completeness, rigor.

UPPP 227.name: Economics of Government
UPPP 227.description: Prepares students to analyze public policy questions with tools from economics. By the end, students should be able to identify important economic issues in public policy debates and consume and critique economic research on these topics.

UPPP 228.name: Demographics for Planning and Policy
UPPP 228.description: Provides planning and policy practitioners with a condensed, nonspecialist orientation to the sources, applications, and interpretation of population statistics, and conveys the steps used in constructing local-area population forecasts and projections.

UPPP 231.name: Transportation and Environmental Health
UPPP 231.description: Critically evaluates how transportation can promote sustainable, healthy, and equitable cities. Examines the interaction of transportation systems with urban form, land use, community health, and environmental quality.

UPPP 235.name: Geographic Information Systems (GIS) Problem Solving in Planning
UPPP 235.description: Explores the application of geographic information systems (GIS) in urban planning.  Steps through a GIS-based planning procedure that balances housing, jobs, tax base, utilities, transportation, and the natural environment.

UPPP 237.name: Introduction to Geographic Information Systems
UPPP 237.description: Application of Geographic Information Systems (GIS) to the field of urban and regional planning.  Emphasizes current issues that occur in actual implementation settings. Lecture/discussion followed by laboratory demonstrating the area of GIS discussed.  Offers "hands-on" student usage of GIS software.

UPPP 239.name: Urban Design Theories and Applications
UPPP 239.description: Introduction to contemporary and traditional theories of urban design and their applications.  Organized around one question:  How might planning and design of built environment contribute to making a good city?  National and international case studies are introduced.

UPPP 240.name: Microeconomics and Public Policy
UPPP 240.description: Introduces the fundamental principles of microeconomics that are required for applied policy analysis. Provides students with an intuitive understanding of the microeconomic approach, and familiarizes them with concepts used in applied public policy analysis.

UPPP 243.name: Health Policy and Management
UPPP 243.description: Multidisciplinary inquiry into theory and practice concerned with delivery, quantity, costs of health care for individuals and populations. Explores managerial and policy concerns regarding structure, process, outcomes of health services including the costs, financing, organization, outcomes, and accessibility of care.
UPPP 243.restriction: Restriction: Master of Public Health Degree students have first consideration for enrollment. Master of Public Policy Degree students have first consideration for enrollment. Graduate students only. Public Health Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Urban and Regional Planning Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

UPPP 244.name: Land-Use Policy
UPPP 244.description: Examination of the role of public policy in guiding growth and development in urban and suburban environments.  Description of a wide-ranging set of growth policies, the rationales underlying their use, controversies and legal constraints, and evaluation of their effectiveness.

UPPP 246.name: Housing Policy
UPPP 246.description: Examines theories and practices of housing policy and the relationship of housing to larger neighborhood, community, and regional development issues. Considers the roles of private for-profit and not-for-profit developers, lenders, and all levels of government in the provision of housing.
UPPP 246.prereqString: Prerequisite: Familiarity with basic statistics is required.

UPPP 251.name: Poverty and Development
UPPP 251.description: Examines competing conceptualizations, methods of measurement, and poverty alleviation strategies widely used in developing countries. Focuses on poverty conceptualized as economic deprivation, well-being, vulnerability, and social exclusion.

UPPP 252.name: Issues in Environmental Law and Policy
UPPP 252.description: Treatment of legal and policy strategies for promoting environmental protection and deterring environmental degradation within the context of other societal objectives. Topical approach with a focus on problems of special interest to criminologists and to environmental policy specialists.

UPPP 260.name: Policy and Ethics
UPPP 260.description: Examines the challenge of identifying ethical principles that can guide us in formulating and assessing public policy, the public policy process from an ethical perspective, and the ethics of the individual engaged in the public policy arena.

UPPP 266.name: Economic Democracy
UPPP 266.description: Explores a wide range of radical democratic and egalitarian visions (including but not limited to the Marxist tradition) for a more sane, just, and sustainable future.

UPPP 273.name: Global Urbanization
UPPP 273.description: Examines the spread of cities worldwide in the 20th century. What are the political and economic causes of this process? What are the social-cultural, political, and economic effects? How is contemporary urbanization linked to global restructuring of other kinds.

UPPP 275.name: Special Topics in Urban Planning
UPPP 275.description: Special topics in urban and regional planning are offered from time to time, but not on a regular basis. Course content varies with interest of the instructor.

UPPP 279.name: Theories of Power and Empowerment
UPPP 279.description: Studies different ways of thinking about power and its uses. Explores theories of power that inform various notions of empowerment, including resistance, participatory democracy, and workplace empowerment.

UPPP 281.name: Advanced Theory
UPPP 281.description: Provides urban planning and public policy students with an introduction to advanced theory. Addresses broad theoretical approaches that cut across disciplinary and topical boundaries. Designed primarily for Ph.D. students.

UPPP 282.name: Urban Design Studio for Planners: An Introduction
UPPP 282.description: Introductory urban design for planners.  Organized around a variety of assignments to encourage learning by design in a studio setting. Students work on design projects and drawing assignments to learn practical aspects of urban design.

UPPP 283.name: Collaborative Governance and Public Management
UPPP 283.description: Introduction to inclusive management. To make effective use of public resources, public managers are inventing ways of managing that alter relationships within organizations, between organizations, between sectors, and with the public. Requires rethinking fundamentals such as leadership and motivation.
UPPP 283.restriction: Restriction: Public Policy Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

UPPP 292.name: Professional Report
UPPP 292.description: Workshop designed to assist M.U.R.P. students in conducting their professional reports.  Students select topics, design projects, conduct professional investigations, and write up reports.

UPPP 294A.name: Urban Planning Practicum I
UPPP 294A.description: Engages students in practical planning projects in the community under a central theme within Planning. Students take a problem-solving approach and employ and further develop data gathering, analysis, graphic and oral communication, public engagement, and report writing skills.

UPPP 294B.name: Urban Planning Practicum II
UPPP 294B.description: Engages students in practical planning projects in the community under a central theme within Planning. Students take a problem-solving approach and employ and further develop data gathering, analysis, graphic and oral communication, public engagement, and report writing skills.

UPPP 296.name: Doctoral Dissertation Research and Writing
UPPP 296.description: Dissertation research with Urban Planning and Public Policy faculty.

UPPP 297.name: Research Design
UPPP 297.description: Provides training in research design and methods. Students learn how to evaluate the strength of research findings based on the methods used by a researcher and learn to use lessons from the course to develop a research proposal.

VIETMSE 1A.name: Fundamentals of Vietnamese
VIETMSE 1A.description: Designed for students with little or no exposure to Vietnamese. Natural approach with emphasis on four fundamental skills of listening, speaking, reading, and writing. Conducted in Vietnamese.
VIETMSE 1A.prereqString: Prerequisite: Placement into VIETMSE 1A is required.

VIETMSE 1B.name: Fundamentals of Vietnamese
VIETMSE 1B.description: Designed for students with little or no exposure to Vietnamese. Natural approach with emphasis on four fundamental skills of listening, speaking, reading, and writing. Conducted in Vietnamese.
VIETMSE 1B.prereqString: Prerequisite: VIETMSE 1A. VIETMSE 1A with a grade of C or better. Placement into VIETMSE 1B is also accepted.

VIETMSE 1C.name: Fundamentals of Vietnamese
VIETMSE 1C.description: Designed for students with little or no exposure to Vietnamese. Natural approach with emphasis on four fundamental skills of listening, speaking, reading, and writing. Conducted in Vietnamese.
VIETMSE 1C.prereqString: Prerequisite: VIETMSE 1B or VIETMSE S1AB. VIETMSE 1B with a grade of C or better. VIETMSE S1AB with a grade of C or better. Placement into VIETMSE 1C is also accepted.

VIETMSE 2A.name: Intermediate Vietnamese
VIETMSE 2A.description: Designed for students to advance their Vietnamese language skills from introductory to intermediate level. Designed to develop writing and reading skills and communicative skills in authentic situations. Students are introduced to aspects of Vietnamese culture relating to lesson topics.
VIETMSE 2A.prereqString: Prerequisite: VIETMSE 1C and VIETMSE S1BC. VIETMSE 1C with a grade of C or better. VIETMSE S1BC with a grade of C or better. Placement into VIETMSE 2A is also accepted.
VIETMSE 2A.restriction: Restriction: School of Humanities students have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

VIETMSE 2B.name: Intermediate Vietnamese
VIETMSE 2B.description: Designed for students to advance their Vietnamese language skills from introductory to intermediate level. Designed to develop writing and reading skills and communicative skills in authentic situations. Students are introduced to aspects of Vietnamese culture relating to lesson topics.
VIETMSE 2B.prereqString: Prerequisite: VIETMSE 2A. VIETMSE 2A with a grade of C or better. Placement into VIETMSE 2B is also accepted.
VIETMSE 2B.restriction: Restriction: School of Humanities students have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

VIETMSE 2C.name: Intermediate Vietnamese
VIETMSE 2C.description: Designed for students to advance their Vietnamese language skills from introductory to intermediate level. Designed to develop writing and reading skills and communicative skills in authentic situations. Students are introduced to aspects of Vietnamese culture relating to lesson topics.
VIETMSE 2C.prereqString: Prerequisite: VIETMSE 2B. VIETMSE 2B with a grade of C or better. Placement into VIETMSE 2C is also accepted.
VIETMSE 2C.restriction: Restriction: School of Humanities students have first consideration for enrollment. International Studies Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

VIETMSE 10A.name: Vietnamese Peer-to-Peer Language Mentor Program
VIETMSE 10A.description: Peer-to-Peer Language Mentor Program in which student mentors work with student mentees to increase the language skills of both participants. One hour weekly meetings. VIETMSE 10A is for language mentors.

VIETMSE 10B.name: Vietnamese Peer-to-Peer Language Mentor Program
VIETMSE 10B.description: Peer-to-Peer Language Mentor Program in which student mentors work with student mentees to increase the language skills of both participants. One hour weekly meetings. VIETMSE 10B is for language mentees.

VIETMSE 50.name: Vietnamese Culture
VIETMSE 50.description: Vietnamese culture and society in modern and historical contexts through the study of literary works, film, and other media. Philosophy and religious practices may also be examined. Course is taught in English.

VIS STD 290A.name: Art History:Theories and Methods
VIS STD 290A.description: Examines canonical texts and explores current directions in Art History.

VIS STD 290B.name: Film & Media Studies: Theories and Methods
VIS STD 290B.description: Examines canonical texts and explores current directions in Film and Media Studies.

VIS STD 290C.name: Visual Studies: Theories and Methods
VIS STD 290C.description: Examines canonical texts and explores current directions in Visual Studies.

VIS STD 294.name: Getty Consortium Seminar
VIS STD 294.description: Special graduate seminar offered at the Getty Research Institute in Los Angeles, involving faculty and graduate students from the five graduate programs in Art History or Visual Studies located in southern California (UCI, UCLA, UCR, UCSB, and USC).

VIS STD 295.name: Graduate Seminar in Visual Studies
VIS STD 295.description: Studies in selected areas of Visual Studies. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

VIS STD 296.name: Directed Reading
VIS STD 296.description: Directed reading on a specific topic agreed upon by student and instructor.

VIS STD 297.name: Writing Practicum
VIS STD 297.description: Offered winter quarter each year and taught in a workshop format. Assists students with the preparation and revision of the dissertation prospectus so that they may advance to candidacy.
VIS STD 297.prereqString: Prerequisite: VIS STD 290A and VIS STD 290B and VIS STD 290C

VIS STD 298A.name: Reading for the Preliminary Examination
VIS STD 298A.description: Directed reading in preparation for the preliminary examination. Formerly Visual Studies 298.

VIS STD 298B.name: Prospectus Research
VIS STD 298B.description: Research and writing of the dissertation prospectus.

VIS STD 299.name: Dissertation Research
VIS STD 299.description: Research and writing of the dissertation.

WRITING 30.name: The Art of Writing: Poetry
WRITING 30.description: Beginners' workshop in the writing of poetry, evaluation of student manuscripts, and parallel readings.
WRITING 30.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfaction of the UC Entry Level Writing requirement.

WRITING 31.name: The Art of Writing: Prose Fiction
WRITING 31.description: Beginners' workshop in fiction writing, evaluation of student manuscripts, and parallel readings.
WRITING 31.prereqString: Prerequisite: Satisfaction of the UC Entry Level Writing requirement.

WRITING 37.name: Intensive Writing
WRITING 37.description: Critical reading and analysis conducted through literary, academic, journalistic, and fictional genres with additional instruction in paragraph development and sentence-level mechanics. Students analyze and apply rhetorical principles in a range of writing assignments. Letter Grade with P/NP Option.
WRITING 37.prereqString: Prerequisite: Students must have taken the UC Analytical Writing Placement Examination.

WRITING 39A.name: Introduction to Writing and Rhetoric
WRITING 39A.description: Introduction to the principles of rhetoric through readings and writing assignments across a range of genres, including fiction, non-fiction, journalism and academic essays.
